name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the informal European Council of 23 September 2015 (2015/2859(RSP)). Normally I would give the floor to the President-in-Office of the Council now, but he is still on his way to the Chamber. That is why I am now giving the floor to the President of the Commission.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President der Kommission. Herr President! Es tut der European Kommission gut, anstelle of the Ratsvorsitzenden das Wort zu ergreifen. (Beifall) Wir haben, sehr geehrter Herr President, als Mitglied of the European Rates am vergangenen 23. September das unsere dazu getan, damit wir uns in Sachen Migration und Flunchtlinge von der Stelle bewegen konnten. Die European Kommission - das ist Ihnen in lebhafter Erinnerung geblieben - hatte dem Rat schon im Mai diesbez-glich Vorschl-ge unterbreitet. Der Rat hat etwas Zeit gebraucht, um sich auf diese Vorschlàge zu einigen. Wir hetten es als Kommission vorgezogen, wenn der Rat - vornehmlich der Innenminister - sich einvernehmlich auf eine solidarische Verteilung der Flàchtlinge in Europa hàtte einigen kunnen. Dies war angesichts widriger, vor allem innenpolitischer Zust-nde und Begebenheiten nicht meglich. Dann haben wir - und das ist ja auch keine Katastrophe - uns an den europeischen Vertrag, seine Sinngebung, seine eindeutigen Festlegungen erinnert. Wir haben - wie ich das auch hier im Hause versprochen hatte - die Gemeinschaftsmethode zum Einsatz gebracht und mit Mehrheit im Rat der Innenminister entschieden. Dies ist eigentlich, interinstitutionell betrachtet und von der Arbeitsweise her gesehen, ein gutes Zeichen gewesen. Ich ehrf-rchtigst den Ratsvorsitzenden. Donald, mechtest of the, oder darf ich weiter? Also ich erfreue mich einer massiven Z-rtlichkeitszuwendung des Europeischen Rates und bin dankbar dafar. Wir hetten eine einstimmige Entscheidungsfindung vorgezogen. Dies war nicht meglich, und deshalb die Gemeinschaftsmethode. Und das war - wie ich finde - richtig. Wir sollten jetzt nicht in diesen Sumpf der gegenseitigen Schuldzuweisungen eintauchen. Wir haben jetzt eine Entscheidung. Diese Entscheidung muss umgesetzt werden. Und wir tun das in go gebotenen Schnelligkeit. We acted, as a Commission, with a speed that no one thought we could. There was a European Council on 23 September. We have proposed to the institutions, and therefore to both branches of the budgetary authority, our proposals for 2015 and 2016, which we will do in the coming weeks. We have proposed a budgetary amount of $800 million to both branches of the budgetary authority.  I am pleased that the European Parliament, once again, has indicated that it will decide quickly in committee, on the 8th, I believe, and in plenary on the 15th.  The European Parliament is up to the common task of ours. He had already given the green light to the Commission's proposal to jointly distribute the number of refugees. This has, in fact, forced the European Council to do the same. Imagine for a moment that the European Council overturned Parliament's decision...  I am therefore grateful to you, Mr President, and to the members of this House for having acted with the speed that characterizes the work of this House. You will do the same on budgetary issues, since it is a question of increasing Frontex's resources, the means of Europol and the resources of the European Asylum Support Office. We will deploy up to 600 civil servants in the coming days and weeks to assist Greece in protecting external borders. By deploying such a large number of staff to Greece, we are actually doubling the number of civil servants who work at DG HOME, as they say, the Directorate General for Home Affairs and Justice. I would like to thank the Member States participating in this initiative and I would like to encourage those who have not yet done so to follow the example of the Austrians, the Germans and others. President Tusk, you, Mr President, and I have seen the President of the Turkish Republic, Mr Erdogan. Turkey is making an extraordinary effort as it is home to 2.2 million refugees, including from Iraq and Syria. It is clear that we need Turkey to protect our external borders. The Commission will do its utmost to help the significant efforts of the Turkish Republic.  We cannot only focus on our own internal affairs, we also have to deal with the problems that exist on the periphery of Europe. In fact, it is the same problem. The European Union and Turkey must work together and must develop, in harmony, the same policy of welcoming, protecting and monitoring the unfortunates who come to us.  I have submitted to the Turkish President, following an agreement with the President of the European Council and the President of the European Parliament, a memorandum on the cooperation that must be established between Turkey and the European Union on refugees. We will release this document this afternoon at 3 p.m. I can't do it now because we have agreed with our Turkish friends to do so at 3 p.m. this afternoon.  We pay particular attention to Greece. 66,000 Greek refugees and asylum seekers will have to be distributed in other EU countries. I have delegated to Athens the Director General responsible for structural reforms in Greece, Mr Verwey, who is negotiating on the spot the programmes to be implemented by Greece. I did the same for Turkey. From tomorrow morning, senior Commission officials will be in Ankara to negotiate the details of the arrangements with Turkey. In addition, I have asked the commissioners responsible - there are several of them, including Frans Timmermans, who does not yet know this - to go to Turkey to negotiate politically with the Turkish ministers the arrangements we are in the process of making with the Turkish authorities.  This common policy between Turkey and the European Union is not a matter that would concern exclusively civil servants and senior officials, although they are of extraordinary competence. I believe that, in the noble sense of the word, the negotiations between the European Union and Turkey must be politicised. Of course, these policies have a cost. I observe, not with concern but with interest, a debate that is currently taking place in Europe as to whether or not the associated costs should be exempted from the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact. The Stability and Growth Pact, to which we have added, by enriching it, a part of economic reading, allows us to respond to this situation, but I would not want us to leave in total irresponsibility. It will therefore be necessary to see, on the basis of an analysis that the Commission is undertaking, whether, on an ad hoc basis, certain countries can evade the unse nuanced application of the Stability and Growth Pact. But let's not do it lightly.  Today we are discussing the cost of the refugee policy. Tomorrow, if we are not careful, we could discuss something else. But the Commission, on this point, is open not to all adventures but to all suggestions. Mr President, I will answer all the questions you will ask me after listening with sustained attention to the President of the Council, whom I greet among us.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, the real test for any community comes at a time of crisis. Just as we check our banks using stress tests, today life itself is using a dramatic migration stress test to check our community. And that is what the last European Council was about. You know its results. Allow me then to share a more general thought with you, especially as, in 10 days’ time, the next European Council will be dealing with the same problem. Historical changes and threats on a large scale demand a sense of dignity and self-belief from every community, particularly now, when the whole world is focusing its attention on Europe and on its reaction to the wave of refugees. Europe is subject to increasingly scathing criticism, and our internal disagreements and mutual recriminations only help our opponents. Almost everyone in Europe has joined the chorus of critics, while very few defend its good name. In the United Nations, one could have the impression that Europe is the worst place in the world for refugees. Believe me, I felt isolated there when I defended Europe’s good reputation, trying to convince the audience that the truth about Europe is completely different. Hundreds of thousands of refugees go to Europe because they know that our community is still the most open and tolerant of all. It is still we who respect international standards and conventions, and it is Europe where people – all people – are safer than anywhere else. Let us not let Europe become a scapegoat as a result of our quarrelling and blaming each other without restraint. Otherwise, before long, theocracies will start to lecture us on what religious tolerance means; dictators will tell us what democracy means; and those responsible for this massive exodus will tell us how to treat refugees. In fact, they are already doing this. There are countries which admit virtually no refugees but which are most vocal when it comes to urging Europe to show more openness. That is why we have to take care of our good name –together. We keep talking about solidarity, about quotas and greater assistance for refugees on our soil, and for those who remain in camps in countries outside the EU. Let us remember, however, that solidarity requires mutual understanding and respect. Without solidarity among Member States, we will not be able to help others. It is our common obligation to assist refugees as well as to protect the EU’s external borders. Everyone must take up this obligation and at the same time, no one should be left alone with the burden. That is how I understand solidarity. We have to respect commonly agreed rules. When someone says that they have no intention of observing European law, for example the Dublin Regulation or quotas, they undermine the essence of solidarity and our community. Observing rules will always mean sacrificing part of our interests. I would like to dedicate these words to the Hungarians and the Italians, to the Slovaks and the Greeks. Let us have no illusions. Today, we have to count mainly on ourselves. The world around us does not intend to help Europe. Many of our neighbours have much bigger problems to tackle, and some look with satisfaction at our troubles. For us, refugees are specific people – individuals who expect our help. There are forces around us, however, for whom the wave of refugees is just dirty business or a political bargaining chip. We are slowly witnessing the birth of a new form of political pressure, and some even call it a kind of new hybrid war in which migratory waves have become a tool, a weapon against neighbours. This requires particular sensitivity and responsibility on our side.  Dear colleagues, you all know the notion of ethics of responsibility from the works of Weber – not Manfred but Max Weber. Today, the ethics of responsibility requires us to refrain from extremes. And by extremes I mean both, on the one hand, anti-immigration rhetoric and, on the other, inviting everyone who wishes to come, despite being unable to take them under our roof. We need to understand that today millions of potential refugees and migrants – not only from Syria but also from Africa, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq and other places – are dreaming about Europe. For all refugees, easy access to Europe and lack of external borders have become, alongside the Willkommen-Politik, a magnet attracting them to us. During my visits to the region, whoever I spoke to – presidents, or refugees in the camps, in Turkey, Jordan or Egypt – warned me of one thing: that a potential victory by Assad’s regime, which is more likely today because of Iran’s and Russia’s engagement in Syria, will result in the next migratory wave. Yesterday this message was confirmed by President Erdoğan. According to Turkish estimates, another three million potential refugees may come from Aleppo and its neighbourhood. Declaring solidarity is always greeted with applause, but calling for responsibility and common sense hardly ever. Practising solidarity is a lot harder than preaching it. I am speaking as a decades-long practitioner.  This is why I ask you all to show responsibility and common sense. The first commandment today is the restoration of control on the EU’s external borders as a sine qua non of an effective, humanitarian and safe migratory policy. Tomorrow, in the European Parliament, you will hear Angela Merkel and François Hollande. We all know how much depends on them. In this crisis situation they have both demonstrated beautiful moral gestures which we all highly appreciate. Tomorrow, they must pass an even harder exam, an exam in responsibility for the protection of the European Community, and its external borders. Otherwise, they, and all of us, will become responsible for the re-emergence of walls and barriers on our internal borders, here in Europe. We have to say it finally, loud and clear: Europe without its external borders equals Europe without Schengen. Europe without its external borders will become a breeding ground for fear in each and every one of us. And this will lead us, sooner rather than later, to a political catastrophe. What ordinary people expect from politicians is, first and foremost, effectiveness and determination. If the leaders of mainstream politics do not realise this, people will start to look for different kinds of leadership, radical and ruthless, because what people want from their leaders above all is a guarantee of order and security for their own community. Either we will face up to the challenge, or others will take our place. The queue of political machos is quite long, but there is still time to stop them. And that depends entirely on us. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work he has I would like to begin by thanking the President-in-Office of the Council warmly for being here. This is the first time that the President-in-Office of the Council has come to the European Parliament for debate, even after an informal Council for reporting. I would like to express my thanks for this. People are unsettled by the migration issue – we all feel that. That is why I believe – also on my group, the PPE- and the Ppe-DE – that we must first of all tell people that we are also able to provide answers. Six months ago, three-quarters of a year ago, who would have thought that European ships – British ships, German ships – would be operating in the Mediterranean today and, together with Italy and Malta, were saving lives there? Who would have thought six months ago that we would be able to set up a distribution mechanism for 160 000 refugees in the European Union and decide to show solidarity? Who would have thought that we would now begin to implement a robust mandate in the Mediterranean in the autumn, so that we would not be dictated by the smuggling gangs on the agenda, but that the state would take responsibility again? And who would have thought that last week's European Council would be able to put significantly more money on the table to help the United Nations and organise aid on the ground? It is important that we also talk about successes, not just about the problems, in order to gain people's confidence in the ability of their representatives to act. The second thing I want to say today is that, of course, many construction sites are still open. On my group's part, I would like to say that we do not need new ideas now, but we need implementation, implementation and implementation. We have a great need for this. The Commission has presented a package that sets the right direction, and the European Parliament has clear political backing for the Commission's package, led by Jean-Claude Juncker: yes to the hotspots, yes to aid at the external borders! Please, don't talk now, but do it! Yes to repatriation: last year, two-thirds of all refugees in Europe were turned away. Yes to the repatriation of rejected applicants! Don't talk, but do! Yes to safe countries of origin. All candidate countries, as the Commission has presented, should be described as safe third countries. Don't talk, but do! That's why: implementation, implementation is now called for. I would like to say a word, particularly on Turkey, because yesterday the talks with President Erdogan took place: we support the classification of Turkey as a safe country of origin, we also support the joint border security activities that are being made and, of course, the financial efforts that we want to make. However, we must also say that we are constantly reminding Erdogan and the Turkish Republic of principles: if a country is a candidate country, then we expect the implementation of civil rights within the interior, then we also expect Turkey to deal properly with internal issues, especially in the Kurdish conflict. Europe must not look the other way on this issue simply because we now need Turkey as a partner. Great challenges mean that we have to give people guidance. One point of reference is that Europe is a continent of humanity. The right to asylum is in our Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is anchored there and is not available for disposition. We are proud of our core values. In this respect, Angela Merkel's statement that we, as a large continent, can do this also applies. Secondly, refugees are welcome, but they are also called upon. There is no right to choose a Member State in the European Union where to go. There is a duty to register, there is a duty to integrate into our social order. This too must be clearly signalled to the people who come to us. And the third is that the state must enforce the law. That is why, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I am grateful to you for what you have said. Border security, securing the external borders, Europe controlling at the border, who comes to this continent and whoever is also rejected, must be carried out, including with technical measures. The state must enforce the law and must also be able to contingent and provide a framework for the environment. framework conditions, orientation, so that our citizens have confidence. Our message as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is: stop producing new ideas, but making them a reality!

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yes, Mrs Weber is right, few would have believed in these results, but among those few of us in the European Parliament, we in the European Commission, because we said these things in the spring and came to fruition in September, it is not a short time. The European institutions must respond quickly and quickly, Mr Tusk.  Now well, let's go ahead and defend this area. I want to be European as a champion of human rights, I do not want to turn this being into that of a bad and ugly bear just because I have to reject refugees. Let us do this by implementing the decisions taken quickly, Mr Tusk. The hotspots linked to relocation, the defence of the external borders, the link between security and reception, the policy that the European institutions are making towards Turkey, lebanon, all this convinces me, it must be done, it must be implemented.  Let us not confuse the responsibilities of the countries that have rowed and of the countries that have borne all the burden, the burden in recent years. Let us put an end to the negative symbols that only denote the inability to govern problems, barbed wire, walls, selfishness, hatred. All this symbolises the inability to solve problems, the problems are solved in a positive way. Let us end this phase and open a new phase so as not to undermine the soul and future of Europe.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the UN High Commissioner said that 8 000 immigrants come to Europe every day. Mr Tusk mentioned, at one point, one million in the coming months. If those numbers are at least partly correct, it is clear that what the Commission and the Council have prepared for us is far from satisfactory. It is a stop-gap: it is certainly not a solution. As usual we have had confused and confusing language, and the traditional share of bullying and invective against those who disagree. We have had disregard for laws that we ourselves established. Humanitarian arguments were mixed with political ones. Mr Timmermans, for example, went so far as to say that the reallocation scheme is good for our souls. Amazing – he really did say that! We have had elements of blackmail and typical euro-casuistry. The immigrants were invited and then disinvited. The Schengen procedures were abolished and then restored again. If this gigantic confusion is a reflection of the state the EU is in, then God help us! What we did not have, however, is the long-term objective. What is the final state of affairs that we want to attain? The Council talked about the cultural and social criteria that are to be taken into account in immigration policies. I think this makes sense. I am afraid, however, that Europeans have built such a powerful system of taboos and inhibitions around the immigration question that there is not much hope for a rational debate. My safe prediction is that we will have more and more of the same.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say bluntly to Mr Tusk that I am getting more and more fed up with the Council, not with him personally – be assured of that – but with the institution that he represents. I am saying this is because, first of all, it has taken a very long time for an informal summit to be organised – because this crisis did not start a few days or a few weeks ago. Then, what was produced from this summit was a one-page statement. This is all that was produced from an informal summit of the European Council on the most important crisis Europe has faced in the last decade – a refugee crisis such as we have never seen before. One page: mainly repeating decisions about the 120 000 refugees that have already been taken by the Ministers for the Interior, and then also pledging EUR 1 billion in additional money. I ask myself how many people from Syria have to die and how many additional people from Syria have to flee to Europe before the European Council takes a comprehensive, global approach to this refugee crisis, as is proposed by the Commission? It is not that you have nothing to work with. A few hours before the European Council, the Commission decided on a global package: including a new European asylum system no longer based on the Dublin Regulation; including a new European migration package in which we create one system, a blue-card system, in Europe – not 28 systems; and including, perhaps most importantly, a European border and coastguard proposal – that, by the way, Mr Tusk, the Ministers of the Interior refused to put in their conclusions on 11 September 2015. They did not talk about it. So I am asking: what is needed? Why was it not possible for this European Council in its summit to decide on the package proposed by the Commission? Parliament has already backed this package. So what is happening? Why can the European Council not overcome these internal divisions? My proposal is very clear, namely that we – the Council and Parliament – should agree to a fast-track procedure for the Commission proposal: to adopt it as quickly as possible, as these procedures are there. Secondly, my proposal concerns the external borders of Europe. Regarding this conflict in Syria, is it not time that the European Union – you the European Council, you Mr Tusk and Ms Mogherini – took an initiative? For the moment we are being pushed out. The Russians are taking action. What they are mainly doing is bombing – bombing civilians and citizens in Syria and the last of the remaining Free Syrian Army fighters. I do not know if there are many of them, but at the moment they are being killed by Russian bombs.  We are the ones who are facing the consequences of this refugee crisis, not the Russians or the Americans. They are talking about Syria, while we, who will face all the consequences of it, are not taking any initiative at European level for the moment. We actually have three different opinions within the Council about this. So take the initiative: call a summit and have 28 bilateral meetings, giving Ms Mogherini a full mandate and also enforcing no-fly safe zones. The current situation is crazy. I hear people saying that it is not possible and that you need a mandate from the UN. No – apparently, to bomb Syrian citizens you do not need a mandate from the UN, but to protect Syrian citizens you need a mandate. Such an approach is completely crazy. Finally, we also need a new donor conference. There is not enough money in these refugee camps. So, Mr Tusk, I am counting on you. The 28 Heads of State are not going to solve these problems. They are not capable of doing so, as they each represent only a nation. You represent a continent. Assume your responsibility. (Applause)

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the obligation of a European parliamentarian is to be in this debate and I deeply regret that Mr Iglesias is not in this debate, because 'whoever covers so much, little squeezes'.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President Tusk, I have listened very carefully to you and you are right. I believe that, as Europeans, we must remain proud of what we have built in Europe. You are right, even if the European Union is not perfect, if our rule of law is still under construction, if our democracies are sometimes faltering and need to be strengthened and if our prosperity is little shared. But if I had to choose, this is still where I would like to live, without any hesitation, and it is no coincidence that many refugees and asylum seekers apply to join the European Union. And you are right: to see theocracy give us lessons in religious tolerance, to see dictatorships give us lessons in democracy, to see countries that do not take a single refugee give us lessons in welcoming, it is daring to say the least. What I see Mr Tusk is that most of the countries you are referring to when you say this are allies of the European Union, and I would like to hear you tell those states everything you have just told us. However, when you saw Mr Erdogan yesterday, which we apparently need, when he puts the press and justice under his boot and restarts the war in his own country, these subjects were not addressed. I therefore call on you to be a little modest on these subjects, even if, you are right, we must be proud to be European.  You said that we must avoid extremes and, once again, I agree with you. Let me give you two figures: the European Union is 23.7% of the world's gross domestic product, we can say, in the big ladle, of the world's wealth. Well, the 160,000 refugees that you have agreed to distribute to Europe, at the commission's initiative, represent 0.2% of the world's refugees. If we are close to an extreme, it is certainly not the extreme of the wide open door and therefore, again, I think the European Union can do better. I would like to invite you to follow the Commission's recommendations. We have heard President Juncker, Vice-President Timmermans repeatedly in this forum, ask you, ask the Member States to put in place a permanent key to the distribution of refugees. I have heard the same people talk about setting up legal paths in Europe to put an end to the deadly business of smugglers. I have finally heard the same ones, and I fully agree with them, to make the case for a European asylum policy and, on this, considerable progress is still to be made. A few were made at the Council, but this is just the beginning. So keep fighting.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, frankly, having heard the comments at this informal Council, I remain grounded. Some people welcome the results achieved, I do not know in what reality, in what world they live.  This migrant crisis with thousands of deaths, it is the usual mountain that gives birth to a mouse: 120 000 more migrants distributed means 20 days of transit to 6 000 people on average per day, it is nothing. We are facing a crisis of voluntary blindness in Europe, in which every state pretends to look the other way, while thousands of people pass through its territory and pushes them in every way to leave as soon as possible. Someone doesn't record them, someone else uses barbed wire, tear gas and beatings.  Is it an external border crisis as someone said? No gentlemen! This is a crisis of internal borders within the EU because when there is a wall from Budapest that also separates Slovenia, which is a member of Schengen, this is a crisis of internal borders and the play of the Hungarian, Slovak and Romanian Governments is a dangerous game, because the solidarity and stability of all are sacrificed to the electoral interests of the few and also when turkey is welcomed. , we celebrate it and forget the suffering of the Kurdish people gentlemen, we lose credibility.  This is today's Europe. This is Europe not step by step, but by wall after wall and there is a chance of change. We make special humanitarian corridors, we take legal action, we completely overtake Dublin. When will this review be put on the table? Let us also overcome foreign and commercial policies of exploitation, decisive action on climate change. Gentlemen, small steps are no longer enough, coherent and courageous choices are needed. These are the choices we have to make. These are the choices that defend our good name, Mr Tusk. Are you here? If not now, when?

name: Louis Aliot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it took several weeks and a horrible photo for the Europe mountain to give birth to this mouse. Yes to help countries facing the refugee crisis outside Europe. Yes also to the aid given to the countries that face the external borders of Europe, such as our Italian or Hungarian friends, but please stop stigmatizing Hungary by Mr Orbon, who, in an urgent way, had to react to this outburst, while the cacophony reigned in the Council. Remember that Austria, in 1956, had taken in 170,000 refugees in a few weeks fleeing communism while Europe at twenty-eight is not able to make any decision.  How can we not see that we are suffering the consequences of your past mistakes today? Your blind affiliation with Mr. Bush's new world order has led to a new global disorder in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Egypt, with abominable human tragedies in which innocent people lose their lives every day.  Our European organisation is not working. Your system is paralyzed, sclerotic! There is, as General de Gaulle said, reality only in the nation. Trust the nations, the sovereignty, and then you will see that efficiency will be much more important.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, with the decisions of the Summit, the European Union is keeping the large volume of refugees and migrants in the hell of the imperialist wars, the fire of which it and its allies, NATO, the European Union and the other imperialists, have set on fire, with their competition for the interests of monopolies.  As for the refugees who arrive at the hot spots, they look at them in the teeth and select only the ones necessary for the capitalist labour market. For the rest, most of them, the European Union and its governments have decided to crack down and deport.  As for the Dublin Regulation and the other mechanisms of repression of the European Union, the rapid intervention forces, they live, reign and are strengthened and lead to new hundred deaths, turning Greece into a refugee assembly station. The JRC calls on the people, the labour movement, to strengthen solidarity with refugees and migrants against European Union policy and to demand, among other things, their direct transfer from the points of entry to their final destination countries, at the expense of the European Union and the UN.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, mass population movements are going to be Europe's big problem over the next twenty years. That is why we need a common immigration and refuge policy that first serves people and establishes a legal immigration system in Europe; establishing, secondly, that without external security at borders, internal borders cannot disappear; thirdly, establish solidarity between Member States; ensuring the cooperation of transit countries, such as Turkey; and finally, to identify all those who enter the European Union — just as we are identified by all of us living in the European Union — so that they can receive help, so that they can count on our solidarity and also to ensure the safety of all.  We need a common policy for a future that is not going to be easy, because it is not just Syria; after Syria, refugees from many more parts will come.  Mr President, winter is approaching - as Mr Timmermans said the other day in this House - and when winter comes, many roads will be closed and there will be less immigration, there will be fewer refugees because they will not be able to cross the sea. They'll disappear from the news. And many countries will feel that because they no longer see them on television, there are no refugees. What a big mistake we can't fall into! We can't postpone the problem because, if we postpone it, it's going to be worse in the spring. The measures exist, Mr Tusk, make the Member States comply with them. If we know what we need to do, it's time to stop talking and start managing.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – We needed hundreds of thousands of refugees on European soil. How many have died to wake Europe up? The agreement on the redistribution of refugees in Brussels and other measures outlined are a positive signal. However, I agree that the current situation is an important test. But I would not say that for the very existence of the European Union, but for its future development, for a new direction that the Union will have to set out to remain a competitive and attractive area. In the coming months, it will be clear how Member States will face migration challenges in practice. Here it will be fairly quick to show which countries follow the fundamental principles of European integration, which are more inclined to harvest rapid profits. I looked at slovenian centres, Slovenia is well prepared and the refugees were well taken care of. The fact is that there will be changes in Europe in the coming years, months. But the influx of migrants will not be the cause of these changes, on the contrary. I believe that if we can manage migration, it will alleviate the demographic situation. Unfortunately, we needed binding measures to bring solidarity up. We do not need and do not want borders between our countries. Slovenian residents do not want to wake up again by the wire fence, as happened the days ago at the border with Hungary. It was supposed to be a test, but it was a test that aroused a lot of discomfort and bitter feelings among the residents. We also do not need new disagreements and conflicts, tensions in the Western Balkans, as we have seen in recent weeks: verbal struggles, border closures have caused great economic damage, but above all they have brought mistrust and fear among people.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: – I would like to thank the President of the Council, Mr Tusk, for the open language for the new political pressure or hybrid war that we are experiencing from third countries at present, and also for the fact that the main focus is on safeguarding the European Union's external borders.  On the other hand, the European Commission's proposal, which was aimed at allusing quotas within the European Union, actually led to a relatively negative assessment of citizens by the European institutions, to a divided mind between democratically elected governments in the European Union and ultimately led to refugees not being happy, because their secondary movement within the European Union from the country where they will be divided is not possible, which actually leads to a discriminatory situation.  And here I would also like an answer from the President of the Commission on another democratic and political issue: that you should, in order to maintain credability, give a quick investigative response to the recent situation that could have affected the Catalan elections, in terms of Spanish, your reply before the elections.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the So let us talk about the successes. Ok. But if we look at them: 160 000 displaced refugees, of whom 8 000 are still missing, and now a little more money for the UNHCR, after the UNHCR has been asking for more money for years – it is somehow clear that these successes are quite, very small and, unfortunately, piecemeal. Where is the Council's decision on finally legal access for refugees, so that we no longer leave them to the smugglers? Where is the decision for a far-reaching Dublin reform, and not just a bit of plaster on the old system? Instead, the Member States seem determined to leave the problem with other states, in other countries, with other people. Above all, there is the problem that we are making a very, very dangerous pact with Turkey. The deal seems to be: Erdogan should continue to take care of the refugees, stop them, and for that he gets no criticism on the Kurdish issue, on freedom of the press and on others. This, Mr Tusk, really is not the Europe we can be proud of.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Can the €100 emergency aid solve the crisis for fugitives in Europe? I think not. So far, the people of Europe do not see any concrete action to address the reasons for relocating African people to Europe. The result of attempts to overcome the consequences is an anti-democratic policy of limiting the sovereignty of states to the allocation of refugees under quotas. No less common is the external borders of the European Union, and the states trying to close their internal borders are almost the opposite of Europe. Imposing will on states that do not agree with quota policies is direct interference with their sovereignty and independence. The influx of refugees into Europe is the vado of the crisis of the future. We can and must defend ourselves against it, but let us have sufficient determination and integrity. Europe owes nothing to anyone, it is open to guests, but to those who come to the front door, not to the house climbing through the window. The public is waiting for us to start defending that house.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In view of this Council meeting, it is clear to me that there is once again total failure within the European Union. After the question of monetary and economic policy and the unsuccessful bailout of Greece, it is now overlaid by refugee policy. Once again, the European Union, its institutions and the whole construct of the European Union are showing total failure. At first it was said: We take them all. Millions have made the journey. Then it was said: No, we do not take them all. After that, there has been an attempt to introduce compulsory quotas across Europe, and countries have been deprived of their sovereignty and also taken into decisions in which they did not really want to be. And now we are faced with the situation that we have ended up in an extortionate situation with the Turks, which once again does not solve the problem. I therefore say that, in order to solve the problem, we must, firstly, fight the Islamic State. I welcome what the Russians have tried to do together with the Americans, but now, unfortunately, only the Russians are doing it. A: Fighting the Islamic State. Secondly, the creation of safe zones in the Arabian Peninsula, in North Africa, to keep the people in the region. Thirdly, to give these people in peaceful areas in the region protection and assistance to accompany this process, but by no means to bring them all into Europe, as the Social Democrats, the Greens and the Conservatives want. That cannot work.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Council on 23 September has decided to take in 120,000 refugees, perhaps hastily labelled as political refugees, which is certainly the case for a few, but probably not for the majority.  I would like to take this opportunity to tell you about two real political refugees to whom Europe does not grant asylum and whose cases are indisputable. They are Edward Snowden and Julian Assange.  Edward Snowden was the revelation of the surveillance programs of the United States of America, perfectly illegal, perfectly unconstitutional, exercising to our detriment.  Well, Edward Snowden only got political asylum in Moscow in 2013. Italy, Portugal, Spain and France have closed their airspace to President Evo Morales' plane for fear that Snowden will be on board.  The same goes for Julian Assange, a prisoner of the foreign embassy in london, the Ecuadorian embassy, which is monitored day and night by Scotland Yard, which has so far cost British taxpayers 6 million pounds.  Shame on this submissive Europe, on this recumbent Europe, on this vassal Europe! Freedom for Snowden, freedom for Assange!

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Europe is on the cusp, at a very difficult time, and both the content of your speech and the way it is presented indicate the extraordinary seriousness of the situation. And they also tell us Members of the European Parliament that the situation is very difficult within the European Council. This is therefore a signal to us that something needs to be changed in the mechanisms of the Functioning of the European Union. The dramatic tone of your speech indicates that this cannot continue.  I would therefore like to ask the President how you see the debate on the division of competences today. In fact, what are the Member States themselves supposed to do today? What are the Member States to do together? What should the European Council do? To what extent do the decisions that are taken – and there is debate in Europe – fall within the framework of the Treaty and how far do they go beyond treaty solutions? This is the moment when the Union must check how it works if the situation you are actually talking about in this way is so complicated. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – My question is very simple. I wonder if you could help me understand – who are these people who were talking today, and what has happened? Everyone is talking about changing. We must have external borders, we must have controls, and we must make sure that we do not get overwhelmed with all these migrants coming in. Who are these people? Are they the same ones who have unfailingly voted through everything, saying that we should allow more and more people to come here and encourage the flow? Do you think they are the same people? Could you help me to identify who on earth is talking today?

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab I don't know, I don't know who these people are. These people need to be checked. There are no simple answers. If there were simple answers, we would not have a debate today. First you have to stop them, then you have to check them, then you have to accept them if they are real fugitives, and if they are not real fugitives, you have to try to send them back if possible. Therefore, I do not know if you are satisfied, but I think there are no such simple answers.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Mr President, last week I travelled to Lebanon and Jordan within a delegation from my political group and as permanent rapporteur of the European Parliament for humanitarian action. We met with the United Nations Refugee Agency, the United Nations Agency for Palestinian Refugees, Unicef, we also met with civilian organizations, with members of the authorities — in the singularly with the president of the Lebanese Parliament — and we also had access to the burj el-Barajneh and Za'atri refugee camps. Between the two camps there are one hundred and twenty thousand refugees. In just two camps – one in Lebanon and one in Jordan – there are the same numbers of refugees that we are discussing in the European Union.  The set of recommendations I acquired at these meetings can be summed up in the following: that Europe work, be involved in the solution to the Syrian war. If Syria's war reaches Damascus or if the situation is reversed and the regime triumphs, there will be millions of refugees, many of them fighting to reach European shores. Let us try to maintain solidarity with Lebanon and Jordan. If there is a collapse in these countries, the situation of millions of refugees who adapt and take refuge in them will also collapse. Let us be involved in avoiding the third Intifada that is currently being managed. Let us try to show the effective solidarity of the European Parliament and the European institutions and, finally, that we should provide education to children in refugee camps. Without education for these children, parents have no choice but to try to reach our borders. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Guerrero Salom, would you agree with me that, rather than dragging people across Europe, it would be better for the European Union to be persuading the Kuwaitis and the Saudis to build good, proper camps on the borders of Syria and Turkey? Would that not be a sensible solution, rather than dragging people across Europe, creating resentment and other problems? Surely that must be a better way of doing it. Would you agree with me, sir?

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr. Coburn, there are few things I can imagine agreeing with you. But I would like to point out that what we are debating is what we do, not what others should do. The obligation is in our field. Refugees come to our countries and we are the ones who have to solve this problem. Then we'll ask others.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A wave of migration is sweeping Europe. According to newspaper reports, Germany alone expects 1.5 million migrants this year. This figure pulverizes all previous estimates and shows that the situation is completely out of control. At the meeting of interior ministers and heads of state a week and a half ago, a quota of 160,000 people was still being negotiated for the whole of Europe. What figures are we talking about next week or next month? Mrs Merkel's "We can do this" shows the Complete loss of reality of the German Chancellor. No, the municipalities cannot do that. The administrations are collapsing under the load, the volunteers are pushing their limits, and the German welcome culture seems to be run out of colourful balloons. The borders must be closed and clear signals must be sent to migrants that Europe cannot absorb all of them. Most refugee camps in the region are already run by unhcr. I think it makes a lot of sense that the funds should be increased here. This means that all politicians in the EU must be aware that the refugees there are safe and are not entitled to continue their journey to Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. "You talked about refugees, as it were, the forces of nature, the waves and the avalanches. Yes, refugees are human beings. You mentioned Germany. Is it not really time to thank Mrs Merkel and Germany for having this big issue better in their possession than many other countries? They try to organize work, debit cards, apartments and welcome. At least find something positive in this matter.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. You say that we should be grateful to Mrs Merkel. But Mrs Merkel should perhaps have discussed this with her people: she never asked Germany whether the Germans were behind her invitation. And I think that's something that just needs to be dealt with.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, many people today have talked about solutions, but we know those are going to be long-term. In the meantime, we have a situation we have to manage. So I welcome the increase in funding for the UNHCR and the World Food Programme, but I think it is really shocking that so many Member States last year cut their support for the World Food Programme, so that we are seeing people in the region concerned living on half a dollar a day. Those Member States – particularly those that have not been willing to join in the solidarity programme – should hang their heads in shame about the additional suffering they are causing. One has to ask whether those concerned would stay if they were trying to live on that and support their family. I would also agree with many of those who spoke on Turkey. It is not a safe third country for Kurds and we should be supporting the Kurds in the area of Rojava, and in Turkey itself, because they are part of the solution.  Lastly, I think we have a challenge about putting into operation the decisions taken. If we are talking about rules and are making it clear to people that there are rules, then can we make sure we have staff on the ground and information in relevant languages, and that the asylum process starts at the moment of arrival, not a few days afterwards once people have been spoken to by Frontex and various other organisations. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, dear colleague, of course this is an emergency situation and we all agree that we have to help people, because we are people. My question is: do you not think that both the Commission and the Council need to explain very clearly how the cause is resolved, in order to increase the confidence of Europeans in taking over these people who are suffering? I did not understand from the Commission and the Council how it resolves the cause of these created situations.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – That is a valid question. We are not hearing much about what is happening to establish peace on the ground, and to actually deal with some of the other underlying issues – questions about democracy and questions about how we are tackling climate change in the region, which is certainly a contributory factor to the instability. Indeed, as was pointed out earlier, we are not really looking at how to have a consistent policy towards governments which actually oppress – and are even bombing – their own people.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I hear from all of you who are in support of the redistribution of migrants how morally superior you are and how barbaric the countries that reject quotas are. But what's that morality? You want to be moral at the expense of others, after all, forced solidarity is not real solidarity. You first break up Syria, Libya, then you bring migrants to Europe, and then you want to share them. Then, in fact, by a reckless vote in the Council, which is nothing more than a dictation, you are advocating the redistribution of people. But every action provokes a reaction, and I firmly believe that the elections in Poland will turn out in such a way that the next Polish government, together with the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia and others, will stand firmly against those permanent quotas.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tusk refers to all migrants as refugees. They are not. Some are, but most are not. They are economic migrants. Last Saturday, hundreds of migrants at Calais again tried to enter the UK illegally. With the risk of criminals and jihadi terrorists slipping across our porous borders, I fear the safety of the British people is at risk yet again. According to Eurotunnel, we are now seeing left-wing British anarchists stirring up trouble in the migrant camps. Please, French authorities, do us all a favour and deal with them in your own unique way of crowd control. While you are doing this, could I remind you that the migrants cutting the fences are criminals, the migrants breaking into lorries are criminals, and the migrants storming the tunnel are criminals? Why are the Calais authorities and the French Government failing to stop this? They can do so under the Dublin Agreement by arresting, detaining and deporting. Hungary’s Viktor Orbán shows leadership by taking the appropriate measures. He is being a good European, entering into the solidarity that is so often spoken about in this Parliament. Other countries should follow his example. The majority of the leaders in this place give out open invitations. Is it any wonder the migrants come? To end this crisis it is crucial to start upholding the Dublin rules and to take back full control of our borders.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Presidents, the demonstration is made: left to their own devices, even the most important Member States, even those who have preferred to stay outside Schengen, are unable to manage the migration problem. The solutions chosen in the panic here and there are divided between the derisory, the ridiculous and sometimes the odious.  Today, there are two mistakes not to make.  The first would be to believe that the exodus, of which Europe is the destination, has its source in the civil war in Syria and will end with it. Tens of thousands of young men, sometimes entire families, have been trying their luck by risking their lives in Africa, the Middle East and Asia for years. Before the Balkan route, there was the Sicilian Canal. Previously, there had been the Canary Islands and there is still today Ceuta and Melilla. Migration flows are going to be a permanent fact of this century. Hope or despair throws on the roads those who do not see a future in their homes.  The second mistake would be to consider that the distribution of asylum seekers, ultimately decided in pain, will solve the problem. This is just the beginning of the beginning of a comprehensive asylum and immigration policy and an appropriate foreign policy that all of Europe needs. The Commission is right to start laying the groundwork. The European Council would make a serious mistake by not carrying the exercise to the end.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Everyone agrees that the Council of 23 September, like the JAI Council of the previous day, has taken some important steps towards action as a Union in the refugee crisis, even if it has been painful, but this response must be part of a much longer and much more comprehensive process. Indeed, repeated meetings should not make us lose sight of the essentials. While it is imperative to act and act quickly, as the humanitarian situation demands it, it is necessary at the same time to ensure medium- and long-term prospects. That is why I will have three questions for the Commission and the Council. Migration policy is becoming very operational as a result of the urgency, but beyond the current choices, the question arises of the extension of this movement. In other words, should we and do we want to do more to communitize our decisions and practices in this area? The second question is that operational measures obviously raise the question of short-, medium- and long-term financing. And this is the question of the European budget that is needed. Do you think we can continue to develop our policies with the current European budget? Finally, with regard to the external dimension, the idea that is being promoted is to fix people seeking international protection in third countries, but what will be the next step? The creation of European-led zones in third countries to identify potential candidates? I would like to hear your answers on all of this. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: question ("blue card"). "You and your party are in favour of forcibly distributing these 160,000 migrants. Then I ask you the question: when the quota is exhausted for these 160 000 migrants who have crossed the Mediterranean and risked their lives, there are 500 000 more that the quota is not enough. What are you and your party going to do with the 500,000? I would like an answer to that.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Mrs Winberg has certainly had the opportunity to participate in several meetings of the LIBE Committee, in which I believe my group has never changed its position, considering, in this case, that the current urgency must be addressed while integrating the policy we are currently pursuing into something broader and, indeed, long-term. That is to say, we must both address the source of our current difficulties by talking to the countries concerned and act on integration. From that point of view, yes, Madam, we are totally different from the integration policies that you are advocating because you do not advocate any of them.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As recently as the summer, 800,000 refugees were expected in Germany this year. A current estimate is 1.5 million. The difference of 700,000 is the fault of Angela Merkel and her irresponsible and destructive policies. Mrs Merkel has repealed the Dublin Agreement and is in breach of the German Basic Law. It must not do that! Most of the people who come are economic migrants, not war refugees. Those who cross four or five safe countries do not flee war. It is an illusion to believe that these migrants will work for German pensions. The German minimum wage is far too big a barrier to this. Germany can mainly only offer social benefits. Mrs Merkel has obviously forgotten who elected her and who to protect. It is high time to wake up and stop this invasion. Australia has done it.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, the European Union does not exist. The Union, as I see it, as I wish it, is united, united and generous. That is what I remember from this pathetic Council of 23 September. I note that when the European Parliament votes by a large majority for a provisional relocation mechanism, the President of the Commission and his teams work tirelessly to ensure that it is together and in solidarity that Member States respond with dignity to the refugee crisis, the Member States behave like shopkeepers, balk, calculate, haggle and even threaten.  The solutions, we know in part, my colleagues will have reminded them. Above all, they require courage and political will. After the Greek crisis, the refugee crisis further undermined the European dream. Ladies and gentlemen, Heads of State or Government, do not push European citizens further into the arms of extremes. Stop selling off the ideals and hope of the European Union, get back on your way! (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)).

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Madam Joly, you say that the European Union will never exist on the basis that you hope it will exist, and does that not underline the problem of this utopian fantasy? Does that not underline how the 28 EU Member States – whether you people here like it or not – will always have their best national interests at heart? Do you agree with me that actually this is really, if you are being honest, a failed plan?

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Sir, the refugee crisis is the result of the chaos of the world and the consequence of our foreign policies, or rather our lack of foreign policy. We have to deal with the immediate. We have to deal with the emergency. As my colleague said, the shame is that the Member States have reduced their participation, their development aid and that the funds for emergency humanitarian aid are dry. The humanitarian food programme no longer has the means to feed people in the camps. That is the shame.

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF).
text: Mr President, in a dictatorial way, Brussels has decided to transform the European Union into one major asylum centre and the redistribution of thousands of fortune seekers has opened pandora's box. Merkel's open invitation has not been rescinded. On the contrary, the party has yet to begin, because more than 600 000 asylum seekers have already entered Europe illegally this year and the only contribution that all these so-called Syrian scientists have made so far is an increase in rapes and brawls.  Fortunately, democratic resistance in the European Union to the squandering of freedom, security and the future is growing by the day, as 66% of the Dutch think that the Netherlands should no longer take in refugees. Meanwhile, a majority of Germans are concerned about the huge influx. Austrians are opting en masse for the FPÖ and therefore against mass immigration. Mr President, enough is enough. Reception only in the region. Not a single asylum seeker. Our borders must be closed. That's the only way to stop this asylum tsunami.  (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. – It draws attention to the lightness with which we are talking in this room of 'pest', 'tsunami', 'invasion'. What you are promoting is institutional xenophobia and racism towards people who have been fleeing misery and bombs. They are not so belligerent when countries are forced to take on austerity policies, but when you simply talk about solidarity, welcome and human rights, you talk about plague. Don't you really believe that what you are doing is destroying the Europe of values and building a Europe of xenophobia?

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. – I leave those comments about racism and xenophobia to you. Do you have any idea where the Netherlands is? I can tell you, that is not next to Turkey and it is not on the Mediterranean. If all these asylum seekers were looking for safety, they would already be safe in at least 100 countries before they come forward to the Netherlands. Because you know, sir, they're not looking for safety. They are looking for a free home, free money and free care and I find it shocking that you knowingly burden our own inhabitants with this enormous catastrophe.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Mr President, there is no doubt that the European Union is the recipient of a huge number of migrants and refugees. This dual crisis is a European problem and needs a European approach, solidarity and responsibility. It is therefore imperative to support frontline Member States such as Greece, Italy and Malta. It is imperative to provide technical and financial assistance to the countries of entry, to provide humanitarian aid to migrants and refugees. The baker from Kos, an island in eastern Europe – President Juncker mentioned in his case – is typical of the principles and values of the European Union, the peoples of Europe. The solution is not easy. Europe must act proactively, turn its attention to transit countries, such as Turkey. To turn its attention to the countries of origin of migrants, and of course, at operational level, better border surveillance, identification of illegal migrant circuits and the strengthening of Frontex are needed.  The European Union wants and can successfully tackle this great challenge. We have confidence in you, Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk. We believe that Europe, and in this great crisis, will do what it has to do, based on history and principles. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask Mr Lamassoure a question, but since my last vote was also competent and emotionless, I would like to ask whether the European solution (...). Yes, yes, it is a mistake (...). (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Presidente. –
text: I am sorry, because we understood with our services that you wanted to put a question to Mr Kefalogiannis, but we said that there is a blue card per speaker.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the September Council, real work has begun and must now be implemented very concretely, very quickly: hotspots, identification, rapid examination of applications, relocation and repatriations must work together because all this is linked. We need effective European direction that respects the rights and humanity of people so loaded with suffering.   Mr Juncker, I have no questions yet. Thank you for your determination, your conviction, continue, please continue. To President Tusk with great respect, but without discounting him for the high responsibility he has, we ask for a stronger and more incisive role in convincing the whole Council that you are guiding that responsibility and solidarity – you spoke about this in your speech – but it was not there and it is up to you to make progress in the Council.  I did not like, I have to say, a certain Solomonic tone of your speech in which you distributed a little responsibility here and there and put countries such as Italy and Greece on an equal footing with countries which I will not mention, but which raise walls, make laws that give three to five years in prison for those who find and do not set a fine example of the Europe that you rightly defended at the UN. So I ask you, since you hear italy's responsibilities, we between Schengen and life have chosen to save and not to remain with our arms crossed, to save children, women and men like you and like me.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Community of European Nations, the Union, was created to end centuries of war and nationalist selfishness in the bloody race between European countries and to become a deep, cooperative community of interests and values. Such a Union of 500 million cannot have a problem with the refugee crisis that we are facing now. In the event that this Union is healthy. But we can see that this system is sick right now. And if the system is sick, it's easier to beat through viruses, and there's a virus that's really entered the institutional system, it's the selfishness of individual political wills, the selfishness of individual heads of government, the playing of domestic political games. That is why I ask Mr Juncker where is the report that was promised to us in September, which we adopted in June, for example because of the undemocratic and anti-European measures of the Hungarian Government. I would also like to add, Mr President, for half a moment that Hungary is not only the face of the Orban government that you have seen on television, but also of the thousands and thousands of people who have helped refugees as civilians and volunteers, many of whom are sitting in the stands, showing them that europe has a future. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card question. " My colleague from Ujhelyi is from Szeged. Would it help the European Parliament to make decisions on the migrant crisis or migration crisis by explaining the problems and difficulties faced so far by mass immigration and the illegal crossing of the border by the inhabitants of Szeged, Szeged, Ásotthalom and others. I believe that your direct experience as a member of parliament from the place can help you make good decisions.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card answer. "Indeed, for 12 years I was an elected MEMBER of Parliament for the city and its region from which the world could now see the most horrific images of the arrival of refugees, where the Orban government began to put up the barbed wire fence, there is my house a few kilometres away. And I inform you, Madam Member, and you know this very well, that Hungary and Hungarian society would not have taken this problem this way if the Hungarian Government had not made it, not made an inciterative political campaign for domestic political reasons. Your extremist party and the increasingly radical, increasingly selfish extremist Fidesz, which created this problem and this bad face of Hungary. Please return to humane and solidarity.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – No, President Tusk, the fortress Europe that seems to want will not protect Europeans. Governments in the Council have long been in denial and therefore fail to welcome solidarity with the influx of refugees, deposition the opening of legal and safe avenues so that we do not continue to feed the business of traffickers, and fail in political, ideological, diplomatic and military combat. There are causes of the crisis, there is war in Syria, chaos in Libya, the Islamic State expanding. They now think they can contain the exodus by pouring buckets of money into the neighborhood rather than at least ensuring that there are schools for children and young people in refugee camps.  They are deceiving Europeans with nationalist reactions that fragment the Union and impede coordinated internal and external action, violate the principles and values of the Union, and play the game of terrorists who want to destroy democracy and human rights. The challenges we are facing are only met by strategic convergence, sharing and synergies of common resources and capabilities, foreign and security and defence policy. Stop boycotting them at the council. We need more unity, not more walls. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague, we are dealing with a lot of international problems. There's a lot of speculation about why people are fleeing. Most people are fleeing violence and war. I think that needs to be clear to everyone, at least when it comes to Syria. But you don't think now is the moment when Europe should rebuild its... their commitment to peace and to represent more effectively that international problems must also be tackled peacefully, above all? We need to give you a chance.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – You are right, colleague, but that is exactly why I ask governments to stop boycotting the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy in the European Council. We need them. We need to act strategically. Only by being coordinated can we make the difference: for example, to end the war in Syria – rather than making it worse, as that would be a victory for Assad – and actually act in support of those who are on the ground fighting Islamic State, for instance the Peshmerga in northern Iraq, whom we are not helping at all, or only in a fragmented and uncoordinated way, thus failing our own citizens. We are failing the security and defence of our own citizens by not addressing the root causes of what makes people flee, be it in Syria, be it in Eritrea or elsewhere.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Mr President, the humanitarian problem is, above all, the saving of human lives, but can one think of security and protection for these peaceful populations, as long as there is no eradication of ISIS first and foremost? and this is also addressed to Mr Tusk, especially personally, for the comments he has made previously.  Our European conscience requires us to help refugees, but we must help stop refugees and this cannot be done without eradicating ISIS. I despise Assad, but we have priorities. Erdoğan, who is now visiting Brussels, is stalking the press, his political opponents, bombing the Kurdish population, continuing the illegal occupation of European territory in Cyprus, but we believe here that for the above reasons we need him. Since he is in Brussels, instead of the transactions we do with him, at least ask him to stop bombing the Kurds.  One final phrase: what differentiates us in Europe is our interests, and so are our values. (Applause)

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Juncker, presenting your agenda, you said that the European Union has 29 members. The 29th Member State area is not imaginary because it is made up of unemployed and disenfranchised Europeans. Today, we are free to add refugees to these unfortunate groups. There are no more local or regional crises in today's world; all crises today have the potential of a global crisis. This crisis very much confirms this to refugee Europe. The European Union is clearly divided within itself over this problem. Only five members accept about seventy per cent of the refugees. The crisis has put us under a lot of pressure by pointing out that European institutions function well under normal conditions, but react badly and slowly to sudden problems. For example, Croatia is the only member of the European Union that is exposed to thousands of refugees without being part of the Schenghenska Zone at the same time. Instead of solidarity, we face political harassment, barbed wire and the militarisation of the border by another EU member state. It all comes down to the question of what kind of society we want to live in and what kind of self-image the European Union wants in the world.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, my stomach is stirring when I hear some statements in this House. The talk of 'pest', the talk of 'invasion', the mix of immigration and terrorism, or immigration and security, seems to me to be an offence to this House and democracy. Whoever speaks like this about human beings deserves only a rating and, even if it is a strong word, I will say it: it is you who are rubbish, who refer thus to human beings fleeing misery and war. On the other hand, I believe that the response to these approaches to litter is slightly hypocritical. No one here says that European foreign policy over the past fifteen years has helped to pour gasoline on conflicts. No one here says that Europe has spent more money on raising walls than on helping refugees. No one here says that precisely the abolition of the Dublin Protocol — if refugees could seek asylum in transit countries, which they cannot ask for at this time — would have prevented us from seeing images like that of a dead child on the beach. I think in front of the trash it takes a little less hypocrisy. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. "Dear colleague, I am still surprised that you are dealing with rubbish in some of your colleagues in this Chamber. The subject is too important for us to send such a quibble to the head.  You cannot deny that this immigration is massive. By its magnitude, it exceeds all that one might have feared. It is therefore not necessarily racism or xenophobia to be concerned about it. I ask you if, beyond your insults, you do not think that states have some reason to be concerned about what is happening. It is understandable that States are trying to reduce the flow of refugees and I believe that the European Union - I am asking you if that is your opinion - should also make efforts to try to fix these refugee flows in their countries of origin by helping them on the spot and not by creating a call for air. , as Mrs Merkel did.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Your Honour, you are European and, perhaps, your grandfather — as my grandparents — were unlucky enough to be forced to leave your country and I would call garbage anyone who referred to your grandfather or mine as a 'pest' or an 'invasion'.  If we have a migration problem in Europe, that has to do with the foreign policy of our states, and I believe that encouraging the most repugnant feelings of selfishness in the face of populations that are only fleeing misery brings nothing to the democratic Europe that we should be building.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – Europe does not need to take responsibility and blame for the refugee problem. Europe has not caused this crisis, Europe is now part of the solution to this problem, so Europe is not sick. And there are also different situations in Europe in different countries, and they must also be respected, and in this way, with seriously responsible rhetoric, also speak in this house. The refugee crisis has been caused by the fall of dictatorial regimes in Libya, Iraq, the destabilisation of Syria. And after the fall of these regimes, extremists who do not respect even human life have come to power, they do not respect even millennial history. There is therefore a problem there, and this problem must first be confronted and the situation in these countries must be regulated and, through a concerted action, to bring about peace in these countries. On the other hand, we must be aware that we will continue to have a refugee crisis in the future, because it is the demographics of Africa that will cause it. We must therefore have sustainable solutions. At the moment, however, we must take care of those who are on European soil today and help them in this difficult situation.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, immediately after the Decision of the European Council of 23 September, which was so painful and postponed on several occasions, I wondered what we could have said most, how we could explain to the citizens of Europe and to those who still believe in the values of the Union if that conclusion had not been reached.  Over and over again, this Parliament has expressed itself by a large majority, and the approach and determinations that have been reached are only a first step for us, because a new course on immigration policies, a process that takes concrete and strong actions that take note of the irreversible geopolitical change that generates migratory flows is no longer deferred. Now we are not going back, we are moving forward together.  The process of integration in the case of refugees leads us to reflect, however, entirely within the Union, first the indifference and then the harsh opposition of certain countries makes us think and leads us to take the consequent actions. Mr Juncker's statements on the state of the Union underlined the lack of union in the Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
