text: Mr President, thousands of refugees are flooding southern Europe, especially Greece, which cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. To date, more than 260,000 refugees have entered our country. The knot, then, has reached the comb and action must be taken immediately.  Firstly, initiatives to promote peace in the Middle East and North Africa. Secondly, to tell Turkey that it must stop trading in the distress of refugees and stop harboring the slave trade. Thirdly, to abolish Dublin III, which turns Greece into a warehouse of souls. Fourthly, the introduction of the refugee allocation clause in all the Member States of the European Union, depending on the GDP, area and population of each Member State. Fifthly, to strengthen Greece economically, in order to better guard European borders. Finally, everyone must understand that the preservation of the Greek borders is the exclusive competence of Greece and our sovereign rights to protect the Greek borders will not be granted to Turkey or the European Union.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tusk, you are concerned about being alone in the corridors of the United Nations defending the good name of the European Union. What horrifies us is that children die on the roads of different countries and the elderly die.  It is narcissism of salon politicians to worry about the good name of the European Union when we make one mistake after another. Not Parliament, which has long warned of what was going on; not the Commission, which has warned how to carry out a comprehensive and common plan. Mr. Tusk, I'm referring to you. You have failed in the Council. And he has announced to us the ethics of Weber's responsibility; you always announce that when you're going to betray something very, very serious.  We know, Mr. Tusk, that you're interested in external borders. He will not be interested in the solidarity in which we cement the European Union, our values or what calls us to efficiency. Unfortunately, that's the way it is.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we are discussing for the umpteenth time, in this Chamber, the refugee problem, whether the refugeeisation of people was a natural phenomenon, such as sunshine or rain. It is not a natural phenomenon, it is the result of the wars and for these wars, especially for the war in Syria, which has been going on for more than four years, and the governments of Western states, both in the United States and in some major European states, which cannot be exempted from the obsession, that they must impose on the whole world, even outside the West. , regimes of their choice. It is clear that the West's attempt to strengthen the Syrian opposition, to overthrow the Assad regime, has failed and has led to the strengthening and the strengthening of the Islamic State phenomenon. We must realise that there is no solution in Syria without Assad, and move realistically to root out the Islamic State, to stop the refugee crisis.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the president of the Commission for his excellent work and for the work she has It was indeed a good decision on 23 September that the Council of Home Affairs Ministers decided to divide refugees into all EU countries. These majority decisions are a good sign interinstitutionally, a sign of solidarity. But now they are implemented.  A coalition of humanity is needed, which must become a reality for the people – women, men, children – who are fleeing the barrel bombs of Assad and ISIS. Merkel said yes: we can do it. In this sense, it is necessary to abolish Dublin, to create legal access routes, decent reception centres and not deportation prisons, as the head of Frontex is now calling for. I am also astonished that Mr Erdogan is now being courted and that his authoritarian behaviour is no longer an issue – Gezi Park, Kurds, journalists, etc. Mr Tusk, what we need from you as President-in-Office of the Council is for you to tell the governments that we need a policy of courage and not fear, a welcome policy against the incitement of populists, whether they are called the CSU, Fidesz, Front National or FPÖ.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I don't know, I'm very shocked. It feels like you're living in a bubble in this House. Hasn't anyone seen what's going on in real life? Here you are talking about solidarity. For me, solidarity is when it stings my heart when I hear that the World Food Programme has had to cut back on help for the people who really need it. One can add up one plus one what it is due to, namely that much of the aid money that would go to those most in need goes to finance the mass immigration that we see today.  In my country, Sweden, people often talk about integration – I got an answer here to my Blue Card question that "we will integrate everyone who comes". Sweden has been involved in this project for many years, and it has never succeeded. So we have up to 200 exclusion zones, 55 so-called no-go zones. It's a disaster. We don't even have housing. We don't have jobs for them. Can you imagine that Sweden is now thinking of building its first refugee camp? We also have winter and minus 20 degrees.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker regrets that no unanimous decision has been reached on a quota issue in the Council of Interior Ministers, adding that this has domestic political reasons. Yes, it is domestic, because there are governments that take into account the will of the citizens. The French foreign minister has attacked Hungary for defending its borders in an unqualified manner. Of the 56,000 respondents in France, 88% agreed with the construction of fences. And Donald Tusk sees defending Europe's reputation as his biggest challenge. Europe is the most open, totant society in the world. This is not the challenge, the challenge is to protect European identity and culture. If you are Democrats, let us together allow the institution of the EU referendum and see what the Will of the People of Europe is on this serious issue.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that Europe cannot take in all the misery of the world, but it is also true that Europe, the whole of Europe, must deal with the misery of the world. We cannot be neutral, immobile, reflexless, when injustices multiply and when serious events happen elsewhere on our planet. It is true that we have to fight the origins, the sources of the migration problem, and some do. I would like to pay tribute here to the Member States of the European Union which have not cut their development aid. There are few of them. I would like to pay tribute here to those who intend to correct up their development aid. I would like to criticise here the Member States of the European Union which have reduced their contribution to humanitarian aid. I would like to criticise those who have reduced their contribution to the UN-managed food fund. I would like to criticise here the Member States which have reduced their contribution to the functioning of the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees.  If we are talking about the origins, we must also talk about those who have helped to increase the mass of problems that, in fact, drive the unfortunates of this world to come to Europe. To be honest, and I repeat this here, in fact, we should be proud that those who are unhappy are heading to Europe because Europe, in their eyes, is a better place to live than elsewhere. Why don't they go to Russia? Why don't they go to China? Why are they not going to the United States? Why don't they go to the Gulf countries? Should we now apologise for being in the eyes of the whole planet the place where it is better to live? We should be proud of that! But it is true that we have to deal with the massive influx of refugees and we are in the process of doing so. The right answer to the migration problem is not to build walls. Refugees, because they are unfortunate, will always find a way to reach European territory. Always. Therefore, building walls will not solve the problem. But those who build these walls should at least pay attention to the language that accompanies their architectural work. We must not forget that words speak to those who hear them.  Why do we say, without protests, that refugees are economic refugees? How do you know? There are those who flee their country because they are persecuted. So let's not mix the categories. Yes, there are economic refugees. Would you not be if you lived in the circumstances of theirs? Yes, it is true that they are not allowed to stay in Europe. But let's not talk about these unfortunates as if they were barbarian hordes, gangsters and organized gangs. That is not the case. They're all unfortunate. (Applause) I said that building walls was not a good answer. I would add: why do some people think they can build walls between the member countries of the European Union? Why is the construction of walls between Eu Member States no longer hindering? It is still implausible that in 2015 some governments will build walls within the European Union. What does that mean?  It's the end of Europe! If everyone did this, it would be the end of Europe. We must, without hindrance, openly criticize governments that resort to this kind of architectural genius. Some of you are critical of the European Union because it would not have been able to make decisions. I would like to remind you here, Mr President, that the European Council took place on 23 September and that Parliament will vote on 15 October on the budget that accompanies the decisions of the European Council. Never - and I know what I'm talking about - has never been a decision made as quickly as this time. The Council, the Commission and Parliament can be proud of this. If we were still so fast, Europe would be in a much better state. You criticise the Member States, yes, but you always say the European Union. That is not correct. Don't say Europe, Europe, Europe... Don't say the European Union, don't say Tusk or Juncker, say the Member States. Some Member States are not in a good place to make the decisions they should make. So do not criticise Europe but criticise the Member States which prevent us from taking action. (Applause)  And don't criticize my friend Tusk. I am still a witness to the progress of the European Council meetings. While some Member States are preventing the President of the European Council from moving forward as quickly as he would like, the President of the European Council, which does everything to get things done. Instead, criticise the Member States that prevent it.  In addition, we should always come back to an important subject. I feel very challenged by the fact that the religious factor or the philosophical factor finds in Europe an importance that does not belong to it. It should not be said that Christians are only admitted to its territory. It should not be said that we do not like to see believers of another obedience evolve on our territory. This is not Europe! Europe is the continent of tolerance. There should be no tolerance for intolerance. Intolerance must be combated; you have to say it every moment. Eber die Turkei will ich gern noch ein Wort sagen: Wer gibt einigen hier das Recht, zu sagen, wir h-tten mit Herrn Erdogan gestern ein Kaffeekr-nzchen abgehalten? Wir haben uns sehr bem-ht, mit der Turkei ein Einvernehmen in Sachen Flàchtlinge herzustellen. Das ist ultrawichtig, nicht nur for Griechenland, sondern for Gesamteuropa. Aber wir haben naturlich auch 'ber andere Fragen geredet. Denken Sie wirklich, dass wir mit Herrn Erdogan Hundchen gehalten h-tten? Naturlich haben wir - im 'brigen auch der President des Parlamentes - die Probleme angesprochen, die uns voneinander unterscheiden. Aber ich bin trotzdem der Auffassung, die Turkei geh-rt auf die Liste der sicheren Lunder. Diejenigen, die denken, dem sollte nicht so sein, sollen die Schlussfolgerungen aus ihren ziehen. Wenn die Turkei nicht auf die Liste der sicheren Lunder geh-rt, wie einige denken, dann muss hier der Antrag gestellt werden, die Beitrittsverhandlungen mit der Turkei abzubrechen. Solange wir aber auch auf die turkische Mithilfe angewiesen sind und solange die Turkei auch auf ein harmonisches gemeinsames Handeln mit der European Union angewiesen ist und solange die Beitrittsverhandlungen nicht gestoppt werden, solange geh-rt auch die Aber denken Sie nicht, dass wir mit Herrn Erdogan nur Freundlichkeiten ausgetauscht h-tten. Trotzdem bin ich der Turkei dankbar - das muss man hier doch einmal feststellen - dass sie 2.2 Millionen Flàchtlinge auf ihrem Territorium beherbergt. (Beifall) Wer sind wir denn, dass wir denken, dies wr keine groe Anstrengung? Wir haben uns darauf verst-ndigt, 160,000 Menschen in Europa solidarisch auf die Mitgliedstaaten zu verteilen. Die Turkei hat 2.2 Millionen Flàchtlinge aufgenommen, vom Libanon und von Jordann ganz zu schweigen, wo die prozentualen Zahlen noch wesentlich deftiger ausfallen. Also: Ein bisschen Bescheidenheit tete uns manchmal gut. Wir sind am Anfang eines langen Prozesses, und deshalb brauchen wir ein permanent System der Umverteilung in Europa, und deshalb brauchen wir auch eine Legalisierung der Einwanderung nach Europa. Ich komme aus einem kleinen Land - Luxemburg, fer die, die es nicht wissen sollten. Ich bin aufgewachsen mit jungen Italianern, mit vielen Portugiesen. Luxemburg geh-rt zu den reichsten Lundern der European Union. Ohne Portugiesen und ohne Italianer wre dieses kleine Land nicht das geworden, was es geworden ist. Einwanderung bringt Reichtum!

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Jean-Claude Juncker for his support. We are here in Parliament to be criticised and I am not here to be applauded: it is our job. Of course we have to be tough if we want to be politicians, and I think that in this context everything must be clear. Thank you, Members, for the discussion. I think after this discussion we are fully aware that this issue is still dividing Europeans – at Member State level and also here in the European Parliament – and I can understand why. At the same time, I feel that today the chance for having a more common approach is much greater than it was a few weeks ago. I have no illusions and I have no doubts: nothing in this matter is easy, firstly because the scale of this issue is bigger than ever before, and that is why it is full of emotion – and not only in this House. First of all I would like to underline that the issue today, because of its scale, is absolutely unique. That is why nothing is easy. Today we are talking about almost 70 million displaced people in the world, and almost all of them are around us. In Africa and Eurasia, there are 70 million.  When it comes to Afghans, for example, we have almost three million Afghans on their way to other countries. They are today in Pakistan, in Iran, in Iraq and in Turkey. Some of them, three million, are already in Europe. We have to be aware that, maybe not for all of them, but for sure for the majority of them, Europe is or can be the final destination. We have about eight million internally displaced people in Syria. There are three million Syrians in Turkey, Jordan and Iraq. There are hundreds of thousands of potential refugees from Yemen. This is why nothing is easy in this case. This is why some of us in Europe are so nervous. This is why we feel something like fear, and I can understand why, because this is something new. For sure it is not a new problem but this scale, this new exodus, is something new, and some Member States have no experience with this kind of problem. That is why emotions are running so high. I cannot agree with the thesis that the majority of refugees are social migrants. First of all, it is impossible today to distinguish between refugees and migrants because, in fact, all of them are escaping war, poverty and hunger – at the same time – from Afghanistan, from Syria and from other countries. This is why the situation is really difficult for us, because we have to treat almost all of them as potential asylum seekers. The second reason why nothing is easy in this case is because this new conflict in Syria – the war in Syria – could very possibly transform into a global conflict as a result of the engagement of some global powers in Syria today. I have no doubt that the current situation is bad enough to provoke a new wave of refugees from Syria. As I mentioned in my first speech here, the current estimate is that about three million new Syrian refugees are on their way today from Aleppo and the neighbourhood of Aleppo. Thirdly, the situation is also difficult because we have no convenient partners around us. I have no doubt that we have to cooperate with other countries, for example Turkey. I can fully understand why some of us are very critical or sceptical when it comes to Turkey but, on the other hand, if we want to cope with this problem we have to consider Turkey as an absolutely key partner in this project. Do we want to lecture Turkey today or do we want Turkey on board to tackle the refugee problem?  I know this is a dramatic dilemma, but today we have to solve this dilemma and our opinion, the opinion of the European institutions, is that we have to try to cooperate with Turkey because we have no other option. As you know, we have more difficult partners around us than Turkey. Turkey is not easy, but it is definitely the best possible partner when it comes to our neighbourhood in the south and in the east.  It is obvious to me that we, and of course also the Member States, have to engage. That is why I am absolutely sure that our next European Council will be dedicated to this issue, and I hope that the discussion today here in Parliament will also be a real inspiration for some leaders and for some Member States – and I am sure that you know what I mean. Było jeszcze pytanie od eurodeputowanego z Polski, kolegi Olbrychta, co możemy zrobić wspólnie, a co osobno, jako państwa członkowskie, w tej sprawie. Jedna sprawa wydaje się dzisiaj oczywista: żadne państwo w Europie samodzielnie nie poradzi sobie z przyjęciem i utrzymaniem uchodźców, stąd kontrowersyjna, ale konieczna idea wzajemnej pomocy, relokacji. I równocześnie dzisiaj widać, że żadne państwo graniczne nie może sobie samo poradzić z takim napływem emigrantów, z jakim mamy do czynienia dzisiaj.  Jedna i druga sprawa wymaga solidarnego i moim zdaniem wspólnotowego podejścia, a nie wzajemnego oskarżania się. Dlatego najwyższy czas, aby pomyśleć o wspólnej odpowiedzialności europejskiej za ochronę granicy zewnętrznej. Dzisiaj widać wyraźnie, że ten ciężar – bo to jest dzisiaj wyjątkowy ciężar i wyjątkowa odpowiedzialność – przekracza możliwości któregokolwiek z państw członkowskich z osobna. To jest prawdziwa rewolucja w myśleniu, ale uważam, że powinniśmy tę rewolucję przeprowadzić, to znaczy Europa jako wspólnota powinna przejąć istotną część odpowiedzialności za ochronę granic zewnętrznych, w tym za organizację tak trudnych projektów jak hot spoty czy obozy dla uchodźców, wtedy, kiedy to konieczne wewnątrz Europy, ale także poprzez pomoc dla organizowania takich punktów na zewnątrz Europy. I to jest, moim zdaniem, bardzo poważny temat dla nas wszystkich: tu w Parlamencie, w Radzie Europejskiej i w innych instytucjach.

name: President. –
text: President Tusk, President Juncker, thank you very much for your speeches, but much more for your engagement on this very difficult issue.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - The conclusions of an informal European Council meeting last September have contributed to a step forward in addressing the migrant crisis. However, this step forward is not a sufficient step. In order to find a solution, we have to acknowledge two things: that the size of the refugee wave in the EU has surprised everyone and; that there are very large differences between member states. As it is realistic that the refugee wave will not stop soon we must create a permanent system of refugee admissions solutions.  We must certainly do everything to address the refugee problem primarily in stabilising the situation in the countries where the migrants come from. We must also help all countries participating in this crisis: Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan. It is important that the EU also stand with Serbia and Macedonia so that these countries can help the EU's efforts.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – On the one hand, it is good news that, following the decision of the Extraordinary European Council, European solidarity with refugees and between Member States has been maintained, and on the other hand, it is regrettable that this solidarity is a little apparent, since the quota of 120 000 that the Member States have agreed to distribute is a fraction of what is actually needed.  However, it is a historic mistake that some countries, Hungary, opposed the deal. The Hungarian Government has questioned solidarity and cooperation at both our borders and at the negotiating table and has gone against basic humanitarian obligations. This has undermined Hungary reputation, but unfortunately in the long term it can also have a negative impact on society's openness and helpfulness through its constant search for enemies and negative propaganda. Fortunately, there Hungary other things: a significant part of society has moved, set an example, and many citizens and NGOs have provided a helping hand to refugees.  Similar examples and decisive action are needed in Europe. We need not only quotas, but also a new comprehensive refugee policy replacing the Dublin system, while protecting the Schengen acquis. Proper border protection and registration of refugees must be solved in such a way that Member States can fully fulfil their human rights and humanitarian obligations and ensure the free movement of European citizens.  In the meantime, the European Union must also help resolve the conflict in Syria and support refugees in neighbouring countries on the ground.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At present, each Member State is either directly affected by this process or is in real danger. It is to be pleased that the European Council has started to look at this problem holistically. The policy decisions taken concern not only the mechanism for relocating refugees, but also the increase in the tightness of the external borders or the increase in assistance in the regions where migrants come from.  International organisations point out that assistance in conflict areas or neighbouring countries is often cheaper and more effective than funding support for refugees arriving in Europe. However, I am afraid that the sum of eur 1 billion may not be sufficient.  The Council conclusions, on the other hand, lacked concrete decisions in relation to return policy. Europe cannot afford to welcome everyone willing to live on our continent – refugees must be separated from economic migrants and the latter should be sent back. It is estimated that of the approximately one million people who will come to Europe this year, more than half are economic migrants. This shows the scale of the next challenge facing the Member States.  A few weeks ago, Jeffrey Sachs asked when the European Union would solve the four most important problems: the crisis in Greece, the influx of migrants, the Ukrainian-Russian crisis, aid to Africa? At what stage are the work to solve these four problems?

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I appreciate that the Heads of State have clearly expressed their desire to address the refugee problem where it arises. Without increasing humanitarian aid in the Turkish and Jordanian camps, strengthening the protection of the European Union's external borders and, last but not least, effective action against the Islamic State, the influx of migrants will not be stopped. At the same time, it is also our common duty to help people fleeing war and violence.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – As a result of the meeting, I appreciate that the joint management of the refugee crisis, which is a historic challenge for Europe, has been at least outlined to the Heads of State or Government. This time, however, the unity needed for implementation has not been achieved, because some leaders, especially the Hungarian Prime Minister, are prioritising their own political interests in this dramatic situation, undermining the common EU solution. Moreover, it has been shown that, although behind-closed-doors consultation may be more effective, its great disadvantage is that it can be used to abuse in external communications by prone, corrupt politicians. Orban is trying to make his domestic political audience believe , unfortunately not without success, that the leaders of the Member States negotiated on his proposals, and that, in the midst of the union's general inertia, measures to promote a solution were taken under his pressure.  I think it is important for the members of the EiT, and in particular President Tusk, to recognise the dangers of this in terms of influencing the Hungarian public and the european public as a whole, and to stand up to statements that discredit both refugees and the EU in the widest public. The EP's task is also urgent: as soon as S&D impeached the Slovak Prime Minister who spoke out against the principles of the party family, the EPP could be expected to finally take decisive action against Orban's disruptive, anti-EU and inhumane policies.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the humanitarian situation of refugees in the EU and neighbouring countries (2015/2877(SDR)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the causes of the refugee flows affecting the European Union lie in the terrible conflicts in Syria and Iraq, as well as in the long-standing crises in Afghanistan and the Horn of Africa.  The decisions taken by the Heads of State or Government at their informal meeting on 23 September confirm the strong commitment of the European Union, whether on the internal or external and humanitarian side of this crisis. In very concrete terms, we are in the process of freeing up the resources necessary to refinance humanitarian organizations active on the ground, such as the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees and the World Food Programme, to better meet the needs of refugees close to their places of origin in Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon and Iraq. In Syria, we remain the main donor in the face of the endless war that this country is going through. We are committed to strengthening the main trust funds to launch concrete projects. This allows us to help refugees in critical areas, such as education or youth employment. I am thinking, of course, of the Madad fund, which was suffering from considerable underfunding, and the emergency fund for Africa. In both cases, it is the response to a common request from the European Parliament and the heads of state or government. At the internal level, the Council, aware of the scale of the crisis and the urgency of providing an effective and rapid response to the humanitarian situation of refugees, has made every effort to treat this issue as a matter of highest priority. For this reason, two extraordinary meetings of the Justice and Home Affairs Council were convened on 14 and 22 September 2015, in addition to the meetings already scheduled by the Presidency, in order to follow up on the guidelines given by the European Council at its meetings in April and June, the European migration agenda presented by the Commission in May and the additional package of measures that the Commission submitted on 9 September.  As Minister for Labour and Employment, as recently as yesterday, at the Ministers' Luncheon, I organised an exchange on the support that the European Union and the Commission can give to the States which currently host the largest number of refugees, to facilitate their integration, to facilitate their access to the labour market, to support language courses , the assessment of their professional qualifications, the schooling of children, etc.  Commissioner Thyssen has presented us with a number of thoughts on the use of funds, particularly from the European Social Fund, to intervene at this level. The Presidency intends to continue, also within the framework of the EPSCO Council, this reflection in order to effectively implement, in a coherent and united way, an approach in the countries that receive the largest numbers of refugees. All these efforts have enabled and must lead to important and significant results in the shortest possible time, including the adoption on 14 September of a Council decision establishing interim measures on international protection for Italy and Greece, which will allow the relocation of a first contingent of 40,000 refugees. At its meeting on 22 September the Council also adopted a second decision to relocate 120,000 people in need of international protection from Italy and Greece or any other Member State that needs it. I am pleased to note that the first hotspots are already operational and I understand that other hotspots will be operational soon. The roadmaps have been submitted by Italy and Greece, they have already been presented at the expert forum organised by the Commission in collaboration with EASO and at the meeting of the Strategic Committee on Immigration, Borders and Asylum on 5 October. At these meetings, the practicalities of implementing relocation mechanisms were discussed in detail. The Council welcomes the excellent cooperation with Parliament in reviewing these decisions and the responsiveness of Parliament. This demonstrates the common will to achieve concrete results in providing refugees with the protection and assistance to which they are entitled, and to the Member States, especially those most at risk, the assistance and assistance they ask for. We also support humanitarian aid to refugees who try to find refuge in the European Union when they cross the southern Mediterranean, especially from Libya. In this context, I would like to underline that we are counting on very concrete results with our partners at the Valletta Summit, whether on the root causes of migration, on refugee protection issues, on the fight against human traffickers or on cooperation on return and readmission. Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, as Presidency, we are actively engaged in mobilising Member States and our key partners to achieve our goal of doubling the contribution from the Union budget and reaching an additional EUR 1 billion to support humanitarian organisations engaged in this crisis.  Recently, the Netherlands and Belgium announced additional contributions of 48.5 million and 30 million euros respectively. The United Kingdom has announced an additional 100 million pounds and France and Germany have each announced an additional 100 million euros.  These efforts, which put the European Union on the front line, must also be accompanied by the support of the entire international community. In this regard, we welcome the fact that, as Chair of the G7, Germany has just organised, on the margins of the Ministerial Week of the United Nations General Assembly, an extra event which has resulted in commitments of more than EUR 1.8 billion. As you know, the Commission has already put forward proposals for budgetary adjustment. For our part, as Presidency, we are determined to support this approach in the Council. Of course, we will need the active support of the European Parliament for the rapid implementation of the decisions taken and the necessary budgetary adjustments. I am sure we can count on you in that regard.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today we are all put to the test. We are faced with what is arguably the biggest challenge to Europe in a generation. What is being put to the test is our capacity to handle a huge humanitarian crisis. What is being put to the test is our capacity to understand that there will be solutions only at a European level. What is being put to the test is the very fabric of our European Union. What is being put to the test is actually the fundamental values we share, and much that was said this morning testifies to this. I have to note that when people try to argue that those arriving in Europe today are, in the majority, people seeking a better future, not refugees – which is completely unfounded, there are no scientific data – and people say this in this House, I draw some hope from this because they do not want to be seen not to be doing something for real refugees. My hope is that once those in this House who currently reject everything we do understand that we are actually dealing with a majority of real refugees, they will see the fallacy of their ways and come to the conclusion that there are only European solutions here. There is no need to hide from that fact. I say this also:  (Interjection from the floor: ‘Go to the camps and talk to them’) It is being said here – because this is apparently the way people who disagree with you think they can make a point – it is being said behind me here ‘Go and talk to them in the camps’. Well, that is exactly what I did. That is exactly what I did, but apparently you only hear what you want to hear when you talk in the camps. I know that, in this day and age, fear is an important factor in European society. Many European citizens are afraid, and you know what fear has as a characteristic: when you are afraid you go and look for proof that your fear is justified and you are not open to proof that your fear is unjustified. Responsible politics in this situation is not to cater to fear, not to create stereotypes, not to put people in groups, but to come up with solutions to a problem instead of just increasing people’s fears in the hope that it will provide you with more votes at the next election. This is also the time when politicians across Europe will be challenged on whether their integrity still prevails or whether they go for the easy solution of catering to fears in the hope of then gaining political position. I hope we will all be responsible in this phase.  The European Council was responsible last week, by paving the way for decisions that can now be implemented. Let me briefly go through them. They decided last week to strengthen external borders and increase the financial and human resources for our agencies, Frontex, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and Europol, and to increase funding for the EU home affairs funding programmes, with EUR 100 million for emergency assistance to the most affected EU Member States. This is in addition to the EUR 73 million already exhausted. Much of this funding is going to address the immediate humanitarian needs – to help Member States provide the necessary shelter, health, welfare and other specific basic needs of new arrivals.  We speeded up the preparation of the Western Balkan conference next Thursday. We speeded up the roll-out of support teams in the hotspots in the most affected Member States, to identify, register and fingerprint migrants. This is essential to make sure we do indeed distinguish between those who have the right to asylum and those who do not.  It was also decided to uphold, apply and implement the existing Dublin rules and the Schengen acquis; to match the mobilised EU budget contributions with Member State contributions, including notably EUR 1 billion for the UNHCR, the World Food Programme and other agencies to respond to the urgent needs of displaced Syrian refugees in the region; to assist Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan in dealing with the refugee crisis through the help of the Trust Fund for Syria; to increase the funding of the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa; and to speed up preparations for the Valetta Summit on 11—12 November. These are important decisions. Let us implement them. The issue here is not that we do not know what to do; the issue is that, as in other areas, we lack self-confidence. We can handle this – I agree with Chancellor Merkel: ‘Wir schaffen das’ – I have no doubts. We need to address the issue of what I would call also in this area ‘moral hazard’. Member States need to be able to trust that other Member States will do their part.  This is the core issue here, that so-called frontline Member States will do their part in making sure that our external borders are better controlled and that people who arrive are immediately fingerprinted, and that those Member States who are not frontline states will do their part in showing their solidarity with the Member States who bear the brunt of the arrivals. There is an issue here of just doing what we agreed, and then the self-confidence in Europe will increase, and mutual trust will also increase – and that is what we need between Member States. As I said before, winter is coming. I spoke to the High Commissioner for Refugees, António Guterres, yesterday and he said clearly that we know how to, and we certainly can, winter-proof the refugee camps, the tents, the reception centres, but we cannot winter-proof masses of people on the move – and moving in an unpredictable and fast manner. You cannot winter-proof movements of people. In Geneva yesterday our interlocutors welcomed the latest EU steps to mobilise the budget for these purposes. To name but a few: EUR 200 million to the UNHCR World Food Programme and other aid agencies to respond to the urgent needs of displaced persons and refugees in the region; EUR 300 million in humanitarian aid next year and, as you know, we asked Member States to match this and the Heads of State or Government agreed to do that.  I am looking forward to taking stock of these promises at the next European Council and I hope people understand that EUR 1 billion of funding is not too much to ask for in humanitarian aid. In this respect, I am again very grateful to this Parliament, yet again leading by example and fast-tracking the adoption of the budgetary proposals we made last week. This Parliament as an institution has assumed its responsibility in an admirable way. The Trust Fund for Syria, aiming to reach EUR 1 billion, was also welcomed by those frontline states that will need to deal with the approaching winter. Humanitarian aid is our urgency of today. When it comes to humanitarian aid, it is not enough to find necessary funding. You need to put in place necessary help mechanisms, linking manpower and assets. And those challenges are high on the agenda of my colleagues Commissioners Avramopoulos, Stylianides and Hahn, and also Commissioner Andriukaitis, who is working on the health issues. The civil protection mechanism is ready to be activated. We need to do this quickly. We do not want to waste time. A quantum leap in reception capacities in Greece is probably the most urgent priority that we are tackling on a daily basis. President Juncker has put in place people to coordinate the national and European technical assistance resources being mobilised to help Greece. Without reception capacity nothing will work, and we all agree on that. Greece will have a separate programme with UNHCR on this. This needs to be finalised in the coming weeks. Greece needs to return to the Dublin system, and I have to say that I salute the Greek Government for committing to returning to the Dublin system. You will not hear me saying that all is ready for winter but this Commission has identified and proposed all the operational and budgetary measures that are needed internally within the EU and outside our borders. With regard to Turkey, the President has said more than enough: we will continue working on this, and you will also be informed this afternoon about exactly what we will be doing in the next couple of weeks. I think you will agree with me that, while working on the humanitarian situation and sharing the burden with the most affected countries, we should also not neglect the wider issue in relation to managing the situation and the root causes of the situation. The Valletta Summit will be important – however, I will limit myself to referring to what President Juncker has said about that. Refugees, on the run from war and persecution, willing to risk everything for even the chance of a decent life, will continue to flee. They simply have no other option. And we have no other option but to provide a safe haven for them, to protect them and to treat them properly, here in the European Union, as well as in other countries where they arrive. So it is time to rebuild our self-confidence and our mutual confidence in our ability to deal with this most pressing humanitarian issue effectively, and together  Wir schaffen das!

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, our debate on the refugee issue, at this time, is directly linked to the previous debate. Quite rightly, you said that the European Union 'has the knife and the sword' to solve this problem. The solution must be found at European level, but the solution is, above all, political. I say this because President Tusk mentioned earlier about the solidarity of the Member States that must be shown and, rightly, about border protection, about the necessary respect for the rules of the European Union. However, the problem cannot be solved unless there is immediate cooperation with the countries of origin of the problem.  You know very well that the European Union has a dominant say in the causes of this refugee crisis, but above all, a memorandum agreement with the countries of transit of these people, and I am referring to Turkey. You are well aware that yesterday President Erdoğan criticised us for not being able to accept the humanitarian crisis of 250,000 people on our territory, when he is hosting two million, apparently forgetting that this number of refugees is being financed and forgetting, obviously, that there have been readmission agreements with the European Union since 2011 and with Greece since 2014. , which are not respected.  With this I would like to say that if everyone does not assume their responsibilities, the European Union, Europe, the Member States cannot solve a problem which, above all and foremost, focuses on man and his survival.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Humanitarian aid is needed these days not only in our own Member States, but also on the way to us, so to speak, in the Balkans, in Turkey and, of course, in the crisis region itself. I think we have to thank the volunteers and the full-time helpers who help everywhere with great commitment to exhaustion, for example in the camps in and around Syria, in Serbia or at Munich Central Station. Of course, the whole thing has to be financed. And it is good what the Council has decided, and what we want to do together on increases. But where would we be today, or what might have been that if the Member States had complied with the commitments they had long since made? Where, for example, is the 0.7% for development cooperation? It is now important to show speed, to pay at last and to act quickly. The refugees, who have suffered many sufferings and borne many burdens, should be worthy of every effort.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Turkey is now receiving financial support from the European Union to ensure adequate reception of asylum seekers. Okay, but don't forget the people with disabilities. These are numerous, partly because of the war situation in Syria. Moreover, they often stay behind in the camps because they are often too poor to pay for the crossing to Europe. Given their limitations, these people need specific support. Sometimes they also need medical or paramedical help. That specific offer is lacking in the camps.  For example, children with disabilities cannot participate in an ordinary class. For example, deaf children need lessons in sign language, blind children need teaching materials in Braille, and so on. Some of the emergency funds allocated should therefore be used specifically to provide a basis of disability-specific support to those people. That is not happening at the moment, or far too little. I was able to see this myself during my visit to the Zaatari refugee camp and surrounding area in Jordan in May this year. Provided that the resources are used smartly and efficiently, the EU can have a major impact on the quality of life of the people in those camps with relatively little money.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to express thanks and gratitude to Turkey, to Jordan and to Lebanon, which have received up to now between three and four million of the ten million Syrian refugees – where we, in the EU, in our 28 countries, up to now have received approximately 500 000. We are the richest continent in the world and this is our contribution. In certain Member States, and I will name names – Hungary – the refugees are being met by barbed wire, a fence, they are being shot at, they are being targeted with tear gas. Furthermore, the national legislation today makes sure that Hungarian citizens who show solidarity and humanitarian care by sheltering refugees in their homes run the risk of being put in prison for three years, and their neighbours are now willing to inform on those Hungarian citizens who take their humanitarian responsibility seriously. Is this the Europe we want to see, Mr President? Is this the EU that we want to see? Not since the Second World War have we had such legislation in our Member States and I feel it shameful that this is where we are today. We can do so much more and we can do so much better, and the world is looking at us. When I was in the US last week, Orbán gave a speech pointing out that this is the reality in Europe today. If this is the situation now, then what will the future be? (Applause)

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – How we treat our refugees says something about our standards, our values, our society. I admire those countries that are trying with all their might to offer refugees who appear in large numbers at our borders and appear at their stations a clean, a whole, a safe place to shelter. But I get mad when I see that there are countries that roll out barbed wire, that use tear gas as a means of controlling crowds and who think they can feed people by throwing sandwiches over the fence. In doing so, they are dehumanising these refugees. If we leave that undiscussed, if we leave it unpunished, then we will legitimise it. That's what's happening here right now. All attempts to discuss the situation in Hungary in a more than non-committal way, in order to link consequences to viktor Orban's actions to investigate article 7, are systematically blocked here. Last night by the Social Democrats. Mr President, if we are not honest and civilised with each other, how can we deal with refugees properly? (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. - I have two short questions. One is: do we expect Member States to protect the Schengen border in accordance with European rules? Hungary the case of a member, that is the first question. Second, 300,000 people crossed hungary's border through Serbia and Croatia. These are safe countries. Those who have indeed left their home countries as political refugees are in Serbia, Croatia, a safe country. Why are they going to Germany? That's because they've actually become economic refugees.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – At the moment I am the chief observer for the elections in Tanzania, and I have been told very clearly that observing and monitoring are not the same thing as taking action. What Hungary is doing on the border is not monitoring or observing: it is pushing people back and, in our law, that is forbidden.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, even today we have listened to the logic of the lesser evil, which seems to be the compass of the decisions taken by the European Union.  Great satisfaction with the provisional measures for the relocation of 40 thousand migrants, great satisfaction with the provisional measures for 120 thousand migrants. Well, I would like to point out that the idea of having a pilot project, with a view to amending the Dublin Regulation, has failed to have objective criteria, so that we have a permanent mechanism and do not have to resort each time to procedures and waiting months for the adoption of emergency measures.  The Commission's proposal has been overturned and the Opinion of the European Parliament has been ignored. Migration is a phenomenon and not a problem, the problem is when you do not have immediate solutions. It is a global and complex phenomenon, it is right to tackle reception, but we must move on to the root causes: armed conflicts, the exploitation of human and natural resources.  That is why we have proposed a stop to arms sales, but we know that the interests of the arms industries are very powerful, so Parliament voted by a majority against stopping the sale of arms. We have proposed legal avenues for access to the European Union so that we do not have operations such as Eunavfor Med, Khartoum, Operation Triton, just one, to avoid costing taxpayers and to allow those fleeing war and persecution to arrive safely.  Well, we have finally proposed the change in Dublin, so that we can act ex ante to protect Those Member States that are in difficulty and not ex post, when they are now with water at their throats.

name: Lorenzo Fontana
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that the thing that surprises me the most is that I feel very critical of Hungary and for heaven's sake all opinions are lawless, but it seems to me that we are forgetting a fundamental problem, particularly on Syria, which is the Islamic State, because I would have liked to know what the European strategies are with regard to this situation. , it seems to me that non-European countries are intervening and I hear nothing from the European Union, or little.  It is also because, if we want to do a real service to refugees, to those fleeing war, we must ensure that wars end, and it seems to me that little is being done in this respect. I have heard of fear, I have a fear, in fact, that foreign policy is entrusted to the same people who caused the damage that this whole wave of refugees has created at the moment. We think that someone who caused this damage directly or indirectly has also been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. This scares me a lot and I hope that the European Union will start to become aware that perhaps it should be a little freer.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr President, a year ago, Commissioner Avramopoulos said that the states of Europe would not become castles again and was calling for a possible review of the Schengen and Dublin II treaties.  A year later, he should not be satisfied, proud of the results of his immigration policy. Hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants have flooded Into European countries, hundreds in the Mediterranean are constantly increasing, and jihadists are taking advantage of migration flows to infiltrate Europe. The authorities of the entry country are unable to control the hordes of incoming, let alone offer the right to real refugees, and countries such as Germany, Austria and Slovenia have reintroduced cross-border controls, while others are building fences and using their armed forces in the battle to enforce order and security.  With wishful meals and a great deal of money, the problem is not solved. Europe must realise that it must stand by the countries fighting the Islamic State. It must force Turkey to stop exploiting illegal immigrants - and indeed with funding from the European Union - passing through its territory, and as the first country of entry, Muslim and neighbouring Syria, to undertake the processing of asylum applications, in accordance with international law and UNHCR regulation.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I am pleased that the Member States, together with the Commission, are finally beginning to take concrete steps. What is particularly important to me is that the speeches we are making – one billion in support of the Madad Fund, for the Emergency Fund to increase aid to Turkey – are actually followed by concrete steps, that there is a guarantee that the funds will actually be increased and that corresponding payments will actually be made, because the current deposit stalwarts in the World Food Programme have been shamefully neglected by both the EU and the Member States. Secondly, a very important question is that we also address the causes of the war and that this is not left to someone who has not made a name for himself in ukraine recently for dealing very peacefully with its neighbours. I have just noticed that Mrs Sargentini tried to attack the S&D. It was the PPE and S&D that did not consider the path of the Greens, the GUE and part of ALDE to be sensible towards Hungary, because we have the same steps in the Czech Republic. We have seen similar steps in Slovakia. This means that it is necessary and sensible to do what President Timmermans has said: to take concrete steps specifically with these states in order to deal with refugees differently and to shape border crossings in a more sensible way in accordance with European rights.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, after listening to the Council this morning, I have the feeling that I have attended a calculated exercise in victimhood to justify the closure of external borders, and we are also saving Schengen. And we are also witnessing the increasingly obvious and serious primacy of security over reception and human rights. Some Member States are buying the discourse of fear of the far right and that can create a political and social crisis with very serious consequences in Europe.  A month ago, Mrs Mogherini quantified what we are talking about when we say that a massive migrant and refugee crisis is coming to Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about 0.1% of the population of the European Union. We are not champions because some Member States decide to open the door to 160,000 people and because some Member States are the main donors in Lebanon, Jordan or Turkey. This is what the European Union uses to outsource the crisis. Actually, we're avoiding responsibility. Creating the breeding ground of fear, from hatred to the other, to the different, imposing the primacy of securocracy always ends up undermining civil liberties and human rights.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I was with some colleagues in Lebanon and Jordan this weekend. We have been able to see how enormous the burden these countries are under. Unfortunately, the limit of resilience has already been reached. We also asked ourselves: what happens if all this no longer works? We can already see the causal link with the reduction in aid. In July, the support was reduced from 27 dollars per month to 13.5 dollars. That was one of the reasons for this massive wave of refugees who then came to Europe. I welcome the Council's decision. I'm just afraid it's coming too late. These funds must be made available quickly, these funds really must exist, and, above all, they must be more. Otherwise, we will really have massive problems.

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR).
text: – Mr President, my country, Finland, expects to receive some 50 000 asylum applications this year, which is ten times the usual annual number. These are mostly young men from Iraq and Somalia and sub-Saharan Africa. They are coming because they were told by smugglers that they will get a free apartment, a well-paid job and a good life in Europe. Instead they find themselves in crowded reception centres, barracks or even tents, with nothing to do because there are no apartments and no jobs. The winter is coming and we will have tens of thousands of disappointed and frustrated young men on the streets. It is dangerous and irresponsible to allow this kind of uncontrolled migration to Europe and within Europe. We need better border controls and faster repatriation schemes on a European level.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Mr President, we have all now, for many months, agreed that the challenge for Europe, the challenge for the Member States, is a historic challenge.  Today, the humanitarian crisis continues to spread not only at Europe's external borders, but also at the very heart of Europe and to question us about its causes.  A few days ago, with Marielle de Sarnez, we went on the Balkan route and what we saw was worthy of the darkest images of the mid-twentieth century and the Second World War, namely men, children, women harassed, exhausted, in distress.  They expect Europe, europe and the Member States, in particular, to use what Mr Juncker has said, a response which is first and foremost a response in terms of immediate aid to NGOs and Member States, particularly to the states that are landlocked in the heart of Europe, such as Macedonia and Serbia, and, of course, to the States which are on Europe's external borders. It is also necessary to coordinate the system of hotspots, not only at external borders but also in landlocked Member States, in order to organise the reception and control this reception at the same time as it is up to us to strengthen Europe's external borders.  These elements are part of the emergency room on the eve of winter.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Mr Schmit, Mr Timmermans, this debate is about the humanitarian situation of refugees in the European Union. And about that, we didn't hear anything. We've heard about grocery lists and bills, but we haven't heard about the humanitarian situation of refugees. Where are the records of people being fed in animal pens, of people being numbered at the entrance to European countries, of people being stuck in trains and abandoned in places, who do not even know where they are, of people being housed in former concentration camps? This is the humanitarian situation of many refugees in the European Union.  The treaty you have adopted, your treaty, says that European values are respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Gentlemen, the treaty is not to be applied à la carte. With austerity already tearing up half, with the refugee crisis on the verge of tearing it all away. What are you going to do to Lord Orban, what are you going to do to your friend? Should he abide by the treaty or is it an exception?

name: Tamás Meszerics (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there is much to welcome in the decisions of the informal European Council and the Home Affairs Council. This is indeed the way to go. May I, nevertheless, point out two things? One is that the EU candidate countries of the Western Balkans, on the direct land route of migration could have been – and should have been – invited at least to the informal Council. Politicians, especially from the former Soviet bloc, should have been more keenly aware of the difference between making decisions for someone and with someone. Anyway, history teaches us that messing up the Western Balkans is not necessarily a very good idea. I would also remind our colleagues in the Council that taking a decision by a qualified majority – which I personally welcome – is a courageous step only if they are willing to go the whole way. Unless there is a willingness to go the whole way and have sanctions for non-compliance, this just adds to the political theatre on this question – of which we already have too much.

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by questioning the very title of this debate. The EU is calling the crisis we have in Europe at the moment a refugee crisis, basically to pull on heartstrings and to suit its own political ends. Let me make it clear that the crisis we have in Europe at the moment is not a refugee crisis, it is an economic migrant crisis. (Applause from certain quarters) That is not just my appraisal. It is also that of Robert Fico, the Prime Minister of Slovakia, who has said that 95% of the people who are coming to our continent are not refugees: they are economic migrants. Indeed Eurostat, the EU’s own statistical collecting body, has reported that 85% of the people coming are not from war-torn Syria, but from Pakistan, Albania, Nigeria and the Gambia. So let us, at least, not insult everyone’s intelligence, and let us call this crisis what it is, however politically incorrect you might find that, Mr Timmermans. It is an economic migrant crisis, not a refugee crisis. Mr Timmermans, it is a case of people moving from poor countries to rich countries and in the meantime breaking international law – and you would think we would do something about that, would you not? But, amazingly, we are not doing something about it. Actually we are just encouraging it. Then, of course, there is the security aspect of this total farce. ISIS has already told us that it is going to flood our continent with their Islamist lunatics, so you would think we would be doing something to prevent that. But no, we are doing quite the opposite: we are putting the lives of our own citizens at risk – the lives of people like those here in the gallery. We are putting them at risk by not stopping the boats. The German authorities last week reported that one in three so-called ‘Syrians’ are arriving with fake passports. They are on sale on the Turkish black market for EUR 750. We do not know who these people are! One of the founding principles of the European Union, Mr Timmermans, is freedom of movement of people. What we are probably allowing now is freedom of movement of jihad. I fear that in the future, in the very near future, we will all have blood on our hands as a result. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – On a point of order, Mr President, I assumed that the Members of this Parliament here are all elected, and indeed I am quite right in believing that all Members of this Parliament were elected in last year’s European elections. Mr Timmermans, with respect, you are a member of the Commission; you have no right to interact during a parliamentary debate. (The President cut off the speaker) (Heckling from the floor (Messrs Nutall and Carver): ‘We got elected; you did not’)

name: Presidente. –
text: It is not a point of order, I would ask you to be respectful of the Rules of Procedure. There are rules which all elected representatives must respect, you are an elected representative, you sit in this Parliament, you respect the rules of Parliament.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card question to Paul Nuttall. – The question really is this: I have visited Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq and also Serbia. All I saw was refugees there. I would like to ask Paul Nuttall this question. Three-year-old Aylan, whose body was found: what was he, in your opinion?

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer to Afzal Khan. – He was the son of a family that had been in Turkey – a safe country – for many, many years. In fact, the father was trying to get to Canada to get a new set of teeth! So, look, the big question here is simply this, our continent is being flooded by migrants at the moment, economic migrants, whilst Saudia Arabia, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates are doing absolutely nothing. In fact all they are doing – I will give you an example – is that Saudi Arabia has offered to build 200 Wahhabi mosques in Germany. It is madness. We need to protect our borders and we should look to the Australians for a way of doing things. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is good that, in the end, the European Commission has understood that mandatory quotas for the relocation of refugees are not the only way to solve the problem. It is good that we will finally start effectively reducing the sources and true roots of migration. Community protection of the external borders, including those in Greece, Italy and Malta, is now becoming a sine qua non for dealing with Europe's biggest crisis. The operational activities of hot spots and the actual u-turn of those who are not entitled to asylum are an urgent necessity in this context, but no less important is the perspective of each refugee and his personal safety. Please tell me how, in the countries that will accept refugees as a result of relocation, to keep them safe, if our colleagues on the right are already stoking xenophobic, anti-immigrant and racist sentiments today, if active resistance is already being organised, threats are exaggerated and sharia is being feared? Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking A new migration package is no longer enough. Today, we need to reorganisation the protection of the European Union's external border so that we can restore real and full control over them. There is also a need for a major educational action to convince local communities that ing refugees do not threaten their safety. Rather, it is proof of their sensitivity and humanity towards those who are fleeing war and bombs.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is the first time our Parliament has discussed this issue, on both the internal and external aspects of the refugee crisis together. I think that is a sign of what has been missing so far in our debate, namely a holistic approach, looking at the two things together. I was in Turkey three weeks ago with a delegation from the Committee on Development and we could see that lack of coherence in our policy there. I think you are absolutely right: we have to talk to Turkey, because without Turkey we are not going to get a solution to the problem, and we have to work more with the United Nations agencies. What we saw there was that we – that is the Member States – have cut our budgets to these agencies, and we have to change that. And yes they were refugees, these people in Turkey. We met children who have lost their limbs: they are refugees, no doubt about it. We need more resources for immediate needs, we need money for education for those children. The families are losing hope, they are getting weary: that is why they are coming here. We need education, and I hope people will support the budget amendments we have to increase money for education. We need a legal route to resettlement, directly from the camps to the EU. And, finally, we need more support for NGOs working directly in Syria. They are not getting enough support. They are the only people getting humanitarian aid into parts of Syria and that is very urgent. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Are you really suggesting that we should have a motorway for ISIS right through Europe? Have you no sense at all? This is ridiculous! What is going to happen to Europe? (Heckling) You are going to change the nature of the whole of Europe. It is madness! (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Linda McAvan (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I tell you what I do know: 15 months ago Nigel Farage told the British public he thought more should be done to support Syrian refugees. Now we have a chance to do it and you lot over there are saying there is no such thing as a Syrian refugee. I think you really do not have a policy, and I think this is just a cheap, electorally motivated attempt to get votes, as Mr Timmermans said earlier.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The situation in refugee camps outside the Union is dramatic and it is there that the greatest humanitarian aid should be directed. It's good that we finally understood that. We also need to think about how to combat not the symptoms, but the causes of this tragedy, and this requires a completely different policy: perhaps including military involvement. However, we will certainly not solve the problem by opening up the external borders of the Union to every refugee, an illegal immigrant, and increasing the chaos. Today, even the Germans have understood that their possibilities are limited and their sense of reality is slowly returning.  Nein, wir schaffen nicht alles, und wir werden auch die Welt nicht erlösen. It must also be made clear that the humanitarian solution is not to forcibly relocate refugees in Europe and forcibly keep them in a country to which they did not intend to emigrate and whose society is not prepared to accept them. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for your speech: much of it made good common sense. Would you agree with me that one of the most disgraceful things that has happened during this whole crisis – whether it be a refugee crisis or migrant crisis, whatever you wish to call it – is people using images of suffering people to try and tug at the heart strings of the public in order to change well—set, well—meaning border controls, which we need within the EU and within Member States, and that the people who use these images to try and tug at our heart strings for their own political gains are a disgrace?

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – My answer to your questions would be that we have to consider suffering people, but we also have to have a responsible policy in the east, the far-east and near-east region, and with our neighbourhood, both in the east and in the south. And we have to be responsible in our policymaking, not just making policies based on emotions, even if they are humanitarian emotions.

name: Presidente. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, in view of the serious delay, I would like to tell you that this is the last blue card I give, because we do not have time to prolong the debate. We have been informed that the Chairman of the Delegation of the House of Representatives of the Kingdom of Morocco, Rachid Talbi El Alami, is in the gallery to follow our work. We welcome the delegation from the House of Representatives and hope that the visit will be interesting and fruitful.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the resumption of the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the humanitarian situation of refugees in the EU and neighbouring countries (2015/2877(SDR)).

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to praise the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, here today. It has not, as is often criticised, exacerbated the refugee crisis and invited the whole world to Europe. On the contrary, it has given Europe a human face and made it clear what all those in power should remember: the right to asylum is an essential and fundamental part of the European catalogue of values. Working out a Europe-wide solution and also involving Turkey is another point that is important, right and very worthy of support. I am therefore pleased when we discuss with Chancellor Merkel in this House tomorrow and hear her plans for the next few years. At the same time, I am also pleased that the French President, Francois Hollande, will be with us, but I find his activities less commendable. I was in Calais two weeks ago and I have to say that the conditions there are shameful for an EU Member State. So, before we criticise other countries for their treatment of those seeking protection, we must put our own house in order.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we must stand with states, humanitarian organisations, local authorities, associations, workers' unions, citizens who help and congratulate refugees. The duty of the European Union is to support them and to provide the necessary funds to help these refugees to live, to live, to educate themselves, to train and to access work.  The much-needed sums that need to be made unblock should lead to a review of the budgetary diet policies imposed on states, town halls and associations. More sustained efforts will no doubt have to be made for international protection of these people thrown on the roads by wars, repression and to secure journeys and not to let money-hungry smugglers make money-hungry smugglers who are enriched on the back of misery and despair.  It is also necessary to forcefully re-establish a truth: a Europe of 500 million inhabitants is not invaded by 700,000 refugees, even if we welcome them. Our entire history shows that migration has not been a burden but a source of human, cultural and economic wealth.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am shocked to hear of the repeated malicious, biased and untrue attacks on Hungary. Turning the existing law inside out, when we should finally be focusing on effective support for genuine refugees. To effectively help people living in large refugee camps in the Middle East. They are the real refugees, not the ones who throw concrete pieces at the hungarian green border, or who start an organised siege at Calais. Let us focus on cooperation with third countries where those in need can receive adequate humanitarian assistance without risking their lives. Where it can still be filtered out without loss of life, who can be eligible for refugee status. This would prevent thousands of people from vomiting inhumanely so that when they reach their destination, it is clear that they cannot remain in the Union. We need responsible speech and action, where, in addition to expressing solidarity and humanitarian aid, we are protecting the Union's external borders. Eu rules are enforced by everyone and we say it, we say honestly that we cannot accept everyone. Precisely so that we can help the truly needy, the refugees. And I think everything else is going to be hypocrisy sooner or later.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is about the humanitarian situation of the refugees, and I am starting with the Balkan countries. Have we actually done enough in recent years for the democratic and economic development of this region, or did we not really care? The camps in Lebanon and Jordan, the situation is also intolerable: no education for children, and even the supply of food is inadequate, partly because our Member States have not provided sufficient resources. Syrian refugees in Turkey: they cannot apply for asylum, they are not allowed to work, they do not receive social support. Under such conditions, they cannot remain in this Turkey. That needs to change. And in the European Union? People are forcibly pushed back or even shelled at the borders. The situation in Italy and Greece is intolerable. But let us be honest: for too long too many states have watched and looked away: we are not concerned about this, because those at the external borders should see how they cope. Now we are seeing many purely national responses, and often it is not a question of protecting people, but of the one issue in many variable forms: foreclosure. On all these issues, the European Union as a whole is not overwhelmed. However, the Council seems to have been overwhelmed so far. Overwhelmed by actually finding common European answers. Now it is just before twelve, and we must now activate all resources – financial and organisational, at European level and on the part of the Member States – for registration, reception, distribution, integration, combating the causes of flight and aid to third countries. The refugees, our citizens, Europe finally need a European Council!

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, we have been having this absolutely fruitless conversation in this chamber for a year. We have been telling you for a year that the atrocities of The Islamic State and its similar organizations in the Middle East will lift a wave of people fleeing them. We have been saying for a year that the Republic of Turkey is involved in this war and it is openly involved in bombing the Kurds' positions in northern Iraq. We have been saying for a year that only military intervention on this territory would stop this wave of refugees and immigrants and somehow save the European continent. Unfortunately none of this happened and yes, my country Bulgaria is badly affected by the wave of illegal immigrants.  Why am I saying immigrants? Because there seems to be a misunderstanding in the room about character and origin and the difference between an immigrant and a refugee. The immigrant comes from a safe country, and such is Turkey, and none of this happens and nothing changes. What should happen, of course, are neither quotas nor hotspots, because you can't keep someone somewhere despite their will. I therefore strongly object to all allocation quotas and hotspots. There is one quota and one point and they are Germany where these people want to go.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the refugee crisis has actually shown the weakness of our European policies. Asylum policy is not politics. It's just a protocol that's not followed. The Schengen regime has completely disintegrated at the external borders of the European Union and has been partially suspended at internal borders.  I remember the crisis of the 1990s in the former Yugoslavia when Croatia – a small country with a third of the occupied territory, exposed to aggression – itself solved the problem of 600,000 refugees from its territory from Bosnia and Herzegovina, more than arrived in the European Union as a whole in this period. And it wasn't the European Union that solved the problem of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, but an external power.  It's still a similar situation today. Countries themselves are solving the problems they face, and some external powers are in their own way solving the crisis in accordance with their own interests. And just as the crisis in the former Yugoslavia led to a common European security and defence policy, I expect this crisis to lead to new better common European policies.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the European Union's management of the refugee crisis to date is evasive and hypocritical. The leadership of the European Union is moving mainly towards repression and less towards the logic of solidarity, thus preserving the conditions that have transformed the Mediterranean, the Aegean, into floating cemeteries.
