The European Union has been reduced to a thankless role, haggling over human lives, refusing to deal with an explosive problem with humanitarian dimensions. Mr Vice-President, brave decisions are needed to create open accommodation structures and to assert the right of refugees to reach European destinations safely. Insisting on the implementation of the outdated Dublin system will lead to the further entrapment of hundreds of thousands of refugees, mainly in Greece. What needs to be done today is the abolition of the Dublin regulations and their replacement by a solidarity pact in the management of migration flows, the creation of European Application and Migration Centres near the war zones and the change in the character of FRODEX.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work he Yes, the Member States and the European Union have made major mistakes in recent years. But that does not help us now. Today, we must solve a problem that many of us have not recognised, both in terms of the capacity of the Member States of the European Union and in terms of the right to asylum. The right to asylum is a fundamental right, and there is no limit to the top. Here we have all complied with the Geneva Convention, and it is also stated in most of our constitutions.  At the same time, however, we must ensure that the people who come are treated decently, that procedures are carried out quickly, that people are not only properly cared for, but that it is also made clear that those who do not belong here must also be sent back quickly. That is why I am also grateful to the Commission for pointing out to my country that it is not being expelled quickly enough, so that we have to put things right at this point. But I think the crucial point is that we have to address the causes. The citizens will not accept it if we only talk about the symptoms, where we are now making progress in resolving things – especially through the Commission's action plan, including through yesterday's talks with Turkey. But we must make it clear that the proxy war in Syria and Iraq will not end if we do not finally get the big players around the table, the Americans and the Russians. We now have many countries bombing, but everyone is bombing another in Syria. If we do not get this right and, at the same time, we are not prepared to pursue an inclusive policy at long last, if we do not make a new Policy on Africa, including a new trade policy, and if we also see climate protection and refugees together, if we do not even present this as an overall concept to the European citizen, then these citizens will drive us all off the court. That is why we must go beyond what we are now doing in practice and also make this great deal and communicate this to the public.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the title of the debate, unlike some other colleagues today, and I very much welcome what Ms McAvan said. This is the first time that the external dimension has been brought together with what we are talking about in terms of the political debate on refugees. I very much welcome the point that Mr Timmermans raised, which is that we have to have a sense of urgency. While the media spotlight understandably is on the conflict in Syria, we are entering the winter period and those of us on the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs understand what that means: it means deaths, both in the Mediterranean and on land, in the corridors, and it will mean a crisis.  I put it to the Council that they should really review the civil protection mechanism and that they should regard this as an urgent consideration. And I say to the Commission and to Vice-President Timmermans that we really need to think not just about the politics of the relocation mechanism but also about how we will deal properly with the question of the roadmap towards the hotspots. This will be the test of whether the Commission is doing the right thing, and of whether we are working together on proper solutions that will be visible to our citizens in the European Union.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that we are holding this debate just a few days after the anniversary of a massacre such as lampedusa, and there are at the same time massacres that are not mentioned, such as the one that has returned more than a hundred corpses to the Libyan coast.  The UNHCR calculated that in 2015 alone, 2 860 people lost their lives trying to reach the Italian coast. So, if there is an emergency, I believe that the only emergency we face is to save lives and avoid massacres that are absolutely avoidable and that Europe takes responsibility for not avoiding. 120 000 quotas are only a palliative, just as it is hypocritical to distinguish between refugees, economic migrants and climate migrants. We have a responsibility to tear down the Dublin Wall, we have a responsibility to implement a policy of humanitarian visas and a humanitarian corridor that saves lives and to open a conference on the debt of the Euro-Mediterranean countries.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, people fleeing to Europe should be treated with dignity, by everyone. We have to step up our common humanitarian efforts, supporting Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey better, as well as Serbia and Macedonia. We need to give more funding to international organisations like UNHCR and the World Food Programme, and increase regional support programmes. It is not enough to pledge money: funding has to be disbursed fast and through a simple procedure, and humanitarian support on the spot is not enough. I led the delegation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to Lampedusa and our findings were that the search and rescue operation in the central Mediterranean is proving effective thanks to coordination between the Italian operation Mare Sicuro, Eunavfor Med, Triton and the NGOs. We also found that military means and EU cooperation in humanitarian operations are essential to save lives and to combat smugglers. However, smugglers are changing their modus operandi and we have to change our mandate: to broaden it and also to focus more on the eastern route from Turkey and Egypt to Greece and southern Italy. There are legal ways in: the problem is that the Member States do not implement them. Resettlement is the highway in, and it is time to move from a voluntary resettlement to a binding resettlement system. It is also important that all Member States apply the asylum package, including registration and fingerprinting at the external borders of the European Union. This is essential in order for freedom of movement and Schengen to function.

name: David-Maria Sassoli (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to appeal to the pro-European forces in this Parliament, there is no point in talking to those of us who are not here.  Mr Timmermans, the Council has taken the reasons for the reception, but we must go further and it is our responsibility to show that the Council's conclusions translate into good policy and good practice. There is an urgent need for European civil protection to be able to coordinate national structures, to be able to tell citizens that reception is no different and far from reception. We also need a border service, now, to give security to the European Union area. European civil protection, border service are indispensable instruments and it is urgent that Parliament and the Commission work together immediately and immediately formulate a proposal.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Mr President, first of all, I welcome the allocation of additional funding for new positions within Frontex and Europol, but I draw attention here to the training of staff from agencies and Member States. Two aspects are important. On the one hand, access to education for young refugees because it is an important vehicle for integration and, on the other hand, psychological assistance to victims. They would have to really get away with it.  Secondly, a more open dialogue with neighbouring countries that are likely to take in refugees in good conditions is needed. Saudi Arabia tells us about 130,000 young Syrian students, the United Arab Emirates puts forward the figure of 100,000 Syrians who have obtained a residence permit since 2011. The question is: beyond the numbers and the status of refugees, what are we doing together to respond coherently to this crisis? Finally, the extraordinary efforts of Lebanon and Jordan are to be commended. The difficulties are enormous, but it must be acknowledged that these two countries are holding up. Our European effort towards them must be up to the task and we must also draw conclusions from what today allows these countries to be islands of stability in the Mediterranean region.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, in short: first, to increase the World Food Programme (WFP); second, the rapid implementation of hot spots so that we speed up the process of aid, identification, registration, distribution and, where appropriate, return with dignity; third, Turkey as a key partner — relations must be strengthened in the fight against irregular and clandestine immigration and smugglers, as well as in terms of refugee aid.  What is this help? Aid must be humanitarian, coordinating tasks with UNHCR, Unicef and European and local NGOs; European funds should serve to build the necessary infrastructure; with specialized staff from European agencies; strengthening asylum procedures or identifying and controlling borders; necessary inclusion of refugees through educational, labour and health programmes. In addition, a donor conference is needed. And finally, Mr President, Greece needs special and differentiated assistance.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we are facing a huge humanitarian emergency, as Vice-President Timmermans said. The worst would have been, once again, nothing to do. The Commission has taken the initiative by making good proposals, but the Council, Mr Schmit, when it decides, does so late and little. The Council is not required not to forget that we are not facing a border crisis but refugees, that we do not forget that we must improve our development aid. But it's not throwing money at the problems they solve. That you realise that it is not the refugees who question Schengen, but the reaction and measures of some of the Member States, and that you realize that 120,000 is insufficient to respond to the scale of the problem. Today, Member States are required to respect the law and cooperate. The Commission is required to exercise its powers as guardian of the Treaties and to ensure that Schengen and asylum laws are respected and we must cooperate with neighbouring countries, cooperate with frontline countries, cooperate with the Member States receiving the most asylum applications, cooperate has never been more urgent and necessary than today.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Today I read the surprising statement of the German Minister of the Interior, who said that... Germany is no longer able to accept refugees and will start returning them. When asked where he would return refugees, he said that not to countries where the level of protection of human rights and freedoms is too low – here he meant Hungary and greece – but to those countries where refugees are treated well, and to explicitly mention Slovenia and Croatia. Both countries have very poor absorption capacity. These are small countries. And, of course, if Germany is going to return most of the refugees arriving, most of them a million and a half, these countries will of course not have to accept a few hundred thousand refugees each. That's why I'm asking for a rethink. I believe that Germany also needs to change migration policy, but in an appropriate way.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am glad that we are finally moving from words to action. That is why the Czech Republic is not protesting against the re-vote in the Council, but we want to be in solidarity and solidarity in the financing of humanitarian aid. Over the past two years, the Czech Republic has contributed EUR 3 million to providing humanitarian aid in Syria and the Countries of the Middle East. In this context, I would also like to ask the Commissioner and the Minister why we are not yet counting Egypt, which already has thousands of refugees on its territory, as a safe country. Ladies and gentlemen, I am very glad that the European Parliament will also respond quickly to financial support and I am ready to vote in favour of a budget that will ensure human conditions in refugee camps.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the humanitarian crisis caused by immigration, the measures envisaged are a step forward, but they are certainly not enough.  I would like to inform you of a subject about which little is said. Children, children, over one hundred thousand, many of them unaccompanied, arrived in the first six months of the year, almost twice as many as last year. More needs to be done for them. Asylum procedures must be speeded up, ensuring that priority is always given to the best interests of the child, as the Court of Justice has made clear, and under the new relocation mechanisms, the obligation of all European states to accept and assist unaccompanied minors, who are in fact on their territory, regardless of the country of first landing or previous asylum applications in other countries, must be respected. Reuniting with families or other relatives must be a priority and we need systems to monitor the movements of unaccompanied minors, not least in order to avoid the risk of them ending up in the hands of criminal organisations not only before, but also after arrival in Europe.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the situation of the thousands of refugees flooding Greece and the rest of Europe is desperate. The refugee waves are increasing and the misery will grow as the war in Syria continues, as long as the European Union tolerates and lets ISIS continue its criminal work.  The humanitarian crisis, however, is not only affecting refugees. It also affects the Greek people who, having been impoverished by the memoranda and the troika, can no longer accommodate other refugees. The troika, however, continues to de impoverished the Greek people with the third memorandum and, while the Greek people who are receiving the huge refugee waves had to be relieved, when the memorandum had to be abolished and the shameful debt written off, you gentlemen of the troika and the Commission continue to press, together with the Eurogroup, Greece, to implement the third memorandum and turn Greece into a social cemetery.  This must stop immediately.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, it is certain that the last session of the European Council has taken a major step forward. It is certain that the Commission's position all this time during the refugee crisis is a great position by which it really wants to resolve this very difficult situation. However, what we cannot escape is that we have welcomed this situation completely unprepared. Both the Commission, both member states and the entire European Union... we welcomed this situation completely unprepared and unfortunately saw great differences between us.  What I want to point out in particular is that the European Union needs to take a much stronger role in the world in addressing the overallness of this situation. I would also like to point out that non-member countries in the Western Balkans such as e.g. Serbia and FYROM (Macedonia) have done more than some member states. And I want to stress that turkey and Lebanon and Jordan do the right thing. Indeed, the European Union and member states need to think hard about their position in the coming months, as this crisis is sure to persist.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the problem of refugees and immigration is inadequate and uneven as far as the Member States are concerned.  Of the 2.4 billion euros approved by the European Commission in the relevant programmes in recent weeks, only 470 million have been approved for Greece. This figure, although it seems large in absolute number, is only a fifth of the total, at a time when Greece, from the beginning of 2015 to mid-September, has accepted some 310,000 registered people out of a total of around 430,000 for the whole Union. In other words, Greece receives two thirds of all refugee and migration flows and on the other hand gets only a fifth of the funds for this purpose. These proportions need to change.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this migration crisis has become the biggest political issue of recent times. Accordingly, we must clarify all the factors to ensure that the best solution is found for both EU citizens and the migrants themselves. The problem is further compounded by ambiguous claims made by Saudi Arabian officials at last week’s Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) meeting, when they suggested that Saudi Arabia is taking in 2.5 million refugees. Matters are not helped by the fact that Saudi Arabia has not signed the 1951 UN Convention on Refugees. According to my maths, this claim does not add up. Bearing in mind the number of people already in both Syria and UNHCR registered camps, my estimates show an unaccounted figure of around 1 to 1.5 million people, many of whom will, of course, already be in further transit to Europe. The Gulf States must rise to the challenge and work with the rest of the world towards a favourable and lasting result. It is therefore essential that all UN members sign up to the 1951 Convention so that we can properly assess the situation.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Up to 1.5 million migrants are said to have arrived in Germany this year, and there is no end in sight to the refugee tsunami. No wonder Europe's so-called representatives of the people, from Juncker to Timmermans, from Merkel to Faymann, are obviously inviting and cheering on it. What is clear is that this immigration will lead to a cost explosion in the billions, because open borders mean costs for those who come. But that also means less money for Europe's poor and less money for Europe's social problems, which we have after all. I guarantee you one thing: the lowering of social standards will also jeopardise social peace in the rich countries of Europe. I would also like to accuse you of reprehensibly ignoring the concerns of Europeans about the progressive Islamisation, about parallel Islamic worlds and also about the threat posed by IS terrorists.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Viktor Orban and the Hungarian government can be loved or not loved, but one thing is for sure, they express the opinion of the majority of the Hungarian people on the issue of mass illegal migration, both in words and with their actions. More importantly, the majority of Europeans also express their views by wanting to defend their country and also to defend Europe. Perhaps our liberal friends remember that this used to be what they called "democracy." When decision-makers were not pushing the ideas of a narrow elite and the media that most people thought were bizarre, they were telling people their opinions. And there was a term for "freedom of expression." Our Western friends take it for granted that mass illegal migration should only be talked about in the kitchen and in private. It's over now.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have just a few points in reaction to what was said. First of all, let me be very clear that we are faced with a huge crisis. It is also clear that Europe cannot – cannot – accommodate all the refugees in the world. Let us be very clear about that. (The President cut off the speaker to address an interruption from the floor)

name: Presidente. –
text: I will explain to you what happened. The Rules of Procedure provide for five catch-the-eye speeches, I have given more, one per group, your group has had a speech and I am sorry, we are already very late, so I cannot give the floor.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Secondly, the humanitarian situation warrants action at all levels – by Member States, by the European Union, inside Member States, inside the European Union and outside of the European Union. I want to thank this Parliament for its leadership in this issue and for its strong support for the Commission’s position. This is the way forward. If we do what we have now agreed, and we do it swiftly, we will come to terms with this issue and we will show the European population that we can handle this and that Europe is capable of handling this. My third point, in reaction to some of the remarks that were made, is that if you do not want to help refugees, if you do not want to do anything else but push them back at the borders, please say so and do not try to justify it by pretending that the people arriving in Europe are not refugees. That is a lie. (Applause) At least have the integrity to say that you just do not want to help people. Do not say that these people are not refugees. Eighty percent of the people arriving today in Greece can be classified as refugees. That is the reality today. (Heckling) Of course the refugee crisis comes with problems. Nobody denies these problems. These problems will have to be tackled. We have to improve our external border control. We have to be much faster at fingerprinting and swiftly identifying people when they arrive to make sure the people who have the right to asylum are selected. Those who do not have the right to asylum should be returned to where they came from. We need to do all this swiftly and we will be implementing this in the next couple of weeks. Just shouting from the sidelines, saying that it is all bad and people should simply disappear from our radar screens, is not going to provide any solution to this problem.  (Applause) My final remark is this: a number of comments were made about the situation in Hungary. I would like to announce to you that this morning the Commission sent an administrative letter to the Hungarian authorities demanding clarification on a number of issues pertaining to the way they have handled asylum and immigration policies and border control. We will await the reply to that and then we will have a dialogue with the Hungarian authorities on the basis of that reply.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, war refugees do not choose to leave their homes, they simply have no other choice. Now, in the case of our humanitarian aid, we are helping displaced people as close as possible to their places of origin and, when they have to flee to neighbouring countries, that is where we need to help them first. Even if humanitarian aid is not always enough, we must avoid, as far as possible, that these desperate people begin the dangerous journey to Europe, which has already claimed far too many victims. I would like to ask a question.  When questioned, a father said: why did I take all the risks to go to Europe? But simply because my children, for 2 years, did not know of a school. I ask all those who are in a logic of denial of facts, as the Vice-President of the Commission has just said: would they have waited two years to get started?  This humanitarian crisis, in fact, as many have pointed out, challenges the very values of our union, values to which we are deeply attached.  The Council will continue to cooperate in this area with the European Parliament in order to find the necessary measures to deal with this crisis. The European Union's action must be strong, effective, comprehensive and up to the challenge we face. Europe is able to control this situation, it will succeed, provided it is united.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – The so-called "refugee crisis" we have been witnessing in recent months highlights the need for a comprehensive and European response to the migration challenge. This response requires the articulation of short-, medium- and long-term measures. The humanitarian dimension of the refugee crisis requires first-rate action. The volume of refugees who are on the doorstep of Europe or who travel the main transit routes, especially that of the Western Balkans, are frequently abused by mafias exploiting their state of need but also by public authorities, including police abuses. Both UNHCR and humanitarian organizations operating on the ground have denounced not only these abuses but also a progressive precariousness of refugee conditions with limited access to basic necessities. The EU must immediately take measures to help resolve the humanitarian emergency including the creation of "humanitarian corridors". These measures should be operational as soon as possible.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider it extremely important that the candidate countries of the Western Balkans, and in particular Serbia, be given priority in the process of finding solutions to the EU institutions on migrant issues. When we take into account the fact that most of the refugees on land arrive in the EU via this so-called Balkan route and the approaching cold weather, two things become apparent: the need for the Commission to treat Serbia and the other candidate countries in the Western Balkans as serious partners. If possible, treat this matter as is customary in the Member States. After all, Serbia is an island between EU Member States and therefore it is not possible to bypass it in the search for European solutions. In close connection with this, I think it is right to expect the European Commission to show maximum efficiency and speed in the process of providing financial assistance to Serbia and the other Western Balkan countries.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The current humanitarian crisis shows that it is of vital importance to engage in responsible politics. I agree that this crisis is very much concerned with responsibility. We must come up with European solutions to European problems. The solution needs to be that of an improved Europe. In a modern Europe, we need modern conventions, unlike Dublin. Solutions take into account both solidarity and responsibility, which should be fundamentally intertwined values. Both of these values are imperative for the existence of the European Union, for the Member States and for their citizens.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – The current humanitarian crisis is unprecedented; the numbers of refugees is increasing daily and is unparalleled in recent times. The complexity of the issue unfortunately gives little hope that the situation will improve in the near future. The Russian intervention is likely to make the issue prolonged and worse in Syria. We have to redouble our efforts to deal with the root causes.  Recently, I visited refugee camps in Serbia, Jordan, Lebanon and Iraq. People are desperate to get to Europe. During the summer months the influx has surged and new migration routes have emerged, creating even bigger challenges for Europe.  For the security of our citizens, as well as incoming refugees, the proper management and control of our external borders is paramount. The burden of this crisis must be shared. Europe must stand together in solidarity and unity committed to its values. I welcome the EU plans to assist the affected countries and also plans to assist the overstretched and underfunded UNHCR and the World Food Programme agencies. These new incentives will not end the crisis, but they are all necessary steps in the right direction.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, as the European Union lumps into finding a solution, thousands of blames continue to suffer.  Each time we repeat that we need to show solidarity, but each time we demonstrate how far we are from speaking in one voice. Building walls within the EU are xenophobic measures that run counter to EU values and policies. At a time when a record number of people are leaving their homes for war and oppression, it is unacceptable for full MEMBERS of the EU to want to isolate themselves from the problem.  We are facing an unprecedented refugee wave, and the faster we understand that there is no national solution to this complex problem, but only a common approach, the faster we will help the thousands of sufferers. This is not only a European but also a regional and global crisis, and this requires us to include in the resolution all the countries neighbouring the EU that bear much of the brunt of the refugee wave.  In this regard, I welcome the decision to re-establish 160 000 refugees within the EU, as well as the decisions to set up hotspots and help 2 million refugees in Turkey. But that's not enough. The EU needs to draw up a common position and actively participate in resolving the conflicts in the region that are the main cause of the refugee wave.

name: Marju Lauristin (S&D)
text: Writing. – In solving the refugee crisis, we must not hide our heads in the sand. The european Union's capacity to act must increase and each Member State must contribute much more to this. Of course, the strengthening of the European Union's external borders is welcome in order to better select the refugees from war refugees, but we must ensure the safe entry of the first ones into the EU and, to that end, strengthen cooperation with third countries such as Jordan, Lebanon and Turkey. We must move forward with practical steps, such as supporting language learning and integrating refugees into European society, and find sufficient resources to do so in the European Social Fund.

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: in writing. – The flow of refugees and migrants has reached an unprecedented scale. This international crisis needs an international response. In order to cope with the current situation, the European Union needs to support Syria and its direct neighbours as well as the Western Balkans.  I welcome that already EUR 4 billion in EU and Member States funding have been spent to help Syria and its neighbours. Turkey is one of the key countries in the region. The European Union’s support for Turkey, a country that has already received 2 million refugees, needs to be stepped up.  Most refugees enter the European Union via the Western Balkan route. Therefore, countries like Serbia are not part of the problem, but part of the solution. Commissioner Johannes Hahn is right when he states that the Western Balkans must ‘not become a parking lot’ for stranded refugees.  I welcome that the European Commission has increased the migration-related assistance for Serbia and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Stability in the Western Balkans is a prerequisite for dealing with the flow of refugees and can just be safeguarded by a clear European perspective for all the countries in the region.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – On the refugee issue, the solution can only be a stronger Europe. We can clearly see that no Member State can cope with today's refugee crisis on its own. Only joining forces can help. The court case on quotas is an example of counterproductive from the point of view of my country, Slovakia, and an irresponsible waste of time on the side of solving the refugee issue. We need immediate concrete action, not a continuation of the embarrassing and unhelpful charade so far. In my opinion, the common foreign policy, common border protection and the setting up of a common army are inevitable and absolute priorities. Member States should stop blaming each other and the Union's alibi. We must move immediately towards closer cooperation, a stronger Europe. This is our only hope that the situation will not destroy our achievements so far.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – The situation with refugees deteriorates by the day and this requires us to react promptly and quickly. We cannot observe what is happening while thousands of people risk their lives, leave their homes to save themselves from war.  We are currently facing a humanitarian crisis the size of which requires an adequate and timely European solution. We must show solidarity and take our share of responsibility for solving this problem. The refugee crisis has another aspect that we must not ignore – people's fears and concerns. Yes, we must show solidarity and be sympathetic to the fate of refugees, but at the same time we must give an adequate response to these fears without falling into the trap of populism. I believe that Europe will only be able to manage the migration crisis if it is united. Instead of erecting walls and closing borders, let's look for a pan-European solution to the problem and stop blaming each other.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – The mass arrival of refugees is one of the biggest challenges facing the Union since its insttremity. How we deal with this crisis determines how europe is seen in the world and how our own citizens see us. Our task is to find a humane and rational solution, a new balance between the requirements of international law and security needs, while protecting and strengthening the core values of our Union. Recent times have shown that shut-in nationalist solutions are going nowhere. Barbed wire, walls, water cannon, tear gas, rubber bullets, violence, disenfranchiseation do not stop the escapees, they only cause immeasurable suffering and take away the remnants of the human dignity of those displaced. While many citizens, communities and cities in Europe have shown their generosity and humanity in recent times, an organised, institutional response is often weak and uncertain.  Over the past week, Europe's leaders have taken a brave decision to brush aside the resistance of nationalists playing the petty political game and move forward towards a stronger common European policy. However, this is not enough. We need to mobilise Europe's resources to help and integrate refugees and to allocate these resources to those where they, cities and NGOs and communities are genuinely supported.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – The situation of refugees in the EU is as difficult as the situation of the population at the minimum subsistence limit in the eastern union countries, but which, unlike refugees, Union laws do not put in a position to seek humanitarian aid. As the ranks of refugees grow and move to Europe, it does not seem to me that the European institutions are really trying to get involved in ending the state of war in Syria and stabilising the situation. As long as political instability and the state of conflict continue in Syria, the situation of refugees, as well as states that cannot afford their management, will become increasingly desperate. It is absolutely necessary to create an appropriate structure for refugees who are already on European territory and who will face the winter season. The current situation is more than desperate, it is a humanitarian crisis that will deepen the crisis already existing in the countries of south-eastern Europe, which were trying to find a functional balance within the EU. Mandatory refugee quotas will only incite poor European populations into violence: it will be a battle between the poor Europeans in the eastern European Union and the poor refugees in Syria.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The tragedy and criticality of the situation forbid any waste of time for profound political analyses and technical approaches. Greece, which is experiencing the greatest extent of the economic crisis, continues almost alone to welcome thousands of persecuted refugees every day. And despite the acute economic and social problems facing hosts without pre-selections, quotas, or sorting, without any exception and no separation. That's the reality. But in fact, all these thousands, millions of impoverished refugees come and wait, here outside the European Parliament. They expect by claiming the minimum: to survive the havoc that with clear responsibility also prevails in the EU at home. And those responsible are talking, safe and distant, how many of them will put the mark on their hand that will lead them to death. And because they refer to numbers instead of people they think it's not their finger that will show the one who won't live. And they want us accomplices. Discussions and decisions on quotas, whether accepted or not, legal or illegal, refugees, 'safe' or not of origin – if possible!!! - they mean very simply, death for a few thousand people. At the same time, however, they also mean definitive death for the already despised fundamental human values that we say we defend as Europe. The responsibility is now personal and it concerns each of us.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The situation is dramatic and has been going on for months without the EU being able to respond consistently with the values it claims. The refugee crisis is the most eloquent proof of the complete hypocrisy of this EU which speaks so much about democracy and human rights but is unable to respond to the problems it itself has created by fomenting chaos and war in Libya, Syria and Iraq. The aid announced in this extraordinary council is welcome but still very scarce, especially in the face of the EUR 40 billion in arms that is sold to the middle eastern countries. On the other hand, background solutions on humanitarian corridors, the revision of the Dublin agreements, or the resolution of conflicts that continue to ignite North Africa and the Middle East continue to be postponed.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider this debate on the humanitarian side of the migration crisis to be very important. The European Union is more frequently criticised than praised in the context of the refugee crisis. I would therefore like to stress that it is precisely on the issue of humanitarian aid to refugees that the EU and its citizens are making every effort and its results are visible. From my point of view, however, this assistance needs to be better organised and streamlined so that it is not only targeted at a proportion of refugees, but includes all those located in the EU and at its borders.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE).
text: Madam President, I am indeed asking for the floor because, on the night of Saturday to Sunday, the south of France, and in particular the Alpes-Maritimes, was devastated by a deluge.  Beyond the immensity of the property damage, more than twenty people have died, some of whom are still missing. I would have liked us to mark a minute's silence in solidarity.  Nevertheless, given that President Hollande will be here tomorrow, I would have liked Parliament, together with our eminent colleagues, to demonstrate to France and to the countries that were affected, during his visit tomorrow, this gesture of sympathy and friendship towards our fellow citizens who have died, who have left.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think there is a problem with the voting lists. Concerning the Geier report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the Committee on Budgets has decided to give the report to a Member who is from the same constituency as the company that is affected. I think this is very problematic. Earlier there were clear rules against this, but today maybe there are not. I think, however, that this is not an appropriate way to handle things. I suggest that the point is removed from the agenda, or at least that, after this sitting, the President engages in discussion with the Committee Chairs with a view to discontinuing such a practice in the future because inevitably it leads to a discussion on conflict of interests. It is not good.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is to say that there is no incompatibility in this vote. There is no illegality. And in a while, we would be saying that when there was a matter for a country that concerns us, we could not vote on it. So it is absolutely legal, it is even a way of bringing Members closer to reality and voters, and this situation happened without any drama, without any problem, without any illegality.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I wanted to thank all the colleagues who contributed to the adoption of this report for the excellent work that has been done and the excellent climate that has prevailed over the past weeks and months. I hope that the European Commission will follow the conclusions of this report and this House very quickly by presenting, in its internal market strategy, a legislative proposal, as we invite.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the UK Government intends to ratify this convention anyway and therefore feels there is no need for EU supervision or authority over this ratification process. Therefore we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ILO estimates that in the EU 880,000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies. In this direction, I voted in favour of the report because it facilitates the fight against trafficking and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was a single-vote consent report in which Parliament gave its consent for Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention against forced labour.  The Protocol is positive and necessary and outlines strong steps that need to be taken in order to combat human trafficking and forced labour, and it is a response to the fact that while most Member States have ratified the Convention, forced labour still exists across the EU. The Protocol specifically addresses the gaps in cooperation by crime agencies in combating cross-border human trafficking. As some aspects of the Protocol fall under EU competence, Parliament is required to authorise Member States to ratify it and the report urges them to do so by the end of 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Among the eight major conventions of the International Labour Organization is the Convention on Forced Labour, signed in 1930. Last year, the International Labour Conference amended this text to adapt it to the current situation and to strengthen certain mechanisms aimed at preventing human trafficking.  As a result of these changes, a Memorandum of Understanding was adopted by the Conference's stakeholders. The European Parliament has been seized on this text in order to allow The Member States to ratify this agreement. As a text that better fights against forced labour, I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote presents the usual dilemma for UKIP MEPs: on the one hand, we support the principle of international cooperation in pursuit of laudable goals such as the prevention of forced labour. On the other hand, we believe that there are two appropriate vehicles for such cooperation i.e. the United Nations and bilateral agreements between governments. Such bilateral agreements work well. Indeed, their first known usage for extradition dates back to the 13th century BC. The European Union has at best a questionable track record at achieving its stated aims in this regard. For that reason, I considered it appropriate to abstain overall.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because this protocol sets out the measures that ILO Member States must take to prevent forced labour: educating and informing people to ensure that relevant legislation on the prevention of forced labour applies to all workers and all sectors of the economy; protect individuals, especially migrant workers, from possible abusive or fraudulent practices during the recruitment and placement process, and combat the root causes that increase the risk of forced labour.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ratify the ILO Protocol. The ILO Convention lays down basic international labour standards, prohibits and criminalises forced labour. The proposed Protocol aims to address shortcomings in the implementation of the Convention and to combat more effectively trafficking in human beings that are to be exploited at work, as well as to better protect victims of forced labour and compensate them for the damage they suffer. The Protocol also stipulates that forced labour victims must take effective measures to identify, release, protect, rest and rehabilitation, as well as other assistance and support. In addition, TKO Member States must ensure that all victims have access to remedies.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of ratifying the International Labour Organization Convention on Forced Labour: in an age of savage globalisation, as the Commission pushes Member States to deregulate the labour market, it is a matter of protecting victims and punishing perpetrators.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Convention on the Abolition of Forced Labour is one of eight basic ILO conventions that define the basic norms of international labour and is seen as an instrument for the protection of human rights. However, 80 years after its adoption, the ILO estimates that there are at least 20.9 million victims of forced labour worldwide.  The aim of this protocol is therefore to address shortcomings in the implementation of legislation and to strengthen measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the exploitation of their work and to protect and compensate victims of forced labour.  In particular, the protocol calls on ILO Member States to develop a national policy and a national action plan to effectively and sustainably abolish forced labour after consultation with workers' and employers' organisations. It also provides protection and assistance to victims of forced labour. The Council's decision will allow MS to ratify parts of the protocol that fall within the Union's jurisdiction.  I can, of course, only support this report, which the Civil Liberties Commission unanimously approved.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council Decision because eighty-six years after the adoption of the Convention specifying that forced labour is prohibited and criminalized, there are 20.9 million people who still suffer from it. This is a systematic violation of human rights that must be avoided. This Protocol can help by laying down requirements for Member States to adopt national plans to eliminate this scourge and, most interestingly, the obligation to protect victims including persons falling into trafficking networks. The adoption of this Protocol and its measures will improve the fundamental rights of individuals and give us more democratic legitimacy.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to allow EU Member States to ratify the protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, because 80 years later there are still cases of forced labour, which is strictly unacceptable. The convention, which is one of the ILO's eight basic conventions defining basic labour standards, has been the subject of a protocol to address gaps in its implementation and also addresses human trafficking.  Thus, the provisions of the protocol establish the obligation to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation. Specifically, the protocol aims, on the one hand, to establish decent working conditions and, on the other hand, to protect victims of forced or compulsory labour and to punish the perpetrators of offences. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this protocol which aims to fill the gaps in the implementation of the Convention on Forced Labour.  I believe it is essential to fill the current regulatory gaps in favour of more effective protection for victims of forced labour and the prevention of phenomena such as trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour is one of the eight fundamental ILO Conventions. However, more than 80 years after its adoption, it is estimated that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The Protocol aims to address existing gaps and make progress in preventing trafficking for labour exploitation purposes, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. It also sets out the measures to be taken by ILO Member States to prevent forced labour: education and information; protection of persons, in particular migrant workers, against possible abusive and fraudulent practices in the recruitment and placement process; and actions to address the root causes that increase the risk of forced labour. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. It is very regrettable that millions of people are still subjected to this type of work around the world today. That is why I voted in favour of granting your approval.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation, in which we support the proposal that the Council Decision empowers Member States to ratify the provisions of the Protocol falling within the eu's competence in the interests of the European Union, and are recommended to do so by the end of 2016. The 2014 Protocol concerns fundamental rights, victims of trafficking in human beings, victims of a crime that affects not only individuals but also society and the economy as a whole, and the fight against this trade. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in guaranteeing the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. The Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour came into force almost a hundred years ago, unfortunately millions more people around the world are suffering from forced labour.  The Protocol instructs The International Labour Organisation (ILO) Member States to develop, in consultation with employers' and workers' organisations, national policies and action plans to effectively and sustainably eliminate forced labour. The Protocol also sets out the measures by which ILO Member States must prevent forced labour by educating and informing people in order to ensure that forced labour prevention legislation applies to all workers in all sectors of the economy, protecting people from possible abuse and fraud in recruitment and employment, and addressing the risks of forced labour growth.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. Forced labour violates human rights and the human dignity of millions of men, women, young girls and boys. The fight against this most violent form of exploitation has played an essential role in many major political and philosophical movements for emancipation. The struggle for emancipation, which was intended to liberate man from political and cultural domination and physical dependencies, has always been an attack on slave labour, which has prevented other entitlements from being enforced. Nevertheless, forced labour in the 21st century still affects 21 million people who are victims of exploitation that generates $150 billion a year in income for the organizers and organizers of this violation. The 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 updates the Convention by providing it with new instruments and binding legal force to combat forced labour. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the support of the EU Council decision, we have today ensured that the states signatory to the ILO Basic Convention, on which international labour standards are also based and is considered a human rights instrument, will have to formulate a national policy and action plan for the permanent abolition of forced labour. I hope that, as soon as possible, all members will ratify this document and bring it into their legislation, facilitating the fight against traffickers, guaranteeing the rights of victims of crime, as well as introducing awareness-raising and education procedures to prevent forced labour. However, the victims will also be better taken care of, so all my support for this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support any report that addresses the issue of improving worker protection and tackling forced labour.  The mere fact that the Report was adopted by unanimous decision of the members present speaks volumes about the importance of this issue and the need to improve the protection of workers.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2014, the International Labour Conference adopted the protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour. The aim of this protocol is to establish decent working conditions and to protect victims of forced or compulsory labour and to punish perpetrators. Of course, I voted for this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was a single-vote consent report in which Parliament gave its consent for Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention against forced labour.  The Protocol is positive and necessary and outlines strong steps that need to be taken in order to combat human trafficking and forced labour, and it is a response to the fact that while most Member States have ratified the Convention, forced labour still exists across the EU. The Protocol specifically addresses the gaps in cooperation by crime agencies in combating cross-border human trafficking. As some aspects of the Protocol fall under EU competence, Parliament is required to authorise Member States to ratify it and the report urges them to do so by the end of 2016.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation because I consider it important that Member States be allowed to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention. The ratification of this protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking and guarantees the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. The original Convention on Forced Labour entered into force almost a century ago; It is therefore regrettable that millions of people around the world are still subject to forced labour.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Forced labour is a crime unfortunately still present nowadays, with tens of thousands of people being victims of human traffickers every year. The Ilo (International Labour Organization) has estimated that about 21 million people worked in slavery in 2014. Although the International Convention against Forced Labour was signed in 1930, action against traffickers is still incomplete and patchy, with particular shortcomings in the cooperation of criminal proceedings between states. We need effective measures for the identification, release, protection, recovery and assistance of victims of forced labour. ILO member states are required to ensure that all victims have access to redress (such as compensation) and that the competent authorities are allowed not to prosecute victims for illegal activities they have been forced to carry out against their will. The European Parliament must therefore ratify the 2014 Protocol on the protection of victims of trafficking as soon as possible, and must also recommend that the Member States ratify it as soon as possible in order to finally put an end to a phenomenon that is, in fact, a disgrace to humanity.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. More than 80 years after the adoption of the Convention on Forced Labour, the International Labour Organization notes that it continues to prosper. 20 million people worldwide are believed to be victims. This protocol strengthens preventive measures to combat forced labour in a sustainable way and aims to protect the victims of forced labour. The proposed Draft Council Decision allows Member States to ratify parts of the protocol that fall within the competence of the European Union.   We have always opposed forced labour and human trafficking as a new form of modern slavery. It would also be interesting to see unconditional human rights defenders outraged at working conditions in Qatar and Saudi Arabia, where the rules of this convention are violated. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the adoption of the Convention in 1930, the International Labour Conference has called on Member States to eliminate the use of forced labour as soon as possible and to criminalise any such act. However, after more than 80 years, the International Labour Organisation (ICO) estimates that at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour worldwide. This protocol aims to address all implementation gaps and to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation, as well as issues related to the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In this context, the Member States of the IPO must develop a well-defined policy and action plan at national level and take measures to apply the provisions of the Protocol.  I voted in favour of the Council's proposal for ratification of the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation, as it concerns fundamental rights, victims and the fight against trafficking and is an important step in guaranteeing the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, the Forced Labour Convention is one of the eight key ILO conventions (they constitute the basic international labour standards). It basically regulates the basis for human rights. This protocol aims to fill the gaps in implementation and make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the eight fundamental conventions of the ILO, which defines fundamental international labour standards, is the Labour Convention, adopted in 1930 and regarded as an instrument for the protection of human rights. The ICO estimates that around 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. I support the ratification in the EU interest by the Member States of the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Labour Convention of 1930. I consider it a priority to address implementation failures, as well as to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation, as well as in protecting and indemnification of victims of forced labour.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the text to authorise Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which strengthens the prevention of trafficking in human beings for exploitation purposes and guarantees the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. Among the most important forecasts is the obligation for States to draw up a national action plan to effectively combat forced labour, taking measures to ensure that legislation on the prevention of forced labour applies to all workers and to all areas of the economy. In particular, the rules aim to protect people, especially migrant workers, from potentially abusive and fraudulent recruitment and placement practices, thus addressing the root causes of the risks of forced labour. This protocol therefore seeks to safeguard fundamental rights and strengthen the fight against trafficking in human beings. Its ratification is a major step forward in the fight against criminal organisations throughout Europe, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was a single-vote consent report in which Parliament gave its consent for Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention against forced labour.  The Protocol is positive and necessary and outlines strong steps that need to be taken in order to combat human trafficking and forced labour, and it is a response to the fact that while most Member States have ratified the Convention, forced labour still exists across the EU. The Protocol specifically addresses the gaps in cooperation by crime agencies in combating cross-border human trafficking. As some aspects of the Protocol fall under EU competence, Parliament is required to authorise Member States to ratify it and the report urges them to do so by the end of 2016.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the UK Government intends to ratify this convention anyway and therefore feels there is no need for EU supervision or authority over this ratification process. Therefore I abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation because closer cooperation between the Member States, judicial institutions and non-governmental organisations will allow for a more effective fight against forced labour and will ease implementation of the resolutions which have been adopted so far. The Protocol of 2014 also aims to educate people on the issue, which will further lead to the prevention of abuses on the labour market and to assistance being provided to the victims of such abuse.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was a question of voting in favour of the decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour, and, in particular, the reference is to certain specific articles concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Authorisation by the Eu ropean Union is required because there are EU competences in this area, and states cannot therefore decide to join without prior authorisation. I was therefore happy to make my contribution in order to strengthen the fight against forced labour and to help its victims.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight basic conventions of the International Labour Organization, which define the fundamental standards of international labour. However, despite the almost universal ratification of this convention, forced labour continues to exist to this day. In 2014, the International Labour Conference adopted the Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour with the aim of filling gaps in implementation and strengthening measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting their work, as well as the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. The proposed decision is intended to allow Member States to ratify the Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organization.  The provisions of the protocol establish the obligation to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation. So I voted for this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation for Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention. The Convention was initially adopted in 1930. However, the International Labour Organization (ILO) estimates that at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour around the world. Almost a century on, forced labour has not been eradicated.  The Protocol of 2014, as an update to the 1930 text, focuses on policies at national level to eradicate forced labour through education and access to information. It also tries to address the root causes of workers’ vulnerability to forced or compulsory labour. It is an important tool for the defence of human rights as it seeks to tackle modern-day issues as well as protecting the victims of forced labour. Member States now need to ratify the Protocol by the end of next year.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Protocol concerns fundamental rights, victims and the fight against trafficking in human beings, which is a criminal offence affecting not only individuals, but also society and the economy as a whole. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in the protection of the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. The ratification of the protocol by the Member States will make it easier to prosecute human traffickers.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising EU Member States to ratify the International Labour Organisation's Convention on Forced Labour on Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters.  To date, around 21 million people worldwide are estimated to be victims of forced labour. It is therefore necessary for the ILO member states to work to eliminate forced labour, to provide adequate assistance to the victims and to combat traffickers. Parliament welcomed the Council's decision to ratify the Protocol and called on the Member States to ratify it as soon as possible.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Helga Stevens' motion for a resolution, which set out a report highlighting the need for decisive action to protect those affected by forced labour. Despite the fact that the 1930 Convention called on the acceding states to prosecute those who exploited workers, today, more than 80 years later, according to ILO estimates, at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. I think it is absolutely necessary to limit the social scourge of exploitation in the workplace completely. In order to do this, I think it is necessary to take into account and support the rapporteur's proposal, which, through the protocol, aims, in fact, to fill the gaps in the implementation of the 1930 Convention and to make more effective the prevention of trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour, including by obliging the STATES participating in the ILO to draw up a national policy for the total elimination of exploitation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the UK Government intends to ratify this convention anyway and therefore feels there is no need for EU supervision or authority over this ratification process. Therefore we abstained.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour which is one of the eight Conventions of the International Labour Organization which form the core of international law instruments on working conditions.  This Protocol in particular aims to address the problems, failures and difficulties of progress in preventing trafficking in persons for labour exploitation, as well as the protection and compensation of victims of this scourge. As this is an issue in which Member States and the Union share competences, the European Parliament also needs to give its assent to Member States to ratify the Protocol on behalf of the Union.   That's what you do today with my support.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 protocol to the ILO Convention is an essential tool for ising the problem of labour exploitation. The aim of the protocol is to fill existing gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make more effective measures to prevent trafficking in human beings and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the Member States, by ratifying the protocol, can really contribute to reducing the crimes of trafficking in human beings and exploitation in Europe, which have negative repercussions not only for individuals but also for society and the economy as a whole.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation that authorises Member States to ratify, by the end of 2016, the sections of the ILO Forced Labour Convention Protocol that deal with EU competence. This Protocol will contribute towards prevention of trafficking of persons as well as provide victims with some redress.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ILO Convention on Forced Labour is one of eight key ILO conventions that make up core international labour standards and is considered an essential human rights instrument. According to ILO estimates, at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The protocol aims to make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the exploitation of labour and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. The Protocol obliges states participating in the ILO to draw up a national policy and action plan for the effective and lasting elimination of forced labour and to take measures to implement the provisions of the Protocol, it also lays down the measures to be taken by ilo member states to prevent forced labour and protect persons, especially migrant workers, from potentially abusive and fraudulent recruitment and placement practices and to address the root causes of the risks of forced labour. For the reasons set out above, I can only vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ILO estimates that in the EU 880,000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies. In this direction, I voted in favour of the report because it facilitates the fight against trafficking and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Stevens' report. It is unacceptable that forced labour is still present in the society and economy of the modern age. Although there is one convention ratified by almost every state in the world from 1930, according to the International Labour Organisation, there are currently at least 20.9 million victims of forced labour worldwide. In order to remedy this problem more effectively, the ILO has drawn up an additional protocol to the Convention. The purpose of the Protocol is to address implementation deficiencies in order to ensure the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. It is a positive step forward that the Protocol requires ILO Member States to develop a policy and action plan for the effective and permanent eradication of forced labour. The Protocol also emphasises the prevention of forced labour and the compensation and protection of victims, which are also important elements in the eradication of the problem. The ratification of the Protocol by the Member States will facilitate action against traffickers. As parts of the Protocol fall within EU competence, the Council's decision is necessary for their ratification. This required Parliament's consent, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote which asked for consent to the draft Council decision which authorises Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization. I have to be clear that I fully support this international convention which seeks to enhance the protection of workers and tackle forced and compulsory labour. I also agree with the aim to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation. However, this Council decision impacts directly on the principle of appropriate competences. So much so that the Council clearly states that the EU cannot ratify the ILO Protocol, as only States can be parties thereto.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, under the Protocol, the ICO Member States must develop policies and an action plan at national level for the effective and sustained suppression of forced labour and take measures to apply the provisions of this Protocol, consulting both employers' and workers' organisations. I believe that we must consider protecting migrant workers from potentially abusive and fraudulent recruitment and placement practices, and we must fight to eradicate the root causes that cause increased risks of forced labour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes ratification by the Council of the Convention of the International Labour Organization (ILO) on forced labour. As part of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, this protocol is particularly aimed at addressing implementation gaps and improving progress in the fight against forced labour trafficking. Forced labour still affects 20 million people worldwide (880,000 in Europe), so it is necessary to combat these practices on a global scale, but also to provide better protection and compensation to victims. Sharing these objectives, I supported the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. There is no problem with this report. The aim is to make the fight against human traffickers more effective by allowing Member States to ratify the 2014 protocol on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour and Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The International Labour Organization (ILO) is the united nations specialized agency that aims to pursue social justice and universally recognize human rights at work, through the promotion of decent employment in conditions of freedom, equality and security for all women and men. The ILO Convention on Forced Labour is an essential human rights instrument. When it was adopted in 1930, the acceding states undertook to stop the use of forced labour as soon as possible and to make its exploitation liable to criminal sanctions. According to ILO estimates, more than 80 years after adoption, at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The new protocol aims to fill the gaps in implementation and make the prevention of labour exploitation more effective and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. The original Convention on Forced Labour came into force almost a century ago, so it is regrettable that millions of people around the world are still subject to forced labour, which is why I have decided to vote in favour of ratifying the protocol.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In order to better combat traffickers and trafficking situations and better guarantee the rights of victims, the International Labour Organization (ILO) has adopted a new protocol to the existing Convention on Forced Labour. The European Union and member states must ratify this protocol as soon as possible and promote it among their international partners.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Forced labour is a violation of human rights and an attack on the dignity of millions of women, men, girls and young boys. To this day, it still affects 21 million people, victims of an exploitation that generates $150 billion in revenue per year for those who organize and supervise it. All forms of trafficking and exploitation must be broken by law and determined actions must be taken to enforce it.  The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight basic ILO conventions that define basic international labour standards. It is seen as an instrument for the protection of human rights. I supported this report because the aim of the protocol concerned is to strengthen measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting their work, as well as the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.  The ratification of this protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking and in securing the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. It will also facilitate the fight against traffickers.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely right that as legislators we take every step possible to stamp out the scourge of forced labour in societies across Europe.  Far too often this Parliament debates issues for which they should have no say and no authority. However crimes such as modern slavery, human trafficking and sexual exploitation are now inextricably linked to free movement and therefore our solutions must too transcend our nation’s borders. I am proud to be able to say that the regions of the United Kingdom have already brought forward legislation with measures that bring full compliance with the new Protocol to this Convention.  My party colleague, Lord Morrow, has fought with great passion and determination to bring about the Northern Ireland Human Trafficking and Exploitation Act which strengthens this provision and refocuses how we combat these crimes from the victims to those that feed the crime gangs responsible. Europe could learn much from this strategy.  Separate work to tighten the framework has been witnessed in England, Wales and Scotland too. But this is not something that we should simply tick off as a job well done. The gangs that lead these abuses are ever evolving and so too should the solutions aimed at stopping them.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. 85 years after the adoption of the Convention on Forced Labour by the International Labour Organization, it is unfortunately still a reality in the Union. In 2012 there was still one million working under duress, only in Europe. In 2014 the International Labour Conference adopted a protocol on the convention, with the aim of modernising it and strengthening the international legal framework. It introduces new obligations to prevent forced labour, protect victims and compensate for their material and physical harm. The draft resolution in question was to have this protocol ratified by the governments and parliaments of the Member States. By giving nation states more voice, while strengthening legal constraints on forced labour networks, this recommendation is moving in the right direction. That is why I voted for this proposal.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Forced Labour Convention is one of the eight main conventions of the International Labour Organisation, which constitute the main international labour norms.
