When the Convention was adopted in 1930, States were invited to stop the use of forced labour as soon as possible and to criminalise the act.  To date, after more than 80 years, the ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. For this reason, I welcome the protocol signed last year in Geneva aimed at closing the gaps in the implementation of the Forced Labour Convention and making progress in preventing trafficking for labour exploitation, the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. I call on the Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol that fall within eu competences and to make efforts to do so by the end of 2016 in order to ensure effective protection and enforcement of labour law, awareness-raising and international cooperation in the field of migration.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Ratification of the Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in protecting the rights of victims of crime across the EU. In addition, ratification of the protocol will make it easier to prosecute people traffickers.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced Labour, adopted in 1930, is one of the eight key ILO conventions. The ILO is a specialised UN agency that promotes human rights and social justice, which sets core international standards at work. The ILO estimates that around twenty-one million people in the world have been forced into forced labour. This report authorises The Member States to ratify, in the interests of the Union, the ILO Protocol of 2014. This protocol aims to strengthen judicial cooperation in order to better combat trafficking in human beings, the exploitation of labour, the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. For the acceding States, there is an obligation to draw up an action plan to eliminate forced labour, while protecting the weakest sections of the population from systematic exploitation practices. The proposals for Council decisions will therefore allow Member States to ratify the sections of the Protocol that fall within the competence of the Union, while also recommending that they undertake to do so by the end of 2016. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are currently victims of forced labour and this draft resolution aims to eliminate disparities, develop the prevention of trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting work and protecting and compensating victims of forced labour. As regards victims, the Protocol provides that effective measures should be taken to identify, release, protect, recover and rehabilitator them, as well as to provide them with assistance and support in other forms. Ratification of the Protocol is therefore an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in ensuring the rights of victims of crime across Europe. Its ratification by member states will facilitate the fight against traffickers.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it aims to combat forced labour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Council decision because it gives authority to Member States in ratifying the Protocol in certain areas, thus closing the gaps in the implementation of the ILO Convention. Supporting the ratification of this protocol is an important signal of Europe's commitment to the fight against trafficking in human beings and victims of forced labour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the protocol seeks to address gaps in implementation and to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation as well as protecting and compensating victims of forced labour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the many steps taken to end the use of forced labour, there are still more than 20 million people who are forced into forced labour. In accordance with the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, Member States cannot decide to ratify the Protocol outside the framework of the institutions of the European Union, as parts of the Protocol fall within the sphere of competence of the European Union. The proposal for a Council Decision empowers Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, those parts of the Protocol which fall within the competence of the European Union and are encouraged to do so by the end of 2016 as far as possible. Ratification of the protocol in question would mark a huge step forward in the fight against traffickers, labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this protocol, which aims to fill the gaps in implementation and make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the ILO Convention on Forced Labour, as the ratification of the Protocol is an important step in combating trafficking in human beings and protecting the rights of victims of crime across the EU. In addition, ratification of the protocol will make it easier to prosecute people traffickers.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report represents Parliament’s position on a draft Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organisation. Articles 1-4 of the Protocol touch on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and thus require the EU to authorise Member States to ratify it. As this is an international convention which seeks to enhance the protection of workers and tackle forced or compulsory labour, it is something which I fully and wholeheartedly support. The report simply confirms Parliament’s consent for the draft decision and has been adopted in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) with the unanimous vote of those members present. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We welcome today’s vote, with which we authorise and recommend Member States to ratify the International Labour Organization’s (ILO) Forced Labour Convention. This is one of the ILO’s eight fundamental conventions which are at the base of international labour standards.  This particular protocol seeks to address gaps in implementation and to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation as well as protecting and compensating victims of forced labour. It is crucially important that the use of forced labour is suppressed in all its forms irrespective of the nature of the work or the sector of activity in which it may be performed.  We therefore strongly support the ratification of this ILO Convention by all Member States, convinced that all measures must be put in place in order to eradicate a practice to which young boys and girls are often exposed and which is still present in some of our Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the protocol in the face of the need to address gaps in its implementation and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. We must continue to fight for the complete eradication of forced labour as we cannot allow millions of people to be subjected to this kind of work around the world today.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. With today's vote, the European Parliament is giving the green light to accession to this important convention, enabling the European Union to strengthen its role as a global player committed to a fairer and fairer order, starting precisely from a more certain and advanced legal framework to protect labour rights and, in particular, the fight against and prevention.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced Labour of 1930, with regard to Articles 1-4 of the Protocol as regards judicial cooperation in criminal matters. I firmly believe that the ILO Convention on Forced Labour is an expression of inestimable value for human rights. I therefore believe that the use of forced labour must be stopped as a matter of urgency, and as early as 1930 the acceding states were urged to do so, but eighty years later there are still millions of people in the world who are victims of this phenomenon. The aim of the protocol is to protect all workers, especially those most in difficulty, such as migrants and children, through the adoption of effective and efficient measures to ensure that they do not prosecute the victims of forced labour but rather ensure a way of redress and compensation. It is only through the ratification of the parts of the Protocol in areas of EU competence that it can be hoped that by the end of 2016 the fight against forced labour will succeed in making effective all those rights denied to victims affecting the whole EU.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour: Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters, because I believe that, in the interests of subsidiarity, it is up to the Member States to sign the Convention. On the other hand, I welcome the standards set out in it by the ILO.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. Human rights must be protected throughout Europe and across European borders. We must create working conditions that do not lead to forced labour.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is the 21st century, yet 21 million people are still performing forced labour. They are modern slaves, generating USD 150 billion for the criminal networks that exploit them on an annual basis. This has to end. That is why I voted in favour of this recommendation authorising Member States to open negotiations on the ILO’s 2014 Protocol on the Forced Labour Convention.  We need new tools and resources for combating forced labour. But most vital will be coordination amongst Member States.  We will only be able to eradicate slavery and stop the exploitation of workers which is undercutting the wages of others, if all EU Member States stand united behind strong measures, so we can finally make slavery history.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The fact that approximately 20.9 million people globally still endure forced labour means that this proposal for a Council decision fully merits to be supported. This shocking statistic means that basic fundamental human rights of so many remain violated. The Protocol outlines the criteria necessary for Members States to adopt national strategies to combat forced labour and apply the Protocol’s provisions through consultation with employers’ and workers’ organisations. Another vital part of this Protocol is the emphasis placed on protecting victims of human trafficking and the fight against traffickers. Therefore, I was very pleased to vote in favour today.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this draft ratification by the Member States of the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, a convention drawn up within the International Labour Organization. I am, of course, opposed to this form of modern slavery, which still affects almost 1 million people in the European Union. The positive thing about the 2014 protocol is that it expands the scope for redress and compensation for victims of forced labour. It also allows for better cooperation between states.  Nevertheless, we must be careful that this text is not diverted from its objective in order to promote illegal immigration. I do not want additional rights, in the form of facilities to enter or stay in our countries, to be granted to illegal immigrants, under the pretext of combating forced labour.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Recommendation as Protocol 2014 aims to address gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In 1930, in adopting the Convention to which this Recommendation refers, the ILO urged States to end and criminalize the use of forced labour. It is regrettable that more than 80 years later, nearly 21 million people in the world continue to be victims of forced labour, and with this Protocol we continue to walk in the direction of preventing these human rights violations from continuing to take place. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. With our vote we support Parliament's approval so that Member States can ratify the Protocol as soon as possible and thus maintain a commitment in the fight against forced labour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as it simply confirms Parliament’s consent and represents Parliament’s position on a draft Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this recommendation concerning ratification by ILO Member States as regards Articles 1 to 4 of the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention, which relate to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Despite being adopted in 1930, over 80 years later the ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour globally. The 2014 Protocol aims to address gaps in the Convention’s implementation and requires Member States to develop a national policy and plan of action for the effective and sustained suppression of forced labour. In addition it details concrete measures Member States must take to prevent forced labour e.g. educating and informing people and ensuring relevant legislation applies to all workers and all sectors of the economy. Particularly positive are the provisions concerning the victims of forced labour who, under the Convention, must have access to remedies, such as compensation, and the fact that competent authorities are entitled not to prosecute victims for unlawful activities that they have been compelled to commit.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe it helps contribute to the effort to put an end to forced labour. More than 80 years after the International Labour Conference called upon states to end the use of forced labour and criminalise the offence there is still an estimated 20.9 million victims of forced labour globally. This concerns fundamental rights, the victims and the fight against trafficking, a crime that affects not only individuals but also the whole of society and the entire economy.  The ratification of this protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking and of ensuring the rights of victims of crime all over Europe. The original Forced Labour Convention entered into force almost a hundred years ago and yet it is regrettable that still millions of people across the world are subject to forced labour. This is simply unacceptable in our modern day.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The Convention on Forced Labour adopted in 1930 called on countries that had ratified it to abolish forced or compulsory labour in all its forms as soon as possible and to make it punishable by criminal sanctions.  Nevertheless, more than 80 years have passed and the ILO estimates that there are about 21 million victims of forced labour worldwide. We know that this form of work generates $150 billion in illegal profits. It is truly intolerable and inhumane. That is why I hope that the 2014 protocol on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour and Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters will be ratified by the Member States and strictly enforced. It would strengthen measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting their work and better ensure compensation for victims of forced labour. I believe that we would have an additional instrument to combat human traffickers, who are a real scourge in Europe and the world.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the passing of 85 years since the Forced Labour Convention was signed, people trafficking and forced labour remain all too common. This Protocol will help in the battle against these crimes and I was happy to vote in favour.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, as evidenced by a report by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights on the exploitation of labour in the EU, although Union legislation contains provisions in this area, workers in Europe remain at risk of being victims of severe labour exploitation. This is especially true for workers outside their country. I therefore warmly welcome and support the recommendation authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol. convention on forced labour with regard to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This represents a small but important step in our joint efforts to penalise labour exploitation in Europe, to combat trafficking in human beings and to ensure decent working conditions.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Recommendation as Protocol 2014 aims to address gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In 1930, in adopting the Convention to which this Recommendation refers, the ILO urged States to end and criminalize the use of forced labour. It is regrettable that more than 80 years later, nearly 21 million people in the world continue to be victims of forced labour, and with this Protocol we continue to walk in the direction of preventing these human rights violations from continuing to take place. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. With our vote we support Parliament's approval so that Member States can ratify the Protocol as soon as possible and thus maintain a commitment in the fight against forced labour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision authorisation of Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour in the interest of the European Union. International Labour Organisations in relation to Articles 1-4 protocol relating to issues relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as this aligns the disproportion in implementation processes in this area and improves labour trading prevention mechanisms.  The Protocol insists on the creation of national policies and action plans for a more efficient and continuous suppression of forced labour. Also, the Protocol provides for support and assistance measures for victims.  I therefore support this recommendation, which encourages further respect for fundamental rights and improves the overall state of the economy and society.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Among the eight major conventions of the International Labour Organization is the Convention on Forced Labour, signed in 1930. Last year, the International Labour Conference amended this text to adapt it to the current situation and to strengthen certain mechanisms aimed at preventing human trafficking.  As a result of these changes, a Memorandum of Understanding was adopted by the Conference's stakeholders. The European Parliament has been seized on this text in order to allow The Member States to ratify this agreement. As a text that better fights against forced labour, I voted in favour.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained. The EU too frequently ‘thinks’ it can or should make decisions that are within a sovereign nation’s jurisdiction. This is the case here.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the Council Decision authorising the Member States to ratify the 2014 ILO Forced Labour Convention in order to promote the combat of this criminal phenomenon which is unfortunately still present in contemporary Europe. The steps to be undertaken will protect the victims of forced labour and fight human trafficking as well as the black market in general.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Helga Stevens' report to authorise the ratification of the International Labour Organization's protocol on forced labour. The aim of this 2014 protocol is to address shortcomings in the implementation of legislation and to strengthen measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting their work, as well as the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. The aim is to make the fight against human traffickers more effective by allowing Member States to ratify this protocol.   The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because the eradication of human trafficking and forced labour is one of the cardinal values of the European Union. The adoption of this protocol will strengthen judicial cooperation between states and enable a better fight against these crimes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. There is no reason to vote against this report: it is recommended that the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour be ratified in order to combat forced, compulsory and trafficking in human beings worldwide. The purpose of the draft Council decision is to authorise the Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol that fall within the competence of the EU. In the spirit of high labour standards to combat forced and compulsory labour, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the report authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention, as this is an international convention which seeks to enhance the protection of workers and tackle forced or compulsory labour.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 6 December 2015, in plenary in Strasbourg, I supported the recommendations on the proposal for a Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the EU, the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced Labour with regard to Articles 1 to 4. The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight fundamental conventions of the International Labour Organisation and is considered an instrument for the protection and promotion of human rights. The Protocol seeks to address shortcomings in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for forced labour (slavery) as well as protecting and compelling victims of forced labour. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europa. It is therefore extremely important that all Member States accede to the swift ratification of the Protocol, as this will greatly facilitate the fight against traffickers. Which, in the light of today's migration crisis, when organised crime is essentially trafficking on a mass scale, is precisely one of the measures that the EU urgently needs today. Like all our Members in an earlier vote in the LIBE committee, they supported this recommendation, so I could not have voted differently in plenary.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I supported the proposal for a resolution because trafficking in human beings and forced labour are the worst violations of human rights, so they must be fought by all means. The ratification of the Protocol will also help to improve the rights of victims of such crimes throughout Europe. The original Convention on Forced Labour entered into force 80 years ago, so it is extremely regrettable that millions of people around the world continue to be victims.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Stevens' recommendation. The ILO Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 is universally regarded as a key document in the history of the protection of human rights, as it prohibits forced labour and its rules stipulate that forced labour must be criminally punishable. The purpose of the protocol to be voted on is to overcome the shortcomings in the implementation of this Convention and to make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organization with regard to Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol on issues related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The aim of this protocol is to establish decent working conditions and to protect victims of forced or compulsory labour and to punish perpetrators. Forced labour is often linked to illegal immigration. The 2014 protocol may therefore also be an instrument against traffickers.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it fights against forced labour by seeking to protect the victims and punish the perpetrators.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report addresses a Council Decision authorising Member States to sign a protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. When entering the Convention into matters of criminal judicial cooperation, this Council Decision is required in the EU and I voted in favour.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. The International Labour Organization estimates that 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour globally. Forced labour is considered one of the most profitable criminal activities in the world.  This report aims at the ratification of the Convention on Forced Labour on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This is one of the eight fundamental ILO conventions for which the opinion of the European Parliament is required. I voted for this report because harmonising international labour standards is a tool for the protection of human rights and reduces the risk of impunity. The Protocol aims at concrete measures: developing a national policy and action plan for the effective and sustained suppression of forced labour.  Even if the ratification of this Protocol is voluntary, the protection of the fundamental rights of these people is a permanent responsibility for each of us.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight core ILO conventions that define international labour standards and is considered an instrument for ensuring human rights.  The Protocol asks ILO Member States to adopt policies at national level and an action plan to effectively and evenly abolish forced labour and to create measures to apply the provisions of the Protocol. It also represents measures that ILO Member States must apply to prevent forced labour – by educating and informing people and applying legislation to prevent forced labour and protect people from potentially fraudulent employment. The Protocol provides certain measures for the identification of victims, their release, protection, recovery and rehabilitation together with other forms of assistance and support.  I supported The Stevens Advocate's report approving the Protocol because I consider forced labor to be against fundamental human rights. Ratification of the Protocol is necessary to take a step forward in preventing trafficking in human beings, exploitation of labour and protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The International Labour Organisation's Forced Labour Convention is undoubtedly one of the most important and fundamental documents relating to the quality of work standards in the world. It is a convention that every country must ratify, and the sooner, the better, because such a step would mean the country's unequivocal support for international human rights norms, and would be quite prudent in putting out the imperialist development of a general society. Forced labour is in fact a form of servitude or even partial slavery, when the employee is hardly paid anything, has no real prospects for the future and their personal development is severely limited or does not exist at all as such. Like my colleagues from the Socialist and Democratic Group and other factions, I voted in favour of this Protocol and call on all 28 Member States of the European Union to ratify this absolutely important and necessary document as early as possible. More than that, I very much hope that something similar could be offered to ratify and implement for other countries in other regions of the world, particularly in Asia and Africa.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour became binding on Slovakia in 1990. By adopting it, all Member States have undertaken to curb the use of forced or compulsory labour in all forms as soon as possible. Nevertheless, estimates say that there are currently 21 million victims of such conduct, which generates around USD 150 billion in illegal profits and, at the same time, harms the economic interests of the Union. It is therefore necessary to reconsider the strengthening of the fight against forced or compulsory labour and adapt it to the conditions of the 21st century. At the 103rd session of the International Labour Conference in June 2014, a new ILO Protocol was adopted which strengthens international cooperation in the fight against forced or compulsory labour and introduces new measures, in particular as regards trafficking in human beings, improving the protection of victims and providing access to compensation. States that ratify the ILO Convention must develop a national strategy and action plan to combat forced labour. Prevention is important in this process, which includes, in particular, informing vulnerable persons and protecting them from possible fraudulent recruitment practices. With this proposal, Member States are empowered to ratify, in the interest of the EU, those parts of the Protocol which fall within the EU's sphere of competence.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision authorizing Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organisation, as regards Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters , because the Protocol seeks to fill implementation gaps and to make progress in: (a) preventing trafficking in human beings for labour exploitation and (b) protecting and compensating victims of forced labour.  This protocol also requires ILO Member States to develop, in consultation with employers' and workers' organisations, a national policy and action plan for the effective and permanent abolition of forced labour. In addition, by focusing on victims, this Protocol stipulates that effective measures should be taken to identify, release, protect, recover and rehabilitate them and be accompanied by other forms of assistance and support. Finally, the Protocol lays down legal obligations for the States carrying out the ratification.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this protocol on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour. The 1930 Convention provides for the abolition of forced labour worldwide. However, despite its almost universal ratification, this convention is still not fully implemented. The provisions of this new protocol provide for the obligation to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms. The protocol also provides for decent working conditions and sanctions against perpetrators. We obviously support this protocol.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Forced Labour Convention is one of the ILO’s eight fundamental Conventions that make up the core international labour standards, and it is considered a human rights instrument. In adopting the Convention in 1930, the International Labour Conference called upon States to end the use of forced labour within the shortest possible period and to criminalise the offence. Yet, more than 80 years later, the ILO estimates that globally at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour. The Protocol seeks to address gaps in implementation and to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation, as well as protecting and compensating victims of forced labour. The Protocol requires ILO Member States to develop a national policy and plan of action for the effective and sustained suppression of forced labour and to take measures to apply the Protocol’s provisions, in consultation with employers’ and workers’ organisations. It also sets out the measures that ILO Member States must take to prevent forced labour.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation, in relation to Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol as regards judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  I consider it of the utmost importance to draw up an effective action plan for the elimination of forced labour, in order to prevent trafficking in human beings, to protect workers from abusive and fraudulent practices, and to compensate the victims of forced labour. Education and training are useful tools to ensure that the rights of victims of crime, throughout Europe, are respected.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight fundamental ILO conventions that make up basic international labour standards and is considered a human rights instrument. With the adoption of this Convention in 1930, the International Labour Organisation called on states to ban the use of forced labour as soon as possible and to criminalise it as a criminal offence. The Protocol seeks to address implementation gaps and to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation, as well as protecting and compelling victims of forced labour. I am convinced that ratification of the Protocol by EU Member States will facilitate the fight against traffickers, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Protocol amending the ILO Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 aims to fill the gaps in the implementation of the same Convention and to make more effective measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation and those relating to the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In view of the ILO's numerical estimates of the victims of these practices (as many as 20.9 million people) and the crimes in respect of which the Protocol intends to intervene (crimes affecting not only individuals but the economy as a whole), I have decided to support this document, which merely welcomes the Council's decision to authorise the Member States to ratify the parts of the protocol in question. , whose competence is community competence.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in combating trafficking in human beings and in guaranteeing the rights of victims of this crime across Europe. Let us hope that member states will ratify it quickly so that we can effectively fight to put an end to the millions of cases of people subject to forced labour.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this recommendation because the aim of this protocol is to remedy the shortcomings in the implementation of legislation and to strengthen the prevention of trafficking in human beings, the exploitation of labour, protection and compensation for victims of forced labour. All countries belonging to the International Labour Organisation will now have to make every effort to completely eradicate the unjust and harmful practice of forced labour. Parliament welcomed the Council's decision to ratify the Protocol and called on the Member States to ratify it as soon as possible.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It is recommended that the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour be ratified in order to combat forced and compulsory labour and trafficking in human beings worldwide. The purpose of the draft Council decision is to authorise the Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol that fall within the competence of the EU. We must therefore support this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as citizens need to be protected from labour exploitation and forced labour.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight basic conventions of the International Labour Organization and an important instrument for the defence of human rights around the world. But more than 80 years after its adoption, 21 million people are still victims of forced labour. In June 2014, the ILO adopted a protocol to improve the fight against trafficking, including protection and compensation for victims and effective sanctions systems. It also sets out the measures that ILO Member States must take to prevent forced labour such as educating and informing people about their rights, especially migrant workers. I regret the procedure by which the Council must first give its approval for Member States to ratify this protocol, but I am voting to ensure equal treatment of victims of this crime throughout Europe.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Among the eight major conventions of the International Labour Organization is the Convention on Forced Labour, signed in 1930. Last year, the International Labour Conference amended this text to adapt it to the current situation and to strengthen certain mechanisms aimed at preventing human trafficking.  As a result of these changes, a Memorandum of Understanding was adopted by the Conference's stakeholders. The European Parliament has been seized on this text in order to allow The Member States to ratify this agreement. It is a text that makes it possible to better combat forced labour. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the ILO Convention on Forced Labour on matters relating to cooperation in criminal matters. It represents one of the eight iLO fundamental labour conventions, inextricably linked to the protection of human rights. The new ILO protocol, adopted by the 103rd session of the International Labour Conference, aims to prevent the use of forced labour, in particular with regard to the context of trafficking in human beings, improving the protection of victims and providing for access to compensation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this initiative because it addresses the gaps in the Forced Labour Convention to better prevent human trafficking. Millions of people are still victims of forced labour and the Convention must be implemented swiftly in order to protect victims.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's approval of the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour on issues related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Once ratified, this protocol should make it possible to fight traffickers more effectively. This is another step towards eradicating forced labour.  It is deplorable that, 85 years after the Convention on Forced Labour came into force, this phenomenon is still taking its toll and is still a scourge of which the EU is not exempt. In the fight against forced labour, particular attention must be paid to prevention, with a focus on vulnerable people - including migrants - who are more likely to fall into the hands of unscrupulous traffickers.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, I am very aware of the experience of recent years of recession, when almost 15% of people in my country have been out of work for some time. Many of them have thus been placed in financial distress, which has made them easy victims of the illegal practices of modern slavery, not only across borders, but also on home soil. I therefore welcome the recommendation to ratify the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, which will facilitate the fight against such traffickers. All the more so because, at the same time, the number of victims of forced or compulsory labour in the world is still estimated at over 21 million victims. I appreciate that the Convention introduces an obligation to ensure their identification, release, protection, recovery and rehabilitation, as well as that other provisions require ratifying States to give all victims access to compensation and to ensure that the competent authorities are entitled not to pursue them for the illegal activities they have been forced to carry out.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the ILO Forced Labour Convention, which represents Parliament’s position on a draft Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization, since I am not in agreement that there exists exclusive EU competence arising from the areas covered by the Protocol, given that both Articles 82(2) and 153(2) TFEU allow Parliament and the Council to establish minimum standards and taking into account Opinion 2/91 in which the Court concluded specifically in the ILO context that the provisions of an international agreement are not of such a kind as to affect rules adopted by the EU, when both the agreement and the EU legislation set out minimum standards. Therefore this raises questions about the necessity and appropriateness of having the proposed Council decisions. I also believe that there is a lack of detailed analysis by the Commission on the distribution of competences to justify the need for these decisions and the lack of clarity in the final text outlining the extent of the competences being exercised (exclusive or shared).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 1930 Convention is one of eight ILO Basic Conventions laying down basic international labour standards. The 2014 Protocol contains important additions to address the shortcomings of the original Convention, but cannot be strengthened under the competence of the Member States, as parts of it fall within the competence of the Union. The draft decision is therefore about the Council empowering Member States to strengthen the parts of the Protocol which are within the competence of the Union. At the last plenary session, the European Parliament agreed to a similar draft Council resolution authoring the strengthening of the Protocol in the Member States with regard to social policy aspects, and this draft would provide the same for aspects relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed decision is intended to allow Member States to ratify the protocol on the International Labour Organization's Convention on Forced Labour.  The provisions of the protocol establish the obligation to prevent forced labour and to provide victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms, including compensation. Specifically, the protocol aims, on the one hand, to establish decent working conditions and, on the other hand, to protect victims of forced or compulsory labour and to punish the perpetrators of offences. The recommendation should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the Convention in 1930, the International Labour Conference encouraged Member States to end the use of forced labour as soon as possible. More than 80 years later, the International Labour Organization estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labor. The Protocol aims to eliminate disparities in implementation, develop the prevention of trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting work and to protect and compensate victims of forced labour. It is important to note that the 2014 Protocol deals with fundamental rights, victims and the fight against trafficking in human beings, a crime that affects individuals but also society and the economy as a whole. I believe that the ratification of the Protocol will be decisive in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in guaranteeing the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to authorise EU Member States to ratify the protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour. The convention, which is one of the ILO's eight basic conventions defining basic labour standards, has been the subject of a protocol to address gaps in its implementation and also addresses human trafficking. More than 80 years after its adoption, forced labour remains. In detail, the protocol envisages requiring the protection of forced labour and providing victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation. It also provides for decent working conditions and protection for victims of forced labour, as well as penalties for perpetrators. I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which simply confirms Parliament’s consent and represents Parliament’s position on a draft Council Decision authorising Member States to ratify the Protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization. Articles 1-4 of the Protocol touch on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters and thus require the EU to authorise Member States to ratify it. This is an international convention which seeks to enhance the protection of workers and tackle forced or compulsory labour.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has always been committed to promoting human rights and decent work and eradicating trafficking in human beings, both internally and in external relations. The new protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour aims to step up the fight against this terrible violation of human rights and to adapt it to the challenges of the twenty-first century. All EU Member States have ratified core labour standards, but for Member States to ratify the Protocol as well, authorisation by the Council is required, as parts of it fall within the EU's competence. The report therefore welcomes the Council's decision to authorise ratification and proposes that Parliament give its approval. In the light of the above, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the phenomenon of forced labour is not a historical concept, but a very real reality of our time. That is why I think it is extremely important that all EU Member States accede to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) convention on this subject as soon as possible. This Convention is important in order to make enforcement, judicial cooperation in the prevention and prosecution of forced labour even more effective, and to protect workers from exploitation and to provide compensation to victims. Fundamental human rights include the right to work and it is crucial that we work by all means to ensure that citizens are provided with the right conditions and protected from falling victim to tyranny. In order to do this, the ep's adoption of this convention is one of the primary steps.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this recommendation for a Protocol that seeks to address the gaps in implementation and to make progress on preventing trafficking for labour exploitation as well as protecting and compensating victims of forced labour.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is absolutely necessary that those elements of the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, which are lacour, be supplemented and adapted to new social and economic realities. Forced labour is, unfortunately, still present in our societies, including in developed, civilised and free countries, where it takes on new forms. Most of the time, however, this forced labour is associated with human trafficking and organised crime, having a cross-border nature. The fight against forced labour, slavery is an element of our civilization, because we are committed to defending and fighting for the rights and freedoms of people. This report, which supports the adoption by Member States of the new Protocol on the Convention, is an important step in the fight against practices that drive forced labour and thus provides means for people in such situations to be helped to overcome them and start a new life.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Forced and compulsory labour and trafficking in human beings must be combated worldwide. This draft Council decision calls on the Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol which fall within the competence of the European Union. The protocol lists decent measures that ILO Member States must take to prevent forced labour. On the basis of the measures before us, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report in support of the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the June 2014 Protocol on the International Labour Organization's Convention on Forced Labour. Forced labour still affects 21 million people, despite 80 years of the Convention.  This new protocol strengthens anti-trafficking measures, including protection and compensation for victims and punitive measures for executioners. It also calls on Member States to ensure prevention through education and information for workers about their rights.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. It was a single-vote consent report in which Parliament gave its consent for Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention against forced labour.  The Protocol is positive and necessary and outlines strong steps that need to be taken in order to combat human trafficking and forced labour, and it is a response to the fact that while most Member States have ratified the Convention, forced labour still exists across the EU. The Protocol specifically addresses the gaps in cooperation by crime agencies in combating cross-border human trafficking. As some aspects of the Protocol fall under EU competence, Parliament is required to authorise the Member States to ratify it and the report urges them to do so by the end of 2016.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The draft decision authorises Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol which fall within the competences of the European Union. The updating of the Convention is necessary and the Protocols should be ratified as soon as possible in order to enhance the fight against trafficking in human beings and forced labour and to provide protection for victims.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of this agreement. Millions of people around the world are suffering from forced labour and human trafficking crimes. This is a sensitive problem that cannot be delayed. An appropriate mechanism for its prevention and criminalisation needs to be established. In this context, it is essential that all States ratify the provisions of the Protocol. More active action is needed to combat trafficking in human beings. Particular attention should be paid to the identification of victims, the promotion of private sector accountability and more effective prosecution in the fight against trafficking in human beings. The rights of victims of crime must be properly and fully guaranteed throughout Europe. The principle that no one can be held in slavery or free (all forms of slavery and slave trade is prohibited) must be implemented without reservation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that, in order to make the legal obligations contained in protocol 2014 of the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour applicable to the Member States, the authorisation of the European Union is necessary and given that the need to protect fundamental rights is an essential pillar of The Union's action, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, the Protocol of 2014 to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It is important that, through appropriate judicial cooperation, we prevent forced or compulsory labour and thus protect the dignity of the individual.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The original Convention on Forced Labour came into force almost 100 years ago, but forced labour still affects around 21 million people worldwide. Contrary to what many people think, the European Union is not exempt from forced labour and the percentage of people working against their own will is as high as 7%. Cases of domestic workers working forcibly or agricultural workers have been found in all EU countries. Forced labor is not only a violation of basic human rights, but also an illegal profit of at least $150 billion a year, according to a report by the International Labor Organization. Therefore, it is a crime that affects not only the individual, but also the entire society and the world economy.  The ratification of the 2014 Protocol is an important step in the fight against forced labour worldwide and the European Union, as well as an important step in the fight against crimes closely linked to forced labour, such as human trafficking, prostitution and child pornography. I therefore welcome the Recommendation on the Council's draft decision authorisation of Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, the Protocol concerning matters in the domain of the European Union concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters, and I have supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Member States to ratify the protocol on the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour. The convention is one of the ILO's eight basic conventions defining basic labour standards. It has been the subject of a protocol to address gaps in its implementation and also addresses human trafficking. More than 80 years after its adoption, forced labour remains.  In detail, the protocol envisages requiring the protection of forced labour and providing victims with protection and access to redress mechanisms, such as compensation. It also provides for decent working conditions and protection for victims of forced labour, as well as penalties for perpetrators. I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the Republic of Croatia has been a member of the International Labour Organisation since 1992 and a signatory to, inter alia, the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour, I fully support the draft Council decision to ratify the 2014 Protocol, which further elaborates and adapts to the modern context the provisions on preventing trafficking in human beings for forced labour and on the protection of its victims. To this day, almost 80 years after the adoption of the aforementioned Convention, forced labor remains a harsh reality for tens of millions of people worldwide. As a community of developed sovereign democratic states, the European Union must express its position more clearly than ever and allow concrete steps to be taken towards combating trafficking and exploitation of people.  I believe that this will be made possible in the most efficient way by the aforementioned 2014 Protocol, under which Member States would develop their own national policies and strategic plans in cooperation with trade unions and employers' associations. These policies would aim to inform and educate citizens about this issue, eradicate in-depth causes affecting the practice of forced labour, ensure the same application of relevant legislation for all workers and economic sectors, protect foreign workers from exploitation, and protect and compensate victims of forced labour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the ILO's eight basic conventions that constitute basic international labour standards and is considered to be a tool for human rights. The ILO estimates that globally there are at least 20.9 million people who are victims of forced labour. Thus, the Protocol seeks to address implementation shortcomings and make progress on preventing human trafficking, and exploiting people for work, as well as protecting and compensating victims of forced labour. The Protocol requires that ILO Member States develop a national and action plan to effectively achieve the suppression of forced labour, and measures are taken to apply the provisions of the Protocol, in consultation with employers and labour organisations. It also outlines the measures that Member States need to take to prevent forced labour and to provide legislation to prevent forced labour. This applies in particular to workers in all sectors of the economy, in particular migrant workers, from potentially offensive and fraudulent employment, and the risk of forced labour. The protocol concerns fundamental rights, sacrifice and the fight against human trafficking, a crime that affects not only individuals, but the whole society and the economy as a whole. I therefore support the report, as the ratification of this protocol is an important step in the fight against human trafficking and ensuring the rights of victims of crime across Europe.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud of Parliaments’ vote on the ILO Forced Labour Convention recommendation. The European Union is a force for human rights and this vote further supports that. The ILO estimates that there are still at least 20.9 million people who are victims of forced labour, and this comes 80 years after the initial adoption of the Convention. This Protocol will help fill in the gaps in the implementation to help prevent the trafficking of labour exploitation. I support the calls for ILO member states to develop a national policy for the constant subduing of forced labour. In addition, the measure also helps the victims of forced labour be released, protected and rehabilitated, as well as allowing them other assistance. This Protocol is based on fundamental human rights, and I believe that it will help to fight the trafficking of victims. This Convention is just as important today as it was almost a century ago.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ILO Convention on Forced Labour is one of eight key ILO conventions that make up core international labour standards and is considered an essential human rights instrument. The aim of this protocol is to make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. Ratification of the Protocol by the Member States will contribute to the fight against traffickers. The report welcomes the Council's decision and proposes that Parliament give its approval. I believe that its ratification is an important step towards greater protection of the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe and, above all, to step up the fight against human traffickers. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of adopting this report.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendations of my colleagues in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. I find it shameful that there are almost 900 000 women, children and men in the European Union who are forced to work in undignified conditions every day, be it sexual exploitation, begging or other degrading work. Worldwide, twenty-one million people are facing these forms of forced labour. In my opinion, the update of the 2014 Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced Labour of 1930 will certainly improve prevention and redress options. Women, children and men should not be exploited under any circumstances, and I particularly appreciate the efforts made to address the root causes that increase the risks of forced labour. I see this recommendation as fundamental and firmly believe that it will lead to positive change.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A new Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced and Compulsory Labour was adopted in Geneva in June 2014. The Protocol regulates gaps in the implementation of the Provisions of the Convention on Forced and Compulsory Labour and aims to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for the purposes of forced labour, as well as in protecting victims of forced labour and providing them with compensation.  The Convention is an important step in the fight against modern slavery. Although 80 years have passed since the universal ratification of the original Convention, at least 20.9 million people worldwide have been victims of forced labour. Therefore, cross-border cooperation to prosecute the perpetrators of these crimes is a key element in order to ensure that modern slavery is punished and put an end to it.  Member States cannot decide to ratify the Protocol outside the framework of the EU institutions, as some parts of the Protocol fall within the eu's competence. The Council therefore adopted a draft decision authorising Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol which fall within the eu's competence. I hereby supported the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Forced labour is a clear violation of human rights and a problem that must be combated in a coordinated manner not only by the Member States but also by international organisations. For this reason, it is necessary to authorise the Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol. The EP's recommendation in this sense therefore has my strong support. At the same time, I believe that there will be early ratification of the Protocol in the Member States and the fight against forced labour will be even more effective.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Forced labour was abolished in 1930 by the International Labour Organization (ILO). However, the ILO estimates that there are now 21 million people victims of forced labour worldwide. It is necessary to continue the fight against this criminal practice at European and international level.  In this context, the European Parliament has approved the ratification by Member States of the 2014 Protocol on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour and Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters. The aim of this text is to strengthen current legislation and help to end the exploitation of people and human trafficking.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation, which relates to the Council's decision to allow Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organization (ILO). The ILO Convention on Forced Labour is part of a set of eight conventions aimed at defining basic international labour standards. Yet the ILO estimates that today more than 20 million people are victims of forced labour worldwide.  We must fight with all the necessary firmness against these unacceptable criminal practices. The 2014 Protocol, which contains measures to implement and strengthen legislation on prevention, but also to protect and compensate victims, contributes to it and induced legal obligations for States Parties. The protection of human rights requires a responsible and firm attitude. We must ensure that the criteria set by the ILO are implemented. That is why it was necessary to support this draft decision.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight key ILO conventions on basic international labour standards. The ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labor. This Protocol creates legal obligations for the countries that ratify it. It is an important step in combating trafficking in human beings and to guarantee the rights of victims of crime across Europe.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour is one of the eight fundamental ILO Conventions. However, more than 80 years after its adoption, it is estimated that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The Protocol aims to address existing gaps and make progress in preventing trafficking for labour exploitation purposes, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. It also sets out the measures to be taken by ILO Member States to prevent forced labour: education and information; protection of persons, in particular migrant workers, against possible abusive and fraudulent practices in the recruitment and placement process; and actions to address the root causes that increase the risk of forced labour. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. It is very regrettable that millions of people are still subjected to this type of work around the world today. That is why I voted in favour of granting your approval.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would have liked to have been able to say that forced labour was a practice of another century, but unfortunately this is not the case. The International Labour Organization reminds us of the sad reality. Today, 20.9 million people are still victims of forced labour worldwide. These figures are all the more outraged since the 1930 ILO Convention on Forced Labour was ratified almost universally. It is therefore quite logical that I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour. This protocol should address gaps in the implementation of the Convention, but also strengthen measures to prevent human trafficking for the purpose of exploiting their work, protecting and compensate victims of forced labour.  Europe, and I can only rejoice, has always promoted human rights and decent work. I therefore call on the Member States to ratify this protocol as soon as possible.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight key ILO conventions.  We are dealing with a legislative motion for a resolution approving the council's draft decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the EU, the 2014 Protocol updating the ILO Convention on Forced Labour 1930 on Articles 1 and 4 of the Protocol on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This measure obliges Member States to develop a national policy and action plan for the effective and lasting suppression of forced labour, adopting measures to ensure full implementation of legislation in this area and to defend workers from possible abusive recruitment and forced labour practices. Like the rapporteur, I believe that the ratification of the 2014 Protocol, which focuses on fundamental rights, is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, functioning as a guarantor of the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe and the world, which is why I have received and voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision authorising the Member States of the European Union to ratify the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation on Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters. The ILO member states must draw up an action plan that will highlight all forms of forced labour, provide effective assistance to victims and punish traffickers.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Recommendation as Protocol 2014 aims to address gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In 1930, in adopting the Convention to which this Recommendation refers, the ILO urged States to end and criminalize the use of forced labour. It is regrettable that more than 80 years later, nearly 21 million people in the world continue to be victims of forced labour, and with this Protocol we continue to walk in the direction of preventing these human rights violations from continuing to take place. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. With our vote we support Parliament's approval so that Member States can ratify the Protocol as soon as possible and thus maintain a commitment in the fight against forced labour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ILO estimates that in the EU 880,000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies. In this direction, I voted in favour of the report because it facilitates the fight against trafficking and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 A new protocol to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention on Forced Labour was adopted in June 2014. The aim of this protocol is to make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. I have therefore decided to support the draft legislative resolution authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 ILO Forced Labour Protocol with regard to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. While respecting fundamental rights, I believe that the implementation of ad hoc measures for the protection, identification and rehabilitation of victims of forced labour is of primary importance, thus ensuring more appropriate and effective forms of support and assistance.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe this is not an EU competency but instead should be done by nation-state governments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation. Because this is an international convention which seeks to improve workers’ protection and tackle forced or compulsory labour, it is something which I completely support. This report simply confirms that the European Parliament gives its consent to the draft decision.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Helping victims of trafficking in human beings for the purpose of forced labour is an essential part of the fight against this crime. I very much welcome the fact that the 2014 Additional Protocol calls for effective measures to identify these victims, free them, protect them, recover and rehabilitate them, and also focuses on their compensation and protection from prosecution. I agree that the Member States should be entrusted with ratifying the Protocol to the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour concerning labour exploitation and trafficking in human beings for this purpose. Under EU law and its interpretation by the settled case-law of the European Court of Justice, Member States would not be able to ratify certain parts of the Protocol falling within EU competence without an EU mandate, which is why I voted in favour of this recommendation. However, it should be recalled that it is equally strongly necessary to act against any other form of trafficking in human beings, be it sexual exploitation, trade in human organs or a new form of so-called surrogacy.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the EU, the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour as regards Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol relating to matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The Protocol requires Member States to draw up a national policy and action plan for the effective and continuous repression of forced labour and to take measures to apply the provisions of the Protocol. The 2014 Protocol concerns fundamental rights, victims and the fight against trafficking in human beings, a crime that has consequences not only for individuals, but also for society as a whole and the economy as a whole. The ratification of the Protocol by the Member States will facilitate the fight against traffickers, so Member States should ratify the Protocol as soon as possible.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Eighty-five years after the signature of the Forced Labour Convention almost 900 000 people in the European Union are still being coerced by their recruiters or employers to work against their free will. Women are especially vulnerable in this regard, half of women in forced labour being sexually exploited. With physical violence replaced by more elusive coercive measures, like the retention of identity documents or threats of denunciation to immigration authorities, such dreadful practices are even more difficult to detect and, as a consequence, successful prosecutions remain rare. Therefore I do hope that today’s consent by Parliament for authorising Member States to ratify the new protocol will endow the responsible authorities with the 21st century means to fight against this terrible form of human rights violation.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour is one of the eight fundamental ILO conventions on which international labour standards are based and is considered a human rights instrument. The Protocol to the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour (2014) aims to address shortcomings in its implementation and to make progress in preventing trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation, in assisting victims of forced labour and in paying their compensation.  The Protocol provides that ILO Member States are to establish a national policy and action plan for the effective and permanent elimination of forced labour and to take measures to apply the provisions of the Protocol in consultation with employers' and workers' organisations. It also sets out the measures to be taken by ILO Member States to prevent forced labour (education and information of people, protection of persons and addressing root causes that increase the risk of forced labour). The Protocol deals, inter alia, with the fight against trafficking in human beings, which is a criminal offence and affects not only individuals, but the whole of society and the economy as a whole. I believe that ratification of the Protocol is an important step, as it will facilitate the fight against traffickers. I agree that the fight against forced or compulsory labour must be effective, and I therefore support the ratification of the Protocol.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour of the International Labour Organisation. The Convention is one of eight key ILO conventions that make up core international labour standards and is seen as an essential human rights instrument, protecting all workers, including migrant workers, who are often most exposed to exploitation and forced labour. Under the Convention, the acceding States must stop using forced labour and make it liable to criminal sanctions.  The protocol aims to fill the gaps in implementation and make the prevention of trafficking in human beings more effective for the purpose of labour exploitation and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour, by promoting greater judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Although the original convention was adopted almost a century ago, it is sad to note that forced labour in the world is still present in the world for millions of people.
