It is all the more necessary to allow states to ratify this additional instrument in order to make the protection rules laid down in the Convention effective.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 The proposal authorizes Member States to ratify and take action by the end of 2016, in the interests of the EU, those parts of the 2014 Protocol that fall under EU jurisdiction. The EU itself cannot do this, as only states can ratify the Treaty on Forced Labour. This Convention is one of the eight fundamental conventions of the ILO (International Labour Organisation) which together constitute the fundamental international labour standards and is regarded as an instrument on human rights. The Treaty (1930) calls on the Member States to eliminate and criminalise the use of forced labour as soon as possible. More than 80 years later, the ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The 2014 Protocol aims to address implementation gaps and make progress in preventing labour exploitation-oriented human trafficking and in protecting and compensation victims of forced labour. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and the safeguarding of victims' rights across Europe and this report allows Member States to do so. That's why I voted for it.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Recommendation to ratify the 2014 Protocol regarding the 1930 Convention on Forced Labour because slavery and forced labour are still a major and difficult-to-solve global problem. According to the latest data and projections, it is assumed that there are currently around 20.9 million people in the world – victims of forced labour, which is inadmissible.  In this regard, the Protocol has the function to make progress in the prevention of human trafficking for the purpose of forced labour, to find past shortcomings in the implementation of policies and legislation that combats forced labour, as well as protection and to compensate victims.  It is therefore necessary to draw up a single national policy and action plan at national levels to effectively support forced labour and punish those who use and propagate it, while measures should be implemented to bring the provisions of the Protocol to fruition. Also, by educating and informing people, forced labour and its illegal use should be prevented, appropriate legislation should be created in all branches of the economy, protect all workers, especially migrants, and in all possible ways help victims of forced labour by reimbursing material and mental damage.  Because of all of the above, the ratification of this Protocol is extremely important.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Convention on Forced Labour is one of eight fundamental ILO conventions representing the main international labour standards. According to international labour organisation (ILO) estimates, there are more than 20 million victims of forced labour worldwide, which is a frightening fact. This Decision allows Member States to ratify parts of the Protocol falling within the competence of the European Union. The protocol requires Member States to adopt national plans in cooperation with trade unions and employers' associations, in order to effectively suppress forced labour. In addition, Member States must educate all relevant stakeholders and ensure the protection of labour rights in all sectors of the economy. In order for Member States to ratify this Protocol, the consent of the European Parliament is required. I support this draft decision that can help prevent human trafficking for the purpose of forced labour, as well as contribute to the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as I support the fight against forced labour as well as measures to eliminate it.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, the Protocol of 2014 to the 1930 International Labour Organisation Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. The International Labour Organisation notes that almost 21 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour, which is very worrying. I support any activity that will help reduce trafficking in human beings for the purposes of forced labour and to better protect victims of forced labour. The 2014 Protocol will certainly contribute to this.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Protocol deals with fundamental rights, victims and the fight against trafficking in human beings, a crime that is a major social issue. The ratification of the Protocol is an important step against trafficking in human beings and the protection of the human rights of its victims throughout Europe. Although the original Treaty on Forced Labour/Slavery came into force about 100 years ago, unfortunately millions of people today remain under the slavery and trafficking regime. The ratification of the protocol by all Member States will lead to the strengthening of the fight against traders of persons, which is why its immediate ratification is an absolute necessity. For the above reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Ratification of the Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and in protecting the rights of victims of crime across the EU. In addition, ratification of the protocol will make it easier to prosecute people traffickers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation as the Convention on Forced Labour is one of the basic international labour standards and updating it is essential. The explanatory memorandum to the Recommendation underlines that, when the 1930 Convention was adopted, the International Labour Conference called on states to eliminate and criminalate forced labour as soon as possible. Despite this, 80 years later, the ILO estimates that there are currently at least 20.9 million victims of forced labour worldwide. This and related phenomena, such as trafficking in human beings and exploitation, must be put to an end! In my opinion, one of the specific types of forced labour is the uninsured system of adequate pay and other benefits for work. I wonder how the Government of Hungary explains its wages of around EUR 150 per month, which are suspected to be in breach of labour law, and how the Government is ingenkelling its policies and action plan for the effective and permanent eradication of forced labour. I should note that the coordination process also includes educating and informing people and ensuring that legislation relevant to the prevention of forced labour covers all workers and all sectors of the economy, protecting citizens, including migrant workers, from potentially abusive and unfair recruitment and mediation practices.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The society of the 21st century should not and must not tolerate under any circumstances and in any form the compulsion to work on the free market. The 2014 International Labour Organisation Protocol deals with the fundamental rights of victims and the fight against trafficking in human beings, a crime that has a degrading effect not only on individuals but also on society as a whole and on the economy as a whole. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation on a Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, and I believe that the ratification of this Protocol is an important step both in ensuring the rights of victims and in combating trafficking in human beings.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ratification of the 2014 Protocol to the Labour Convention is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings and the guarantee of the rights of victims of this crime in Europe. The Labour Convention, which we discuss, defines international labour standards and serves as a tool for the protection of fundamental human rights. Despite the adoption of this Convention by the Member States of the International Labour Organisation, 20.9 million people are still victims of forced labour worldwide. I voted for the ratification of the Protocol because we need a policy and action plan at the level of each Member State to eliminate forced labour practices. I expect that, for greater effectiveness in implementation, the provisions of the Protocol will then be discussed with employers' and workers' organisations. Unfortunately, we currently lack a mechanism for educating and informing people about the prevention of forced labour. The most exposed to the phenomenon are migrant workers, by the nature of abusive and fraudulent recruitment and placement practices. Through this Protocol we will be able to identify, release and provide assistance and support to victims, including by not prosecuting them for the illegal activities they have been required to carry out.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interests of the European Union, the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organization with regard to Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol on issues related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters.  The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the eight basic ILO conventions that define basic international labour standards and is an instrument for the protection of human rights.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The ratification of the 2014 Protocol of the Forced Labour Convention is a significant step in the fight against trafficking and in ensuring the rights of victims of crime in Europe. Moreover, it is an important human rights instrument and I therefore voted in favour of the report. The Convention called upon the States to end the use of forced labour in 1930, yet the International Labour Organization estimates that today there are still 20.9 million victims of trafficking globally. The Protocol aims to address gaps in implementation and strengthen trafficking prevention. The draft Council Decision authorises Member States to ratify, in the interest of the EU, those parts of the Protocol that fall into areas of EU competence and recommends they do so by the end of 2016.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I supported the Protocol to the Convention on Forced Labour because I believe that its adoption and implementation can address shortcomings in the implementation of the Convention, which aims primarily at preventing human trafficking due to forced labour and protecting victims of forced labour.  I strongly support the call on Member States to take measures to prevent forced labour, such as educating and informing people and protecting people from potentially offensive and fraudulent employment, as such crimes affect both individuals and economies as a whole.  Given that at least 20.9 million people are victims of forced labour, I believe that the implementation of these recommendations is of utmost essence, especially in terms of punishing perpetrators and depriving them of the profits of forced labour.  I believe that this modern slavery can only be eradicated while ensuring international legal assistance and exchanging information.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Recommendation on a draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify, in the interest of the European Union, the Protocol of 2014 to the ILO Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour of 1930 on matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters, I supported, as the ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people are still victims of forced labour. The aim of the proposal is to make progress towards preventing trafficking in human beings, and the proposal aims to protect victims of forced labour and ensure that they are compensated. Ratification of the Protocol would therefore certainly take a step towards combating traffickers.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Recommendation as Protocol 2014 aims to address gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In 1930, in adopting the Convention to which this Recommendation refers, the ILO urged States to end and criminalize the use of forced labour. It is regrettable that more than 80 years later, nearly 21 million people in the world continue to be victims of forced labour, and with this Protocol we continue to walk in the direction of preventing these human rights violations from continuing to take place. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. With our vote we support Parliament's approval so that Member States can ratify the Protocol as soon as possible and thus maintain a commitment in the fight against forced labour.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Convention on Forced Labour is one of the ILO's eight basic conventions, which define basic international labour standards. However, more than 80 years later, and despite the almost universal ratification of the Convention, forced labour continues to exist. In 2014, the International Labour Conference adopted the Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour with the aim of filling gaps in implementation and strengthening measures to prevent trafficking in human beings for the purpose of exploiting their work, as well as the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. The proposed decision is intended to allow Member States to ratify the Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organization (ILO).  I therefore voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. The International Labour Organisation Convention on the Abolition of Forced Labour was adopted as early as 1930, but despite this, according to the ILO, 21 million people are now victims of forced labour, generating an illegal profit of $150 million each year in the private economy. Forced labour is a real global problem, affecting all regions and countries in the world, industrialised or developing, rich or poor. Forced labour is the opposite of decent work, in violation of all its fundamental norms. In this respect, the 2014 Protocol, in addition to the Convention on Forced Labour, is a binding legal instrument aimed at strengthening prevention, protection and compensation measures, as well as doubling efforts to eliminate contemporary forms of slavery.  By ratifying this Protocol, States undertake to ensure that all victims have access to all possible remedies, as well as that competent authorities have the right not to prosecute victims for illegal activities they have been forced to perform.  The ratification of this protocol is therefore an important step in the fight against slavery. I therefore voted in favour of ratifying the 2014 Protocol on Forced Labour.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation in accordance with Community decision-making.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Recommendation as Protocol 2014 aims to address gaps in the implementation of the Convention and to make progress in preventing trafficking for the purposes of labour exploitation, as well as in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour. In 1930, in adopting the Convention to which this Recommendation refers, the ILO urged States to end and criminalize the use of forced labour. It is regrettable that more than 80 years later, nearly 21 million people in the world continue to be victims of forced labour, and with this Protocol we continue to walk in the direction of preventing these human rights violations from continuing to take place. The ratification of this Protocol is an important step in the fight against trafficking in human beings, as well as in ensuring the rights of victims of crime throughout Europe. With our vote we support Parliament's approval so that Member States can ratify the Protocol as soon as possible and thus maintain a commitment in the fight against forced labour.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for as I agree that the fight against forced labour should be effective and I support ratification of the Protocol.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The ratification by the Member States of the Protocol will make it easier to combat traffickers, and I therefore welcome the draft Council decision and I propose that Parliament give its consent, and I call on the Member States to ratify the Protocol without delay.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation on the ratification of the 2014 Protocol to the 1930 Forced Labour Convention, which concerns matters relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters in cases of forced labour. The 1930 Forced Labour Convention of the ILO is one of the ILO’s eight fundamental Conventions that make up the core international labour standards, and it is considered a human rights instrument. By supporting this text Member States will be enabled to ratify this 2014 Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Convention of 1930, an important step considering that the EU is committed to promoting human rights and decent work, and to eradicating trafficking in human beings, both internally and in its external relations.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The document invites Member States to ratify those parts of the Convention on European competition matters by the end of 2016. We are talking about a Convention which aims to make progress in combating trafficking in persons for the purpose of labour exploitation as well as compensating those who are victims of forced labour. That is why I consider it necessary to support the rapporteur's proposal and vote in his favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ILO estimates that in the EU 880,000 people work hard: many of them women victims of sexual exploitation; so a greater effort is needed from EU states and institutions, including within their own economies. In this direction, I voted in favour of the report because it facilitates the fight against trafficking and the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Forced labour is a disgrace. It harms the rights and dignity of the individual. Today, it is estimated that there are still around 21 million people worldwide who are exploited and would make $150 billion a year.  I support this report because the protocol aims to take measures to prevent such abuses and because it could prevent people smuggling.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Forced labour remains a reality worldwide, with the International Labour Organization counting nearly 21 million people who are believed to be victims.  Reviving the fight against this situation and updating legislation to combat forced labour is a good thing. This is what the protocol adopted by the ILO in 2014 proposes to do. This legally binding instrument aims to combat "modern" forms of forced labour. Through the implementation of this protocol, States commit to developing national policies for plans to combat forced labour, including the introduction of sanctions against the instigators of these crimes, the improvement of and protection and compensation for victims of forced labour. The latter are often the most vulnerable populations, especially migrants who are particularly victims of abusive and fraudulent practices.  The report presented to the European Parliament proposes ratification of this protocol. I voted for it because it can improve binding tools in the fight against trafficking and make progress for respect for human rights.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation concerns the 2014 Protocol on the Convention on Forced Labour, which is one of the eight key World Labour Organisation (ILO) conventions on international labour standards. With the adoption of the Convention in 1930, the International Labour Conference called on member countries to put an end to the use of forced labour. However, more than 80 years later, the ILO estimates that at least 20.9 million people worldwide are victims of forced labour. The Protocol requires countries that are part of the ILO to develop national policies and action plans for the effective and lasting suppression of forced labour. The ratification of the Protocol is an important step in judicial cooperation in criminal matters and in the fight against trafficking in human beings in order to guarantee the inalienable rights of victims.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It is recommended that the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour be ratified in order to combat forced and compulsory labour and trafficking in human beings worldwide. The purpose of the draft Council decision is to authorise the Member States to ratify those parts of the Protocol that fall within the competence of the EU. We must therefore support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agreed with the Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision authorising Member States to ratify the 2014 Protocol to the Convention on Forced or Compulsory Labour, 1930, of the International Labour Organisation, with regard to Articles 1 to 4 of the Protocol on issues relating to judicial cooperation in criminal matters in the interests of the European Union. The Protocol creates legal obligations for the ratifying States and can only be ratified by States that have also ratified the Convention. According to the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Union, Member States cannot decide to ratify the Protocol outside the framework of the EU institutions, as it falls partly within the competence of the EU. The protocol aims to fill implementation gaps and make progress in averting trafficking in human beings for the purpose of labour exploitation and in the protection and compensation of victims of forced labour.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the Protocol of 2014 on the Forced Labour Convention of the International Labour Organization with regard to matters related to judicial cooperation in criminal matters. My position in that matter can simply be explained by the following.  During the last Plenary Session I voted in favour on the same Protocol – on the issues concerning the social policy. At that time, I stated that preventing the trafficking of labour exploitation and compensating the victims of forced labour should be of high importance to us. I still believe this is a very important aspect. The aspect we, as the European Union, should focus our attention on. According to statistics millions of people are forced to work – not only in undeveloped countries, but even in the developed ones! However, in order to stop this problem, or at least minimise it, we have to support the parts of the Protocol that fall into competences of the EU such as the articles related to social policies as well as judicial cooperation.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the ILO Convention on Forced Labour: judicial cooperation in criminal matters, which aims to prevent trafficking in human beings for labour exploitation and to protect and compensate victims of forced labour. We need effective measures to tackle forced labour and ratifying this protocol will make it easier to prosecute people traffickers. It is a disgrace to all of us that millions of people around the world are still in forced labour.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Protocol to the ILO Forced Labour Agreement. Within this framework, Parliament authorised the Member States to adopt those parts of the Protocol which fall within the competence of the European Union, since the Member States cannot decide to adopt them on their own. I fully support the objectives of the Agreement on Forced or Compulsory Labour and find it sad that, even 80 years after its adoption, its main objective, the complete elimination of forced labour, has not been met. I therefore think that this subject needs to be addressed more intensively, in particular by the status of victims of forced labour, through these victims and their access to justice and proper compensation.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject control measures to the substance known as 4-methylamphetamine. It has been illegally distributed without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as it has been associated with several deaths in various Member States due to their high toxicity.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances are extremely dangerous to human life. They are the cause of many forfeitures and can eventually lead to the death of their dependent consumers. Further research is needed to better assess the harmful effects of these substances.  However, we have enough elements to put them through control measures. For example, the report aims to establish rules to severely regulate the use of 4-methylamphetamine throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services.   With regard to a problem which requires the cooperation of all Member States, I believe that it is a useful text that will facilitate the repression of the trafficking concerned. So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am on record as supporting a ban on so-called legal highs in the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, there are two problems here. Firstly, it is inappropriate for this matter to be dealt with at European level. Drug policy should always remain firmly within the domain of the Member States. For example, Portugal and the Netherlands have a much more liberal stance than many in the UK would be happy to adopt. That is a matter for the national governments, and this resolution is in effect a backdoor means of handing power to the European Union. Secondly, individual substance bans are an ineffective tool: changing from one substance to another of similar chemical composition is too easy. Overarching legislation, rather than individually referencing chemicals, is what is needed. So, although I support the general principle, I felt that I must abstain on these votes.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to promote the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances that threaten the health of Europeans.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to impose control measures and criminal sanctions on certain psychotropic substances, as provided for under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. According to the study, 4-methylamphetamine use can cause acute health problems and undesirable effects, and such cases have already been reported. Between 2012 and 2012, 21 deaths were recorded in four Member States, with 4-methylamphetamine detected in samples taken after death. I agree with the need to take control measures in favour of this substance, as it poses a risk to human health.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Yes, this new psychotropic substance must be subject to control measures throughout the European Union. This will require improved cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services and the protection agencies of our respective citizens. That is why I validated this decision by my vote.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In accordance with EU legislation on the exchange of information, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control this psychoactive chemical throughout the Union. The illicit presence and manufacture of this substance is documented in several Member States and several deaths due to it have been recorded within the Union. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to follow the Council's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. 4-methylamphetamine is a synthetic derivative methylized in an amphetamine ring. It has appeared on the illicit amphetamine market, on which it is sold and used as an amphetamine, a regulated drug. A total of 21 deaths were recorded in four Member States, in which 4-methylamphetamine alone or in combination with one or more other substances, particularly amphetamine, was found in post-mortem samples. The report should call on Member States to submit the new psychoactive substance 4-methylamphetamine to EU-wide control measures. Given the health risks it poses, I voted for this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 4-3amphetamine to control measures, since it is currently used to synthesize chemical drugs and psychotropic substances, and I believe that its use must be subject to stricter controls in the Member States.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. 2012 There have been 21 cases of deaths in four Member States, where 4-methylamphetamine has been detected alone or in combination with one or more substances, especially amphetamine, in autopsies. Although the available information does not allow to determine with certainty the role of 4-methylamphetamine in these deaths, in some cases the substance was the main drug detected, with levels comparable to those found in certain cases of death caused by amphetamine use. I voted in favour of subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the Union. This substance carries significant health risks, as attested by its detection in several reported fatalities, especially when used in combination with other substances. Due also to its great similarity in appearance and effects with amphetamine, the fact that it can be consumed inadvertently, as well as its limited medical value and use, justify the decision to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the Union. The adoption of control measures at Union level can also help prevent 4-methylamphetamine from becoming an alternative to amphetamine in illegal drug markets.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament supports the Council's draft on the application of control measures to the psychoactive substance 4-methylamphetamine. The European Parliament and the Council have agreed, in accordance with a joint 2005 decision, to exchange information on new psychoactive substances, on their risk assessments and to provide for control measures. The development of psychoactive substances is particularly dangerous for human health and the environment and urgent action by the Member States is therefore necessary. The joint decision on the exchange, risk assessment and control of information on new psychoactive substances shall draw attention to information on suspected adverse reactions to be transmitted in accordance with the established pharmacovigilance system. This Decision also provides for an assessment of the risks associated with these new psychoactive substances with a view to authorising the control measures applied in the Member States for the use of new psychoactive substances.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it of the utmost importance that the legislation keeps pace with the incredibly rapid development of new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes caused by the slowness of the legislation. Almost daily we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but often are not yet considered illegal.  In my opinion, we need to ensure that member state authorities have adequate legal instruments in place to effectively counter the production and distribution of these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in a timely manner to prevent further tragedies. For these reasons, I supported the report as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the position of the group and the rapporteur, Mr Boni, to fully support the positions of the Commission and the European Council. Control measures, or even a ban on a synthetic substance called 4-methylamphetamine in all 28 countries, is welcome, as the number of poisonings and even deaths rises sharply.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this report and the ban because 4-methylamphetamine is an amphetamine derivative that is responsible for 21 malpractice deaths according to official EU statistics. Young people are the target group of consumers and as such suffer the most harm from consumption. Deaths have been registered across Europe, and recently a teenager died in the middle of consumption in Croatia. Some of the compounds that are on the market are extremely strong and can cause consequences such as increased pressure, paranoia, psychosis, nausea, seizures and in some cases – death. The most severe consequences occur because the active substance is incorrectly distributed per product during mixing and drying. As a result, some packages are many times stronger and more harmful than usual. The common market and the abolition of borders have brought multiple benefits to Europe, but in this case this freedom has negative side effects. Member States cannot tackle the problem of 'legal drugs' on their own, as they cannot keep up with the speed at which new compounds appear.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that, considering all the elements in our possession (cases of death, limited therapeutic usefulness, etc.) with regard to 4-3lanphetamine, it may be useful to subject it to control measures throughout the Territory of the Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject 4-methylamphetamine, a psychotropic substance, to control measures throughout the European Union. This substance has already caused a dozen deaths suggesting that it poses a sufficiently significant danger for its use to be better supervised. It seems clear that further studies need to be carried out to better understand the health risks that individuals face after absorbing this substance. It is essential that these controls are introduced at European level so as not to hinder cross-border cooperation between the various national services.   That is why I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. Between 2010 and 2012, 21 deaths were reported in four Member States, with 4-methylamphetamine alone or in combination with other substances. In some cases, the predominant substance detected was 4-methylamphetamine. This substance is a synthetic derivative by methylating the nucleus of amphetamine, a controlled substance that produces physical effects comparable to those produced by other stimulants such as amphetamine. Although scientific evidence on global risks and specific consumption patterns of 4-methylamphetamine is still limited at this time, there are reasons for subjecting the substance to control measures at Union level. Furthermore, taking into account the fact that the manufacture, trafficking and supply of 4-methylamphetamine appear to involve organised crime and given the similarity of this substance to amphetamine, the possibility of 4-methylamphetamine becoming an alternative to amphetamine justifies all the more the subjection of the substance to control measures. I voted in favour of the draft decision implementing the Council on the subjecting of 4-methylamphetamine to control measures, since the main objective is for the Member States to subject 4-methylamphetamine to the control measures and criminal sanctions provided for by their legislation, in accordance with their obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, These 4 reports regulate the control of new substances or currently used as chemical parts for drugs or new similar substances. Parliament is being asked for its approval for more controls on these substances.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the introduction of control measures on 4-ythylaphetamine, which is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine sold on the illicit market and on the Internet, where this substance was detected in a commercial product. The physical effects induced by the use of this substance are not yet well known, but the few reports available speak of negative stimulating effects that include hyperthermia, hypertension, anorexia, nausea, palpitations, insomnia, paranoia, anxiety and depression. It should also be noted that its combination with other amphetamines or caffeine may lead to a higher risk of overall toxicity. 4-ythylaphetamine has no established or recognized medical value and, apart from its use as an analytical reference standard and for scientific research, no other applications are available for this substance. Trade in 4-ylamphetamine within the Eu ropean Union must be subject to control measures, and that is why I voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which would subject 4-methlamphetamine to control measures. The substance in question is a heavy-duty substance associated with a number of deaths across EU countries. It has been sold on the illicit market as amphetamine and has no established or acknowledged medical value or use.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, I chose to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision as 4—methylamphetamine, like all new substances, should be controlled and carefully studied to foresee and prevent any undesirable effects after its use. It has already been linked to 21 deaths in the past two years and we must ensure that this does not happen again.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of the new psychoactive substance 4-3lanphetamine. On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject this new substance to control measures throughout the Union. As I regard the fight against drugs as a fundamental issue, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question aims to establish the control of new psychotropic substances whose use has already caused dozens of deaths to control measures throughout the EU.  Further research is needed to define its health and social risks, but it is clear that the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for subjecting these substances to control measures throughout the European Union. So I voted for this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the Council's draft implementing decision and call on the Council if it intends to derogate from the text adopted by Parliament to inform it of this.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject the substance 4-3lanphetamine to control measures. During the debate, the European Commission and the Council stressed the danger of this substance and the need to subject it to control measures, given also the number of deaths and intoxications caused by it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I fully agree with the Council decision to subject substances 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydroossazol-2-amine(4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylyl)-piperazine to control measures.  Although I am not an expert, I have noted that these new substances have resulted in a significant number of deaths and patients who have been intoxicated and that further tests are therefore needed to ensure the safety of European citizens. Finally, thanks to Mrs Michał Boni's report, it has been made clear how dangerous these new substances are to human beings, and the European Union cannot stand still in the face of these important health issues.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2005/387/JAI on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the dangers inherent in new drugs require rapid and concerted intervention by States at European level.  When a new substance is found, the Member State should report this to Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, which will also try to assess its risk to public health as well as associated crime. Once the procedure is complete, they may request control or prohibition measures from Member States. Although Parliament's involvement is unnecessary - given the exclusively technical content of this decision - Parliament must be consulted and has to give its opinion.  This psychoactive substance has been found in 15 Member States, caused several deaths, is in a very similar appearance to amphetamine and is usually distributed among the same groups linked to trafficking in it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 4-3lanphetamine is a very potent addictive stimulant. It is used in the medical field for specialist prescriptions, but the circulation of this product must be monitored in order to avoid the illicit and inappropriate trade and use of the chemical compound. Prolonged and excessive use of lythylanphetamine has been found to cause severe brain damage to those who take it. I therefore welcome the draft Council decision aimed at implementing control measures on the movement of 4-3lanphetamine in the Member States of the European Union.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A risk assessment report was submitted to the Commission detailing the increasing mortality rate and overall health detriments associated with the substance stated. I voted in favour of the proposal in question which aims to protect EU citizens from health and social risks by requesting Member States to legislate in relation to the substance in question to further avoid fatalities, within their own drug-abuse legislative framework.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of the new psychoactive substance thylanphetamine. On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject this new substance to control measures throughout the Union, so I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject control measures to the substance known as 4-methylamphetamine. It has been illegally distributed without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as it has been associated with several deaths in various Member States due to their high toxicity.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal since it invites Member States to subject 4-methylamphetamine, which is a psychoactive substance, to control measures across the Union. This is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine which is sold on the illicit amphetamine market. So far there have been 21 fatalities registered in four Member States where the presence of this substance has been detected in post-mortem samples. As a result of the health risks it poses, I agree that this psychoactive substance should be subjected to control measures across the Union.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that the draft decision on subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures is a welcome one.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the implementation of the decision subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures within the Member States. These new substances pose a danger, resulting in a significant number of deaths and poisonings. Considering that this report contributes to better protection of European citizens, I voted in favour.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. 4-methylamphetamine is a psychoactive substance that damages the central nervous system and impairs mental functions. Currently legal and for sale on the internet, it replaces "traditional" drugs and spreads on the internal market.  From now on, this substance should only be used for research and scientific development purposes. It will be permanently restricted and subject to the EU's criminal law provisions, which is in line with the application of the European precautionary principle.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we be on the agenda with new drugs being marketed by drug traffickers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, exploiting legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is essential that at European level there should be a more active concern about the control of psychoactive substances. There is a wide variety of substances that are legal to date and are spreading in European society, especially through the internet. These are real drugs that pose a real danger to European citizens both for individual health and for public health. These new psychoactive drugs and the dangers associated with them are often little known by users.  Methylamphetamine is a synthetic drug that has appeared on the illicit amphetamine market. This substance is very dangerous. 21 cases of death were recorded in four Member States and its presence was detected in 15 Member States. A harmonised European regulation to control this substance would improve cross-border cooperation to prevent it from becoming the legal substitute for amphetamine in the drug market.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the steps endorsed by this report and its sister report which would result in some of the most lethal psychoactive substances – or legal highs – being closer regulated or banned altogether.  In my constituency, Northern Ireland, there has been a spate of recent deaths, particularly among young people, caused exclusively by this scourge. Earlier this year, a case brought by Belfast City Council resulted in the conviction of three individuals who had failed to comply with safety regulations in the sale of these substances.  While this outcome was sadly too late for many who had paid the ultimate price of the damage wrought by these drugs, the verdict was the first of its kind in the United Kingdom. I hope that it acts as a deterrent and sends a message that preying on those who are vulnerable to these influences must end. However, prosecuting in line with the current controls on these products cannot be enough. Stricter regulation or outright bans must be brought forward, and I and my party will continue to lead this fight in every aspect of our representation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up to date with new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, exploiting legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because to combat the trafficking of synthetic drugs it is essential to exchange information, assess risks and control new psychoactive substances, in particular 4-methylamphetamine.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better control of this substance.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because I feel we are continuing down a failed road and that what is proposed is a denial of reality.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more controls for the substances in question.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the inclusion of 4-methylamphetamine in control measures, because I believe that every new psychoactive substance should be subject to risk control and evaluation and the results of the controls should be disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to European Union legislation on information exchange, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Commission proposes to control, throughout the whole territory of the European Union, this psychoactive substance. The presence and illicit manufacture of the substance is confirmed in several Member States and several deaths caused by it have been recognised within the European Union. The report supports the Commission’s proposal. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of all these implementing decisions in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. It is vitally important to keep up to date with the new drugs being constantly developed by drug traffickers and criminal organisations. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive substances which change constantly in order to take advantage of legislative gaps. As we witness day by day, these new drugs are not only extremely toxic and have caused large numbers of deaths, but are often not even recognised as illegal. We must enable our law enforcement authorities to counter such criminal activity, providing them with the necessary instruments to fight back the spreading of these new substances. At the same time we must make sure that schools are supported in education and prevention activities. Special attention must be given also to helping the young victims and their families.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's opinion on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 4-3amphetamine, a synthetic derivative of amphetamine, to control measures. The risks associated with this substance are lethal, twenty-one deaths have been recorded in four Member States, in which autopsy has detected traces of this substance. 4-3lanphetamine sold in the form of pasta, powder, tablet and liquid has even appeared in e-commerce and distributed as amphetamine.  Since this substance has no known, proven or recognised therapeutic properties or uses in the Union, and which is already subject to control in ten Member States, I very much hope that the remaining Member States will subject this substance to control measures, in order to avoid problems in law enforcement and judicial cooperation across borders. Finally, only control measures at Union level can help prevent the substance in question from developing as an alternative to amphetamine on the markets for illegal drugs.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on control measures for 4-methylamphetamine, as I consider uniform, appropriate, technically applicable rules to be very important in this context.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the introduction of control measures for 4-methylamphetamine. The number of poisonings and deaths caused by this dangerous drug is enormous. We must take measures to prevent the spread of such psychoactive substances, which are often not considered illegal.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Risk Assessment Report reveals that there is limited scientific evidence available on the characteristics and risks of 4-methylamphetamine and points out that further studies are required on the overall health and social risks associated with the substance. However, and as a result of the health risks it poses, the Council decision proposes that it should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EEDTO) has ruled that psychotropic substance 4-methylamphetamine poses health risks. Support, therefore, subject this new psychotropic substance to control measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft given the obvious public health risk arising from the illegal sale of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. The first is a derivative of two substances that are already banned, and the second is much higher toxicity than morphine. In addition, there is no evidence that any of the substances have any medical or legitimate use of any other kind. Although there is no extensive scientific basis on the harmful effects of these substances, we rely on the precautionary principle to support their immediate prohibition.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as the proposal aims to invite the Member States to subject new psychoactive substances to control measures across the EU. The substance 4-methylamphetamine is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine which has emerged on the illicit amphetamine market. So far there have been 21 fatalities in four Member States which have been attributed to the drug. Given the health risk posed by it, I agree with the Council decision which proposes that it should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures. 4-methylamphetamine belongs to the phenethylamine family and is chemically very close to amphetamine. Risk assessment reports to date reveal that there is limited scientific evidence available on the characteristics and risks of 4-methylamphetamine and points out that further studies are required on the overall health and social risks associated with the substance. The evidence available provides sufficient grounds for subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures across the European Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. Both the Commission and the European Council have highlighted the fact that the new substances have provoked a large amount of toxicity and therefore a large number of deaths. I support the stance of the Commission and the European Council regarding the danger surrounding these new substances and I therefore also believe in the strict necessity of control.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with a view to the maintenance of control measures for new drugs. It is of the utmost importance to be aware of the newer and new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We need to stop the spread of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified to exploit legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new substances that are toxic, in many cases causing death, but most of the time they are not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I support enforcement decisions aimed at introducing controls at the European Union's borders on certain psychoactive substances.  Currently, these substances, whose marketing is favoured by the internet, are spreading alarmingly in Europe. Their use is poorly controlled and their effects unknown, the national authorities of several Member States have identified several cases of deaths and direct or indirect accidents related to the consumption of these substances. That is why I share the analysis of providing strict supervision of these substances and limiting their sale and use in the European Union as much as possible.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft given the obvious public health risk arising from the illegal sale of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. The first is a derivative of two substances that are already banned, and the second is much higher toxicity than morphine. In addition, there is no evidence that any of the substances have any medical or legitimate use of any other kind. Although there is no extensive scientific basis on the harmful effects of these substances, we rely on the precautionary principle to support their immediate prohibition.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision on subjecting the substance 4-methylamphetamine to control measures because, according to current information and knowledge, it is clear that 4-methylamphetamine causes serious psychological and health adverse consequences such as anorexia, insomnia, hyperthermia, depression and many others.  4-methylamphetamine is a derivative of methamphetamine that does not have authorisation to be placed on the EU market and has no proven medical value. In addition, 4-methylamphetamine is produced and distributed by the same organized criminal groups engaged in methamphetamine trafficking.  Therefore, I strongly support the subjecting of 4-methylamphetamine to control measures for the safety of all CITIZENS of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused the death of several people. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services. The report also provides for better public protection from the risks caused by the use of these substances. So I voted FOR.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on subjecting 4—methylamphetamines to control measures as there are still debates about legal highs and recreational drugs. These matters are not competencies of the EU and should be decided at nation-state level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michal Boni's report on the decision to continue the controls recommended by the Commission and the Council on 4-methylamphetamine in the Member States because of the toxicity of this substance which has sometimes led to deaths. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because 4-methylamphetamine is a product that appears to pose great risks to human health and therefore needs further monitoring and research.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposed measures are appropriate and fall within the competence of the Union, not least because control measures are to be made uniform in order to make the internal market work. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. There have been a total of 21 fatalities registered in four Member States associated with the new psychoactive substance. The risk assessment report reveals that there is limited scientific evidence available on the substance and points out that further studies are required on the overall health and social risks associated with the substance. However, and as a result of the health risks it poses, I agree that it should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The text on the subjection of methamphetamine to control measures has passed the European Parliament very readily and I am glad that I was able to help. Methamphetamine is now probably the most dangerous drug that has destroyed the lives of hundreds of thousands of people and families around the world. The Czech Republic is currently the largest illegal producer of meth in Europe, despite the fact that the National Drug Control Centre achieves very good results. However, the problem, which is often perceived as purely Czech, also needs to be looked at through Pan-European optics. A persistent trend in the production of methamphetamine is the extraction of pseudoephedrine from over-the-market medicines, which are sold without any restrictions in some European countries. As the popularity of methamphetamine has increased in recent years, coupled with the increasing production capacity of brewhouses, the amount of toxic waste that ends uncontrollably in water and the wild and poses a significant threat to the environment, animals and human life and health is also increasing. The topic of methamphetamine is therefore very complex and it is therefore good that we are dealing with it with our European partners. However, why my colleague Petr Mach voted against the text is a mystery to me. Surely he, too, must recognize that individual freedom has its limits, especially when we talk about such highly addictive substances destroying individuals, families, and communities.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up to date with new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively counter these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – 4-ythylanphetamine is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine, phythylated to the aromatic ring, which occurs mainly in seized samples, in the form of a powder or paste in combination with amphetamine or caffeine, but which has also been observed in tablet form and liquid form. Being similar to amphetamine as far as effects are concerned, I believe that continuity of control measures must be ensured, preventing it from becoming an alternative to amphetamine on the markets for illegal drugs.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft enforcement decision of the Council subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures. A total of 21 deaths have already been recorded in four Member States, in which 4-methylamphetamine alone or in association with one or more other substances was found in post-mortem samples. Further research is needed to define the health and social risks of this psychotropic substance, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to the protection of the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it protects the peoples of Europe, through cross-border police cooperation, against this new psychotropic substance.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a consultation of the European Parliament on Council decisions on the inclusion by Member States of specific control measures on substances which have been considered psychotropic and toxic. Having found several dozen deaths in different Member States from one of these substances (some of them conventional drugs), it has been decided to subject to specific risk assessment and control measures, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because 4-methylamphetamine is a toxic substance that must be subject to strict control measures in the EU states. This substance has appeared on the illicit amphetamine market, where it is sold and used as a controlled drug, amphetamine. 4-methylamphetamine is produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the trafficking of amphetamine. With the adoption of this report, this psychoactive substance will be subject to strict control measures: a rapid exchange of information between Member States' authorities and EU bodies (Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction), a risk assessment by a scientific committee and a European procedure for the control of notified substances. Union States must endeavour to subject this psychotropic substance to the control measures and criminal sanctions provided for by their legislation, in accordance with their obligations under the UN Convention against Illicit Drug Trafficking. We must combat drug use at European level and ensure a high level of protection of the health of our citizens through close cooperation between the Union and the Member States.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ MeP Michał Boni's report discusses subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures after a scientific committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction carried out a risk assessment. I supported the Report because of the importance of combating drug abuse, which poses a major Union problem. 4-methylamphetamine originates in the illicit amphetamine market and is used and sold as a controlled drug amphetamine. It has a similar effect to other stimulants, and 21 deaths are registered, alone or in combination with one or more substances, especially amphetamines.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 4-methylamphetamine, which was detected more than 60 years ago and has since been used with variable frequency, is a very strong substance, which can be dangerous for unconscious use (e.g. for slimming or serotonin elevations). A few years ago (2012-2013), a few dozen people died from amphetamine use in Europe, with traces of 4-methylamphetamine also found in their blood at the same time. Given the situation with the use of various chemical substances in the world and in Europe in particular, control over such substances and other similar substances is very necessary, as it would guarantee not only a higher level of public health, but also potentially reduce sudden mortality among mainly young people using health-threatening substances.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the inclusion of 4-methylamphetamine in control measures, because this report strengthens the powers of the European Parliament, since it asks the European Parliament to be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this request for control measures. According to studies, 4-methylamphetamine has already caused dozens of deaths and, although further research is needed, this is enough to impose control measures throughout the European Union. This will protect the public from the risks associated with this substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report implementing the decision on subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 4-3amphetamine to control measures. This substance, with a stimulating effect, has no known, proven or recognised therapeutic properties or uses from the European Union and poses serious risks to the health of citizens. Introducing control measures for these substances throughout Europe is important to avoid the serious damage that their consumption or development entails and is a fundamental response to the emergence of new harmful substances.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The debate between the European Commission and the European Council has shown that 4-3amphetamine has caused a huge number of deaths and intoxications. Mrs Michał Boni's report reflects a real awareness of the dangers that these substances could cause in the absence of adequate control measures. That is why I have chosen to support the document with a vote in favour.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because 4-lytilanphetamine is a psychotropic substance which, without proper control, proves potentially dangerous. During the debate, the European Commission and the Council brought to the attention of those present the large number of people who were intoxicated or even died as a result of taking this substance. I therefore believe that it is necessary for national legislation in this area to be implemented by Community regulations.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of substances/drug 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 and should therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. With the manipulation of synthetic molecules new psychoactive substances appear.  4-methylamphetamine is one of these substances, derived from amphetamines and without known therapeutic use, it is now used as a substitute substance for amphetamines in the illicit drug trade. This substance causes significant health risks due to its toxicity to the body and its apparent similarity to amphetamines. The report before us validates the Council's proposal to subject this substance to control measures.  Because of the health risks it poses, as demonstrated by its discovery in several cases of death, I vote FOR

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused deaths. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. As well as protecting the public from the risks caused by the use of these substances. The congressman voted FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council implementing decision subjectto 4-methylamphetamine to control measures is part of the need for control and risk assessment of new psychoactive substances, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the consultation to combat the abuse and trafficking of drugs, including the risk assessment of new psychoactive substances.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the Council's draft decision to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the European Union. The measures taken against this substance currently differ from one Member State to another. Harmonisation at European level makes perfect sense, in particular in order to facilitate the cooperation of the law enforcement and judicial services of the Member States. The fragmentation of Member States' actions in this area can only undermine the effectiveness of our fight against drugs. Once a new substance appears on the drug market, Member States should agree as soon as possible to adopt a coordinated approach to controlling the new substance and preventing its use.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures across the Union. The substance in question is distributed as a dangerous drug, with 21 deaths reported in four Member States between 2010 and 2012 in post-mortem samples. I welcome the fact that the aim of this proposal is to call on the Member States to subject the production, sale and supply of 4-methylamphetamine to the criminal penalties provided for in their legislation. Furthermore, subjecting a substance to control within the Union could help to prevent problems in cross-border law enforcement and judicial cooperation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to invite the Member States to subject the new psychoactive substance to control measures across the European Union, which is very important. The substance 4—methylamphetamine is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine. It has emerged on the illicit amphetamine market where it is sold and used as the controlled drug, amphetamine. The information available suggests that 4-methylamphetamine is produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamine. The risk assessment report reveals that there is limited scientific evidence available on the characteristics and risks of 4-methylamphetamine and points out that further studies are required on the overall health and social risks associated with the substance. However, and as a result of the health risks it poses, the Council decision proposes that it should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council intends to take a decision on the subject of eight relatively new psychoactive substances. They are all present in the Member States of the European Union and are distributed on the Internet, and deaths have been recorded in all contexts. Libe, the ep's competent committee, almost unanimously supported the draft decisions in its reports. Given their proven danger, I support their control myself.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Four reports are proposed at this session to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures across the EU.  The affected products are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. Each of these substances has already caused dozens of deaths.
