Further research is needed to define the exact health risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union. The aim of these decisions is to avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to allow the protection of the public from the risks associated with the consumption of these substances in a precautionary manner.  These initiatives should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. We have observed the appearance and proliferation of new psychoactive substances, many of them escaping member states' legal prohibitions and restrictions, since these "drugs" are easily manipulated and tampered with in laboratories. 4-methylamphetamine — a new amphetamine-derived psychoactive substance, which has already been discovered in 15 Member States and has even been discovered in one of them as a laboratory for its production — has caused 21 fatalities. I believe that the European Union should find a mechanism to address this situation, protect consumers and prevent markets from permeability to new illicit substances.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns one of four reports on the submission of new psychotropic substances to control measures throughout the Union. These substances are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. They pose a public health problem as they are responsible for the deaths of dozens of people. While further scientific studies are needed to determine the exact health risks, it seems that the first elements are sufficient to constitute legitimate grounds for subjecting these substances to controls in the EU to avoid potential obstacles to cross-border cooperation. So I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which supports efforts to collectively tackle the sale of legal highs which have caused a number of death and fatalities in the UK and across Europe. Moreover, the information available suggests that some of the psychoactive substances such as 4-methylamphetamine are produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamine. Trafficking occurs across borders and it is essential that Member States work together to disrupt the EU’s trafficking networks.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of the 4-ytilanphetamine decision would ensure the continuity and extension of control measures through Member States on new substances. During the debate, the Commission and the Council stressed that the new substances caused a large number of deaths and poisonings. Since the report supports the position of the two institutions on the danger of these new substances and the need for controls, I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will regulate control measures for the following drug substance: 4-methylamphetamine.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. 4-methylamphetamine is a stimulant substance that, in addition to hallucinogenic effects, also leads to rapid heart rate and pupil enlargement. Currently, there is limited information regarding this "drug". Due to the uncertainty, control measures are to be introduced. I support this report and vote in favour of it.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report approving the Council text calling on Member States to submit the substance 4-methylamphetamine to control measures by the European Union and to set up exchanges on the risks and analyses associated with this substance between states.  As this drug has psychostimulating capabilities that are highly addictive, it is urgent that its control be generalised and harmonised at European level. The report calls on Member States to legislate on the issue within the next 12 months.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The introduction of control measures is necessary to prevent the misuse of 4-methamphetamine.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the council's draft proposing a ban on amphetamine-like drugs found in caffeine.  In view of the health risks and other side effects of this substance, it is necessary to apply uniform control measures throughout Europe. It should be noted that the above controls will prevent the spread of the drug. Tougher criminal sanctions will help curb the illicit amphetamine market where it is sold. It should be noted that this substance can become an alternative to amphetamine and cause extremely severe consequences. In order to avoid particularly dire consequences, I support the proposal for this 4-MA synthetic substance to be banned in the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the rapporteur's work and thanking him for his work, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of introducing 4-methylamphetamine control measures, as the substance caused several deaths and poisonings, according to the European Commission. It is necessary to establish appropriate controls on this substance and to carry it out in all Member States in order not to unduly endanger the health of citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ According to data from the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, between 6,500 and 8,500 deaths directly caused by excessive, irregular and illicit drug use have been reported in Europe each year. Throughout the countries of the European Union, including in the Republic of Croatia, cannabis is the most commonly used drug, followed by amphetamines.  4-methylamphetamine is a derivative of amphetamines, originated in the illicit amphetamine market where it is sold. This hazardous substance was discovered in fifteen Member States of the European Union, while one country also reported production on its territory. Although extensive data on the consequences of using the substance are not yet available, limited scientific evidence suggests a number of health risks associated with the use of this drug, especially in combination with other substances, when it becomes life-threatening.  I therefore fully support the Commission's decision to subject this new psychoactive substance, 4-methylamphetamine, to additional control measures across the European Union and have therefore supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns one of four reports on the submission of new psychotropic substances to control measures across the EU. These substances are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45.  They pose a public health problem as they are responsible for the deaths of dozens of people. While further scientific studies are needed to determine the exact health risks, it appears that the first elements are sufficient to provide legitimate grounds for subjecting these substances to controls in the EU to avoid potential obstacles to cross-border cooperation. So I voted for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ 4-methylamphetamine is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine that is most commonly illegally sold and used as amphetamine. It is produced and resold by the same criminal groups. So far, 21 deaths have been reported directly related to the use of this substance. The current system of regulation at European level shows that, despite the dangers this substance poses to humans, only 8 member states control 4-methylamphetamine as part of the overall legal framework of drug testing. Due to the fatal consequences this substance can cause, as well as the lack of control at European level, I agree with Parliament's recommendation and support the proposal to introduce a single control system at European level.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒u2012 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine are chemical substances that have been proven to cause toxicity in humans, and have been found in a number of Member States, as substances associated with fatalities and detected in post-mortem causes. Some Member States use legal measures to control them, but all citizens in all Member States need to be protected. The risk assessment report shows that further research will be needed to identify the health and social risks of 4-methylamphetamine. However, the available evidence and information provide sufficient grounds for the need to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the Union. As a result of the health risks this poses, as documented upon detection in several reported deaths, from the fact that users may unknowingly consume it and lack of medical value or use, these chemistry substances should be subjected to control of measures in the Union. I therefore support a proposal aimed at inviting Member States to submit 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine control measures throughout the Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Until now, the decision adopted by the Council on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new drugs and synthetic drugs has proved to be a useful tool for Member States. During the debate in the LIBE Committee, the European Commission and the Council stressed that 33stphetamine has already caused a large number of deaths and poisonings. The report supports the position of the two institutions, agreeing on the danger of this new substance and the need for more controls. I am therefore in favour of its approval by Parliament.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU plays a crucial role in harmonising the permitted substances within its territory. Successive laws authorising or reversing the movement of certain chemicals deemed dangerous are intended to protect the health of European citizens. In this context, the European Parliament has supported the Council's position to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures, and I welcome that.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A 4-methylamphetamine (a psychoactive) is a synthetic derivative of amphetamine. While the risk assessment of this substance for health and society still lacks some scientific demonstration, there is already sufficient foundation for establishing control measures in the EU. There have been 21 deaths in 4 Member States related to the substance, which has been found in 15 Member States and is related to organised crime groups.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. 2012 There have been 21 cases of deaths in four Member States, where 4-methylamphetamine has been detected alone or in combination with one or more substances, especially amphetamine, in autopsies. Although the available information does not allow to determine with certainty the role of 4-methylamphetamine in these deaths, in some cases the substance was the main drug detected, with levels comparable to those found in certain cases of death caused by amphetamine use. I voted in favour of subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the Union. This substance carries significant health risks, as attested by its detection in several reported fatalities, especially when used in combination with other substances. Due also to its great similarity in appearance and effects with amphetamine, the fact that it can be consumed inadvertently, as well as its limited medical value and use, justify the decision to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures throughout the Union. The adoption of control measures at Union level can also help prevent 4-methylamphetamine from becoming an alternative to amphetamine in illegal drug markets.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft Council implementation decision subjecting 4-methylamphetamine to control measures and calls on the Council to consult again with the European Parliament in case it intends to substantially amend the text we have approved.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the use of the psychoactive substance 4-methylamphetamine has been identified in 15 Member States and there are well-founded doubts that it may be produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamines, it is essential to subject this substance to control measures throughout the Union for the health risks it poses. That is why I voted in favour of this Report, which approves the draft Council implementing decision on this matter.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council's decision to subject 4-3amphetamine, a substance with stimulating effects, considered by the European Union to be dangerous to the health of its citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft given the obvious public health risk arising from the illegal sale of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. The first is a derivative of two substances that are already banned, and the second is much higher toxicity than morphine. In addition, there is no evidence that any of the substances have any medical or legitimate use of any other kind. Although there is no extensive scientific basis on the harmful effects of these substances, we rely on the precautionary principle to support their immediate prohibition.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject control measures to the substance known as 4-methylamphetamine. It has been illegally distributed without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as it has been associated with several deaths in various Member States due to their high toxicity.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 4-3amphetamine to control measures. A psychotic substance, natural or synthetic, that affects the nervous system and causes stimulating or depressive effects, just like illicit drugs. The procedure voted on today provides for a ban on the manufacture and marketing of these substances, and also provides for criminal sanctions throughout Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe this matter is not an EU competency but instead should be addressed by nation-state governments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned about the health risks that 4—methylamphetamine poses, and I agree with the Council decision to subject it to control measures across the Union in order better to serve the interests of the citizens of not only the West Midlands but also the rest of the European Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution as I welcome the Council's decision to make new psychoactive substances (in this case 4-methylamphetamine), which affect the central nervous system, fall under control measures in the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because given the reports and results of many European relevant health institutions on 4-methylamphetamine, it is evident that this substance should be subjected to control measures in the European Union. It is a substance that has proven to be dangerous for human health and has already killed 21 people in Europe, when in fact it is a stimulating derivative of amphetamines that has been studied for appetite suppression purposes. Today, it appears on the EU market as a dangerous drug - a type of amphetamine.  As it is a substance produced and sold as a drug on illegal markets, and in particular online, while one Member State has also discovered that this drug is also produced on its territory, it should be banned and not allowed to come into the hands of citizens, especially children. So far, it is positive that as many as eight Member States have apparently brought this new drug under the control of their anti-drug laws, and other members need to do so.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the introduction of surveillance measures for 4-methylamphetamine. 4-methylamphetamine is a synthetic derivative that is mainly found in the form of a powder or paste, but also appears in tablet form and in liquid form. It has appeared in an illicit drug market where it is sold and used as a controlled drug amphetamine. The effects of consuming and combining 4-methylamphetamine with other substances, including amphetamines and caffeine, can cause an increased risk of body toxicity. 4-methylamphetamine was found in 15 Member States, including four Member States, where a total of 21 deaths were reported in which this substance was found in autopsy samples. 4-methylamphetamine has no recognised medical value or authorisation to access the Union market. As 10 Member States are already supervising 4-methylamphetamine, the introduction of Union-wide surveillance measures can help avoid problems in cross-border prosecution and judicial cooperation, and help prevent 4-methylamphetamine from developing into an alternative to amphetamines in the illicit drug market.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. I fully recognise the risks associated with the free sale of this substance. However, as practice has shown, a restrictive drug policy has more negative than positive consequences, and the ban on dangerous drugs leads to the development of new, even less safe and untested drugs, which entail new and unknown risks.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance to draw attention to new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively counter these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Legal highs, colloquially called various products containing psychoactive substances, contribute to the loss of health and life of thousands of People in Europe every year. The fight against them is particularly difficult, not only because of the problem with the detection of psychoactive substances in the body, but above all because manufacturers of legal highs make constant changes in their chemical composition, which prohibits production and sale.  Extending the list of substances subject to control measures is therefore the right step, but in the long term the continuous addition of further boosters differing only slightly in composition from previously banned ones is inefficient. In this regard, consideration should be given to another way of excluding harmful substances, that is, not on the basis of specific names or a detailed chemical composition, which is very easy to modify, but because of the effects of taking harmful stimulants. Otherwise, we will always be one step behind manufacturers and distributors of boosters.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague's text. I note, however, that when it comes to products that can become drugs, it is already difficult to find consistency and openness within national policy. I therefore have little hope at European level on this specific topic. If things change, I will gladly continue to participate in the debates and represent my citizens in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report aiming to subject 4-methylamphetamine to control measures. The substance 4-methylamphetamine emerged on the illicit amphetamine market in 2009. By the time of an EU risk-assessment in 2012, it had been detected in 15 Member States and there had been a total of 21 fatalities registered in four Member States related to its abuse. The controls are especially desirable because of the health risks it poses, especially when used in combination with other substances, its strong resemblance in appearance and effects with amphetamine, the fact that users may consume it unknowingly, and its limited medical value or use.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported a report subjecting the substance 4-methylamphetamine to surveillance measures, as this would prohibit the production of this psychoactive substance and its use would be punishable.  In fact, from 2010 to 2012, only four Member States found that the substance was linked to 21 deaths. Scientific research conducted by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction has shown that this substance has a similar impact on the human body and behaviours such as drugs, such as increasing blood pressure, nausea, headache, insomnia, paranoia, anxiety and depression.  As this substance has not been proven to have medical value, I believe that this ban will increase the health security of EUROPEAN Union citizens and combat cross-border crime.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision introducing 4-methylamphetamine control measures, as I believe that we need better data exchange, effective risk assessments and stricter controls on new psychoactive substances occurring on the black market. Only then can we be on track to prevent drug use among EU citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft given the obvious public health risk arising from the illegal sale of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. The first is a derivative of two substances that are already banned, and the second is much higher toxicity than morphine. In addition, there is no evidence that any of the substances have any medical or legitimate use of any other kind. Although there is no extensive scientific basis on the harmful effects of these substances, we rely on the precautionary principle to support their immediate prohibition.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures across the EU. This substance has already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define health and social risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for monitoring measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to the protection of the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances. I therefore voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council as the urgency of banning in all Member States a substance whose risk to public health is evident is imposed in all Member States. Between April and August 2012 alone, 24 deaths associated with consumption of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol were identified. The substance has no known medical or other use.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree that the synthetic drugs mentioned in the report should be subjected to control measures.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision speaks of new substances that have caused a large number of deaths and toxicity. The proposal aims to ensure the continuity of control measures in the Member States relating to these new substances and so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject control measures to the substance known as 4-methylamphetamine. It has been illegally distributed without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as it has been associated with several deaths in various Member States due to their high toxicity.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 4-methylamphetamine is a derivative of synthetic methylated ring of amphetamine, which has been predominantly seized in powder and paste in samples containing amphetamines and caffeine, but which has also appeared in tablets and liquids. The main chemical precursor to the synthesis of 4-methylamfetamine is 4—methyl—BMK, which appears to be being marketed on the Internet and is not controlled under the 1988 United Nations Convention against Illicit Trafficking in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained on the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on control measures for 4-methylamphetamine. I see no need to adopt control measures for psychoactive substances at European level. It is therefore quite right that certain Member States have agreed on derogations. The principle of subsidiarity is blatantly violated by a European regulation of these issues.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcomed the report on the inclusion of 4-methylamphetamine as well as three other new inam and psychotropic substances under the fast-track control measures. Unfortunately, legislation sometimes fails to keep up with human innovation in this dangerous field. At the same time, it is very necessary that these substances cannot be sold under the label that they are legal, which can make many appear harmless, with reports from different Member States suggesting that they are very dangerous substances with dozens of fatalities. And although we already regulate these substances by national law in Slovakia, the importance of Pan-European regulation and control is undeniable. I therefore supported all four reports.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject the substance known as indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures. According to a scientific risk assessment report this substance can cause tachycardia, hyperthermia, midriasis, agitations and tremors. Other than this, it has no known medical value either. This decision also makes it easier for Member States to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances are extremely dangerous to human life. They are the cause of many forfeitures and can eventually lead to the death of their dependent consumers. Further research is needed to better assess the harmful effects of these substances.  However, we have enough elements to put them through control measures. Thus, this report aims to establish rules to severely regulate the use of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole throughout the European Union and to develop measures of cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services.   With regard to a problem which requires the cooperation of all Member States, I believe that it is a useful text that will facilitate the repression of the trafficking concerned. So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am on record as supporting a ban on so-called legal highs in the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, there are two problems here. Firstly, it is inappropriate for this matter to be dealt with at European level. Drug policy should always remain firmly within the domain of the Member States. For example, Portugal and the Netherlands have a much more liberal stance than many in the UK would be happy to adopt. That is a matter for the national governments, and this resolution is in effect a backdoor means of handing power to the European Union. Secondly, individual substance bans are an ineffective tool: changing from one substance to another of similar chemical composition is too easy. Overarching legislation, rather than individually referencing chemicals, is what is needed. So, although I support the general principle, I felt that I must abstain on these votes.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to promote the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances that threaten the health of Europeans.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to impose control measures and criminal sanctions on certain psychotropic substances, as provided for under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The high toxicity of 5-(2-amino-propyl) indole and other synthetically produced psychoactive substances has a harmful effect on the human body. These chemicals may, among other things, result in rapid heartbeat and hyperthermia, but may also cause pupil dilation, restlessness and tremor, epileptic seizures. In addition, when they enter the body, they can interact with other substances, drugs or stimulants. From the beginning of 2012, it became known from the publication of several Member States that the use of these psychoactive substances had fatal consequences. If these new psychoactive substances become more widely available on the black market, this could greatly hamper the EU's fight against drug trafficking and use. On this basis, I supported the EU's imposition of these drugs under control measures and criminal sanctions.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Yes, this new psychotropic substance must be subject to control measures throughout the European Union. This will require improved cross-border cooperation between law enforcement agencies and the protection agencies of our respective citizens. That is why I validated this decision by my vote. It cannot be over again how much cooperation between our Member States has become as useful as it is necessary after the EU's internal borders have been abolished.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In accordance with EU legislation on the exchange of information, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control this psychoactive chemical throughout the Union. The illicit presence and manufacture of this substance is documented in several Member States and several deaths due to it have been recorded within the Union. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to follow the Council's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is a derivative of indole, obtained by synthesis, substituted for the phenyl side of the indole part of the molecule. It is a stimulant substance that can also produce hallucinogenic effects. It is available for sale on the internet and in specialist stores. Between April and August 2012, there were 24 deaths in four Member States, where 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, alone or associated with other substances, was detected in post-mortem samples.  However, due to the health risks involved, as evidenced by its detection in several reported deaths, this report proposes to invite Member States to subject this substance to control measures throughout the EU. Given this information, I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 5-(2aminopropyl) pain to control measures, as this is a component used to date to synthesize drugs and psychotropic substances, I believe it is necessary to subject its use to stricter controls.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Between April and August 2012, four Member States recorded 24 fatalities in which 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole had been detected separately or in combination with other substances in samples taken for autopsy. Although it is impossible to determine with certainty the role of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole in all fatalities, in some cases it has been recorded as a specific cause of death. If the availability and consumption of this new psychotropic substance were to expand, the consequences for individual and public health could be significant.  The available tests and information are sufficient grounds for subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures throughout the Union. Given the health risks posed, as attested by its detection in several of the reported fatalities, the fact that it could be inadvertently consumed and the absence of medical value or use, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol must be subject to control measures throughout the Union. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament approves the Council's draft on the application of control measures to the psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole. The European Parliament and the Council have agreed, in accordance with a joint 2005 decision, to exchange information on new psychoactive substances, on their risk assessments and to provide for control measures. The development of psychoactive substances is particularly dangerous for human health and the environment and urgent action by the Member States is therefore necessary. The joint decision on the exchange, risk assessment and control of information on new psychoactive substances shall draw attention to information on suspected adverse reactions to be transmitted in accordance with the established pharmacovigilance system. This Decision also provides for an assessment of the risks associated with these new psychoactive substances with a view to authorising the control measures applied in the Member States for the use of new psychoactive substances.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it of the utmost importance that the legislation keeps pace with the incredibly rapid development of new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified, taking advantage of legal loopholes created by the slowness of the legislation. Almost daily we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but often are not yet considered illegal.  In my opinion, we need to provide the national authorities with the right legal instruments so that they can effectively combat the production and distribution of these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in a timely manner to prevent further tragedies. For these reasons, I supported the report as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. It's exactly the same story as methylamphetamine. It is a dangerous synthetic substance which, even in my opinion, must be banned or controlled. The statistics are unforgiving, and for this reason I also supported this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that, considering all the elements in our possession (cases of death, limited therapeutic usefulness, etc.) with regard to the 5-(2 aminopropyl)indole, it may be useful to subject it to control measures throughout the Territory of the Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole, a psychotropic substance, to control measures throughout the European Union. This substance has already caused a dozen deaths suggesting that it poses a sufficiently significant danger for its use to be better supervised. It is clear that further studies need to be carried out to better understand the health risks that individuals face after absorbing this substance. It is essential that these controls are introduced at European level so as not to hinder cross-border cooperation between the various national services.   That is why I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, these four reports regulate the control of new substances or currently used as chemical parts for drugs or new similar substances. Parliament is being asked to approve more controls on these substances.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the introduction of control measures on the substance 5-(2aminopropyl)indole, which is a stimulating substance with possible hallucinogenic effects, available for sale on the Internet and in specialised stores as a 'chemical used for research'. Studies have not yet been published assessing its acute and chronic toxicity, psychological and behavioural effects or the potential for dependence, but we are aware of the acute toxicity of this substance, which can cause harmful effects in humans, such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, midriasis, agitation and tremor. If this new psychoactive substance were available on a larger scale, the impact in terms of people's health and public health could be considerable. In view of the health and social risks and the lack of therapeutic properties or uses, 5-(2-aminopropyl) must therefore be subject to control measures.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is aimed at preventing 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole from being sold in the EU as a drug for human consumption.  Four people died as a result of ingesting this substance in 2012 and many others suffered non-fatal intoxications. New psychoactive substances enter the market all the time and this legislation responds to one such discovered threat.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, I chose to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision to control 5—(2-aminopropyl) indole because it is a new substance and we do not at this time know the ramifications of being exposed to it.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of the new psychoactive substance 5-(2 aminopropyl)indole. On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject this new substance to control measures throughout the Union. As I regard the fight against drugs as a fundamental issue, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question aims to establish the control of new psychotropic substances whose use has already caused dozens of deaths to control measures throughout the EU. Further research is needed to define health and social risks, but it is clear that the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for subjecting these substances to control measures throughout the European Union. So I voted for this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Council Decision of 10 May 2005 on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychotropic substances, I am voting in favour of the Council Plan.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject the substance 5-(2 aminopropyl) to control measures. During the debate, the European Commission and the Council stressed the danger of this substance and the need to subject it to control measures, given also the number of deaths and intoxications caused by it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft because I fully agree with the Council's decision to subject substance 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures because it is considered in Mr Barrio's report to be dangerous and toxic to humans.  In addition, this drug results as a pain derivative with stimulating effects and has been openly sold as a drug by online sellers since 2011. Daily consumption of the drug can lead to high heart rate, anorexia, diuresis and mild hypothermia for about twelve hours. Finally, I fully agree with the position expressed by the European Commission and the European Council to subject this drug to additional controls because it has resulted in a significant number of deaths and intoxicated persons, and I believe that the European Union must give priority to the protection of its citizens.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2005/387/JAI on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the dangers inherent in new drugs require rapid and concerted intervention by States at European level.  When a new substance is found, the Member State should report this to Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, which will also try to assess its risk to public health as well as associated crime. Once the procedure is complete, they may request control or prohibition measures from Member States. Although Parliament's involvement is unnecessary - given the exclusively technical content of this decision - Parliament must be consulted and has to give its opinion.  The substance has been found in nine Member States and is already controlled in five, with several cases of deaths associated with its consumption known.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Data from the European Commission and the European Council show that these substances have caused a large number of deaths and intoxications. In this respect, I fully support this proposal, stressing the need to implement controls on these substances.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A risk assessment report was submitted to the Commission detailing the increasing mortality rate and overall health detriments associated with the substance stated. I voted in favour of the proposal in question which aims to protect EU citizens from health and social risks by requesting Member States legislate in relation to the substance in question to further avoid fatalities, within their own drug-abuse legislative framework.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of the new psychoactive substance. On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject this new substance to control measures throughout the Union, so I can only vote in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject the substance known as indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures. According to a scientific risk assessment report this substance can cause tachycardia, hyperthermia, midriasis, agitations and tremors. Other than this, it has no known medical value either. This decision also makes it easier for Member States to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal since it invites Member States to subject the new psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the EU. This substance is commercially available on the internet and from ‘head shops’. There have been a total of 24 fatalities registered in four Member States from April to August 2012. Based on the available evidence and information that exists, I agree that this psychoactive substance should be subjected to control measures across the EU.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, such as 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol, is a welcome one.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the implementation of the decision subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole to control measures within the Member States. These new substances pose a danger, resulting in a significant number of deaths and poisonings. Considering that this report contributes to better protection of European citizens, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. It is preferable that the substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole be subject to control measures in all EU Member States, because it can have harmful effects in humans.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole is a psychoactive substance that damages the central nervous system and impairs mental functions. Currently legal and for sale on the internet, it replaces "traditional" drugs and spreads on the internal market.  From now on, this substance should only be used for research and scientific development purposes. It will be permanently restricted and subject to the EU's criminal law provisions, which is in line with the application of the European precautionary principle.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is essential to adapt the European policy on combating psychoactive substances. Many substances that have so far been considered legal are spreading in European society, especially thanks to the Internet. However, these are real drugs that represent a real danger to European citizens both for individual health and for public health. The substance involved in this execution decision is a synthetic derivative of indole that can produce hallucinogenic effects, tachycardia and hyperthermia. Between April and August 2012, 24 deaths related to the drug were recorded in four European countries, while its presence was detected in nine Member States. European legislation to control these psychoactive drugs is therefore essential for better cross-border coordination in the fight against drugs.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up to date with new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified, exploiting legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because to combat the trafficking of synthetic drugs it is essential to exchange information, assess risks and control new psychoactive substances, namely 5-(2 aminopropil).

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better control of this substance.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because I feel we are continuing down a failed road and that what is proposed is a denial of reality.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more controls for the substances in question.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the inclusion of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indium in control measures because I believe that every new psychoactive substance should be subject to risk control and evaluation and the results of the controls should be disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to European Union legislation on information exchange, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Commission proposes to control, throughout the whole territory of the European Union, this psychoactive substance. The presence and illicit manufacture of the substance is confirmed in several Member States and several deaths caused by it have been recognised within the European Union. The report supports the Commission’s proposal. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of all these implementing decisions in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. It is vitally important to keep up to date with the new drugs being constantly developed by drug traffickers and criminal organisations. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive substances which change constantly in order to take advantage of legislative gaps. As we witness day by day, these new drugs are not only extremely toxic and have caused large numbers of deaths, but are often not even recognised as illegal. We must enable our law enforcement authorities to counter such criminal activity, providing them with the necessary instruments to fight back the spreading of these new substances. At the same time we must make sure that schools are supported in education and prevention activities. Special attention must be given also to help the young victims and their families.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I consider uniform, appropriate, technically applicable rules to be very important in this context.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the introduction of control measures for 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole. The number of poisonings and deaths caused by this dangerous drug is enormous. We must take measures to prevent the spread of such psychoactive substances.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to invite the Member States to subject the new psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the European Union. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is commercially available on the internet and from ‘head shops’, marketed as a ‘research chemical’. There were a total of 24 fatalities registered in four Member States from April to August 2012. That is why it is vital that the substance is subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (OEDT) has ruled that the psychotropic substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol presents health risks. Support, therefore, subject this psychotropic substance to control measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Council as the urgency of banning in all Member States a substance whose risk to public health is evident is imposed in all Member States. Between April and August 2012 alone, 24 deaths associated with consumption of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol were identified. The substance has no known medical or other use.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as it calls on Member States to subject a new psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the EU. This substance is commercially available on the internet and from ‘head shops’ and has been attributed to 24 fatalities registered in four Member States. Given the health risk posed by it, I agree that it should be subjected to control measures in the EU.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole (5—IT) to control measures. Four Member States have already reported a total of 24 fatalities where 5-IT has been detected in post-mortem samples. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is a synthetic derivative that contains a positional isomer of alpha-methyltryptamine (AMT), which belongs to the tryptamine family, many of which have hallucinogenic and other psychoactive effects in humans. Despite the structural similarities of 5-IT to AMT, 5-APB and phenethylamines such as MDA, it is difficult to predict the pharmacological profile of 5-IT based on a comparison with these other substances due to potential differences in mechanisms of action. There is to date no data available from scientific studies on its pharmacokinetics.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to ensure that these new substances continue to be controlled across all Member States. The two institutions have recognised the new substances as dangerous, as they have provoked many deaths due to toxicity. I support the rapporteur’s views expressing the dangerousness of these new substances and the need for strict controls to be put in place.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with a view to the maintenance of control measures for new drugs. It is of the utmost importance to be aware of the newer and new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified to take advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new substances that are toxic, in many cases causing death, but most of the time they are not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively counter these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I support enforcement decisions aimed at introducing controls at the European Union's borders on certain psychoactive substances.  Currently, these substances, which are promoted by the internet, are spreading alarmingly in Europe. Their use is poorly controlled and their effects unknown, the national authorities of several Member States have identified several cases of deaths and direct or indirect accidents related to the consumption of these substances. That is why I share the analysis of providing strict supervision of these substances and limiting their sale and use in the European Union as much as possible.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council as the urgency of banning in all Member States a substance whose risk to public health is evident is imposed in all Member States. Between April and August 2012 alone, 24 deaths associated with consumption of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole were identified. The substance has no known medical or other use.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision on subjecting 5-(2-aminopropil) to control measures due to the acute toxicity of the substance and the harmful consequences it may have for the human body.  5-(2-aminopropil) is a substance with hallucinogenic effects that is not used for medicinal purposes and has no medical benefit identified. Greater availability would certainly pose a greater threat to individuals and public health, but more research is needed to identify accurate health and social threats.  Therefore, I strongly support the subjecting of 5-(2-aminopropil) indole control measures for the safety of all CITIZENS of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused the death of several people. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject the indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. The report also provides for better public protection from the risks caused by the use of these substances. So I voted FOR.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures as there are still debates about legal highs and recreational drugs. These matters are not competencies of the EU and should be decided at nation-state level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleague Teresa Jimenez Becerril Barrio on the decision to continue the controls recommended by the Commission and the Council on 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole in the Member States because of the toxicity of this substance which sometimes leads to deaths. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because 5-(2 aminopropyl)indole is a dangerous substance for health. It must thereby be subject to control measures, and further research must be carried out.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposed measures are appropriate and fall within the competence of the Union, not least because control measures are to be made uniform in order to make the internal market work. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There have been a total of 24 fatalities registered in four Member States associated with the new psychoactive substance. The available evidence and information and the result of the health risks that it poses recommend that these substances should be subjected to control measures across the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance to be aware of the newer and new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified, exploiting legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I supported this report and other similar reports, given the importance of exchanging information, risk assessment and monitoring on new psychoactive substances. There are terrible dangers posed by rapidly spreading, widely available psychotropic psychotropic products, both for the health of individuals, especially young people, and for societies as a whole.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – 5-(2 aminopropyl)indole (5-IT) is an indolic derivative that can be interpreted as a positional isomer of alpha-methyltryptamine (AMT), but which does not belong to the chemical group of tryptamines. This substance has been considered as the main cause in numerous cases of death. I therefore believe that it is necessary to ensure the continuity of control measures; For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft enforcement decision of the Council subjecting the 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures. A total of 24 cases of death have already been recorded in four Member States, in which 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole or in association with one or more other substances was found in post-mortem samples. Further research is needed to define the health and social risks of this psychotropic substance, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to the protection of the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it protects the peoples of Europe, through cross-border police cooperation, against this new psychotropic substance.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a consultation of the European Parliament on Council decisions on the inclusion by Member States of specific control measures on substances which have been considered psychotropic and toxic. Having found several dozen deaths in different Member States from one of these substances (some of them conventional drugs), it has been decided to subject to specific risk assessment and control measures, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported The Report of Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio because of the importance of combating drug abuse, which is a major problem, especially among young people across the Union. It underlines the importance of further research into the health effects of 5-(2-aminopropil) indole, but analyses so far already show the necessity of subjecting it to control measures in the Union. The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction carried out a risk assessment and concluded that this substance is a stimulant that can also have hallucinogenic effects, and we can find it in the form of powders and tablets. There were 24 deaths registered in four Member States where 5-(2-aminopropil) indole was used independently or in combination with other substances and six member states had already adopted legal provisions for its control.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole first appeared in Albert Hoffman's laboratory in 1962 and was already classified as a "designer drug". This substance is very psychoactive and is nowadays actively sold on the black market. In Sweden alone, 14 people died from the use of the drug between April 2012 and June of the same year, all aged between 20 and 30. In some countries around the world, such as Australia, the UK and Denmark, as I know, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole was legally banned. In other words, even if, in a controlled manner, this substance can theoretically help someone, bearing in mind the specifics of such a hypothetical situation, the substance is generally life-threatening, so legal control is all necessary. I voted in favour!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the inclusion of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indium in control measures, because this report strengthens the powers of the European Parliament by requesting that the European Parliament be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this request for control measures. As with the previous substance, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole has already caused dozens of deaths. That is why we want to impose control measures throughout the European Union. This will protect the public from the risks associated with this substance.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report implementing the decision on subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 5-(2 aminopropyl) to control measures. This substance, which can have hallucinogenic effects, has, in most cases, harmful effects on humans. I therefore consider it necessary to subject this substance to control measures in the European Union, thereby helping to protect citizens from the risks caused by its consumption.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is necessary for the substance 5-(2 aminopropyl)pain to be subjected to strict control measures within each Member State, in order to reduce the impact on mortality that it could cause, if it continues not to be included in a suitable surveillance system.  It is for this reason that I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, which approves greater control over the substances mentioned above.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the Council decision on substance 5-(2 aminopropyl)pain because, on the basis of the evidence and information available to date, I believe it is right that this psychoactive substance should be subject to control measures throughout the European Union.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of the substance/drug 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole and should therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. New synthetic psychoactive substances are emerging. 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole (or 5-API, 5-IT) is a derivative of indole with stimulating effects. It has been considered a narcotic in France since 2013. The report before us validates the Council's proposal to subject this substance to control measures. I voted for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused deaths. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject the indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. It also aims to protect the public from the risks caused by the use of these substances. I'm voting FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council implementing decision which subjects 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures is part of the need for control and risk assessment of new psychoactive substances, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the consultation to combat the abuse and trafficking of drugs, including the risk assessment of new psychoactive substances.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is a stimulant substance that can produce hallucinogenic effects. This can be found on the internet or in specialized stores. We currently have very little information on health and social risks.  However, due to reported deaths, this substance must be brought under control. Today, only six Member States do so. As a security measure, I am pleased that all Member States will have to do the same.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of this proposal, I appeal to the Council to subject the substance to more accurate control measures. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is a synthetic indole derivative substituted on the phenyl side of the indole circular system. It appears to be a stimulant that can also have hallucinogenic effects. Available information and data indicate that the acute toxicity of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole may cause adverse effects in humans, such as tachycardia and overheating of the body, and may also cause the spread of the relic (mydriasis), agitation and soaring. There are no published studies assessing its acute and chronic toxicity, effects on mental health, behaviour or possible dependence, as limited information and data are available. However, the available evidence and information provide sufficient reason to subject 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the Union. As a result of the health risks posed by its presence in several reported cases of death and the fact that it has no medical value or use, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole should be subjected to control measures throughout the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to invite the Member States to subject the new psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the European Union, which is extremely important. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is commercially available on the internet and from ‘head shops’, marketed as a ‘research chemical’. The existing information and data suggest that the acute toxicity of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole can provoke adverse effects in humans. The available evidence and information and the result of the health risks that it poses recommend that it should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council intends to take a decision on the subject of eight relatively new psychoactive substances. They are all present in the Member States of the European Union and are distributed on the Internet, and deaths have been recorded in all contexts. Libe, the ep's competent committee, almost unanimously supported the draft decisions in its reports. Given their proven danger, I support their control myself.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Four reports are proposed at this session to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures throughout the European Union.  The affected products are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45.  Each of these substances has already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define the exact health risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union.  The aim of these decisions is to avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to allow the protection of the public from the risks associated with the consumption of these substances in a precautionary manner. These initiatives should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would argue that the 5—(2—aminoproppil)indole, a new psychoactive substance, should be subject to control measures in all Member States of the European Union and to the criminal penalties provided for in their legislation under the obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. The main reason, according to the information available in the risk assessment reports, is that the high toxicity of these substances can seriously harm people's health. Furthermore, the risks are compounded by the fact that, according to information received, certain people inadvertently consume these substances in combination with or replacing other psychoactive substances. I believe that the proliferation of new psychoactive substances, which are harmful to people's health, should be seen as a public health problem and their fight is imperative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the vote on 4-methylamphetamine, this vote on 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole aims to subject these substances on which it has a strong presumption of harmful health to controls throughout the European Union and thus to avoid the obstacles to cross-border cooperation that may arise. I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which supports efforts to collectively tackle the sale of legal highs which have caused a number of death and fatalities in the UK and across Europe. Moreover, the information available suggests that some of the psychoactive substances such as 4-methylamphetamine are produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamine. Trafficking occurs across borders and it is essential that Member States work together to disrupt the EU’s trafficking networks.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of the decision on substance 5-(2 aminopropyl)indole would ensure the continuity and extension of control measures through Member States on new substances. During the debate, the Commission and the Council stressed that the new substances caused a large number of deaths and poisonings. Since the report supports the position of the two institutions on the danger of these new substances and the need for controls, I have decided to support it favourably.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will regulate control measures for the following drug substance: 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole is a stimulating substance that, in addition to hallucinogenic effects, also leads to rapid heart rate and pupil enlargement. Currently, there is limited information about this "drug". Deaths from this drug have also been detected, although there is not 100 percent certainty that the drug was solely responsible for it. 4-methylamphetamine is the same substance in which the same control measures are to be introduced. I support this report and have therefore also spoken in favour of it.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report acts as Parliament approves the Council's text to transfer the control of the Aminopropyl substance to the European Union. It calls on Member States to legislate on this issue in the next 12 months. As the sale of this dangerous psychoactive substance has already been regulated by France, it is important to increase its control under a more general and harmonised authority. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The introduction of control measures is necessary to prevent misuse of the substance.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the rapporteur's work and thanking her for her work, I have decided to vote in favour of the project.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of introducing control measures for 5 (2 aminopropyl)indol, as the substance caused several deaths and poisonings, according to the European Commission. It is necessary to establish appropriate controls on this substance and to carry it out in all Member States in order not to unduly endanger the health of citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal to subject the psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropil)indole to additional control throughout the European Union, as the available evidence and information indicate the need to subject this dangerous substance to additional controls. As a result of the health risk posed by this substance, which has been detected and demonstrated in several reported deaths, as well as the fact that users may unknowingly consume it even in the absence of medical value, 5-(2-aminopropil)indole should be subjected to scrutiny throughout the European Union. Nine European countries reported detecting 5-(2-aminopropil)indole to EMCDDA and Europol. Six Member States already control 5- (2-aminopropil)indole using different types of legal provisions. Risk assessment reports reveal that there is limited available scientific evidence on hazard 5-(2-aminopropil)indole therefore highlighted the necessity of further research to identify the health and social risks it poses.
