Precisely because of the dangers that this psychoactive substance carries with it, I think it is necessary to subject it to additional control measures.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the vote on 4-methylamphetamine, this vote on 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole aims to subject these substances on which it has a strong presumption of harmful health to controls throughout the European Union and thus to avoid obstacles to cross-border cooperation that may arise. I voted for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. So far, 24 deaths have been reported directly related to the use of this substance. The current system of regulation at European level shows that despite the dangers posed to humans by this substance, only 6 Member States control 5-(2-aminopropil) indole as part of the overall legal framework for substance testing. Due to the fatal consequences that 5-(2-aminopropil) indole can cause, as well as the lack of control at European level, I agree with Parliament's recommendation and support the proposal to introduce a single control system at European level.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In accordance with the Council Decision on the Exchange of Information, Risk Assessment and Control of New Psychoactive Substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assesses the risks to the new psychoactive Substance 5- (2-aminopropil) indole. Substance 5- (2-aminopropil) indole is a synthetic derivative of indole, and is a known substance that can also have hallucinogenic effects. 5-(2-aminopropil) indole is found mainly in powder form, but also in the form of tablets and capsules, and is commercially available online. Existing data indicate the toxicity of 5-(2-aminopropil) indole, and the possibility of producing adverse effects in humans. In four Member States from April to August 2012, a total of 24 deaths were registered, in which 5-(2-aminopropil) indole was detected independently or in combination with other substances, in post-mortem samples. Further research is therefore strongly needed to identify the health and social risks posed by 5-(2-aminopropil) indole. I support the report that 5-(2-aminopropil) indole should be subject to union-wide control of measures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council Decision on the rapid exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new drugs and synthetic drugs has already proved to be a useful tool for Member States in the fight against drug trafficking.  I believe that Community legislative action must aim to ensure the continuity of control measures through the Member States, facilitating the flow of information and supranational cooperation in the social and health field. I have therefore decided to support the rapporteur's proposal through my vote in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of the potential risks posed by the psychoactive substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, the European Parliament has supported the Council's position to subject this substance to a strengthened control procedure and I welcome this.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The 5-(2-aminopropil) is a psychoactive substance marketable on the Internet. While the risk assessment of this substance for health and society still lacks some scientific demonstration, there is already sufficient ground for establishing control measures in the EU. There have been 24 substance-related deaths, which has been reported in 9 Member States and is related to organised crime groups.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Between April and August 2012, four Member States recorded 24 fatalities in which 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole had been detected separately or in combination with other substances in samples taken for autopsy. Although it is impossible to determine with certainty the role of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole in all fatalities, in some cases it has been recorded as a specific cause of death. If the availability and consumption of this new psychotropic substance were to expand, the consequences for individual and public health could be significant.  The available tests and information are sufficient grounds for subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures throughout the Union. Given the health risks posed, as attested by its detection in several of the reported fatalities, the fact that it could be inadvertently consumed and the absence of medical value or use, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol must be subject to control measures throughout the Union. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft enforcement decision of the Council subjecting the indole 5-(2-aminopropyl)to control measures and which calls on the Council to consult again with the European Parliament if it intends to substantially amend the text we have approved.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After analysis of the psychoactive substance 5—(2-aminopropyl)indole by the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, it has been found that it may produce hallucinogenic and other adverse effects on humans, and is even available on the Internet and in head shops. In view of the 24 fatal cases recorded in four Member States, there are well-founded reasons for subjecting this substance to control measures throughout the Union for the health risks it poses. For this reason, I voted in favour of this legislative motion for a resolution, which adopts the council's draft implementing decision to ask all Member States to submit this substance to control measures.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject the 5-(2 aminopropyl) indole to control measures, a substance which can have hallucinogenic effects and which is considered harmful to human health. The Commission and the Council have pointed out that this substance has caused a large number of deaths and poisonings.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council as the urgency of banning in all Member States a substance whose risk to public health is evident is imposed in all Member States. Between April and August 2012 alone, 24 deaths associated with consumption of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol were identified. The substance has no known medical or other use.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject the substance known as indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures. According to a scientific risk assessment report this substance can cause tachycardia, hyperthermia, midriasis, agitations and tremors. Other than this, it has no known medical value either. This decision also makes it easier for Member States to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the draft Council implementing decision subjecting 5-(2 aminopropyl) to control measures. A psychotic substance, natural or synthetic, that affects the nervous system and causes stimulating or depressive effects, just like illicit drugs. The procedure voted on today provides for a ban on the manufacture and marketing of these substances, and also provides for criminal sanctions throughout Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe this matter is not an EU competency but instead should be addressed by nation-state governments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The existing information regarding this substance suggests that there are severe adverse effects provoked by the consumption of it. For the safety of my constituents, I believe that bringing this drug under the control measures proposed here will better protect citizens from its harmful effects.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution as 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole is a psychotic substance that has stimulating or depressive drug-like effects and therefore needs to be controlled in the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support the Report because I believe that 5-(2-aminopropil) is an indole harmful substance to be subjected to control measures in the European Union, as 24 people have died from it in the past few years, most notably in Sweden. It is a substance that is dangerous to human health and appears on the EU market today as a dangerous psychoactive drug. Since it is a substance that is produced and sold as a drug in illegal markets, and especially online, it must be banned and should not be allowed to come into the hands of citizens, especially children.  It is currently positive that six Member States have already brought this new drug under the control of their anti-drug laws, and other members need to do the same. Unfortunately, this drug is currently not sufficiently known to the public, the available scientific evidence on it is limited, however, as it is known to be a substance that is harmful to the shell body and psyche, this drug should be suppressed and banned by laws at the national level of all EU Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the introduction of surveillance measures for 5-(2-aminopropil)indole. 5-(2-aminopropil)indole is a stimulant that has hallucinogenic effects and causes various adverse effects on human health. Four Member States reported 24 deaths and 21 were linked to this new psychoactive substance.  If this new psychoactive substance becomes widely available, the consequences for society and public health can be significant. 5-(2-aminopropil)indole has no medical value and the Commission considers that there is a basis for subjecting these substances to control measures across the Union. I support the Commission's position, and these substances need to be subjected to control measures and criminal sanctions as provided for in the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances in 1971 to combat harmful synthetic substances.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance to draw attention to new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively counter these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague's text. I note, however, that when it comes to products that can become drugs, it is already difficult to find consistency and openness within national policy. I therefore have little hope at European level on this specific topic. If things change, I will gladly continue to participate in the debates and represent my citizens in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole appears to be a stimulant substance that may also have hallucinogenic effects. It is commercially available on the internet and from ‘head shops’, marketed as a ‘research chemical’. A total of 24 fatalities have been registered in four Member States from April to August 2012 in relation to it. The available scientific evidence provides sufficient grounds for subjecting 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole to control measures across the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report subjecting substance 5-(2-aminopropil) indole to surveillance measures, as scientific research by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction has established that this substance is a psychotic substance that affects the central nervous system, just like illegal drugs. Namely, it has been found that it can cause hallucinations, changes in thinking, behavior, observation, awareness and mood, and in this way it represents a legal alternative to illegal drugs such as cocaine or ecstasy.  Given the harmful effects that this substance may cause, I believe that its spread must be prevented in order not to mislastage this substance, thus circumventing consumer law.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision introducing control measures for 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol, as I believe that we need better data exchange, effective risk assessments and stricter controls on new psychoactive substances occurring on the black market. Only then can we be on track to prevent drug use among EU citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council as the urgency of banning in all Member States a substance whose risk to public health is evident is imposed in all Member States. Between April and August 2012 alone, 24 deaths associated with consumption of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indol were identified. The substance has no known medical or other use.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures throughout the European Union.  This substance has already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define health and social risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for monitoring measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to protect the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.  I therefore voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council, since the substances included in the report pose an obvious risk to public health and their free movement has no benefit.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree that the synthetic drugs mentioned in the report should be subjected to control measures.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision speaks of new substances that have caused a large number of deaths and toxicity. The proposal aims to ensure the continuity of control measures in the Member States relating to these new substances and so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject the substance known as indole 5-(2-aminopropyl) to control measures. According to a scientific risk assessment report this substance can cause tachycardia, hyperthermia, midriasis, agitations and tremors. Other than this, it has no known medical value either. This decision also makes it easier for Member States to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Substance 5—(2—aminopropyl)indole is a synthetic derivative of indole replaced in the phenyl part of the indole ring system. It appears to be a stimulating substance, which can also have hallucinogenic effects. The substance 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole was found mainly in the form of powder, but also in the form of tablets and capsules. It has also been found in samples of a product sold similar to ecstasy tablets and is marketed on the Internet. Existing information and data suggest that acute toxicity of 5—(2—aminopropyl)indole may cause adverse effects in humans, such as shorthand, hyperthermia, agitation, and tremor. The specific physical effects of 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole in humans are difficult to determine, because there are no published studies assessing its acute and chronic toxicity, psychological and behavioural effects, or the potential for dependence, and therefore little information and limited data are available.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of the substance/drug 5-(2-aminopropyl) indole and should therefore be supported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained on the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on control measures for 5-(2-aminopropyl) indol. I see no need to adopt control measures for psychoactive substances at European level. It is therefore quite right that certain Member States have agreed on derogations. The principle of subsidiarity is blatantly violated by a European regulation of these issues.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 25I NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxyptamine to control measures. These substances are being illegally sold as drugs or substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Many Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances are extremely dangerous to human life. They are the cause of many forfeitures and can eventually lead to the death of their dependent consumers. Further research is needed to better assess the harmful effects of these substances. However, we have enough elements to put them through control measures. Thus, this report aims to establish rules to severely regulate the use of 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services.  With regard to a problem which requires the cooperation of all Member States, I believe that it is a useful text that will facilitate the repression of the trafficking concerned. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am on record as supporting a ban on so-called legal highs in the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, there are two problems here. Firstly, it is inappropriate for this matter to be dealt with at European level. Drug policy should always remain firmly within the domain of the Member States. For example, Portugal and the Netherlands have a much more liberal stance than many in the UK would be happy to adopt. That is a matter for the national governments, and this resolution is in effect a backdoor means of handing power to the European Union. Secondly, individual substance bans are an ineffective tool: changing from one substance to another of similar chemical composition is too easy. Overarching legislation, rather than individually referencing chemicals, is what is needed. So, although I support the general principle, I felt that I must abstain on these votes.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to promote the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances that threaten the health of Europeans.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to impose control measures and criminal sanctions on certain psychotropic substances, as provided for under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Yes, this new psychotropic substance must be subject to control measures throughout the European Union. This will require improved cross-border cooperation between law enforcement agencies and the protection agencies of our respective citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this wise decision.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In accordance with EU legislation on the exchange of information, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control this psychoactive chemical throughout the Union. The illicit presence and manufacture of this substance is documented in several Member States and several deaths due to it have been recorded within the Union. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to follow the Council's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The 25I-NBOMe is a powerful synthetic derivative, a classic serotonergic hallucinogen, which has been subject to EU-level control measures since 2003. There were 4 deaths related to 25I-NBOMe in three Member States and 32 poisonings.  AH-7921 is an atypically structured painkiller that can be easily mistaken for doxylamine, an antihistamine with sedative and hypnotic properties. Between 2012 and September 2013, there were 15 deaths in three Member States and 6 poisonings in one state. MDPV is a synthetic derivative with a substituted cathinone and is subject to control measures under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Between September 2009 and August 2013, there were 108 deaths and 525 poisonings in eight Member States and Norway.  Methoxetamine is a substance similar to ketamine and phencyclidine, an internationally controlled substance. 20 methoxetamine-related deaths were reported by six Member States and also 20 cases of poisoning reported by five Member States.  Given the risks, this proposal should invite member states to submit this to checks and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision subjecting substances 4-iodo-2,5-dimethyloxy-N-(2-metoxybenzil)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[(1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl)methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methyleneoxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(ethylamino)-2-(3-methyloxyphenyl)cyclohexanone (methylohetamine).  I believe that, in order to combat the proliferation of synthetic drugs in Europe, we need to increase controls on substances, even new ones, that can be used for the synthesis of psychotropic substances.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. There have been four deaths associated with 25I-NBOMe in three Member States, with the reporting of thirty-two cases of non-fatal poisoning. If the availability and consumption of this new psychotropic substance were to increase, the consequences for individual and public health could be significant.  No data are available on the prevalence of consumption of this substance, but the limited information available suggests that it can be consumed in a wide range of environments, such as home, bars, nightclubs and music festivals. The 25I-NBOMe is openly marketed and sold online as a 'research chemical', and information obtained from seizures, collected samples, websites of internet consumers and retailers suggests that it is sold as a medicine itself, and is also marketed as a 'lawful' substitute for LSD. The SEDD has detected more than fifteen Internet retailers that sell this substance and may be based in the Union and China. I believe that the evidence and information available is reason enough to subject it to control measures throughout the Union, so I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, approving the Council's draft on the application of control measures to psychoactive substances 4-iodine-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[[1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methyloxyphenyl)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexanone (metoxamine).  The European Parliament and the Council have agreed, in accordance with a joint 2005 decision, to exchange information on new psychoactive substances, on their risk assessments and to provide for control measures. The development of psychoactive substances is particularly dangerous for human health and the environment and urgent action by the Member States is therefore necessary. The joint decision on the exchange, risk assessment and control of information on new psychoactive substances shall draw attention to information on suspected adverse reactions to be transmitted in accordance with the established pharmacovigilance system. This Decision also provides for an assessment of the risks associated with these new psychoactive substances with a view to authorising the control measures applied in the Member States for the use of new psychoactive substances.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it of the utmost importance that the legislation keeps pace with the incredibly rapid development of new drugs, which are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes caused by the slowness of the legislation. Almost daily we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but often are not yet considered illegal.  In my opinion, we need to provide the national authorities with the right legal instruments so that they can effectively combat the production and distribution of these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in a timely manner to prevent further tragedies. For these reasons, I supported the report as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 No amendments were even tabled on the fourth batch of hazardous chemical substances. Thus, in Parliament, we have practically unanimously supported these solutions for a comprehensive approach by all Member States to human treatment of the so far little known but extremely dangerous compounds.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report and the ban because 5-2-aminopropil indole has caused 24 deaths in the EU since August 2012, according to official statistics. Young people are the target group of consumers and as such suffer the most harm from consumption. Deaths have been registered across Europe, and recently a teenager died in the middle of consumption in Croatia. Some of the compounds that are on the market are extremely strong and can cause consequences such as increased pressure, paranoia, psychosis, nausea, seizures and in some cases, death. The most severe consequences occur because the active substance is incorrectly distributed per product during mixing and drying. As a result, some packages are many times stronger and more harmful than usual. The common market and the abolition of borders have brought multiple benefits to Europe, but in this case this freedom has negative side effects. Member States cannot tackle the problem of 'legal drugs' on their own, as they cannot keep up with the speed at which new compounds appear.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that, considering all the elements in our possession (cases of death, limited therapeutic usefulness, etc.) with regard to 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine, it may be useful to subject them to control measures throughout the Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, psychotropic substances, to control measures throughout the European Union. These substances have already caused a dozen deaths suggesting that they pose a sufficiently serious danger for their use to be better supervised. It seems clear that further studies are needed to better understand the health risks that individuals face after absorbing these substances. It is essential that these controls are introduced at European level so as not to hinder cross-border cooperation between the various national services.   That is why I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. These four reports regulate the control of new or currently used substances as chemical parts for drugs or similar new substances. Parliament is being asked to approve more controls on these substances.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the introduction of control measures on substances 25I-NBOMe (a powerful synthetic derivative of a classic serotonin hallucinogen), AH-7921 (a synthetic opioid analgesic), 3MDPV (a synthetic derivative of tarin) and metoxyetamine (chemically similar to ketamine and phenycloline). These substances do not have any therapeutic properties for human or veterinary use.  In view of the health risks involved, trade in these substances within the Union must be subject to control measures in order to ensure the protection of human health and avoid negative consequences for public health. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will subject the aforementioned drugs to control measures There have been over 100 deaths associated with these drugs. Currently they are sold on the internet as ‘research chemicals’ and then re-sold as drugs. The lack of medical value or use of these substances, coupled with the dangers they pose to those who ingest them, are reason enough to subject these newly detected substances to control measures.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, I chose to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this vote because new substances such as this one can be linked to a large number of deaths and toxicity within the Member States. These substance need to be studied more closely in order to fully understand their implications.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of new psychoactive substances 4-iodo-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-metoxybenzil) phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichlorine-N-[(1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl)methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methyleneoxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(ethylamino)-2-(3-methyloxyphenyl) cyclohexanone (methylohetamine).  On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject these new substances to control measures throughout the Union. As I regard the fight against drugs as a fundamental issue, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question aims to establish the control of new psychotropic substances whose use has already caused dozens of deaths to control measures throughout the EU. Further research is needed to define its health and social risks, but it is clear that the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for subjecting these substances to control measures throughout the European Union. So I voted for this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Council's draft and the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we support the Council's plan.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine to control measures. During the debate, the European Commission and the Council stressed the danger of these substances and the need to subject them to control measures, given also the number of deaths and intoxications caused by these substances.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft because I fully agree with the Council's decision to subject substances 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxyetamine to control measures and I believe they are dangerous and harmful drugs for those who use them. In addition, the substance 251-NBOMe appears to have effects similar to LSD and other substances, on the reporting of cases presented to the emergency room following intoxication, may have side effects such as: tachycardia, hypertension, agitation, aggression, convulsions, hypertension, high number of white blood cells and acute kidney damage. In conclusion, I believe that additional measures for these medicines are necessary and vital, especially because of the role that the European Union plays vis-à-vis its citizens in protecting their health.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2005/387/JAI on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the dangers inherent in new drugs require rapid and concerted intervention by States at European level.  When a new substance is found, the Member State should report this to Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, which will also try to assess its risk to public health as well as associated crime. Once the procedure is complete, they may request control or prohibition measures from Member States. Although Parliament's involvement is unnecessary - given the exclusively technical content of this decision - Parliament must be consulted and has to give its opinion.  The three drugs have been found in most Member States and the degree of control varies between legislation and other measures. In total, they have already caused about 200 deaths and hundreds of non-fatal poisonings. It is of particular danger to 25I-NBOMe, sold as a legal version of LSD.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the need to step up controls on the drugs in question because, according to the data presented by the European Commission and the European Council, they are the cause of the high number of deaths and poisonings recorded in Europe.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A risk assessment report was submitted to the Commission detailing the increasing mortality rate and overall health detriments associated with the substance stated. I voted in favour of the proposal in question which aims to protect EU citizens from health and social risks by requesting Member States to legislate in relation to the substance in question to further avoid fatalities, within their own drug-abuse legislative framework.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of new psychoactive substances. On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject these new substances to control measures throughout the Union, so I can only vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 25I NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxyptamine to control measures. These substances are being illegally sold as drugs or substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Many Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which invites Member States to subject 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures across the EU. There were fatalities registered with all these psychoactive substances. For example, MDPV, which has been present on the Union drug market since November 2008, is allegedly responsible for the death of 108 persons in eight Member States and Norway between September 2009 and August 2013. Furthermore, 525 intoxication cases which were non-fatal were associated with MDPV. AH-7921 is responsible for 15 fatalities; 251-NBOMe has been responsible for four deaths; and methoxetamine was responsible for 20 deaths. For these reasons I strongly support and voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that the draft decision on the subjecting of 4-iodo-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dicloro-N-[1-(dimethylamino)cycloh xyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedioxipyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexanone (methoxetamine) of control measures is a welcome one.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the implementation of the decision subjecting 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures within the Member States. These new substances pose a danger, resulting in a significant number of deaths and poisonings. Considering that this report contributes to better protection of European citizens, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. It is preferable that 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine be subject to control measures in all EU Member States, as these substances can have harmful effects in humans.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV are psychoactive substances that damage the central nervous system and impair mental functions. Currently legal and for sale on the internet, they replace "traditional" drugs and spread on the domestic market.  From now on, these substances should only be used for research and scientific development. They will also be permanently restricted and subject to the EU's criminal law provisions, which is in line with the application of the European precautionary principle.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is essential to adapt the European policy on combating psychoactive substances. Many substances that have so far been considered legal are spreading in European society, especially thanks to the internet. However, these are real drugs that represent a real danger to European citizens, both for individual health and for public health.  The four synthetic drugs involved in this execution decision cause symptoms such as hallucinations, paranoia, anxiety, psychosis, tachycardia, high blood pressure, etc. They have been detected in more than 20 Member States and have already caused more than 147 deaths and more than 572 cases of poisoning. European legislation to control these psychoactive drugs is essential for better cross-border coordination in the fight against drugs.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up with the new drugs that drug dealers and criminal networks are launching. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because in order to combat the trafficking of synthetic drugs it is essential to exchange information, assess risks and control new psychoactive substances, in particular 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better control of these substances.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because I feel we are continuing down a failed road and that what is proposed is a denial of reality.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more controls for the substances in question.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of report A8-0264/2015, because every new psychoactive substance must be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to European Union legislation on information exchange, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control, throughout the whole territory of the European Union, this psychoactive substance. The presence and illicit manufacture of the substance is confirmed in several Member States and several deaths caused by it have been recognised within the European Union. The report supports the Council’s proposal. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of all these implementing decisions in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. It is vitally important to keep up to date with the new drugs being constantly developed by drug traffickers and criminal organisations. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive substances which change constantly in order to take advantage of legislative gaps. As we witness day by day, these new drugs are not only extremely toxic and have caused large numbers of deaths, but are often not even recognised as illegal. We must enable our law enforcement authorities to counter such criminal activity, providing them with the necessary instruments to fight back the spreading of these new substances. At the same time we must make sure that schools are supported in education and prevention activities. Special attention must be given also to help the young victims and their families.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I consider uniform, appropriate, technically applicable rules to be very important in this context.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the introduction of control measures for 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetonine. The number of poisonings and deaths caused by these dangerous drugs is enormous. We must take measures to prevent the spread of such psychoactive substances.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which aims to invite the Member States to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures across the European Union, given the health risks connected to these substances.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (OEDT) has ruled that psychotropic substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxethamine present health risks. Support, therefore, subject these psychotropic substances to control measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Council's draft, since the substances included in the report pose an obvious risk to public health and their free movement has no benefit.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as it concerns substances which pose a risk to public safety. The substances known as 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine have been linked to a number of deaths across the EU and I agree that they should be subject to control measures and criminal sanctions at EU level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with the ALDE Group in favour of subjecting 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures. A risk assessment carried out by the Scientific Committee of the Lisbon-based European Monitoring Centre on Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) showed that these four substances do not provide any concrete medical benefits. These new substances are currently being used as alternatives to illicit drugs and have already been linked to numerous fatalities and intoxications across the EU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to ensure that these new substances continue to be controlled across all Member States. The two institutions have recognised the new substances as dangerous, having provoked a large number of deaths due to toxicity. I support the rapporteur’s views expressing the dangerousness of these new substances and the necessity for strict controls to be put in place.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with a view to the maintenance of control measures for new drugs. It is of the utmost importance to be aware of the newer and new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly being modified to take advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new substances that are toxic, in many cases causing death, but most of the time they are not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively counter these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I support enforcement decisions aimed at introducing controls at the European Union's borders on certain psychoactive substances.  Currently, these substances, whose marketing is favoured by the internet, are spreading alarmingly in Europe. Their use is poorly controlled and their effects unknown, the national authorities of several Member States have identified several cases of deaths and direct or indirect accidents related to the consumption of these substances. That is why I share the analysis of providing strict supervision of these substances and limiting their sale and use in the European Union as much as possible.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council, since the substances included in the report pose an obvious risk to public health and their free movement has no benefit.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision on the subjecting of substances 4-iodine-2,5-dimetooxy-N-(2-metoxybenzil)phethylamine (251-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[1-(dimetilamino)cycloh (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedypirovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-metoxininefil)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexanon (methoxetamine) control measures because acute and chronic toxicity of these substances can significantly harm the human body. On the other hand, the psychological consequences and the possibility of addiction further make them dangerous, regardless of the limited data available. In addition, greater availability and use of such substances could have serious implications for individuals and public health. Therefore, I strongly support the subjecting of substances 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxetamine through control measures to the safety of all CITIZENS of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused the death of several people. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. The report also provides for better public protection from the risks caused by the use of these substances. So I voted FOR.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on subjecting 251-NBOMe, AH-7921,MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures as there are still debates on legal highs within recreational drugs. These are not the competencies of the EU and should be decided at nation-state level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleague Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio on the decision to continue the controls recommended by the Commission and the Council on 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine in the Member States because of the toxicity of these substances which sometimes led to deaths. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine have no recognized medical use and are likely to pose a risk to human health. Our lack of scientific knowledge about these products therefore requires additional control measures and research.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposed measures are appropriate and fall within the competence of the Union, not least because control measures are to be made uniform in order to make the internal market work. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There have been a large number of fatalities registered across the EU associated with the four new psychoactive substances. The available evidence and information and the result of the health risks that they pose recommend that these substances should be subjected to control measures across the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up with the new drugs that drug dealers and criminal networks are launching. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases causing death, but often not yet considered illegal.  We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Decision of the Council of the European Union of 25 September 2014 subjects substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine to control measures, in view of the health risks and the lack of properties or therapeutic uses of these substances. The high level of alert for the registration of deaths in Europe following the intake of these substances leads me to vote in favour, as it is necessary to ensure the continuity of control measures.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft enforcement decision of the Council subjecting 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures. There were four deaths related to 25I-NBOMe in three Member States.  Further research is needed to define the health and social risks of these psychotropic substances, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for them to be subjected to control measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to protect the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it protects the peoples of Europe, through cross-border police cooperation, from these new psychotropic substances.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a consultation with the European Parliament on Council decisions on the inclusion by Member States of specific control measures on substances which have been considered psychotropic and toxic. Having found several dozen deaths in different Member States from one of these substances (some of them conventional drugs), it has been decided to subject to specific risk assessment and control measures, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Twenty-two Member States and Norway reported detection of 25I-NBOMe and four deaths from the effects of this substance were recorded. The effects of AH-7921, alone or in combination with other substances, caused 15 deaths in three Member States. MDVP has effects similar to cocaine and methamphetamine. 108 deaths have been recorded and in twenty-five Member States the MDVP is controlled through national legislation while five member states use other measures. Metoxetamine is used as a substitute for ketamine and is the cause of the 21st fatality. I supported Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio's report on the subjecting of substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxetamine by control measures.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 25I-NBOMe is a strong psychosonic substance, which, although small doses can help in stimulating the thinking process or improving mood, too high doses can lead to a person's death. AH-7921 is an opiate which, as was discovered a few years ago, was used for some time in Japan in the production of synthetic hashish. In Brazil and Israel, for example, this substance, which was never and nowhere in the world was sold commercially, is prohibited. The substance is known as partial (~80%) morphine substitute. MDPV (methylenedioxypirovaleron) is a psychoactive entertaining drug. There are known cases where its use led to severe psychological as well as physical injuries. Attention and euphoria of the stimulating substance. In some countries it is forbidden, in others – controlled. Overdose can lead to death. Methoxethamine, a dissociative drug known as a twice-three-times more potent ketamine analogue. The substance is known to be specially designed for sale on the so-sold grey market. In Switzerland and Russia, for example, it is prohibited. In general, in view of the list of substances viewed in this report and their specificities, there are only two options for action in principle: control or prohibition, no less. I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the inclusion of substances: 4-iodine-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N- [[1-(dime) methylamine)cyclohexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedoxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylamine)cyclohexanone (methexetamine) in control measures, because this report strengthens the powers of the European Parliament by requesting that the European Parliament be consulted again in the event that the Council intends to make significant amendments to the Text.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this request for control measures. As with previous substances, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine have already caused dozens of deaths. That is why we want to impose control measures throughout the European Union. This will protect the public from the risks associated with these substances.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report implementing the decision on subjecting the following to control measures: 4-iodo-2,5-dimethoxy—N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro—N-[[1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4—methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2—(ethylamino)cyclohexanone (methoxetamine).

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it appropriate to introduce control measures throughout the European Union on substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxyetamine. These substances cause serious damage to the health of citizens and many of them can be taken unk knowingly, without therapeutic use, and can be produced without the use of sophisticated equipment.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with a favourable vote the draft Council decision aimed at subjecting substances 4-iodo-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-metoxybenzil)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[2)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe) to control measures.(1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl)methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methyleneoxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(ethylamino)-2-(3-methyloxyphenyl)cyclohexanone (methylohetamine). These are psychoactive substances whose harmful potential is the subject of proven studies carried out by the Commission and the European Council.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of substances/drugs 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxeamine. We must therefore support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. New synthetic psychoactive substances are emerging. Methoxetamine, also known as MXE or 3-MeO-2-Oxo-PCE, is a derivative of ketamine that also contains structural characteristics of eticcyclidine and 3-MeO-PCP. This substance has been controlled in France since 2013. The report before us validates the Council's proposal to subject this substance to control measures throughout the Union. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused deaths. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. It also aims to protect the public from the risks caused by the use of these substances. I voted FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council implementing decision subject to substances 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures is part of the need for control and risk assessment of new psychoactive substances, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the consultation to combat the abuse and trafficking of drugs, including the risk assessment of new psychoactive substances.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The evaluation of the Scientific Committee for the European Drug And Drug Observation found four substances (25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine) as requiring control measures throughout the UNION. Further research seems needed to determine the health and social risks of these four substances. However, due to the recent reported deaths and therefore as a precautionary measure, we have asked Member States, in accordance with their national laws, to monitor them and apply criminal sanctions.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to subject the substances in question to more accurate control measures. These are substances that are not established or recognised as medicinal products and for therapeutic use. Substance 25I-NBOMe is a potent synthetic derivative of 2,5-dimethoxy-4-iodinephenenetylamine (2C-I), a classic serotonergic hallucinogen that has been subject to risk assessment and control measures and has been the subject of criminal sanctions at Union level since 2003, as provided for in a Council Decision. AH-7921 is a structurally atypical synthetic opioid analgesic. MDPV is a ring-substituted synthetic derivative of cationone, chemically related to pyrovalerone, both of which are controlled under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Metoxetamine is an arylcyclohexylamine substance that is chemically similar to ketamine and the internationally controlled substance phencyclohine (PCP). Like ketamine and PCP, methonethamine has dissociative properties. Substances should be subject to control measures throughout the Union as a result of the health risks they pose. If these psychoactive substances become available, the consequences for the health of individuals and the public could be considerable.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to invite the Member States to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures across the European Union, which is extremely important. The substance 25I-NBOMe is openly marketed and sold on the internet as a ‘research chemical’ and information obtained from seizures, collected samples, user websites and internet retailers suggests that it is being sold as a drug in its own right and also marketed as a ‘legal’ replacement for LSD. MDPV is similar to that for cocaine and methamphetamine, albeit more potent and longer lasting. Acute toxicity can provoke adverse effects on humans. It is widely available from internet suppliers and retailers, ‘head shops’ and street-level dealers. Methoxetamine is a substance which is chemically similar to ketamine and the internationally-controlled substance phencyclidine (PCP). The available evidence and information and the result of the health risks that it poses recommend that these substances should be subjected to control measures across the European Union.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council intends to take a decision on the subject of eight relatively new psychoactive substances. They are all present in the Member States of the European Union and are distributed on the Internet, and deaths have been recorded in all contexts. Libe, the ep's competent committee, almost unanimously supported the draft decisions in its reports. Given their proven danger, I support their control myself.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Four reports are proposed at this session to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures across the EU.  The affected products are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. Each of these substances has already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define the exact health risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union. The aim of these decisions is to avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to allow the protection of the public from the risks associated with the consumption of these substances in a precautionary manner.  These initiatives should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new psychoactive substances, such as substance 4-iodine-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), substance 3,4-dichloro-N-[[1-(dimethylamino)cyclo-hexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), substance 3,4—methyleneddioxipyrovalerone (MDPV) and substance 2-(3-methoxyphisnil)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexaone (methoxethane), should be subject to control measures in all Member States of the European Union and to the criminal penalties provided for in their laws , under the obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. According to the information available in the risk assessment reports, the high toxicity of these substances can seriously harm people's health. Furthermore, the risks are compounded by the fact that, according to information received, certain people inadvertently consume these substances in combination with or replacing other psychoactive substances. I believe that the proliferation of new psychoactive substances, which are harmful to people's health, should be seen as a public health problem and their fight is imperative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures. As with the two previous reports, I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which supports efforts to collectively tackle the sale of legal highs which have caused a number of death and fatalities in the UK and across Europe. Moreover, the information available suggests that some of the psychoactive substances such as 4-methylamphetamine are produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamine. Trafficking occurs across borders and it is essential that Member States work together to disrupt the EU’s trafficking networks.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application of decisions on substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine would ensure the continuity and extension of control measures through Member States on new substances. During the debate, the Commission and the Council stressed that the new substances caused a large number of deaths and poisonings. Since the report supports the position of the two institutions on the danger of these new substances and the need for controls, I have decided to support it favourably.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will regulate control measures for the following drug substances: 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report calls for control measures for 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetonine. I also support this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I have approved this report in support of the Council text calling on Member States to submit the controls on Dimethoxy and Phenethylamine to the authority of the European Union. Member States are also invited to share their knowledge of the risks and analyses of these substances. Control of these drug users must be generalized and harmonized to avoid any risk of proliferation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The introduction of control measures is necessary to prevent misuse of the substance.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and I am voting in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of introducing control measures for 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methenetamine, as the substances, according to the European Commission, have caused several deaths and poisonings. It is necessary to establish appropriate controls on these substances and to implement it in all Member States in order not to unduly endanger the health of citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Due to the health risks posed by substances 25I-NBOM, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxetamines, as documented in the detection of several deaths, due to the fact that users may unknowingly consume them, due to lack of medical control or control of use, the aim of this proposal is to invite all Member States to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures throughout the European Union. For all the above reasons, I agree with the decision to carry out additional controls and limit the use of these substances which have proven to be dangerous and toxic in order to prevent the negative consequences they have. By subjecting these life-threatening substances to control measures, we preserve the health and lives of all CITIZENS of the European Union, which must be our primary goal.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is intended to subject 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures. As with the two previous reports, I voted in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ So far, 4 deaths related to the use of 25I-NBOMe have been recorded, with only 6 Member States controlling the use of this substance at national level and another 7 Member States using other legal frameworks to do so. 15 deaths were linked to the use of the AH-7921 substance. As many as 108 deaths are associated with MDPV and 20 with metoxetamine. For all of the above, I agree with the proposal to subject the substance 4-iodine-2.5-dimetoxi-N-(2-methoxybenzil) phenythylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3.4-dichloro-N-[1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylithime) cyclohexanone (methoxetamine) control measures at European level, thereby preventing their distribution and fatal effects on human health.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I agree with colleague Teresa Jimenez-Becerril Barrio's report on the subjecting of substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxetamine by control measures. The purpose of the decision is to ensure the implementation of control measures against these new substances in the Member States of the European Union. The Scientific Committee of the European Centre for Drug Control and Drug Addiction carried out an analysis of the risks of psychoactive substances and submitted a risk assessment report to the Commission and the Council. The debate in the European Commission and the European Council concluded that the new psychoactive substances caused a series of poisonings and deaths. These substances affect human health, and the risk is increased by the fact that some users consume them unconsciously together or instead of other stimulating substances.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Council Decision on the rapid exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new drugs and synthetic drugs establishes a new three-step procedure.  Under this procedure, a new psychoactive substance may be subject to control measures in the European Union. I am in favour of adopting this report, which aims to subject substances 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine to the most stringent control measures provided for by the EU.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the publication of a report expressing concern about the possible risks posed by psychoactive substances 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, the European Parliament has supported the Council's position to strengthen the control measures on the aforementioned substances and I welcome this.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is certain that the assessment of the risks of these substances to health and society (25I-NBOMe – hallucinogen; AH-7921 - analgesic opiate; MDVP - psychotropic; methoxetamine – anesthetic/narcotic) still lacks some scientific demonstration, there is already sufficient grounds for establishing control measures in the EU. All these substances are related to various deaths and organized crime.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. There have been four deaths associated with 25I-NBOMe in three Member States, with the reporting of thirty-two cases of non-fatal poisoning. If the availability and consumption of this new psychotropic substance were to increase, the consequences for individual and public health could be significant.  No data are available on the prevalence of consumption of this substance, but the limited information available suggests that it can be consumed in a wide range of environments, such as home, bars, nightclubs and music festivals. The 25I-NBOMe is openly marketed and sold online as a 'research chemical', and information obtained from seizures, collected samples, websites of internet consumers and retailers suggests that it is sold as a medicine itself, and is also marketed as a 'lawful' substitute for LSD. The SEDD has detected more than fifteen Internet retailers that sell this substance and may be based in the Union and China. I believe that the evidence and information available is reason enough to subject it to control measures throughout the Union, so I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft Council implementation decision on 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures and calls on the Council to consult again with the European Parliament whether it intends to substantially amend the text we have approved.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After analysis by the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, it was found that the substances 25i-NBOme, AH-7921, MDPV and Methythanamine have hallucinogenic effects, causing poisoning and deaths in several Member States due to their high toxicity. Given the fact that these substances are sold on the Internet and present serious health risks, it is essential that Member States submit them to control measures throughout the Union, and i therefore voted in favour of this legislative motion for a resolution, which adopts the council's draft implementing decision.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council's decision to subject substances considered harmful and dangerous to human health such as: 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, 3MDPV and metoxyetamine to control measures.  The European Union has always cared about the health of its citizens, and it is right that the European Parliament should express its opinion on this matter.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council, since the substances included in the report pose an obvious risk to public health and their free movement has no benefit.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 25I NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxyptamine to control measures. These substances are being illegally sold as drugs or substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Many Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the draft Council implementing decision subjecting substances such as: -methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrous to control measures 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenyletyl)-piperazine (MT-45). They are psychotic substances, natural or synthetic, that affect the nervous system and cause stimulating or depressive effects, just like illicit drugs. The procedure voted on today provides for a ban on the manufacture and marketing of these substances, and also provides for criminal sanctions throughout Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe this is not an EU competency but instead should be done by nation-state governments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the casualties to these substances, I do not believe that it is right that I would not do what I can, with the legislative responsibility that my constituents have given me. These substances should be brought under control measures to have a chance of protecting European citizens from the harmful and damaging effects of these substances.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The substances listed in the title of the resolution may cause, for example, hallucinations, changes in thinking, behaviour, consciousness or moods. For this reason, I agree with their control within the EU.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
