text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report because 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and metoxetamine have no proven or recognized use in human or veterinary medicine. 25I-NBOMe is a powerful synthetic derivative of 2C-I, a classic serotonergic hallucinogen that has undergone risk assessment, control measures and criminal sanctions at EU level. There is not much available data on the use of substance 25I-NBOMe, but the limited data that exists indicates that it can be consumed in different places. AH-7921 is a structurally atypical synthetic opioid painkiller known as "doxylam" among internet suppliers, consumer websites, and media. There are no data on the frequency of consumption of AH-7921, however the available data suggest that it is not widely used and used at home. MDPV is an annuously substituted synthetic derivative of catinono, chemically associated with pyrovalerone, and both substances are subject to scrutiny under the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. Consumer websites show that its acute toxicity can cause adverse effects on humans, and since four Member States have also been detected in biological samples examined in relation to mortality in road accidents caused by driving under the influence of drugs, this substance should definitely be regulated and controlled by national and European legislation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to subject 251-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine to control measures across the European Union. At least three Member States have recorded fatalities as a result of consumption of each of these substances and so intervention is necessary.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the introduction of surveillance measures for 25I-NBOMe, AH-792, MDPV and metoxetamine. 25I-NBOMe was detected in 23 Member States and four deaths related to the substance were reported. On the illegal market, it is sold as LSD. AH-7921 is a synthetic painkiller and has been detected in eight Member States and has recorded 15 deaths related to the substance. It's sold online. MDPV is a synthetic derivative subject to control under the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. There were 108 deaths in eight Member States. It is widely available among online suppliers and on the street. Metoxetamine has caused around 20 deaths in six Member States. This is devastating data. These substances should be subjected to control measures and criminal penalties as provided for in the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. I support this initiative because we must fight harmful synthetic substances that cause serious diseases and deaths in the European Union.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance to draw attention to new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague's text. I note, however, that when it comes to products that can become drugs, it is already difficult to find consistency and openness within national policy. I therefore have little hope at European level on this specific topic. If things change, I will gladly continue to participate in the debates and represent my citizens in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this report seeking to put potentially dangerous new psychoactive substances under control. The substance 25I-NBOMe is a classical serotonergic hallucinogen, which has been subject to control measures and criminal sanctions at EU level from 2003. AH-7921 is a structurally atypical synthetic opioid analgesic commonly known as 'doxylam'. It can be easily confused with ‘doxylamine’, an anti-histaminic medicine with sedative-hypnotic properties, which could lead to unintentional overdoses. MDPV is a ring-substituted synthetic derivative of cathinone chemically related to pyrovalerone, which are both subject to control under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. One hundred and eight fatalities were registered in eight Member States and Norway between September 2009 and August 2013 relating to it. Methoxetamine is a substance which is chemically similar to ketamine and the internationally-controlled substance phencyclidine (PCP). Twenty deaths associated with methoxetamine have been reported by six Member States. The risk assessment recommended by the Council concluded that these substances should be put under control to minimise the health and social risk they cause.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to undergo 4-iodine-2.5-dimetoxi-N-(2-methoxybenzil)phenythylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3.4-dichloro-N-[1-(dimethylamino)cyclohexyl]benzamide (AH-H-Y-Y 3.4-methylenedypirovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-metoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylithimo) cyclohexanon (metoxetamine) control measures, as research by the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction has shown that these substances do not have recognised use in human or veterinary medicine, have hallucinogenic effects and cause a severe form of agitation , confusions of intense sound and visual hallucinations, aggression, violence and self-harm.  In addition, these substances pose health risks as they have been detected in autopsy samples of multiple deaths and are listed among the causes of death. Specifically, there is a certain risk that users may consume new psychoactive substances such as these unknowingly, which can lead to fatal consequences. For these reasons, I believe that the European Union should regulate and prevent the further spread and use of these substances.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - Report on the draft Council implementing decision imposing control measures on 4-iodo-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybendyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[[1-(dimethylamino cyclohexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedioxypirovaleone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexanon (methethetamin) that we need better data exchange, effective risk assessments and stricter controls on new psychoactive substances occurring on the black market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council, since the substances included in the report pose an obvious risk to public health and their free movement has no benefit.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures across the EU. This substance has already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define health and social risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for monitoring measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to the protection of the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances. I therefore voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree that the synthetic drugs mentioned in the report should be subjected to control measures.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision speaks of new substances that have caused a large number of deaths and toxicity. The proposal aims to ensure the continuity of control measures in the Member States relating to these new substances and so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 25I NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxyptamine to control measures. These substances are being illegally sold as drugs or substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Many Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Substances 25I-NBOMe, AH—7921, MDPV and methoxamamine were not assessed at UNITED NATIONS level at the time the risk assessment was requested in the Union, but were assessed in June 2014 by the Committee of Experts on Drug Addiction of the World Health Organisation. There were four deaths associated with substance 25I-NBOMe recorded in three Member States. Severe toxicity associated with its use has been reported in four Member States. If this new psychoactive substance becomes widely available and used, the implications for individual and public health may be significant. The substance AH-7921 is a synthetic, structurally atypical synthetic opioid analgesic commonly known by internet providers as 'doxylam'. It can be easily confused with doxylamine, an anti-histamine drug with sedative-hypnotic properties, which could lead to accidental overdoses. Information on acute and chronic toxicity associated with MDPV, as well as its psychological and behavioural effects, and on the potential for dependency, is not properly known throughout the Union. Information from published studies, confirmed by clinical cases, suggests that the psychopharmacological profile observed for PvM is similar to that of cocaine and methamphetamine, although more potent and longer lasting. In addition, the substance MDPV is ten times more potent in its ability to induce locomotor activation, taquicardia and hypertension.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of substances/drugs 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxeamine. We must therefore support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. -u2012 In the EUROPEAN Parliament resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on control measures for 4-iodine-2,5-dimethoxy-N-(2-methoxybenzyl)phenethylamine (25I-NBOMe), 3,4-dichloro-N-[1 (dimethylamino)cyclohexyl]methyl]benzamide (AH-7921), 3,4-methylenedioxypyrovalerone (MDPV) and 2-(3-methoxyphenyl)-2-(ethylamino)cyclohexanone (methoxetamiin) I abstained. I see no need to adopt control measures for psychoactive substances at European level. It is therefore quite right that certain Member States have agreed on derogations. The principle of subsidiarity is blatantly violated by a European regulation of these issues.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures.  Both substances are being illegally sold as substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Eight Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances are extremely dangerous to human life. They are the cause of many forfeitures and can eventually lead to the death of their dependent consumers. Further research is needed to better assess the harmful effects of these substances. However, we have enough elements to put them through control measures. Thus, this report aims to establish rules to severely regulate the use of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. With regard to a problem which requires the cooperation of all Member States, I believe that it is a useful text that will facilitate the repression of the trafficking concerned. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am on record as supporting a ban on so-called ‘legal highs’ in the UK. Nevertheless, there are two problems here. Firstly, it is inappropriate for this matter to be dealt with at EU level. Drug policy should always remain firmly within the domain of the Member States. For example, Portugal and the Netherlands have a much more liberal stance than many in the United Kingdom would be happy to adopt. That is a matter for the national governments and this resolution is in effect a backdoor means of handing power to the European Union. Secondly, individual substance bans are an ineffective tool; changing from one substance to another of similar chemical composition is too easy. Overarching legislation, rather than individually referencing chemicals, is what is needed. So although I support the general principle, I felt that I must abstain on these votes.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it aims to promote the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances that threaten the health of Europeans.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to encourage Member States to impose control measures and criminal sanctions on certain psychotropic substances, as provided for under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Yes, this new psychotropic substance must be subject to control measures throughout the European Union. This will require improved cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services and public protection agencies.  That is why I voted for it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In accordance with EU legislation on the exchange of information, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control this psychoactive chemical throughout the Union. The illicit presence and manufacture of this substance is documented in several Member States and several deaths due to it have been recorded within the Union. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to follow the Council's proposal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures because of their proven harmfulness. As with the previous three reports, the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union to avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services and to protect the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances. So I voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Boni report because I believe that the increase in controls on substances that can be used for the synthesis of synthetic drugs in Europe is fundamental to the fight against proliferation.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Between June 2013 and June 2014, 31 deaths related to 4.4'-DMAR were recorded in three Member States, 28 deaths related to the presence of MT-45 in biological samples. The risk assessment report reveals that little scientific evidence is available on 4.4'-DMAR and notes that more research is needed to determine the health and social risks it poses. As for the information available on MT-45, it suggests that it is consumed mainly in private, either by consumers willing to test a new substance, either by opiate-dependent consumers who do not have access to heroin or other opiates. The tests and information currently available are sufficient grounds for subjecting the 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures throughout the Union. As a result of the health risks posed by their consumption, as their detection attests in several deaths, their possible inadvertent consumption and the absence of medical value of these substances, 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 must be subject to control measures. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, approving the Council's draft on the application of control measures to psychoactive substances concerning the application of a Council implementing decision on the application of control measures to 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazol-2-amamine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylethyl)piperazine (MT-45). The European Parliament calls on the Council to consult Parliament again if it intends to substantially amend the text adopted by Parliament.  The European Parliament and the Council have agreed, in accordance with a joint 2005 decision, to exchange information on new psychoactive substances, on their risk assessments and to provide for control measures. The development of psychoactive substances is particularly dangerous for human health and the environment and urgent action by the Member States is therefore necessary. The joint decision on the exchange, risk assessment and control of information on new psychoactive substances shall draw attention to information on suspected adverse reactions to be transmitted in accordance with the established pharmacovigilance system. This Decision also provides for an assessment of the risks associated with these new psychoactive substances with a view to authorising the control measures applied in the Member States for the use of new psychoactive substances.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it of the utmost importance that the legislation keeps pace with the incredibly rapid development of new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes caused by the slowness of the legislation. Almost daily we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but often are not yet considered illegal.  In my opinion, we need to provide the national authorities with the right legal instruments so that they can effectively combat the production and distribution of these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in a timely manner to prevent further tragedies. For these reasons, I supported the report as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Then there are the 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45, and at this point the European Commission expects the continuation of restrictive measures for the whole EU area and for all Member States, which is why we in the EPP Group supported this.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report and prohibition because the misuse of these substances is a threat to public health in the EU. Young people are the target group of consumers and as such suffer the most harm from consumption. Deaths have been registered across Europe, and recently a teenager died in the middle of consumption in Croatia. Some of the compounds that are on the market are extremely strong and can cause consequences such as increased pressure, paranoia, psychosis, nausea, seizures and in some cases, death. The most severe consequences occur because the active substance is incorrectly distributed per product during mixing and drying. As a result, some packages are many times stronger and more harmful than usual. The common market and the abolition of borders have brought multiple benefits to Europe, but in this case this freedom has negative side effects. Member States cannot tackle the problem of 'legal drugs' on their own, as they cannot keep up with the speed at which new compounds appear.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported placing these substances under control measures as considerable research conducted by the EMCDDA shows clearly that these chemical substances merit control. They have been directly responsible for a number of deaths and intoxications across the European Union and are legally marketed as substitutes for either research chemicals or illegal substances. It is essential that they are controlled in an EU context to prevent them gaining a foothold in the market (illicit or legal) and to prevent distributors preying on legislative discrepancies between Member States.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that, considering all the elements in our possession (cases of death, limited therapeutic usefulness, etc.) with regard to 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45, it may be useful to subject them to control measures throughout the Territory of the Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45, psychotropic substances, to control measures throughout the European Union. These substances have already caused a dozen deaths suggesting that they pose a sufficiently serious danger for their use to be better supervised. It seems clear that further studies are needed to better understand the health risks that individuals face after absorbing these substances. It is essential that these controls are introduced at European level so as not to hinder cross-border cooperation between the various national services.   That is why I have spoken in favour of this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. These four reports regulate the control of new or currently used substances as chemical parts for drugs or similar new substances. Parliament is being asked to approve more controls on these substances.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the introduction of control measures on substances described in the report (4,4'-DMAR and MT-45) as they have no therapeutic properties for human or veterinary use and no other evidence indicates that they are used for other purposes. The substance 4,4'-DMAR is a derivative of two synthetic stimulants already subject to control measures, and has appeared on the market of new psychoactive substances as a "chemical used for research" first retail on the Internet, then also available on the street, often peddled as ecstasy or amphetamine. Fortunately, it seems that its use would not be widespread. The substance MT-45 has been present on the drug market since October 2013 and is accompanied by acute toxicity far greater than that of morphine. In view of the health risks involved, trade in these substances within the Union must be subject to control measures and I therefore voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will subject 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45  to control measures. The high toxicity of these drugs and their link to high numbers of fatal and non-fatal intoxications mean that control measures are necessary to get avoid future tragedies. New psychoactive substances emerge on the market all the time and can be extremely harmful to consumers.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, I chose to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this vote because these chemicals are new and we currently do not know the ramifications down the road that they may have for the citizens of Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of new psychoactive substances 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydroossazol-2-amine(4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylyl)-piperazine (MT-45). On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject these new substances to control measures throughout the Union. As I regard the fight against drugs as a fundamental issue, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question aims to establish the control of new psychotropic substances whose use has already caused dozens of deaths to control measures throughout the EU. Further research is needed to define its health and social risks, but it is clear that the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for subjecting these substances to control measures throughout the European Union. So I voted for this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the Council draft and the Council Decision of 10 May on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychotropic substances, I am voting in favour of the Council's draft

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. During the debate, the European Commission and the Council stressed the danger of these substances and the need to subject them to control measures, given also the number of deaths and intoxications caused by these substances.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I fully agree with the Council's decision to subject substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 as medicines that have caused numerous deaths and intoxications to control measures. In addition, MT-45 has been shown to have about 80% of the power of morphine and an opioid form. It has also been used as a conductor from which a large family of powerful opioid drugs has been developed, and repeated use of MT-45 has been associated with hearing loss and consciousness. Finally, 4,4'-DMAR is a psychostimulating and empatogenic drug detected in the Netherlands in December 2012 that has claimed many lives in Hungary, the Netherlands and Northern Ireland. The European Union must safeguard the health of its citizens, so new and more detailed analyses of these drugs are more than laws.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There were four reports on the subject of drugs today. UKIP notes two things; firstly, that the UK has an opt-out in this area. Secondly, we note that the UK Government already has very sensible laws and controls in place in the fields of drugs and public health. Therefore, we chose to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2005/387/JAI on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the dangers inherent in new drugs require rapid and concerted intervention by States at European level.  When a new substance is found, the Member State should report this to Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction, which will also try to assess its risk to public health as well as associated crime. Once the procedure is complete, they may request control or prohibition measures from Member States. Although Parliament's involvement is unnecessary - given the exclusively technical content of this decision - Parliament must be consulted and has to give its opinion.  Both drugs have already caused several deaths. The 4,4'-DMAR is already sold on the street, often as ecstasy or amphetamines. Thirty-one deaths are known in a one-year period. In relation to MT-45, 28 deaths were found in a period of not more than six months and their level of toxicity is several times higher than morphine.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision proposing to subject four drugs that cause serious damage to the health of those who use them to more control measures.   On the basis of the information made available by the European Commission and the Council, a risk assessment analysis was carried out which showed that the toxicity of the substances in question is such that their consumption can seriously harm people's health. In addition, the risks are aggravated by the fact that, according to the information transmitted, some people would sometimes take these substances without their knowledge in combination or as an alternative to other psychoactive substances. I therefore believe that it is of great importance to increase control in the trade and distribution of these substances. In this connection, I would remind you that this proposal for a Council decision is intended to urge the Member States to subject substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures and to apply the criminal sanctions provided for in their legislation, in accordance with the obligations laid down in the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A risk assessment report was submitted to the Commission detailing the increasing mortality rate and overall health detriments associated with the substance stated. I voted in favour of the proposal in question which aims to protect EU citizens from health and social risks by requesting Member States legislate in relation to the substance in question to further avoid fatalities, within their own drug-abuse legislative framework.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Council Decision 2005/387/JHA on the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (EMCDDA) assessed the risks of new psychoactive substances (MT-45). On the basis of this report, the Commission calls on the Member States to subject these new substances to control measures throughout the Union. For obvious reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures.  Both substances are being illegally sold as substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Eight Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which aims to subject 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures across the EU. 4,4'-DMAR consists of two synthetic stimulants detected in nine Member States. Furthermore there have been 31 deaths associated with this substance registered in three Member States. On the other hand, MT-45 is one of a series of analgesics. A total of 28 fatalities were recorded by one Member State. Based on the evidence and information currently available I agree that these substances should be subjected to control measures.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the exchange of information, risk assessment and control of new psychoactive substances 44-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenietyl)piperazine (MT-45) is a welcome one.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the implementation of the decision subjecting 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures within the Member States. These new substances pose a danger, resulting in a significant number of deaths and poisonings. Considering that this report contributes to better protection of European citizens, I have spoken in favour of the report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 are psychoactive substances that damage the central nervous system and impair mental functions. Currently legal and for sale on the internet, they replace "traditional" drugs and spread on the domestic market.  From now on, these substances should only be used for research and scientific development. They will also be permanently restricted and subject to the EU's criminal law provisions, which is in line with the application of the European precautionary principle.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is essential to adapt the European policy on combating psychoactive substances.  4.4'-DMAR is a derivative of synthetic stimulant. Its presence was observed from December 2012 in nine Member States. 31 deaths related to this substance were recorded between June 2013 and June 2014. MT-45 is a painkiller and has been on the market since October 2013. It is mostly sold on the internet. Between November 2013 and July 2014, 28 deaths were recorded in a Member State and studies show that its toxicity is high and higher than that of morphine.  European legislation to control these psychoactive drugs is essential for better cross-border coordination in the fight against drugs.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up with the new drugs that drug dealers and criminal networks are launching. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, because to combat the trafficking of synthetic drugs it is essential to exchange information, assess risks and control new psychoactive substances, namely 4,4' D-Mar and MT 45.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better control of these substances.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the importance and urgency of this issue in terms of public health and safety, I voted in favour of the four pieces of legislation, so that we can prevent and prevent the spread of the listed harmful substances in Europe.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because I feel we are continuing down a failed road and that what is proposed is a denial of reality.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of more controls for the substances in question.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of subjecting substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. I believe that every new psychoactive substance should be subject to risk control and evaluation and the results of the tests should be disseminated as information between Member States.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to European Union legislation on information exchange, assessment and control of new psychoactive substances, the Council proposes to control, throughout the whole territory of the European Union, this psychoactive substance. The presence and illicit manufacture of the substance is confirmed in several Member States and several deaths caused by it have been recognised within the European Union. The report supports the Council’s proposal. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of all these implementing decisions in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. It is vitally important to keep up to date with the new drugs being constantly developed by drug traffickers and criminal organisations. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive substances which change constantly in order to take advantage of legislative gaps. As we witness day by day, these new drugs are not only extremely toxic and have caused large numbers of deaths, but are often not even recognised as illegal. We must enable our law enforcement authorities to counter such criminal activity, providing them with the necessary instruments to fight back the spreading of these new substances. At the same time we must make sure that schools are supported in education and prevention activities. Special attention must be given also to help the young victims and their families.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I consider uniform, appropriate, technically applicable rules to be very important in this context.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the introduction of control measures for 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. The number of poisonings and deaths caused by these dangerous drugs is enormous. We must take measures to prevent the spread of such psychoactive substances.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to invite the Member States to subject 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures across the European Union, given the health risks connected to these substances.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction (OEDT) has ruled that psychotropic substances 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 present health risks. Support, therefore, subject these psychotropic substances to control measures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Council.2012. 4-methlamphetamine has a higher toxicity than amphetamine and therefore poses an obvious risk to public health. Moreover, since the substance has no known or other legitimate medical applications, its free movement has no obvious benefit to society as a whole.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as it concerns substances which are a threat to public safety. The substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 are synthetic stimulants which have been linked to a number of deaths in the EU. They have been mis-sold on the illicit market as ecstasy and amphetamines. Given the risk to health involved, I support measures for these substances to be controlled at EU level.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of subjecting 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. Since October 2013 MT-45, a synthetic opioid, has been detected in three Member States. A total of 28 deaths associated with MT-45 have been reported in one Member State, within a period of nine months, as well as 18 non-fatal intoxications.  According to the information available from the risk assessment reports, the toxicity of these substances is such that it can cause severe harms to the health of individuals. Moreover, the risks are heightened by the fact that these substances are reported, in some cases, to have been consumed unknowingly by certain users together with or instead of other psychoactive substances.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in order to ensure the continuity of control measures across Member States on the new substances. Both the Commission and the European Council have highlighted that the new substances have provoked a large amount of toxicity and therefore a large number of deaths. I support the stance of the Commission and the European Council regarding the danger surrounding these new substances and I therefore also believe in a strict necessity of control.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with a view to the maintenance of control measures for new drugs. It is of the utmost importance to be aware of the newer and new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly modifying them to exploit legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new substances that are toxic, in many cases causing death, but most of the time they are not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I support enforcement decisions aimed at introducing controls at the European Union's borders on certain psychoactive substances.  Currently, these substances, whose marketing is favoured by the internet, are spreading alarmingly in Europe. Their use is poorly controlled and their effects unknown, the national authorities of several Member States have identified several cases of deaths and direct or indirect accidents related to the consumption of these substances. That is why I share the analysis of providing strict supervision of these substances and limiting their sale and use in the European Union as much as possible.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft. 4-methlamphetamine has a higher toxicity than amphetamine and therefore poses an obvious risk to public health. Moreover, since the substance has no known or other legitimate medical applications, its free movement has no obvious benefit to society as a whole.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision on the subjecting of substances 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4.5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine 4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylene)piperazine (MT-45) control measures on the ground that neither the proven human or veterinary medical benefit of the two substances within the European Union has been established. However, established deaths related to the consumption of 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 indicate that further research is needed to identify their health and social threats with certainty. Therefore, I strongly support the subjecting of substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 through control measures to the safety of all CITIZENS of the European Union.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused the death of several people. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. The report also provides for better public protection from the risks caused by the use of these substances. So I voted FOR.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on subjecting 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures as there are still debates on legal highs within recreational drugs. These are not the competencies of the EU and should be decided at nation-state level.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Michael Boni's report on the decision to continue the controls recommended by the Commission and the Council on 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 in the Member States because of the toxicity of this substance which has sometimes led to deaths. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 are products on the drug market and are believed to have been the cause of several deaths. Further work is therefore needed to establish the health risks posed by such products.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposed measures are appropriate and fall within the competence of the Union, not least because control measures are to be made uniform in order to make the internal market work. That is why I am voting in favour.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There have been 31 deaths associated with this substance registered in three Member States. However, the evidence and information currently available and the results of the health risks that they pose recommend that it should be subjected to control measures. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance that we keep up with the new drugs that drug dealers and criminal networks are launching. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The psychoactive substance MT-45 is a single-structure synthetic opioid while the substance 4,4'-DMAR is a derivative of aminorex and 4-methylminorex (4-MAR), two synthetic stimulants subject to control measures under the United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances of 1971. Both are present on the EU drug market and it has been shown that they were the cause or cause, along with other substances, of several cases of death. Monitoring and efficient control measures must be ensured, and for these reasons I am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft enforcement decision of the Council submitting the 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphényl)-4.5-dihydrooxazol-2-amine (4.4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4- (1.2-dipphenylethyl) piperazine (MT-45) to control measures. Between June 2013 and June 2014, 31 deaths related to 4.4'-DMAR have already been recorded in three Member States, in which 4.4'-DMAR alone or in association with one or more other substances was found in post-mortem samples.  Further research is needed to define the health and social risks of these psychotropic substances, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for them to be subjected to control measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to protect the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it protects the peoples of Europe, through cross-border police cooperation, from these new psychotropic substances.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a consultation of the European Parliament on Council decisions on the inclusion by Member States of specific control measures on substances which have been considered psychotropic and toxic. Having found several dozen deaths in different Member States from one of these substances (some of them conventional drugs), it has been decided to subject to specific risk assessment and control measures, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MeP Michał Boni's report highlighting the importance of researching the effects of substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 on health, introducing control measures for said substance and combating drug abuse, which is a major problem, especially for young people in the Member States. MT-45 has been present on the Union market since November 2013 and 28 deaths related to this substance have since been reported. 4,4-DMAR has been available on the drug market in the European Union since at least December 2012. It is sold independently, but also in the illegal market of ecstasy and amphetamines. There are 31 deaths associated with this substance. Three Member States control 4.4-DMAR within national legislation and five Member States use other measures. Due to this statistic, the report calls for further research and additional control measures for these substances.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 4,4'-DMAR (4,4'-dimethylaminoreks) – psychostimulant drug, entactogen, hence "designer drug". A few dozen people died as a result of the use of the substance in 2013-2014 (Ireland, Hungary, United Kingdom). MT-45 (also known as IC-6) – opioid analgesic. There are known cases of hearing loss and unconsciousness due to the use of this substance. Having said this alone, I voted in favour of this report, because such substances cannot be left without legal control. I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the inclusion of 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'- DMAR) and 1-cycloexyl-4-(1,2-biphenylethyl)piperazine (MT-45) in control measures, because this report strengthens the powers of the European Parliament by requesting that the European Parliament be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this request for control measures. As with previous substances, 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 have already caused dozens of deaths. That is why we want to impose control measures throughout the European Union. This will protect the public from the risks associated with these substances.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report implementing the decision on subjecting 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazol-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylethyl)piperazine (MT-45) to control measures.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. I believe that it is appropriate to introduce control measures in the European Union on these substances, to study the health and social risks involved and thus to avoid obstacles to law enforcement and judicial cooperation across borders and to protect European citizens from the risks that these substances could entail.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my agreement with this report, as I fully agree with the need to ensure the efficiency of monitoring and control systems within the Member States with regard to the substances covered by this document.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the introduction of substance control measures described in the report (4,4'-DMAR and MT-45) as they are potentially dangerous elements as they can be used for drug development. The substance 4,4'-DMAR is a derivative of two synthetic stimulants, and has appeared on the online market among the so-called "legal drugs"; it quickly began to be passed off on the street, alongside other dangerous substances such as ecstasy or amphetamines.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of substances/drugs 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 and should therefore be supported.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. New synthetic psychoactive substances are emerging. MT-45 is a synthetic opioid discovered in the 1970s and recently re-emerged on the market for new synthetic drugs. The report before us validates the Council's proposal to subject this substance to control measures throughout the Union. Because of the health risks it poses, as demonstrated by its discovery in several cases of death, I vote FOR.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Psychotropic substances have already caused deaths. Further research is needed to identify health and social risks.  The report aims to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures throughout the European Union and to develop cross-border cooperation measures between law enforcement and judicial services. It also aims to protect the public from the risks caused by the use of these substances. I voted FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council implementing decision subjecting substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures is part of the need for control and risk assessment of new psychoactive substances, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support the consultation to combat the abuse and trafficking of drugs, including the risk assessment of new psychoactive substances.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the draft 4.4-DMAR implementation decision on 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. With this enforcement decision, the Council intends to invite Member States to subject these substances to the controls and sanctions provided for in their national laws.  After assessing the health risks posed by these substances, the Commission had decided that they should be subject to controls throughout the European Union. In the fight against the use of psychotropic substances, there is no doubt about the added value of concerted action at European level. Where a substance poses a risk to public health, it is essential that it be monitored and monitored throughout the Union.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree to subject the substance to control measures. In both cases, it is an enlarged substance sold as a drug, mainly in Europe and the USA. The new psychoactive substance 4,4'-DMAR appears to have psychostimulating properties. 4,4'-DMAR is a substance structurally related to two substances listed in the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances (4-Methylaminorex and Aminorex). Substance 4,4'-DMAR has been available on the drug market in the European Union since at least December 2012. The new psychoactive substance MT-45 is a synthetic opioid with a unique structure that was studied for its analgesic properties in the 1970s. Mt-45 has been available on the drug market in the European Union since October 2013. I firmly believe that there are grounds for subjecting 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to strict control measures throughout the Union. The main of these is that the toxicity of these substances is so high that it can seriously harm the health of individuals and lead to death. The European Monitoring Centre for Drugs records reports of deaths caused by the use of these hazardous substances. Moreover, the risks are reinforced by the fact that in some reported cases these substances were often taken without their knowledge by some users together with other psychoactive substances.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to invite the Member States to subject 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures across the European Union, which is extremely important. The substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 are two synthetic stimulants controlled under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. They emerged on the new psychoactive substances market sold by internet retailers, and are now available on the street market. There are several studies on animals indicating that the acute toxicity of MT-45 is several times higher than that of morphine. The substance appears to be mostly used in the home environment either by users willing to try a new substance or by opioid dependent users with no access to heroin or any other opioid. The risk assessment reports reveal that there is limited scientific evidence available on 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 and they pointed out that further research would be needed to determine the health and social risks that they pose. However, the evidence and information currently available and the results of the health risks that they pose recommend that they should be subjected to control measures.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council intends to take a decision on the subject of eight relatively new psychoactive substances. They are all present in the Member States of the European Union and are distributed on the Internet, and deaths have been recorded in all contexts. Libe, the ep's competent committee, almost unanimously supported the draft decisions in its reports. Given their proven danger, I support their control myself.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. Four reports are proposed at this session to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures throughout the European Union. The affected products are 4-methylamphetamine, 5-(2-aminopropyl)indole, 25I-NBOMe, AH-7921, MDPV and methoxetamine, and 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. Each of these substances has already caused dozens of deaths.  Further research is needed to define the exact health risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for testing measures throughout the European Union. The aim of these decisions is to avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to allow the protection of the public from the risks associated with the consumption of these substances in a precautionary manner. These initiatives should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I advocate that the 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-di-hydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and the 1- cyclo-hexyl-4-(1,2-diphenyl)piperazine (MT-45), new psychoactive substance, they should be subject to control measures in all Member States of the European Union and to the criminal sanctions provided for in their legislation under the obligations under the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances. According to the information available in the risk assessment reports, the high toxicity of these substances can seriously harm people's health. Furthermore, the risks are compounded by the fact that, according to information received, certain people inadvertently consume these substances in combination with or replacing other psychoactive substances. I believe that the proliferation of new psychoactive substances, which are harmful to people's health, should be seen as a public health problem and their fight is imperative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures because of their proven harmfulness. I voted for this text, as I did in the three previous reports.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which supports efforts to collectively tackle the sale of legal highs which have caused a number of death and fatalities in the UK and across Europe. Moreover, the information available suggests that some of the psychoactive substances such as 4-methylamphetamine are produced and distributed by the same organised crime groups that are involved in the manufacture and trafficking of amphetamine. Trafficking occurs across borders and it is essential that Member States work together to disrupt the EU’s trafficking networks.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will regulate control measures for the following drug substances: 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report calls for control measures for 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45. I also support this report, and I am in favour of it.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I supported this report which endorses the Council's text to transfer to the European Union the powers of controls relating to the substance Mephedrone (full name 4-methylmethinone abbreviated 4-MMC). This new synthetic product with psychoactive effects having harmful effects on health, it is important that control is strengthened by generalisation and harmonization of its study at European level.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The introduction of control measures is necessary to prevent misuse of the substance.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the work done by the rapporteur and thanking him, I am voting positively.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of introducing 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 control measures, as the substances caused more deaths and poisonings, according to the European Commission. It is necessary to establish appropriate controls on these substances and to implement it in all Member States so as not to unduly endanger the health of citizens.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The currently available evidence and information at our disposal provides us with sufficient grounds to object to the psychoactive substances 4,4-DMAR and MT-45 and to take steps to step up control measures across the European Union when it comes to these substances. Due to the health risks posed by these substances, the acute toxicity indicated by the tests, and the documented several deaths resulting from the consumption of these substances, as well as the lack of their medical value, I support this report and support the implementation of control measures for psychoactive substances 4,4-DMAR and MT-45.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures because of their proven harmfulness. I voted for this text, as I did in the three previous reports.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Between November 2013 and July 2014, 31 deaths related to the use of the substance 4,4'-DMAR were recorded. Of particular concern is that this substance is often the subject of smuggling of criminal groups. Between November 2013 and July 2014, there were 28 deaths related to the use of MT-45 reported in only one of the EU Member States, partly as a result of insufficient control at national and European level. For all of the above, I support Parliament's agreement with the Council proposal that substances 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4.5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1 -cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-dipheniletyl) piperazine (MT-45) subject to control measures at European level, thereby preventing their distribution and fatal effects on human health.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I agree with colleague Michal Boni's draft report on the subjecting of substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 control measures. Following the Council's decision to request an assessment of the risks of use, manufacture and trafficking of these psychoactive substances, the Scientific Committee on Monitoring Drugs and Drug Addiction carried out the research and submitted a risk assessment report to the European Commission and the Council. While scientific evidence on the overarching risks of action of these substances is currently limited, it has been concluded that there is a basis for subjecting these substances to control measures in the Member States of the European Union. It is considered that these substances, due to toxicity, can cause serious adverse consequences for human health, and during the hearing in the Commission and the Council it was concluded that they caused a series of poisonings and deaths. In addition, the risks were further increased as cases were reported where users were taking these substances with or instead of other psychoactive substances. This requires the implementation of control measures, as well as the criminal sanctions imposed.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Decision 2005/387/JHA states that a new psychoactive substance may be subject to control measures in the European Union. In view of this, I am in favour of giving Member States the opportunity to subject substances 4,4' - DMAR and MT - 45 to a more careful assessment of the damage they cause to human health. I also believe that it would be desirable to establish a complete picture of the criminal sanctions which may be provided for in the respective national legislations.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU plays a crucial role in harmonising the permitted substances within its territory. Successive laws authorising or reversing the movement of certain chemicals deemed dangerous are intended to protect the health of European citizens. In the event of a health risk, the EU can strengthen control measures or prohibit the movement and sale of a specific substance.  In this context, in the face of the potential risks of 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45, the European Parliament has supported the Council's position to subject these two substances to control measures and I welcome this.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is certain that the assessment of the risks of these substances to health and society (4,4'-DMAR – synthetic stimulant; MT-45 – analgesic) still lacks some scientific demonstration, there is already sufficient grounds for establishing control measures in the EU. All these substances are related to various deaths and organized crime.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Between June 2013 and June 2014, 31 deaths related to 4.4'-DMAR were recorded in three Member States, 28 deaths related to the presence of MT-45 in biological samples The risk assessment report reveals that little scientific evidence is available on the 4.4'-DMAR and notes that more research is needed to determine the health and social risks it poses. As for the information available on MT-45, it suggests that it is consumed mainly in private, either by consumers willing to test a new substance, either by opiate-dependent consumers who do not have access to heroin or other opiates. The tests and information currently available are sufficient grounds for subjecting the 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures throughout the Union. As a result of the health risks posed by their consumption, as their detection attests in several deaths, their possible inadvertent consumption and the absence of medical value of these substances, 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 must be subject to control measures. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the draft enforcement decision of the Council submitting 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4.5-dihydrooxazol-2-amine (4.4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4- (1.2-dipphenyl)pipérazine (MT-45) to control measures and which asks the Council to consult again with the European Parliament if it intends to substantially amend the text we have approved.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision subjecting substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. Such substances were considered synthetic stimulants and are being consumed as a substance on their behest and sold on the illicit market as ecstasy and amphetamines. There have been 31 deaths associated with 4,4'-DMAR in three Member States and 28 MT-45-related deaths. For these reasons, it is absolutely essential to subject both substances to control measures throughout the Union.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Council decision to subject substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures because they are considered dangerous to human health. The debate between the Commission and the Council has shown that these substances have caused a great deal of death and intoxication.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft. 4-methlamphetamine has a higher toxicity than amphetamine and therefore poses an obvious risk to public health. Moreover, since the substance has no known or other legitimate medical applications, its free movement has no obvious benefit to society as a whole.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures.  Both substances are being illegally sold as substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Eight Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the draft Council implementing decision subjecting substances such as 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. These are psychotic substances, natural or synthetic, which affect the nervous system and cause stimulating or depressive effects, just like illicit drugs. The procedure voted on today provides for a ban on the manufacture and marketing of these substances, and also provides for criminal sanctions throughout Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe this is not an EU competency but instead should be done by nation-state governments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As these substances have become better understood and the harmful effects from human consumption have become better known it is important that these two substances be subjected to control measures across the Union.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 These new psychotic substances have no medically recognized benefit. On the contrary, they cause various changes in thinking, behaviour or hallucinations, so they must be controlled in the EU as a whole, not just in some Member States.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report because substance 4,4'-DMAR is a synthetically substituted oxazolin derivative, and this substance has appeared on the psychoactive substance market as a research chemical sold by online sellers and is also available on the streets, where it appears as a new and as yet unregulated and underexplored drug. It is sold and used as a standalone substance or in the form of ecstasy or amphetamines. Substance 4,4'-DMAR is not listed in the list of substances to be controlled, it has not been considered under the United Nations system, is not currently under consideration or is planned for consideration. There is no established or recognised use of substance 4,4'-DMAR in human or veterinary medicine in the Union, where the substance MT-45, present on the market as a drug, is sold as a research chemical and mainly online. There is no evidence so far of organised crime's involvement in production, distribution, trading and supply, but as it is a new type of drug, the substance MT-45 which is not listed on the list of substances to be controlled should begin to be regulated.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the introduction of supervisory measures for 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45. The new psychoactive substance 4,4'-DMAR has psychostimulative properties and has been available on the EU drug market since at least December 2012 and has been detected in nine Member States. In addition, three Member States reported 31 deaths and one fatality poisoning. Information about the deaths suggests that users unknowingly took substance 4,4'-DMAR in search of other stimulantes. The new psychoactive substance MT-45 caused 28 deaths in one Member State, as well as 18 poisonings without fatalities. While evidence at this stage on the risks of these substances is limited, the Commission considers that there is a basis for subjecting these substances to control measures across the Union. The main reason is that the toxicity of these substances can cause severe adverse consequences for human health, all the more so because users are often unaware of the nature of the substance they consume, thinking it is something else. I support the Commission's position, as I consider that these substances should be subject to control measures and criminal penalties as provided for in the 1971 United Nations Convention on Psychotropic Substances.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Each new psychoactive substance should be subject to control, risk assessment and the results of controls disseminated as information between Member States.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the report with the aim of maintaining control measures for new drug components. It is of the utmost importance to draw attention to new drugs that are being marketed by drug dealers and criminal networks. We must stop the distribution of psychoactive ingredients, which are constantly changing, taking advantage of legal loopholes. Every day we are confronted with new drugs that are toxic, in many cases cause death, but are often not yet considered illegal. We must provide member state authorities with the right tools to effectively combat these new drug components. At the same time, we must do everything we can to ensure that school teachers and parents are properly informed in order to prevent further tragedies.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague's text. I note, however, that when it comes to products that can become drugs, it is already difficult to find consistency and openness within national policy. I therefore have little hope at European level on this specific topic. If things change, I will gladly continue to participate in the debates and represent my citizens in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which supports subjecting 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures across the EU. The substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 are new psychoactive substances. While more research is needed, available evidence suggests they pose health and social risk. The substance 4,4'-DMAR emerged on the new psychoactive substances market in 2012 as a ‘research chemical’ sold by internet retailers, and it is now available on the street market. There have been 31 deaths associated with 4,4'-DMAR registered in three Member States, between June 2013 and June 2014. MT-45 was invented in the early 1970s. A total of 28 fatalities due to MT-45 occurring between November 2013 and July 2014 have been reported by one Member State.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report on surveillance measures for substances 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4.5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-(DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-dipheniletyl) piperazine (MT-45), given the risks assessed by the Scientific Committee of the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction.  According to these results, these substances are new psychoactive substances that have become available on the drug market since 2013, and in three Member States of the European Union in one year there have been numerous deaths related to these substances, and poisoning without deaths. I believe that this is sufficient evidence of the risks of using these substances, and further information on their harmfulness is provided by the fact that several animal studies have shown that the acute toxicity of MT-45 is several times greater than the toxicity of morphine.  Although these substances are not widespread, they are mainly used by addicts who do not have access to heroin, and therefore it is obvious that their use must be regulated at the very beginning and prevent further spread.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Report on the draft Council implementing decision establishing control measures for 4-methyl-5-(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylethyl)piperazine (MT-45) because I believe that we need better data exchange, effective risk assessments and tighter controls on new psychoactive substances occurring on the black market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft. 4-methlamphetamine has a higher toxicity than amphetamine and therefore poses an obvious risk to public health. Moreover, since the substance has no known or other legitimate medical applications, its free movement has no obvious benefit to society as a whole.
