name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to subject new psychotropic substances to control measures throughout the European Union. These substances have already caused dozens of deaths. Further research is needed to define health and social risks, but the available evidence provides sufficient grounds for monitoring measures throughout the European Union. This would avoid the emergence of obstacles to cross-border cooperation between law enforcement and judicial services, and to the protection of the public from the risks associated with the use of these substances.  I therefore voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the council's draft. 4-methlamphetamine has a higher toxicity than amphetamine and therefore poses an obvious risk to public health. Moreover, since the substance has no known or other legitimate medical applications, its free movement has no obvious benefit to society as a whole.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree that the synthetic drugs mentioned in the report should be subjected to control measures.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This decision speaks of new substances that have caused a large number of deaths and toxicity. The proposal aims to ensure the continuity of control measures in the Member States relating to these new substances and so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Council Decision urging Member States to subject substances known as 4.4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures.  Both substances are being illegally sold as substitutes for other better-known drugs without consumers being duly informed of the risk to their health, as they have been associated with several deaths in various Member States. Eight Member States have already taken control measures on this substance. This decision also makes it easier for them to exchange information on these new psychoactive substances and their potential health damage within the EU.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The substance 4,4'-DMAR has emerged in the new market for psychoactive substances as an "experimental chemical" sold on the Internet, and is now available in high street markets. 4,4'-DMAR is being sold and consumed as a substance by itself, but has also been incorrectly sold on the illicit market as ecstasy and amphetamine. There were 28 deaths between November 2013 and July 2014 in one Member State, in most cases being found in biological samples to have MT-45. Eighteen non-fatal poisonings were also reported by the same Member State. The clinical characteristics were identified as being similar to those of opiate poisoning.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report leads to control measures/research of substances/drugs 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 and should therefore be supported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I abstained from the European Parliament's resolution on the draft Council implementing decision on control measures for 4-methyl-5(4-methylphenyl)-4,5-dihydrooxazole-2-amine (4,4'-DMAR) and 1-cyclohexyl-4-(1,2-diphenylethyl) piperazine (MT-45). I see no need to adopt control measures for psychoactive substances at European level. It is therefore quite right that certain Member States have agreed on derogations. The principle of subsidiarity is blatantly violated by a European regulation of these issues.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote on the need to subject substances 4,4'-DMAR and MT-45 to control measures. The discovery of these substances in many fatalities calls for more research into the health risks that these substances pose, given also their already widespread spread both on the Internet market and on the road. Taking this decision, it is now necessary for the Member States to take the necessary measures, in accordance with their national laws, to subject these psychoactive substances to control measures.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against this due to the fact that the EU is looking to mobilise EUR 16 274 765 for Bulgaria and Greece due to flooding that took place early in 2015. Public sector and infrastructure damage is at the centre of attention relating to the claim, while private sector damage is left to the insurance companies to deal with. There have been no reports made available relating to assessment or loss adjusters from both nations. We do not know what criteria has been met to make this claim or if the validity or reliability of this claim has been stretched and challenged by the EU.  It is obvious that the existing infrastructure was not prepared to handle flooding and this opportunity could contribute towards development of the infrastructure in certain places. However it is a small amount in comparison to what Bulgaria has claimed in terms of financial damage, which is estimated at EUR 239 million and as for Greece it is estimated at nearly EUR 400 million. UKIP voted against.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report supports the use of new funds to flood-affected regions (Greece) and an abnormally harsh winter (Bulgaria); regions that are also among the poorest in the EU. I voted in favour because the EU needs to help alleviate situations like this.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for increased efforts and funding to assist areas of Greece and Bulgaria that were adversely impacted by severe climatic conditions in early 2015. Due to these situations the governments of these countries applied to the European Solidarity Fund. EUR 16 274 765 will be mobilised under the European Solidarity Fund to cover the cost of recovery operations in both countries, as both cases match the European Solidarity Fund’s criteria. Bulgaria was adversely affected by severe winter weather which included heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides. Immense damage was done to public infrastructure, communication and transport networks, enterprise and residential areas, not to mention the agricultural sector and forests.  In Greece there was a similar situation with major flooding and consequently significant damage to infrastructure, especially water supplies and sewage systems, public buildings, residential areas and businesses. The impact on Greek agriculture saw the destruction of farming infrastructure, warehouses and crops. The report garnered the support of 95 % of MEPs without any amendments or objections being made. The aid will reimburse expenses incurred in recovery and reinforcement works after the natural disasters.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund with regard to the disasters suffered by the inhabitants of Evros and Central Macedonia last February. This report approves the provision of financial assistance of EUR 9.9 million to be made available for the restoration of public buildings, private homes, businesses, farms and affected cultural heritage sites.  A few days after the devastating floods, I tabled a written question to the European Commission focusing mainly on improving infrastructure in the Evros region, so that next year we can avoid the overflow of the river which caused very significant problems last year.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to mobilise 16.3 million euros from the European Solidarity Fund following the bad weather in Bulgaria and Greece. I supported helping the affected populations and voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these matters should not be funded by the European Union. Administration costs mean that the whole is, in fact, less than the sum of its parts and the amounts of money requested are too small for there to be any macroeconomic justification. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Bulgaria and Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The EU Solidarity Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this necessary deliberation in view of the disasters that have affected this part of the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, calling on the Commission to mobilise eusf funds (EUR 16 274 765) to provide financial assistance in connection with the disaster in Bulgaria (severe winter conditions have led to a disaster classified as 'major natural disasters' under the EUSF) as well as two disasters in Greece (floods in the Evro region and Central Greece classified as 'regional disasters' under the EUSF) occurring in early 2015.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The mobilization of the European Solidarity Fund seemed to me to be fully justified in helping Bulgarians and Greeks in the wake of the severe weather they have suffered in recent months. What is this EUR 16.3 million compared to the gigantic wastes that the European Union has become accustomed to? I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Bulgaria and Greece applied for assistance under the EU Solidarity Fund after being hit in early 2015 by severe flooding not only causing extensive damage to public infrastructure, businesses and homes and private property, but also causing damage to the agricultural sector. Given the extent of the damage, the proposed decision on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund must help Greece and Bulgaria in the wake of the major regional natural disasters that have hit their territory. Therefore, I approved that decision.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in support of requests from Bulgaria and Greece due to the large floods in both countries. In the case of Bulgaria, it affected most of the southeast at the end of January and the beginning of February 2015. In Greece, Evros and central and western regions in February 2015. This assistance will enable urgent first-need and recovery operations. Both cases were classified as 'regional catastrophes' and therefore need this contribution to carry out the indicated operations.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In late January and early February 2015, Bulgaria experienced torrential rains, snowfall, floods and landslides in most of its territory, causing considerable damage to public infrastructure, businesses and private homes and property, and hitting the agricultural sector hard.  In early February 2015, Greece was hit by large-scale floods in a large area around the Evros and Ardas rivers in eastern Macedonia and Thrace, destroying basic infrastructure, public buildings, private homes, businesses and causing damage to the agricultural sector.  On the basis of the requests for intervention submitted by Bulgaria and Greece, the Fund's assistance, which is based on estimating the total amounts of damage caused, is as follows: direct damages in Bulgaria are estimated at EUR 243.305 million and those in Greece at EUR 395.878 million. The Fund proposes aid for Bulgaria of EUR 6,377,815 and for Greece EUR 9,896,950, for a total of EUR 16,274,765. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bulgaria and Greece were hit by severe flooding classified as major natural disasters in early 2015. This vote will allocate EUR 16 million to the reconstruction and support of the affected populations.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission proposes to mobilise the EUSF to provide financial assistance in connection with a natural disaster in Bulgaria (harsh winter weather conditions and classified as a 'serious natural disaster' according to the EUSF) and two in Greece (floods in Evros and Central Greece, both classified as 'regional disasters' according to the EUSF).  All of them from early 2015. I support the adoption of the Commission's proposal for a Decision because in both cases they meet the EESF criteria because of the nature of the disasters, their enormous scope and their profound impact on local communities and economies; and because the damage has profoundly affected regions, not only public infrastructure, but also private property, businesses, agricultural land and forests. Under the overall EU budget for the 2015 financial year, the ESF will be mobilisation of EUR 16 274 765 in commitment and payment appropriations. After deducting the advances paid equivalent to 10% (EUR 637 782 for Bulgaria and EUR 989 695 for Greece), the outstanding amount is EUR 14 647 288 (EUR 5 740 033 for Bulgaria and EUR 8 907 255 for Greece).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament supports the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) and to provide financial assistance to Bulgaria, as the harsh winter conditions have led to a disaster classified as 'major natural disasters' under the EUSF. Parliament also supports the proposal to provide financial assistance to Greece in the event of two disasters: the floods in the Evro region and central Greece, which are classified as 'regional disasters' under the EUSF.  January 2015 and in February. At the beginning, a large part of Bulgaria was affected by heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides, the most severe damage suffered in the south-eastern region of the country. These phenomena have caused serious damage to public infrastructure.  February 2015 At the beginning, floods in Eastern Macedonia and Thrace caused serious damage to basic infrastructure, public buildings, private houses, businesses and Greek agriculture, and agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops were destroyed. 17 settlements were damaged in the water supply and sewerage infrastructure. At the same time, large areas of Central and western Greece have been hit by other floods, which have caused even greater damage, resulting in a disruption of electricity supply, the isolated use of several mountain settlements and the destruction of some of Greece's cultural heritage sites.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Commission's proposal that the 2013 budget should be amended in accordance with the procedure for the 2013 budget. On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with the Regulation establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. As has been the case so many times this year, my support for the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund is being mobilised, this time for Bulgaria, which has been hit hard by the unusually harsh winter conditions, and Greece, whose province of Evros has faced catastrophic floods. We have thus earmarked approximately EUR 16 million to address these consequences.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this Financial Assistance Report on Greece and Bulgaria, which have been hit by severe winter conditions, and floods in 2015. This proposal is in line with past practice, and the entire amount will be financed through the redistribution of available funds for progress from the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for increased efforts and funding to assist areas of Greece and Bulgaria that were adversely impacted by severe climatic conditions in early 2015. Due to these situations the governments of these countries applied to the European Solidarity Fund. EUR 16 274 765 will be mobilised within the framework of the European Solidarity Fund to cover the cost of recovery operations in both countries as both cases match the European Solidarity Fund's criteria. Bulgaria was adversely affected by severe winter weather which included heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides. Immense damage was done to public infrastructure, communication and transport networks, enterprise and residential areas, not to mention to the agricultural sector and forests.  In Greece there was a similar situation with major flooding and consequently significant damage to infrastructure, especially water supplies and sewage systems, public buildings, residential areas and businesses. The impact on Greek agriculture saw the destruction of farming infrastructure, warehouses and crops. The report garnered the support of 95 % of MEPs without any amendments or objections being made. The aid will reimburse expenses incurred on recovery and reinforcement works after the natural disasters.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is essential for the Union to show its solidarity, especially with those countries and regions that have been affected by major natural disasters. It is therefore our duty to help the Greek and Bulgarian citizens and governments who suffered the enormous damage caused by the floods that affected them at the beginning of the year.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Between January and February 2015 some regions of Greece and Bulgaria were hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides. These events have caused extensive damage to public infrastructure (schools, dams, telecommunications networks and roads), homes and private activities (hundreds of buildings have been flooded), as well as damage to the agricultural sector and forests resulting from mudslides, landslides and landslides.  The exceptional nature and seriousness of the situation made it necessary to use the European Union Solidarity Fund, of which an advance of 10% of the amount envisaged was paid. Parliament must approve the mobilisation of the Fund for the allocation of the amounts provided for by the Commission as an emergency contribution to the affected regions as soon as possible, since the speed of the institutional response to flood intervention is essential for the resumption of economic activities and the normal conduct of citizens' daily activities.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. At the beginning of February, Greece and Bulgaria were confronted with severe floods that caused extensive property damage. The Bulgarian authorities have estimated the cost of these bad weathers at 243 million euros, or more than 0.6% of GNI, which is the threshold for triggering funds from the EUSF. According to Athens, the damage caused by these floods amounts to 396 million euros, or 4.78% of the weighted average GDP of the five affected regions, exceeding the trigger threshold set at 1.5% of regional GDP.  For these two natural disasters, the Commission has already advanced 10% of the planned financial contribution. By deducting these advances, the balance payable is 14.6 million euros. The Commission proposes to draw on the EUR 50 million provided in the 2015 budget, notably for advance payments and commitment appropriations.  With regard to Greece and Bulgaria, the triggering of the EUSF respects the thresholds that had been set beforehand. I have no objection to some of the provisions in the 2015 budget being used to pay the balance of contributions. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The beginning of 2015 was an extremely difficult time for Bulgaria and Greece. Both snow and flooding have led to total direct damage of EUR 243 305 million in the case of Bulgaria and EUR 395 878 million for Greece. Events in these two countries are considered to be a major natural disaster. As for Bulgaria, the south-eastern region was the worst affected, with more than 300 buildings flooded in one city alone. Also, the volume of flooding was very high, many agricultural land and pastures were flooded.  As for Greece, the agricultural sector has been most affected. About 17,500 hectares of land were flooded, and agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops were destroyed. 150 km of roads were damaged or destroyed, and water supply and sewerage infrastructures were damaged in 17 settlements. The profound impact that these disasters have had on the two countries, as well as the high degree of damage, led me to vote in favour of the allocation of EUR 16 274 765 for the two countries and, therefore, in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in the case of Bulgaria and Greece.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Solidarity Fund for Bulgaria and Greece for a total amount of around EUR 16 million. For Bulgaria, these are floods and heavy snowfall that occurred in February 2015 and the event has been classified as a major natural disaster. For Greece, on the other hand, there is talk of floods at the same time in the central, western and Evros region. The amount of some 16 million is broken down as follows: 6.4 million for Bulgaria and 9.9 million for Greece. There is every reason to assume that the procedure has been followed correctly and, in accordance with what has been done with disasters in our territories, the Lega Nord delegation is voting in favour.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the mobilisation, pursuant to point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Budgetary Discipline, Cooperation on Budgetary Issues and Sound Financial Management of 2 December 2013 (between the EP, the Council and the Commission), the EU Solidarity Fund for Financial Assistance for Disasters in Bulgaria (the harsh winter conditions triggered a catastrophe classified as a 'major natural disaster' under the EUSF) and Greece (for two disasters , i.e. the floods in Evros and the central region of Greece, classified as 'regional disasters' under the EUSF), which took place in early 2015.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance in relation to the disasters that occurred in Bulgaria and Greece in early 2015.  Large areas in the south-eastern region of Bulgaria have been hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides, which have brought the country's agricultural and forestry sector to its knees. At the same time, widespread floods in northern Greece overwhelmed public buildings, businesses and private homes, destroying farms, warehouses and crops and severely damaging water and sewerage infrastructure in different parts of the country. At the same time, many areas of central and western Greece have suffered another series of floods which have caused even greater damage, even going so far as to destroy part of Greece's cultural heritage. I believe that in the face of these disasters, the European Union must show solidarity with the Member States affected. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide aid to Bulgaria and Greece.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, and against the amendments. The purpose of this resolution is to make available exceptional measures to enable Greece to use already available EU structural funds.  Tighter financing conditions, as well as economic uncertainties in recent months, have disrupted investment programs and the ability of the Greek authorities to fully utilise the available EU funds. The Greek economy is in urgent need of a cash injection, as funds for public investment to revive the economy are lacking. This means that Greece is less able to co-finance this policy, and many projects may not be completed.  Also, if Greece does not use the funds still available under the 2007 – 2013 period before the end of 2015, these funds will be lost, and Greece will miss out on about 2 billion euros. I voted against the amendments as a positive vote, would mean that the resolution may go for a second reading and postpone the decision, which would risk losing part of these important appropriations for Greece.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are voting against this due to the fact that the EU is looking to mobilise EUR 16,274,765 for Bulgaria and Greece due to flooding that took place early in 2015. Public sector and infrastructure damage is at the centre of attention relating to the claim. Whereas, private sector damage is left to the insurance companies to deal with. There have been no reports made available relating to assessment or loss adjusters from both nations. We do not know what criteria has been met to make this claim or if the validity or reliability of this claim has been stretched and challenged by the EU.  It is obvious that the existing infrastructure was not prepared to handle flooding and this opportunity could contribute towards the development of the infrastructure in certain places, however it is a small amount in comparison to what Bulgaria has claimed in terms of financial damage, which is estimated at EUR 239 million and as for Greece it is estimated at nearly EUR 400 million. Hence, I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because there needs to be a fund for citizens in these countries that offer a fast and rapid response in order to help them recover from disasters. The fund has been accessed by Greece for flooding and Bulgaria for severe winter conditions. The budget will not be amended instead the remaining 50 Million euros will be used as advancements for this fund.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the request to mobilise the Solidarity Fund to help the areas of Bulgaria and Greece hard hit by the atmospheric events of early 2015. They were hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides, which caused damage estimated at around EUR 250 million in Bulgaria, and around EUR 400 million in Greece.  I certainly voted in favour of mobilising the fund so that the Eu ropean Union can come to the aid of the people affected.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Quite rightly the Commission, assisted by the European Parliament, proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance to deal with the disaster in Bulgaria from adverse winter conditions that have caused a disaster which is described as a major disaster. Two disasters in Greece, namely the floods in Evros and Central Greece, which are classified as regional disasters and occurred at the beginning of 2015, are also rightly included in this context.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for Greece and Bulgaria. The Fund enables the EU to act quickly and effectively in emergency situations, thereby demonstrating its solidarity with populations affected by natural disasters. Bulgaria has applied because of the damage caused by adverse winter conditions, while Greece has submitted two applications in relation to violent floods in some of its particularly disadvantaged regions. Bulgaria has estimated the damage at around EUR 243 million and will receive total aid of EUR 6 377 815, while Greece, which has suffered eur 395 million in damage, will receive total aid of EUR 9 896 950. The Fund will mobilise a total of EUR 16 274 765. After deduction of advances already paid of 10%, the balance to be paid is EUR 14 647 288.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that, in accordance with the objectives of the European Union, it is permissible to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund and grant financial assistance to Greece for floods in the Evros region and other western regions, and to Bulgaria for adverse winter conditions. In addition, these events have caused considerable damage to public infrastructure, such as dams, communication networks and roads, and to businesses, homes and private activities in the Bulgarian case. The Bulgarian authorities, in addition, have estimated total direct damage at EUR 243.305 million. Finally, I fully agree with the allocation of funds to the Greek cause, because the floods have caused damage to basic infrastructure, businesses and Greek agriculture, destroying agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are voting against this due to the fact that the EU is looking to mobilise EUR 16,274,765 for Bulgaria and Greece due to flooding that took place early in 2015. Public sector and infrastructure damage is at the centre of attention relating to the claim. Whereas, private sector damage is left to the insurance companies to deal with. There have been no reports made available relating to assessment or loss adjusters from both nations. We do not know what criteria has been met to make this claim or if the validity or reliability of this claim has been stretched and challenged by the EU.  It is obvious that the existing infrastructure was not prepared to handle flooding and this opportunity could contribute towards the development of the infrastructure in certain places, however it is a small amount in comparison to what Bulgaria has claimed in terms of financial damage, which is estimated at EUR 239 million and as for Greece it is estimated at nearly EUR 400 million. UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure rapid, effective and flexible aid to the population of a Member State, as well as to countries negotiating their membership in the event of a major natural disaster. This fund complements member states' public funds in emergency situations, including the urgent recovery of infrastructure, temporary accommodation and emergency services to meet the immediate needs of the population, as well as the clean-up of disaster-affected areas.  In 2015, Bulgaria was affected by severe win-win conditions that caused a "major natural disaster" - and Greece affected by two disasters - floods in the Evros river basin and central regions of Greece - considered "regional disasters".  Following the disasters, the countries concerned requested assistance from the European Union Solidarity Fund.  I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 16,274,765 in appropriations for authorisation and payment under the European Union Solidarity Fund with the aim of reducing the pain, suffering and loss of those affected by these disasters.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the Commission's proposal to mobilise the Eu ropean Union Solidarity Fund in response to requests for assistance from Bulgaria and Greece following the natural disasters that occurred in early 2015.  Rapid, effective and flexible action is needed in situations that fall under the category of 'major natural disaster' because the affected regions have suffered very serious damage in the agricultural sector, infrastructure and connections. In addition, natural disasters have had a dramatic impact on local economies, communities and the environment. I therefore supported Mrs Novakov's report, also considering that the two states affected fall into the category of less developed regions for which European Structural and Investment Funds are provided.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal to use of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) showcases the solidarity and cooperation that is possible within Europe and within the policies of the European Union. The EUSF is an annual fund dedicated to potential emergencies and natural disasters in member states. Given that two natural disasters have already occurred in the EU since the start of the calendar year, the Parliament fully supports the allocation of financial support to aid Bulgaria (due to severe and frigid winter months) and Greece (heavy flooding in the Evros and central/western regions). Moments like these are opportunities to put aside our political differences and come together to aid fellow Europeans in need.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the request to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) with reference to two catastrophic situations that took place at the beginning of 2015 in Bulgaria and Greece. At the end of January and the beginning of February, large areas of Bulgaria, especially the south-eastern region, were hit by heavy rain, snowfall, floods and landslides, which caused damage estimated at around EUR 250 million. The Greek authorities have estimated damages of around EUR 400 million. The report aims to allocate around EUR 10 million to Greece and EUR 6 million to Bulgaria, to try to help these areas, which are so badly affected by severe natural phenomena. I am voting in favour because it is a special financial instrument that should demonstrate the solidarity of the European Union, even though the rules, modalities and timing of use of the Fund are not optimal as it can be used up to a maximum of EUR 500 million per year.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report supports the use of new funds to flood-affected regions (Greece) and an abnormally harsh winter (Bulgaria); regions that are also among the poorest in the EU. I voted in favour because the EU needs to help alleviate situations like this.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that, under the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, the European Union Solidarity Fund should provide financial support for the two disasters caused by the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 and the floods in Greece at the beginning of 2015. Much of Bulgaria was hit by heavy rain, snowfall, flooding and landslides in late and early January 2015. These events have caused significant damage to public infrastructure, businesses, private property, as well as to agriculture and forestry.  The Bulgarian authorities estimate the direct damage caused by the disaster at a total of EUR 243,305 million. Severe flooding in Greece at the beginning of February 2015 caused damage to basic infrastructure, public buildings, residential buildings, businesses and Greek agriculture. The Greek authorities estimate that the total direct damage caused by the floods is EUR 395,878 million. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. Since the two applications fulfil the criteria of the European Union Solidarity Fund and because the damage affected not only public infrastructures (water supply, sewage, electricity) but also the regions concerned, including private property, businesses, agricultural land and forests, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in relation to a disaster in Bulgaria and two disasters in Greece which occurred in early 2015. The full amount of the mobilisation will be financed through the reallocation of the available appropriations for advances in the general budget of the EU for the financial year of 2015. I voted in favour of this report since I agree with helping Member States which are hit by natural disasters that have devastating effects.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the two Member States fulfil the conditions for the granting of aid provided by the Solidarity Fund and I believe that the Fund must be mobilised to provide a financial and aid contribution to the regions of Bulgaria and Greece which were seriously affected by the damage in 2015.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to mobilise, for the second time this year, the European Union Solidarity Fund following disasters in Bulgaria (exceptional winter weather) and Greece (floods in Evros and the central and western regions). With an annual budget of up to EUR 500 million, this solidarity fund enables the EU to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to such emergencies. The current envelope provides for the mobilization of 6.4 million euros for Bulgaria and 9.9 million euros for Greece. In a spirit of solidarity with the people affected by disasters, I voted for the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help Greece and Bulgaria. Both countries suffered natural disasters during 2015. It is important to help their people financially so that they can get their economy back on their feet as quickly as possible.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Between the end of January and the beginning of February 2015, large areas of Bulgaria were hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides. These events have damaged public and private infrastructure and caused damage to the agricultural sector. In Greece, at the same time, widespread floods have damaged businesses, buildings, infrastructure and temporarily isolated some mountain settlements. For these reasons, I welcomed the European Commission's proposal to mobilise the Solidarity Fund, which will grant financial assistance to Bulgaria and Greece, countries affected by these violent natural phenomena.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Following the floods in Bulgaria and Greece last winter, the Commission received requests for financial assistance from these states under the European Union Solidarity Fund.  These countries will be granted aid of EUR 16,274,765 and will be able to rebuild their infrastructure more quickly and not burden already fragile economies. It should be noted that this fund contributes to the rationalisation of EU expenditures because it reallocates funds initially planned, and not used, for rural development programmes.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission has proposed to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund following disasters in Bulgaria (severe winter conditions resulting in a "major natural disaster" in the sense of the EUS) as well as two disasters that hit Greece (floods in the Evros region and central Greece) in early 2015. I therefore voted in favour of the NOVAKOV report on the mobilization of this fund in the wake of the various disasters. I believe it is essential and vital to provide financial assistance to our member countries affected by such disasters. Thanks to the vote on this resolution, the EU will release 6.3 million euros for Bulgaria and 9.8 million euros for Greece. This mobilization does not require an amendment to the 2015 budget as the Commission proposes to draw on an envelope mobilised at the time of the adoption of the 2015 budget, specifically intended for advances.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the request to the EU Solidarity Fund to reimburse part of the costs paid by Bulgaria and Greece to repair the damage caused by the harsh winter conditions that prevailed in south-eastern Bulgaria and central, eastern and western Greece in January and February 2015. These exceptional climatic conditions have had dramatic consequences. In Greece, floods destroyed public buildings, private homes, businesses, agricultural areas and cultural heritage sites in the central and Evros regions. South-eastern Bulgaria has been affected by heavy rains, floods and landslides that have damaged, communication and road networks, as well as public and private buildings. Bulgaria will receive EU aid of 6.3 million euros and the two Greek regions will receive a total amount of 9.9 million euros. I hope that these aids will enable local authorities to take the necessary measures to limit the risk of such disasters happening again and to help local people rebuild.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Two natural disasters hit Bulgaria and Greece in early 2015. National and regional in scope, respectively, they remain a severe blow to the economic development of these two countries, which are already in difficulty. Bulgaria's particularly harsh winter has caused extensive damage to public infrastructure, private buildings and farms. The two floods in Thrace and eastern Greek Macedonia also particularly affected the economic activity of these regions, at 0.62% of the national annual GDP for Bulgaria and 4.78% of the annual GDP of the regions concerned for Greece. Supporting European cooperation and solidarity when it is not synonymous with guardianship for states but in a logic of humanitarian solidarity, I voted in favour of this report receiving requests for help from Greece and Bulgaria.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to support Bulgaria and Greece, which suffered enormous damage as a result of the floods at the beginning of the year. This Fund was established in 2002 precisely with the aim of providing financial assistance to countries affected by major natural disasters. In my opinion, however, this mechanism is not working and the compensation granted by it is extremely insufficient. There is even one extreme injustice – non-Member States receive more than member states. This is the example of Serbia. At the beginning of the year, I referred a written question to the Commission asking whether the Commission intends to propose changes to the legal framework on the SOLIDARITY FE for a fairer calculation and distribution of compensation. However, the Commission considers that the Fund as a whole is functioning well, is fair and helps the countries concerned overcome the financial burden caused to them by disasters. Although the aid will be granted almost a year after the disaster and covers only part of the damage suffered by the State, the Commission does not intend to propose a further revision of the instrument in the near future.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that the 2013 2013 european council will be the first to be edd with a proposal for a Directive on the use of the 2013 On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (the 'Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the disaster-affected regions, and the Fund's intervention should not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. Bulgaria has submitted a request for mobilisation of the Fund following strict summer conditions. Greece has made two requests to mobilise the Fund following floods. I therefore agree that the fund in the amount of €16 274 765 should be mobilised to satisfy the requests made by Bulgaria and Greece.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund for Bulgaria and Greece. In fact, this proposal will not involve any change in the 2015 budget, as it will be financed in full by the redistribution of appropriations already available; I also believe it is necessary to approve and support the principles and objectives of the EUSF.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe it is a good use of EU funds.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Commission's proposal to grant financial assistance in the context of the disaster in Bulgaria and Greece. In late January and early February 2015, a large part of Bulgaria was hit by torrential rains, snowfall, floods and landslides, with the south-eastern part most severely affected. These events have caused considerable damage to public infrastructure, such as dams, communication networks and roads, as well as in businesses, private dwellings, and caused damage to the agricultural and forestry sectors. Widespread flooding in eastern Macedonia and Tritium in early February 2015 caused damage to basic infrastructure, public buildings, houses, businesses and Greek agriculture, where agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops were destroyed. In 17 municipalities, water and sewerage infrastructure was damaged. During the same period, a large part of central and western Greece was also affected by several floods, causing even more damage, leading to power outages, the isolation of several mountain settlements and the destruction of some Greek cultural monuments. As the applications of both countries meet the criteria of the European Union Solidarity Fund and these natural disasters have had a serious impact on the economies and regions of both countries, I see no reason for these countries to be refused assistance from the EUSF.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of mobilising the European Solidarity Fund for Bulgaria and Greece for a total amount of around EUR 16 million for flood disasters.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 My vote is positive regarding the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: Disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The EU must be flexible when there are reasons for compensating countries affected by natural disasters.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In early 2015, Bulgaria and Greece have been affected by severe floods that caused significant damage to public infrastructure, businesses, homes, private property and to the agricultural sector as well. Considering the fact that they have been submitting an application to the EU Solidarity Fund, and the fact that the applications meet the conditions for awarding aid from the Fund, I endorsed the mobilization of EUR 16 274 765 in commitment and payment appropriations by the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that the 2013 2013 european council will be the first to be edd with a proposal for a Directive on the use of the 2013 On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to help alleviate the consequences of the catastrophes in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015 by meeting both cases the criteria of the European Solidarity Fund. Solidarity is one of the main foundations of the EU, so in situations such as those experienced in Bulgaria and Greece, we must put all means at our disposal to overcome these complicated situations.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the 'Report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: Disasters in Bulgaria and Greece 2015', as For me European solidarity in crisis is a key element of our European Union. This applies to the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece – but this also applies at the moment in refugee policy.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund by Bulgaria and Greece. Countries affected by natural disasters and bad weather conditions need the European solidarity of the other Member States.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which  concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (set up to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity) to provide assistance to Bulgaria (severe winter conditions) and  Greece (flooding in Evros and Central Greece).

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. The severe weather in Greece and Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 caused considerable material damage to public infrastructure and the agricultural sector to the point of being recognized as natural disasters. This significant damage justifies the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund. That is why I am supporting today this report, which will enable the deployment of more than EUR 16 million to help these two Member States respond to this emergency.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, which will release European Structural and Investment Funds for the catastrophes in Greece and Bulgaria, by amending the disaster provisions on these two points of geography. We still understand that the fund does not take care of the total needs that both spaces need to meet.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as it concerns the European Union Solidarity Fund, which is emergency financial aid which can be used by Member States following disasters in their countries to help to rebuild basic infrastructure, fund emergency services, fund temporary accommodation  and assist with clean-up operations.  It does not entail the use of additional appropriations and instead the full amount for the fund will be financed through the reallocation of the available appropriations for advances in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that that, pursuant to point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) should provide financial assistance in the context of the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the floods in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (classified as a "regional disaster").  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund in response to disasters in Bulgaria and Greece which occurred earlier this year. The fund allows the EU to assist when emergency situations and disasters strike Member States or their regions and to show solidarity with citizens affected. Across Bulgaria severe winter weather conditions damaged public infrastructure as well as private homes and businesses at a cost of €243,305 million which qualifies as a 'major natural disaster' and I welcome that the Commission paid a 10% advance which was used by the Bulgarian authorities for urgent response. Two separate severe flooding incidents in the Thrace and central and western Greece also damaged infrastructure, public buildings, private homes & businesses, impacted farming infrastructure, warehouses and crops and resulted in power failures, the isolation of some mountainous settlements and the destruction of some of Greece’s cultural heritage assets. Combined the two events had an estimated cost of €395,878 million and qualified for the fund under the regional disaster criteria.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in order to grant financial assistance to Greece and Bulgaria following the natural disasters both Member States suffered in early 2015. In reference to Bulgaria, severe winter conditions such as heavy rainfall, snow and landslides caused an estimated EUR 243 305 million in damages according to Bulgarian authorities. These events caused considerable damage to public infrastructure, such as dykes, communication networks and roads, as well as businesses, private homes and assets (over 300 buildings in the city of Burgas alone were flooded), and harm to the agricultural sector and forests. In respect to Greece widespread flooding in Eastern Macedonia and Thrace in early February 2015 caused damage to essential infrastructure, public buildings, private homes, businesses and in Greek agriculture, destroying farming infrastructure, warehouses and crops. Water supplies and sewage infrastructure were damaged in 17 settlements. In parallel, major parts of central and western Greece were hit by another series of floods causing even greater damage, resulting in power failures, the isolation of a number of mountainous settlements and the destruction of some of Greece’s cultural heritage assets.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal of 17 July 2015 provides for facilitation for Greece to finance projects under the five European Structural and Investment Funds. The critical points of the Commission's proposal include control over the appropriate use of funds, budgetary neutrality, the lack of administrative capacity of Greek authorities to implement programmes and equal treatment with other EU countries. I reject the Commission's proposal because neither the third aid package of EUR 86 billion agreed at the euro summit on 12 July 2015 nor this additional package of measures are the right medicine for Greece. Rather, we must face the truth: Greece is completely uncompetitive. Although a debt cut has already taken place with economically correct accounting, Greece cannot be healthy until it leaves the monetary union. Only such a step is a prerequisite for international competitiveness. In the transition process, the EU can help and thus show its solidarity. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that the 2013 2013 european council will be the first to be edd with a proposal for a Directive on the use of the 2013 On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to deal with major natural disasters and to express the EU's solidarity with the affected regions.  I am pleased that the European Union has mobilised the solidarity fund for Bulgaria and Greece, which was hit by floods in the Evros region and in the centre of the country in early 2015. We are not talking enough about this fund, which is the very concrete expression of European solidarity. This is regrettable, because it would help people to become aware of their belonging to the same space of solidarity beyond national borders.  On this occasion, I hope that the French State will ask for this fund to help citizens and local authorities who were hit by severe weather at the beginning of October on the Côte d'Azur.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, which will release European Structural and Investment Funds for the catastrophes in Greece and Bulgaria, by amending the disaster provisions on these two points of geography. We still understand that the fund does not take care of the total needs that both spaces need to meet.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The European Union Solidarity Fund enables the Union to respond in a rapid and efficient manner to emergency situations and to show solidarity with the population of regions faced by disasters. This report concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 16 274 765 in commitment and payment appropriations. This financial assistance relates to a disaster in Bulgaria, which had to face severe winter conditions and two disasters in Greece, flooding in Evros and Central Greece that occurred in early 2015.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as I believe that there needs to be an express response and an adequate solution for the affected regions of Greece and Bulgaria, whose citizens need effective assistance and solidarity.  Bulgaria has applied for the mobilisation of the Fund due to difficult winter conditions that have endangered public infrastructure, communication networks and roads, office buildings and homes, the agricultural sector and forests. On the other hand, in Greece, floods have damaged and isolated many mountain settlements, and destroyed some of the cultural heritage. In 17 settlements, sewage was damaged, and major damage was also caused in agriculture, on farms, public and commercial buildings, and in private homes.  I therefore support the financial support provided to these countries through the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable the EU to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies and to express solidarity with the people of disaster-affected areas. Bulgaria has submitted a request for intervention from the Fund after suffering severe winter conditions. For its part, Greece submitted two requests for intervention from the Fund after experiencing floods. The Fund should therefore be mobilized to make a contribution to these two affected countries. Upon review, I consider that these applications meet the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations.  That is why I voted for this text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrey Novakov's report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The Fund will provide EUR 6.3 million for Bulgaria to help repair the damage caused by exceptional winter conditions, and EUR 9.8 million for Greece, which is the victim of floods in the Evros region and central Greece.  I welcome the positive vote of the European Parliament because the European Union Solidarity Fund is essential to deal with natural disasters and expresses the Union's solidarity with the affected regions. Faced with the human tragedy and the material damage caused by the deadly floods in The South of France in October, the French EPP delegation asked the Prime Minister to request this fund for the affected French regions.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because Bulgaria and Greece suffered exceptional weather conditions during the winter of 2014/2015, causing very severe damage. It was therefore necessary to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help them.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I strongly support giving assistance to regions affected by major natural disasters.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report contains a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. Specifically, there are disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The fund is intended to enable the European Union to react quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergencies and to show solidarity with the populations in the disaster-affected regions. Bulgaria has applied for the Fund because of severe winter weather conditions, and Greece has submitted two applications for mobilisation due to flooding. All applications meet the conditions for granting assistance. The Fund should therefore be used to provide a total financial contribution of EUR 16 274 765 for applications submitted by Bulgaria and Greece. In order to allow as little time as possible to reach the mobilisation of the Fund, this Decision should apply from the date of its adoption. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that the 2013 2013 european council will be the first to be edd with a proposal for a Directive on the use of the 2013 On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Bulgaria and Greece were struck by natural disasters in 2015, severe winter conditions and floods in Evros and Central Greece. Greece and Bulgaria have requested that European Union Solidarity Fund is applied. Both cases fulfil the criteria for the mobilisation of the European Fund. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Natural disasters and floods have caused damage of hundreds of millions of euros in Bulgaria and Greece. The report proposed to approve EUR 6.4 million for Bulgaria and EUR 9.9 million for Greece under the EU Solidarity Fund. In essence, these are symbolic amounts, yet they are of some kind of assistance to the two peripheral countries, so of course I supported their award. It is regrettable and also thought-provoking, compared to other budget items, that the total annual amount of the fund is only EUR 500 million.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Writing. We support the basic objective of the Commission's proposal to mobilise investment funds for Greece. However, the reduction in the co-financing share from 5% to 0% risks creating false incentives that ultimately lead to misinvestment. We reject this and have therefore abstained from the final vote.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund following the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. In January and February 2015, Bulgaria experienced torrential rains, snowfall, floods and landslides over most of its territory. These have caused considerable damage to public infrastructure, such as, communication networks and roads, businesses, and homes and private property, and have caused damage to the agricultural sector and forests. In early February, Greece was hit by large-scale floods in eastern Macedonia and Thrace, causing similar damage to those in Bulgaria. In both cases, this is a natural disaster, which justifies the mobilization of the Solidarity Fund to the tune of 16.3 million euros.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The disasters in Bulgaria and Greece respectively have caused very serious damage to public infrastructure, communications networks, roads, as well as to businesses, homes and private activities. The emergency requires early intervention and, given that the applications meet the conditions for granting Fund support under Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002, I have decided to give a positive opinion to this report. In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the Solidarity Fund, capable of providing support in the event of disasters and tragedies.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it helps victims of bad weather in Bulgaria and Greece to the tune of 16.3 million euros.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission proposes to mobilisation the European Union Solidarity Fund to provide financial assistance in relation to natural disasters in Bulgaria and Greece during 2015. I agree with the proposal for a decision because it meets the criteria of the European Solidarity Fund as well as the need for aid because of the scope and its profound impact on the affected regions.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report contains a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. Specifically, there are disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The fund is intended to enable the European Union to react quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergencies and to show solidarity with the populations in the disaster-affected regions. Bulgaria has applied for the Fund because of severe winter weather conditions, and Greece has submitted two applications for mobilisation due to flooding. All applications meet the conditions for granting assistance. The Fund should therefore be used to provide a total financial contribution of EUR 16 274 765 for applications submitted by Bulgaria and Greece. In order to allow as little time as possible to reach the mobilisation of the Fund, this Decision should apply from the date of its adoption. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this issuance of taxpayers' money. The European Union is not supposed to serve as an insurance company. If the Member States want to help Bulgaria and Greece, this should be their voluntary activity.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund to help Bulgaria and Greece, as the Purpose of the Fund is to provide quick, effective and flexible responses in catastrophic situations, thus showing solidarity with the population of regions affected by disasters.  Bulgaria has submitted a request to mobilise the Fund due to difficult winter conditions, and Greece has submitted two flood claims, totalling 16.2m euros.  Bulgarian regions have been hit by rains, floods, snow and landslides, causing significant damage especially to public infrastructure, private property and the agricultural sector. The damage is estimated at 243.3m euros.  Severe flooding in eastern Macedonia and Thrac has caused major damage to agriculture in warehouses and crops, public buildings, private homes and business premises in Greece. The damage was estimated at 395.8m euros.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Greece and Bulgaria are asking for money from the European Union Solidarity Fund to make up for the damage caused by the floods. The Fund was set up as an extra relief measure for regions affected after major floods in 2002. The fund is eur 500 million per year. Its rulebook provides for a certain threshold: if the loss has exceeded this threshold, financial assistance from the Fund may be d turned.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The south-eastern part of Bulgaria was hit by torrential rains, snowfall, floods and landslides at the beginning of 2015, causing serious damage to infrastructure, public and private property, and particularly affecting agriculture and forestry. The estimated damage is almost EUR 250 million. For the same meteorological reasons, damage has also been caused in Greece, where some cultural monuments have also been destroyed. However, the transport sector was hardest hit. Emergency measures required EUR 308.445 million. The affected regions in Bulgaria and Greece fall into the category of less developed regions under the European Structural and Investment Funds. Both countries have fulfilled the conditions for granting assistance from the EU Solidarity Fund, therefore a total assistance of EUR 16 274 765 is provided to Greece and Bulgaria under the rules of this Damage Elimination Fund.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015) , because the widespread flooding in the region of Eastern Macedonia and Thrace and in the regions of Epirus, Western Greece, Central Greece and Thessaly caused huge damage to basic infrastructure, private housing, public buildings, businesses and Greek agriculture, destroying agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops. These devastating floods also resulted in power outages, the isolation of some mountain settlements and the destruction of some of Greece's cultural heritage sites. For these reasons, and in conjunction with the bleeding of my fellow citizens from the memorandums of the PASOK, SW, SYRIZA-ANEL governments, it is imperative that these funds be paid immediately and without delay to compensate for the above damage caused by the floods.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this decision to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Bulgaria (severe winter conditions causing a disaster classified under the EUSF as a “major natural disaster”) and two disasters in Greece (flooding in Evros and Central Greece, classified under the EUSF as “regional disasters”) that occurred in early 2015.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mrs Novakov on the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in support of Bulgaria and Greece. I believe it is the responsibility of this Parliament and the European institutions to respond to natural disasters and to express European solidarity with the regions and countries affected by major disasters, given their wide scope and their profound impact on local communities and economies. The Commission proposes to grant financial assistance to Bulgaria and Greece following heavy rains, floods and natural landslides in early 2015. The aid in question, some EUR 6 377 815 to Bulgaria and some EUR 9 896 950 to Greece, is intended to cover part of the costs of emergency and rehabilitation operations, and partly to help restore public infrastructure, water and electricity supplies, and to deal with damage to businesses and farms in order to enable the territory to start again.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for the benefit of Bulgaria and Greece, both of which were affected by natural disasters during 2015. With the idea that the European Union has a duty to support its Member States when needed, I decided to support the proposal with a vote in favour.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to grant financial assistance in relation to the disasters that occurred in Bulgaria and Greece in early 2015. The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up precisely in view of this type of event: large areas in the south-eastern region of Bulgaria were hit by heavy rain, snowfall, floods and landslides; while widespread floods have bent over businesses in central Greece. I believe that the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in order to provide EUR 16 million in aid to Bulgaria and Greece is not only a demonstration of the capabilities of the EU institutions, but also a gesture of fraternity between the Member States.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Bulgaria has applied for restraining order due to severe winter conditions, as has Greece, which has submitted two applications due to severe flooding. The Solidarity Fund's task is to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergencies and to show solidarity with the populations of the affected regions. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds that will help Bulgaria and Greece react in a flexibly and effectively when faced with unforeseen disasters.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to deal with the major natural disasters that are multiplying in Europe and to express the EU's solidarity with the affected regions. The report here foresees the expenditure of 16.3 million euros following the damage caused by floods in Greece and Bulgaria in early 2015. After deducting the amount already paid for the 10% advance, the remaining balance amounted to 14.6 million euros. With the 2015 Solidarity Fund budgeted for $50 million, no amendments to the 2015 budget are required. So I'm voting for it. However, I deplore the lack of will to prevent the causes of these "catastrophes" which are much less natural than they seem. Their resurgence, as we saw in Nice recently, demonstrates the urgency of ecological planning while wild European liberalisation leaves impoverished states in the face of climate change.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of distribution of funds to Bulgaria and Greece after regional disasters in January and February of 2015. These funds will aid Bulgaria after severe winter conditions and Greece after extensive regional flooding.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund and the allocation of aid to Bulgaria and Greece in the context of the natural disasters that affected them in 2015.
