This is the fulfilment of the spirit of the European Union Solidarity Fund, which was created so that affected regions within Europe can be helped in the event of major natural disasters. I support this proposal as a way for the Union to express its solidarity with the peoples of its Member States affected by the disaster.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report that concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. It is very important to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity for a total amount of EUR 16.274,765 in commitment and payment appropriations. This financial assistance relates to a disaster in Bulgaria due to a severe winter conditions and two disasters in Greece (flooding in Evros and Central Greece) that occurred in early 2015.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Bulgaria applied for the Fund due to cold winter weather and Greece for flooding totalling EUR 16 274 765. The Commission has established that the applications meet the requirements for the use of the Fund laid down in Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EUSF aims to provide a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of disaster-affected regions. The MOBILISE was requested to provide financial assistance following a disaster in Bulgaria (severe win-win conditions which caused a "major natural disaster" in the eusf' meaning) and two disasters in Greece (floods in the Evros river basin and central regions of Greece, considered 'regional disasters' under the EUSF). These weather stems from considerable damage to public infrastructure, including dams, communication networks and roads, as well as businesses, housing and private property (more than 300 buildings in Burgas have been flooded), damaging bulgaria's agricultural and forestry sectors and causing damage to essential infrastructure, public buildings, private housing, businesses and the agricultural sector, destroying agricultural infrastructure in Greece, warehouses and crops. I support the adoption of this report as it meets the requirements.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the mobilization of the European Solidarity Fund for a total of 16.3 million euros to provide financial assistance in the wake of the natural disasters that have occurred in Bulgaria and Greece. Both countries have experienced severe weather, leading to extensive damage to public and private infrastructure. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which will assist Greece and Bulgaria in rebuilding basic infrastructure, fund emergency services, temporary accommodation, clean-up operations or counter immediate health risks.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the NOVAKOV report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Disasters of 2015 in Bulgaria and Greece. The European Commission has proposed mobilising the EU Solidarity Fund following a disaster in Bulgaria (severe winter conditions resulting in a "major natural disaster") as well as two disasters in Greece (floods in the Evros region and central Greece) in early 2015. The European Union must remain an example of solidarity, especially among its member countries. Natural disasters are events that we cannot always anticipate and every European region may be hit hard one day.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to mobilise the EUSF to grant financial assistance in relation to a disaster in Bulgaria and two disasters in Greece that occurred in early 2015. After deduction of advances already paid of 10% (EUR 637,782 for Bulgaria and EUR 989,695 for Greece), the balance to be paid is EUR 14,647,288 (EUR 5,740,033 of which for Bulgaria and EUR 8,907,255 for Greece). As these appropriations will help the two countries repair the damage to public and private infrastructure, private housing, businesses, agriculture, the environment and cultural heritage, I have decided to support this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund was established precisely to provide adequate assistance in the event of disasters such as floods in the Evros region of Greece at the beginning of the year or winter heavy rains, snowfalls and landslides in Bulgaria. The Objective of the Fund is to help the Union respond quickly, flexily and effectively to these disasters. In all three areas, we still have work to do to improve the mobilisation of the Fund, so I finally welcome this report. The European Union is based on solidarity, one of its most important core values, and it is in this spirit that the Member States must act. As is known, twice gives, who gives quickly. What has happened requires swift action, and to this end we must use the Solidarity Fund with immediate effect so that we can help the Member States that have been affected by the disaster as soon as possible.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to grant financial assistance relating to a disaster in Bulgaria (severe winter conditions causing a major natural disaster) and two disasters in Greece (flooding in Evros and Central Greece) that occurred in early 2015.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the allocation of nearly 6.4 million euro to the €1.5 billion in assistance from the EU Solidarity Fund to address the damage caused by the severe disasters at the beginning of the year in Bulgaria. Heavy rains in January and February caused floods and landslides that damaged local infrastructure and a number of private homes in the southeast of the country. To my great regret, in the last year and a half this has been another devastating disaster that has befallen my country and this is the third application for assistance from the Fund. Yes, the amount we will receive is small compared to the amount of damage, but it will help restore public infrastructure. And what will happen to the people whose homes have been destroyed? The Solidarity Fund does not repair damage to private property, but we have a moral obligation to help injured citizens and to take the necessary measures to prevent disasters of this magnitude in the future. I believe that this is only possible through prevention.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution as it calls for increased efforts and funding to assist areas of Greece and Bulgaria that were adversely impacted by severe climatic conditions in early 2015. Due to these situations the governments of these countries applied to the European Solidarity Fund. EUR 16 274 765 will be mobilised within the framework of the European Solidarity Fund to cover the cost of recovery operations in both countries as both cases match the European Solidarity Fund's criteria. Bulgaria was adversely affected by severe winter weather which included heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides. Immense damage was done to public infrastructure, communication and transport networks, enterprise and residential areas, not to mention to the agricultural sector and forests.  In Greece there was a similar situation with major flooding and consequently significant damage to infrastructure, especially water supplies and sewage systems, public buildings, residential areas and businesses. The impact on Greek agriculture saw the destruction of farming infrastructure, warehouses and crops. The report garnered the support of 95% of MEPs without any amendments or objections being made. The aid will reimburse expenses incurred on recovery and reinforcement works after the natural disasters.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – In the early 2015, severe winter conditions caused natural disaster classified as "major" in Bulgaria and another serious one (classified as "regional") in Greece. The calamities resulted in high-cost damages for the less developed South-East region in Bulgaria, and Evros and Central regions in Greece. Considerable damage occurred to public infrastructure, such as dykes, communication networks and roads, as well as businesses, private homes and immovable assets.  The total estimated support from the European Solidarity Fund was calculated to EUR 16.3 million. In fact, the mobilisation would not require an amendment to the 2015 budget, but will provide crucial help for the affected and vulnerable communities. The two cases match the European Solidarity Fund’s criteria. The nature of the disasters and their vast extent profoundly impacted on the local communities and economies. Damage has affected the regions thoroughly - not only public infrastructure (water supplies, sewage and electricity infrastructure) but also private property, businesses, agricultural land and forests.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Due to the lack of liquidity, for example, regional development is also suffering from a bottleneck. The aim is now to ensure that additional advances under the EMFF and, in certain areas, the full financing of certain programmes by the EU is to be ensured. The total amount is EUR 4 billion. As the entire European economy is suffering from this development, I voted in favour of the measure.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report calling for the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to help Bulgaria and Greece. The EUSF was created to help Member States and regions cope with major natural or regional disasters. At the beginning of 2015, Bulgaria and Greece suffered destructive floods resulting in damage estimated at 243 and 396 million euros respectively. The destruction of public infrastructure, communication networks and are all factors that justify the need for the EUSF. The report therefore proposes to validate the payment of 6.4 million euros for Bulgaria and 9.9 million euros for Greece, with the aim of helping them overcome these devastations (a total of 16.3 million euros).

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Bulgaria and Greece are in a difficult situation, both economically and naturally. It is important to assist in the restoration of national infrastructure, companies and private property. Bulgaria is preparing for harsh winter conditions and Greece is battling flooding in the Evros River and the central and western parts of the country, making it important to secure the future.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the proposal tabled.  It should be noted that Bulgaria has experienced particular difficulties due to the harsh winter conditions and the floods in Greece. Both parties suffered comprehensive losses. The nature of the disasters and their extensive damage has been caused not only to public infrastructure, but also to local communities, the economy of the country and private property, businesses, agricultural land and forests. EU financial support is therefore necessary to address the consequences of natural disasters.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the data on the damage caused by natural disasters in Greece and Bulgaria, I consider the total amount of the proposed aid to be necessary and appropriate. For this reason, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The severe natural disasters in Bulgaria necessitated an urgency response and thus the support of the European Solidarity Fund. I would like to congratulate my colleague Andery Novakov on the report, which successfully reflects the situation and calls for the mobilisation of the EUSF for a total amount of EUR 16.3 million, of which  EUR 6.4 million for Bulgaria, in order to grant the very much needed financial assistance.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. Severe winter conditions and flooding in the central and western parts of Greece are calling for intervention from the European Union. I supported the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund for Bulgaria and Greece, as I believe that the European Union must respond to such disasters quickly, effectively and flexibly and show solidarity with the people of the affected regions.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the decision to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help disasters affected by Bulgaria and Greece, as the criteria set out to assist countries affected by natural disasters are met.  Member States have the right to mobilise a certain sum of money from European funds in order to take care of national economies through the crises of affected countries, to allow the normal functioning of the labour market to be restored and for affected countries to re-engage in the trade flows of the European Union.  The damage caused by the natural disasters that hit Bulgaria is estimated at 243.305m euros and is being treated as a major natural disaster, while the one that struck Greece is categorised as a disaster for a region. In both countries, natural disasters have damaged public infrastructure, business facilities, and jobs have been questioned.  Based on the information currently available, the amount of money provided for Bulgaria and Greece is considered sufficient for cases of new possible applications for assistance from the Funds for the remainder of the year, so I support the decision to mobilise the European Solidarity Fund to assist the two countries.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total of 16.3 million euros. The aim is to provide financial assistance after the natural disasters that have occurred in Bulgaria and Greece. Both countries have experienced severe weather, leading to extensive damage to public and private infrastructure.  I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Given the violent echo and destructive consequences of regional natural disasters that hit Greece and Bulgaria in January and February 2015, I support the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to subsidise the recovery of the two countries through the European Union Solidarity Fund. Severe flooding in central Greece and devastating winter conditions in Bulgaria have led to serious damage and destruction of certain parts of infrastructure, communication networks and roads, forests, public institutions, private homes and business enterprises. These are disasters that have had a dramatic impact on local communities and the economy, and which the Commission has found to actually fit the criteria for funding from the Solidarity Fund. Bulgaria and Greece are also countries that have been experiencing negative trends in economic growth and general development for years, and other Member States should not allow them to face the consequences of these contingencies on their own. Finally, the Solidarity Fund also significantly assisted Croatia in recovering one part of the country from the severe floods that swept through it in May 2014. Solidarity is one of the fundamental values of the European Union, and natural disasters are one of the most serious accidents that a country can manage, so it is only right to ensure that we bear the burden of recovery together.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad that the Parliament had voted to mobilize the EU Solidarity fund in order to cope with the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece. Early this year, Bulgaria was hit with heavy snow and rain causing floods and landslides. These events caused major damage private homes and businesses, as well as public infrastructure. In Greece, widespread flooding in the central and western regions. These floods have damaged water supplies and agriculture in addition to public and private structures. These incidents have been qualified as a “major national disaster” and as a “regional disaster” according to the Regulation, and I have relieved that these regions can finally get the aid that they need to recover and rebuild. I would like to remind at this moment how helpful was the EU Solidarity fund in the Czech Republic after the huge floods in 2013.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has set up the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to respond to major natural disasters and in this way express its solidarity with the affected regions within the EU. This fund allows, for the period 2014-2020, to mobilise an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million.  I am in favour of allocating part of this sum (EUR 6 377 815.00) to Bulgaria, which was hit hard between January and February 2015 by heavy rain, snowfall, floods and landslides which caused considerable damage to public infrastructure. I am also in favour of allocating part of the EUSF (EUR 9,896,950.00) to Greece, which is also affected by two floods: the first at the beginning of February 2015 in Eastern Macedonia and Thrace, which caused enormous damage to basic infrastructure, public buildings, private homes, businesses and agriculture; the second, even more serious, hit central and western Greece, causing the power outage and the destruction of part of the cultural heritage in this region. I hope that these sums will be of real help to the people of these states.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for Greece and Bulgaria. Both of these countries faced serious natural disasters in January and February, and I therefore believe that financial assistance from the European Union is needed. In my opinion, more than EUR 6 million for Bulgaria and almost EUR 10 million for Greece will certainly help the affected countries to recover as soon as possible and as best as possible from the devastating natural events. I consider it essential that the European Union contributes to these countries. Devastating floods have also affected the Czech Republic several times in the last twenty years, and I am aware of the important nature of financial assistance for the restoration of, for example, infrastructure as soon as possible. I therefore believe that the funding from the European Union Solidarity Fund will be used effectively to help people in both countries.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up in 2002 to provide financial assistance to eligible countries affected by large-scale natural disasters or extraordinary regional disasters. The Commission proposes to mobilise the EUSF to provide financial assistance following the harsh winter in Bulgaria, which caused a disaster classified as a 'major natural disaster', and two floods in Greece classified as 'regional disasters' according to the EUSF criteria. I supported both proposals as both cases meet the requirements of the EUSF and have a strong impact on local communities and economies. My group supports the principle and objectives of the EUSF, which is why I supported the resolution on the mobilisation of the Fund.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In early 2015, Bulgaria was hit by a very harsh winter and Greece suffered severe flooding in the Evros region and central Greece. These exceptional climatic conditions have severely affected these countries and caused several damage.  In this context, the countries wanted to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund to help local and regional authorities repair the damage caused. The Commission has proposed allocating 6.3 million euros to Bulgaria and 9.8 million euros to Greece. The European Parliament has approved this request for mobilisation. I voted in favour of this report and I believe it is important to use this solidarity fund in such circumstances I hope that we will also be able to benefit from this fund for the deadly disasters that have occurred in the South of France in recent weeks.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of providing financial assistance, through the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), to those affected by the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece that took place earlier this year, as these two countries suffered significant material damage due to weather conditions. I am pleased that more than 600 MEPs have shown solidarity with those affected. The numerous damage suffered by public infrastructure in these two states, such as those affecting levees and communications and road networks, in particular major damage in rural regions, such as those suffered by large agricultural and forest areas or agricultural infrastructure, such as deposits and silos, will be much easier to remedy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report on the proposal to mobilise the Union Solidarity Fund for financial assistance following a disaster in Bulgaria (severe wintry conditions) and two disasters in Greece (floods in the Evros river basin and central regions of Greece). The total amount of aid proposed was €16 274 765 (10% have already been advanced).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission proposes to mobilise the EUSF to provide financial assistance in connection with a natural disaster in Bulgaria (harsh winter weather conditions and classified as a 'serious natural disaster' according to the EUSF) and two in Greece (floods in Evros and Central Greece, both classified as 'regional disasters' according to the EUSF).  All of them from early 2015. I support the adoption of the Commission's proposal for a Decision that in both cases they meet the EESF criteria because of the nature of the disasters, their enormous scope and their profound impact on local communities and economies; and because the damage has profoundly affected regions, not only public infrastructure but also private property, businesses, agricultural land and forests. Within the framework of the overall EU budget for the 2015 financial year, the EUSF will be mobilisation of EUR 16,274,765 in commitment and payment appropriations. After deducting the advances paid equivalent to 10% (637,782 euros for Bulgaria and 989,695 euros for Greece), the outstanding amount is 14,647,288 euros (5,740,033 euros for Bulgaria and 8,907,255 euros for Greece).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The EU Solidarity Fund will reimburse part of the costs paid by Bulgaria and Greece to repair the damage caused by harsh winter conditions in south-eastern Bulgaria and central, eastern and western Greece in January and February 2015. In Greece, floods destroyed public buildings, private homes, businesses, agricultural areas and cultural heritage sites in the central and Evros regions. Southeastern Bulgaria has been hit by heavy rains, floods and landslides that have damaged, communication and road networks, as well as public and private buildings. Bulgaria is expected to receive EU aid of 6.3 million euros and the two Greek regions will receive a total amount of 9.9 million euros.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for a total amount of EUR 16.3 million (in commitment and payment appropriations) — EUR 6.4 million for Bulgaria and EUR 9.9 million for Greece — as a financial response to the devastating natural disasters in those Member States , in early 2015. From the analysis to the report, the EUSF mobilisation criteria are met and, being aware of the nature of the disasters, their wingspan and the profound impact these tragedies have had on local communities, I voted in favour of this mobilisation.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for Greece and Bulgaria. The European Union expresses its solidarity with the populations affected by natural disasters by raising financial funds. The Commission has already proposed an advance of EUR 637,782 for Bulgaria, or 10% of the fund's contribution, in line with Article 4a(2) of the Regulation. The amount has already been used by the Bulgarian Government for the urgent recovery of transport infrastructure, drainage and safety and preventive infrastructure. The Commission voted EUR 989,695 for Greece, or 10% of the financial contribution provided for by the EUSF. After deduction of advances already paid by 10% and after approval by the EP, the balance to be paid is EUR 14,647,288.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, which will release European Structural and Investment Funds for the catastrophes in Greece and Bulgaria, by amending the disaster provisions on these two points of geography. We still understand that the fund does not take care of the total needs that both spaces need to meet

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report supports the use of new funds to flood-affected regions (Greece) and an abnormally harsh winter (Bulgaria); regions that are also among the poorest in the EU. I voted in favour because the EU needs to help alleviate situations like this.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ While I understand that this is for aid, which could be used to help victims, the British public are already more than generous with donating funds to charitable causes when natural disasters occur. I do not believe foreign aid to be within the remit of the EU, so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s Solidarity Fund is an emergency financial aid following disasters in Member States or candidate countries. Both Bulgaria and Greece have submitted applications to mobilise the Fund: Bulgaria for severe winter conditions and Greece has submitted two applications for flooding. I voted in favour of this reasonable request and I am delighted to see that many others joined me in this show of solidarity.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Solidarity is one of the values on which the European Union stands. Requests by Bulgaria and Greece to provide funding from the EU Solidarity Fund due to heavy torrential rains, snowfall, floods and subsequent landslides in Bulgaria and floods in the Evros river basin and central and western parts of Greece were considered justified. For this reason, I voted in favour of mobilising the Solidarity Fund in the event of the disasters in question.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Bulgaria and Greece were hit by natural disasters in early 2015. Heavy rains, floods and landslides have destroyed public, private and agricultural infrastructure. Bulgarian authorities estimate the total direct damage caused by the disaster at 243.305m euros, while Greece estimates the damage at 395.878m euros. The Commission has proposed mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) and granting financial assistance for the disaster in Bulgaria under the category of 'major natural disasters' and two disasters in Greece defined as 'regional disasters'.  The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to provide Member States with swift, effective and flexible financial assistance in the event of an emergency and to show solidarity with the inhabitants of the region affected by the disaster. At the plenary session, I supported the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) and approve financial assistance related to the disaster in Bulgaria and Greece. These Member States need funds to restore infrastructure in the local and regional community.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Bulgaria and Greece were hit by major natural disasters in early 2015. In southeastern Bulgaria, large areas have been hit by floods and landslides that have damaged public infrastructure, with more than 300 buildings flooded in burgas only. The floods also plagued central, western Greece and the evros river, causing damage to public buildings as well as agriculture, as crop warehouses were flooded. The EU Solidarity Fund serves us precisely for such unforeseen events, which is why I support its use to help bulgarian and Greek citizens to mitigate the impacts that these disasters have had on them. Local authorities will need funding for basic emergency operations to restore the transport network, sewerage, safety and preventive infrastructure. The Commission proposes aid amounting to EUR 16 million, which corresponds to the scale of these disasters.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the EU Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies and to show its solidarity to the people of disaster-affected areas. Bulgaria has thus submitted an application for the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund in relation to severe winter conditions (at the beginning of February 2015 it was hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides) and Greece made two applications for the mobilisation of the Flood Fund (in early February 2015, the wider area of eastern Macedonia and Thraca was hit by severe flooding, while a new wave of flooding also covered large parts of central and western Greece). In order to secure a financial contribution, the Fund would use funds of EUR 16 274 765. The Commission then considered that the applications met the conditions for granting assistance from the Fund as provided for in Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002. Both examples meet the criteria of the EU Solidarity Fund: the nature of the disasters themselves, their exceptional impact on the local population and the economy, the damage in regions that was not limited to public infrastructure but also affected private property, business units, agricultural land and forests. That is why I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund as reconstruction aid following the natural disasters that struck Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. As, unfortunately, has already happened in many Member States in the past, the allocation of the Solidarity Fund will serve to cover in part the costs incurred by Bulgaria and Greece in repairing the serious damage caused by floods, heavy rains and other extreme weather phenomena, which hit the two countries of south-east Europe at the beginning of this year. They will therefore receive aid of EUR 6.3 million and EUR 9.9 million respectively to meet the costs of emergency and rescue operations and to meet in part those of reclamation in the disaster regions, in particular the rehabilitation of the transport and communications infrastructure affected.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report contains a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. Specifically, there are disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The fund is intended to enable the European Union to react quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergencies and to show solidarity with the populations in the disaster-affected regions. Bulgaria has applied for the Fund because of severe winter weather conditions, and Greece has submitted two applications for mobilisation due to flooding. All applications meet the conditions for granting assistance. The Fund should therefore be used to provide a total financial contribution of EUR 16 274 765 for applications submitted by Bulgaria and Greece. In order to allow as little time as possible to reach the mobilisation of the Fund, this Decision should apply from the date of its adoption. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – Solidarity is manifested in difficult situations in the European Union caused by natural disasters. I therefore support the use of the Fund for such activities.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Report because it is in the spirit of democracy, Christian principles and humanity to help people, and consequently bulgaria and Greece, which have recently experienced three natural disasters in their climate.  Given that the Solidarity Fund was established and has a function precisely for such problems, it is evident that it needs to be mobilised since these are situations described for the purpose of this Fund. This is an eclectic example of emergencies and opportunities to show solidarity with other Member States and therefore a Fund aimed at helping populations from disaster regions needs to be mobilised. As the Commission has assessed that the requirements of Greece and Bulgaria meet the criteria and conditions for granting aid, there are no other serious obstacles to this support not being activated.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Bulgaria's application to mobilise the Fund (concerning severe winter conditions) and both of Greece's applications to mobilise the Fund (concerning floods). This aid can be used by Bulgaria and Greece to rebuild their respective basic infrastructure, fund emergency services, provide temporary accommodation, fund clean-up operations and counter immediate health risks.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this initiative, which aims to help Member States suffering the severe consequences of natural disasters. The European Union Solidarity Fund effectively demonstrates solidarity and helps affected areas of the European Union and local people in distress.  At the beginning of 2015, Bulgaria faced severe winter conditions, while Greece and eastern Croatia suffered massive flood damage in mid-2014. The European Commission has concluded that the demands of Bulgaria and Greece to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund are justified, so I support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the damage caused by natural disasters in Bulgaria and Greece, I supported the proposal to mobilise resources from the Solidarity Fund.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund for disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. Bulgaria has been hit by heavy rains, snow and flooding, while Greece has been hit by major flooding. The European Union Solidarity Fund was established with a view to a rapid and effective response to emergencies in the Member States. The European Union has been built on the foundations of solidarity, and I therefore support any solidarity with the areas in the Member States that have been affected for one or other reasons.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU must be flexible when there are reasons to compensate countries affected by natural disasters.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes that the 2013 2013 european council will be the first to be edd with a proposal for a Directive on the use of the 2013 On the basis of point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2015, the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSR) provided financial support for the disaster in Bulgaria at the beginning of 2015 (due to exceptionally harsh winter weather conditions classified as a "major natural disaster" according to the EUSR) and the two disasters in Greece that were also classified as "regional disasters" in Evros, central Greece, in early 2015 (according to the EUSR).  The Commission has carried out a thorough examination of all three applications in accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund, as amended by Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014, and in particular Articles 2, 3 and 4 the following. The European Union is disbursing a total of EUR 16 274 765 to Bulgaria and Greece to mitigate the damage. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Novakov report for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) in favour of Bulgaria and Greece affected by severe natural phenomena at the beginning of 2015. Some large areas of Bulgaria had been hit by heavy rains, snowfall, floods and landslides, suffering damage of around EUR 250 million. While the floods in Eastern Macedonia and Thrace caused some EUR 400 million in damage. Thanks to this report, EUR 10 million will be allocated through the EUSF to these two countries. This will help those areas which have already been hard hit by natural phenomena, already affected by the economic crisis such as Greece.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union Solidarity Fund allows us to support Member States whose populations are facing disasters at local and regional level.  Unfortunately, both Bulgaria and Greece have had to submit requests to mobilise this fund as a result of the harsh winter conditions in the case of Bulgaria and the floods in the case of Greece. Earlier this year, large areas of Bulgaria suffered from heavy rains, snow, floods and landslides, with the south-east region most affected. In the case of Greece, large-scale floods in the regions of Eastern Macedonia and Thrace have damaged essential infrastructure and public buildings and destroyed agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops. Water supplies and sewerage infrastructure in 17 localities were affected. I voted in favour of granting this financial assistance. The nature of the disasters and their scale have had a profound impact on local communities and economies, and I am pleased that we have a tool at our disposal to show solidarity throughout the Union.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, it is also Europe's role to help countries but especially citizens who have experienced the worst and to be able to give them the necessary tools to rebuild their lives and their future.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing financial assistance to Bulgaria and Greece, which were severely hit by natural disasters in 2015. Major parts of Bulgaria suffered from heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides in January and February 2015. Greece was affected by wide-spread flooding in the Evros and the central and western regions in February 2015. These disasters caused considerable damage to public infrastructure, businesses, private homes and agriculture. Thanks to the mobilisation of the Fund, Bulgaria and Greece receive in total EUR 6 377 815 and EUR 9 896 950  in aid respectively, including already contributed advance payments.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund in the case of Greece and Bulgaria, which are affected by major natural disasters, i.e. emergency regional disasters to provide them with adequate financial assistance.  Since I myself come from a country that was hit by floods last year and this year with fires, I am well aware of how adversely natural disasters can affect people's dignified lives.  As in Croatia, in Bulgaria and Greece natural disasters have caused a decrease in the quality of life in local communities and are extremely disadvantaged for economies that are still disadvantaged without it. Given that this is an appropriate way of showing solidarity and support to vulnerable citizens of these countries, I believe that this mobilisation is very much needed for their citizens to help rebuild infrastructure and normalise life in the affected areas.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015) was supported as the Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to provide the Union with a to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to show its solidarity with the population of disaster-affected areas. Unfortunately, this has also happened in the case of Greece and Bulgaria. With this decision, after deducting the 10% advance already paid, mePs also allocated EUR 14 647 288 to the two countries, of which EUR 5 740 033 for Bulgaria and EUR 8 907 255 for Greece.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, which will release European Structural and Investment Funds for the catastrophes in Greece and Bulgaria, by amending the disaster provisions on these two points of geography. We still understand that the fund does not take care of the total needs that both spaces need to meet.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Use of the EU Solidarity Fund to repair damage caused by natural disasters in Bulgaria and Greece. I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, which will release European Structural and Investment Funds for the catastrophes in Greece and Bulgaria, by amending the disaster provisions on these two points of geography. We still understand that the fund does not take care of the total needs that both spaces need to meet.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote in favour as this is a useful use of the EU solidarity fund (EUSF) to address two natural disasters.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund concerning the disasters in Bulgaria and Greece. The report deals with the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to support the recovery after the natural disasters that occurred in these two countries. This fund aims to give aid in the event of a major natural disaster with serious repercussions on living conditions, the natural environment or the economy and is designed to provide fast, effective and flexible emergency financial aid.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a European Union fund so that we can act quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergency situations. With this action 6.4 million euros will be used as financial assistance to respond to disasters caused by the heavy cold and snowfall that Bulgaria suffered in early 2015. EUR 9.9 million will also be earmarked as financial assistance for the floods suffered by Greece. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of these measures.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report supports the use of new funds to flood-affected regions (Greece) and an abnormally harsh winter (Bulgaria); regions that are also among the poorest in the EU. I voted in favour because the EU needs to help alleviate situations like this.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In late January and early February 2015, vast regions of Bulgaria were hit by heavy rainfall, snow, floods and landslides, with the south-eastern region being the most affected. These phenomena have caused considerable damage. In early February 2015, the regions of Eastern Macedonia and Thrace were hit by widespread floods, which caused damage to essential infrastructure, public buildings, private housing, businesses, as well as in Greece's agricultural sector, destroying agricultural infrastructure, warehouses and crops. In the same period, vast areas of greece's central and western regions were affected by another series of floods, which caused even higher damage, resulting in power cuts, isolation of several mountain settlements and destruction of some greek cultural heritage assets. The Commission proposes mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to provide financial assistance. We agree with this mobilisation, but we do not stop mentioning that the European Union's sectoral policies – such as the CAP – contribute to an increased exposure to the risk of disasters in certain regions.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Bulgaria has applied for restraining order due to severe winter conditions, as has Greece, which has submitted two applications due to severe flooding. The Solidarity Fund's task is to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly in emergencies and to show solidarity with the populations of the affected regions. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agree with the disbursement of funds from the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) to Greece and Bulgaria. Natural disasters occur by chance. The EUSF was created to provide solidarity in the event of major natural disasters in the European context. It is thus one of the few instruments that is meaningfully located at a supranational level. This means that the EU is approving €16.2 million to provide assistance due to natural disasters in Greece and Bulgaria in the winter of 2015. In Greece, five regions have been affected by severe flooding, while in Bulgaria the severe winter has caused considerable damage. The funds – €9.9 million for Greece and €6.3 million for Bulgaria - will cover part of the costs of emergency relief and reconstruction in the aftermath of these natural disasters. The funds will be used in particular to restore vital infrastructure and services and to reimburse emergency and rescue costs and will cover part of the clean-up costs in the affected regions.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The financial and economic crisis is having devastating consequences for the people of Greece, and it is lacking in all corners. In the current situation, the Greek state is not able to co-finance the European Structural and Investment Fund, and it therefore needs solidarity. The pre-financing of the current financial period proposed by the Commission will enable Greece to complete important public projects that have already begun. Given the situation in Greece, I see an absolute need for a simplified and accelerated aid procedure, and that is why I supported the Commission's proposal.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the mobilisation of more than EUR 16 million from the EU Solidarity Fund in the event of disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The European Commission has proposed mobilising the Fund to provide financial assistance to Bulgaria, which has been affected by a major natural disaster caused by winter conditions at the end of January. The same applies to Greece, where the floods at the beginning of the year, which took place in Evros and the central region of that country, were classified as "regional disasters". The objective of the EU Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and with flexibility to emergencies and to express solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Novakov on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund: Disasters in Bulgaria and Greece in 2015. The widespread flooding in the region of Eastern Macedonia and Thrace, but also in central Greece caused enormous damage to basic infrastructure, private homes, public buildings, businesses as well as to Greek agriculture. At the same time, large parts of central and western Greece were also affected by floods that caused even greater damage, resulting in the destruction of some important cultural heritage monuments in Greece. The decision to mobilise the Solidarity Fund is more than correct.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the call for mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) with reference to two catastrophic situations that took place at the beginning of 2015 in Bulgaria and Greece. At the end of January and the beginning of February, large areas of Bulgaria, especially the south-eastern region, were hit by heavy rain, snowfall, floods and landslides, causing damage estimated at around EUR 250 million. Widespread floods in eastern Macedonia and Thrace in early February 2015 caused about 400 million euros in damage, according to greek authorities.  With this report, it is proposed to allocate around EUR 10 million to Greece and EUR 6 million to Bulgaria, in order to try to help, in some way, these areas, which are so badly affected by serious natural phenomena. It should be stressed that the European Union Solidarity Fund, despite the rules, modalities and timing that are not always optimal, remains a useful support, which shows precisely the 'solidarity' of the European Union by financially supporting a Member State, an accession country or a region affected by major natural disasters.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on helping two Member States, Bulgaria and Greece, to cope with the consequences of the natural disasters that struck them earlier this year. Both of these countries have been hit by heavy torrential rains, floods and landslides, which have caused major damage to both public and private property. In my opinion, it is necessary to help states that have been put in an unenviable situation as a result of such unforeseen events, and I have therefore welcomed the opportunity to support the report on the financial contribution to these States from the European Union Solidarity Fund. The Fund is an expression of belonging between Member States as one of the important values that the European Union professes.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Parliament today called for strong legislation from the European Commission to protect trade marks, especially artisans. The naming of products such as Albacete knives or Talavera de la Reina pottery needs the European Commission, its legislative initiative, precisely so as not to disappear.  Thousands of jobs and thousands of people need the European Commission's legislative action, precisely to maintain rural people, jobs and production. The 'made in' is blocked in the Council and another of the protection instruments we have at European level are geographical indications also protected for non-agricultural products.  I ask the European Commission to take seriously the message — almost unanimous — sent today by the European Parliament and to protect these products, to protect citizens, to protect small entrepreneurs, to protect artisans, and to protect them precisely from unfair competition coming from other parts of the planet and which gives them just where it hurts the most : in the quality of its products and also in its artisanal and local production.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would also like to explain why I voted in favour of Mrs Rozière's report on extending EU protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. I think this is an important report and a task for the European Commission, which should prepare the legislative procedure for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. It turns out that it is useful, and it is also very necessary that traditional crafts, traditional products are protected. I consider it very important that this resolution also includes the promotion of the transfer and development of traditional know-how and the associated skills, which are inherent in apprenticeships, to vocational training. The European Parliament also stresses the importance of investment in education and training and encourages Member States to use financial support.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Virginie Rozière on a fantastic result, and 608 votes in this Parliament have backed the principle of extending geographical indication to non-food products. I represent Scotland in this Parliament and it is absolutely important for some of our most peripheral areas in the European Union that products like Harris tweed and Scottish tartan have this extension of protection. We live in a more globalised world where there are more challenges in terms of property rights and ownership. I think that we all can be very grateful to Virginie Rozière’s report for what we have done today as a Parliament, but also to the fact that the majority – the vast majority of people in this Chamber – backed the extension of geographical indication to non-agricultural products. The challenge now is: what will the Commission come forward with and what will the Council support? So now the pressure is on the Commission and the Member States to take forward what we have done today.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the creation of an EU-wide system of protection of geographical indications has already proved its vital importance for many of our agricultural products. Now it is vital that we extend it to include authentic local products. The fact is that we have a fragmented situation where some Member States offer no protection, while others have widely differing definitions. This will mean there is a clear and strong legal framework for protecting our local producers, and that is why today I voted in favour of the extension of the geographical indications to non-agricultural products. My region of the West Midlands houses world-renowned china products, like Wedgewood, Steelite, Royal Worcester and Spode in Stoke-on-Trent. I call on the Commission to take strong measures to make sure that authentic products from the Potteries can no longer be priced out of the market by cheap knock-offs. They are a crucial part of my region’s heritage, and I urge the Commission to ensure they receive proper protection.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour, and why, let me quote one of the ideas in the preamble to our national legislation on a similar subject: 'in order to strengthen togetherness, unity and national consciousness, the values of our nation must be gathered'. In a peculiar way, as more and more slurs Hungary, we have more and more tourists. Thank you very much for this, we invite and welcome people from Europe and beyond, look at our many hungaricums. This is also enlisted in the legislation, such as the Lake of Hévíz and traditional Hévíz medicine, matyó and kalocsa folk art, puszta or puskás ferenc oeuvre, and nowadays the most important is the oeuvre of János Hunyadi and the triumph of Nándorfehérvár, where Hunyadi defended Hungary and Europe from a mass foreign invasion at the head of central European forces. The noon bell is in his memory.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – I therefore take the view that geographical indications for non-agricultural products are useful and good, in particular, in terms of product transparency. In addition, they also help consumers to choose their products more lightly and also contribute to their product information. At this point, However, I would like to point out that a geographical indication does not necessarily guarantee the traceability of the product, but merely contributes to easier traceability. However, in order to ensure traceability, further grips are needed. Here, in particular, I applied to product safety legislation and market surveillance. I also want to establish an important point that is crucial for the Green Group. It is that the report does not specify in sufficient detail the extension of intellectual property to new products. However, impact assessments should also be carried out on how a single EU introduction of geographical indications on non-agricultural products would affect the costs of business, the state and consumers. And since I believe that the report is somewhat flawed at certain points, I abstained in the vote on the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I, like the absolute majority of my colleagues, also supported this report. I believe that, at a time when there is protection at EU level of the geographical indication of agricultural products and this current regulation is good, effective, it makes sense to extend this EU regulation to non-agricultural products as well. This will only unify the regime that already exists for a particular type of product. It is quite clear that it is much more effective to protect the specificities of our products at one European level, not to have 28 vested, fragmented separate arrangements, each of which, of course, is legally a little different. It is important that this regulation does not entail any burden on entrepreneurs, it is a voluntary matter. It will therefore be up to the manufacturer whether or not to use this protection, neither the State nor the European Union is forced to do anything about it here. I think that's very important and it needs to be pointed out to the entrepreneur.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, today I supported an initiative to extend the protection of the Geographical Indication of the European Union to non-financial products.  Non-agricultural products, as well as agricultural products, are carriers of economic growth and development and this is an innovative approach to the traditions and peculiarity of individual regions. This is another way of promoting the European values that we must stand for. Also, with the aim of creating new jobs, encouraging medium and small entrepreneurs and craftsmen, everything we need in rural areas, but also in all other parts of the European Union.  In Croatia we have a lot to offer and show to Europe and the world. Just as agricultural products are recognized as special and high values and qualities such as Neretva mandarins, Baranja kulen, Lyc potatoes, Krk olive oil, Ogulin sauerkraut, so, even from non-agricultural products, we are proud of lacemaking, wooden toys from Hrvatsko Zagorje... (The president has interrupted the lec phone.)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – In Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo, agus ar ndóigh bhí mé ag freastal ar an díospóireacht aréir. Bhí I know soiléir go raibh an chuid is mó de na Feisirí and bhfabhar na dear. Chonaiceamar é seo sa volta: sé chéad is a hocht as sé chéad nócha ceathair ag vótáil i bhfabhar.  Gan dabht ar bith, do I know le feiceáil gur chabhraigh na tásca geografacha (GIanna) go mór le táirgí talmhaíochta agus cén fáth nach gcabhródh siad le táirgí nach táirgí talmhaíochta iad? Tugann I know aitheantas dóibh; tugann I know seans dóibh margaíocht a dhéanamh, agus dar ndóigh níos mó earraí a dhíol. Sa tslí sin beidh siad in ann níos mó jabanna a chruthú agus saibhreas a chothú. Mar a dúirt an rapóirtéir, tá súil agam anois go ndéanfaidh an Coimisiún gach iarracht na a lot of seo in chur and bhfeidhm comh luath agus is féidir leis.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have just adopted the own-initiative report calling for the Member States and the Union to introduce an indication of origin for non-agricultural products as well, just as there are protected geographical indications protecting cheeses, meat and products of the earth, we would like to protect the excellent non-agricultural products that we produce and process in Europe and Italy. , products such as Carrara marble, Murano glass, slate, ceramics and much more.  If such a system is introduced it will help to combat counterfeiting and promote made in Europe and around the world. There is only one regret, the report calls for the introduction into the list of protected geographical indications to be made for a fee. Instead, we demand that registration be free of charge. However, given the importance of this issue, we voted in favour of the report here in plenary.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – The possible extension of the protection of geographical indications in the European Union to non-agricultural products is very important and necessary. I support it. It helps to improve the level of consumer information and thus enables them to navigate more effectively in goods sold on the market. Extending and effectively implementing such a system would give people greater confidence in the quality of the product, as well as to act as a remedy and a remedy for the manufacturer, since producers are also actually consumers. In fact, maintaining the production of traditional crops can help to halt the decline in the population in rural areas and the degradation of these areas, and the outflow of young people from the countryside. For example, in the case of my country, in the case of Latvia, such trends are particularly strong both among the regions of the country in the poorest region of Latgale and in other regions.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I, too, supported this proposal, which was tabled here by my colleague, saying that, in my opinion, it is not essential to fully convince myself of the importance of this protection at EU level, which is indeed indisputable. It is not only about crafts, but it is generally about local production, about protecting it from unfair competition and also about consumer protection. I don't think that's been said yet, it's a question of informing specific end-consumers of this particular local production. But what has not yet been said here is the question of supporting the promotion of this protection at international level. If only the European Union is aware of and protects the value of these traditional crafts and this production, it will be relatively little. We also need to ensure an international level of protection, which is why I support the resumption of negotiations on the TRIPS international trade agreement on trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights. I think this is absolutely crucial for the European Union.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider this measure, which we have voted on today, to be extraordinarily important.  I hope that the Commission will act promptly and tenaciously to define an even more organic measure. I believe that this is something that links Italian history in particular, a centuries-old history, to European manufacturing and therefore protection with geographical indication makes even more competitive our small and medium-sized enterprises that are facing an increasingly global market that must have the certainty of quality, that which Italian companies link to their products.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report proposes that the European Commission brings forward a legislative proposal to create a system of Geographical Indication Protection for non-agricultural products similar to the system already extant for agricultural products such as wine and cheese. The UK Independence Party voted against this proposal because as a matter of principle it is against the EU having the power to legislate so as to make laws binding on the United Kingdom. Furthermore this proposal is likely to produce a significant regulatory burden on producers, create a large and expensive bureaucracy to service the system. In addition it is wholly unclear how this ill-thought out proposal will interact with existing bodies of law such as Copyright, Trade Marks, Patents and other protection for intellectual property.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The possible extension of the protection of typical EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products is a major step towards the protection of traditional High Quality European products. Protection arises from the need to preserve products that are the result of traditional knowledge and techniques, as well as characteristic elements of entire European regions. Products of excellence are continually the victims of counterfeiting and fraud. In order to stem these phenomena, which are detrimental to both consumers and producers, I believe it is necessary to create a protected geographical indication, including for non-agricultural products, so that we can provide adequate protection for both sides. European harmonisation is needed because some States do not offer specific protection, while in others definitions and procedures can be found. In Italy, for example, there is no such protection. In this respect, I believe that a harmonised procedure must be completely free of charge without adding any burden to companies. We have fought for this and we will continue to be vigilant. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that the GI system for agricultural products has been revealed as a positive mechanism for protecting small local producers in certain nations and States currently belonging to the EU.  That is why I think it is positive to extend this system to products other than agricultural products taking into account the experience and lessons learned during this time with agricultural products.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products. The report aims to extend the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This proposal allows protection of the "Made in France" and therefore of French producers. Through this process, the consumer also benefits by benefiting from guarantees in terms of product quality. This is a step forward for French producers, although we regret a rather vague definition of non-agricultural PGIs and the registration process.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Union, and Greece in particular, has a fairly significant production outside of agricultural products which must be protected by a single system of protection of geographical origin. That is why I voted in favour of the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the possible extension of EU protection of geographical indication to non-agricultural products.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to extend the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products, including certain French products. Through a protected geographical indication, the producer can thus recognize know-how and offer quality products to consumers. In France, companies are forecasting a significant increase in demand for products in certain sectors thanks to this code. Since this is about protecting the 'made in France', I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I remain to be convinced that the extension of geographical indication protection would be positive for the economy. It has various potential drawbacks: 1. It provides barriers for entry of new businesses into a market; 2. It narrows competition and therefore consumer choice; 3. It fixes capital within a narrow geographical area. In addition to the above, such decisions should be taken at national level not at EU level. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which supports local economic development, boosts tourism, strengthens consumer confidence and helps preserve cultural heritage and traditional know-how.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of The Virginia Rozière initiative, which is a response to the lack of protection for manufactured goods in Europe. To date, national legislation that is too disparate in this area does not protect the know-how of our industrial and artisanal products. This approach establishes a clear link between the product on the one hand, and the geographical area on the other, through a european-recognized registration system. This will enhance our heritage while contributing to growth in Europe.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to extend the protection of geographical indication to non-agricultural products. A geographical indication indicates that the reputation, quality or other characteristic of the product is related to a specific area. Currently, it is intended solely for agricultural products and is used by around 3 000 people. agricultural products. I agree with the need to exploit the economic potential of protecting the distinctiveness and quality of non-agricultural products, to preserve the know-how and jobs associated with them, and to contribute to the fight against counterfeiting. I therefore support the relevant EU rules proposed for this purpose.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. We are often accused of "euroscepticism" when we are not accused outright of being 'anti-European', but we do not hesitate to support the - too rare - projects that seem to us to go in the right direction. This is the case for this report on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products. So I voted in favour, although this is only a draft and many points remain unclear or clearly unsatisfactory at this stage.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. If agricultural products of a particular geographical origin that have specific qualities or are manufactured using traditional methods may be subject to unit protection of geographical indications at EU level, the same is not true for non-agricultural products. The rapporteur, whose report I approved, supports the introduction at European level of a single instrument for the protection of indications of non-agricultural products. This would lead to positive economic benefits for local or regional producers, generate jobs in less advantaged regions and give clear guidance to consumers on the origin and methods of manufacturing products.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of Union geographical indications to non-agricultural products, which entails a request to give appellation of origin to union artisan products. This resolution will increase the protection of local artisan products through the extension of the GI system already enjoyed by certain quality agricultural articles of the Union. This will enable more support for the development of the local economy, boost tourism, strengthen consumer confidence and help preserve cultural and traditional heritage.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products should make it possible to better protect non-agricultural products, especially at a time when the number of counterfeits is increasing. This will benefit French products such as Laguiole knives, Calais lace, Aurillac umbrellas or Aubusson tapestry. The PGI is a name or symbol that refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how. This guarantees consumers a quality offer and also allows producers to showcase their products. This extension should thus make it possible to further protect the "made in France", especially since international demand is expected to increase possiblely (up to 25%!) in certain sectors, such as textiles, benefiting from the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  So I voted for this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Rozière report, which calls on the Commission to draw up a proposal extending the system of quality certification to non-agricultural EU artisanal and traditional products. I believe that legislation of this kind would allow the excellence of our territories to have further protection on the market, although the Commission's work will have to be closely monitored in order to avoid disorderly overlaps with the existing system in agriculture outlined and to ensure that this legislation is genuinely effective.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament considers that a safeguard at European Union level should be created as part of a more ambitious strategy to support high-quality EU products and builds on the stronger commitment of the EU institutions to consider the production and crafts sector as a driver of economic growth and completion of the single market, thereby increasing the value of local industrial products and artisans, supporting local economic development and job creation in the areas concerned , boosting tourism and strengthening consumer confidence. The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's initiative to hold stakeholder consultations with a view to establishing the possibility of extending the protection of the European Union's geographical indication to non-agricultural products, and welcomes the October 2014 Report on the protection of the European Union's geographical indication. the results of the completed consultations and clearly supports the EU framework for protection based on geographical indications of non-agricultural products.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. At present, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another, and in some Member States the products of other Member States are not protected.  Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, because such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States but also of Europe.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The EPP supported the possibility of extending the protection of the European Union's geographical indications, which is now limited to agricultural products, to non-agricultural products. Traditional products, which are made using traditional methods and specific local techniques, are as such part not only national but also common European cultural heritage. As such, we must preserve them, because they are also increasing the tourist attractiveness of individual rural areas. I am convinced that this will encourage the development of secluded areas and ensure that old habits and customs are preserved.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this own-initiative report because the benefits of extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products are undoubted for SMEs and Italian artisans, as well as for consumers all. The report rightly points out that high-quality traditional European products are the result of traditional knowledge and techniques and represent an EU cultural heritage and an essential element to be preserved in the economic and social life of many European regions.
