However, I have my doubts as to the extent to which it is possible to require producers to pay a contribution for the registration of their product, although it is specified that this contribution should be one-off, fair in relation to the costs incurred and applied uniformly throughout the European Union. In my opinion, registration should be free of charge.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ How much is European skill, tradition and knowledge worth? If it is done in a small craft and on smaller quantities, it is expensive. And it disappears very easily under the onslaught of counterfeits from third countries. European textile manufacturers, for example, complain that around 40 percent of revenues must be spent on litigation with counterfeiters instead of increasing production, and many factories have long since shut down.  The origin label carries a lot of advantages that, for example, a protected character label does not have. Above all, it is a recognition in consumers. Consumers like to buy products with a designation of origin because they know they have bought quality and authentic.  Not when they get home, they turn over an overpaid product and it says "made in China." Small craftsmen and poor regions would benefit the most from such a label. Four million new jobs! The legal basis has already been laid with a label for agricultural products, and the new copyright directive is already the first stop where we can immediately start building a success story.   When someone with skepticism tells me about this topic I simply ask them where Would European agriculture be if there were no labels of origin for, for example, wines, or certain fruit or meat products? We must not be afraid to protect what is ours and ask trading partners to respect it!

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products such as Laguiole knives, Calais lace, etc. It allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer guarantees of quality.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that extending the protection of eu geographical indications to non-agricultural products can also encourage innovation in traditional production processes and the creation of new start-ups for traditional products and also contribute to the sustainability of jobs created in poorly developed areas, in particular by offering small businesses and micro-enterprises , which are responsible for about 80% of typical locally produced products that could find protection through the geographical indications system, the possibility of increasing sales through more effective marketing operations and an incentive to cooperate more, given the collective nature of the system.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of this important own-initiative report marks an important step in the protection of non-agricultural products and calls for action by the European Commission to extend the legislation on agricultural geographical indications to these products.  The EU Member States are rich in non-agricultural products, based on traditional knowledge and production methods deeply rooted in the cultural and social heritage of many geographical regions. The introduction of a harmonised system of protection would be necessary to encourage the development of the European economy and culture, particularly in the less developed regions. The protection of GIs, in fact, would be an engine of innovation to protect the high quality of products while maintaining competitiveness and preserving the knowledge rooted in the generations.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. A protected geographical indication or PGI is a sign of identification of the European Community which refers, as the name suggests, to the geographical origin of a product when it derives part of its specificity from that origin. Created in 1992, the PGI allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer guarantees of quality. The report recommends extending this protection to non-agricultural products. Some companies whose success is based on particular know-how believe that the extension of this protection will enable them to benefit from a 25% increase in international demand.  Attached to the promotion of "made in France" and French entrepreneurs, I can only rejoice in this legislative advance. Consumers will have more detailed information and will buy a product knowingly. This extension will make it possible to combat counterfeiting more effectively. Our entrepreneurs will be rewarded even more. So I voted for that proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The geographical indication serves to identify a product originating in a country, region or locality, where a quality, reputation or other characteristics of the product are linked to its geographical origin. However, non-agricultural products do not currently enjoy uniform protection of geographical indication at EU level, beyond national provisions. There are currently no rules at European level to protect the names of these industrial and artisanal products. In view of this, to date, 15 Member States have created mechanisms to protect geographical indications for non-agricultural products. But this protection is reduced, with geographical indications (GIs) protected either by establishing the offence of deception, by trade mark law or by specific GI provisions. I voted in favour of the initiative report on the possibility of extending the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products, as there is an urgent need to create a single system for the protection of geographical indications throughout the European Union, these products being part of the cultural, social and economic heritage of a particular place and demonstrating the scale of European know-how and cultural heritage , representing a history with specific knowledge of certain European areas.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The initiative calls on the Commission to prepare a proposal extending the 'system' of quality certification to non-AGRICULTURAL EU artisanal and traditional products. I agree with most of the text, but there is a reservation as to whether the Commission will create a disorderly overlap with the existing system in agriculture and outlined in the CAP (WTO, rural development, etc.). Great attention will have to be paid to the issue of the necessary budgetary cover for implementation and controls, avoiding drainage of resources from the amounts reserved for agriculture and, if possible, trying to redefine, for that sector too, the protections offered to operators and guarantees for consumers.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European geographical indications for agricultural products are very important not only for the sake of transparency, but also for the proper functioning of the single market. These indications are guarantee of quality. So it seems quite natural to want to extend them to non-agricultural products. Indeed, the industry and craft sectors are full of special masters that would be good to protect and report to consumers. We must be sure that the cultural specificities and European know-how are preserved. It is also with these types of measures that we will be able to improve the functioning of the single market. Extending geographical indications to non-agricultural products will benefit both producers and consumers. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products. High-quality traditional European products are the result of traditional knowledge and techniques and represent the EU's cultural heritage. In addition, they generate activities that have a direct link with local realities, particularly in rural areas, helping to increase the overall attractiveness of a territory. Today, however, there is an increasing risk of a gradual extinction of traditional skills and trades. As a result, the protection of geographical indications (GIs) of non-agricultural products could prove to be an incentive to safeguard cultural heritage and traditional know-how. I therefore hope that, as indicated in the adopted report, the Commission will present a legislative proposal without delay with the aim of establishing a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this file is to create a system of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, which are primarily issued from the rural areas. The main idea of the geographical identification is to create an EU wide label that would protect and underline and identify the special know-how and designate the quality, authenticity and characteristics of the product. It is argued that that such a system would foster growth, SME's growth, and maintain a link between the production and the territory it comes from as well as the itinerary of the productions.  Several fields are identified, such as the relations between the EU and the third countries and it underlines the fact that a geographical identification system could protect the local producers vis a vis the international competition. Moreover, it should also be noted that fifteen member states already have this system and that it is judged as primarily positive. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report proposes that the European Commission brings forward a legislative proposal to create a system of Geographical Indication Protection for non-agricultural products similar to the system already extant for agricultural products such as wine and cheese. The UK Independence Party voted against this proposal because as a matter of principle it is against the EU having the power to legislate so as to make laws binding on the United Kingdom. Furthermore this proposal is likely to produce a significant regulatory burden on producers, create a large and expensive bureaucracy to service the system. In addition it is wholly unclear how this ill-thought out proposal will interact with existing bodies of law such as Copyright, Trade Marks, Patents and other protection for intellectual property.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because currently only agricultural products with a specific geographical indication (GI) and made in certain quantities are granted an EU wide protection. On the other hand, traditional European products must be preserved within communities as these products are directly linked to ways of life within these communities and preservers their identity which will benefit tourism, culture, employment and trade.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report considers that traditional European production must be protected not only and exclusively with regard to agricultural products. The quality of knowledge and techniques refined over time is indeed a heritage to be safeguarded in every area, and Parliament has therefore welcomed the Commission's initiative to extend the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products as well.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Virginie Rozière's report on extending the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products.  In my opinion, this is a very good report, which takes into account both the need to preserve our unique and varied European heritage and the economic growth potential of our territories. The approach taken by Mrs Rozière seems constructive to me, the geographical indication being not seen as a condition of market access but as the consecration of know-how. These ancestral know-how are not immune to counterfeiting, which has developed considerably in the digital sphere in recent years. The answer to these risks of usurpation can only be European: a single protection regime must be put in place, the coexistence of national legal protections is no longer sufficient.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to extend the protection of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products. A PGI is a name or symbol that refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how. It allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer guarantees of quality. In France, particularly in certain sectors such as textiles, companies have estimated a possible 25% increase in international demand as a result of such protection. So I voted for this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As we stand today, agricultural products in the EU benefit from geographical indications, namely recognising the distinctive origin of a product where its qualities most likely derive from. This is essentially a means to protect unique regional and local heritage and we should take responsibility to protect these manufacturers from unfair competition. Today, the Parliament voted in favour of extending this regulation to non-agricultural products as well. The system is currently very fragmented, as only 15 Member States have this sort of legislation in place. The Commission should immediately engage in the process of coming up with a proposal to create a system for protection of artisanal arts and crafts. It is even more important to get this process underway as we must ensure that quality products and craft skills are not jeopardised in trade talks with third parties, as this would be the case with the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP).

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has a rich range of non-agricultural quality products, an expression of the different local, often artisanal, characteristics which constitute an immense cultural and economic heritage not only for the country of origin, but for the whole Union. Geographical indication (GI), currently provided only for products of agricultural origin, has favoured and increased the positioning of these products in international markets as they are considered by consumers to be safe and of quality. The lack at European level of a harmonised and coherent system for the protection of GIs for non-agricultural products has so far undermined the EU's ability to negotiate trade agreements with third countries which, in their legislation, provide for all GIs for non-agricultural products. The possibility of extending GIs in Europe to non-agricultural products as well as protecting our traditional products would strengthen the EU's negotiating capacity both bilaterally and multilaterally in the WTO. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report and I support the request to the European Commission to evaluate and present legislative proposals as soon as possible for the uniform protection of European GIs for non-agricultural products.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is very important that non-agricultural products of a particular geographical origin having specific characteristics or manufactured on the basis of traditional methods can benefit from uniform protection at Union level through geographical indications. It would therefore be particularly important for the European Union to adopt legislation on non-agricultural geographical indications in order to take full advantage of the positive economic consequences of protecting the distinctiveness and quality of these products, to provide consumers with reliable information on their location and method of production and to preserve the know-how of the jobs associated with them.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products.  Geographical indications can have considerable economic potential and adequate protection can bring important benefits, especially for SMEs and eu regions. Europe has a real heritage of traditional and artisanal skills of the highest standard. However, at European level, there is no uniform system for geographical indications of non-agricultural products.  This report welcomes the Commission's proposal for a public consultation with stakeholders and invites it to present a legislative proposal on the subject, considers it necessary to establish at EU level a protection instrument for the manufacturing and craft sector, considers that these measures should be accompanied by information and communication measures and underlines the important benefits that the extension of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products will bring to consumers , producers and citizens.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Virginie Rozière's proposal because I believe that the extension of GIs to non-agricultural products is useful in many respects. Geographical indications would, in fact, contribute effectively to combating counterfeiting, the fraudulent use of indications of origin and other unfair practices which, in addition to deceiving the consumer, are particularly harmful to niche companies that produce those products in various parts of Europe that make each of the Member States characteristic and valuable. I would like to stress that the use of these specifications for non-agricultural products will also serve to ensure that the purchaser has purchased a product with high-quality know-how, and this would make each State commercially stronger. Personally, I would like not to stifle traditions by maximizing these particular characteristics in every part of the EU, and that is why I would like to support the rapporteur.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report proposes that the European Commission brings forward a legislative proposal to create a system of Geographical Indication Protection for non-agricultural products similar to the system already extant for agricultural products such as wine and cheese. The UK Independence Party voted against this proposal because as a matter of principle it is against the EU having the power to legislate so as to make laws binding on the United Kingdom. Furthermore this proposal is likely to produce a significant regulatory burden on producers, create a large and expensive bureaucracy to service the system. In addition it is wholly unclear how this ill-thought out proposal will interact with existing bodies of law such as Copyright, Trade Marks, Patents and other protection for intellectual property.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Several agricultural products (by origin or production by traditional methods) benefit from the protection of geographical indications in the EU. It is desirable that this protection be extended to non-agricultural and traditional products such as handicrafts, embroidery and ceramics, which currently do not have a unitary protection system, enjoying different levels of protection in the Member States. In Portugal it will be the case, among others, of the carpets of Arraiolos or the Scarves of The Boyfriends of Minho so well defended by Deputy José Manuel Fernandes. I fully support Mrs Roziére's report for considering it vital to protect these traditional quality know-how products and traditional techniques that are part of the EU's cultural heritage and which generate activities directly related to local ways of life, especially in rural areas, helping to increase the attractiveness of these areas, preserve local identities and promote their specificity , with benefits for tourism, culture, employment and trade. In addition to the economic potential and the protection of their jobs, I underline the benefits for citizens and consumers who are more protected and increase their confidence in these products. I invite the European Commission to present the legislative proposal that creates this system quickly.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important own-initiative report. Food products have already been protected in relation to geographical indications since 1992. With this act, Parliament is calling on the European Commission to extend this protection to non-agricultural products as well, and I fully agree with this for a number of reasons. Firstly, because this supports typical products and, secondly, because local employment is encouraged: two good reasons for stimulating the territorial economy, especially that of rural areas.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Geographic indications (GI) are an extremely valuable component to the European economy and fully deserve consideration for expansion. While such labels are protected and regulated by EU law, they are currently limited to wine, spirits, and foodstuffs. However, the European Commission has recently considered extending these indicators to non-agricultural/non-food products. This proposal calls upon the Commission to draft legislation that acts upon this idea, and I fully support this measure. Expanding geographic indicators of more products in the European economy has the potential to boost consumer awareness and confidence in small markets and strengthen local economies across the continent. This will also strengthen non-agricultural products which are identifiable with Malta such as glass blowing.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns Parliament's reaction to the publication of the Commission's Green Paper entitled 'Making the most of Europe's traditional know-how: a possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products'. These products are rooted in the cultural and historical heritage of particular geographical locations, an essential element to be preserved in the economic and social life of many European regions. At present at European level, the protection of GIs is provided for wines, alcoholic beverages, aromatised wines and agricultural and food products. On the other hand, there is no harmonisation with regard to the protection of GIs for non-agricultural products.  The report welcomes Parliament's extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products as well. In particular, it calls on the Commission to set up a single protection system at EU level, given that the absence of such a system leads to an inadequate and fragmented European framework, due to different levels of protection within national and local rules. I am abstaining, as the benefits are undoubted for SMEs and craftsmen as well as for Italian consumers, and there is also the possibility of requiring producers to pay a contribution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that the GI system for agricultural products has been revealed as a positive mechanism for protecting small local producers in certain nations and States currently belonging to the EU.  That is why I think it is positive to extend this system to products other than agricultural products taking into account the experience and lessons learned during this time with agricultural products.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's report seeks to extend the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products in the European Union. On the basis of the Commission's Green Paper on the subject and consultation with stakeholders, Parliament calls on the European Commission to draw up a legislative proposal to extend EU protection to non-agricultural products. Under the current system, Member States apply different rules, which has a negative impact on the EU internal market. Extending protection to non-agricultural products can help to better protect local and regional products and, at the same time, to help people to thrive. Eu legislation requested by Parliament is expected to bring about, inter alia, the expected return on tourism, employment and culture. European products produced by high-quality, unique and traditional procedures will thus be protected in Europe. I hope that the products of the Central European regions, including the Hungarian-ded areas, will be significantly protected in Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since it puts pressure on the Commission to present a proposal for a unified system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. I voted in favour to send an important signal to the Commission which on this point seems reluctant to make a proposal in the near future.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since geographical indications have huge economic potential and adequate protection of them can bring important benefits, in particular to European SMEs and regions, I believe that this protection promotes and facilitates access to the common market, but also to the markets outside the Union of European artisanal products, which are the fruit of traditional knowledge and skills, which contribute to the preservation of valuable know-how , characteristic of entire social and local communities and which are also a significant component of Europe's historical, cultural, economic and social heritage.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to extend the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. Like their agricultural counterparts, these geographical indications identify a product whose quality, reputation or characteristics are mainly due to geographic origin. Currently used only in the agricultural field, this system should be developed for traditional European products based on authentic know-how and techniques. These products are often a central asset for the attractiveness of European territories and contribute to their local economic dynamism. The extension of such a geographical identification regime will therefore aim to protect the authenticity and quality of European products, to provide reliable information to consumers and to better combat counterfeiting. Convinced that these measures will contribute to the strengthening of European competitiveness, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this legislative proposal in order to remedy the fragmentation of the internal market, to enhance the know-how of our European territories, to guarantee the authenticity and quality of our European products and to strengthen the European Union's position on geographical indications in the negotiations it is conducting with its trading partners.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published a Green Paper launching a public consultation on possible EU intervention extending to non-agricultural products the geographical indications legislation already adopted for agricultural products. At present there is no harmonised regulation for non-agricultural products, unlike for agricultural products and alcoholic beverages. The advantage generated by this measure would be primarily economic, since it would facilitate a distinction between products using this type of labelling, making them more commercially attractive. The introduction of a harmonised system of protection would also promote the development of the European economy and culture. Protection would also encourage innovation to protect the high quality of products while maintaining their competitiveness. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Recognition and protection of geographical indications is essential to the preservation of artisanal production and know-how in Europe. This protection system, in place for agricultural geographical indications in Europe, should be extended to non-agricultural products, such as the Laguiole knife or Murano glass. This will help to strengthen the competitiveness of many European companies. This means that 4 million jobs are affected in Europe, in local SMEs or in artisanal structures. It will also help to better inform consumers about the quality and origin of the products.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the ROZIÈRE report on a possible extension of the European Union's protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products. Indeed, its application will help to remedy the fragmentation of the internal market while promoting the know-how of our European territories. Consumers will be able to have guarantees on the authenticity, quality and reliability of protected products. Finally, having voted for this report, I welcome the european Union's position on GIs (geographical indications) in its trade negotiations.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. At present, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another, and in some Member States the products of other Member States are not protected. Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. While agricultural products have been protected at European level since 1992, so far there has been no common legislation on industrial and artisanal products. It was therefore logical to extend to these products the protection of geographical indications, which symbolize traditional know-how and a local culture and which cannot be accepted by competing companies. That is why I supported the proposal to extend the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. I am convinced that this measure is likely to provide better guarantees to consumers, help producers and stimulate the local economy. These new rules could increase the attractiveness of the product to the consumer and allow the producer to increase the added value of its products. Among the 800 products identified by the European Commission that could be affected are several Belgian products such as Antwerp diamonds, Binche lace or Mons earthenware.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The reference to the geographical origin of products, whether agricultural or not, is an essential fact. It must be brought to the attention of the consumer for two reasons. First of all, it brings real added value from our world-renowned terroir. Finally, it allows the consumer to differentiate the imitations of the original product. By valuing the know-how on the labelling of non-agricultural products, this proposal makes it possible not to see our crafts (knives of Laguiole, lace of Calais, etc.) unfairly put in competition with low quality products and at lower costs. This will allow consumers to make informed choices, which could facilitate the French purchasing process. Representing the French and the patriots, I can only support this initiative which allows our craftsmen to stand out from ever more unfair competition. That is why I voted for this proposal.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Rosier's report on the possible inclusion of non-agricultural products in the European Union's protection of geographical indications. There are plenty of products on the EU market that are part of the cultural, social and economic heritage of a place or region in the EU and which are rooted in traditional know-how and production methods. As regards their legal protection: non-agricultural products are industrial products and crafts that do not have this type of legal protection, and I therefore agree with the rapporteur that the European Commission should propose an instrument for their protection at European level.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Hungary agriculture and the food industry are of particular importance in their economies. The same can be said of wine production closely linked to these industries, but the country boasts a number of traditionally high-quality products in addition to agricultural land. Designations such as Szeged peppers, Gyula sausages, macaque onions, Tokaj wine or Eger bull's blood, which are recognised on the international stage, not only contribute to the colouring of the image of the country of origin, but also, in addition to maintaining the quality requirements of the products, represent a significant added market value through protection in the form of collective entitlement. In general, the concept of geographical indications is used as a collective name for all the signs used in circulation to identify the geographical origin of products. Currently, at European level, the protection of origin provided by geographical indications covers only agricultural products which meet the conditions. This own-initiative report calls on the European Commission to also come forward with a legislative proposal for products that do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by their traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. With this report on the extension of geographical indications in the EU, in which I have personally participated as rapporteur of the PPE Group and which has been approved, it is intended that, like agricultural products of a clearly defined geographical origin and manufactured using traditional methods, they can benefit from the protection of the geographical indication throughout the EU , that same protection extends to the category of non-agricultural products, thereby laying down rules applicable throughout the European Single Market. Within the framework of the European Single Market, national laws in this area need to be harmonised. It is also necessary for public administrations to protect traditional products in order to combat fraud of these products, and also to incorporate a management, inspection, infringement and sanction regime to control geographical indications in products marketed in Europe. This boost to geographical indications is key because it can bring significant benefits to the consumer and also to companies that produce these non-agricultural products and are generally SMEs.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Commission's Green Paper entitled 'Making the most of Europe's traditional know-how: a possible extension of the protection of geographical indications from the European Union to non-agricultural products' is followed by this own-initiative report. At present, at European level, geographical indications are provided only for wines, alcoholic beverages and agricultural and food products. They form part of the Union's cultural heritage and define the typical features of European regions.  The report welcomes the extension of GI to non-agricultural or food products and calls for the creation of a single eu-wide protection system to deal with distortions in the single market created by an excessive fragmentation of GI protection rules in the various Member States. This undoubtedly helps SMEs, craftsmen and, above all, consumers, who should be able to make a choice on the basis of clear and precise information. I voted in favour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider that traditions reinforce our roots and promote development. Portugal is very rich in handicrafts, embroidery and ceramics. These products should benefit from a European system for the protection of geographical indications. In this way, we protect the production method, tie the product to the site, preserve knowledge and jobs and give reliable information to the consumer. This legislation should promote innovation in traditional production processes and the creation of new companies, as has happened in Portugal and, above all, in Minho, as evidenced by the scarves of lovers of Vila Verde and the initiative Namorar Portugal. It should be noted that micro-enterprises and small businesses account for around 80% of typical local products. Viana embroidery, Guimarães embroidery and The Vinhais Mask are examples of products that can benefit from the legislation I defend. I therefore agree that the new rules could promote innovation in traditional production processes and the creation of new companies in the traditional products sector, also contributing to the sustainability of jobs.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better protection of the original appeals.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a 5 Star Movement we are in favour of the protection of non-agricultural geographical indications. We are convinced that this is an indispensable tool for enhancing and protecting typical local production, crafts, small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers. Europe has always been characterised by the fact that each region can boast peculiar productions of excellence, not only in the agricultural sector. These excellences are not only important from a cultural point of view, but have historically generated wealth and can, if well protected, become, even more than before, an opportunity for sustainable development for our territories. The instrument we are calling for to be introduced into EU legislation could also help to put a stop to the consumer type-approval imposed by large distribution chains in non-food sectors as well. For these reasons, I declare my vote in favour of the resolution on the possible extension of the protection of geographical indications from the European Union to non-agricultural products, in the hope that the Commission will take up the European Parliament's request and draw up a legislative proposal as soon as possible.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mrs Roziere's report because I believe that we need an instrument for protecting and enhancing high-quality EU products, ensuring greater product safety and, at the same time, more effective protection for consumers.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe geographical indication works well in the food sector and should be extended to other areas.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications play a key role in the European Union's trade policy. If the European Union were to adopt legislation on non-agricultural GIs, the positive economic effects of protecting the specific character and quality of these products could be exploited, it could improve consumer awareness and encourage innovation in traditional production practices and the sustainability of jobs created in poorly developed areas. Industrial and craft products linked to their place of origin or linked to a particular area are of key importance for the economy and society in many European regions by supporting activities that cannot be relocated elsewhere and are directly linked to the local way of life, especially in rural areas. Legislation on non-agricultural geographical indications could effectively help to combat counterfeiting, fraudulent use of geographical origin names and other unfair practices that are misleading to the final consumer and harmful, in particular, to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the initiative calling on the Commission to prepare a proposal extending the system of quality certification to non-agricultural EU artisanal and traditional products.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I support, and vote in favour of, the report on the possible extension of EU geographical indication protection to non-agricultural products. Geographical indications are a guarantee for consumers mainly for product quality and legitimate competition on the market.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is very important for the Commission to come up with a Proposal for a unified system of geographical indication protection of non-agricultural products, proposing a system which would permit co-existence of already established rights but with the possibility of European-wide registration and uniform protection and guarantees. This system of protection by geographical indications would have very positive effects on traditional arts and crafts and would solve problems arising from the current fragmentation of legal protection. I strongly support the adoption of this report in this plenary session.  Creation of a system of protection of non-agricultural products is very much needed in this sector.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. At present, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another, and in some Member States the products of other Member States are not protected.  Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of an EU protection system based on geographical indications for non-agricultural products. Non-agricultural products are an important element of our cultural heritage and are an essential part of the economic and social life of many regions of Europe. It should be noted that the reputation of a geographical indication is a collective, intangible good, which, if not protected, can be used freely and without restrictions, leading to a decrease in value and even leading to the loss of the product itself. Similarly, it must be noted that harmonised European legislation in this area will always be beneficial for the European Union in international trade negotiations.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that diminish their added value, strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I particularly welcomed the launch of the public consultation on the possible extension of the legislation on geographical indications to non-agricultural products as well. The Green Paper, published by the Commission in July 2015, highlights the high and heated interest of Member States in ensuring that non-agricultural products, but the result of local tradition, culture and crafts, can also benefit from special evidence and regulation to ensure their peculiarities and exceptional ities. This is a wonderful opportunity to demonstrate how Europe can be a source of promotion, guarantee and enhancement of local products and territories, and how the Union's strength lies precisely in respecting and enhancing its diversity and uniqueness in order to relaunch economic development, attract curiosity and international tourism and offer ever greater guarantees to both producers and consumers. I therefore congratulate Mrs Roziere on the excellent synthesis work she has done in her report.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Rozière's report on the possible extension of the protection of geographical indications from the European Union to non-agricultural products because I consider this to be a useful vote for our country's business system and economy. The system of protection of geographical indications in agriculture has allowed the promotion of those products more closely linked to the territories, certifying their origin and quality. There is no doubt, in fact, that, just as the brand has allowed a formidable promotion, including tourism, of the places of production, becoming an opportunity for the growth of that culture of tourism that today is able to become a formidable attractor of visitors and travelers. I therefore believe that geographical indications are not only a guarantee of quality and origin in the internal market but also an important lever for the internationalisation of our production. The system of small craft enterprises will be able to take advantage of every useful opportunity offered by this important Initiative of the European Parliament, using the financial instruments for the promotion of its quality products abroad. I also believe that the expected results also go in the direction of expanding the number of workers employed in the sector: this is a further opportunity for the economic growth of the territories.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products, as the EU food labels have proved their worth and are protecting regional smes in particular. I also know many products from my home region of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania beyond the food that deserves this protection.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The creation of EU protection in the form of geographical indications for non-agricultural products appears to be a necessity, given that craftsmanship and craft production are also drivers of the Union's economic growth. As an integral part of our identity, they are an important part of the cultural heritage of individual Member States and guarantee the quality of traditional products.  Extending the protection of geographical indications will also have a positive impact on both producers and consumers, increasing their confidence in products by taking into account information on the quality, origin and methods and conditions of their production.  The introduction of such rules can stimulate innovation in traditional production processes and contribute to job creation in underdeveloped areas by providing small businesses and micro-enterprises with opportunities to increase sales through a more effective marketing strategy.  Furthermore, the introduction of geographical indications will contribute to combating the market for counterfeit products and the illegal use of geographical indication names and other illegal practices that mislead consumers and are harmful to traders.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Eu-wide protection of non-agricultural indications of origin does not only benefit businesses at local level. It also provides consumers with reasonable guarantees that the product actually originates from the indicated place of origin and has certain quality characteristics. It is estimated that international demand for non-agricultural products can be increased by up to 25% through comprehensive protection of geographical indications. We must combat counterfeiting and other unfair practices. I therefore voted in favour of uniform European legislation on Tuesday.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this initiative, which calls on the European Commission to implement a European system for protecting local know-how by creating geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  Such protection would not only allow local crafts to be recognized and given greater visibility by recalling the link between production and territory, but also protect these traditions from imitations and counterfeiting.  The report also reiterates the importance of preserving the traditional skills and know-how that contribute to the attractiveness of the territories and their cultural influence.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on protected geographical indications concerns non-agricultural products, such as Laguiole knives, Calais lace, etc. These indications value traditional and local know-how, offering the consumer quality guarantees. At present, these indications exist but, as the report states, they are fragmented: "some Member States offer no specific protection, others have instituted different definitions, procedures and different levels of protection [...]".  It is therefore necessary to remain vigilant about the real intentions of the promoters of this report who, when they refer to the current system, accuse it of distorting and hindering the "unified development of the common market". All the more so since the report put to the vote calls on the Commission to present a single system of protection of these geographical indications, accompanied by a single European register, which could, in the long run, mean that states cannot create new non-agricultural geographical indications without the assent of the European Union. In the end, we will judge the tree to its fruit: either the Commission will develop these geographical indications to protect jobs in Europe, or it will sacrifice to American requirements, under the transatlantic treaty, and it will limit this protection.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for Mrs Rozière's report. It is not perfect, but its objective is laudable: to defend and promote traditional and artisanal products and know-how, to avoid counterfeits, embezzlement of notoriety, misuse, even confiscations of names by the deposit of trademarks, such as Laguiole, for example, and its famous cutlery have been victims. Two points, however, since we talk about the importance for the consumer to be certain of the origin of the products he buys and the role that this origin can play in his choices. In international trade, the protection proposed by the Rozière report, similar to that enjoyed by food products, is necessary, but far from sufficient. There are no longer any transatlantic disputes on this issue, and the free trade agreements, namely CETA, with Canada, and the future TTIP, with the United States, are extremely worrying. Secondly, it is very regrettable that the original marking is not mandatory on all products, especially imported ones. The Commission has withdrawn its legislative project under pressure from certain states such as Germany, which wants to continue to claim to produce things that it merely assembles, including cars, and to misrepresent its reputation.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the possible extension of the protection of EUROPEAN geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This type of indication has historically existed for agricultural products, thus trying to satisfy the protection of products of priority interest to the primary sectors of the respective countries. The extension to other types of products is interesting, starting in addition to the experience gained in agricultural products. We still understand that this requires detailed analysis of each sector for which geographical indications could be created.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party I voted in favour of this report as it will protect both industries producing authentic local goods and consumers. It will make it harder for factories to pass off cheap knock-offs in the place of much-loved originals. Great British products like traditional Cumberland Sausages and Beacon Fell traditional Lancashire cheese are already protected under a geographical protection scheme and this Report would seek to extend protection like this to non-agricultural products. This means Scottish tartan, West Midlands ceramics and Clipsham limestone would be able to apply for similar geographical protection which would then be recognised across the EU.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday 6 October, MEPs adopted the report on the possible extension of protected geographical indications (PGI) to non-agricultural products. Many European and French products could be affected by this European scheme, for example the "Menton lemon" or "Marseille soap". An extension of geographical indications to non-agricultural products would represent a real economic and cultural opportunity in Europe, as well as a recognition of the know-how of our regions. Direct and indirect employment in the non-agricultural geographical indications sector accounts for more than 4 million jobs in Europe and, in 2010, the estimated value of sales for EU geographical indications was EUR 54.3 billion, of which EUR 11.5 billion was export sales.  It is therefore more than necessary to put in place at European level a protection of geographical indications that would not only protect our companies from counterfeiting and unfair competition, but also to be able to guarantee consumers the preservation of traditional know-how, the manufacture of quality products and better protection of their cultural heritage.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. At present, there is no EU-wide system for protecting geographical indications for industrial and artisanal products. Products such as Laguiole knives, Aubusson tapestry or Limoges porcelain, to name but a few examples in France, are currently protected in only half of the EU countries.  It is therefore urgent that the EU has a real system of protection of know-how. This system will benefit consumers and manufacturers as well as regions.  That is why I supported the report of my colleague Virginie Rozière. In particular, the report calls for the adoption of a unified system for protecting non-agricultural geographical indications, including a European-recognised registration system. The challenge is simple: it is not only a question of preserving and valuing European heritage, but also of making a significant contribution to employment and growth in Europe by preventing the relocation of these productions.  It is now up to the European Commission to take up this issue and propose as soon as possible European legislation that will finally allow! To ensure the protection of products that have the characteristics of a place or region.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because a single system would exploit the positive economic effects of protecting the distinctiveness and quality of such products, providing consumers with reliable information on their place and method of production and helping to combat counterfeiting. Furthermore, extending the scope of the geographical indications (GIs) protection system to cover non-agricultural products could help make the EU’s position on GIs even stronger and more cogent both in bilateral trade negotiations and multilateral forums; the ultimate aim being to provide a high level of protection for all high-quality European products outside the EU. A geographical indication protection system would help European trade and make EU businesses become even more competitive on a global scale.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At European level, at present, the protection of origin covers only agricultural products which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. Under the rules in force, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another. In some EU countries, products from other Member States are not protected.  This report was made following research on the subject and consultation with stakeholders. The document also asks the Commission to initiate the protection of products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products but are part of the European cultural heritage due to their traditional production. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We all appreciate that when you buy a glass of Champagne, you expect it to come from that region. Agricultural products in the EU are given this protection yet this is not currently the case for non-agricultural products like Scottish tartan or Staffordshire pottery. I voted for this report, along with my Socialist colleagues, to send a strong message to the Commission that it should put forward legislation to correct this anomaly. This would be a real step forward for consumers, manufacturers and local regions. Crucially, it will help protect local jobs and could boost tourism.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the establishment of a European legal framework for the protection of non-agricultural products in order to better recognise and value the quality and origin of these products. It is true that the lack of harmonised regulation at EU level severely weakens local production, which is competing with poor quality imitation and counterfeit products. I have very concrete examples in my region of products of excellence threatened by competition from counterfeit products. I'm thinking in particular of the Laguiole knives. In my opinion, the protection of our local traditions and know-how is a European imperative, because this culture of excellence contributes to the influence of French and European culture in the world. I am therefore convinced that labeling non-agricultural products as we already do for agricultural production will preserve many activities and revive the local economy in our regions.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The various pieces of EU legislation which protect geographical indications for food and drink have been a huge success story.  Whilst the EU often tends towards harmonisation, geographical indications do the opposite and help protect Europe's cultural variety and diversity.  The possibilities of extending GIs to non-agricultural products are exciting and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the possible extension of the protection of EUROPEAN geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This type of indication has historically existed for agricultural products, thus trying to satisfy the protection of products of priority interest to the primary sectors of the respective countries. The extension to other types of products is interesting, starting in addition to the experience gained in agricultural products. We still understand that this requires detailed analysis of each sector for which geographical indications could be created.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims to put pressure on the European Commission to come up with a proposal for a unified system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, based on the one already existing for agricultural products. The report proposes a system that would allow the co-existence of already established rights and offers the possibility of European registration and uniform protection and guarantees. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the possible extension of the protection of the Geographical Indication of the European Union to non-financial products, as there are many traditional European high-quality products based on traditional knowledge and techniques, and represent part of the EU's cultural heritage and part of the economic and social life of many European regions. In particular, such products are directly linked to local lifestyles in rural areas, and contribute to increasing the overall attractiveness of certain areas, safeguarding local identities and promoting their specifics. Such production has positive effects on tourism, culture and trade.  I support the Commission's initiative to examine the possibility of introducing a European protection instrument as part of a broader strategy to promote high-quality EU products. As in the case of agricultural and food products, the new system should be a guarantee of authenticity and origin with a clear link to geographical origin.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to extend protection to non-agricultural products, including certain French products.  Through a protected geographical indication, the producer can have know-how recognized and offer quality products to consumers. In France, it is estimated that this geographical indication will lead to an increase in demand for products in certain sectors. As it is a question of protecting the 'made in France', I voted for this report.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Geographical indications (GIs) is a sign used to help consumer identify food products whose qualities or reputation are recognised as unique to their particular country, region or town of origin. This indication allows the Czech Republic to protect its well-known beers, wines and liqueurs, for example. The registered products then receive an EU high level of recognition and protection.  Regional artisanal products however, are not covered by the European GI system. The manufacturers thus have to register them in each member states, and adapt to very different national registration procedures. I see the extension of the system to non-agricultural products as logical next step as it will protect manufacturers from unfair competition, boost local production while providing consumers with better information about the origin of the artisanal products they buy.  For these reasons, I decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Virginie Rozière's report on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products.  While today the name "camembert" is subject to legal protection, non-food products such as Laguiole knives, for example, do not benefit, allowing any company to use Laguiole's reputation for quality and reliability to produce lower quality knives by passing them as Laguiole knives.  The text calls on the Commission to adopt a legislative proposal to protect non-agricultural products, so that European consumers can be assured of the authenticity and quality of the protected products they buy. The extension of this protection will also strengthen the EU's negotiating position in its trade negotiations with third countries. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because traditional European products are important elements in preserving economic and social life in many parts of Europe.  Indicating the geographical origin of these products will support the local economy, protect know-how in a uniform manner in the EU and provide reliable guidance to consumers as to where and how they are produced.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Committee on Legal Affairs in the European Parliament has recognised that we should introduce rules governing the affixing of geographical indications also to non-agricultural products. Under such a system, consumers would have access to information on the origin of a product, which would make it easy to identify and make a more informed decision to purchase it. Linking the purchased product to a specific region would facilitate the assessment of its quality, production standards and the origin of its ingredients or components. In addition, support for local products leads directly to the flourishing of the local economy, the preservation of traditional production methods, the protection of culture and the development of tourism. It is also necessary to take care of copyright-regulating instruments that protect the market from counterfeiting.  If we create the right legal framework for such a system, we will indirectly support the development of entire regions where such goods are produced, and let us not forget that very often these are rural areas. By supporting local production, not only agricultural production, we will also support the local community.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The protection of geographical indications is a mainstay in the area of the quality characteristics of European products. I am therefore in favour of extending this protection and am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the resolution on the possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products. For the time being, a common system for the protection of geographical indications at EU level is intended only for agricultural products based on traditional recipes and knowledge, but there are many other products whose production is based on specific regional knowledge and popular recipes. This resolution calls for a common framework in the European Union to present geographical location for products of regional and local importance, thus both preserving and promoting local skills and promoting trade. The geographical location should be indicated on the product with a view to demonstrating its quality and linking to a specific area, which could also contribute to tourism. The establishment of such a common framework could have great economic potential and it is important that the application procedure for EU-level geographical protection is as simple and costly as possible.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report calling to extend geographical protection for authentic, original regional products. This is good news for consumers and industries that are producing authentic local goods, and will make it harder for factories half way round the world to pass off cheap knock offs as originals.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The aim of this report is to centralise control and, in my view, to restrict the trade of similar products which is harmful to competition. However, the nation states or regional actors are best placed to determine their own needs. In addition, competition must be protected and goods that are modelled on a protected product and clearly marked as similar must not be excluded from competition. That is why I cannot agree.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. At present, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another, and in some Member States the products of other Member States are not protected.  Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The proposal for a resolution helps to preserve the european Union's evolving values and valuable expertise, which is a significant part of Europe's historical, cultural, economic and social heritage, and I was happy to vote for it. Extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products in the European Union would support and facilitate the protection of European craft products resulting from traditional knowledge and skills. The designation of origin would facilitate better access to the EU's common market and markets outside the EU, contributing to the development of social and territorial communities and rural areas.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. – The extension of unitary geographical indication (GI) protection to non-agricultural products at EU level is another step towards an even more unified single market. I voted in favour of this report as a GI protection system would be beneficial in economic, social and cultural terms. The Commission estimates that there are around 4 million jobs directly and indirectly employed in these sectors and that two-thirds of the regions producing non-agricultural geographical indication products have a poverty rate or an unemployment rate above 20 percent. As the local products that may be subject to such protection are usually based on the activities of small and medium enterprises (SMEs), the extension of GIs would enhance the competitiveness of SMEs in particular and would stimulate the grow of local industries. What is more, such local industries are very important sources of established yet vibrant cultural and social heritage, which further highlights the authenticity of European products and thus makes them even more attractive and competitive.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the ROZIÈRE report on a possible extension of the European Union's protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products. We call on the European Commission to propose a legislative instrument in favour of the protection of references at the place of origin of our handicrafts.  As a member of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I have contributed to the drafting of this report through my amendments, because I believe that the protection of European know-how against unfair competition and counterfeiting is essential to ensure the quality and safety of products for consumers, while promoting the image of our European products internationally.  As far as the Ile-de-France is concerned, this could be the case, for example, of the porcelain and crystals of Sèvres, the silverware of Paris or the tile of Provins.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This extension has the merit of extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products, such as Calais lace for example.  A PGI, which refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how, allows the producer to showcase its products and offers the consumer quality guarantees. In France, in some sectors, the potential increase in international demand resulting from the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products has been estimated at 25%. It is therefore a question of protecting and promoting the "made in France".  This report is therefore generally positive, even if some of its passages are unsatisfactory: the definition of the PGI is relatively vague, and the mandatory registration process is quite mysterious at this stage.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it has the merit of extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products, such as Laguiole knives or Calais lace, among others. A PGI is a name or symbol that refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how. It allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer guarantees of quality. The aim here is to protect the "made in France". This report is therefore generally positive, even if some of its passages are unsatisfactory (fuzzy definition of non-agricultural PGI and mandatory registration process quite mysterious at this stage).

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This text defends the "Made in France" by protecting well-known and well-known know-how, such as Limoges porcelain or Laguiole cutlery.  More generally, the extension of PGIs (protected geographical indications) is part of an approach to the singdge of local crafts and highlights the peculiarities of the various States of the European Union, including France. So I logically voted for this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. With this report, Parliament urges the Commission to develop a unified system of protected geographical indications for Non-Agricultural European products, on the basis of the existing system for agri-food products. The proposed system would maintain already recognised rights, to which it would add the creation of a register and guarantee mechanisms at European level. From the S&D Group we believe that this system would benefit both European producers, who would obtain a certification of the provenance and quality of their goods, as well as consumers, who would have more information and guarantees about the products. For these reasons, we voted in favour.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
