text: Writing. The aim of this report is to centralise control and, in my view, to restrict the trade of similar products which is harmful to competition. However, the nation states or regional actors are best placed to determine their own needs. In addition, competition must be protected and goods that are modelled on a protected product and clearly marked as similar must not be excluded from competition. That is why I cannot agree.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The labelling of agricultural products and foodstuffs is subject to common European rules. The European Union shall allow for additional, supranational guarantee and protection of geographical indications, designations of origin for agricultural products and traditional specialities guaranteed. Examples of wines, cheeses or different meat products protected at European level are already known to the European consumer, who is increasingly looking for goods of guaranteed origin. Bulgarian manufacturers are also interested in the European protection system, as evidenced by the registrations of several products already. However, the current European legal framework does not provide for this possibility for non-agricultural products. This was identified as a gap for Europe, known for its high-quality craft products. The local craft production is a testament to the uniqueness of each European region and is an integral part of our cultural heritage. The resolution adopted by an overwhelming majority of Parliament calls on the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to establish a European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. I welcome good European ideas like this. The need for a new impetus in the development of traditional production methods and craft training is palpable. I hope that this European initiative will contribute to the preservation of the traditional craft sector and work for its recognizable place on the European and international market.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications have advantages and economic potential for products, which is multiplied by the provision of legislative protection. EU legislation makes it possible to grant agricultural products of particular geographical origin, which have certain characteristics or are produced according to traditional methods, europe-wide uniform protection of geographical indications. However, non-agricultural producers who decided to protect the geographical indication of their products throughout the EU had to ensure separate protection in each Member State. In line with the objectives of the internal market, the European Commission has identified this problem and carried out an analysis of the existing legal framework for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Member States. The analysis showed that the existing legal instruments available to producers of non-agricultural products at national and European level are insufficient. With the proposal on the table, we are opening up space for a substantive and legislative solution for the protection of geographical indications also for non-agricultural products.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the possible extension of EU geographical indication protection to non-agricultural products; for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 5/10/2015, and why a number of traditional products based on know-how and traditional techniques form part of the European Union's cultural heritage, contribute to the strengthening of the local economy and support the employment and activity of small and medium-sized enterprises. Measures must therefore be taken to protect non-agricultural products from unfair competition in order to preserve traditional skills and the reputation of a geographical indication which is an intangible collective good.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Even if some passages remain unclear, the whole is very satisfactory: it will allow to attribute the protected geographical indication (PGI) to non-agricultural products, such as laguiole knives or Lace from Calais. This extension will protect the "Made in France", a symbol for consumers of traditional know-how and a guarantee of quality.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The campaign to extend GI protection to non-agricultural products will make it harder for factories half way round the world to trade on the value and reputation of great Scottish products like Scottish tartan or Harris Tweed. I want to see these products being able to apply for the same geographical protection as Stornoway Black Pudding and Arbroath Smokies. The European system for GIs on agricultural products has brought tangible benefits for Scottish producers and a quality guarantee for consumers. These are measures where the strength of the EU can give robust protection for authentic and traditional Scottish products abroad, boost production and protect Scottish jobs. It would also enable the EU to enjoy the same protection for such products outside the EU in the framework of international trade negotiations. It is now for the European Commission to take up the case, and I hope it will make the proposals soon.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's initiative to extend the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products. The importance of geographical indications is certainly a good tool for improving traceability, transparency and information for consumers and, in particular, an effective tool for combating imitations and counterfeit products, increasing consumer protection.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indication refers to goods originating in a country, region or place in which the quality, reputation or other characteristic of a product is associated with its geographical origin. Examples are Bordeaux wine, Murano glass or Parma ham. Agricultural products of specific geographical origin, such as cheese, wine, meat, fruit and vegetables, which have certain characteristics or are produced by traditional practices, may be granted eu-wide protection of geographical indications such as Parmesan cheese. Non-agricultural products such as ceramics, marble, cutting shoes, footwear, tapestries or musical instruments are not yet granted uniform protection in the form of geographical indications at EU level beyond national legislation. Because I believe that the EU can boast of its wealth and non-agricultural products, be it Czech crystal or Karar marble, and that our unique and diverse heritage must be protected, I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called. IG (geographical indications) have the function of assigning and ensuring the geographical derivation of a given product, in order to guarantee the quality of the same. If a European system for geographical indication of origin has been set up for agricultural products, this does not apply to non-agricultural products. The absence at European level of a uniform and effective system for protecting and protecting the origin of products is increasingly leading to forms of indiscriminate counterfeiting and unfair competition.  Several studies have shown that setting up a system for the geographical indication of non-agricultural products would be beneficial socially and culturally, leading to an increase in employment, an increase in tourism and an increase in exports to third countries. For all these reasons, I have decided to welcome this report, which proposes extending the protection of geographical indications in the European Union to non-agricultural products as well.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today decided to vote in favour of the initiative calling on the Commission to formulate a proposal extending the 'system' of quality certification to non-AGRICULTURAL EU artisanal and traditional products. It is in fact an important link between Italian history and European manufacturing production. So this form of protection, through geographical indication, gives our small and medium-sized enterprises the power of competition they need at the level of the global market, which they would otherwise not be able to cope with. The protection of GIs, in fact, represents an innovative drive for the protection of product quality, while maintaining competitiveness.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted enthusiastically for my colleague Virginie Rozière's report, which calls on the European Parliament to increase the protection of geographical indications in the Union.  At present, while agricultural "GIs" (Champagne wine, Agen prunes, etc.) are widely protected, the same is not true for non-agricultural products such as Laguiole knives or Marseille soaps. The extension of GIs to more than 800 artisanal products , which Parliament, through the Rozière report, calls for - would have only benefits for both consumers and workers. Under this system, Europeans would have access to reliable information on products that are recognized as quality. In addition, the extension of GIs to manufactured products would have the effect of combating counterfeiting and combating related relocations.  At a time when some European countries, such as France, are trying to promote "terroir diplomacy" in their trade relations, Parliament's initiative is more than welcome. The aim now is to push the European Commission to propose a legislative initiative on non-agricultural PMIs. That is why I have co-signed a letter to Commissioner Katainen on this subject.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it will allow consumers to make more informed choices about where products come from and the methods of production used.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The reference to the geographical indication (GI) today protects agricultural products of a particular geographical origin that have specific qualities or are manufactured using traditional methods.  The report before us envisages extending this principle to non-agricultural products based on very high-level traditional techniques and crafts, which are an integral part of regional and local culture. Fifteen Member States (including France since June 2015) have adopted this system. Its application at European level would increase the protection against counterfeiting of Laguiole knives or Marseille soap and I welcome that.  Protecting the geographical indication of non-agricultural products is a tool for preserving cultural heritage and traditional know-how, and it guarantees fair remuneration to producers. It remains to be seen whether these PMIs will be respected in the context of the large transatlantic market. In the meantime, I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to extend protection to non-agricultural products, including certain French products. Through a protected geographical indication, the producer can have know-how recognized and offer quality products to consumers. In France, it is estimated that this geographical indication will lead to an increase in demand for products in certain sectors. As it is a question of protecting the 'made in France', I voted for this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the possible extension of the protection afforded by the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products. It is essential that the quality of traditional European products is maintained and preserved. This proposal improves the fight against fraud by helping to abolish fraud and, above all, to avoid unfair competition that misleads consumers. Non-agricultural products are part of our history, our identity and are also the cultural heritage of the Member States.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which asks the Commission for a legislative proposal to extend the geographic protection to non-agricultural products. Such an extension would create single European system of protection of geographical indications that would exploit the positive economic effects of protecting the distinctiveness and quality of traditional products, provide consumers with reliable information on their place and method of production and help combat counterfeiting.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support this report, which aims to strengthen trade at the local and regional level.  Extending the protection of eu's geographical indications to non-agricultural products is an essential step for local producers. It helps to increase the overall attractiveness of a territory, to preserve local identities and to promote their peculiarities. It is in the EU's interest to adopt such legislation to protect the know-how and jobs they generate, and to make the most of the positive economic benefits.  In addition, the geographical indication of the products allows consumers to be fully informed of the origin of the product and thus to be better able to choose knowingly.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 After the labelling of products by place of origin has proved its worth in food, I welcome the report on the possible extension of the protection of european Union geographical indications to non-agricultural products. As the EU is particularly rich in such authentic products, which are based on local know-how and traditional local production methods often rooted in the cultural, social and historical heritage of a given geographical location, this will also contribute to their preservation for the future. Geographical indications of a product also have the potential to contribute to highlighting the relationship between human activity, culture, landscape and resources. In the case of Slovakia, it is possible to talk about Modran majonia majonia, levitic gold ion, salt-ban lace or Piešťany mud in this context. I believe that extending the protection of geographical indications of the European Union will also be a service to the consumer, as it is a way of increasing its confidence in products bearing the Union label. However, I join the call for the regulator to take into account geographical indications that already exist in the Member States in order to avoid unnecessary bureaucracy when registering them at European level.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this INI report, which aims to put pressure on the Commission to come up with a Proposal for a unified system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, based on the one already existing for agricultural products. I find it important that the report proposes a system that would allow the co-existence of already established rights, but offering the possibility of European-wide registration and uniform protection and guarantees.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 For agricultural products originating in a specific geographical area which have certain characteristics or are produced by traditional methods, uniform PROTECTION has long existed throughout the EU. In its Green Paper "Harnessing Europe's traditional expertise: possible extension of the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products", the Commission also examined the extension of such protection to non-agricultural products. As a result of the public consultation on the Green Paper, the proposal proposes that the EP take a position on the extension. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report aims to extend the protection of Protected Geographical Indications (PGI) to non-agricultural products.  In France, for example, this would give protection to property that refers to a geographical origin and traditional know-how. The most cited example is that of the knives of Laguiole. The PGI allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer quality guarantees. In practical terms, the IPG is a way of boosting the "made in France" commercially and securing it in the face of counterfeits. The text presented here is generally an improvement that deserves to be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union does not currently have a single system for the protection of geographical indications of non-agricultural products, unlike agricultural and food products. I believe that this gap provides an inappropriate European framework, as some Member States do not have specific protection and others have established different definitions, procedures and levels of protection under national and local standards. It is important that madeiran producers, regional associations and public authorities work together to preserve our culture and centuries-old traditions, including tapestry, Vimes or Madeira embroidery. It is an opportunity to modernize, internationalize and safeguard these products. I fully endorse this document because the protection of non-agricultural products given by geographical indications can highlight the CULTURAL HERITAGE of the EU, preserving the economy of many regions of Europe; support entrepreneurship at local and regional levels, fostering the maintenance of infrastructure and the creation of more skilled and territory-linked jobs; and will have positive effects for consumers, producers and the entire European economic and social fabric.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to apply the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products such as Laguiole knives or Calais lace, among others.  Protected geographical indication allows the protection of a name or symbol that refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how while offering guarantees to consumers on the quality of these products. These PGIs are crucial because they increase the international demand of recipient companies (according to some studies, by almost 25%!).  Considering that this is a way to protect the "Made in France", I decided to vote for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is an important step in seeing GI extended to non-agricultural products such as Scottish tartan, Harris tweed, London’s Saville Row bespoke tailoring, Stoke ceramics, Yorkshire stone will have the same GI protection as agriculture products like Melton Mowbray pies, Cornish pasties, Wensleydale cheese, Lincolnshire sausage, Arbroath smokies. This will protect, preserve and develop a positive future for these products and the highly skilled jobs that the industry offers. This is great news for consumers and for the protection of our industries that are producing authentic local goods, and will make it harder for factories to pass off cheap knock offs as originals.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The promotion and protection of European culture are central aspects in parliament's request to the Commission to submit a legislative proposal without delay with the aim of establishing a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. Protecting geographical indications means above all promoting a vision of Europe: our Union is much more than a trading platform, it is a place where beauty and quality are produced. Small businesses, responsible for about 80% of typical local products, are echoes of a history and culture, they represent europe's heritage, our heritage. Because, more than products, famous names such as Murano, Bohemia, Laguiole, Savile Row, Solingen, are the result of traditional knowledge and techniques. Non-agricultural products generate activities closely linked to local realities; they contribute to increasing the attractiveness of a territory, preserving local identities and promoting their distinctive character, with beneficial effects for tourism, culture, employment and trade. I enthusiastically support this resolution in the belief that the system of geographical indications can have many and varied positive effects for citizens, consumers, producers and the european economic and social fabric as a whole.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report, we intend to reaffirm the importance of geographical indications, in the wider context of intellectual property rights, as a tool to improve traceability, transparency and consumer information.  We are convinced that EU legislation for non-agricultural products would, in fact, make full use of the positive economic effects of protecting the distinctive character and quality of these products, while at the same time helping to preserve the cultural and artistic heritage of European local and regional traditions. We have an obligation to support micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and producers in combating imitations and counterfeit products, ensuring that they have a more socially, economically and environmentally sustainable approach to economic development within and outside the EU, as well as fair competition and consumer protection.  A system, however, which must be coherent, simple, transparent and not bureaucratically and financially burdensome for SMEs. We therefore call on the Commission to include a new, coherent and well-prepared strategy, with regard to all GIs, which will ensure that they are complied with and recognised, in the future communication on the European Union's trade and investment strategy.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, following consultation with interested parties, calls on the Commission to make a legislative proposal extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products, thus contributing to the creation of a single protection system for the whole of Europe. Considering that the absence of a uniform EU system of protection for geographical indications of non-agricultural products leads to an inadequate and particularly fragmented European framework, due to the fact that some Member States do not offer any specific protection while in others there are different definitions, procedures and levels of protection that hinder the harmonious development of the common market and an obstacle to consumer protection , I have chosen to vote in favour of the report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Europe is not exhausted in agricultural products when it comes to special traditional goods. One of the foundations of European diversity is the existence of various traditional, regional industries that contribute to our identity. I therefore welcome this report, which also aimed to extend the PROTECTION of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. European unikum products and their quality must be protected as effectively as possible, which they need, in particular, outside the EU's borders. In this way, consumers can avoid a number of counterfeits and frauds, and producers of products can also benefit from the quality certificate of the European geographical designation of origin. I trust that the European Commission will come up with a concrete legislative proposal on the subject as soon as possible.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will enable a EU geographical indication (GI) protection instrument at European level, as part of a broader strategy for promoting high-quality EU products, based on a stronger commitment from the EU institutions to treat manufacturing and craft industries as a driving force for growth and the completion of the single market, thus enhancing the prestige of locally based manufacturing and handicraft production, supporting local economic development and employment in the areas concerned, boosting tourism, and strengthening consumer confidence.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Within the European Union, there has already been a single support for EU agricultural specialities to be protected by geographical indications. This report now calls for EU-wide protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, such as Bohemian crystal glass. I voted in favour of this report because it is also a contribution to the fight against counterfeiting and other unfair practices.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The parliamentary resolution presented in this report proposes the creation of a geographical indication system for non-agricultural products. This system is already used for agricultural products (AOP and AOC) and its benefits have been widely seen.  Thus, the resolution proposes the establishment of a major European label, in the field of handicrafts among others, to protect and promote the know-how and authenticity of the products.  I am voting in favour of this resolution which offers a chance to promote the situation of European SMEs and to protect local products.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products has a positive impact on both consumers and producers and benefits tourism, culture, employment and trade.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to better protect traditional products and knowledge.  In particular, there is a need for a common protection at EU level for geographical indications. Geographical indications would help consumers to identify authentic products and to ensure that they comply with standards of origin and quality.   The protection of geographical indications in the European Union would enable consumers to recognise authentic, original products. It would be an effective tool in the EU single market to prevent abuses.  It should be noted that the protection of such products is currently insufficient and their economic potential is not being exploited.  It should be noted that the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products would contribute to European growth and job creation.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I supported the relevant resolution to extend the protection and registration of geographical indications to non-agricultural products, i.e. protection including local goods and handicrafts based on traditional know-how. I consider it necessary to promote this resolution and to adopt immediately relevant legislation which will establish a framework of protection which will make it compulsory to display geographical indications on local goods and handicrafts, such as Lefkaritika Embroidery in the case of my country of Cyprus. The above indicative registration of local goods will certainly lead to the extension of this protection to other local products and will contribute to the re-emergence of crafts and enterprises whose involvement will further stimulate the economy of our local communities, with beneficial effects and the preservation of our common cultural heritage. Of course, the need for proper consumer information and the fight against unfair and speculative commercial practices which have found a ground for existence, as well as the european protection gap in our local products, must not be overlooked.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the manufacturing and craft sector is a key axis of the European economy and given the current legislative imbalance between PGI products and non-agricultural products, I consider it important, also in order to protect national territorial realities, the establishment of a PGI mark also for non-agricultural products. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I support the geographical indications for agricultural products I see possible positive outcomes for the European economy. As one of the youngest members in Parliament, but also as person who respects traditions, I believe that the combination between innovative ideas and the experience of production will lead to an economic success. Currently, national laws are fragmented and offer different levels of protection within national and local transversal rules, but we must avoid such fragmentation as it undermines the European single market.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the possibility of extending the protection of the geographical indications of the European Union to non-agricultural products, as I believe that geographical indication also benefits when it is used in other things, such as the labelling of different processes and techniques for the manufacture of hand-made products and the labelling of different non-agricultural products. The geographical indication represents the visibility and quality of the product or craft and contributes to the positive economic effects of the local economy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Croatia has many traditional products and they represent the peculiarity and heritage of our people and therefore deserve to be protected. Such a product is lace, special not only because of its beauty, but also because of the effort that generations of our grandmothers put into making it. Croatian lace was protected by UNESCO, and lepoglava, Pag and Hvar are especially proud of it.  The hardworking hands of Slavonian women make the most beautiful gold embroidery I have ever seen, and the Međimurje basket made of whips, or a laptop bag made of corn commodity, is a real hit. Brač stone is embedded in the most important cultural goods of Croatia and still enjoys a special status in the production of used objects. Handmade wooden toys, characteristic for Croatian Zagorje moms smile on the face of each child. Petrinjska stucka is not only special because of its appearance, but also because it is made by the last Petrinja potter.  I therefore support the European Parliament's resolution on the possible extension of the protection of the GEOGRAPHICAL INDICATION of the European Union to non-agricultural products, as they are products that represent our tradition and the value we need to protect, for the sake of our history and for our future. Because of history, so we don't forget them and for the future, so we don't destroy them.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to apply the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products such as Laguiole knives or Calais lace, among others. Protected geographical indication protects a name or symbol that refers to the geographic origin of a product and traditional know-how while providing consumers with guarantees about the quality of these products. These PGIs are crucial because they increase the international demand of recipient companies (according to some studies, by almost 25%!). Considering that this is a way to protect the "Made in France", I decided to vote for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Extending the geographical indication to non-valuable products such as Pag lace and Brač stone will increase their recognition and value on the market, and therefore sales. It will also allow for more transparent information to consumers about the quality of the products they buy, which is why I fully support this proposal. I hope that the Commission will use it as a starting point and present this proposal as soon as possible. Extending the geographical indication to traditional non-cultural products would allow authentic products that have existed in our culture for hundreds of years to be equally adequately protected at the EU level, just as krk prosciutto, Krk potatoes and Baranja kulen are for example. I am particularly pleased that the report adopted an amendment to ask that "negotiations on trade agreements also cover open lists of all products (agricultural and non-agricultural) protected by a geographical indication, so that Pag lace and Brac stone are part of future EU trade agreements with non-member countries. This amendment is particularly important for Croatian products, as, by including open lists, it also applies to products that are still in need of protection by geographical indication.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the report on the possible extension of the Eu GIs to non-financial products. Currently, only agricultural products of a given geographical origin with certain qualities or products made in accordance with traditional methods are subject at EU level to a single GI protection.  Extending the protection of geographical indications to non-financial products will have multiple positive effects. For consumers, it will mean providing reliable information about the location and method of production of a particular product. In addition, the extension of protection will contribute to the sustainability of small and medium-sized enterprises that are the backbone of the European Union economy and employ around 33 million people.  Manufacturers across the European Union have been building quality policies for their products for years. The designation of origin is one of the main factors that enables them to have a competitive advantage, significantly contributes to the preservation of their cultural and gastronomic traditions and supports rural development together with measures of market support and producer income. These companies often do not have sufficient financial resources to protect their products and therefore need protection at Union level that will ensure the promotion of high-quality EU products, both in the internal market and globally.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of GIs for non-agricultural products could be an important incentive at European level considering that geographical indications can have considerable economic potential, especially for SMEs and peripheral regions of the EU. In addition, such protection would help the public authority to combat counterfeiting to protect the consumer and to help improve the traceability of products. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of approving this initiative and I hope that the effects of the new system on producers, their competitors, consumers and Member States will be fully taken into account in the continuation of Community action.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, we voted on a text calling for the protection and promotion of our local know-how and crafts by applying a geographical indication, much like PDOs and PGIs.  I welcome this, especially as I am fighting precisely because our region, our Eurocirconscription is rich in ancestral know-how. For example, I went to Laguiole last year. I met the leaders and the ironworkers there. I had already mentioned this idea of IG for crafts, even before Parliament took up this issue!  These GIs are still reserved for agricultural products and I hope that the Commission will quickly propose a GI for our crafts. First of all to avoid fraud, but above all to make our know-how known and recognized all over the world.  I am particularly sensitive to this issue, as 80% of the companies involved are SMEs. They perpetuate techniques that make their city and region famous.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as European consumers are increasingly interested in product safety, product origin, their authenticity and their production methods, and not just agricultural products. I believe that the measure to give European citizens the right and the opportunity to identify the origin and quality of any product are justified. Because we are facing important trade negotiations with the United States of America, and the national laws in force protecting non-agricultural products establish different levels of protection in the Member States, I believe that it is indispensable to create a single system of protection throughout the European Union. The protection of geographical indications of non-agricultural products is important for consumers, but at the same time it can contribute to the preservation of Europe's local and regional traditions, values that are part of The European cultural and artistic heritage.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted this lunchtime in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission to extend the protection of geographical indications (GI) to non-agricultural products.  If the Commission responds to this request, more than 800 listed products, in particular Belgian local products, as varied as Belgian bluestone, Tournai carpets, Val Saint Lambert glass and crystal or Antwerp diamonds, would benefit from the geographical indication.  They would then share this quality label with emblematic agricultural products such as the brussels full-earth chicory, the gaumais pâté, the Ardennes ham or the Liège pékèt. In Europe, the regional products concerned would include porcelain, ceramics, ironwork, weaving and embroidery. All these activities put at the service of quality crafts that suffer from unfair and illegal competition from imitations and counterfeits.  The 15 existing national GI laws are not enough to protect this regional and local know-how. Hence the need to create a uniform system at European level. This registration mechanism, which MEPs call for, should be 'simple, useful, accessible' and should benefit producers and chambers of commerce in the first place.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution to extend the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products. I am in favour of a legislative proposal to establish a single European protection system, including a compulsory product registration process and a single European register of non-agricultural products that benefit from a protected geographical indication. However, I think it is important that this new system can co-exist with the rights already associated with the products.  These legislation on geographical indications would preserve and enhance traditional and quality know-how, thereby strengthening Europe's historical, cultural, economic and social heritage. It would also make it easier for consumers to choose the authenticity and quality of the product through reliable information on the location and method of production. These provisions would also have the advantage of encouraging innovation by supporting SMEs, combating imitation and counterfeiting, or encouraging fair competition.  Finally, this protection system would boost European exports and allow us to gain market share, while defending the products concerned within the framework of the common trade policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report provides that non-agricultural products (handicrafts, ceramics, embroidery) benefit from a European system for the protection of geographical indications. As with agri-food products, this system must be noticeable in the eyes of the consumer and guarantee confidence in terms of quality, authenticity and transparency. It seems to me to be advantageous, especially with regard to the protection of micro and small enterprises (responsible for about 80% of the production of these products). This legislation can also help to effectively combat the fraudulent misuse and use of geographical indications, misleading practices of the final consumer and harmful to producers who, for the most part, still do not have the legal or financial means to defend their interests.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The text of the resolution passed today urges the European Commission to present an initiative that extends the protection of geographical indications at European level beyond what has already been done since 1992 for agricultural products, to include regionally and locally produced goods and handicrafts (such as Belgian blue stone or Val Saint-Lambert glass). I welcome this, because such a decision would support local economic development, boost tourism, strengthen consumer confidence and help preserve cultural heritage and traditional know-how. The European Commission has already identified 800 products in Europe that could benefit from such protection. For the European Parliament, this list could be revised upwards. Moreover, the products concerned should be able to be easily registered and included in a public register.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The current geographical protection of agricultural product names enables the culture and culinary heritage of a particular country to be preserved over the centuries. However, as we know, heritage is not only food, but also various crafts. In Lithuania, there is not yet a visible abuse of geographical indications in the field of non-agricultural, although in my country there are unique articles, such as musical instruments, which have clear geographical indications. However, where there is at least a theoretical possibility of such abuse, preparations should be prepared in advance. It would be a pity if, let's say, the well-known bagpipe Labanoras bag in our country, with a clear geographical link to the area from which this musical instrument originates, starts to produce anything other than the original examples. This would undermine the name and authenticism of this article. I believe that there should be no difference between agricultural and non-agricultural products in the area of the protection of geographical indications. It will not be easy to regulate, but it would serve the protection of the cultural identity of each EU country, which is becoming very relevant in this increasingly globalised world.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution assumes extreme relevance and relevance by the opportunity to legislate on a possible extension of the protection afforded by EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products, including, inter alia, handicrafts, embroidery and ceramics.  Such a measure will have a very positive impact at local level by providing protection to the unique characteristics of these products and ensuring their quality (and traceability), providing consumers with reliable information on the place and method of production, promoting process innovation and the creation of new enterprises in the traditional products sector. It will also be able to boost tourism by ensuring the safeguarding and sustainability of jobs in areas where employment is scarce. Harmonised European legislation in this area, extended to non-agricultural products, will not only help combat contrapartation, but also strengthen the system for the protection of geographical indications in bilateral and multilateral trade negotiations.  I am pleased with the opportunity of this proposal, which makes a relevant contribution to the economic, social and territorial cohesion of the regions and to what is the European cultural heritage, with the ultimate goal of providing a high level of protection for all traditional European products, whether agricultural or not, outside the EU.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the possible extension of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. Many European and French products could be affected by this European device, including the Laguiole knife, the Calais lace or the Cherbourg umbrella. An extension of geographical indications to non-agricultural products would represent a real economic and cultural opportunity in Europe, as well as a recognition of know-how. Direct and indirect employment in the non-agricultural geographical indications sector accounts for more than 4 million jobs in Europe. There is an urgent need to put in place at European level a protection of geographical indications that would not only protect our companies from counterfeiting and unfair competition, but also to be able to guarantee consumers know-how and quality products. This European protection must be put in place by ensuring that the scheme is simple and inexpensive so that our businesses, and in particular our SMEs, can access it.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products, because I believe that the recognition of the origin and method of production of products are necessary tools to promote the creation of a single and efficient market. Consumer confidence is at the basis of the proper functioning of the market and it would increase through greater information and more careful traceability and transparency of the product. The protection of quality products both inside and outside the European Union must be guaranteed.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the possible extension of the protection of EUROPEAN geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This type of indication has historically existed for agricultural products, thus trying to satisfy the protection of products of priority interest to the primary sectors of the respective countries. The extension to other types of products is interesting, starting in addition to the experience gained in agricultural products. We still understand that this requires detailed analysis of each sector for which geographical indications could be created

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that the GI system for agricultural products has been revealed as a positive mechanism for protecting small local producers in certain nations and States currently belonging to the EU.  That is why I think it is positive to extend this system to products other than agricultural products taking into account the experience and lessons learned during this time with agricultural products.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Traditional European high-quality products are the result of traditional knowledge and techniques and represent an important cultural heritage of the European Union. In particular, non-agricultural products contribute to increasing the overall attractiveness of a territory, preserving local identities and promoting their distinctive character, with beneficial effects for tourism, culture, employment and trade. At present, there is provision at European level for uniform protection of GIs for wines, agricultural products and foodstuffs. However, there is no uniform harmonization or protection of GIs for non-agricultural products. On the contrary, national legal instruments apply, so that the level of legal protection varies from one Member State to another, leading to higher burdens for European producers. I therefore voted in favour of this report, in the hope that the Commission will present its legislative proposal as soon as possible within the framework of the European internal market strategy.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The system of geographical indications (IG) as a quality name can be an added value for products that meet the requirements for enjoying it. This added value can be reflected in consumer information and preference, both inside and outside the European Union, which is all the more relevant in a context of erosion of our trade borders and closer ties with other regional partners. Current experience with agricultural product Gi shows that there is widespread ignorance on the part of consumers about them, which can counteract the intended effect. It is important to take this experience into account, in matters where it is relevant, and from this to draw knowledge to possibly lay the foundations for a good strategy for non-agricultural products. This should be done in a cost-benefit logic, without losing sight of the desired objectives: strengthening the territorial role of European production, which in this case can only be achieved if this system has a clear impact from the point of view of consumer recognition and preference.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not believe this to be an EU competency.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to thank Ms Rozière for the excellent work that she has put into this report and I want to join her in pressuring the Commission to come up with a proposal for a unified system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. The Commission appears to be reluctant to make a proposal and I want to join other MEPs in sending an important signal from Parliament as to our position and hopefully get the Commission to take action.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In Slovakia, artisan products have a long tradition. Lace from Španá Dolina or Salt Blue lace from Prešov became known. We must protect their uniqueness, as well as our other products, through legal protection. I therefore voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament resolution on the possible extension of the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products, which offers the opportunity to further protect our heritage.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that the non-agricultural products sector can be considered a very important element of the cultural heritage of the EU Member States, but its serious shortcoming is that it has no uniform system for the protection of geographical indications. This shortage also often results in counterfeiting and fraudulent use of geographical origin names and unfair practices that are intruding on the final consumer and harmful, in particular, to micro-enterprises and SMEs. What worries me much more is that traditional skills and crafts, which have been rooted in cultural, social and historical heritage in many rural areas, are gradually disappearing. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that by extending geographical indications to non-agricultural products, we can stop the decline in traditional production, the depopulation and destruction of rural areas, as well as the outflow of young people leaving these areas. I believe that extending the protection of geographical indications will provide sufficient impetus to improve access to the common market and markets outside the EU. I expect that, in order to revitallach the traditional crafts sector, we will use interregional and transnational cooperation and, on the basis of good practice, encourage the development of rural areas.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the application of the geographical designation of origin should also be extended to non-agricultural products, as they also contribute to increasing the attractiveness of a region and preserving the uniqueness of local identities, thus having a positive impact from a touristic, cultural, employment and commercial point of view. It is very important that the Commission takes into account the needs of producers when designing the scheme: it does not undersk up excessive bureaucratic requirements and it also keep the costs of the procedure low. This is also important because we are essentially talking about small producers, small entrepreneurs, whose admistrative costs of a few hundred euros, especially in the new Member States of the European Union, are also a significant item. I would like to stress that, in relation to the brand name/logo, the text quite rightly refers to the 'language of origin', since it is the language of publicity in the region concerned, hence the traditional name of the product, which may prevail, and not the official language of the Member State concerned.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the non-binding resolution calling on the Commission to present a legislative proposal extending the EU system of protection of geographical indication (GIs) from agricultural products to locally produced goods and craft goods focused on traditional knowledge.  The introduction of an EU regime for the protection of GIs for typical local products would be an important step both for consumers, who are allowed to buy more consciously products that comply with certain production and quality rules, and for producers, who would be protected from unfair competition from counterfeit products, in support of the traditional and artisanal skills of the specific place that ensure the quality of typical products and the preservation of regional knowledge. I believe that, once introduced, this type of protection can offer great economic potential, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises and regions of the EU, and at the same time allow the Union to protect these products outside the EU, within the framework of international trade negotiations.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The aim of this report is to centralise control and, in my view, to restrict the trade of similar products which is harmful to competition. However, the nation states or regional actors are best placed to determine their own needs. In addition, competition must be protected and goods that are modelled on a protected product and clearly marked as similar must not be excluded from competition. That is why I cannot agree.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The consumer must be sure that the product he has purchased meets the required parameters. Labelling according to the place of origin has proven itself for food and extending it to other products would only strengthen the prestige of European products and would also help local producers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Report because traditional European high-quality products based on traditional knowledge and techniques form part of the EU's cultural heritage and as such are a key element to be preserved within the economic and social life of many regions of Europe.  Such products can contribute to the development of new strategies to support entrepreneurship at local and regional level. It is also possible to create new jobs for skilled workers closely related to certain fields, giving a new impetus to professional and craft training. Geographical indications can have great economic potential and can benefit SMEs and EU regions through their protection.  Consumers' growing interest in the origin, authenticity and production methods requires information from manufacturers and product labelling allows consumers to make informed decisions established on the origin and quality of products when purchasing products. Uniform European legislation in this area would benefit the European Union in international trade negotiations, and I therefore support the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report, urging the Commission to come up with a Proposal for a unified system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, similar to the one already existing for agricultural products. I am firmly in favour of the proposed system of European-wide registration and uniform protection and guarantees.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Protected Geographical Indication (GIs) Programme, in addition to protected designation of origin programmes and traditional specialties guaranteed, represents the European Union's efforts to promote and protect the quality of agricultural goods and food products. These programs encourage the diversity of agricultural production, protect product names from abuse, and inform consumers about the products they use. Extending the OZP to non-agricultural products would cover a wide range of authentic products derived from local traditions and skills abounding in the European Union, which are an integral part of the EU's regional and local culture. Enlargement has significant economic potential in terms of developing tourism as well as creating jobs. I fully support this proposal because I believe it will ensure, not only the protection of the Union's cultural heritage, but also the quality of products placed on the EU market, and will help stop the emigration of younger people from rural areas, as projections suggest that more than four million jobs would be created.  One of the products that has not yet been mentioned in the framework of intangible heritage is certainly konavo embroidery, and during the discussion I took the opportunity to inaugurate it as an authentic Croatian product that should be included in the list of non-agricultural products whose geographical origin should be protected.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. If someone wants to protect a particular production process or technology, they can use a patent or trademark to do so. However, the possibility to produce a given product should not be limited to a specific geographical location. Whether someone buys a product that does not originate in their original region should depend solely on the customer's decision.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the possibility of extending the Geographical Indications of the European Union to agricultural products. The EU geographical indication for agricultural products has proved very good, and we must now extend it to non-agricultural products. In addition to creating 4 million new jobs through this move, strengthening prosperity and growth and strengthening the position of small and medium-sized enterprises, we will make sure that we preserve our cultural heritage, product authenticity and traditional knowledge. At the same time, we will ensure fair payment to producers for their originality and as much as possible. The European Commission should present as soon as possible legislation to effectively protect EU geographical indications for non-agricultural products, which will also ensure the visibility of our products in the world.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's report from the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI), which proposes extending EU protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products. There is currently an EU regulation on the protection of geographical indications for agricultural products which are of specific quality and are produced in a certain established way in well-defined regions. I believe that it is appropriate that a similar EU arrangement should also exist for non-agricultural products, of which countless member states can certainly offer, and the protection of their designation by a single EU regulation will make individual regions more attractive, strengthen the economy of individual regions, further contribute to higher employment or to the strengthening of tourism. I therefore welcome the fact that this proposal has received a great deal of support not only in the JURI Committee, but also in the Plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Wales has a rich history of traditional industries and crafts, and in our agricultural sector we have already benefitted from being able to demonstrate clearly to consumers the quality of produce from Wales.  I welcome initiatives that support our traditional producers of non-agricultural goods and enable them to showcase the authenticity of their products to as many consumers as possible. Looking beyond the adoption of this report, it is important that any future system for geographical indication for non-agricultural produce is well thought through, with careful prior evaluation and consideration given to the cost implications and the impacts for producers and consumers. We must ensure that costs and red tape for businesses are kept to a minimum.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are a guarantee for consumers mainly for product quality and fair competition on the market.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Geographical indications are used to indicate the origin of the goods, indicating the country, region, county, place, manufacturer or producer to which the goods are most linked. At present, at European level, protection of origin covers only agricultural products that meet the conditions, which are produced by traditional process and represent high quality. At present, the protection of these products varies from one Member State to another, and in some Member States the products of other Member States are not protected.  Following research on this subject and consultation with stakeholders, this own-initiative report calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for products which do not fall within the scope of agricultural products and which, by traditional production, form part of the European cultural heritage. Such a regulation would significantly improve the international competitiveness not only of the Member States, but also of Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion, which aims to provide a geographical indication of other products in addition to food, which has been protected at EU level since 1992. This will provide consumers with adequate information, but the initiative will also help to protect cultural heritage, boost local businesses and promote local products. A geographical indication is therefore a name or symbol referring to the origin of a product. The indication usually symbolises the traditional process, special knowledge or local culture necessary for the production of the product and cannot therefore be used unauthorised by other undertakings. The European Commission has more than 800 products that would be affected by such new regulations, such as antwerp diamond and Murano glass, such as fish lace, herend and raven house porcelain. In practice, the motion is a strong signal to the European Commission, which is taking the initiative to propose a single geographical indication system as soon as possible and to take into account existing systems.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The globalisation of the world's economies significantly increases the mobility of business, the production of goods and the provision of services. This is a positive process and it is difficult to imagine restrictions, for example, on the protection of the geographical origin of certain products or services.  On the other hand, there are undoubtedly areas and industries which, due to their regional or local specificities, should be protected as regards origin or specific production methods. This catalogue of industries or fields includes the production of food products, but also crafts, handicrafts or local artistic creation. These forms of economic activity should be subject to special legal protection, not only because of respect for the rights of those communities which have been engaged in such production for decades, and often for centuries, but also because of the protection of a particular tradition and culture for posterity. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament's report on extending the protection of European Union geographical indications to non-agricultural products.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The perfect quality and reputation of products from traditional regions of the European Union can be found in what we call geographical indications of these products. The know-how and traditional techniques applied during their manufacture are part of the cultural heritage of the European Union.  By the existence of geographical indications, traditional agricultural products from european Member States of high quality have contributed to increasing the overall attractiveness of their regions. At the same time, these products have been shown to maintain local identities and promote diversity of places, having an perfect economic impact and immeasurable benefits for the tourism, culture, employment and trade sectors. I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to come up with a proposal for a single, harmonised system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products under the existing system for agricultural products. I hope that we can thus encourage entrepreneurship at local and regional level and help promote activities directly related to local realities. Geographical indications for non-agricultural products have a huge economic potential and their adequate protection can bring significant benefits to European SMEs and regions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Blue stone from Belgium, Val St Lambert Glass, Binche lace, Tournai carpet, Antwerp diamonds, Mons earthenware and nearly 800 other handicrafts are currently protected in only half of European countries. The European Parliament is in favour of the introduction of legislation that establishes a protected geographical indication in all Member States in order to promote these products but also to combat counterfeiting, avoid unfair competition and consumer deception. Protecting our know-how means protecting the employment associated with these most often artisanal activities and safeguarding our heritage.  A European system to protect geographical indications for non-agricultural products would be a real step forward for consumers, manufacturers to protect the know-how and jobs it generates from counterfeiting, the fraudulent use of geographical indication names and other unfair practices

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In this own initiative report that I supported, the European Parliament asks the Commission for a legislative proposal with the aim of establishing a single European system of protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. Uniform protection at the EU level would foster both its commercial policy and consumer protection. Among other things, it has a potential to foster innovation and the creation of new start-ups, in particular for small enterprises, combat counterfeit or imitation products and ensure more sustainable approach to economic development. The report asks the Commission to create a system based on best practices and non-discriminatory principles that would provide for strict control and a two-stage registration procedure. Such system should be accompanied by a single standardised and public European register for non-agricultural products benefiting from geographical indication protection.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The report by Virginie Rozière aims to push the European Commission to legislate on a system of recognition of non-agricultural geographical indications (a kind of territory label). While agricultural geographical indications are recognised in EU legislation, there is no framework for non-agricultural GIs. Local craftsmen cannot have their know-how recognized in most countries.  Laguioles knives, Carrara marble or Scottish tartans are not just brands, they are part of the European intangible heritage.  Thus, I have strongly supported this report, because an extension of the system of geographical indications will enable the effective preservation of heritage and employment, will be a bulwark against relocations and will simplify the lives of our craftsmen and the choice of European consumers.  We expect the Commission, which alone has the power of legislative initiative, to quickly propose legislation resuming this proposal, which is widely agreed in the European Parliament.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported this excellent proposal because I believe that it does not violate the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in any segment, and represents a true example of the additional value that the Union can provide to member states. As the European Union market is more than rich in products that have been part of the cultural, social, and economic heritage of individual Member States of the Union, the proposal to extend the protection of geographical indications, in addition to agricultural products (which have been protected at European level since 1992), to non-agricultural products, is extremely positive, useful and purposeful. Various industrial products and handicrafts traditionally rooted in certain geographical regions have been unfairly left out of the process of protecting geographical indications for many years, and I am therefore extremely pleased that this unjust practice has been embarked on.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the possibility of extending the protection of the European Union's geographical indications to non-agricultural products, as I believe that it brings many benefits to the Member States. The introduction of geographical indications can have a direct impact on tourism, local economic development and the preservation of cultural heritage, and help to strengthen consumer confidence. Currently, only agricultural products of a certain geographical origin can be given a single protected geographical indication in the EU, and this practice is not yet known for non-agricultural products.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the possible extension of the protection of EUROPEAN geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This type of indication has historically existed for agricultural products, thus trying to satisfy the protection of products of priority interest to the primary sectors of the respective countries. The extension to other types of products is interesting, starting in addition to the experience gained in agricultural products. We still understand that this requires detailed analysis of each sector for which geographical indications could be created.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. As shadow rapporteur for the ECR in the IMCO Committee, I have two objectives. Firstly, I voted in favour of the creation of a single European legal framework to put an end to the proliferation of national regulations and to achieve European legal certainty. At the same time, I have opposed the centralisation of the supervisory authorities, because I believe that the control needs should be determined by the national side and that expenditure on control should also remain at national level. The nation states or regional actors are best placed to determine their own needs. Secondly, I have tried to protect competition and have proposed that goods that are modelled on a protected product and clearly marked as similar should not be excluded from competition. Already in the IMCO Committee I was not able to prevail with my position. There should be a centralisation of control and, in my view, a restriction on the trade of similar products which is, in my view, anti-competitive. That is why I have already rejected the opinion of the IMCO Committee and I am now also opposed to the proposal of the JURI Committee, which has not changed these objectives.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a report that has the merit of extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural products, such as Laguiole knives or Calais lace, among others. A PGI is a name or symbol that refers to the geographical origin of a product and traditional know-how. It allows the producer to promote its products and offers the consumer guarantees of quality. In France, in some sectors, companies have estimated that the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products would lead to a possible 25% increase in international demand. The aim here is to protect the "Made in France". This report is therefore generally positive. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Within the European Union there are many non-agricultural products that come from the traditions of each Member State and have become an important part of their local and regional culture. The notoriety and authenticity of these products make them highly sought after and may, in this respect, be subject to falsification, which may constitute injury to consumers and producers. There is a need to develop a single system for the protection of geographical indications at European level, as there are different levels of protection in the Member States, which is a problem for their effective protection. There is a need at European level for the promotion of these high-quality products. This can increase the prestige of manufacturing and artisanal products in Europe's regions and, therefore, stimulate the local economy by creating new jobs in these sectors, encouraging tourism and increasing consumer confidence. This strategy can foster the development of small businesses, which account for around 80 % of the production of traditional local products, through more efficient sales methods and closer cooperation within this unitary system at European level. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the possibility of extending the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the possible extension of the protection of EUROPEAN geographical indications to non-agricultural products. This type of indication has historically existed for agricultural products, thus trying to satisfy the protection of products of priority interest to the primary sectors of the respective countries. The extension to other types of products is interesting, starting in addition to the experience gained in agricultural products. We still understand that this requires detailed analysis of each sector for which geographical indications could be created.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstained because voting in favour of an extension of intellectual property protection to new categories of goods is a position I and my Group could, in principle, not support.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – I believe that, in addition to supporting innovation, it is necessary to protect traditional products whose production methods have been passed down from generation to generation.  A protected geographical indication for foodstuffs is already well in operation in the EU; The list also includes three unique Latvian products – sklandrausis, Carnikava lamps and sweetened rye bread.  By extending the protection of geographical indications to non-agricultural and artisan products of regional and local importance, the production of which is based on traditional skills or knowledge will benefit regions, small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, craftsmen and, of course, consumers. Also in Latvia there is no shortage of products specific to a particular place or geographical area, such as Latgale pottery.   The introduction of geographical indications for non-food products will boost the economy, tourism and help preserve cultural heritage and traditional skills. The establishment of such a list would also provide the European Union with the same protection for exports of products as part of international trade negotiations. Consumers will also benefit from the system providing reliable information on the place and method of manufacture to help make informed choices by preventing the deception that names or descriptions might cause. The establishment of such a register would also make it possible to combat counterfeiting, prevent unfair competition and other unfair practices.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-binding resolution concerning the legal protection of geographical indications of local and regional artisanal know-how. The resolution calls on the Commission to propose legislation to extend EU-wide protection of geographical indications (GI) to include regionally and locally manufactured goods and handicraft products. The aim of these provisions is, on one hand, to support the economic potential of product quality and to guarantee such quality for consumers, and on the other hand, to preserve cultural heritage and traditional know-how.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about an area where it is important to move forward since quality European products based on traditional knowledge and techniques represent an indispensable cultural heritage of the Union. We are talking about intangible goods that could be lost if they are not properly protected. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of this report and thus to ask the European Commission to develop a legislative proposal extending so-called "appellations of origin" to non-agricultural products.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Roziére report because the extension of the system of protected geographical indications to non-agricultural products would have abundant positive repercussions for both the EU as a whole and for Spain.  It would first create a quality assurance that would protect types of artisanal and traditional production crucial to the economy of certain regions with respect to illegitimate copies that undermine their added value. It would strengthen the economic sustainability of thousands of SMEs and ensure the maintenance of the corresponding jobs. In addition, it would provide the consumer with an additional guarantee of the quality and traceability of the products they consume.  Spain is proof of the success of the current system of protected geographical indications for agri-food products; I therefore believe that their extension to non-food products will generate similar benefits at European level in terms of the sustainability of SMEs engaged in these products, employment and consumer protection.
