name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I believe that the GI system for agricultural products has been revealed as a positive mechanism for protecting small local producers in certain nations and States currently belonging to the EU.  That is why I think it is positive to extend this system to products other than agricultural products taking into account the experience and lessons learned during this time with agricultural products.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Geographical indication can be an important indicator of both heritage and quality for many products. It is important that we extend to non-agricultural products the same protections that consumers already enjoy in relation to agricultural products. If a product is associated with a certain region or area then the consumer should be allowed to purchase with the confidence that this is in fact a correct and accurate portrayal. Furthermore, this protects businesses that rely on the production of certain materials that are associated with an area, often drawing on long tradition and practice to provide good quality for those who purchase their goods. I was proud to vote in favour of these common sense protections for both businesses and consumers.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'This report aims to extend the protection of geographical indications. It is those geographical indications that make a particular region known and can boost the local and regional economy. The local traders and producers do sail with it and local customs and traditions are less easily lost. This protection allows additional jobs to be created and crafts honoured. So I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The geographical indication of the origin of agricultural products has been more well-established in terms of protection, thanks in particular to the AOP and AOC designations. Supporting the implementation of an equivalent system for craft products is therefore positive.  In the face of international competition, local producers need this protection, which values the quality and authenticity of locally manufactured handicrafts. Such a measure could have significant benefits for SMEs and the recognition of their know-how. This would increase access to reliable information for European citizens about the place and modes of production by providing them with guarantees on the origin of the products.  This resolution has the merit of being a first step in order to better protect local production in the European Union. It remains to be seen what conclusions can be drawn from the other European institutions so that, beyond good intentions, real legal protection can be achieved.  However, I voted for it, because it is a good move.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution supports the idea of creating a system for geographical indication of non-agricultural products, taking into account traditional European quality products based on know-how and traditional techniques that are an integral part of the EU's cultural heritage and which must be preserved.  The protection of GIs could act as an incentive to preserve cultural heritage and traditional know-how, and can help prevent the depopulation and destruction of rural areas and to halt the exodus of young people leaving these areas, ensuring fair remuneration for producers. Good legislation can help effectively combat terrorism, promote and facilitate access to the common market and markets outside the EU, stimulate economic development at regional and local level.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I am opposed to extending the existing eu rules on origin labelling of agricultural products to other sectors, which have hitherto only made much sense. The previous rules for agricultural products are not honest and allow Lübeck marzipan not to come from Lübeck and Black Forest ham from the Black Forest. It is therefore a legalised consumer misrepresentation. At the same time, brand lawyers are being given a playing field for trials that are as pointless as they are lucrative. Bad rules must be abolished. Expanding them is a big mistake.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is the next step in efforts to extend geographical indication protection for authentic local products. It is great news for consumers and for our industries that are producing authentic local goods, and will make it harder for factories to pass off cheap knock offs as originals. This means original regional products could have the same protection as authentic regional food like Melton Mowbray pork pies.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. Protecting our agricultural heritage with geographical indications was necessary. Expanding this opportunity to non-agricultural products is a new step in preserving our rural heritage.  This will not only recognise the know-how in this area, but also protect these quality products (especially with regard to counterfeits). Finally, it will have positive economic benefits for the regions that make a living from these products.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Virginie Rozière's report on the possible extension of EU geographical indication protection to non-agricultural products. We must protect high-quality traditional European products, based on traditional techniques, as they form an integral part of Europe's cultural heritage. These products are directly linked to local lifestyles, especially in rural areas, and contribute to strengthening and promoting their distinct character, which works for the benefit of cultural tourism, employment and development.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products is good news for Europe. I voted in favour of this report in line with the European Commission's view because I believe it brings multiple advantages to Europeans. It has positive effects for citizens as consumers, they will make more informed decisions, being able to identify the origin and quality of them, providing information about the product. It is beneficial for product-producing regions receiving this seal by strengthening their industry or crafts and giving a distinction to the region. It will generally benefit the European economic and social fabric by protecting consumers, products and producers.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcomed this report calling for the protected geographical indication mark (PGI) to include not only food, but also craft works, thus helping to preserve Europe's cultural heritage and economic growth, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, while ensuring greater consumer protection. This report considers that high-quality traditional European products, the result of traditional knowledge and techniques, represent an EU cultural heritage and an essential element to be preserved in the economic and social life of many European regions. The report, in particular, calls on the Commission to establish a single protection system at EU level, given that the absence of such a system leads to an inadequate and particularly fragmented European framework, due to the fact that some Member States do not offer any specific protection while in others different definitions, procedures and levels of protection apply within national and local rules. This fragmentation hinders the harmonious development of the common market and uniform protection and effective competition on an equal footing, which prevents consumers from receiving accurate, truthful and comparable information.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Country, region or place of origin labelling is mandatory in the European Union only for agricultural products. I therefore supported this initiative by the European Parliament to lay down similar rules for non-agricultural products, especially for traditional regional products. I am convinced that this will lead to recognition of their quality and, at the same time, their promotion in the common European market.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Traditional products form part of our cultural identity, cultural heritage, and emphasize the beauty and traditions of individual regions of the European Union. These products are often produced in rural areas and in regions with low employment options. They are produced by family businesses or small and medium-sized enterprises on the basis of traditional know-how and can play an important role in the field of job creation. Therefore, their lack of protection, which was due to the absence of uniform legislation at European level, has, in particular, led to a deterioration in the reputation of traditional products by imitating them, a reduction in the confidence of consumers who see traditional products as a guarantee of quality, but ultimately also to the threat to traditional crafts and the jobs they provide. As the Slovak Republic also has many unmistakable traditional products that are not agricultural products (which have been protected at Pan-European level since 1992), I supported this report.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Proper indication of the origin of regional products plays an important role for both producers and consumers. Manufacturers are guaranteed that the product is protected against unauthorised copying by means of a certification system and certain requirements for the materials used or manufacturing methods. Consumers, on the other hand, are given a tool to make informed purchases in line with their preferences and expectations.  The creation of such an effective marking system at European level has succeeded in the area of marketing of agricultural products and has contributed to raising consumer awareness. Agricultural products from the Polish also become more recognisable and, thanks to their high quality, have become permanently present on the markets of the other Member States.  We can achieve similar success in the area of non-agricultural products, which is why I voted in favour of this report. Such a system will not only guarantee the protection of traditional production methods, but will also create jobs in regions where local crafts are an important part of cultural and economic heritage. However, the green light for the creation of a System of European Designations does not imply unconditional consent to possible defects in the system. Of course, the creation of EU standards for non-agricultural designations of regional products must include a reliable information campaign for consumers and must not create an insurmountable administrative barrier for producers who wish to register their products in such a database.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on extending the regulation on the indication of geographical origin to non-agri-food products as well, because I believe that it can be an effective tool for supporting and making our local excellence more competitive. The report considers the high quality of European artisanal products, the result of traditional knowledge and techniques, as a cultural heritage to be preserved in order to protect the specific characteristics of individual territories and to enhance local production chains. The absence of a harmonised system leads to an inadequate and particularly fragmented European framework and distorting effects on the harmonious development of the common market, preventing us from making full use of the economic, social and cultural potential derives from these products. I therefore welcome the firm request to the Commission to present a legislative proposal to this effect.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Of course, I voted in favour of giving Greece, which is in difficulty, so to speak, more EU money and assistance. However, as I said in my speech on this subject, I would encourage the Greek citizens to follow and monitor carefully how these funds are spent and, if they are careful to distribute these instruments in opaque, corrupt tenders, they should immediately rebel or report them to the European Union. As I have done with regard to manipulations of Hungarian land, I have noticed, on the basis of several reports, that eu land-based subsidies are being manipulated by giving land leases to ineents who then put the money in their own pockets. I have indicated the problem to the European Commission, who have turned to OLAF, and I encourage my own compatriots to ... (the President has withdrawn the floor)

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today we supported concrete measures to amend regulations to help Greece absorb European funds more rapidly. We must not forget that other Member States also have difficulties in financing investments and strategic projects and do not often have sufficient funds for co-financing and pre-financing.  For this reason, I urge the European Commission to consider helping to implement and accelerate the implementation of European funds in other Member States as well, in particular in the eight Member States which are particularly lagging behind and for which the European Commission has also set up task force. For them as a whole, too, it is necessary to think about how to simplify the rules and simplify the whole regulation in order to make the implementation of European funds as swift and concrete as possible in these Member States. Of course, we urge governments to simplify implementing rules as end-users find it increasingly difficult to cope with different regulations.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I had the honour to speak on behalf of the EPP when Mr Tsipras, the Greek Prime Minister was here, and at that time I was rather critical of him. But I did say that if he went away and put a serious package together, the European Union would meet him more than halfway. He has done that and, in fairness, he has been re-elected. Having said that, it is going to be very difficult for Greece. Like yourself, Madam President, I come from Ireland, and we know how difficult the bail-out programme was. But by sticking with it, we are now coming out the other side and things are improving. I want to see the same happening for Greece, but certainly every effort must be made to help them, and if, through the Structural Investment Funds, we can be more lenient with Greece, then we have an obligation to do that. We are also conscious of the fact that Greece is bearing a lot of the brunt of the migration crisis. That, with their bail-out situation, makes it difficult, so we must help them in every way, and this is a good step.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I abstained from this material, not that I did not want to support Greece. I am aware of the situation in which Greece finds itself, and I was prepared to support the material that would provide for an exception for Greece in the implementation of the Structural Funds, as the exception was formulated by the July European Council, that is, for the period 2014 to 2020, that is, for the future. I did not support the material on the grounds that, in addition to the European Summit decision, the European Commission has submitted material that regulates the rules for the de facto end of the programming period for 2007 to 2013. According to some experts and lawyers, such a proposal is retroactive and, in some respects, troubled. I think that the aid we are approving should be approved for the future, not for the legal relationships that have already been established and which are now being accounted for and ending.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – This proposal concerns financial assistance to Greece. And the idea is good: to raise the maximum share of the European Union budget for pre-financing and temporary payments to 100%. The same with the Convergence, Regional competitiveness and employment objectives programme funds for 2007-2013, and the same with additional assistance in 2014-2020. In particular, I will note the case of fishing and investment. Of course, this assistance is not intended to cover simple expenditure in specific areas, but to increase overall competitiveness in the Greek economy and among its workers. Aside from this, however, the main objective is to stimulate the Greek Government's efforts to initiate and phase out reforms, which would also allow Greece to return to the most developed, competitive and advanced countries in Europe and the world. I have to say that Greek health is Europe's health. I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this motion for a resolution, which is really intended to help hard-fought Greece. I will admit that I would probably never vote for Prime Minister Tsipras, but to help a particular country that is in such serious economic problems, I consider this to be a sign of the real European solidarity that we are talking about here in many respects.  In my opinion, the EUR 500 million that should be additionally increased by the aid, i.e. reserves or advances, which is effectively the budgetary impact for this year and next year, are relatively small money, given that they can actually be provided under a clearly defined regulatory framework and if (and I am also reproaching the resolution) more conditional on the transfer of these funds to carry out specific homework by Greece. , to kick-start economic growth. So that, once again, this potential is not just squandered.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, I voted in favour of this report because the measures to be taken to support Greece are decisive. A country that has suffered and is suffering, precisely because of the memoranda; the memoranda have impoverished Greece. At the same time, the Memorandums imposed a reduction in public investment. Therefore, without public investment, there could be no co-financing on the part of Greece. So the absorption of Community funds could not be done. Clearly, therefore, these measures were decisive in order to move forward. To move on to a stage where the European Union itself, through the troika, has impoverished Greece, so we also say the saying: "Burn you, John, and rub you with honey".  In other words, the European Union is now coming to supplement, to help the Greek people, albeit limited, to relieve themselves of these aggressive and unfair policies of the memorandum itself.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejected this report because receiving financing from the EU at an earlier date will not correct the Greece's liquidity problems. The EU should allow and accommodate Greece to leave the Eurozone if they so desire. By allowing Greece to leave the Eurozone they could devalue their currency and default on IMF and Troika loans. This would be a much more prudent method for recovery in the medium and long term compared to only short term finance that only answers immediate liquidity issues.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the Commission proposed amending two articles of Regulation No 1303/2013 to ensure that EU funding, available to Greece, is available to beneficiaries as quickly as possible. Key elements include increasing the co-financing rate for 2007-2013 programming projects from 95% to 100%, and with regard to the 2014-2020 programming, with an additional initial pre-financing of 7% in the operational programmes of cohesion policy in Greece. This would allow Greece not to lose 2 billion euros this year and to have immediate liquidity in the two-year period 2015 - 2016 for 2 billion euros. The Greek State will have to ensure the establishment of a mechanism to ensure that the additional amounts made available as a result of the measures taken are used exclusively for payments to beneficiaries.  In the REGI Committee, an overwhelming majority voted for the simplified procedure to allow voting in plenary to facilitate the use of funds in Greece. In view of the situation in Greece and the important measures taken, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading for the Greek State to gain short-term advantages in its financing, by advanceing some of the payments budgeted in the 2014-2020 Structural and Cohesion Funds, from the increase in the co-financing ceiling, as well as from the implementation of the outstanding payments under the 2007-2013 framework. It is estimated that these measures will have a positive balance for Greek public finances of around EUR 2 billion, a small share compared to the 260 billion that Greece has had to borrow from the troika institutions (IMF, European Central Bank, and European Commission) in exchange for measures that have deepened the pauperization of Greek society. Moreover, they are not an extra disbursement of the European institutions but a step forward in what was budgeted for the 2018 and 2020 financial years respectively.  Despite this necessary general criticism of European economic policy, the proposal allows the Greek Government to receive extra liquidity in the short term, so, not being a solution in itself to the economic problems arising from the contraction of public spending, I have decided to give my vote in favour.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which changes the Structural Funds regulation and investments to allow advance structural fund payment, and to facilitate pre-financing and co-financing, to Greece. This amendment offers a brief and minor relief to Greece's economy, allowing it to quickly access these vital funds. Tighter financing conditions, as well as economic uncertainties in recent months, have caused liquidity problems, disrupting investment programs and the ability of the Greek authorities to fully utilise the available EU funds.  The Greek economy is in urgent need of a cash injection, as funds for public investment to revive the economy are lacking. This means that Greece is less able to co-finance this policy, and many projects may not be completed.  The resolution is also urgent because if Greece does not use the funds still available under the 2007 – 2013 funding period before the end of 2015, these funds will be lost, and Greece will miss out on about 2 billion euros for much-needed projects and job creation.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I chose to abstain in the vote on Amendment No 2, which states that the EU should allow Greece to withdraw from the euro if it is judged to be one of several carefully tested ways of overcoming Greece's financial situation. In principle, I think the proposal is a good one, but it does not belong in this report, which deals with exceptional measures to provide investment aid to Greece immediately.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report of the Committee on Regional Development approves the amendment of the General Regulation on the rules for the use of the 5 EU Structural and Investment Funds. (Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund) in order to enable Greece to ensure the timely use of the money at its disposal from the 2007-2013 programming period (before the end of 2017) , and to meet all the necessary conditions for access to European funds during the current 2014-2020 programming period. In particular, the percentage of European funding is increased to 100%, effectively abolishing the national contribution for projects from 2007 to 2013, so that the 2 billion can be used immediately, making the full amount available immediately. Further, for the period 2014-2020 it was decided to increase the level of initial pre-financing by 7 percentage points or by 1 billion.  The European Union is supporting Greece on the path of investment by giving it the necessary resources to emerge from the vicious cycle of recession.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is the situation in Greece. It is a package of measures to provide additional aid to Greece to the tune of two billion euros for the years 2015 and 2016.  This choice of the Commission is questionable. We do not know how the Greek government will make use of these funds. Thus, it is very likely that some of them will be allocated to the reception facilities of immigrants. Other Member States can be expected to apply for the same preferential regime. Moreover, it has been a while since the Greek government was unable to resolve the crisis despite EU aid.  At the National Front, we believe that the only viable solution for Greece is a concerted exit from the eurozone. This is absolutely necessary for the Greek government to have sufficient leeway to turn the country's economy around. So far, Greece has plunged into a lasting crisis that makes it financially and politically increasingly dependent on the European authorities.  We have tabled several amendments to ensure that these elements are taken into account. These were not adopted. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I note that the EFDD amendments to this report failed, although they were simple common sense. We pointed out that EU-imposed austerity had had a negative impact upon the Greek economy. We suggested that Greece should be allowed to leave the euro area; this failed too. The whole report is a bad report and we could not support it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which gives Greece specific aid measures. Clearly, these should only be released with the assurance of the effectiveness of the reforms prescribed and on which the Greek government is committed.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this proposal and voted in favour of it because the situation in Greece requires our adequate attention and quick decisions. We must continue showing the European solidarity by creation of favourable conditions for the best and full use of EU funds and by encouraging Greece to implement necessary reforms.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on special measures for Greece. Greece faces insufficient liquidity and lacks the public funds available to promote the public investment necessary to promote sustainable recovery. The Commission has proposed to amend the Common Provisions Regulation in order to provide additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the Investment for growth and jobs goal and programmes financed by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in Greece. I agree that support must be urgent.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. So far, we have opposed the specific measures proposed for Greece, and especially the third bailout plan of 86 billion euros. This time, it is the mobilization of structural funds which, as a matter of principle, should be earmarked for projects that support growth and job creation. It remains to be seen whether the Greeks will be the sole beneficiaries of these payments and, on this issue, the Commission does not give sufficient guarantees. In fact, this concern was expressed by several Members during the debate in the REGI committee, where my colleague Steeve Briois sits. Uncertainty hangs over the true effectiveness of these proposals. Co-financing rates have already been raised several times in favour of Greece and, despite this, the Greek government remains unable to provide a financial contribution. In these circumstances, can we still speak of "co-financing"? Therefore, it is rather donations to Greece at the expense of other Member States that contribute to the EU budget. I could have voted for this text if some of the amendments tabled by our group had been accepted: this was not the case.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The financial crisis has hit Greece hard. The social and economic situation has become catastrophic. Indeed, the number of Greeks at risk of poverty has more than doubled in five years, from 20% in 2009 to more than 44% in 2014.  The national unemployment rate is 25.8% (February 2015 figures)! Wages fell by an average of 38% between 2009 and pensions by 45%. Greece is experiencing serious liquidity problems and does not have sufficient public funds to finance the necessary investments to stimulate growth and job creation.  I therefore voted in favour of a plan that should ensure that Greece has sufficient financial resources to implement programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund (FC) and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (FEAMP).

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Structural and Investment Funds in the case of Greece, as this supported an investment plan worth EUR 35 billion to improve Greece's competitiveness, including EUR 20 billion from structural and investment funds and EUR 15 billion in agricultural funds. Support for this initiative will enable the Council of the Union to take swift action and its immediate entry into force. The decision ensures that these extraordinary funds for Greece from the 2007-2013 programming period are available on time, before it expires in 2017 and will also help Greece to meet the requirements for access to Community funds allocated in the current 2014-2020 period.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to adopt specific measures for Greece through cohesion policy. It must help Greece use the structural funds despite its inability to co-finance public investment projects. The proposal calls for an additional 2 billion euros (1 billion euros in 2015 and 1 billion euros in 2016).  In the wake of the financial crisis and the austerity policy imposed by the troika, Greece suffers from serious liquidity problems, but the counterpart of this aid is still the same: even more austerity, budget cuts and privatizations... Solutions that don't work yet.  Above all, Greece must regain its national currency and get out of this austerity straitjacket and, as it stands, I have therefore voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Mihaylova report does not analyse in a sufficiently critical and balanced way the real causes that led to the collapse of the Greek economy. That is why I cannot support it and I did not support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investment under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMP. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase to 100% the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece to advance distribution of more than EUR 2 billion and potential savings of nearly another 2 billion euros, complete ongoing projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately upon submission of their payment applications.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament points out that Greece needs to be given support. It was therefore decided to apply a simplified procedure without amendment to this Regulation. This procedure should contribute to joint efforts to assist Greece and allow for the entry into force of this Regulation as soon as possible. The impact of the financial crisis on Greece was exceptional. The country faces insufficient liquidity and lacks the public funds available to promote the public investment necessary to promote sustainable recovery. This has led to an extraordinary situation requiring special measures. Importantly, insufficient liquidity and a lack of public funds in Greece would not be an obstacle to investment through programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees increased advance payments, the abolition of the 95% co-financing ceiling and national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy.  Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the common provisions under the third memorandum, which also includes an aid measure for Greece in the implementation of cohesion projects. We know that cohesion projects are one of the key tools of solidarity within the European Union and that Greece has major problems with their closure and funding, so this aid of two billion, which is intended either to be 100 per cent co-financed or to advance, is a very concrete step in helping Greece at these difficult times.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report because Greece is in a very difficult financial and economic situation. I believe that we need to do everything we can to help this EU Member State as fast and efficiently as possible, with as urgent measures as possible, without further procedures that would further slow down the Commission's process of providing an additional advance.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which changes the Structural Funds regulation and investments to allow advance structural fund payment, and to facilitate pre-financing and co-financing, to Greece. This offers a brief and minor relief to Greece's economy, allowing it to quickly access these vital funds. Tighter financing conditions, as well as economic uncertainties in recent months, have caused liquidity problems, disrupting investment programs and the ability of the Greek authorities to fully utilise the available EU funds.  The Greek economy is in urgent need of a cash injection, as funds for public investment to revive the economy are lacking. This means that Greece is less able to co-finance this policy, and many projects may not be completed.  The resolution is also urgent because if Greece does not use the funds still available under the 2007 – 2013 funding period before the end of 2015, these funds will be lost, and Greece will miss out on about 2 billion euros for much-needed projects and job creation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because the EU's cohesion policy and its Structural Funds were, during the crisis, indispensable tools to enable businesses and citizens to continue their activities and to face and overcome the most difficult times. The situation in Greece is even more difficult because of the budgetary policies that greece has to implement. These specific measures are therefore intended to enable Greek companies to receive the funds to which they are entitled in order to emerge from the crisis as soon as possible, which we all want.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This Commission proposal calls for an additional EUR 2 billion of Cohesion Policy funds to be mobilised for Greece, which is no longer able to co-finance public investment projects. Athens is facing serious liquidity problems as a result of the austerity measures imposed by the troika. The text specifically envisages increasing the level of initial pre-financing paid to the 2014-2020 Greek operational programmes and increasing the co-financing rate to 100% for the 2007-2013 programmes. On the form, we strongly condemn the Commission's choice to have resorted to the simplified procedure. In essence, these aids are supposed to support growth and job creation in Greece, although they are insufficient. The amendments we tabled were intended to regulate the use of these funds for Greece so that they are not used to finance infrastructure for the reception of illegal migrants. We also wanted these aids to be exceptional and temporary in order to prevent other Member States from requesting it. These amendments were rejected, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the financial crisis, Greece has faced a lack of liquidity and insufficient public funds for the investments needed to support a sustainable recovery. In this context, the amendment to this Regulation provides for additional pre-financing for operational programmes financed for the period 2014-2020 under cohesion policies, with the main objectives of 'investment for growth and employment' and for programmes under the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. I voted in favour of amending the regulation on the common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, because I believe that the proposed measures aim to counter the lack of liquidity in the Greek economy and to boost investment immediately, measures which are absolutely necessary and which allow for the rapid launch of a greater number of projects.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against. The report, of course, is careful not to point to austerity as one of the causes of Greek ruin. At least it allows Greece to take the only way to free itself from its status as a South American economic colony and return to growth (and thus repay its debts): the exit agreed by the euro. What is more, it is not made clear that these 'specific measures for Greece' cannot one day be extended to other Member States, nor that these emergency provisions cannot in any way allow the use of the Structural Funds with the effect of facilitating the transit and settlement of illegal immigrants in the Schengen area. As the ENF and EFDD amendments will not be adopted, the final vote will be against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Greece is having a great deal of difficulty overcoming the crisis. The country no longer has any liquidity to implement investment projects essential to the implementation of the structural reforms necessary for its economic recovery. The situation requires quick reactions. The future of the eurozone and the European Union is at stake.  For this reason, the European Parliament has granted, in an expedited procedure, additional pre-financing for the operational programmes relating to cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries. These are financings that would have been returned to Greece anyway. The Union therefore does not give more money to Greece, but somehow makes an advance on its due.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013. As I said in my speech, this regulation makes it possible to implement, in view of Greece's liquidity shortage, a rapid and important corrective to enable greece to take advantage of the extraordinary support measures resulting from cohesion policy funding still available from the 2007-2013 programming. The aim of this regulation is to restore the right balance to Greece's investment in the programmes financed by the European Funds, by making up for greece's lack of liquidity. In any case, I would like to stress that it is important, precisely in phases and emergency regimes, that there should be the widest and most timely information on the processes in progress.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which changes the Structural Funds regulation and investments to allow advance structural fund payment, and to facilitate pre-financing and co-financing, to Greece. This offers a brief and minor relief to Greece's economy, allowing it to quickly access these vital funds. Tighter financing conditions, as well as economic uncertainties in recent months, have caused liquidity problems, disrupting investment programs and the ability of the Greek authorities to fully utilise the available EU funds.  The Greek economy is in urgent need of a cash injection, as funds for public investment to revive the economy are lacking. This means that Greece is less able to co-finance this policy, and many projects may not be completed.  The resolution is also urgent because if Greece does not use the funds still available under the 2007 – 2013 funding period before the end of 2015, these funds will be lost, and Greece will miss out on about 2 billion euros for much-needed projects and job creation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejected this report because receiving financing from the EU at an earlier date will not correct the Greece's liquidity problems. The EU should allow and accommodate Greece to leave the Eurozone if they so desire. By allowing Greece to leave the Eurozone they could devalue their currency and default on IMF and Troika loans. This would be a much more prudent method for recovery in the medium and long term compared to only short term finance that only answers immediate liquidity issues.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree that this measure should help foster a sustainable recovery in Greece in the current situation, including its migration crisis situation. It will help in addressing the current severe liquidity shortages and lack of public funds.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece has been severely affected by the financial crisis. Negative GDP growth rates for several years have caused Greece serious liquidity problems and the lack of public funds for public investment needed to foster a sustainable recovery. It is essential that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not stand in the way of investment in programmes financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund, as well as by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. The proposal allows the advance payment of EUR 2 025 600, so I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I oppose the specific measures proposed for Greece. The report in question refers to the mobilization of structural funds which, in principle, should be used for projects that support growth and job creation. Moreover, one worrying detail: we cannot be sure that the payments will benefit the Greeks only, because the Commission does not give sufficient guarantees. Moreover, it is no longer a question of co-financing because today the Greek government is no longer able to contribute financially to EU projects. Finally, the proposals set out in this report risk making the Greek economy even more dependent on EU funds.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Mihaylova report in order to enable the Greek authorities to make immediate use of the exceptional measures provided for in the amendment of Regulation 1303/3013. However, I have strong objections and reservations, both with regard to the Rules of Procedure itself and with regard to the timing of the decision to amend it. Given that the mandate to amend the Rules of Procedure was given immediately after the signing of the 3rd Memorandum, it would at least be hypocritical to regard this decision as an expression of solidarity, or as an ex post administration of justice. It is clear that this decision is the product of blackmail towards Greece and the Greek people, a very small "exchange" for the signing of an agreement with the main characteristics of the implementation of extreme austerity measures, the sale of public property and the transfer of national sovereignty. The EU has used the freeze on European funds as a threat and a means of economic suffocation to impose austerity measures.  The case of Greece is not an isolated event. Unfortunately, Cohesion Policy is increasingly part of the logic of Economic Governance and the European Semester, giving access to European funds only to 'disciplined' countries.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is rightly proposed by the Commission to amend the Regulation laying down common provisions in order to provide for additional pre-financing for the operational programmes of cohesion policy 2014-2020 under the 'Investment in Growth and Employment' objective. In addition, a ceiling of 100% is foreseen for the cumulative total of pre-financing payments and interim payments and an increase in the co-financing rate to 100% for the operational programmes for the period 2007-2013 for the convergence and regional competitiveness and employment objectives in Greece.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the possible extension of the protection of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products.  Geographical indications can have considerable economic potential and adequate protection can bring important benefits, especially for SMEs and eu regions. Europe has a real heritage of traditional and artisanal skills of the highest standard. However, at European level, there is no uniform system for geographical indications of non-agricultural products. This report welcomes the Commission's proposal for a public consultation with stakeholders and invites it to present a legislative proposal on the subject, considers it necessary to establish at EU level a protection instrument for the manufacturing and craft sector, considers that these measures should be accompanied by information and communication measures and underlines the important benefits that the extension of EU geographical indications to non-agricultural products will bring to consumers , producers and citizens.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After so much austerity, Greece needs European solidarity. I do not want to go into the merits of the choices made by the troika, but it seems clear to me that a country that is committed to paying its debts must be helped to get out of the stagnant situation in which it had fallen. Surely we must prevent this aid from being perceived as an incentive to reduce like Greece before making reforms, but the message also valid for Italy is not to stop trying to improve itself (instead of wasting time with non-urgent measures) and roll up its sleeves, which has not happened since 2011.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejected this report because receiving financing from the EU at an earlier date will not correct the Greece's liquidity problems. The EU should allow and accommodate Greece to leave the Eurozone if they so desire. By allowing Greece to leave the Eurozone they could devalue their currency and default on IMF and Troika loans. This would be a much more prudent method for recovery in the medium and long term compared to only short term finance that only answers immediate liquidity issues.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to increase the initial pre-financing level of Greece's Cohesion Policy programmes under the Growth and Employment Investment Target and Programmes under the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) for the period 2014-2020 and, on the other hand, to increase to 100% the maximum co-financing rates of operational programmes under the Convergence Objective and the Regional Competitiveness and Employment Objective. These measures are intended to address a severe lack of liquidity in the Greek economy and to give an immediate and desired stimulus to investment. In order to ensure that the additional initial pre-financing amount is used effectively and reaches the beneficiaries of the ESF, the Cohesion Fund and the EMFF as soon as possible, the additional pre-financing amount should be reimbursed to the Commission if it is not followed by an appropriate level of payment requests within a specified period. For all this, I support the Mihaylova Report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report because I am not convinced that suspending co-financing for Greece is the right way forward. I know from experience that projects that have 100% funding and no own funding do not sufficiently achieve the objective pursued. A separate financial contribution, albeit small, leads, like a kind of 'minimal correction', to the handling of the necessary responsibility with the subsidies. We need this in a case such as Greece, where there are currently no sufficiently functioning structures for the money to arrive where it is needed!

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece is still paying dearly for the consequences of the financial crisis: the country faces liquidity problems and does not have the public funds to foster a sustainable recovery. I am therefore in favour of this proposal and support the amendment of the rules of the regulation on common provisions, as I consider these initiatives to be essential in order to provide an immediate and indispensable impetus for investment. These exceptional measures will enable more projects to be launched quickly and, if managed very precisely, will mark an important step in the recovery of the greek country's financial situation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Refinancing cohesion policy in the EU is an example of responsible economic aid that provides opportunities to spur growth, investment and job creation. It is positive that this proposal is fully prepared to take on the urgent challenges in Greece and for this reason I support the measure.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the 2014-2020 programming period, around €20 billion of Structural Funds will be available for Greece. In July 2015, the Commission proposed the amendment of two articles of Regulation No 1303/2013 to ensure that EU funding available under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), (ESF), (FC), (EMFF) is actually used for on-the-spot investments and is available to beneficiaries as quickly as possible. There are three key elements: – an increase in the co-financing rate for projects in the 2007-2013 programming period from 95 % (already in vogue instead of the 85% normally applicable) to 100%; – "early release" of the final balance, equal to the remaining 5%, normally given at the closing of the programming in March 2017, as soon as possible; – for the 2014-2020 programming, provision for an additional initial pre-financing of 7% in the operational programmes of cohesion policy in Greece. I am voting in favour because the combined provisions of the three measures would, among other things, reduce the risk of around EUR 2 billion being lost by automatic decommitment due to delays in the spending of the Greek authorities and would give immediate liquidity of one billion euros (in addition to a further billion in 2016).

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading for the Greek State to gain short-term advantages in its financing, by advanceing some of the payments budgeted in the 2014-2020 Structural and Cohesion Funds, from the increase in the co-financing ceiling, as well as from the implementation of the outstanding payments under the 2007-2013 framework. It is estimated that these measures will have a positive balance for Greek public finances of around EUR 2 billion, a small share compared to the 260 billion that Greece has had to borrow from the troika institutions (IMF, European Central Bank, and European Commission) in exchange for measures that have deepened the pauperization of Greek society. Moreover, they are not an extra disbursement of the European institutions but a step forward in what was budgeted for the 2018 and 2020 financial years respectively.  Despite this necessary general criticism of European economic policy, the proposal allows the Greek Government to receive extra liquidity in the short term, so, not being a solution in itself to the economic problems arising from the contraction of public spending, I have decided to give my vote in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The final green light to amend the cohesion policy regulations is absolutely positive, which will make it easier and less expensive for Greece to absorb the Structural Funds. This is certainly a step in the right direction, showing the other side of the Union: solidarity, light years away from grexit's idea and aware of its responsibilities towards the citizens, towards all citizens. This cannot make us forget the other serious emergency that is before everyone's eyes: the terrible tragedy of migrants and refugees. There are resources from the 2007-2013 programming which, if not spent by 2015, will return to member states' budgets and remain unused; will be wasted! Let us put these resources at European level, concentrate them on a single specific axis – coordinated by the committee services and subject to additional controls, as in the case of Greece – and make them available to those states and regions that, more than others, come to terms with migratory flows on a daily basis. We are for a different Europe, which does not forget its historical roots, the suffering suffered and the tragedies experienced and which, on the basis of this, makes the true spirit of welcome and solidarity prevail.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. Greece has suffered significantly as a result of the financial crisis. It is important that the lack of Greek liquidity and public resources does not hinder investment in programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund, as well as the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. Thus, the European Commission has proposed to amend the Common Provisions Regulation in order, inter alia, to provide Greece with additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes under the objective of 'investment in growth and jobs' for the period 2014-2020.  Parliament has decided to introduce a simplified procedure without amendments, taking into account the urgency of the necessary support. This procedure should allow the Regulation to enter into force as soon as possible. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution to provide additional pre-financing in the current financial period, as well as to increase to 100% the co-financing rate for 2007 to 2013 operational programmes for Greece. Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, so much so that it has difficulties to co-finance the investments of the European Structural and Investment Funds. Considering the urgency of the support that is required in Greece, I support a simplified procedure in this case.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As Greece faces unprecedented pressure on its borders on the wave of migrants, I believe that these measures are a strong message of European solidarity, and I appreciate that the Commission will provide Greece with almost EUR 450 million in support to respond to migration and security challenges.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to provide additional pre-financing to Greece as part of the 2014-2020 Cohesion Policy and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. Hard hit by the crisis, Greece is facing a shortage of cash and public funds to finance the investments needed for economic recovery. The report therefore proposes to increase the share and co-financing rates of EUROPEAN funds for investment projects that will create growth and employment, particularly in key sectors such as fishing and port activities. Considering that investment assistance in the real economy will be one of the key levers for Greece's exit from the crisis, I supported the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Greece, currently in a precarious financial situation, will be able by this proposal to have payment credits made by the European Union in advance. This will enable the country to quickly implement programmes supported by the various European Structural and Investment Funds, through investments on the ground. I voted in favour of this Commission proposal, which is budgetaryly neutral.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees increased advance payments, the abolition of the 95% co-financing ceiling and national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of these provisions, which I hope will allow Greece to breathe in the financial turmoil it has been experiencing for several years.  The sums that will be released will make up for the lack of liquidity that prevents the Greek state and its communities from investing in new projects in order to revive sustainable growth and get out of the pod of which they are trapped. In this context, the country must be able to look to the future and be able to generate and finance cohesion projects under the 2014-2020 programmes.  It is also crucial today to send a strong political message to the Greek people and their government, who have, through the last two elections, demonstrated their commitment to Europe.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to encourage the European Commission to validate the allocation of additional funds to Greece. In trying to make up for the lack of liquidity in the Greek economy, the aim was to enable Greece to set up the investment programmes of the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Fund for Maritime and Fisheries Affairs. By providing additional financing, Greece will be better equipped to boost its economy thanks in particular to the funds allocated to it by the European Union. However, it seems essential not to sign cheques blindly and unconditionally. I have therefore conditioned my vote on this report on the fact that this flower made to Greece does not set a precedent and that the funds are used by the Greeks, not to welcome illegal immigrants. Since the main political groups in the system preferred to support the financing of mass immigration, I voted against this report, which merely pursues a policy without effect or effectiveness.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The principle of equality in the European Community is fundamental. I, as is the position of my country, have been put on hold for the adoption of this report, because if such measures are taken for one country, then others should be able to benefit, and you know, Bulgaria is in a difficult economic situation, one of the poorest in Europe (not to say the poorest), and any assistance to us is welcome. In the end, I voted in favour of this report, and I sincerely hope that everyone will be so in solidarity when we also need the rapid implementation of certain projects and similar measures must also be approved for Bulgaria. This report proposes measures to address Greece's critical lack of liquidity and to encourage the rapid launch of necessary projects under the ESI Funds.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I chose to abstain in the vote on Amendment No 2, which states that the EU should allow Greece to withdraw from the euro if it is judged to be one of several carefully tested ways of overcoming Greece's financial situation. In principle, I think the proposal is a good one, but it does not belong in this report, which deals with exceptional measures to provide investment aid to Greece immediately.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour, because Greece currently needs all possible liquidity which is not accompanied by additional measures. In any case, there must be a guarantee that these amounts will actually be allocated to development, which is not guaranteed through this report. In any case, this pre-financing is only a drop in the ocean of economic destruction caused to our country by the European Union and its domestic fans and supporters.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees increased advance payments, the abolition of the 95% co-financing ceiling and national co-financing for Greece. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Peter Eriksson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I chose to abstain in the vote on Amendment No 2, which states that the EU should allow Greece to withdraw from the euro if it is judged to be one of several carefully tested ways of overcoming Greece's financial situation. In principle, I think the proposal is a good one, but it does not belong in this report, which deals with exceptional measures to provide investment aid to Greece immediately.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. In view of the extremely difficult period of the financial crisis resulting from very high unemployment and the economic austerity that Greece has undergone, there is a right to abandon the usual arrangements to grant Structural Fund support against a certain amount of co-financing. However, it is very important that the 100% financing procedure from Structural Funds is used only in very extreme situations. The rule must be that funds are always conditional on a certain amount of co-financing.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal reinforces solidarity - but the european union's budgetary solidarity is something that has existed for many dozens of years. I would remind you that the European Social Fund has even existed since 1958. But it is a strengthening of solidarity that will relieve Greece, which has financial difficulties, a difficulty in liquidity, and will therefore be able to use the funds with less financial effort on its part. This less financial effort, this strengthening of solidarity, requires greater vigilance, requires additional responsibility. The amounts to 100% co-financing, the pre-financing rates amount to about EUR 2 billion, require that these amounts be used in projects that are sustainable. We want smart solidarity that contributes to Greece's growth, which contributes to strengthening Greece's competitiveness, bringing more jobs, and therefore these funds, in addition to social cohesion, in addition to economic cohesion, owe greater wealth to Greece. I hope that Greece, the Greek authorities, will seize this opportunity that they cannot waste.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, because it only amplifies Greece's debt process and diverts the structural funds from their original foundations.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the exceptional and dramatic financial situation in Greece, I voted in favour of the proposal to address the lack of liquidity in the Greek economy. This proposal will not affect the budget in the period 2014-2015 and will leave unchanged the annual allocation of commitment appropriations for the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe the release of these funds is vital for Greece to recover.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The financial and economic crisis has affected all the Member States of the European Union, but Greece has intervened in a special way. The country faces a lack of liquidity and public funds available for public investment, which are needed to promote sustainable recovery. However, the lack of liquidity and public finances must not hinder investments under programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, because if these investments were stopped, the country would run into existential problems. I therefore agree with the European Commission's proposals, which will provide additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for 2014-2020 under the Investment for growth and jobs goal. The amount of the additional initial advance payments must be used effectively and reach the beneficiaries of ESF, Cohesion Fund and ENFR funds as quickly as possible so that they can make the planned investments and receive reimbursements as soon as payment applications are submitted.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, which of course does not also indicate in the wrong measures taken in recent years to Greece one of the causes of the worsening situation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds: specific measures for Greece. My country currently needs all possible liquidity which is not accompanied by additional measures. In any case, it must be ensured that these amounts are actually allocated to development, which is not guaranteed through this report. In any case, this pre-financing is nothing more than a drop in the ocean of economic destruction caused to my country by the European Union and its domestic fans and supporters.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report since the availability of these funds has already been guaranteed and has no impact on the budget.  In this unique circumstance I welcome the help that the EU can give to Greece. The EU's main focus should be the creation of jobs and growth for the citizens of Greece.  I am glad to see the quick reaction of the Parliament on this matter.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, faces a critical lack of public funds and consequently is in difficulties to co-finance the investments of European Structural and Investment Funds, I support the proposal to provide additional pre-financing in the current financial period, as well as to increase the co-financing rate to 100% for 2007-2013 operational programmes. In view of the urgency of the support needed in Greece, I welcome the agreement within the political groups on the necessity of the introduction of a simplified procedure, as well. Greece is a part of the European architecture, and it has to stay this way.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal foresees increased advance payments, the abolition of the 95% co-financing ceiling and national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects.  Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report in the face of the pressing need of the Greek economy for public investment needed to drive a sustainable recovery. However, in the face of Greece's difficult financial situation, it is essential to ensure from the EU that the lack of liquidity and public funds in Greece does not hinder investment under programmes financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund, and by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (ESF).

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been necessary to address with specific measures to prevent the lack of liquidity and public funds from hindering investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. I voted in favour of amending the Structural Funds Regulation so that it is possible to grant additional pre-financing to the operational programmes of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 under the investment objective for growth and employment, to allow the maximum limit of the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% , and increase to 100% the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes of the convergence and regional competitiveness and employment objectives. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2 billion euros and potential savings of about another 2 billion euros, complete the ongoing projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we have shown the face of European solidarity in the face of a country in great economic difficulties such as Greece. In addition to the sacrifices required of it, today's vote provides for an additional financing programme and some important measures to help the population and ensure that the lack of temporary liquidity does not prevent the effectiveness of certain European programmes, which would otherwise be endangered.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
