text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recent exceptional measures proposed by the Ec in favour of Greece, aimed at amending the common provisions governing the implementation of the Structural and Investment Funds, as I strongly agree with the need to ensure immediate liquidity for Greece and for this reason to unlock investment and allow Greece to make maximum use of the funding provided under cohesion policy. From the outset, my group S&D has largely supported an accelerated procedure for amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/20132, laying down common provisions relating to the five Structural Funds on which the EU's economic and social cohesion policy hinges, in order to allow Greece to advance payment appropriations, with no budgetary impact in the period 2014-2020.  The latest agreement between Greece and the European institutions, with the support of the IMF, has allowed Greece to remain in the eurozone and the eurozone to preserve itself. The EP's broad support for the cash advance to Greece is therefore a concrete act, largely supported by progressive forces, to give the Greek people breathing space, so that Greece can move towards a path of sustainable economic growth, based on the creation of new jobs and the attractiveness of new investment.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. Today, contrary to my group's line, I voted in favour of the report on general provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds: specific measures for Greece, because I am genuinely concerned about helping the crisis-hit country – but aid that is coming to people, families and communities. No help that only saves banks and bankers. The money arrives through the Structural Funds and can make investments possible across the board. That helps Greece, it helps its citizens.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not vote in favour of the report in this form. Greece deserves Europe's help. Nevertheless, a basic requirement is that disbursed funds are also used efficiently in Greece.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report, given Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis and consequently is in difficulties to co-finance the investments of European Structural and Investment Funds. The modification moreover does not imply any changes in the Multiannual Financial Framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments. The proposal consists of frontloading payment appropriations and is budgetary neutral over the 2014-2020 period.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. The liquidity problems of the Athens government are jeopardizing the financing of all projects for the period 2014-2020.  That is why I voted for this report, which includes a derogation from the pre-financing and co-financing of projects financed by the Cohesion Funds and European Structural Funds for the benefit of Greece, in order to support it in the economic and social situation in which it finds itself.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. The specific measures for Greece are to pre-finance and co-finance Greek operational programmes, so that Greece can benefit from European structural and investment funds, without having to advance sums it does not have to make. Co-financing, for example, will reach a rate of 100% for the 2007-2013 programmes. At this level of co-financing, it is more appropriate to talk about a "gift" to Greece than to co-financing. It is clear that this particular regime is at the expense of the other Member States that contribute to the EU budget. It may also prompt other Member States to call for similar measures. Above all, the debates in committee have highlighted the risk that these funds will be allocated to programmes aimed at facilitating the reception and integration of illegal migrants on Greek territory. In which case, far from promoting the development of Greece, these funds will be used to impoverish and impoverish the whole of Europe at the same time.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, by released European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, amending cohesion policy provisions and increasing EU funding to 100% in 2007-2013 (eliminating the need for co-financing), immediately disbursing 5% of the budget and improving pre-financing conditions for projects in 2015 and 2016 , thus providing liquidity to the Greek government. These funds do not occur under the memorandums, although the negotiation process and questions about the government's solvency had blocked some items.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as Greece has been very affected by the consequences of the on-going financial and economic crisis. Greece is currently in difficulties when it comes to co-financing EU investments such as European Structural and Investment Funds.  The modification does not imply any changes in the EU budget's annual ceilings for commitments and payments. Instead, the plan will mean frontloading payment appropriations. In this sense it is budgetary neutral over the 2014-2020 period.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees an increased advance payment, a 95% co-financing ceiling and the abolition of national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  As a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these exceptional but important measures to amend the common rules governing the implementation of the ESIF, to provide immediate liquidity to Greece and help the country make full use of available EU funding, to finance investment and encourage economic growth and job creation. For the 2007 to 2013 programming period there will be an early release of the remaining payments normally held until the closure of the programmes in addition to an increase of the maximum co-financing rates for the period from 95% up to 100%. The Commission also propose to increase the rate of pre-financing for certain EU programmes for the 2014-2020 period. It is important to note that the proposal will not have any impact on the overall allocations under the MFF to Greece or to any other Member State. I believe that while these measures are exceptional the situation in Greece warrants such a proactive response and will hopefully make a difference to its citizens in the short and long term.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report due to the fact that Greece has been affected by the financial crisis in a very unique manner. The country has to face liquidity shortages and a major lack of public funds available for the public investment needed in order to foster a sustainable recovery. It is vital that the lack of liquidity and of public funds in Greece does not hinder investment under programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund and by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). It is of the utmost importance that we support our fellow Member State in order to ensure it is able to make a sustainable recovery.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees an increased advance payment, a 95% co-financing ceiling and the abolition of national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremictional to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment). It is therefore important to stress that this is a unique, one-off step, which in no way can set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Greece's dire financial situation, compounded by lies by the Tsipras government, lack of liquidity and lack of public funds, has hampered the implementation of investment projects partially financed by the EU. Also, at the EU summit on 12 July 2015, the Heads of State and Government decided to change the common rules governing the implementation of the five European Structural and Investment Funds to provide emergency liquidity to Greece and to help the country take full advantage of available EU funding. These common provisions pave the way for a new programme of support for Greece to regain credibility and sustainability. Although not in favour of the policy pursued by the government of the day, I believe that the Greek people should not be doubly sanctioned and that the return to growth also requires an investment policy in the country. It is for these different reasons that I have decided to support this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The financial crisis in Greece has hit real people who were utterly blameless in the global collapse of financial institutions.  These proposed measures are to be welcomed and it is essential that the funds become available at the earliest possible opportunity.  I therefore voted in favour of this report under the simplified procedure.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, by released European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, amending cohesion policy provisions and increasing EU funding to 100% in 2007-2013 (eliminating the need for co-financing), immediately disbursing 5% of the budget and improving pre-financing conditions for projects in 2015 and 2016 , thus providing liquidity to the Greek government. These funds do not occur under the memorandums, although the negotiation process and questions about the government's solvency had blocked some items.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council establishing common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and the setting of general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in view of the specific measures for Greece, as I consider the proposal to be commission is very well structured, and recognises the real problems currently facing the EU. I also support an accelerated procedure to show the solidarity of the entire European Union towards Greece, and to achieve the need in question without much formality. Such a thing represents a new opportunity for Greece and its government, as the emergency requires extraordinary measures. In addition, it is also necessary to ensure the continuation of investments foreseen under individual programmes.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is the situation in Greece. It is a package of measures to provide additional aid to Greece to the tune of two billion euros for the years 2015 and 2016.  This choice of the Commission is questionable. On the one hand, we do not know how the Greek government will make use of these funds. Thus, it is very likely that some of them will be allocated to the reception facilities of immigrants. On the other hand, other Member States can be expected to apply for the same preferential regime. Moreover, it has been a while since the Greek government was unable to resolve the crisis despite EU aid.  Together with my colleagues from the National Front, we believe that the only viable solution for Greece is a concerted exit from the eurozone. This is absolutely necessary for the Greek government to have sufficient leeway to turn the country's economy around. So far, Greece has plunged into a lasting crisis that makes it financially and politically increasingly dependent on the European authorities.  We have tabled several amendments to ensure that these elements are taken into account. These were not adopted.  I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Mihaylova report on 'specific measures for Greece'. The initiative is part of a package following the decisions of last July's EU summit on Greece. With this vote, Parliament supported the European Commission's proposal to provide emergency liquidity to Greece. This fast-track vote was essential given the urgency of the situation in Greece and the risk that greece could see many ongoing projects buried. In addition, these measures will be fiscally neutral over the entire 2014-2020 period, as they consist of an adjustment of funding conditions.  However, I believe that in the future the European Parliament will have to be more involved upstream in order not to have its prerogatives cut. It will also need to ensure that the funds are used properly by ensuring that they are well fuelling the real economy.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the consequences of the financial crisis are putting Greece in an exceptional fiscal position.  It is therefore necessary for the country to retain access to liquidity in order to invest under EU-supported programmes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained on this proposal. I am aware of the catastrophic situation of the Greek economy, of the poverty of the people and of the many individual fates that have lost everything during and after the crisis. However, I do not believe that more money from unused EU pots will contribute to a sustainable solution in the long term. Greece needs, first and foremost, structural reforms and fiscal consolidation so that markets can regain confidence in the country, not just more money. Furthermore, I believe that unused funds should be repaid to the paying Member States aliquot.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The proposed modification does not imply any changes in the Multiannual Financial Framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments, however, given the urgent support needed in Greece, it ensures that the available EU funding is effectively used for investments on the ground and reaches beneficiaries as rapidly as possible.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal of 17 July 2015 provides for facilitation for Greece to finance projects under the five European Structural and Investment Funds. 1) Final payments for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework can be made prematurely, even without the necessary final documentation. 2) The co-financing obligation for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework is no longer required by the Greek side. 3) An advance of up to EUR 2 billion will be granted for programmes under the current financial framework. The critical points of the Commission's proposal include control over the appropriate use of funds, budgetary neutrality, the lack of administrative capacity of Greek authorities to implement programmes and equal treatment with other EU countries. I reject the Commission's proposal because neither the third aid package of EUR 86 billion agreed at the euro summit on 12 July 2015 nor this additional package of measures are the right medicine for Greece. Rather, we must face the truth: Greece is completely uncompetitive. Although a debt cut has already taken place with economically correct accounting, Greece cannot be healthy until it leaves the monetary union. Only such a step is a prerequisite for international competitiveness. In the transition process, the EU can help and thus show its solidarity.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds: a specific measure for Greece is an exceptional measure aimed at providing immediate support to Greece by giving it access to union cohesion policy funds, which are still available from the 2007-2013 programming period, and their use before the end of 2015, and therefore the adoption of this Regulation was urgent and I voted in favour of the proposal. This is a measure that should help Greece get the economy going, not put the country into chaos, as we have been used to from the past. After years of hard policy cuts, we have got our hands on a document that talks about the positive impact of public investment on the economy. It is a pity that this sheer banality has not been known to European leaders and their "experts" before. Especially as the world watched the Greek economy sink to an imaginary bottom, and the Troika's leaders continually undermined its foundations. Given Greece's plight, there is now a paradoxical situation in which Greece is unable to pay into the Structural Funds, but urgently needs money from them in order for the Greek economy to flourish. The measure taken should help Greece to bridge the problem.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees an increased advance payment, a 95% co-financing ceiling and the abolition of national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The point of the proposal is that aid from the various European financial funds to Greece can be used for the country before the end of 2015, which I think is fair, so I voted in favour. Greece would already receive these funds from the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund, and the amendment concerns speed and, to some extent, the facilitation of co-financing.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this measure, which aims to provide support to Greece, so that it can benefit, by the end of 2015, from EU funding under cohesion policy funds. The aim is to allow the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the operational programmes for the period 2007-2013 to 100% so as to allow a faster recovery of the Greek economy.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Structural funds are framed by a set of budgetary procedures and rules that require states to finance part of the projects, with the rest co-financed by the Structural Funds. This share varies depending on the level of development of the regions. In the Greek budgetary situation, due to enormous European budgetary pressures, it is impossible to provide this necessary participation for the release of European funds, however small. This is a paradox: it is difficult for Greeks to use European funds because European budgetary rules prevent them from taking out the necessary share of the projects financed. With this new proposal, structural financing will now be able to cover 100%, which represents a saving of 2 billion euros for the Greek Treasury. The 5% reserve on European funds can also be released, which brings in an estimated 500 million euros in cash. Finally, pre-financing rates for the next budget period are increased. I supported these new rules, but I regret that they were adopted after the blackmail imposed on the Greek people last July. The funds should have been released much earlier instead of being used as a bargaining chip for shameful blackmail.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the specific measures for Greece.  Uncertainty hangs over the true effectiveness of these measures. Co-financing rates have already been raised several times in favour of Greece and, despite this, the Greek government remains unable to provide a financial contribution for projects co-financed by the EU. Indeed, we can no longer talk about co-financing if the Member State's contribution falls to 0%. These are no longer structural funds but grants to Greece at the expense of other Member States that contribute to the EU budget.  On the contrary, these proposals risk making the Greek economy even more dependent on funds from the EUROPEAN Union budget and may prompt other Member States to call for similar measures in their favour. In addition, the ENL Group's amendments were all rejected, including the one which proposed that the initial pre-financing should not be used under any circumstances for programmes aimed at facilitating the reception and integration of illegal migrants on Greek territory.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives money to money lost to Greece, which will be unable to repay it given its appalling debt ratio. The EU continues to flee forward instead of seeing the failure of the eurozone and its austerity policy.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR recognises the serious economic situation faced by Greece and its unique liquidity crisis. We therefore voted in favour of a Commission proposal to address this through the front-loading of regional development funds already allocated to Greece to provide rapid investment and support jobs and growth.  This measure is limited to Greece alone, will not impact on other Member States and does not entail any new money during the current multiannual financial framework. Increased payments in 2015 and 2016 will be offset within the current financial period so that no increase to the agreed budget is necessary. All of which means no additional money from European taxpayers, simply the release of resources already allocated. This measure is not about the future of Greece, the future of regional development funding or about the migration crisis. A change in approach to all these is clearly needed. Engaging with the amendments proposed by other political groups – whatever their individual merits – risked slowing down the legislative process significantly and the issues they raise are simply too big to be debated in any appropriate sense within this very specific proposal. We therefore voted against all amendments to this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The exceptional situation in Greece in recent years has made it necessary to address with specific measures the problems of lack of liquidity and public funds by the Greek Government, so as not to hinder investments under the programmes financed by the ERDF, the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EF). The Commission therefore proposes that the Common Provisions Regulation for these funds be amended to adopt various financial measures to make the conditions for implementation of the operational programmes and projects linked to these Structural Funds in Greece more flexible. By agreeing with these measures, we voted in favour of it.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal of 17 July 2015 provides for facilitation for Greece to finance projects under the five European Structural and Investment Funds. 1) Final payments for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework can be made prematurely, even without the necessary final documentation. 2) The co-financing obligation for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework is no longer required by the Greek side. 3) An advance of up to EUR 2 billion will be granted for programmes under the current financial framework. The critical points of the Commission's proposal include control over the appropriate use of funds, budgetary neutrality, the lack of administrative capacity of Greek authorities to implement programmes and equal treatment with other EU countries. I reject the Commission's proposal because neither the third aid package of EUR 86 billion agreed at the euro summit on 12 July 2015 nor this additional package of measures are the right medicine for Greece. Rather, we must face the truth: Greece is completely uncompetitive. Although a debt cut has already taken place with economically correct accounting, Greece cannot be healthy until it leaves the monetary union. Only such a step is a prerequisite for international competitiveness. In the transition process, the EU can help and thus show its solidarity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation addresses liquidity problems and the lack of public investment to support growth and employment in Greece, given its current exceptional situation. Not only would this not only mean halting economic growth in Greece, but it would also have an impact on the economic and economic situation of the whole EU. The measures will allow funds from the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund to be made available to beneficiaries as soon as possible. Advance payments in the form of additional pre-financing of cohesion policy operational programmes for 2014-2020 under the Investment for Growth and Jobs goal and programmes financed by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in Greece will be possible in individual programmes. At the same time, we will allow the ceiling for the cumulative sum of pre-financing and interim payments to reach 100%, and for the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes for the Convergence and Regional competitiveness and employment objectives in Greece to be increased to 100%.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions for the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions for the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund, with regard to specific measures for Greece, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 5/10/2015.  However, in reality with one hand the European Union gives funds to the NSRF, which Greece is entitled to anyway, and with the other hand takes them back double and triple. Moreover, according to European Commission data, more than 40% of the European funds allocated to Greece go directly back to the hard core countries of the European Union, such as the Netherlands, for the purchase of industrial equipment, raw materials, consumer goods and so on.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. We have always opposed the specific measures proposed for Greece and the misuse of European funds. This is about using funds to support growth and job creation to help a country!  This text is all the more absurd because it has been fast-tracked in Parliament, depriving MEPs, and therefore the peoples of Europe, of the right to amend this text! The European Commission is using these funds as an infusion that keeps feeding a country unable to survive: rather than recognising that Greece is on the brink because of European policies, it is freely distributed money in the hope that it will get away with it.  We oppose this free distribution, without controls or criteria, of European money.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the consequences of the current economic and financial crisis in Greece is certainly the lack of liquidity and public funds for investment aimed at fostering and strengthening the country's recovery. It is important that the lack of these funds does not stand in the way of investment under the various cohesion policy programmes for the period 2014-2020. I consider the decision taken by the Commission to amend the regulation laying down common provisions to be fundamental and to apply the simplified procedure which will allow the regulation to enter into force as soon as possible.  The aim of this change is to support and facilitate a rapid recovery of the economic system to Greece by using EU funding by the end of 2015.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution today because it only amplifies Greece's debt process and does not offer a plausible solution to the Greek country's economic crisis.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. A few months after Greece was forced to impose a new diktat by its creditors, it is now indisputable that the solution found has not solved anything. The third aid plan has mainly enabled the country to meet its deadlines and the need for liquidity is still strong.  To address, at least in part, this liquidity crisis, the European Commission has submitted to Parliament for approval a proposal to use the European Structural Funds (FEDER, ESF, Cohesion Fund, FEAMP) to revitalise the real economy in Greece. This emergency response is welcome. Indeed, the European cohesion policy is one of the only genuine Community policies of investment, solidarity, and sometimes even redistribution. It is more than necessary to mitigate the disastrous effects of austerity on the ground: rampant increases in poverty, weakening of health and education systems.  In approving this report, I voted for immediate aid to the Greeks. But our action would be futile if it merely "picked up the pieces". On the contrary, it must address the root causes of the Greek crisis and thus be accompanied by a real reorientation of the European Union's macroeconomic policy.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report does nothing to contribute to a long-term improvement in the situation in Greece. That is why I do not support this report. A truly meaningful aid to the Greek people can only lie in leaving the eurozone.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as Greece needs further support to assist with economic recovery.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Writing. The FDP deputies abstained in the final vote. We do indeed support the basic objective of the Commission's proposal to mobilise investment funds for Greece. However, the reduction in the co-financing share from 5% to 0% risks creating false incentives, which can ultimately lead to misinvestment. We reject this.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. As a result of European intransigence, Greece now faces a shortage of liquidity and a lack of public funds available to finance the necessary investments.  In order not to hinder investment in programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (FEAMP), the Commission has proposed amending the Common Provisions Regulation. The proposal thus allows the prepayment of EUR 2,025,600 and the elimination of the need for national co-financing through the application of a maximum co-financing rate of 100% for eligible expenditure, which should represent savings of almost EUR 2 billion for the Greek budget.  Given the urgency of the situation, I vote for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is the situation in Greece. It is a package of measures to provide additional aid to Greece to the tune of two billion euros for the years 2015 and 2016.  This choice of the Commission is questionable. On the one hand, we do not know how the Greek government will make use of these funds. Thus, it is very likely that some of them will be allocated to the reception facilities of immigrants. On the other hand, other Member States can be expected to apply for the same preferential regime. Moreover, it has been a while since the Greek government was unable to resolve the crisis despite EU aid.  At the National Front, we believe that the only viable solution for Greece is a concerted exit from the eurozone. This is absolutely necessary for the Greek government to have sufficient leeway to turn the country's economy around. So far, Greece has plunged into a lasting crisis that makes it financially and politically increasingly dependent on the European authorities.  So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and the Council laying down common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds, which provide for specific measures for Greece.  It is essential that the lack of liquidity and public funds resulting from the serious financial crisis in Greece does not impede investment under these programmes, which is essential to the country's economic recovery.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The financial crisis in Greece is compounded by a lack of public funds and a liquidity shortage that must be addressed immediately. I therefore voted in favour of this measure to transfer funds to provide pre-financing for certain job-related programmes in Greece.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the face of the glaring lack of liquidity in the Greek economy and public funds, it was necessary to adopt an exceptional measure to help finance investments supported by European cohesion funds and essential for a sustainable recovery.  The conditions for growth must not be unreasonably translated into socially unsustainable policies. It is essential to empower everyone to work, create and undertake. The role of the state, and therefore of politics, is to ensure a fair redistribution of prosperity, taking into account the work factor, risk-taking, responsibilities, social justice, etc.  We must be careful not to dehumanize society by making decisions that do not jeopardize the future.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis. It faces a critical lack of public funds and consequently is in difficulties to co-finance the investments of European Structural and Investment Funds. Therefore the EC had come up with the proposal to provide additional pre-financing in the current financial period (2014-2020), as well as to increase - to 100% - the co-financing rate for 2007-2013 operational programmes. This will allow Greece – in addition to the frontloading of EUR 2 025,600 mn and possible savings for the Greek budget of close to EUR 2 bn - to finish ongoing projects and to reimburse beneficiaries. I fully support the report on common provisions of the European Structural and Investment Fund with regard to specific measures for Greece and that is why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Greece is at risk of a lack of liquidity as a result of the financial crisis and a lack of public resources for public investment essential for a sustainable recovery. In order not to prevent programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) from being carried out, the Commission proposes that the EP and the Council amend Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down general provisions on these funds with regard to specific measures for Greece. The proposed amendment is an exceptional measure aimed at providing immediate support to Greece in order to have access to and use the EU funds still available from the cohesion policy programming period 2007-2013 before the end of 2015. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to adopt specific measures for Greece through cohesion policy. As a result of the financial crisis and the austerity policy imposed by the troika, Greece is suffering from serious liquidity problems. This proposal calls for mobilising an additional EUR 2 billion of cohesion policy funds for Greece, with zero co-financing, with Europe putting together all the sums. These are no longer structural funds but grants to Greece at the expense of other Member States, which risk making the Greek economy even more dependent on the EU and prompting other Member States to call for similar measures. The European Union is not seeking a lasting solution to this crisis and is not questioning the devastating effects of its policy on the Greek issue. Its only response is to provide additional funds to a state that fails to manage its own budget with the constraints imposed on it. The Commission should stop treating cohesion policy funds as emergency funds and stop making the Greek economy dependent on structural funds.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report in the face of the pressing financial situation of Greece, a Member State shaken by liquidity problems and lack of public funds. I would like to say that it is essential that this lack of liquidity and public funds in Greece does not prevent investment under the programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). Given the exceptional nature of the situation, I believe that the European Union should seek to intervene with specific measures, simplified procedural treatment and that it should be operational as soon as possible, in order to contribute to the overall aid effort to Greece.  I support the amendments to the Common Provisions Regulation in this report, in view of its objective of supplanting the lack of liquidity in the Greek economy and boosting investment in the short term, enabling the rapid launch of a larger number of projects.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to adopt specific measures for Greece to help Greece use the structural funds to compensate for its inability to co-finance public investment projects. For example, it is proposed to mobilise an additional EUR 2 billion over two years. The counterpart to the payment of these sums is a mad austerity denounced by all the serious economists of the world as well as by the most orthodox institutions, such as the IMF or the World Bank. Aid to Greece has fed a bottomless well, and this in sheer loss.  To vote in favour of this text would be to give a blank answer to the troika's disastrous policy. As long as Greece does not regain its national currency, this financial infusion will be doomed to failure. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Greece has been very much affected by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis. It faces a critical lack of public funds and consequently is in difficulties to co-finance the investments of European Structural and Investment Funds. I voted in favour of the report as it does not imply any changes in the Multiannual Financial Framework annual ceilings for commitments and payments. The proposal consists of frontloading payment appropriations and is budgetary neutral over the 2014-2020 period. It also proposes to provide an additional initial pre-financing for 2014-2020 cohesion policy operational programmes under the Investment for Growth and Jobs Goal and for programmes financed from the EMFF in Greece.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the MIHAYLOVA report, which aims to facilitate access to EU funds for Greece.  This Member State has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a very special way. The country faces a lack of liquidity and a lack of public funds available to finance the investments needed to promote a sustainable recovery.  In this context, the Commission's proposal provides for additional pre-financing for operational programmes under cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. It also increases the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% with regard to the "convergence" and "regional competitiveness and employment" objectives in Greece. Although I have given my full support to this solidarity initiative, it must nevertheless be made clear that these are exceptional measures adopted in a particular context. Indeed, European funds should not be seen by the Member States as a simple piggy bank at their disposal, but rather as a means of implementing policies decided at European level. If solidarity is to be at the rendezvous, responsibility remains de rigueur.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the green light for certain specific measures for Greece, a country particularly hard hit by the consequences of the financial crisis.  The lack of liquidity and public investment funds preventse, in fact, a sustainable recovery. In view of the exceptional nature of the situation, we believe that specific measures should be taken to support new investments in the programmes financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. The aim is to provide for additional pre-financing of cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020, under the 'Investment for growth and employment' objective and the programmes supported by the EMFF, allowing the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and bringing the co-financing rate of operational programmes for the period 2007-2013 for the convergence objectives to 100% , regional competitiveness, employment.  We note the urgency of the support requested and, as a result, we have decided to apply a simplified procedure to the regulation without amendments, which should contribute to the overall effort to help Greece, allowing the regulation to enter into force as soon as possible.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential that the lack of liquidity and public funds in Greece does not constitute an obstacle to investment under programmes financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund, as well as by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). As a result, the Commission has proposed amending the Regulation laying down common provisions in order to provide for additional pre-financing of the cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 and to allow the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100%. Therefore, since Parliament has decided to apply a simplified procedure to the regulation in question without amendments, which should contribute to the overall effort to help Greece and allow the regulation to enter into force as soon as possible, I have decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will provide additional pre-financing for 2014-2020 cohesion policy operational programmes under the Investment for Growth and Jobs Goal in Greece.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that Greece's economic and social situation is a very specific, delicate and, above all, urgent one. The lack of liquidity of the Athens government is very seriously affecting the implementation of the various projects started during the 2007-2013 budget year and jeopardises the financing of any projects for the period 2014-2020. In these circumstances, offering a 100% EU pre-financing and co-financing exemption, these initiatives will help to complete projects and start new ones, while unlocking around EUR 2 billion from Greece's national budget. I believe that only through this kind of complementary and situation-specific measures can we help Greece overcome this crisis by ensuring, through the measures proposed in this report, that the European funds, but also the Greek budget, are used correctly and efficiently.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adjustment of the conditions for drawing on the Structural Funds for Greece, because I believe that Greece needs our solidarity at a time when it is facing a severe economic crisis. Moreover, it is a budget-neutral solution, which does not mean new expenditure on the EU budget, but works with the funds already allocated to Greece in the EU budget. It will be the Commission's task to ensure that they are properly used. I believe that we must help Greece, but at the same time demand compliance with the agreed conditions. The government needs to manage the allocated funds very responsibly, and in this way, too, it has strengthened confidence in the country's economy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it has serious consequences for lower-income members of society, such as fishing workers. Furthermore, this does not lead to any long-term improvement in Greece's situation.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This proposal by the European Commission aims to amend the general regulation of EU funds to provide specific measures for Greece.  These specific measures aim to facilitate the implementation of European Cohesion Funds for Greece in the current liquidity crisis.  I voted in favour of this proposal which, thanks to a simple relaxation of the existing mechanisms, gives Greece an essential liquidity contribution so as not to hinder the investment efforts carried out with the help of European funds (FEDER, ESF) so far.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to help Greece, which suffers from the aftermath of the financial crisis, get back on its feet as soon as possible, encourage economic recovery, investment and job creation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The financial crisis and EU austerity measures have been an unbearable burden for some countries and have had particularly negative consequences. Greece is one of those countries, which has been hit hard by the crisis.  Appropriate assistance measures are needed to help the country stabilise the situation. However, it is necessary to ensure that such special measures are temporary and exceptional. In addition, it is essential that these measures are also available to other Member States, but only in certain strictly regulated cases, in an extraordinary situation requiring special measures.  Particular attention must be paid to the absorption of support from EU funds and investment conditions. It is therefore appropriate to increase the level of initial pre-financing for cohesion policy programmes and programmes supported by the EMFF. Another important aspect is to increase the maximum co-financing rates by up to 100%.  It should be noted that the convergence and regional competitiveness and employment objectives must be key factors in the implementation of specific measures.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The increase in the pre-financing of the EU 'structural funds' in Greece concerns only large business groups and not the relief of popular needs. On the other hand, the disbursement of pre-financing is an integral and condition for the implementation of the 3rd unpopular memorandum of the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government and the "quartet" to support the profitability of monopolies, implementation of the barbaric measures provided for: completion of the demolition of the public insurance system and industrial relations, liberalisation of collective redundancies and the strike action, new reductions in wages and pensions , taxation of popular income, the dismantling of poor farming, privatisations, further dismantling of public health-welfare and education. On the basis of the above criteria, the JRC voted against the relevant EU regulation. The people have experience of the 2007-2013 funds that were cut off from monopolies at a time when the working-class people were going bankrupt. The only solution for the people is to organise the fight not to pass the fire measures, to recover the losses, on the road to breaking with the EU, their monopolies and their power.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given Greece's economic and financial situation, I welcome the proposal to increase funding for cohesion policy programmes with the aim of employment and growth. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The consequences of the economic crisis have posed significant challenges to the Greek economy, particularly due to the liquidity shortages and the lack of public funds available. The increased pre-financing and co-financing rates proposed by the Commission are an immediate and necessary response given the urgency of the situation. However, the increased financial support must be accompanied by measures ensuring fiscal prudence and calling for responsible economic policy. This is an important precondition for the long-term and sustainable impact of investment, as well as a precondition for true European solidarity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Greece has been particularly affected by the effects of the financial crisis, which has been accompanied by years of constant declines in GDP, which has caused a severe lack of liquidity, and public funds needed to stimulate sustainable recovery. The crisis greece has been in for several years requires special measures created exclusively for this country. With the Greek crisis affecting all sectors of the Greek economy, assistance is necessary.  Similarly, paying particular attention to the use of the funds made available to Greece, I welcome paragraph 6 of Article 152, which asks Greece to report on spending within operational programmes by the end of 2016. This is unfortunately an emergency and I believe that stricter controls on the use of funds by national governments, and for the implementation of projects from operational programmes, should be carried out wherever those minimum effects that were foreseen when approving these programmes are not achieved.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Commission proposal aims to adopt specific measures for Greece to help Greece use the structural funds to compensate for its inability to co-finance public investment projects.  For example, it is proposed to mobilise an additional EUR 2 billion over two years. The counterpart to the payment of these sums is a mad austerity denounced by all the serious economists of the world as well as by the most orthodox institutions, such as the IMF or the World Bank. Aid to Greece has fed a bottomless pit and austerity measures have been imposed in sheer waste.  To vote in favour of this text would be to give a blank answer to the troika's disastrous policy. As long as Greece does not regain its national currency, this financial infusion will be doomed to failure. So I voted against it.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The serious problems of the lack of liquidity as well as the available public resources facing Greece, as a consequence of the economic crisis that the country has been going through in recent years, could create particular problems in the absorption of Community funds in both the previous (2007 - 2013) and the current (2014-2020) programming period, and thus delay or not implement the planned investments in the country. I therefore voted in favour of this report, also recognising the nature of urgency, which aims to adopt specific measures to strengthen the effective use of EUR 35 billion. Eur 1 million earmarked for Greece in the EU budget for the period 2014-2020. I believe that the exceptional measures provided for in the regulation will be able to support the prospect of the best possible absorption of the resources allocated by the European Structural and Investment Funds and thus the achievement of a sustainable recovery of the Greek economy, through the creation of new jobs, as well as the promotion of investment.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the particularly difficult situation in which the Greek economy has found itself in the context of not only the financial but also the wider socio-economic crisis, it is necessary to provide measures that will in a systemic and thoughtful way address the specific problems facing this country. Given the particularly poor situation in Greece's public finances, there is a risk that the funds earmarked for economic growth and the development of less developed EU countries such as Greece will not be used to the extent necessary for economic recovery and the launch of a new investment wave that would allow exit from a closed cycle of illiquidity and recession. It is these funds in the proposals that are the cornerstone of European solidarity and their facilitated and increased availability is a precondition for effective action towards facilitating the difficult Greek situation.  Accordingly, the proposed amendments aimed at increasing the pre-financing level for Greece's cohesion policy programmes, increasing co-financing rates for the 2007-2013 programmes and lifting the payment ceiling for programmes should be commended and supported. Particularly important is the pronounced emphasis on boosting investment and employment, which constitute the most sensitive, but also the most important areas, i.e. the backbone of economic recovery and growth. The envisaged regulatory mechanism should also be supported, which should ensure the actual impact of these funds through strict application deadlines with regard to the Commission.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Given the fact that Greece has been hit by the financial crisis in a unique way and that the lack of liquidity and public funds is hampering investment under programmes funded by the European Union (European Regional Development Fund, European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund and European Fisheries Fund), I support my colleague Mihaylova's report welcoming the European Commission's proposal to amend Regulation No 1999/2013; 1303/2013 The situation in Greece requires exceptional measures such as: increasing the level of initial pre-financing of Greece's cohesion policy programmes and the 2014-2020 European Maritime and Fisheries Fund programme. In addition, co-financing rates of operational programmes from 2007-2013 should be increased to increase regional competitiveness and employment. Expected savings for the Greek budget based on the amendment the Provisions should amount to almost EUR 2 billion, thereby boosting investment and supporting the liquidity of the Greek economy. Consequently, I support the Recommendation of the Fisheries Committee, which underlined the importance of making effective use of additional initial pre-financing in order to reach the beneficiaries as soon as possible and enable them to achieve the investment envisaged.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, Greece has been hit by a deep economic and financial crisis that has been going on for several years. Over time, this crisis has caused a number of liquidity problems and a lack of public funds needed to lift the country's economy. It is essential that this lack of liquidity and public funds does not stand in the way of investment under programmes financed by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF) and the Cohesion Fund, as well as by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF). The Commission has therefore proposed amending the regulation laying down common provisions in order to provide for additional pre-financing of the operational programmes of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and to allow the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100%. I believe that the European Commission's proposal, in addition to being dictated by common sense, can be an important aid to Greece and its people.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed releasing the last 5% of payments to Greece from the EU budget until the closure of the programmes, increasing the maximum co-financing rate to 100%, and making additional initial advances available for 2015 and 2016. I supported the Commission's proposal, provided that this action is extraordinary, one-off and the amendment is budget neutral for the period 2014-2020; it will not entail any changes to the annual ceilings of the Multiannual Financial Framework for commitment and payment appropriations. In addition, the annual breakdown of commitment appropriations for the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund remains unchanged.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of Greece's dire financial situation, the European Commission has proposed using European structural and investment funds.  The country no longer has sufficient liquidity and therefore cannot implement investment projects essential to restarting the country's growth. In this context, this solidarity measure will provide emergency liquidity to the country.  The European Parliament has approved the implementation of these specific measures for Greece. These measures will have a neutral impact on the 2014-2020 budget.  I voted in favour of these provisions, which are in line with the decisions taken by European heads of state last July.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The austerity policies have had terrible impacts on the lives of people, families, businesses and countries intervened by the Troika. Austerity has only created more misery, more poverty, more bankruptcies, more fears, more emigration, more flight of senior staff, more depression and suicides. This happened in Greece, but also in Portugal. We felt for 4 years the hardness of being a minor son of Europe.  Greece has been severely punished during these years. In addition, hundreds of refugees arrive in Greece every day and we almost "demand" the Greek government to deal with it, just because Greece is one of the doors of this United Europe.  We now have the opportunity to help Greece by approving this set of specific measures through European funds. It's not about "giving more money" to Greece. It is a question of anticipating the financing of operational programmes to promote growth and jobs. We know that cohesion policies have been and are fundamental to the countries that have been hit hardest by the crisis. Just as there has been technical assistance from the European institutions in implementing austerity measures, there should also now be when we talk about investments.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece to advance the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. As Greece has been hit hard by the financial crisis, the country has, and still still faces, a shortage of liquidity and a lack of public funds available to finance the investments needed to promote a sustainable recovery.  In this context, the Commission's proposal that we voted on today in Strasbourg provides for additional pre-financing for operational programmes under the cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 under the 'Investment for Growth and Jobs' target, as well as for programmes funded by the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries in Greece.  It also provides that the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments can reach 100%, and allows for a 100% increase in the co-financing rate of operational programmes 2007-2013 with regard to the objectives of "convergence" and "regional competitiveness and employment" in Greece.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Having been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way, Greece is now facing liquidity problems and a lack of public funds available for the investments needed to foster a sustainable economic recovery, thus lacking additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes in the period 2014-2020. This is an exceptional situation requiring exceptional measures, and additional pre-financing is therefore provided for operational cohesion policy programmes for 2014-2020, under the Investment for Growth and Jobs objective and for programmes financed by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund; The proposal also provides for a ceiling of 100% for the cumulative total of pre-financing and interim payments, increasing to 100% the co-financing rate for the operational programmes for the period 2007-2013, under the convergence, regional competitiveness and employment objectives in this country. It should be noted that this solution, which I voted in favour of, requires greece to make a serious commitment effort, which involves speeding up the pace of its payment requests for the programmes concerned before the end of 2016, under penalty of repaying the additional initial pre-financing.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new funding allocated by the European Union aims to promote and support Greece's economic recovery. I agree with the Commission's proposal to amend the Regulation for Greece on common provisions in order to obtain additional funding for the operational programmes of cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020. The amendment would allow the ceiling applicable to the cumulative total of processing and interim payments to be 100%.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, by released European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, amending cohesion policy provisions and increasing EU funding to 100% in 2007-2013 (eliminating the need for co-financing), immediately disbursing 5% of the budget and improving pre-financing conditions for projects in 2015 and 2016 , thus providing liquidity to the Greek government. These funds do not occur under the memorandums, although the negotiation process and questions about the government's solvency had blocked some items

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading for the Greek State to gain short-term advantages in its financing, by advanceing some of the payments budgeted in the 2014-2020 Structural and Cohesion Funds, from the increase in the co-financing ceiling, as well as from the implementation of the outstanding payments under the 2007-2013 framework. It is estimated that these measures will have a positive balance for Greek public finances of around EUR 2 billion, a small share compared to the 260 billion that Greece has had to borrow from the troika institutions (IMF, European Central Bank, and European Commission) in exchange for measures that have deepened the pauperization of Greek society. Moreover, they are not an extra disbursement of the European institutions but a step forward in what was budgeted for the 2018 and 2020 financial years respectively.  Despite this necessary general criticism of European economic policy, the proposal allows the Greek Government to receive extra liquidity in the short term, so, not being a solution in itself to the economic problems arising from the contraction of public spending, I have decided to give my vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it calls for the Commission to create new legislation. I do not recognise the Commission as a legislative body.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Greece has been affected quite severely by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis. With a lack of public funds and, as a result, its difficulties – if not inability – to co-finance the investments of the ESI Funds, it is particularly important to provide this support. I voted in favour of this report, through the simplified procedure, to get the funds where they are most needed without unnecessary delay.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on the European Parliament resolution dealing with the common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds – in the case of specific measures for Greece, I voted in favour of adopting the proposal tabled. The aim of the resolution is to make it possible to increase the initial advance payments for Greece's cohesion policy programmes as part of the Investment for growth and jobs target for the period 2014-2020.  The proposal also provided for an increase to 100 % of the maximum co-financing rate for operational programmes for the period 2007-2013 under the Convergence objective and the Regional competitiveness and employment objective. Under these revised rules, savings of almost €2 billion can be expected in the Greek budget. The adjustment should also help address the significant liquidity shortage in the Greek economy and encourage investment, which will help to initiate more projects.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The financial crisis has led to a continuing negative growth rate in Greece, serious liquidity problems and a lack of public investment funds essential to boost growth and job creation.  As an exceptional measure, in view of the state of emergency, the Commission has proposed the application of three elements to ensure that available EU funds from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund (CF) and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund (EMFF) are used effectively for investments on the ground and reach beneficiaries as quickly as possible.  At the plenary session, I supported a proposal to raise the level of initial pre-financing of funds available for the period 2014-2020 for cohesion policy programmes under the Growth and Jobs Investment Target and EMFF-backed programmes to directly encourage investment for the efficient use of investments on the ground and for the beneficiary itself to receive funding, as quickly as possible.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for an EP legislative resolution, which takes into account the consequences of the financial crisis affecting Greece and the exceptional situation in Greece, which needs to be addressed by specific measures. The country is currently facing liquidity shortages and public funds available for public finances, which are needed for investments under programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund. The Commission has therefore proposed to amend the Common Provisions Regulation to provide additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for 2014-2020 and to allow the ceiling for the cumulative sum of pre-financing and interim payments to reach 100% and the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes for the Convergence and Regional competitiveness and employment objectives in Greece to be increased to 100%.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Greece has been significantly affected by the financial and economic crisis as the country faces severe liquidity shortages and a lack of available public funds for public investment needed to promote a sustainable economic recovery. The proposed amendment to the Regulation constitutes an exceptional measure aimed at immediately assisting Greece so that it can access and use the Union funding for cohesion policy still available from the 2007-2013 programming period before the end of 2015.  The lack of liquidity and public funds in Greece must not hinder investment under programmes supported by the European Structural and Investment Funds, which is why I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the package of measures in favour of Greece, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission aimed at allowing the actual expenditure of a large proportion of the European Structural and Investment Funds and the agricultural funds allocated to Greece until 2020. The aim is, on the one hand, to speed up the implementation of European funds to help Greece use the funds still available for the 2007-2013 programming period by 2017, and, on the other hand, to help the Greek country meet the requirements for access to funds in the new 2014-2020 programming. This is a one-off measure justified by greece's particular economic situation, which does not provide for a further disbursement from the EU budget, since these funds have already been allocated to the country. It is important to note that in order to facilitate the expenditure of these funds, Greece will be allowed EU funding at 100% of the 2007-2013 operational programmes, removing the requirement for national co-financing, which in a country where serious liquidity problems hamper investment would have frustrated the very objectives of cohesion policy.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal of 17 July 2015 provides for facilitation for Greece to finance projects under the five European Structural and Investment Funds. 1) Final payments for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework can be made prematurely, even without the necessary final documentation. 2) The co-financing obligation for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework is no longer required by the Greek side. 3) An advance of up to EUR 2 billion will be granted for programmes under the current financial framework. The critical points of the Commission's proposal include control over the appropriate use of funds, budgetary neutrality, the lack of administrative capacity of Greek authorities to implement programmes and equal treatment with other EU countries. I reject the Commission's proposal because neither the third aid package of EUR 86 billion agreed at the euro summit on 12 July 2015 nor this additional package of measures are the right medicine for Greece. Rather, we must face the truth: Greece is completely uncompetitive. Although a debt cut has already taken place with economically correct accounting, Greece cannot be healthy until it leaves the monetary union. Only such a step is a prerequisite for international competitiveness. In the transition process, the EU can help and thus show its solidarity.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – Greece must comply with the rules, and the European Union must monitor not only this compliance, but also the use of European money.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because Greece's financial crisis has led to negative GDP growth rates in Greece for many years, causing a lack of liquidity and a lack of public funds for public investment needed to foster a sustainable recovery. In order to ensure that Greece has sufficient financial resources to implement the programme, I consider it necessary to raise the level of initial pre-financing of operational programmes with a view to investing in growth and jobs.
