In order to improve the effective use of available funds in Greece to finance operations, regional competitiveness and employment adopted in 2007-2013, the maximum co-financing rate and the cap on payments for programmes at the end of the programming period should be raised. Given the support required, this Regulation should enter into force immediately.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, proposing to increase the level of initial pre-financing of the funding available for the 2014-2020 period for cohesion policy programmes. This will ensure that the available EU funding is used effectively in Greece, and will reach the intended beneficiaries quickly.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 Greece was hit in a special way by the financial crisis. The country is currently facing a lack of liquidity and public funds needed for public investments that would ensure a sustainable recovery. In its proposal, the Commission therefore seeks additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes under the Investment for Growth and Jobs target for the period 2014-2020, as well as for programmes funded by the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in Greece. The Commission proposal also provides for a ceiling of 100 per cent for the total amount of pre-financing and interim payments, as well as an increase in the co-financing rate to 100 per cent, for operational programmes between 2007 and 2011 for convergence and regional competitiveness and employment targets. Given the urgency of the situation, the Regional Development Committee adopted this report through a simplified procedure without corrections. Given that this procedure will allow regulation to enter into force as soon as possible, and to provide Greece with the assistance it badly needs, I fully agree with the Committee's position.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. In fact, I do not agree that Greece should have special advantages in the use of Eu funds. This is not only unfair to other EU countries, but also directly motivates Greece to behave more irresponsibly. If, for example, Greece has not been able to spend the allocated EU funds even at the current levels of cofinancing, increasing the co-financing rate to 100% is likely to lead to even less efficiency in the money spent and even more spending just for spending itself. Moreover, Euro funds do not help Greece (or other countries), they only distort the economy, teach foreign money dependencies and discourage autonomy and productivity.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds: specific measures for Greece. The situation in Greece is serious as the country faces a severe liquidity shortage and a lack of public funds available for public investment. Many EU-funded programmes are not implemented in Greece due to a lack of liquidity. It is therefore necessary to take the necessary measures to free up funds. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Budgets, I welcome the fact that the Commission's proposal is financially compatible with the multiannual financial framework and will not affect the 2014-2020 budget.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 In the context of the negative growth rates presented in Greece as a result of the economic crisis and the harsh neoliberal memorandum measures imposed, the Commission through its proposal raises the need for specific measures in the case of the use of European funds by Greece. For the period 2014-2020 Greece is to receive an amount of 20bn from the European Funds.  However, due to the harsh memorandum measures and the objective impossibility of implementing the conditions for the use of several funds, Greece risks losing 2 billion euros from the 2007-2013 financial period. That is why the Commission proposes to allow it to take the necessary steps immediately to ensure co-financing from the European funds.  As ACPL we voted in favour of the Commission's proposal as drastic measures to finance programmes in Greece are necessary because of the huge liquidity problems facing the country, which is mainly due to the stifling memory measures imposed on it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Greece currently needs all possible liquidity which will not be accompanied by additional measures. Above all, it must be ensured that the funds are actually allocated to development, which is not guaranteed through this report. In any case, this pre-financing is only a drop in the ocean of economic disaster experienced by Greece.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 17 July 2015, following the conclusions of the European Summit of 12 July 2015, the European Commission presented its proposal for amendments to the common provisions of the 2014-2020 programming period in order to provide the liquidity needed for the implementation of Greek cohesion programmes. The proposal foresees an increased advance payment, a 95% co-financing ceiling and the abolition of national co-financing for Greece. The Commission considers these measures necessary because the crisis in Greece has led to continued negative growth indicators, liquidity problems, a resumption of growth and a lack of public resources to create jobs.  I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal, but I think it is important to emphasise a few aspects. Above all, I consider it essential to monitor closely the proper use of extra payments. I would also like to draw attention to the fact that these measures are intremtrious to a number of fundamental principles (e.g. co-financing, subsidiarity, additionality, equal treatment), so it is important to stress that this is a specific one-off step which cannot in any way set a precedent or have an impact on the shaping of the future nature of cohesion policy. Given that the Commission's proposal raises budgetary concerns not only in law and in principle, I therefore consider it necessary to clarify the actual budgetary effects as soon as possible. It is important that the proposals in the Commission's draft do not involve amendments to the MFT and do not affect the cohesion envelope of Greece or the other Member States.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece's situation is exceptional in the effects of the financial crisis in that state. The lack of liquidity and public funds has considerably slowed the implementation of sustainable economic recovery measures.  Once again, I voted in favour of these exceptional measures to provide immediate support to Greece in the form of access to European Union cohesion funds available from 2007-2013.  Greece can access and use these liquiditys, which are so necessary for the functioning of current investment programmes, such as the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Fisheries and Maritime Affairs Fund (EMFF), by the end of 2015. This vote is one of solidarity, and the European Parliament takes responsibility and responds with a measure proportional to the urgent situation of lack of liquidity in Greece.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the issues relating to the financial compatibility of the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending the Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 with common provisions relating to the European Regional Development Fund, to the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries, with general provisions applicable to the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Fund for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries, with regard to specific measures for Greece.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative report. It proposes amending a Regulation, which is an exceptional measure, aimed at providing immediate support to Greece by enabling it to access and use before the end of 2015 the EU funding for cohesion policy still available from the 2007-2013 programming period. The Regulation to be amended is the Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Writing. The FDP deputies abstained in the final vote. We do indeed support the basic objective of the Commission's proposal to mobilise investment funds for Greece. However, the reduction in the co-financing share from 5% to 0% risks creating false incentives, which can ultimately lead to misinvestment. We reject this.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This report is the European Parliament's response to the European Commission's communication of 15 July, in which the Commission granted renewed access to the significant funds greece has at its disposal within the Budget of the European Union. The Commission called the communication "A New Start for Growth and Job Creation in Greece", with funding available at 35 billion for 2014-2020, of which 20 billion will be available from the European Structural and Investment Funds.  The recommendation contains three main activities, namely how to assist Greece, which in principle consist of a zero co-financing rate for Greece, which in addition to the advantages for this Member State of the Union, in this critical situation can contain many dangers. I therefore urge the European Commission to develop strict surveillance mechanisms. I believe that the proposed measures are insufficiently elaborated, and in the long term (even in the short term) of very questionable quality. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, I supported the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund on the general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in respect of specific measures for Greece, as it paves the way for the swift adoption of measures by the Council and their immediate entry into force. The aim is to achieve a more efficient spending of EUR 35 billion allocated to Greece under the EU budget for 2014-2020 through one-off measures.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, by released European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, amending cohesion policy provisions and increasing EU funding to 100% in 2007-2013 (eliminating the need for co-financing), immediately disbursing 5% of the budget and improving pre-financing conditions for projects in 2015 and 2016 , thus providing liquidity to the Greek government. These funds do not occur under the memorandums, although the negotiation process and questions about the government's solvency had blocked some items.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on Mrs Mihayl's report, I voted against it because I believe that the ongoing processes should not be entered in this way. Support to Greece is to be implemented in a completely different way, e.g. by supporting the investment environment or perhaps by redirecting the implementation of certain European projects, for example in the field of energy.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The Commission proposal of 17 July 2015 provides for facilitation for Greece to finance projects under the five European Structural and Investment Funds. 1) Final payments for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework can be made prematurely, even without the necessary final documentation. 2) The co-financing obligation for programmes under the 2007-2013 financial framework is no longer required by the Greek side. 3) An advance of up to EUR 2 billion will be granted for programmes under the current financial framework. The critical points of the Commission's proposal include control over the appropriate use of funds, budgetary neutrality, the lack of administrative capacity of Greek authorities to implement programmes and equal treatment with other EU countries. I reject the Commission's proposal because neither the third aid package of EUR 86 billion agreed at the euro summit on 12 July 2015 nor this additional package of measures are the right medicine for Greece. Rather, we must face the truth: Greece is completely uncompetitive. Although a debt cut has already taken place with economically correct accounting, Greece cannot be healthy until it leaves the monetary union. Only such a step is a prerequisite for international competitiveness. In the transition process, the EU can help and thus show its solidarity.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is my belief that this additional investment will be important for Greece to achieve higher growth in the coming year and so will help a little to make better the lives of its citizens in the short and medium term.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this legislative act, by released European Structural and Investment Funds for Greece, amending cohesion policy provisions and increasing EU funding to 100% in 2007-2013 (eliminating the need for co-financing), immediately disbursing 5% of the budget and improving pre-financing conditions for projects in 2015 and 2016 , thus providing liquidity to the Greek government. These funds do not occur under the memorandums, although the negotiation process and questions about the government's solvency had blocked some items.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour for a balanced mix of measures to increase liquidity and facilitate the financing of projects in Greece.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of these exceptional measures to enable the effective use by the Greek authorities of EUR 35 billion, to support the boost of growth, investment and job creation in Greece. This is a substantial part of our response to the financial crisis in Greece: now we have to ensure that EU funding is used for investments on the ground and reaches beneficiaries as rapidly as possible, in order to create much needed jobs and economic growth. Nevertheless, if Greece doesn’t speed up the pace of its payment applications for the programmes concerned before the end of 2016, it runs the risk of having to reimburse the additional initial pre-financing.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Greece is in a delicate situation, the European Commission's proposal and the regional development committee's decision to use the simplified procedure for this measure clearly indicates the urgency of the measure. While further debate and control in parliament would have been ideal, we are aware of the urgency of the measure and I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. Greece has been affected by the consequences of the financial crisis in a unique way. This has led to an exceptional situation that has been considered necessary to address with specific measures so that the lack of liquidity and public funds does not hinder investments under the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund and EMPF. Support amending the Common Provisions Regulation to, inter alia, provide for additional pre-financing for cohesion policy operational programmes for the period 2014-2020 under the investment in growth and employment objective, as well as allowing the maximum cumulative total limit for pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate of the 2007-2013 operational programmes to 100% of the convergence and competitiveness and employment. This will allow Greece the advance distribution of more than 2,000,000,000 euros and possible savings of about another 2,000,000,000 euros, complete the current projects and reimburse the beneficiaries of the funds, so that they can make the planned investments and be reimbursed immediately after the submission of their payment applications.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I chose to abstain in the vote on Amendment No 2, which states that the EU should allow Greece to withdraw from the euro if it is judged to be one of several carefully tested ways of overcoming Greece's financial situation. In principle, I think the proposal is a good one, but it does not belong in this report, which deals with exceptional measures to provide investment aid to Greece immediately.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is a position of the European Parliament adopted at first reading for the Greek State to gain short-term advantages in its financing, by advanceing some of the payments budgeted in the 2014-2020 Structural and Cohesion Funds, from the increase in the co-financing ceiling, as well as from the implementation of the outstanding payments under the 2007-2013 framework. It is estimated that these measures will have a positive balance for Greek public finances of around EUR 2 billion, a small share compared to the 260 billion that Greece has had to borrow from the troika institutions (IMF, European Central Bank, and European Commission) in exchange for measures that have deepened the pauperization of Greek society. Moreover, they are not an extra disbursement of the European institutions but a step forward in what was budgeted for the 2018 and 2020 financial years respectively.  Despite this necessary general criticism of European economic policy, the proposal allows the Greek Government to receive extra liquidity in the short term, so, not being a solution in itself to the economic problems arising from the contraction of public spending, I have decided to give my vote in favour.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 This report dealt with specific measures to ease the situation in Greece with structural and investment funds. The report itself rightly highlights the structural reforms that are necessary in Greece. Amendment No 2, on the other hand, on which I abstained, referred as an addition to the options that Greece should have. According to the amendment, there should also be a possible withdrawal from the euro area. Greece's euro difference is possible, as the Commission has plans in place to do so.  I believe that the problems of the euro area should be solved by all the countries of the euro area adopting a national currency alongside the euro. As long as this is not possible, individual Member States should be able to withdraw from it. I therefore support the position expressed in the amendment. However, I abstained because I believe that this report was not appropriate to take a position on the future of the euro area.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Greece has been a laboratory for austerity policies. Alexis Tsipras's government has tried to fight on foot against the noose that eurozone heads of state and government have tried to tighten on him. By pushing him to Grexit, he had to accept a scandalous memorandum after shameful blackmail. If there is much to say about this memorandum and whatever one thinks of the decision taken, there is an urgent need for Greece to release these funds. Greece is sorely short of cash and investment and this requires immediate action. The European Parliament has proposed, as part of the Cohesion Policy, the implementation of specific measures for Greece, in order to enable funds to be released quickly. Three exceptional measures are proposed: making available to Greece 5% of immediate payments of funds still blocked, increasing EU funding to 100% for the 2007-2013 financing period (instead of co-financing) and improving the increased pre-financing rate of EUR 1 billion for the 2015 and 2016 projects. I'm obviously voting for.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measures relate to the availability of the 2007-2013 Table funds, amounting to 800 million, financed at 100%, allowing the closure of the projects that were applied for in this area. This measure is so much more relevant considering the financial, economic and social situation of Greece and the delays in the overall allocation of structural cohesion funds in the 2014-2020 Framework. It is understood that this aid is positive and may alleviate the suffering of many people. However, it is only a palliative. In this sense, it is urgent that fundamental measures be taken to restore the Greek economy on a solid basis and in accordance with the will of the Greek people. The situation in Greece confirms our analysis that it is urgent to open a comprehensive process of renegotiation of sovereign debt at European Union level and to hold an intergovernmental conference reviewed by the treaties and in particular the budgetary treaty and eliminate the monetary corset that gives any possibility of alternative and sovereign development. This position and the coherence it obliges, which justified a vote in favour of the above amendments, should not interfere in the sense of solidarity that the Greek people deserve, and we do not intend to block the allocation of EU funds.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the special rules for disbursing money from EU funds to Greece. We are talking about EUR 35 billion that Greece is to receive. This is a side deal between the euro rescuers to accompany the official rescue package. Greece should be allowed to receive this EUR 35 billion without having to pay for the usual co-financing. In addition, the money is to be disbursed as early as 2015 and 2016. This will allow for the greatest degree of irresponsibility. What is supposed to be an investment package to "stimulate" the Greek economy so often will prove to be a gigantic waste. Greece will build escalators to nowhere, stations without track connections and power lines without customers. And you can't even blame him. I refuse to make myself, as an MEP, the vicarious agent of the euro saviours, and I am voting with conviction against this nonsense. Sooner or later it will become clear that the problem with the Greek bailout is that the euro rescuers will eventually run out of other people's money.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds, which contains specific measures relating to Greece. The Commission has proposed in the case of Greece to amend the Structural Funds Allocation Regulation so that additional pre-financing is foreseen for operational programmes financed in the period 2014-2020 under cohesion policy under the Investment for Growth and Employment objective and for programmes supported by the European Maritime And Maritime Affairs Fund in Greece. Another provision is to allow the ceiling for the cumulative total amount of pre-financing and interim payments to be 100 % and to increase the co-financing rate for the 2007-2013 operational programmes aimed at achieving the convergence, regional competitiveness and employment objectives in Greece to 100 %. I believe that the exceptional situation in which Greece finds itself requires exceptional measures, and it is essential that the lack of liquidity and public funds in that country does not hinder investments made under programmes supported by the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund (ESF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Maritime And Maritime Fund (EMFF).

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. For my part, I too voted in favour of the package of specific, exceptional measures to strengthen the effective use of EUR 35 billion. Eur 1 million earmarked for Greece in the EU budget for the period 2014-2020. The additional liquidity in the Greek economy resulting from the amendment of the current regulation is really valuable for the Greek economy, as the abolition of the need for national co-financing will allow the continuation of projects that are currently frozen due to a lack of national resources. The fact that no other European country has suffered as much as Greece from the economic crisis combined with the fact that these special measures are neutral for the European budget, as they do not impose any additional burden, is perhaps the best response to those who are said to be reacting to this decision.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The increase in the pre-financing of the EU 'structural funds' in Greece concerns only large business groups and not the relief of popular needs. On the other hand, the disbursement of pre-financing is an integral and condition for the implementation of the 3rd unpopular memorandum of the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government and the "quartet" to support the profitability of monopolies, the implementation of the barbaric measures they provide for: completion of the demolition of the public insurance system and industrial relations, liberalisation of collective redundancies and the hit of the strike right, new reductions in wages and pensions , taxation of popular income, the dismantling of poor farming, privatisations, further dismantling of public health-welfare and education.  On the basis of the above criteria, the JRC voted against the relevant EU regulation. The people have experience of the 2007-2013 funds that were cut off from monopolies at a time when the working-class people were going bankrupt. The only solution for the people is to organise the fight not to pass the fire measures, to recover the losses, on the road to breaking with the EU, their monopolies and their power.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to DE/ADAM OPEL. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014 - 20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Germany has applied for EUR 6 958 625 to deal with 2692 redundancies.  The blame factor is aimed at emerging markets and competitiveness in the world market. Small car sales have dropped by 25% from 2007/13 in EFTA nations. Personalised services such as careers advice and mobilisation have been mentioned relating to seeking other jobs. There is also a mention of business start-up grants to be given to the beneficiaries. The matter of concern relates to contracting out the personalised services, organisations that provide aid to those who have been made redundant are already in receipt of funding from other funding streams such as the ESF. If this is the factual case then why is the EU happily granting more funding to OPEL? Companies that are not competitive enough must not seek a bailout from the taxpayer to pay for redundancies. UKIP voted against.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Opel's redundancies in one of the German regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the German car manufacturing company Adam-Opel. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis. In Germany, 2 881 workers were dismissed in Adam Opel AG and one supplier as a result of the over-capacity caused by the sharp decline in car sales arising from the global financial crisis.  The social partners established a 'transfer company' to formally employ the workers for one year, and this report states that Adam-Opel will use the maximum 35% of the EGF funds allowed to pay the salaries of the workers in the transfer company (as a 'training allowance').  I have concerns with the way in which some German companies have used the EGF in this way, as I believe it is the responsibility of the company itself to meet these costs, and the EGF should be used to provide additional support. Despite this concern I support the dismissed workers receiving the benefits associated with the mobilisation of the EGF, so I voted in favour.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. \u2012 Flanders, where I was elected, was once known for its car assembly. From the Minerva automobile, over Ford Genk, to Renault Vilvoorde, Audi in Vorst, Opel in Antwerp, Volvo in Ghent and so on. Unfortunately, these factories on Volvo and Audi are closed. Certainly the closure of the Opel factory, in my hometown Antwerp, arrived very hard. General Motors preferred the 'motherland' of Opel, Germany and without any schadenfreude ('Schadenfreude' is said in German I think) I can speak here of a certain irony that the EU is now being called to help with the closure of this Opel factory. Flanders is a region characterised by a service economy. But I also see a future for anchoring the industry. The governments in my country, the Belgian and Flemish, must finally reduce the burden on businesses and workers substantially.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the recent redundancies at Adam Opel AG, Germany received a financial contribution from the Fund of EUR 6,958,623 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim here is to help the reintegration of workers who are suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, particularly in the European automotive industry, whose car sales have fallen dramatically and reached their lowest point in twenty years. It should be noted that manufacturers of small and medium-sized cars, whose prices are in the middle range, are the most affected by these developments.  Germany is planning effective and adapted measures to find new work for laid-off workers.  So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Germany, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. Nevertheless, this device is widely requested, in case not, I allow myself the possibility of voting in favour of its mobilization.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for German purposes in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Adam Opel AG. I support the mobilisation of EUR 6 958 623 for the return of 2 692 redundant workers to the labour market.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Opposed to this hypocritical system of the "globalization adjustment fund", I nevertheless voted in favour of this report which proposes to release 7 million euros for the reintegration of 2,692 workers laid off by Opel in Germany.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In February 2015, Germany applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) following layoffs at Adam Opel AG and a supplier in Germany. Adam Opel AG has suffered greatly from the austerity measures imposed on European countries, which have contributed to the fall in sales.  As the conditions for the mobilization of the EGF are respected, I supported the EUR 6,598,623 granted to workers affected by the liberal and banking crisis to help them in their reintegration into the workforce.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Adam Opel in Germany. The German authorities declared the complete closure of the production plant in Bochum due to the global economic and financial crisis explaining the 25% decline in the registration of vehicles registered between 2007-2015. This is the thirteenth application under review under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 958 623 and affects 2,692 workers of the 2,881 workers laid off at Adam Opel and supplier.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On 26 February, Germany submitted the EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies at Adam Opel AG and a supplier in Germany. Germany argues that with the crisis, car sales in Europe have fallen to their lowest level since 1997. In Western Europe, sales fell dramatically to their lowest point in 20 years.  As a result of the financial and economic crisis, the number of newly registered cars in the EU and EFTA Member States fell by 25% between 2007 and 2013. In total, there were 2,826 laid-off workers at Adam Opel AG and 55 laid-off workers at Johnson Controls Objekt Bochum GmbH and Co. KG, a supplier to Adam Opel AG. In view of the German demand, it is proposed that the EGF contribute eur 6,958,623. So I voted in favour of supporting employees and repairing the damage done by European policies.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising EUR 6 958 623 from the EGF for the benefit of the 2 881 workers made redundant by Opel di Bochum. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a means of supporting the internal market, but it is not the cure for the malfunctioning of this failed Europe system which, through its austerity policies, has contributed to the dramatic fall in Opel/Vauxhall sales and the consequent job losses.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have today voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. On the other hand, I am opposed to the committee's procedure for appointing a rapporteur who comes from the region/constituency to which the aid is directed. That means an obvious conflict of interest. I would also like to emphasise that the high level of unemployment in europe could be combated more effectively if we stop the austerity policies pursued by the European Commission and the governments of the Member States for a long time, and instead pursue a policy of public, green investment.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 958 623 from the EGF for Germany for the 2 881 redundancies that took place at Adam Opel AG (Bochum, North Rhine-Westphalia), which operates in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. Measures for laid-off workers covered by this application include vocational training measures, vocational guidance, workshops, business creation advisory service, job search, job fairs, mentoring services and post-recruitment counselling and training assignment. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament agrees with the Commission's proposal to grant financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to Adam Opel AG, Germany, when 2 881 workers were dismissed.  The German authorities give reasons for the complete closure of the Adam Opel AG plant in Bochum. They link this closure to the global financial and economic crisis, explaining that the number of new registered cars in the EU Member States and EFTA countries decreased by 25% between 2007 and 2013 and that manufacturers of small and medium-sized vehicles belonging to the mid-price segment were particularly affected. Personalised services to be provided to redundant workers, consists of the following actions: vocational training measures (Qualifizierungen), vocational guidance (Berufsorientierung), groups and workshops of similarly qualified workers, business start-up advice (Existenzgründerberatung), job search (Stellenakquise), job fairs (Jobmessen), further mentoring and counselling (Nachbetreuung und - beratung), training allowances (Transferkurzarbeitergeld).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. I agree with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution.  Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Nearly 2,900 workers have been left without a job in the German city of Bochum since the car factory there began laying off due to poor results. The fact is that the car industry was badly affected in the last economic and financial crisis, austerity in state budgets has further reduced people's disposable income and the situation has deteriorated further. Less than seven million aid will be allocated in Germany to the restructuring of the car industry in critical areas in order to preserve at least the existing jobs, so my vote is my vote on this proposal.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Mobilisation Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Adam Opel), to help 2692 former workers through a coordinated package of measures. The dramatic decline in car sales in Europe, caused by the global financial and economic crisis, has led to the emergence of surplus workers in the auto industry, and in this way they are wanted to be helped through vocational training measures (career guidance, workshops, advisory services).

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the German car manufacturing company Adam-Opel. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis. In Germany, 2,881 workers were dismissed in Adam Opel AG and one supplier as a result of the over-capacity caused by the sharp decline in car sales arising from the global financial crisis.  The social partners established a 'transfer company' to formally employ the workers for one year, and this report states that Adam-Opel will use the maximum 35% of the EGF funds allowed to pay the salaries of the workers in the transfer company (as a 'training allowance').  I have concerns with the way in which some German companies have used the EGF in this way, as I believe it is the responsibility of the company itself to meet these costs, and the EGF should be used to provide additional support. Despite this concern I support the dismissed workers receiving the benefits associated with the mobilisation of the EGF, so I voted in favour.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that it is up to the Union to help those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis. In particular, in the present case, the impact of the crisis on Adam Opel AG, which saw sales of its cars fall by 39% and which could not compensate for this decline with access to other markets other than the European market, as decided by its parent company General Motors, is undeniable.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to provide Germany with a financial contribution of 7 million euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the dismissal of 2,881 employees at Opel. This assistance is intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. While the German company saw its sales fall by 39% between 2007 and 2013, the entire European automotive sector is affected by a continuous decline in the number of newly registered cars (-25% between 2007 and 2013). While these layoffs are directly related to the current economic crisis and unfair competition from emerging countries, it is not necessary to absolve the US parent company General Motors, which has forced Opel to sell its cars only on the European market.  On the one hand, this application fulfils the conditions for the granting of financial contributions from the WEF. On the other hand, we believe it is important to help the laid-off German workers who are suffering, as in France, the disastrous consequences of savage globalisation. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The effects of the economic crisis are still being felt in car production, so in Western Europe car sales have fallen dramatically, reaching their lowest level in 20 years. Small and medium vehicle manufacturers in the mid-price segment were particularly affected, with Adam Opel AG being one of them. Overproduction caused by a sharp drop in car sales as a result of the financial and economic crisis forced Adam Opel AG to adjust its production capacities in Europe in order to align them on demand. This led to massive redundancies and subsequently the complete closure of the Bochum production plant, one of the five production facilities of Adam Opel AG. For this reason, 2,881 workers were made redundant. These redundancies can have a significant negative impact on the local economy in Bochum, given that the unemployment rate in the Ruhr region, where Bochum is also located, is already well above the national average.  In this context, the EU-granted EUR 6 958 623 financial aid is a real support for the reintegration of workers into the labour market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, € 6,958,623 for 2,881 redundancies at Opel di Bochum. The manufacturers of small and medium-sized cars in the mid-price segment, in which Opel is one of the main players, have been particularly affected, and in any case more so than cheap and high-end and luxury vehicles. Decrease in EU+EFTA registrations between 2007 and 2013: -25% (Opel -39%). Opel was disadvantaged by its parent company General Motors, which allowed it to sell its vehicles exclusively in Europe, thus excluding it from emerging markets on other continents; Moreover, the austerity policies imposed on European countries have contributed to the dramatic decline in Opel/Vauxhall sales. Bochum has already benefited from EGF support after Nokia suspended mobile phone production resulting in the loss of 1,300 jobs. As if that were not enough, Outukumpu intends to suspend the local production of stainless steel at the end of 2015. I am always on the side of the workers and their families!

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the sacked employees of Adam Opel following the total shutdown of the Bochum production plant in Germany. The amount of aid amounts to 6,958,623 euros. 2692 laid-off workers will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. This assistance is justified given the significant global competition in the automotive sector. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the solidarity of the Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to the application made by Germany to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Adam Opel AG , an undertaking operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, and with a supplier. This question concerns 2,692 of the 2,881 workers made redundant. In order to establish the link between redundancies and major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, the German authorities indicate that between 2007 and 2013 there was a 25% decrease in the number of newly registered cars in the EU and EFTA Member States and that small and medium-sized car manufacturers in the average price segment were particularly affected. In view of the link between redundancies and structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the German car manufacturing company Adam-Opel. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis. In Germany, 2,881 workers were dismissed in Adam Opel AG and one supplier as a result of the over-capacity caused by the sharp decline in car sales arising from the global financial crisis.  The social partners established a 'transfer company' to formally employ the workers for one year, and this report states that Adam-Opel will use the maximum 35% of the EGF funds allowed to pay the salaries of the workers in the transfer company (as a 'training allowance').  I have concerns with the way in which some German companies have used the EGF in this way, as I believe it is the responsibility of the company itself to meet these costs, and the EGF should be used to provide additional support. Despite this concern I support the dismissed workers receiving the benefits associated with the mobilisation of the EGF, so I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to DE/ADAM OPEL. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014 - 20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Germany has applied for EUR 6 958 625 to deal with 2692 redundancies.  The blame factor is aimed at emerging markets and competitiveness in the world market. Small car sales have dropped by 25% from 2007/13 in EFTA nations.  Personalised services such as careers advice and mobilisation have been mentioned relating to seeking other jobs. There is also a mention of business start-up grants to be given to the beneficiaries. The matter of concern relates to contracting out the personalised services, organisations that provide aid to those who have been made redundant are already in receipt of funding from other funding streams such as the ESF. If this is the factual case then why is the EU happily granting more funding to OPEL? Companies that are not competitive enough must not seek a bailout from the taxpayer to pay for redundancies. I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I understand that the Adam Opel could be sold within Europe only so it could not emerge in the marker of other continents. Therefore, this report will support the funding to help providing assistance to workers who are affected by this disadvantage.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automotive sector is heavily affected by international competition, as well as by the economic crisis, which has had a considerable impact on demand. I therefore voted in favour of mobilising the Fund to the amount of approximately EUR 7 million, which is intended to provide support to the almost 2 900 workers affected by the closure of the Opel plant in Bochum.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is almost EUR 7 million for the reintegration of 2,692 workers laid off by Opel in Germany following the economic crisis.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This is a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Germany in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers by Adam Opel AG, which was active in the field of vehicle manufacturing. The application concerns 2881 workers who have been made redundant. This support is important because it helps workers to return to employment and to be temporarily relieved as a result of their dismissal.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of the German company Adam Opel. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund for a total amount of EUR 6 958 623. The request is based on the professional relocation of 2 881 redundant workers from Adam Opel, an economic company classified in Division 29 of NACE Rev. 2. It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. Among the causes of the crisis that has hit Adam Opel hard, the policy of the parent company General Motors, which has prevented it from selling its cars outside the European market, thus excluding it from emerging markets on other continents, and the austerity policies imposed in other European countries.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Adam Opel case. The plant was in very poor market conditions, going through a serious crisis that led to a large number of skilled workers being considered redundant. I think it is right to help the laid-off workers in this plant, especially since all the parameters fall within the parameters laid down in this regard by EU rules. It is therefore appropriate to make the contribution to the support of these people by using the special European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, set up precisely to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to DE/ADAM OPEL. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014 - 20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Germany has applied for EUR 6 958 625 to deal with 2692 redundancies.  The blame factor is aimed at emerging markets and competitiveness in the world market. Small car sales have dropped by 25% from 2007/13 in EFTA nations.  Personalised services such as careers advice and mobilisation have been mentioned relating to seeking other jobs. There is also a mention of business start-up grants to be given to the beneficiaries. The matter of concern relates to contracting out the personalised services, organisations that provide aid to those who have been made redundant are already in receipt of funding from other funding streams such as the ESF. If this is the factual case then why is the EU happily granting more funding to OPEL? Companies that are not competitive enough must not seek a bailout from the taxpayer to pay for redundancies. UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 6,958,623 in favour of Germany with the aim of supporting the 2,881 workers made redundant in Adam Opel AG and a supplier company.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the conditions are right to accept Germany's request to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by adam opel and his supplier. The German authorities indicate that between 2007 and 2013 there was a 25% decrease in the number of newly registered cars in the EU and EFTA Member States and that the manufacturers of small and medium-sized cars in the average price segment were particularly affected. As the EGF is an instrument for providing additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows, it is therefore right to use this Fund as the direct link between closure and the global financial and economic crisis is confirmed.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Contractual duties made Adam Opel unable to trade internationally severely disadvantaging the business and the workers. These measures would help redundant workers to find new jobs by providing them with career guidance and peer groups, vocational training, business start-up advisory services, job scouting, mentoring and advisory services after reemployment and training allowances. I have thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Geier report deals with Germany's request to mobilise the EGF for around EUR 7 million, in support of almost 2,900 workers affected by the closure of the Opel plant in Bochum. I am voting in favour of mobilising this fund. Aware that it is certainly not the best tool that can help workers, but in the absence of alternatives it must be supported nonetheless.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Opel's redundancies in one of the German regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Car sales in Western Europe have fallen dramatically and reached a 20-year negative record, with the number of cars sold in Europe now at its lowest level since 1997. These events are directly related to the global financial and economic crisis. Manufacturers of medium-priced, small and medium-sized vehicles are particularly badly affected by the crisis, such as Adam Opel AG, while the sale of low-cost or premium or luxury vehicles has not been so affected by the crisis. Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I supported Germany's use of the Fund to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and to support their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which provides for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Germany in reference to redundancies at Adam Opel AG and one supplier operating in the manufacturing of motor vehicles. The redundancies were caused by a dramatic drop in car sales in Europe. Employees who lose their jobs should be supported across all of the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the mobilization of EUR 6,958,623 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the benefit of the 2,692 people made redundant by the car manufacturer Adam Opel AG in Germany. With an annual budget of 150 million euros per year during the period 2014-2020, the EGF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. Faced with international competition, some European sectors are undergoing major and sometimes costly restructurings in employment. Considering that one of the aims of European funds is to support workers and enable them to retrain permanently, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's support for European citizens in difficulty is essential, as in the case of people in Germany facing redundancies in the automotive sector. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows. Between 2007 and 2013, there was a 25% drop in the number of newly registered cars in the Member States of the European Union. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Germany in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Adam Opel AG, a production plant that has suffered greatly from the crisis in the automotive sector in recent years.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The closure of the Opel plant in Bochum following a 39% drop in sales between 2007 and 2013 led to a very large wave of layoffs among plant staff, with a considerable drop in the local economy. The mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to provide additional assistance to Germany for the reintegration of former Open Bochum employees.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, structural reforms are needed to reconnect with economic growth. The N-VA Members of the European Parliament have therefore abstained in this matter.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they lost their jobs as a result of changing world trade patterns. However, me and my group do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for introducing such policies, nor do we believe it to be an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. And that's why I'm voting no. However, I stress that I fully support measures to introduce policies that create growth and jobs. This report requires 6.9 million euro. 2,692 workers who lost their jobs at Opel.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this case of the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as I am concerned it could be used to finance the Member State's obligations. It would therefore not be an appropriate use of the fund. It is vital to my constituents in Wales that we ensure that the European Union is as transparent and as accountable as possible, and that resources are allocated strictly on the basis of need. I regret that the UK Government does not allow access to this fund for communities in need in Wales.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (the 'Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the disaster-affected regions and that the Fund's intervention should not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. Germany submitted an application following redundancies at Adam Opel AG and a supplier company in Germany. I therefore agree that a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 should be mobilised to satisfy germany's request.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates are critical of the Globalisation Fund as such and have voted against its creation. We have also opposed the EU alleviating funds for this purpose in budgetary votes. However, we do not fight over individual payments once the fund is in place.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe these funds are necessary to help the economy of the area affected.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and taking into account the Council Regulation, as well as the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 to Germany, namely for Adam Opel AG, which had to lay off 2 881 workers. Adam Opel AG, which is owned by General Motors, disadvantaged the company because it allowed it to sell only within Europe, thus excluding it from emerging markets on other continents. Car sales volumes in Western Europe have fallen sharply, reaching their lowest levels in 20 years.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of allocating the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 2,881 redundancies to Opel in Bochum.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel application. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In February 2015, Germany submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) due to redundancies in the company Adam Opel AG. Considering that the conditions for mobilizing the EGF are met, I supported the mobilization of € 6 598 623 paid to workers affected by the crisis to help them in their professional reintegration in Germany.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application complies with the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation; The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel application. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization which, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 6,958,623, requested by Germany in relation to the Adam Opel AG crisis. It is once again a question of supporting workers in the automotive industry: 2,881 workers made redundant by Opel as a result of the crisis in the sector in Europe, where car sales have returned to 1997 levels, with a 25% decrease in new registrations and a 39% drop in sales of Opel products in 5 years. The company, which specializes in sales of small/medium-sized cars, also pays for the impoverishment of European consumers caused by the wrong austerity policies; It is therefore essential for Europe to make every effort to ensure that it is not once again the workers who suffer. The EGF's funding of vocational training and guidance measures, business start-up advisory services, job search, mentoring, training and placement allowances, managed by the government and trade unions, is an important step pending an overall solution to the crisis in the European automotive sector.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: Application EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel, as I am aware of the fates of many workers in Bochum – and I am convinced that the payments made by this fund can help to facilitate personal and regional structural change. This EU money is arriving – especially for families in Bochum.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to use the EGF under application EGF/2015/002/EN/Adam Opel. At a time of increasing globalisation and a sometimes weakening global economy, it is important that European companies remain competitive in the future. Workers who have lost their jobs as a result of this adjustment deserve support to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Adam Opel AG, manufacturer of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, in order to ensure support is provided to employees of the company who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund application in favour of Germany. The funding application of automobile manufacturer Adam Opel AG is well merited given the difficult conditions created by the financial crisis in terms of a twenty record drop in car sales. This was compounded by a decision by its parent company, General Motors, to disallow the export of their vehicles to any market outside Europe.  Therefore, I fully support this approval of this financial instrument which gives redundant workers the tools to be once again reintegrated into the workforce.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, start-up consultancy services, job search, job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of €6 958 623 from the EGF in the case of 2 692 made redundant at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. This is one of many applications we have received for workers in the motor industry (to date 21 EGF applications) which has been hit particularly hard by both the economic crisis and globalisation. Within the industry this is particularly true for manufactures of small and medium-sized vehicles in the medium price band of which Adam Opel AG is one. This is evidenced by the fact that while the number of newly registered cars in the EU saw a drop of 25% between 2007 and 2013, sales of Opel/Vauxhall-branded cars in Europe fell by 39% for the same period. Also the Ruhr area has faced large redundancies before and further redundancies in the steel industry are expected towards the end of the year. It is crucial then that the German authorities decided to initiate the implementation of the personalised services to the affected workers on 1 January 2015, well ahead of the decision and even the application on the granting the EGF support for the proposed coordinated package and similarly I welcome the speedy evaluation time by the Commission and Parliament.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) be used to further train former Opel employees to reconnect with the labour market and develop new skills and skills. Overall, the aim is to respond better to changes caused by globalisation, including the exodus of large companies abroad. We naturally want to support growth and employment. However, I am convinced that the fund and the investment of funds in former Opel employees are not the right political instrument for this. We should also rely on the initiative of the workers for large companies and focus on the competitiveness and productivity of the European economy. That is why I voted against. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Germany. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set in 2006 to express solidarity with European workers. It is mean to reintegrate into the labour market the workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. The 2 December 2013 Meduinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good governance providing financial assistance to the German company Adam Opel.  The global economic crisis has also greatly affected the automotive industry, where devastating data show a significant drop in mid-priced car sales in which small and medium-sized vehicles include small and medium-sized vehicles, and lead actor Adam Opel AG. Consequently, with the decline in sales, there has been the redundancies of a large number of employees in Opel who are significantly supported by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  I therefore support Germany's request to help reintegrate redundate workers into the labour market and contribute to economic and social growth.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing.
