This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Germany, with a view to obtaining a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 6,958,623 following 2,881 redundancies at Adam Opel AG. This initiative is part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, and to the reintegration of laid-off workers in the sad context of the car industry in Western Europe, where car sales have fallen dramatically and reached their lowest point in twenty years. Manufacturers of small and medium-sized cars in the intermediate price range have been particularly hard hit, as has Adam Opel AG, in particular because of the austerity measures imposed on European countries. After review, I consider that this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Germany is considering effective and appropriate measures for laid-off workers for reintegration. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. All too often, as repeated here, the EU is the cause and the problem and then tries to mollify the impact with financial help.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jens Geier's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked Opel employees. This fund will release EUR 6,958,623 for 2,692 employees who have been laid off as a result of the total shutdown of the production plant in Bochum. This amount will be used to fund training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries re-enter the labour market. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the German demand for the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund is well founded. It follows the dismissal of 2,881 people by Opel during the economic and financial crisis.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The closure of Opel's plants in Bochum was a direct result of the financial crisis, falling sales of up to 25% between 2007 and 2013 and increased competition in the medium-price segment of third-country manufacturers. The mobilisation of the fund is intended to help 692 former Opel employees, against which no objections can be raised. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) be used to further train former Opel employees to reconnect with the labour market and develop new skills and skills. Overall, the aim is to respond better to changes caused by globalisation, including the exodus of large companies abroad. We naturally want to support growth and employment. However, I am convinced that the fund and the investment of funds in former Opel employees are not the right political instrument for this. We should also rely on the initiative of the workers for large companies and focus on the competitiveness and productivity of the European economy. That is why I voted against.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Geier's report. I believe that the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of Germany in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Adam Opel AG is correct. In fact, the EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes due to globalisation. In the present case, the German authorities indicate that between 2007 and 2013 there was a 25% decrease in the number of newly registered cars in the EU Member States, of which the aforementioned company was certainly affected.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in Adam Opel AG. Following the total shutdown of Opel's production plant in Bochum, almost three thousand workers were laid off at Opel and a supplier.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade. The European Union does not provide a structural solution to these problems. On the contrary, as a promoter of globalization, she is one of them. However, while the WEF can help reintegrate laid-off workers back into the labour market, it cannot be opposed.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it unlocks almost 7 million euros for the reintegration of 2,692 workers laid off by Opel in Germany because of a drop in global demand due to the economic crisis.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6,958,623 from the EGF for Germany for the 2,881 redundancies in Adam Opel AG (Bochum, North Rhine-Westphalia) operating in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. Measures for laid-off workers covered by this application include vocational training measures, vocational guidance, workshops, business creation advisory service, job search, job fairs, mentoring services and post-recruitment counselling and training assignment. Naturally in our group we agree with the existence and implementation of this Fund, which is why we voted in favour.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) be used to further train former Opel employees to reconnect with the labour market and develop new skills and skills. Overall, the aim is to respond better to changes caused by globalisation, including the exodus of large companies abroad. We naturally want to support growth and employment. However, I am convinced that the fund and the investment of funds in former Opel employees are not the right political instrument for this. We should also rely on the initiative of the workers for large companies and focus on the competitiveness and productivity of the European economy. That is why I voted against.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. In 2012, Germany, one of the world's richest countries, is demanding that the Orwellian-named fund bail out the low competitiveness of German firms caused by a slushy welfare state and an overregulated economy. There can be no vote other than against this euro nonsense.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported A report by MEP Geier approving a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help former employees of Germany's Adam Omel AGa.  In February 2015, Germany applied for €6.9 million to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Adam Opel AG. The European Fund was created to provide assistance to former employees in finding a new job, education or self-employment, which lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis.  Adam Opel AG reached a record low number of cars sold due to the crisis, resulting in the redundancies of 2826 workers and another 55 workers who became technologically redundant at the Johnson Controls facility bochumu GmbH & Co., a supplier of Adam Opel AG.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This fund is designed to help redundant people acquire a new specialty or find a job. This is applied when more than 500 people are made redundant, e.g. when production moves out of the EU. In the case of Latvia, an attempt was made to obtain funds from this fund for Liepājas Metalurgsi, but no data on whether this was successful.  The German Government is asking for around 7 million. One of the three Opel plants ceased operations and more than 1,000 workers have been made redundant. This is because demand for cars is at its lowest since 1997. Between 2007 and 2013, the purchase of new cars in Europe decreased by 25%. The decline, in particular, affected producers whose output is destined for the middle class: demand has shifted towards more thrift cars.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany applied for a financial contribution from the EGF in February 2015 as a result of the redundancies of Adam Opel AG and one supply company in Germany. The layoffs have caused production in the automotive industry to fall as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Personalised services will affect 2,692 out of a total of 2,881 redundancies. In support of and implementation of the proposed measures in the application submitted by Germany, the EGF is mobilised to provide a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (Application EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel, from Germany), because the German authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 1 January 2014, well before the decision and even from the request for EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Germany to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Adam Opel AG.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Germany.  Germany has in fact applied for a financial contribution totalling EUR 6 958 623 following the redundancy of 2 881 workers at Adam Opel AG, a motor vehicle manufacturing company.   Adam Opel AG has been particularly hard hit not only by the economic and financial crisis, but also, and above all, by its parent company General Motors, which has allowed it to sell its vehicles exclusively in Europe, thus excluding it from emerging markets on other continents, causing a dramatic decline in car sales, especially in Western Europe. The activation of the fund will only finance measures which will contribute to the reintegration of redundancies into the labour market, thus creating conditions enabling redundant workers to find temporary or permanent jobs, participate in vocational training programmes and acquire the skills required. I believe that special assistance is extremely important for the workers made redundant and for those affected by the current global economic climate. The European Union must be an example and a guide in development aid.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 14 July 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Germany to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at Adam Opel AG, a company operating in the "Manufacture of Motor Vehicles, Trailers and Semi-Trailers" sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide support to workers affected by structural changes in world trade flows.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today chosen to vote in favour of the report on the proposal on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), with reference to the application made by Germany to allow workers made redundant at Adam Opel AG to be reintegrated into the labour market. This question concerns almost all workers made redundant (2 692 out of 2 881), so I think it is right that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be used to support European workers during a period of delicate transition of employment.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The German authorities claim that the redundancies were triggered by the complete closure of the Bochum plant of Adam Opel AG. For them, this closure is linked to the global financial and economic crisis. The support applies in the areas of qualifications, vocational orientation, peer groups/workshops, start-up counselling, job acquisition/job fairs, follow-up and counselling and transfer short-term worker allowance. I therefore support this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this application as workers need support in periods of adjustment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Opel site in the German Ruhr has closed its doors and has put nearly 3,000 employees on the job. However, the German brand is owned by General Motors, the third largest manufacturer in Europe now, which generates a growing turnover of 156 billion in 2014. The rapporteur denounces the attitude of the parent company General Motors, "which allowed it to sell its vehicles only in Europe and thus excluded it from emerging markets on other continents" and also stresses "that the austerity measures imposed on European countries have contributed to the dramatic fall in sales of Opel/Vauxhall", but without proposing to put a stop to absurd austerity policies...  Let us not lose sight of the will of American manufacturers to strike the European car industry, as the opportune Volkswagen case suggests.  I abstain in order not to oppose the granting of this fund to the licensed victims of German neoliberal policy, while denouncing these multinationals that relocate to Asia, from where they then export to European markets.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Germany, with a view to obtaining a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 6,958,623 following 2,881 redundancies at Adam Opel AG.  This initiative is part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to reintegrate laid-off workers in the sad context of the car industry in Western Europe, where car sales have fallen dramatically and reached their lowest point in twenty years. Manufacturers of small and medium-sized cars in the intermediate price range have been particularly hard hit, as has Adam Opel AG, in particular because of the austerity measures imposed on European countries. Upon review, this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Germany is considering effective and appropriate measures for laid-off workers for reintegration. For these reasons, the Member voted for this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, application EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel. According to the Commission, the measures described are active labour market measures falling within the eligible actions defined in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. These actions do not replace passive social protection measures.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This is an application that meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the Unions disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 2 692 workers in the automotive industry in Germany due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of this report, which helps declining car companies. Adam Opel AG was damaged by parent company General Motors' decision to exclude it from emerging markets. This decision has led to many layoffs in a region where the unemployment rate is already well above the country's average as a whole. Therefore, it was necessary to intervene to revive the economy in this more disadvantaged region, in order to restore an economic balance.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established for the period 2014-2020 to provide support to states whose labour market has been affected by the global economic and financial crisis.  Following examination of application EGF/2015/002DE/Adam Opel, the Commission decided that the conditions laid down for the submission and submission of the proposal were fulfilled by the Federal Republic of Germany. The application for a contribution has been approved and Germany is eligible for a financial contribution to support redundant workers due to globalisation, the subsequent closure of the company's production plant. I agree with the decision to mobilise a fund to provide staffing services and measures for workers in order to integrate into the labour market. I appreciate the Commission's accelerated procedure for releasing the fund.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because I am in agreement to give the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Germany. The application relates to 2 881 redundancies in Adam Opel AG and 1 supplier, operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, within the period 15 August 2014 – 15 December 2014. The EGAF funding of EUR 6 958,623 shall contribute to help 2 692 former workers through a coordinated package of vocational training measures such as career guidance, peer groups/workshops, business start-up advisory service and similar. The redundancies were caused by a dramatic drop in car sales in Europe, on the background of the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an important institution of solidarity within the Union: it contributes to the early re-creation of workers in jobs that have ceased to exist as a result of the globalisation process, with a lasting application in a competitive sector. It is an active employment policy instrument that shares the burden of returning to the labour market between the worker, the Member State concerned and the Union, and its outcome helps workers who are able to re-enter work, member states that are forced to deal with unemployment and the Union which is aiming to increase employment. Germany submitted applications for 2 881 redundancies at Adam Opel AG and one supplier, Belgium for 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk and its 11 suppliers and down processors, and Italy for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of 1 249 redundancies from gruppo alitalia group. All three applications meet the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, with Germany eligible for the Fund's support of EUR 6 958 623, Belgium EUR 6 268 564 and Italy EUR 1 414 848. I voted in favour of the proposals accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created with the purpose of giving complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In the present case, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Germany to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in Adam Opel AG, NACE Revision 2, division 29 (Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers) and in a supplier company. The source of the redundancies is the total closure of Adam Opel AG's production unit in Bochum due to a 25% decrease between 2007 and 2013 in the number of new cars registered in the EU and efta Member States. I stress the importance of improving the employability of all workers made redundant through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, and it is vital that the proposed training is adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers but also to the real environment of enterprises. I therefore support the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the mobilization of almost 7 million euros to help 2,692 workers laid off by Opel in Germany. Indeed, it is clear that this "restructuring" is linked to the financial and economic crisis that has hit Europe since 2008 and which has broken domestic demand throughout the Union (although this phenomenon was accelerated by the absurd austerity policy orchestrated by the Commission).  Although it may seem strange to see the Union coming to the aid of laid-off workers when it is largely responsible for the causes of these redundancies (i.e. international competition and the breakdown of domestic demand) and even though these subsidies can be defying and disempowering large companies, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, e.g. when a large company shuts down or production is moved outside the EU, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Labour MEPs have consistently supported EGF applications, moreover it is worth noting that opportunities for the UK to claim from this fund may arise in the near future and the EGF could help those made redundant and wider communities affected by large shocks to the local economy. It is also worth noting the EGF can do this whilst minimising the cost to the UK Government.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted three Mobilisation reports of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of its three reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 6,958,623 from this Fund to 2,692 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of ADAM OPEL AG in Germany.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this Fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application under consideration, the thirteenth in the 2015 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 6,958,623 in favour of Germany and concerns 2,692 of the 2,881 workers made redundant at Adam Opel, a company operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. Given that the EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade and that the European Parliament has often stressed the need for greater visibility of the Fund as an instrument of union solidarity with these workers, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Adam Opel AG, Germany.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the German car manufacturing company Adam-Opel. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis. In Germany, 2,881 workers were dismissed in Adam Opel AG and one supplier as a result of the over-capacity caused by the sharp decline in car sales arising from the global financial crisis.  The social partners established a 'transfer company' to formally employ the workers for one year, and this report states that Adam-Opel will use the maximum 35% of the EGF funds allowed to pay the salaries of the workers in the transfer company (as a 'training allowance').  I have concerns with the way in which some German companies have used the EGF in this way, as I believe it is the responsibility of the company itself to meet these costs, and the EGF should be used to provide additional support. Despite this concern I support the dismissed workers receiving the benefits associated with the mobilisation of the EGF, so I voted in favour.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. With the Globalisation Fund, the European Union has a budgetary instrument that provides financial support to workers affected by the far-reaching global structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund starts exactly where society needs it most. That is why I have spoken out clearly in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to approve the payment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds (FEAM) to Adam Opel AG of Germany, following the closure of the Bochum plant in the deindustrialized Ruhr region (2881 redundancies). The FEAM is designed to compensate and financially assist European companies that have closed sectors because of an inability to remain competitive in the global market, so that they can engage in social policies to reorient employees. In this case, Opel saw its car production fall by 39% between 2007 and 2013, while China doubled its production of passenger cars over the period.  Although the justifications seem legitimate for the payment of these funds to this company, I have decided to abstain, finding that the report does not go far enough in denouncing a European trade policy that favours relocations to Asia.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The German car industry is suffering from a downturn in dwindling car sales. As the German industry relies heavily on car production, the decline has led to large-scale redundancies. Production needs to be supported for the industry to function.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I agree that the Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be mobilised for this German company. This EU support is essential for the economic and social recovery of the EU. The support provided will help stabilise the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers in the Arnsberg region of Germany and will contribute to the promotion of employment. In particular, 2 881 workers will be facilitated by reintegration into the labour market. Active labour market measures will help redundant workers find another job or set up their own business, reduce the negative effects of unemployment and help the needy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the crisis in the auromobilistic sales sector in Europe, with particular attention to Germany's needs, I believe that the fund needs to be used to deal with this problem. Therefore, I have chosen to guarantee my vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ After considering germany's application for financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, and taking into account the number of targeted beneficiaries, the proposed measures and estimated costs, the Commission proposes to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund by EUR 6,958,623, representing 60 % of the total cost of the proposed measures. I agree with this fund mobilization measure because it needs to provide assistance to all redundant workers, of whom there are 2,826 in Adam Opel AG and 55 at Johnson Controls facility Bochum GmbH & Co., a supplier of Adam Opel AG. The German automotive industry reached its lowest level since 1997, and the consequences of this crisis in the automotive industry, which in turn is a direct result of the global financial crisis, are devastating for jobs that need to be preserved. It is necessary to be understanding towards companies that are not good at globalisation and which could fail without help. Competitiveness and market diversity are the characteristics of the European Union and this needs to be well supported and integration itself should be maintained.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the mobilization of almost 7 million euros to help 2,692 workers laid off by Opel in Germany. Indeed, it is clear that this "restructuring" is linked to the financial and economic crisis that has hit since 2008 and which has broken domestic demand throughout the EU (although this phenomenon was accelerated by the absurd austerity policy orchestrated by the Commission). While it may seem strange to see the EU coming to the aid of laid-off workers when it is largely responsible for the causes of these redundancies (i.e. international competition and the breakdown of domestic demand), and if these subsidies can undoubtedly disempower large companies, I have decided to vote in favour of this text to support sacked employees, victims of this absurd system.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an important instrument of solidarity, i.e. assistance for all those affected by structural changes in global trade, in not all workers whose work becomes more costly in the context of production relocation, but also under the impact of the financial crisis and the resulting business decisions or business closures. In the case of Germany's Adam Opel, there were 2,692 redundancy out of a total of 2,881 workers, a direct result of the global financial crisis and a 25% drop in the number of registered cars in the EU between 2007 and 2013, which created a problem of overcapping in Adam Opel. I welcome the Commission's decision to allocate EUR 6 958 623 in this case, as well as specific envisaged assistance measures in the form of vocational training and personal counselling.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for the mobilisation of the EGF in relation to germany's application to make a financial contribution to Bochum's Adam Opel. This application was made following the redundancy of 2,881 workers due to the permanent closure of the company. Sales of cars produced by the German company in question fell sharply between 2007 and 2013 to the lowest level of sales in the last twenty years. I hope that today's vote, as well as being an aid to their families, will help to enable the employees of Opel di Bochum to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Once again, we are voting again over time to mobilize the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Anyone who watches my speeches on this subject will surely not be surprised that, even this time, it seems that globalisation affects only the old Member States. Once again, I would therefore like to call on the new Member States to also pursue these funds.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The process of globalisation has opened Up European markets to international competition, bringing about economic and structural changes in our businesses. The EU has set up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of globalisation on European economies, but especially on workers.  The fund was requested in 2015 by Germany to support sacked employees following the permanent closure of the Adam Opel production plant in Bochum, Germany. EUR 6,958,623 have been requested. I support this request and stress the importance of this fund in helping workers in the industrial sector access new training and reorient themselves to other more dynamic sectors.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament approved the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 2,692 licensees at the Adam Opel AG plant in Germany. This means that the German authorities will be able to benefit from an envelope of almost 7 million euros so that they can implement measures for these laid-off workers. The decisions taken in the head of the parent company "General Motors", combined with the austerity measures, contributed to the dramatic drop in sales of the Opel plant. The German authorities have already announced the concrete measures envisaged through this funding: short-term allocation; career reorientation; Helping to start a business Looking for a job participation in job fairs follow-up service and post-hiring assistance. During this week of plenary session, a total of EUR 14.6 million will have been allocated through the activation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which has a total annual budget of 150 million euros.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in global trade patterns (globalisation) or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Germany submitted this application based on the sharp decline in car sales by Adam Opel AG. 2826 workers were made redundant (55 more workers made redundant from suppliers and producers of Adam Opel AG). EUR 6 958 623 have been mobilised for aid. Germany submitted this application on the basis of a Criterion of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund which defines at least 500 workers made redundant in a company of a Member State within a reference period of 4 months. Without understaining the general principle, it nevertheless appears to be a criterion tailored to large enterprises.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The report refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6,958,623 from the EGF for Germany for the 2,881 redundancies that took place at Adam Opel AG (Bochum, North Rhine-Westphalia) operating in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. Measures for laid-off workers covered by this application include vocational training measures, vocational guidance, workshops, business creation advisory service, job search, job fairs, mentoring services and post-recruitment counselling and training assignment. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because the German car manufacturer had closed its factory in Bochum, Germany, in order to reduce its excess production capacity, with sales falling by 39% between 2007 and 2013. With the closure of the facility resulting in nearly 2900 redundancies, 2692 people could now benefit from the EGF's aid, worth 7 million euros, allocated by Germany.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global economic and financial crisis, assisting them in their reintegration into the labour market. It was in this context that Germany submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF to deal with the 2881 redundancies in Adam Opel AG. As it is certain that it meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour of mobilising the fund, amounting to EUR 6958623, in order to provide rapid support to workers with a view to their reintegration into the labour market, and with the assurance that they will obtain adapted training and new and recognised qualifications and competences.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the total amount of EUR 6 958 623 in favour of Germany. This fund will be used to promote the professional relocation of 2,692 of the 2,881 workers made redundant by Adam Opel, a car manufacturing company.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE)
text: Written. "My belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why I am opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which I believe is an expression of protectionism. We in the People's Party have previously accepted that the fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Opel's redundancies in one of the German states most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, because I do not believe that this is a competency of the EU. Germany is an incredibly wealthy country and they should handle their own affairs with German taxpayers’ money, not EU tax money. Furthermore, the UK does not benefit from this globalisation fund.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have consistently supported EGF applications and there is no reason to change my position for this application from Adam Opel. Germany’s decision to submit this application is perfectly legitimate and in line with what I see as an appropriate mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Adam Opel AG, a German company, I voted in line with the EKR's position against this resolution. I consider it important to create a policy that helps employment growth and job creation. At the same time, however, I share the position of the EKR and therefore do not consider the European Globalisation Fund to be a proper and adequate instrument for this purpose.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The global financial and economic crisis has also had an impact on the automotive sector, which has seen a dramatic slump in car sales in Europe. Adam Opel AG had to lay off 2 881 employees due to redundancy and terminate the contract with one of the suppliers. The large-scale structural changes caused by world trade can also be mitigated by the use of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I therefore support the release of these funds for the reintegration of workers made redundant due to the closure of the Bochume production plant. The nearly EUR 7 million earmarked for this assistance should provide workers with professional advice, vocational retraining or start-up counselling services so that they can find employment again. However, training funds may not replace an undertaking by a Member State or a former employer. It is therefore essential for the Commission to ensure that the funds are used for personalised and in-depth measures that the company would not have been able to implement without support from the Fund.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Union has introduced legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. However, the EGF funds may not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million.  Following the redundancies of 2 881 workers from Adam Opel AG, Germany submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF No EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel, which fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation. Under that regulation, Germany was entitled to EUR 6 958 623 of the financial contribution.  I agree that Union financial assistance for redundant workers should be dynamic and should be made available as quickly and in the most efficient way possible, as the EGF fund is of paramount importance to the Member States during this crisis period. However, in the case of the case, there are concerns about the misuse of financial assistance and the use of it to fulfil certain obligations of a Member State, which is why I abstained.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Opel, in response to a request from the German Government following the closure of the well-known car manufacturer's plant in Bochum. Faced with a crisis resulting from the decline in production and sales of small and medium-sized machines (from the data provided, sales fell by as much as 39% between 2007 and 2013), Opel closed its Bochum factory, resulting in the dismissal of 2,900 workers. Most of them will be eligible for aid under the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the intervention of which was approved today to the value of EUR 7 million. This appropriation will be used to finance vocational training measures, vocational guidance, business start-up advisory services, job search and training allowances.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) be used to further train former Opel employees to reconnect with the labour market and develop new skills and skills. Overall, the aim is to respond better to changes caused by globalisation, including the exodus of large companies abroad. We naturally want to support growth and employment. However, I am convinced that the fund and the investment of funds in former Opel employees are not the right political instrument for this. We should also rely on the initiative of the workers for large companies and focus on the competitiveness and productivity of the European economy. That is why I voted against.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the restructuring of companies and the education of employees and young people in the affected region. At the same time, I am aware of the importance of the right economic policy that precedes such situations.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of amendment DE/Adam Opel. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a social policy instrument of the European Union. At the request of EU Member States, workers whose jobs have been lost as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis can be assisted in their search for a new job. The Globalisation Fund provides EUR 7 million in funds. This money will help workers find new jobs. I welcome the investment in training to help jobseekers find high-quality jobs.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up precisely to help people, i.e. workers who have been made redundant, which is also the case here when we talk about the request of the State of Germany and its company Adam Opel. Such people should be helped to re-enter the labour market or enable them to engage in self-employment, which also enters the domain and the EGF's domain.  As germany guarantees this company of its own, I believe that the funds can be allocated to that Member State without controversy in order to dispose of its citizens in some way, and in particular because that requirement complies with the requirements for determining the financial contribution from the EGF.  Therefore, since all legal and legislation procedures have been followed and everything was done correctly, I supported this report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this German application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 2881 redundancies in Adam Opel AG. Germany intends to use the funds to finance a series of measures intended to assist the redundant workers in finding another job, retraining or setting up their own business.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional assistance to workers in the Member States of the European Union, suffering as a result of major structural changes in global trade. The European Commission has accepted a decision to mobilise funds (€6,958,623) for Germany's benefit, for the purpose of reintegration into the labour market of more than 2,600 workers laid off when the Bochum plant, specialised in the production of Opel Adam cars, closed. Due to unfavourable global developments in the economy, the decision of general motors owners to sell vehicles exclusively on the European market, a decline in the number of new vehicle registrations in the European Union (25% for the period 2007-2013) and data that the number of new vehicles sold in Europe was the lowest since 1997, the factory had to be closed and workers laid off. I support this mobilization of funds to help laid-off workers.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree to provide EUR 6.9 million for 2 692 redundancies who are 'victims of globalisation'. The redistribution of money from productive employees and firms to unproductive employees and firms is making the EU's competitiveness worse, thus increasing the problems that the Globalisation Fund is trying to address itself. In order for the EU economy to be more competitive than the rest of the world, the exact opposite is needed – reducing the tax and regulatory burden and ending the harmful policies that have a negative impact on the EU economy, often achieving the opposite of the intended results, such as the EU's absurdly stringent climate objectives.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the role of Adam Opel, Germany. The application fulfils the eligibility criteria and I therefore support the granting of a financial contribution to Germany of EUR 6 958 623. Car sales in Western Europe, in particular sales of small and medium-sized vehicles, including Adam Opel AG, have fallen significantly as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, and the number of first-time registered cars in the Member States has fallen sharply in recent years.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Germany has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the redundancies of 2881 people at Adam Opel AG and one supplier. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Germany is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 under that Regulation. Germany envisaged the following measures for redundant workers covered by this application: vocational training measures, career advice, groups of similarly positioned persons / job conferences, start-up consultancy services, job search/job fairs, follow-up mentoring and counselling services and training grants. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The effects of the economic and financial crisis that began in 2008 are still being felt throughout the European Union. The machinery sector was among the most affected. In Western European states, car sales have fallen dramatically, reaching their lowest level in 20 years. Small and medium vehicle manufacturers in the mid-price segment were particularly affected, in particular the parent business branches facing structural economic difficulties. In this case there is also Adam Opel AG, who had to lay off 2,881 people in Germany. I am pleased that we have at our disposal this rapid assistance tool, which can provide support to workers affected by this unfortunate situation. Unfortunately, workers are directly exposed to international business practices or economic cycles. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can financially support a number of measures to reintegrate into the labour market, retrain and transfer to other undertakings, which can engage.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, it is also Europe's role to help countries, but especially citizens who have experienced the worst, and to be able to give them the tools to rebuild their lives and their futures.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for the German car manufacturer Adam Opel AG. Due to the financial crisis, car sales in Western Europe have dropped dramatically. Those hardest hit were the manufacturers of small and medium-sized vehicles of the medium-price segment and Adam Opel AG as a major player in this field suffered particularly hard. Sales of Opel/Vauxhall-branded cars in Europe fell by 39 % between 2007 and 2013. Nearly 3000 workers were dismissed when the Adam Opel AG plant in Bochum shut down in December 2014. The resulting redundancies negatively impact the local economy in Bochum, where the unemployment rate is already far above the German average. Under the EGF Regulation, Germany is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 which will help 2,692 redundant workers to find new jobs.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ While I support the need to support unemployed young people up to the age of 25 through education, vocational training or training, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund cannot effectively help redundante workers find work, i.e. achieve a long-term solution.  Germany argues that the closure of the Adam Opel AG plant in Bochum and thus the redundancies of workers is linked to the global financial and economic crisis; but it is obvious that €6 958 623 in financial assistance from the Fund cannot bring them back to the labour market, as it will not create new jobs.  As I have pointed out in previous similar requirements for the mobilisation of the European Global Development Fund, long-term objectives can only be achieved by reducing the tax burden on companies and removing bureaucratic barriers that hinder business.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (application EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel, Germany) has been sh butted. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to workers when they lose their jobs as a result of structural changes in world trade or when large companies cease to operate. This was also the case in the case of the Opel plant in Germany, when as many as 2692 workers lost their jobs.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report proposes that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) be used to further train former Opel employees to reconnect with the labour market and develop new skills and skills. Overall, the aim is to respond better to changes caused by globalisation, including the exodus of large firms abroad. However, I believe that such processes do not fall within the EU's remit and must be dealt with at a subsidiary level. That is why I voted against them in many other cases where such programmes were put to the vote. Germany is strong enough to meet these requirements itself, and that is why I remain faithful to my previous voting behaviour.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is positive that the European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support for workers who suffer the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global economic and financial crisis and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market . And it is good that the German authorities have moved fast to get this grant. Adam Opel AG was disadvantaged by its parent company General Motors , which only allowed to sell their vehicles in Europe , thus excluding Opel emerging markets in other continents ; believes that the austerity policies imposed in European countries contributed to the sharp decline in sales of Opel / Vauxhall. I welcome that the dismissed workers could benefit from the variety of the proposed measures , in order to improve their employment prospects and adapt to the actual demand in the labor market .

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of funds should be transparent and efficient. I voted in favour of the application report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstained as in this case there is a high risk the EGF contribution could be used to finance MS obligations.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – In Western Europe, car sales have fallen dramatically to their lowest level in 20 years. It follows that these events are directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis, as referred to in Regulation (EC) No 546/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council(6); Furthermore, I stress that manufacturers of small and medium-sized vehicles belonging to the mid-price segment have been particularly affected and that the crisis has therefore had a particularly significant impact on Adam Opel AG, which is one of the most important players in the medium-priced small and medium-sized car market.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EGF application filed by the German company Adam Opel AG on 26 February 2015. It is worthwhile to remind that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and/or as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. In this particular case, therefore, the EGF will be mobilised in order to provide a financial contribution of EUR 6 958 623 in respect of the application submitted by Germany.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay redundancies as a result of the cessation of different business activities of Member States. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Opel's redundancies in one of the German regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This mobilisation of the EGF serves to minimise the impacts of adam opel's redundancies. The dismissal of 2 881 employees in Adam Opel AG and in a supplier undertaking justifies the mobilisation of the sum of EUR 6 958 623 in response to germany's application.  These redundancies have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy of Bochum, a highly industrialized area traditionally specialising in coal extraction and steel production, which has faced serious structural challenges since the 1960s. The unemployment rate in the Rhur region has already reached levels well above the national average, currently around 11 %. The fund provides for measures to support workers that will do little to solve the social problem in which it finds itself. On the contrary, it is therefore more necessary to implement investment policies that create and maintain jobs with rights.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Like my group, I am voting against any disbursement from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), as well as against it. The EGF is designed to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020. This fund can cover up to 60% of the costs of projects that can help redundant workers find a new job or start their own business. The EGF is only used where more than 500 workers are made redundant by a single company (including suppliers and downstream companies) or where many workers in a single industry lose their jobs in one or more neighbouring regions. There is no reason to locate these measures at European level. This is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. I voted for the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at the request of Opel - Germany. The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Germany to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Adam Opel AG plant. In practice, more than EUR 6.9 million will be mobilised from the EGF for Germany with a view to reintegrating 2,692 of the 2,881 workers made redundant from Adam Opel and one of its suppliers to the labour market.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to BE/FORD GENK.  The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Belgium has applied EUR 6 258 654 to deal with a total of 5 111 redundancies. The money is needed to deal with re-training and job search. Personalised services will be accessed through contractors who have managed to get ESF funding. There is an element of mobilisation within the Member States to access employment. The blame factor is aimed at China and the decrease in demand for large passenger cars. 14.6% decrease in demand for these cars in the EU. If it is the case that Ford cannot keep up with competition and innovation from emerging markets then the tax payer is not obliged to bail this company out from redundancy expenditure. UKIP voted against.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Ford's redundancies in one of the Belgian regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the Belgian car manufacturing industry. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis.  In this case, 5,111 workers were dismissed at the Ford Genk car plant and 11 suppliers and downstream producers in Belgium in 2014. The dismissals were partly as a result of the loss of market share for the EU automotive industry over the past decade due to the geographical shift in consumption linked to globalisation. I voted in favour of mobilising the fund in order to provide valuable practical assistance to these dismissed workers in job-search and training services.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: Written. 'What about the closure of car-assembling plants in Flanders, besides what I pointed out in connection with the German Opel fabriek of Bochum, still has to be of the heart, is the following. The European Union sometimes plays a cynical role in this matter with what I might call psychological blunders at best. For example, the European Union carried out the decision - approximately at the same time as the closure of the Ford plant in Genk, Flanders - to take almost EUR 100 million in aid to a Ford plant in - please hold on - Turkey. So you take money from the taxpayer, then hand it out in Turkey and even more of these kind of beautiful countries, and then, partly because of your politics, have to close factories in the EU. Closure of which you have to compensate for the consequences with so-called European money.  Although the European Union sometimes has no logic, it may not even have its own logic (unless it is a waste of taxpayers' money) and you cannot expect the citizen, who has to go through all this, to understand the logic of it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text follows Belgium's request for a financial contribution of EUR 6,268,564 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to 5,111 redundancies, most of which were made at Ford Genk.  It is therefore a question of helping workers who are bearing the brunt of the major changes in the world economy, as evidenced by the disastrous situation of the Belgian car industry, which last year experienced a sharp decline in production even as world production increased. The layoffs at Ford Genk will severely affect the province of Limburg where the company was the largest employer. So I think, since this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulation, I have therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. Nevertheless, this mechanism is widely requested, on a case-by-case basis, I allow myself the possibility of voting in favour of its mobilization.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Belgian purposes in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Ford Genk. I agree with the mobilisation of EUR 6 268 564 for the return of 4 500 workers to the labour market.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, knowing that this 'adjustment fund' is only a bad thing: if it really wants to combat the deleterious effects of globalisation, the European Union must renounce the dogma of the free movement of goods and people and no longer stand in the way of the implementation of protectionist measures. Until we change this aberrant system, I am in favour of using this fund to help the 4,500 workers laid off by Ford in Belgium.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In March 2015, Belgium applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following layoffs at Ford Genk and 11 downstream suppliers and producers. Struck by the crisis, the Belgian automotive industry suffered a sharp decline in production of more than 15%, while overall production increased by 18.9%. The local economy suffered greatly as Ford Genk was the largest employer in the province concerned (Limburg).  I have, of course, supported the proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF to the tune of EUR 6,268,564 in order to help workers who have lost their jobs.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Ford Genk in Belgium. The Belgian authorities state that the fact giving rise to redundancies is the final closure of the plant in Genk and link it to profound structural changes in the patterns of international trade caused by the globalisation and loss of market share of the European automotive industry. This is the fourteenth application under review under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 268 564 and concerns 4 500 workers of the 5 111 workers laid off in Ford Genk and eleven suppliers or transformers.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On 24 March 2015, Belgium submitted the EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies at Ford Genk and 11 downstream suppliers and producers in Belgium. Belgium argued that the European automotive industry had lost a considerable market share over the past decade. Production of passenger cars fell by 14.6% in the EU-27 between 2007 and 2012. During the same period, China more than doubled its market share in passenger car production.  The economic and financial crisis has worsened the situation of the European automotive industry, which has also been hampered by import restrictions in third countries such as Argentina, Brazil and Russia while the EU continues to open its borders without any restrictions.  Nevertheless, I voted for the aid of EUR 6,268,564 to support the 3,701 workers laid off at Ford Genk and 1,180 workers laid off at 11 suppliers or downstream producers of Ford Genk.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report authorising the mobilisation of EUR 6 268 564 from the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, for the benefit of 5 111 workers made redundant as a result of the final closure of Ford in Genk.  At this time of generalised crisis, every form of aid, every opportunity is a very important strategic resource that cannot be ignored or so much worse overlooked. With this in mind, the EGF is one of the most useful tools provided by the EU to give practical help to all those workers who have lost their jobs.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a report on a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 from the EGF following the 5 111 redundancies in Ford Genk (Belgium) and eleven suppliers or transformers operating in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers.  With this request, and to date, this sector has been the subject of 22 EGF applications, 11 of them based on globalization of trade and 10 on the global financial and economic crisis. This application contains three types of measures for covered laid-off workers: individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and recycling, and compensation and incentives. In 2013 there was a first wave of layoffs in Ford Genk that resulted in a first application to the FEAG and the second concerns the layoffs that the Ford Genk plant carried out in 2014 until the final closure of the facility in December 2014. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament agrees with the Commission's proposal to grant financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to the Belgian plant Ford Genk, where 5 111 workers have been made redundant from 11 suppliers or downstream companies. According to the Belgian authorities, the increase in redundancies at Ford Genk was due to the final closure of the Ford plant in Genke. They link this closure to the significant structural changes in world trade trends resulting from globalisation and recall that the European automotive industry has lost a significant market share over the last decade. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers include three measures: (i) individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services, (ii) training and retraining, and (iii) benefits and incentives.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. I agree with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to make a financial contribution under that Regulation. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The redundancies are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8 000 jobs in total, most of which affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Very similar to Olova's story is also this one from Belgium, only here on wallpaper car manufacturer Ford. Here, too, the crisis has claimed its toll, with a total of more than 8000 workers made redundant. That is why here, too, we have supported the proposal and allocated aid, which we hope will be aimed at restructuring and increasing competitiveness.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Ford Genk) Mobilisation Report, to help around 4,500 former workers through a coordinated package of personalised services, including individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training, benefits and incentives. Protecting workers and their rights always comes first to me as a social democrat and we must do everything we can to help workers who have lost their jobs and financial security through the impact of the global economic crisis.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the Belgian car manufacturing industry. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis.  In this case, 5,111 workers were dismissed at the Ford Genk car plant and 11 suppliers and downstream producers in Belgium in 2014. The dismissals were partly as a result of the loss of market share for the EU automotive industry over the past decade due to the geographical shift in consumption linked to globalisation. I voted in favour of mobilising the fund in order to provide valuable practical assistance to these dismissed workers in job-search and training services.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that it is up to the Union to help those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis. In this case, the closure of Ford Genk had a devastating impact on the economy of the whole Limburg region, having led to a 2% increase in unemployment and a fall in GDP of between 2.6% and 2.9%.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing.
