This proposal aims to provide Belgium with a financial contribution of around 6.3 million euros, from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the dismissal of 5,111 employees, including 3,701 at Ford Genk. This financial assistance corresponds to 60% of the total estimated cost of the proposed measures as set out in the EGF regulation and is intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. While China has managed to double its market share in the automotive sector, EU Member States saw their new car sales fall by 14.6% between 2007 and 2012. These results show us that the decline in sales and the numerous economic layoffs in the European automotive sector are mainly the result of unfair competition from emerging countries, led by China. The social, environmental and monetary dumping they practice is never denounced by european authorities who deplore the effects they cherish. Even if these funds are not a lasting solution to the problems related to wild globalization, we believe it is important to help Belgian laid-off workers. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The decrease in car production caused by major structural changes in world trade as a result of globalisation has led, among other things, to the permanent closure of the Ford Genk plant. 5,111 people were fired from the Ford plant in Genk, which is a loss for limburg Province, as the Ford plant was the largest employer in the province. The European Commission's decision to allocate EUR 6 268 564 to 4 500 redundant workers to support their reintegration into the labour market is a real support. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the Ford plant in Genk, because it is an important financial source for a new professional start, but also an opportunity to improve the employability of all workers.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, 5,111 redundancies due to the final closure of Genk's Ford in 2014, including 1,180 at eleven suppliers and producers downstream. The EGF will be mobilised for € 6,268,564 (60% of total costs), covering approximately 4,500 redundancies. This mobilisation of the EGF follows that due to the first wave of redundancies in 2013. Ford was the largest employer in the province of Limburg; redundancies have caused significant damage to the area's economy, given the total loss of more than 8,000 jobs (including indirect losses), most of which affect EU citizens aged 30-54, the increase in the unemployment rate between 1.8 and 2 percentage points (with an increase of up to 29.4% in the regional unemployment rate , from 6.8% to 8.8%,a fall in GDP of between 2.6% and 2.9%, as well as a potential 10.9% drop in labour productivity due to the great importance of the car industry for labour productivity in the region. I always remain on the side of the workers and their families!

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Ford Genk in Belgium. The amount of aid amounts to 6,268,564 euros. 4881 employees will be able to benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the world of work. The demand is justified given the decline of the Belgian automotive sector in the face of increasing international competition.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to the application made by Belgium following the redundancies at Ford in Genk, operating in the automotive manufacturing sector , trailers and semi-trailers, and at 11 suppliers and producers downstream in Belgium. This application concerns 5,111 workers made redundant. In addition, eligible beneficiaries include 230 workers made redundant before or after the four-month reference period. In order to establish the link between redundancies and major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, it has been shown that between 2007 and 2012 car production decreased by 14.6% in the EU, while, over the same period, Asian competitors increased their market share in the sector in question. In view of the link between redundancies and structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the Belgian car manufacturing industry. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis.  In this case, 5,111 workers were dismissed at the Ford Genk car plant and 11 suppliers and downstream producers in Belgium in 2014. The dismissals were partly as a result of the loss of market share for the EU automotive industry over the past decade due to the geographical shift in consumption linked to globalisation. I voted in favour of mobilising the fund in order to provide valuable practical assistance to these dismissed workers in job-search and training services.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to BE/FORD GENK.  The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion Belgium has applied EUR 6 258 654 to deal with a total of 5111 redundancies. The money is needed to deal with re-training and job search. Personalised services will be accessed through contractors who have managed to get ESF funding. There is an element of mobilisation within the Member States to access employment.  The blame factor is aimed at China and the decrease in demand for large passenger cars. 14.6% decrease in demand for these cars in the EU. If it is the case that Ford cannot keep up with competition and innovation from emerging markets then the tax payer is not obliged to bail this company out from redundancy expenditure. I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I understand that Ford Genk is the largest employer of the Limburg province; however, its production decreased 15.58% while the global production increased 18.9%. This phenomenon has affected workers as well and I think the funding will certainly improve their conditions, thus I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the second simultaneous request to mobilise the Fund to help the automotive sector, a sign that it suffers widespread. I therefore felt it was absolutely right to vote in favour of the allocation of just over EUR 6 million for the reintegration into employment of 4 500 people who have been out of work as a result of Ford's decision to close the Genk plant and concentrate its production capacity in Valencia, Spain.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is more than 6 million euros for the reintegration of 4,500 workers laid off by Ford in Belgium as a result of the drop in demand in the face of globalisation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The application concerns 5111 workers made redundant by Ford Genk, a vehicle manufacturer, to mobilise the European Adjustment Fund for Belgium with a view to their reintegration into the labour market. It concerns the mobilisation of an amount of around EUR 6 million aimed at making it available to support redundant workers who are in a difficult position. It is important to mobilise this Fund in favour of workers, in cooperation with the respective countries, because it is a network for the protection of the dismissed.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of the Belgian company Ford Genk. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund for a total amount of EUR 10 447 607. The request is based on the professional relocation of 5 111 redundant workers, of whom 3 701 concern Ford Genk and 1 180 concern eleven suppliers and producers downstream, operating in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 and 11 downstream suppliers and producers, and it is estimated that some 4 500 redundant workers will participate in the measures.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. Among the causes of the crisis that hit the Ford Genk hard, a 14.6% drop in car production in the EU-27 between 2007 and 2012, while over the same period China more than doubled its market share in the sector in question. These events are directly linked to major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Ford Genk case because, taking into account the various data, there is a decrease in demand for vehicles, therefore a serious decline in car production in the province of Limburg, the total loss of more than 8,000 jobs in that sector of employment and the fact that the workers made redundant are all between 30 and 54 years old. I believe that the conditions are in place to use the EGF, which was set up precisely to provide additional support to workers who are found to be victims of globalisation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to BE/FORD GENK.  The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Belgium has applied EUR 6 258 654 to deal with a total of 5 111 redundancies. The money is needed to deal with re-training and job search. Personalised services will be accessed through contractors who have managed to get ESF funding. There is an element of mobilisation within the Member States to access employment.  The blame factor is aimed at China and the decrease in demand for large passenger cars. 14.6% decrease in demand for these cars in the EU. If it is the case that Ford cannot keep up with competition and innovation from emerging markets then the tax payer is not obliged to bail this company out from redundancy expenditure. UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 6,268,564 in favour of Belgium with the aim of supporting the 5,111 workers made redundant in Ford Genk and 11 suppliers or downstream producers.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgian authorities claim that the event that led to the redundancies at Ford Genk is the permanent closure of the plant in the city of Genk. Unfortunately, the causes of this closure are due to the continuous changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, and also to the fact that the European car industry has lost a significant market share over the last ten years. The Commission has also concluded that belgium's application fulfils the conditions for financial assistance from the Fund, which was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows. I therefore fully agree with Belgium's request to protect these workers, supporting them in terms of personalised assistance in job search, case management and general information and training, retraining, allowances and incentive services.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Major structural changes in case of Ford Genk necessitate funds to be allocated. These measures co-financed by the EGF would help 4 500 redundant workers to find new jobs by providing them with individual job search assistance and professional development as well as a variety of training courses and hiring bonuses. In this case Ford Genk being the largest employer in the region as well as having the most dismissals of employees in the area raising unemployment in the region.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium (Rübig report) has applied for EGF mobilisation for just over EUR 6 million to facilitate the reintegration into employment of 4,500 Limburg workers who have been out of work following Ford's decision to close its Genk plant and concentrate its production capacity in Valencia, Spain. I am voting in favour because this instrument can help workers, although it is not the solution to the problem.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Ford's redundancies in one of the Belgian regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Between 2007 and 2012, passenger car production in the EU-27 decreased by 14.6%, and over the same period China more than more than re-2000 its market share in the production of passenger cars. These events relate directly to significant structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation. The Belgian car industry suffered a 15.58% fall in production, while global production increased by 18.9%. In Belgium, 5 111 people were dismissed from Ford Genk and therefore submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The redundancies are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8 000 jobs in total, most of which affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I supported Belgium's use of the Fund to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and to support their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that provides for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Belgium relating to redundancies in Ford Genk and 11 suppliers operating in the motor vehicle industry. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns, mainly in the production of passenger cars. I believe that employees made redundant should be supported through training and re-training and hence I voted in favour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the mobilization of 6,268,564 euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the benefit of the 4,500 people made redundant by the car manufacturer FORD Genk in Belgium. With an annual budget of 150 million euros per year during the period 2014-2020, the EGF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. Faced with international competition, some European sectors are undergoing major and sometimes costly restructurings in employment. Considering that one of the aims of European funds is to support workers in this context and to enable them to retrain permanently, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's support for European citizens in difficulty is essential, as in the case of people in Belgium facing redundancies in the automotive sector. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – The amount proposed in this Directive will be used to reorient workers who lost their jobs at the closure of Ford in Genk in 2014 to another job. Ford Genk was the largest employer in Limburg and it is important that people are quickly helped on their way to a new job. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps to enable personal services and guidance to a new job. I think it is important that, with the help of the EU, we can support the economy in Limburg.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium. This fund will enable employees made redundant at Ford Genk to return to the labour market. The permanent closure of the plant is due to the serious crisis that has hit the car industry over the last ten years and the changes in world trade due to globalisation.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The closure of the Ford plant in Genk following a decline in production of some cars and sales of new cars within the EU, mainly to the benefit of Asian manufacturers, has led to the dismissal of all the plant's staff.   A very large wave of layoffs among the factory staff, with a considerable fall in the local economy.  The mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to provide additional assistance to Belgium necessary for the reintegration of former Ford Genk employees.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 This file provides financial support for the guidance of 4881 dismissed employees of Ford Genk. This can be done in the form of career guidance, retraining, start-up support and premiums for new self-employed persons. The support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) complements the Limburg reconversion tools within the framework of the Strategic Action Plan for Limburg in the Square (SALK). The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the EGF, but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. However, as long as the EGF remains in force in the unaltered form, the N-VA shall support any EGF dossier relating to its own Member State.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they lost their jobs as a result of changing world trade patterns. However, me and my group do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for introducing such policies, nor do we believe it to be an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. And that's why I'm voting no. However, I stress that I fully support measures to introduce policies that create growth and jobs. This report requires 6.2 million euro. 4,881 workers who lost their jobs at Ford/Genk.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 under that Regulation from the total cost of EUR 10 447 607. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The layoffs are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8,000 jobs in total, the majority of redundancies affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54, with an increase in the unemployment rate of between 1.8 and 2 percentage points (the region's unemployment rate rises from 6.8% to 8.8%), GDP falls by between 2.6% and 2.9%, and labour productivity is potentially reduced by 10.9%. , because of the very important role played by the automotive industry in terms of labour productivity in the region. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (the 'Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the disaster-affected regions and that the Fund's intervention should not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. Belgium has submitted an application following redundancies or terminations of activity at Ford Genk and in 11 downstream suppliers or producers. I therefore agree that a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 should be mobilised to meet belgium's request.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates are critical of the Globalisation Fund as such and have voted against its creation. We have also opposed the EU alleviating funds for this purpose in budgetary votes. However, we do not fight over individual payments once the fund is in place.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe the funds are essential to the people of Genk.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and taking into account the Council Regulation, as well as the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 to Belgium, namely Ford Genk, which had to lay off 8 000 workers. Production of passenger cars in the EU-27 decreased by 14.6 % between 2007 and 2012 and China's share of the passenger car market more than doubled over the same period. As a result of the redundancies, the economy of Limburg province is severely damaged.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of allocating the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 5,111 redundancies due to the final closure of Genk's Ford in 2014.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk application. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2015, Belgium submitted a request for financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) following 5 111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of which 3 701 workers were made redundant in Ford Genk and 1 180 in 11 suppliers and downstream producers. Those events are directly linked to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. I therefore supported the mobilisation of the EGF of up to EUR 6 268 564 to help workers who have lost their jobs.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 under that Regulation from the total cost of EUR 10 447 607. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The layoffs are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8,000 jobs in total, the majority of redundancies affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54, with an increase in the unemployment rate of between 1.8 and 2 percentage points (the region's unemployment rate rises from 6.8% to 8.8%), GDP falls by between 2.6% and 2.9%, and labour productivity is potentially reduced by 10.9%. , because of the very important role played by the automotive industry in terms of labour productivity in the region. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk bearing in mind that this fund supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the patterns of world trade, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk application, submitted by Belgium. The EGF contribution of EUR 6,268,564 will support the very serious consequences of the redundancy of 5,111 workers, including 3,701 from the Ford Genk plant and 1,180 employed in related industries and downstream industries. The EU's intervention is the first, good news, for some 4,500 workers. The Ford Genk affair, an expression of the general crisis in the European automobile sector and global competition, has serious consequences for the production of regional territory, which has fallen by more than 15%: the province of Limburg loses its main employer and 8,000 jobs between direct and indirect employment, and sees the unemployment rate increase by 1.8/2 percentage points, a fall in GDP of between 2.6% and 2.9%, and a fall in labour productivity of 10.9%.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in line with my group's line: Amendment EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk. I am very critical of the Globalisation Fund as a whole. In the present case, I am also convinced that the wrong economic policy decisions have caused Belgium to take the jobs.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to use the EGF under application EGF/2015/003/BE/Ford Genk. At a time of increasing globalisation and a sometimes weakening global economy, it is important that European companies remain competitive in the future. Workers who have lost their jobs as a result of this adjustment deserve support to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Ford Genk in order to ensure support is provided to employees of the company who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the application of Ford car manufacturers in Genk, Belgium because this case falls completely in line with how the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds should be used. The financial crisis as well as major changes in trade patterns due to globalisation resulted in the need for these funds to help struggling communities affected by large redundancies. The sum of EUR 6 268 564 made available provides a platform for re-training and preparation to re-enter the workforce.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the application by the Belgian authorities for EGF funds for workers made redundant in Ford Genk and its suppliers/downstream producers of which 4 500 are expected to participate with a contribution of EUR 6 268 564 from the fund. The manufacture of passenger cars in the EU is an industry heavily affected by globalisation - production of passenger cars decreased by 14.6 % in the EU-27 between 2007 and 2012 while China more than doubled its market share. Ford was the largest employer in the province of Limburg and the loss of more than 8 000 jobs including indirect job losses has had a huge impact on the region’s economy mostly affecting people between the ages of 30 and 54 in their prime working life. The use of the fund should help to support these workers with a coordinated package of personalised services including job search assistance, training and re-training and allowances and incentives. While it is important to build upon the skills acquired by the affected workers in these services it is also crucial to improve their employability and anticipate current and future labour market demands to provide real added value.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 under that Regulation from the total cost of EUR 10 447 607. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set in 2006 to express solidarity with European workers. It is mean to reintegrate into the labour market the workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as I believe that the consequences of the economic crisis, which has greatly affected Ford Genk in Belgium, need to be addressed in as efficiently and quickly as possible. Belgium's automotive industry saw a 15.58% drop in production, among which Ford Genk had great difficulty and laid off thousands of workers in two waves, until the final closure of the plant in December 2014. Belgium has applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support redundantic people by providing a wide range of measures to make it easier for redundantic workers to return to the labour market. Emergencies imply specific measures that I support in this case.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Belgium for a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 6,268,564 following 5,111 redundancies, most of which occurred at Ford Genk.  This initiative is therefore part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, and to the reintegration of laid-off workers, in a grim context where the Belgian automotive industry experienced a decline in production of 15.58% while world production increased by 18.9%. These layoffs at Ford Genk seriously damage the social fabric of the province of Limburg, where the company was the largest employer. After review, I consider that this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Belgium is committed to taking effective and appropriate measures to reintegrate laid-off workers. So I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. All too often, as repeated here, the EU is the cause and the problem and then tries to mollify the impact with financial help.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Paul Rubig's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Ford's sacked employees in Belgium. The fund will provide EUR 6,268,564 for the 4,881 sacked employees, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because Belgium's request for financial assistance from the European Adjustment Fund follows the dismissal of more than 5,000 people by Ford Belgium, and therefore justifies the use of this instrument.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. If Ford Genk were to close, around 8,000 jobs would be lost – including indirect job losses – particularly affecting people aged between 30 and 54, which would lead to a two percentage point increase in the unemployment rate in the Limburg district to a total of 8.8%. Regional GDP would weaken by 3% and labour productivity in the region would fall by 10.9%. In order to help the staff and the region in the spirit of a Europe of solidarity, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 under that Regulation from the total cost of EUR 10 447 607. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The layoffs are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8,000 jobs in total, the majority of redundancies affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54, with an increase in the unemployment rate of between 1.8 and 2 percentage points (the region's unemployment rate rises from 6.8% to 8.8%), GDP falls by between 2.6% and 2.9%, and labour productivity is potentially reduced by 10.9%. , because of the very important role played by the automotive industry in terms of labour productivity in the region. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I regret that workers in Belgium are in such a difficult situation. At the same time, I am confident that Belgium, as one of the richest EU countries, can compensate for any losses of workers without any difficulty. In my view, only peripheral countries and recently acceded Member States should be granted aid from that fund. It may be worth comparing the funds requested with the aid allocated to whole countries in connection with natural disasters.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is the instrument promoted by the European Union to provide support to workers made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. Today we are voting on a request from the Belgian authorities, who have called for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of workers made redundant at Ford's plant in Genk. I know that I am voting in favour of this proposal because it is another sign of concrete help that the European Parliament is sending to workers and companies in difficulty as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off by Ford in Genk, Belgium. Following the final closure of the Ford plant in Genk, more than 5,000 workers were laid off at Ford and 11 downstream suppliers or producers. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade. The European Union does not provide a structural solution to these problems. On the contrary, as a promoter of globalization, she is one of them. However, while the WEF can help reintegrate laid-off workers back into the labour market, it cannot be opposed.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it unlocks more than 6 million euros for the reintegration of 4,500 workers laid off by Ford in Belgium because of the drop in global demand linked to the economic crisis.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Report on a financial contribution of EUR 6,268,564 from the EGF following the 5,111 redundancies in Ford Genk (Belgium) and eleven suppliers or transformers operating in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers.  With this request, and to date, this sector has been the subject of 22 EGF applications, 11 of them based on globalization of trade and 10 on the global financial and economic crisis. This application contains three types of measures for covered laid-off workers: 1) individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, 2) training and recycling, and 3) compensation and incentives. Naturally in our group we agree with the existence and implementation of this Fund, which is why we voted in favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. In 2012, Belgium, one of the world's richest countries, is calling for an Orwellian-named fund to bail out the low competitiveness of German firms caused by a slushy welfare state and an overregulated economy. There can be no vote other than against this euro nonsense.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. In March 2015, Belgium applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Ford Genk amount to €6.2 million. The European Fund was created to provide assistance to former employees in finding a new job, education or self-employment, which lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis. Belgian company Ford Genk suffered a 14.6% drop in passenger car sales, due to the economic crisis, due to the growing influence of manufacturers from China and Southeast Asian countries. As a result of the drop in sales, 3701 workers were made redundant at Ford Genk, and an additional 1180 workers became redundant in 11 suppliers and other manufacturers cooperating with Ford Genk. I supported the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Ford Genk help laid-off employees.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Belgian Government is seeking assistance in connection with similar problems at the Ford plant in Ghent. The amount is the same – about 7 million – and the reasoning is similar – a 15% reduction in demand. In addition, the situation is affected by the decrease in demand in Russia, Brazil and Argentina.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the redundancies of 5 111 workers, of whom 3 701 have been made redundant from Ford Genk and the rest from supply companies and downstream automotive manufacturers. European automotive production decreased by 14.6% between 2007 and 2012, while production in China's automotive sector doubled over the same period. Measures for reintegration into the labour market are to affect 4 500 redundancies. Belgium has fulfilled the conditions for efg support and is therefore releasing a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 from the Fund out of a total cost of EUR 10 447 607.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (Application EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk, from Belgium), since the Belgian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 1 January 2015, well before the decision and even from the request for EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Ford Genk.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has applied to the Commission to mobilise a total of EUR 6 268 564 under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to workers made redundant by Ford Genk, a car manufacturing company. The application appears to comply with the requirements for determining the financial contribution laid down in the Regulation. This instrument was set up to provide active labour market support measures, exclusively designed to help workers made redundant and made redundant as a result of structural changes and to facilitate their access to new employment.  I therefore voted in favour of the report and the Commission proposal on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium, in order to allow the occupational reintegration of workers made redundant at Ford Genk, operating in the field of "Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers".

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the Ford plant in Genk, Belgium. Belgian authorities claim that Ford was the province's largest employer; the redundancies caused considerable damage to the area's economy, with the total loss (including indirect losses) of more than 8,000 jobs. This is also due to changes in international trade flows due to globalisation, resulting in a loss of market share in the European automotive sector. This is the fourteenth application to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of 6,268,564 euros and concerns 4,500 workers out of 5,111 workers made redundant at the Ford plant in Genk.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Belgium submitted the application on the basis of redundancies and the cessation of operations at Ford Genk and 11 suppliers and downstream manufacturers. The reason for the closure is due to far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns as a result of globalisation. The aim is to help redundant workers to reintegrate into the labour market. We must therefore support this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application for funds to help workers who suffer from unforeseen redundancies.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Last year, Ford's site in Belgium closed its doors, laying off 4,500 people. That same year 2014 Ford made 3.5 billion profits. Probably in connection with the 49% increase in Ford car production in China that same year. We are proposed here to support the relocation of the automotive industry via a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAM). Once again, the Fund is playing its destructive role. Instead of helping workers it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Belgium for a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 6,268,564 following 5,111 redundancies, most of which occurred at Ford Genk.  This initiative is therefore part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, and to the reintegration of laid-off workers, in a grim context where the Belgian automotive industry experienced a decline in production of 15.58% while world production increased by 18.9%. These layoffs at Ford Genk seriously damage the social fabric of the province of Limburg, where the company was the largest employer. Upon review, this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Belgium is committed to taking effective and appropriate measures to reintegrate laid-off workers. The congressman voted FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, application EGF/2015/003 BE/FORD. According to the Commission, the measures described are active labour market measures falling within the eligible actions defined in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. These actions do not replace passive social protection measures.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This is an application that meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the Unions disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 4,500 workers in the automotive industry in Belgium due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Major changes in the structure of global trade are having an impact on employers. After the economic crisis, the Belgian automotive industry experienced a 15.58% decline in production while world production increased by 18.9%. The automotive industry has undergone numerous restructurings, such as the dismissal of a large number of employees due to the permanent closure of the Ford Genk plant, which is hurting the regional economy.  It was necessary to help this company, which occupies an important place in the Belgian economy and therefore employs a significant number of workers.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Following examination of application EGF/2015/003BE/Ford Genk, the Commission decided that the conditions laid down for the submission and submission of the proposal were fulfilled by Belgium. The request for a contribution has been approved and Belgium is eligible for a financial contribution to support redundant workers due to globalisation and significant changes in the structure of world trade. Production in the Belgian automotive industry decreased by 15,58 %, linked to the closure of the Genk plant and redundancies at other Ford production plants. I agree with the decision to mobilise a fund to provide staffing services and measures for workers in order to integrate into the labour market. I join the appeal to the Commission to carry out a study on asian and South American markets, to make European producers more competitive and to gain a stronger presence in these prosperous markets.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because it is important to give the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The application relates to 5 111 redundancies in Ford Genk and 11 suppliers or downstream producers, operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, within the period 1 September 2014-31 December 2014. The EGAF funding of EUR 6 268 564 shall contribute to help 4 500 former workers through a coordinated package of personalised services including individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and re-training, allowances and incentives. The redundancies were caused by the major structural changes in the world trade patterns, directly linked to globalisation, namely the production of passenger cars having decreased by 14.6% in the EU-27 between 2007 and 2012, while in the same period China more than doubled its market share.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created with the purpose of giving complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In the present case, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in Ford Genk (Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers) and 11 suppliers or producers downstream. The source of the redundancies is the total closure of the plant, as the European car industry has lost a significant market share. I stress the importance of improving the employability of all workers made redundant through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, and it is vital that the proposed training is adapted not only to the needs of redundant workers but also to the real environment of enterprises. I therefore support the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be mobilised to provide 6.3 million euros in aid to the 4,500 workers laid off by Ford in Belgium for their reintegration into the labour market. The record clearly shows that this restructuring is linked to the major structural change in international trade due to globalization and slowing growth in Asia as well as to increased international competition.  I voted in favour of this aid to promote the reintegration of these workers, even though I believe that these subsidies can disempower the big bosses.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, e.g. when a large company shuts down or production is moved outside the EU, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Labour MEPs have consistently supported EGF applications, moreover it is worth noting that opportunities for the UK to claim from this fund may arise in the near future and the EGF could help those made redundant and wider communities affected by large shocks to the local economy. It is also worth noting the EGF can do this whilst minimising the cost to the UK Government.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted three reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these three reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 6,268,564 from this fund to 4881 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of Ford Genk and 11 subcontractors in Belgium.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. This application, the fourteenth in the 2015 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 6,268,564 for Belgium. It covers 4,500 of the 5,111 workers made redundant at Ford Genk, a company operating in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers, and 11 suppliers or manufacturers downstream. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of Mr Rübig's report because I believe that workers, victims of the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the advancement of globalisation, must have full support from the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Ford Genk, Belgium.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in the Belgian car manufacturing industry. The EGF can be mobilised to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis.  In this case, 5,111 workers were dismissed at the Ford Genk car plant and 11 suppliers and downstream producers in Belgium in 2014. The dismissals were partly as a result of the loss of market share for the EU automotive industry over the past decade due to the geographical shift in consumption linked to globalisation. I voted in favour of mobilising the fund in order to provide valuable practical assistance to these dismissed workers in job-search and training services.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I also support this report, as the Fund supports affected workers in difficult financial times.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution aims to validate the payment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds (FEAM) to Ford Genk of Belgium, following the closure of its entire plant in the Limburg region (loss of 8,000 jobs). The FEAM was designed to contribute financially to the reintegration of people made redundant by a European company whose closure was caused by an inability to remain economically competitive in a globalised market. The extent of the social consequences caused by the closure and the economic justifications of the latter (a decrease in Belgian car exports of 16.41% in 3 years) obviously makes the use of FEAM legitimate.  Nevertheless, this report includes an amendment calling on the Commission to conduct an economic study on the Asian and South American markets to inform European industrialists of the changing requirements for competitiveness in these markets. This would be tantamount to asking the Commission to encourage these manufacturers to relocate. That's why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Belgian car industry is struggling with a lack of income, which has led to redundancies. The market has favoured Asian car production in recent decades, from which European companies benefit little. This change has been strongly influenced by this change in the Belgian car industry. Financial support will therefore help them to cope with the losses.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is essential for this German company. It should be noted that the Ford Genk plant was the largest employer in the province of Limburg, so the redundancies caused significant damage to the limburg economy. In order to help people who have been particularly hard hit by their loss of employment, effective assistance is needed so that they can find a new job as soon as possible. Such assistance may include job search, vocational guidance, tailor-made vocational training and retraining, as well as special temporary measures. The support provided represents solidarity across the EU and it is therefore essential to ensure its proper uptake. In order to prevent the spread of negative consequences in the region, redundant workers need to be helped to find new jobs and reintegrate into the labour market as soon as possible.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the crisis in the car sales sector in Europe, with particular attention to belgium's needs, I believe that the fund needs to be used to deal with this problem. Therefore, I have chosen to guarantee my vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account that the Belgian automotive industry has been steadily declining for some time and has reached a bigger decline than has been recorded in other Member States of the European Union combined, and that the number of jobs in the automotive sector in Belgium has been drastically decreasing for the third year in a row, and workers are constantly being laid off, I supported the Belgian demand for the mobilisation of the European Fund for Adaptation in Aid to Belgium in the automotive industry. In the economic crisis facing the whole world, we must do everything we can to preserve jobs and manufacturing, which will then contribute to strengthening national economies and economic development. It is important that workers do not bear the brunt of the crisis, so I welcome the fact that with this mobilisation of the European Adjustment Fund, the European Union will help, in particular, workers who will have the bulk of their resources available and then the recovery of the auto industry in Belgium. The Belgian request for mobilisation meets the conditions necessary for the authorisation to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, so I supported it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be mobilised to provide 6.3 million euros in aid to the 4,500 workers laid off by Ford in Belgium for their reintegration into the labour market. The record clearly shows that this restructuring is linked to the major structural change in international trade due to globalization and slowing growth in Asia as well as to increased international competition.  I voted in favour of this aid to promote the reintegration of these workers, even though I believe that these subsidies can disempower the big bosses. A real change in economic model and intelligent protectionism would be more effective than these short-term relief measures.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an important instrument of assistance for all those affected by structural changes in global trade, in particular workers whose work becomes sublet in the context of production relocation, but also influenced by the financial crisis and the resulting business decisions or business closures. I welcome the Commission's decision to grant Belgium €6 268 564 in aid in the case of Ford Genk, as well as concrete measures to assist workers in the form of job search assistance, training and subsidies.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to Belgium's application to provide a financial contribution to Ford Genk. This application was made following 5,111 redundancies, of which 3,701 concerned Ford Genk and 1,180 concerned eleven suppliers and producers of the related product. The car manufacturing sector has experienced serious difficulties in recent years due, in particular, to a sharp decline in the EU's market share. Some car manufacturers, and their suppliers, have been forced to close production plants and restructure their workforces. The latter have led to a large number of redundancies. I hope that the mobilisation of the EGF will prove to be a decisive instrument for supporting these workers and a valuable aid for entrepreneurs affected by the crisis in the automotive sector.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The automotive industry has been heavily affected by global competition and the increase in offshoring of production sites. The direct consequence is the closure of European sites and the dismissal of many European workers. The EU has set up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of globalisation on workers.  This fund was requested by Belgium to the tune of EUR 6,268,564 following the closure of the Ford Genk plant. I support this request and stress the importance of this fund in helping workers in the industrial sector access new training and reorient themselves to other more dynamic sectors.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Clear support for former laid-off workers at the Ford Genk plant. This is the message delivered this afternoon by MEPs who approved the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 6,268,564. In concrete terms, this is a sum intended for the 4,500 laid-off workers of the car manufacturer, which closed its Genk plant in December 2014, in order to facilitate their job search and more generally their career reorientation. This small financial boost comes after a closure that has become inevitable in a difficult economic environment. The Belgian automotive industry experienced a 16% decline between 2011 and 2013, while world production increased by 19% during the same period. This decline had a significant economic impact on the province of Limburg, where Ford Genk was the largest employer. The Belgian government has very specific ideas about the use of this aid: support in the search for a job; training and retraining; allowances and incentives.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in global trade patterns (globalisation) or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Belgium submitted this application based on the sharp decline in Ford Genk car sales. 3701 workers were made redundant (1,180 more workers made redundant from Ford Genk suppliers and producers). Eur 6 268 564 were mobilised for aid. Belgium submitted this application on the basis of a Criterion of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund which defines at least 500 workers made redundant in a company of a Member State over a reference period of 4 months. Without understaining the general principle, it nevertheless appears to be a criterion tailored to large enterprises.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a report on a financial contribution of 6,268,564 euros from the EAGF following the 5,111 redundancies in Ford Genk (Belgium) and eleven suppliers or transformers operating in the manufacturing sector of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers.  With this request, and to date, this sector has been the subject of 22 EGF applications, 11 of them based on globalization of trade and 10 on the global financial and economic crisis. This application contains three types of measures for covered laid-off workers: individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and recycling, and compensation and incentives; In 2013 there was a first wave of layoffs in Ford Genk that resulted in a first application to the FEAG and the second concerns the layoffs that the Ford Genk plant carried out in 2014 until the final closure of the facility in December 2014.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have of course voted in favour of this report, which mobilises the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) in favour of Belgium and the car manufacturer Ford Genk following the wave of layoffs that occurred after the closure of the plant. Remember, the closure was largely due to a decline in passenger car production and sales of new cars within the European Union, mainly to the benefit of Asian manufacturers. The EGF's request for mobilization, worth 6.3 million euros, is now aimed at helping 4,500 former workers find jobs. Belgium had already received 570,000 euros to help former Ford workers, from the first wave of layoffs in 2013, to get back to work.  I regret, however, that this new tranche of aid is coming... it's late. Moreover, and in general, more resources should be devoted to anticipating restructuring.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of structural changes in international trade, it is important that the European economy is able to implement effectively the instruments to support workers who are affected in this way and thus enable them to reintegrate into the labour market. Bearing in mind this premise, I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium, amounting to EUR 6 268 564, following 5111 redundancies at Ford Genk, which operates in the manufacturing of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers) With this financial contribution from the EGF, it will be possible to mitigate the effects of globalisation , which has had a drastic effect on the reduction of the production of passenger cars by co-financing active labour market measures, leading to long-term and long-term employment, as well as the award of self-employment subsidies, incentives to hire and foster entrepreneurship.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the total amount of EUR 6 268 564 for the Belgian company Ford Genk. This fund will be used for the professional relocation of 4,500 of the 5,111 redundant workers and 11 downstream suppliers or producers.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Ford's redundancies in one of the Belgian regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I do not believe this to be an EU competency. Furthermore the UK does not qualify for this fund.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Like the EGF/2015/002 DE/Adam Opel application, I believe that this application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is completely in line with how the EGF should be being used.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in a request from the Belgian company Ford Genk, I voted in line with the ECR's position against this resolution. I consider it important to create a policy that helps to grow employment and create jobs. At the same time, however, I share the ECR's position and therefore do not consider the European Globalisation Fund to be a proper and adequate instrument for this purpose.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Ford Genk was the largest employer in the Limburg area of Belgium. More than 5 000 people lost their jobs as a result of the closure of the production plant and 11 suppliers were also affected by the decline. This situation is linked to the overall decrease in passenger car production in Europe, which has recently been reduced by 14%. Meanwhile, vehicle production in China has almost doubled. I welcome the fact that the Belgian Government has already started to provide rapid assistance to affected employees through personalised services. I also support the fact that the financial contribution provided by the EU will be earmarked for individual assistance in finding a new job, for training and retraining, and, to a lesser extent, for contributions and incentives. As global consumption moves geographically outside Europe and the majority of those made redundant are working-age men, the redundancies will need to be provided with skills that will enable them to return to the work cycle as quickly as possible.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the redundancies of 5111 redundancies, of which 3701 were made redundant at Ford Genk, 1180 from 11 suppliers and manufacturers in the production phase and to 11 suppliers or manufacturers in the downstream phase. 4500 workers are expected to participate in the measures. The application submitted fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation and Belgium is thus entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 (the total cost is EUR 10 447 607). Ford Genk was the largest employer in Limburg province, and the layoffs caused significant damage to the limbo economy. More than 8000 jobs have been cancelled, with the majority of eu citizens aged between 30 and 54 being made redundant. The situation led to an increase in the unemployment rate of 1.8-2 percentage points and a fall in GDP of 2.6-2.9 per cent. As the Union has put in place appropriate instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, and Belgium fulfils the conditions for disbursing the financial contribution, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Ford and 11 of its suppliers, following the closure of the car factory in Genk, following a request from the Belgian Government. This is the second intervention by the Fund for Ford Genk employees, who, following a first wave of redundancies in 2013, had received 570,000 euros of aid through Belgium aimed at finding a new job. Now, with the final closure of the factory due to the decline in car production and sales in the EU, Belgium has called for a second intervention by the Fund, which is now approved by Parliament, which will allow 4 500 employees laid off by Ford Genk to take advantage of individual routes aimed at relocation to the labour market, totalling EUR 6.3 million.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the restructuring of firms, but on the other hand, I am of the opinion that there are more conceptual solutions than subsidies.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of amendment BE/Ford Genk. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a social policy instrument of the European Union. At the request of EU Member States, workers whose jobs have been lost as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis can be assisted in their search for a new job. In this case, the Globalisation Fund provides EUR 6.3 million. This money supports the 4,500 former Ford Genk workers in their search for new jobs. I welcome the investment in training to help jobseekers find high-quality jobs.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because the purpose of the European Fund is to support redundant and self-employed workers and have ceased to act due to structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation. Thus, Belgium applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the request was supplemented by additional information. This requirement complies with the requirements for determining the financial contribution from the EGF. In order for EGF funds to be used as soon as possible, the decision should apply from the date of its adoption. It was concluded that the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF were met, and I therefore supported the report.
