name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Belgian application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 5111 redundancies in Ford Genk. Belgium intends to use the funds to implement a package of personalised services which has been drawn up in consultation with the targeted beneficiaries, their representatives, social partners, local, regional and national public employment bodies and training institutions as well as the company.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to provide additional assistance to workers in the Member States of the European Union, suffering as a result of major structural changes in global trade. The European Commission has accepted a decision to mobilise funds (EUR 6 268 564) for Belgium's labour market reintegration of more than 4 500 workers laid off at the closure of ford's factory in Genk caused by unfavourable trends in the auto industry and the loss of significant market share. This assistance and mobilisation of funds will provide individual job search assistance for each worker, additional education and training, and incentives to recruit them. I support this report and believe that we must do everything to protect workers and production in the Member States.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the role of Belgium - Ford Genk. Ford Genk, which was the largest employer in the province of Limburg, Belgium, had to lay off more than 8000 employees due to major structural changes in world trade flows. This led to the company's final closure in late 2014. As the second application by Ford Genk fulfils the eligibility criteria for aid, I also supported the report.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF in view of the 5 1111 redundancies at Ford Genk, of whom 3 701 employees have been dismissed from Ford Genk and 11 from 11 suppliers or down processors. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Belgium is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 under that Regulation from the total cost of EUR 10 447 607. Ford Genk has been the largest employer in limburg province so far. The layoffs are causing significant damage to Limburg's economy, with the loss of more than 8,000 jobs in total, the majority of redundancies affect EU citizens between the age of 30 and 54, with an increase in the unemployment rate of between 1.8 and 2 percentage points (the region's unemployment rate rises from 6.8% to 8.8%), GDP falls by between 2.6% and 2.9%, and labour productivity is potentially reduced by 10.9%. , because of the very important role played by the automotive industry in terms of labour productivity in the region. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like Adam Opel in Germany, the Ford Genk factory turned to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to counter the effects of the economic crisis felt in the car manufacturing industry.  Some time ago, Ford Genk was the largest employer in limburg province, but the waves of layoffs brought the total job loss to 8,000. 8 000 people aged 30 to 54 will now be able to benefit from financial assistance through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  I voted in favour of this measure with the hope that 8 000 jobs will be somewhat transferred to the region through retraining and reintegration programmes into the labour market.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, it is also Europe's role to help countries, but especially citizens who have experienced the worst, and to be able to give them the tools to rebuild their lives and their futures. The situation affects me all the more because it happened in Belgium in this case and Genk has taken full force of disastrous decisions, guided by so-called stock market imperatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In December 2014, the Ford Genk car manufacturer’s plant in Belgium closed down due to the global economic crisis. That led to a total loss of more than 8 000 jobs, including indirect job losses. Belgium applied for a financial contribution which will allow for measures targeting an estimated 4 500 redundant workers. Under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund Regulation, Belgium will receive EUR 6 268 564 from the total costs of EUR 10 447 607. I believe it is important to swiftly reintegrate the dismissed workers to the labour market and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Belgian company Ford Genk, as I believe the fund is not an effective tool for providing financial assistance to Member States. In fact, I believe that these short-term measures cannot help redundantant workers find a new job, and will also not help Belgium reduce the unemployment rate. Given the fact that in the European Union from 2007 to 2012 the production of passenger cars decreased by 14.6%, and in some parts of the world, for example China, more than doubled, it is clear that this problem cannot be solved by monetary fees. High tax burdens and bureaucratic barriers are the main problems of slugging and weakening the Economy of the European Union and should focus on finding solutions to these problems, both in the automotive industry and in other sectors.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (application from Belgium — EGF/2015/003 BE/Ford Genk) was supported. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to workers when they lose their jobs as a result of structural changes in world trade, or when companies stop working or move their production. This was also the case in the case of the Ford car plant in Belgium. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund's funding will make it easier for as many as 4500 workers to be able to get back into the labour market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is positive that the European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support for workers who suffer the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global economic and financial crisis and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. I welcome that the dismissed workers could benefit from the variety of the proposed measures , in order to improve their employment prospects and adapt to the actual demand in the labour market.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of funds should be transparent and efficient. I voted in favour of the application report.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support for people who lose their jobs because of major changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation or because of the economic and financial crisis. For the period 2014-2020, the maximum annual budget available to this fund is EUR 150 million. The funds are allocated to projects designed to help the laid off to find a new job or start their own business.  On 24 March 2015, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), following redundancies and cessations of activities at the Ford plant in Genk and at 11 downstream suppliers and producers.  The application concerns 4,500 of the 5,111 workers made redundant and envisages seeking financial aid to implement several measures to support the laid-off persons. The European Parliament's report notes that all the criteria for allocating a financial contribution from the EGF have been met and approves the Commission's decision to allocate an amount of EUR 6 268 564 following the request submitted by Belgium. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ In favour as agree for the use of the EGF in this case.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EGF application filed on 24 March 2015 by Ford Genk, the largest employer in the Belgian province of Limburg. It is worthwhile to remind that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and/or as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. In this particular case, therefore, the EGF will be mobilised in order to provide a financial contribution of EUR 6 268 564 in respect of the application submitted by the Belgian authorities.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay redundancies as a result of the cessation of different business activities of Member States. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds because I believe that we should help alleviate the effects of Ford's redundancies in one of the Belgian regions most affected by the closure of traditional industries. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because my region can really use this money to guide the more than 5000 laid-off workers back to a new job. After the redundancies that followed the closure of Ford Genk, the fruit growing which is suffering severe consequences from the Russian sanctions and the precarious situation of the Belgian army, it is really time for the European Union to help to rebuild employment in Limburg. Sixty percent of the costs resulting from the closure are borne by the Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium's application to this Fund concerns 5 111 workers made redundant in Ford Genk and 11 suppliers or producers downstream. The main company operates in the manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers. This is the mobilisation of EUR 6 268 564 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will serve as individual assistance in job search, individual case management and general information services, training and retraining, subsidies and incentives, justified by the loss of significant market share of the automotive industry in the last decade. The closure of this plant means an increase in the unemployment rate that can reach 29.4 % of the region's unemployment rate, and a potential drop in labour productivity of 10.9 %, due to the high importance of the automotive industry for the region's labour productivity.  We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support those targeted with the consequences of political decisions, and further reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of these neoliberal policies that have once again led to this outcome.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Like my group, I am voting against any disbursement from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), as well as against it. The EGF is designed to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020. This fund can cover up to 60% of the costs of projects that can help redundant workers find a new job or start their own business. The EGF is only used where more than 500 workers are made redundant by a single company (including suppliers and downstream companies) or where many workers in a single industry lose their jobs in one or more neighbouring regions. There is no reason to locate these measures at European level. This is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. I voted in favour of mobilising more than EUR 6.2 million from the EGF for Belgium, with a view to reintegrating 4,500 of the 5,111 workers made redundant by the Ford plant in Genk and by 11 other downstream suppliers and producers. According to the Belgian authorities, the redundancies at Ford Genk are the effect of the permanent closure of the plant as a result of major structural changes in the structure of world trade, as a consequence of globalisation.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to Alitalia Airlines. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Italy submitted an application for EUR 1 414 848 to meet the redundancy costs of 1 249 employees. The Italians have stated that excessive competition from Gulf and Turkish airlines is to blame for the redundancies so they have decided to apply for EU money as a result of not being competitive enough. Personal Services will be accessed like retraining and help to get employment for employees over 50. There is an element of mobility to seek employment in other Members States. This company was privatised in 2009 and passenger numbers have declined by 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. Alitalia has to take responsibility for being competitive and cannot expect the taxpayer to pay for redundancies as a direct result of not being competitive enough. UKIP voted against.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds, agreed with the social agents, because of the high number of redundancies in Alitalia. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in Italian airline Alitalia. The EGF was established to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis. In general it can be mobilised for use if more than 500 workers in a company or sector are made redundant, and can be used to assist the dismissed workers find new jobs through job-search services and training. In this case, Gruppo Alitalia has made 1,249 workers redundant in Lazio in 2014 as a result of increased global competition in the aviation sector; 184 of these workers have not yet secured new employment. The report authorises the mobilisation of EGF funding in order to provide personalised job-search services. I supported the use of the fund as it will provide valuable practical assistance to the unemployed.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the 1,249 redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia, Italy has requested about 1.5 million euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This is an initiative to help workers suffering the consequences of changes in economic globalization, particularly with a view to their reintegration. I can only deplore the situation of the aviation sector in Europe, whose market shares are declining under pressure from the Gulf airlines and Turkey in particular.  After review, it appears that this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulation, as Italy is committed to undertaking effective and appropriate measures to reintegrate dismissed workers. So I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Italy, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. Nevertheless, as this arrangement is widely requested, on a case-by-case basis, I allow myself the opportunity to vote in favour of its mobilization.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Italy's needs in order to support the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Gruppo Alitalia. I support the mobilisation of EUR 1 414 848 for the return of 184 redundant workers to the labour market.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. If I voted in favour of the release of this aid to Italian employees who are victims of ultraliberalism and unfair competition imposed on Alitalia in this case, I continue to denounce the inconsistency of this European Union, which is acting as an arsonist.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In March 2015, Italy applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) following the redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia in Italy. Indeed, as a result of the crisis, the international air transport market has suffered serious economic disruptions, in particular a decline in the Union's market share.  With the conditions set out in the EGF regulation, I supported the proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF to the tune of EUR 1,414,848 to help Italian workers who are victims of the liberal crisis and austerity measures.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Alitalia. The Italian authorities state that the fact giving rise to redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia is the decrease in the number of passengers transported in 2014 to the 2010 figures, a decrease of 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. This is the fifteenth application under review under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 414 848 and concerns 184 workers from the 1,249 workers laid off in Gruppo Alitalia.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On 24 March 2015, Italy submitted the EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia application for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia in Italy. Italy submitted that, despite the fact that the international air transport market remained dominated by European airlines on a global scale, the sector has suffered severe economic disruptions, in particular a decline in the European Union's market share. The considerable increase in the number of passengers transported to and from Italy by Gulf airlines and Turkish Airlines has been at the expense of Alitalia. During the reporting period, 1,247 workers were laid off at Gruppo Alitalia. In view of the Italian demand, it is therefore proposed that the EGF should contribute to the coordinated set of personalised services to the tune of EUR 1,414,848. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report authorising the mobilisation of the EGF to the value of EUR 1 414 848 for workers affected by the restructuring which followed the acquisition of Alitalia by Etihad.  While waiting for the EU to adopt more effective trade policies, dedicated to protecting our labour market, the best and perhaps only instrument on which we can rely to protect our redundant workers is precisely the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report today. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a report on the financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 from the EGF following 1 249 redundancies in Grupo Alitalia, which operates in the Lazio region of Italy in the air transport sector.    This application contains five types of measures for covered laid-off workers: admission and evaluation of skills, support for the active search for employment, training, reimbursement of mobility costs and support for recruitment of over 50s. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament agrees with the Commission's proposal to grant financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) when 1 249 workers have been made redundant from Gruppo Alitalia. The Commission granted the application of that Italian airline in order to obtain the support necessary for their reintegrating into the labour market. According to the Italian authorities, the reason for the redundancies of Gruppo Alitalia is the reduction in the number of passengers flying between 2014 and 2010, which resulted in a 3.6% decrease compared to 2013 and by 6.4% in 2012, and losses accumulated in 2009 with the full privatisation of Alitalia.  The personalised services intended to be provided to redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) uptake and skills assessment, (ii) support for active job search, (iii) training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) hiring allowances for those over 50.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. I agree with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The story of the Italian national carrier Alitalia is also known to us Slovenes. Our national carrier, Adria Airways, has also faced serious problems for years. After the hard throes, the Italians have only found a strong strategic partner for an exhausted society that is still operating. However, the fund's money will be spent to the greatest extent to retraining and finding jobs for redundant workers, especially for those over 50 years of age who are still much more difficult to employ today.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for workers made redundant by the Alitalia group in the Lazio region, which gives Italy the right to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848. The fund represents a great opportunity to respond to the effects of the economic crisis and to assist the workers most affected to re-enter the labour market. The allocation of the EU fund and the planned measures for the 184 former employees bode well: the Italian authorities are endeavouring to provide personalised services, active support in the search for impetus, bonuses for recruitment over 50 and training, taking into account the future prospects of the labour market, the skills required and the needs of workers who have difficulty finding a new job.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Mobilisation Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Al Italia), to help 184 former workers with a coordinated package of measures, including active job search support, training, reimbursement of mobility costs, employment benefits for people over 50... These surpluses are caused by major structural changes in the international aviation market directly linked to globalisation.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in Italian airline Alitalia. The EGF was established to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis. In general it can be mobilised for use if more than 500 workers in a company or sector are made redundant, and can be used to assist the dismissed workers find new jobs through job-search services and training. In this case, Gruppo Alitalia has made 1,249 workers redundant in Lazio in 2014 as a result of increased global competition in the aviation sector; 184 of these workers have not yet secured new employment. The report authorises the mobilisation of EGF funding in order to provide personalised job-search services. I supported the use of the fund as it will provide valuable practical assistance to the unemployed.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that it is up to the Union to help those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the crisis. In this case, a further increase in the number of unemployed would place a greater burden on the IGC's benefit system, which is already under pressure.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to provide a financial contribution of around 1.4 million euros to Italy, which comes from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following 1,249 redundancies at Alitalia, Italy's main airline. These aids are intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. The European air transport market is experiencing severe economic disruption and has seen its market share shrink considerably mainly due to unfair competition from the Gulf countries and Turkey. In the face of this scourge, the European Commission is continuing its work of trade liberalisation, which is at the root of these social plans. European authorities should act upstream by combating the social, environmental, fiscal and monetary dumping practised by emerging countries instead of coming to the bedside of companies in liquidation and laid-off workers.  Solidarity of sacked Italian employees who are suffering, as in France, the disastrous consequences of savage globalisation, I can only approve the mobilization of these funds. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the sectors affected by the crisis is air transport. The international air transport market has suffered serious economic disruptions, in particular as regards a decrease in the European Union's market share and a huge increase in the number of passengers carried by Turkish airlines and Gulf countries. All this has taken place at the expense of European companies such as Alitalia. In these circumstances, the labour market was affected, which led to an increase in unemployment in the Lazio region, where Alitalia is located. Between 2008 and 2013, employment in the Italian air transport sector decreased by around 20%. With a view to economic recovery, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an effective instrument that provides additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. The EUR 1 414 848 granted by the EU to the 184 redundancies targeted from Alitalia is a considerable financial aid. In this context, I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Alitalia, because I support the reintegration of workers and, consequently, economic growth in that area.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. € 1,414,848 to cover only 184 redundancies out of 1,249 in Lazio. The cause of the redundancies is the restructuring following the acquisition of Alitalia by Etihad. The report rightly regrets the fact that not even 15% of redundant workers will benefit from the measures and that the costs under 'preparation, management, information and publicity activities, and control and reporting' are high (4% of the total). Always on the side of work and workers!

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. MEPs accepted Italy's request for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to intervene for employees of Alitalia, which has been heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. The amount of aid amounts to EUR 1,414,848. 184 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. International competition in the aviation sector has led to a decline in the UNION's market share, which justifies the Fund's call for mobilization.  I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to the application made by Italy to support the occupational reintegration of workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group. The application concerned 1,249 workers made redundant by the Alitalia group. The event that caused the redundancies at the Alitalia group is the return of the number of passengers transported in 2014 to 2010 levels, with a decrease of 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012, associated with the losses accumulated by the total privatisation of Alitalia in 2009. It is good that an Italian company has benefited from the EGF, a tool so far little used by Italian companies due to the lack of support from local and national institutions that submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in Italian airline Alitalia. The EGF was established to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis. In general it can be mobilised for use if more than 500 workers in a company or sector are made redundant, and can be used to assist the dismissed workers find new jobs through job-search services and training. In this case, Gruppo Alitalia has made 1 249 workers redundant in Lazio in 2014 as a result of increased global competition in the aviation sector; 184 of these workers have not yet secured new employment. The report authorises the mobilisation of EGF funding in order to provide personalised job-search services. I supported the use of the fund as it will provide valuable practical assistance to the unemployed.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to Alitalia Airlines. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Italy submitted an application for EUR 1 414 848 to meet the redundancy costs of 1249 employees. The Italians have stated that excessive competition from Gulf and Turkish airlines is to blame for the redundancies so they have decided to apply for EU money as a result of not being competitive enough. Personal Services will be accessed like retraining and help to get employment for employees over 50. There is an element of mobility to seek employment in other Members States. This company was privatised in 2009 and passenger numbers have declined by 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. Alitalia has to take responsibility for being competitive and cannot expect the taxpayer to pay for redundancies as a direct result of not being competitive enough.  I voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Alitalia needs recovery after the serious economic disruption. The funding will also improve workers' conditions that are also affected by the crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The request for mobilisation of the fund concerns Alitalia, on which last March the Italian Government made the request for almost one and a half million euros. This money is expected to support 184 workers, with a need of 1,249. In any case, I certainly voted in favour.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide tailor-made services to redundant workers in order to find a new job. That is why the request to help 184 workers made redundant by Alitalia due to a decrease in its market share of international passenger air transport is absolutely legitimate. In fact, there were 1,200 redundancies, but these 184 are the people who are in the most difficulty. The economic crisis of recent years has hit the air transport sector hard, as has the rise in the price of fuel. Passengers have fallen sharply, causing airline revenues to fall. I am therefore voting in favour of Mrs Vana's report.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is a 1.4 million euro aid granted for the reintegration of 184 workers dismissed by Alitalia in Italy.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Increased competition from airlines, including low-cost airlines, non-EU countries, instability in the price of oil and the prolonged effects of the economic crisis are at the root of the decrease in the loss of market share of EU air transport. A sector that had so far resisted the direct and indirect consequences of an unprecedented crisis. The fifteenth request for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Fund within the 2005 budget concerned Alitalia, which in the period 2010 and 2014 suffered a reduction in the number of passengers of 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. This led to the redundancy of 1 249 workers, 189 of whom were in the Lazio region alone, who considered it appropriate to use the EGF to deal with the difficult situation faced by the airline's employees.  The active measures for the labour market that will be implemented with the Fund (skills balance, training also on demand, mobility bonus for training and recruitment bonus for those who have exceeded the threshold of fifty years) will serve to increase the employment opportunities of Alitalia staff. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The application concerns 1249 employees made redundant by the Alitalia group, which is active in the aviation sector. The international aviation market has been badly damaged, leading to either closures or mass redundancies of workers. It is proposed to mobilise the amount of EUR 1,414,848 to be used to assist in the reintegration of dismissed persons into the labour market.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of the Italian company Alitalia. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund for a total amount of EUR 1 414 848. The request is based on the professional relocation of 184 of the 1 249 redundant workers of Alitalia, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 51 of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2 region of Lazio.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. Among the causes of the crisis that has hit Alitalia hard, the deterioration in the economic situation of the international air transport market, in particular the decrease in the Union's market share and the huge increase in the number of passengers carried by Turkish and Gulf carriers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Alitalia's situation with regard to redundancies due to the crisis in the airline. I am well aware of the situation of my country's flag carrier and I am well aware that a great many workers have been made redundant. I think it is right and proper to vote in favour of the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which was set up to support those workers who, caught up in the globalisation mechanism, have lost their jobs but not because of their own productivity or their own productivity.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This fund relates to Alitalia Airlines. The total budget for EGF for the period 2014-20 is EUR 1.05 billion. Italy submitted an application for EUR 1 414 848 to meet the redundancy costs of 1 249 employees. The Italians have stated that excessive competition from Gulf and Turkish airlines is to blame for the redundancies so they have decided to apply for EU money as a result of not being competitive enough. Personal Services will be accessed like retraining and help to get employment for employees over 50. There is an element of mobility to seek employment in other Members States. This company was privatised in 2009 and passenger numbers have declined by 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. Alitalia has to take responsibility for being competitive and cannot expect the taxpayer to pay for redundancies as a direct result of not being competitive enough. UKIP voted against.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1,414,848 in favour of Italy with the aim of supporting the 1,249 workers made redundant in the Alitalia group.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the conditions are valid to accept Italy's request to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by the Alitalia group. The EGF is an instrument set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows. This request is in line with the basic prerequisites for making the demand for EGF funding, as it stems from the need to address the redundancies of Alitalia workers after the collapse in the number of passengers on Alitalia routes registered after privatisation in 2009. In particular, these funds will guarantee personalized services, which will be offered to redundant workers and which will consist of five types of measures: the skills balance, the accredited entity, on-demand training, the mobility bonus for training and the recruitment bonus over 50.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to serious economic disruption and a decrease in passengers, redundancies have occurred with large portions of more being laid off without other job and training. Funds in this case will provide opportunities and compensation to workers and training to address unemployment. I thus voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds, agreed with the social agents, because of the high number of redundancies in Alitalia. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In recent years, the international air transport market has been the victim of serious economic fragmentation, in particular the Union's market share has decreased and the number of passengers carried by the Gulf countries and Turkey's air transport companies has increased to the detriment of European companies such as Alitalia. Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following a dismissal of 1 249 people from the Gruppo Alitalia group.  As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I supported Italy's use of the Fund, which was set up to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, and to support their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Italy, which relates to redundancies in the Group Alitalia caused by the major structural changes in the international air transport market linked to globalisation. I agree with offering active job-search support, training and other measures which help employees particularly employees who are over 50, integrate back into the employment market, hence my vote in favour.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a Five Star Movement, the Vana report touches us closely, since it is the request that the Italian Government presented in March 2015 to help some workers made redundant by Alitalia; the requested amount amounts to 1,414,848 euros and should affect 184 beneficiaries, out of a total of potentially eligible persons of 1,249. We are in favour of mobilising this fund as a general rule. We are aware, however, that it is certainly not the instrument that can best help workers, but in the absence of alternatives it must be supported nonetheless. For the Alitalia case we have made an in-depth reflection, since on the one hand it seems quite anomalous the request for such a low number of beneficiaries compared to potential candidates, and we also know well all the problems related to the management of Alitalia; However, it seems very difficult to oppose the granting of facilities which should help redundant workers, and that is why our vote was positive.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the mobilization of EUR 1,414,848 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the benefit of the 180 people made redundant by the airline Alitalia in Italy. With an annual budget of 150 million euros per year during the period 2014-2020, the EGF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. Faced with international competition, some European sectors are undergoing major restructuring and sometimes costly in jobs.  Considering that one of the aims of European funds is to support workers in this context and to enable them to retrain permanently, I have spoken in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament's support for European citizens in difficulty is essential, as in the case of people in Italy facing redundancies in the civil aviation sector. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will allow the reintegration of 184 workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group. The loss of jobs is due to the contraction, between 2008 and 2014, of the European Union's market share in international passenger air transport. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a concrete sign of European solidarity and will enable former employees of the Ggruppo Alitalia to look for new jobs.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. As a result of the financial and economic crisis, the international air transport market has been severely disrupted. European airlines are facing increased competition from airlines from the Gulf countries and Turkey. In Italy, Alitalia had to lay off many employees as a result of these losses in its market share, with a very negative impact on the local economy.  The mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to provide additional assistance to Belgium necessary for the reintegration of former Alitalia employees.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, structural reforms are needed to reconnect with economic growth. The N-VA Members of the European Parliament have therefore abstained in this matter.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to help workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they lost their jobs as a result of changing world trade patterns. However, me and my group do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for introducing such policies, nor do we believe it to be an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. And that's why I'm voting no. However, I stress that I fully support measures to introduce policies that create growth and jobs. This report requires 5.2 million euro. 1,152 workers who lost their jobs at Alitalia.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I am in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund under consideration, because it will benefit Italy and, in particular, will support the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group. The application relates to a total amount of EUR 1 414 848 but unfortunately concerns only 184 of the 1 249 workers made redundant by the group.  The Italian authorities have given all the necessary guarantees that: – the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination in access to and implementation of the proposed actions will be respected; - the conditions relating to collective redundancies laid down in national legislation and EU legislation have been met; - the Alitalia Group, which made the redundancies and continued its activities also as a result of this measure, has fulfilled its legal obligations regarding redundancies by granting its workers all the services provided for; - the proposed actions will not receive any financial support from other Union funds or financial instruments and any double funding will be prevented; - the proposed actions will be complementary to the actions financed by the Structural Funds; - the financial contribution from the EGF will comply with the Union's procedural and substantive state aid rules.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (the 'Fund') aims to enable the Union to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to express its solidarity with the population of the disaster-affected regions and that the Fund's intervention should not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 500 million. The Italian authorities submitted an application following dismissals in the Alitalia Group. I therefore agree that a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 should be mobilised to respond to the Italian request.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates are critical of the Globalisation Fund as such and have voted against its creation. We have also opposed the EU alleviating funds for this purpose in budgetary votes. However, we do not fight over individual payments once the fund is in place.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe the funds are essential to the recovery of the local economy.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and having regard to the Council Regulation, as well as the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 to Italy, namely for The Alitalia Group, which had to lay off 1 249 workers. There has been a serious economic disruption in the international air transport market, in particular a rapid reduction in the Union's market share and a huge increase in the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish carrier companies to the detriment of European companies such as Alitalia.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the allocation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Although it concerns only 184 redundancies out of 1,249 in Lazio. The cause of the redundancies is the restructuring following the acquisition of Alitalia by Etihad.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support the EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia application. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In March 2015, Italy submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the dismissals occurred to Alitalia Group in Italy. As a consequence of the economic crisis, the international air transport market experienced indeed a decrease in the share of the EU market. Considering that the conditions laid down by the EGF Regulation are fulfilled, I supported the mobilisation of the EGF of up to EUR 1 414 848 to assist Italian workers, victims of the economic crisis and of austerity measures.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia bearing in mind that this fund supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the patterns of world trade, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I congratulate my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets on the rapid and thorough work of examining the request for the release of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Italy's application in the Alitalia case.  184 workers will benefit from the measures provided for in the Fund, totalling EUR 1 415 000. I would very much like to express a particularly favourable opinion on the speed of the timing of the verification and acceptance of the proposal: the application submitted by Italy at the end of March, the closure of the European Commission's judgment in August. This is an important example of the European institutions being close to the specific needs of the families and workers concerned.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia application, submitted by Italy. I believe that it is right for the European Union to intervene in support of Alitalia, because the air transport sector, once the flagship of European greatness, is now in a very deep crisis due to foreign competition and globalisation. The increase in the number of passengers transported by Turkish and Gulf carriers to the detriment of European airlines and the growth of low-cost airlines have seriously eroded the market share once the preserve of flag carriers, causing mass redundancies. For this reason, I am in favour of allocating an EGF contribution of EUR 1 414 848 for interventions in support of identified workers, who will benefit from a set of personalised services such as skills budget services, on-demand training, mobility bonuses for training and recruitment bonuses for workers over 50. I believe that specific attention should be paid to older workers, who are most at risk of long-term unemployment and permanent social exclusion: this is the Europe of solidarity, which does not abandon its citizens in times of difficulty.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report, along the lines of my group. I am very critical of the Globalisation Fund as a whole. In the present case, I am also convinced that Italy's wrong economic policy choices have caused the loss of jobs.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to use the EGF under application EGF/2015/004/IT/Alitalia. At a time of increasing globalisation and a sometimes weakening global economy, it is important that European companies remain competitive in the future. Workers who have lost their jobs as a result of this adjustment deserve support to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Alitalia in order to ensure support is provided to employees of the company who lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund helps those who have been made redundant due to the negative effects of global trade patterns affecting their company, for example, the shutting down of a company to move production abroad. Today I voted in favour of the Alitalia application for Italy. The package of EUR 1 414 848 will help reintegrate Alitalia employees back into the workforce, paying particular attention to those over 50 years of age. Given the difficult challenges faced by the aviation industry in recent years, I welcome this application.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Italy's request for a financial contribution from the Globalization Adjustment Fund to help workers made redundant by the airline Alitalia to find work.  The programme implemented by the Italian authorities is specifically aimed at helping workers over the age of 50, who are finding it more difficult to find work. The requested financial assistance is EUR 1,414,848. The Italian company had to lay off 1,249 employees to deal with what the report calls "serious economic disruptions. Sweet euphemism to describe the unfair competition of Gulf and Turkish companies that practice social dumping. This competition has weakened Alitalia as it also weakens our national airline Air France. For my part, I hope that member states can fight social dumping without waiting for the green light from Europe. I also note that the politicians of the Member States sometimes have some responsibility for this unfair competition, since they give openings of lines to Gulf companies, in order to facilitate arms sales.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the application for EGF assistance by the Italian authorities for EUR 1 414 848 following the redundancy of 1 249 workers from Gruppo Alitalia. With a decline in the Union’s market share and a huge increase in the number of passengers carried by third country international carriers the air transport sector and EU companies such as Alitalia have been heavily affected. I welcome the authorities´ proposals for a package of personalised services which will include intake and skill assessment, active job search support, training, reimbursement of mobility costs, and particularly the hiring benefits for over 50s which will provide incentives for this marginalised group. However I note that just 184 (14.7%) of the 1,249 affected workers are to be targeted by the proposed measures which is a very low percentage of eligible redundant employees.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Italy. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set in 2006 to express solidarity with European workers. It is mean to reintegrate into the labour market the workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as I believe that assistance to Alitalia workers made redundant should be provided as quickly and efficiently as possible. The re-inclusion of redundante workers in the labour market is achieved through numerous measures such as enrolment and skills assessment, active job search assistance, training, reimbursement of mobility costs and encouragement to recruit people over 50. Given that there have been serious economic distortions in the international aviation market, the timely reaction is extremely important. This is why Italy has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF I support.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Italy to obtain a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 1,414,848 following 1,249 redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia. This initiative is therefore part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, and to the reintegration of laid-off workers, in the sad context of the international air transport market which has suffered serious economic disruptions. Indeed, there is a sharp decline in the Union's market share and a considerable increase in the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish airlines which has occurred at the expense of European airlines such as Alitalia. Upon review, I consider that this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Italy is committed to taking effective and appropriate measures to reintegrate laid-off workers. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. All too often, as repeated here, the European Union is the cause and the problem and then tries to mollify the impact with financial help.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Monika Vana's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Alitalia. The fund will provide EUR 1,400,000 for the 184 sacked employees to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the Italian request follows the dismissal of 1,250 people in an Alitalia branch. The mobilization of the European Adjustment Fund will enable the training and replacement of many of these employees.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This is the fifteenth application for payments from the Globalisation Fund. This time, we are talking about more than EUR 1 million to be spent on 184 employees who have been made redundant by Alitalia. The application and the situation of the workers corresponds to the criteria for mobilisation. That is why there is nothing to prevent these former employees from re-entering the labour market through training and similar measures. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report is on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The EGF provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes due to globalisation. This time, this fund focuses on European air transport and supports Alitalia’s redundant workers. Since 2002, Alitalia has faced serious financial difficulties. Italian authorities are planning to cover five measures: intake, skill assessment, active job search support, training and reimbursement of mobility costs, and hiring benefits for over-50s. I voted in favour because the report anticipates future labour market perspectives and also adapts to the needs of the dismissed workers.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today, we have voted on 4 more calls for the globalisation adjustment fund to be mobilised. The one in favour of Italy concerns a contribution of 1,414,848 euros, which will benefit the workers made redundant by Alitalia. Given that the EGF aims to provide support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, I believe that the 'Alitalia case' is fully covered. Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping people suffering the effects of a devastating economic crisis.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off by Gruppo Alitalia in Italy. This request concerns 184 of the 1,249 workers made redundant at Alitalia.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade. The European Union does not provide a structural solution to these problems. On the contrary, as a promoter of globalization, it is one of them. However, while the WEF can help reintegrate laid-off workers back into the labour market, it cannot be opposed.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it releases 1.4 million euros for 184 workers laid off by Alitalia in Italy because of the economic crisis.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Report on the financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 of the EGF following 1249 redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia, which operates in the Lazio region of Italy in the air transport sector. This application contains five types of measures for covered laid-off workers: 1) admission and evaluation of capacities, 2) support for active job search, 3) training, 4) reimbursement of mobility costs, and 5) recruitment aid for over 50s. Naturally in our group we agree with the existence and implementation of this Fund, which is why we voted in favour.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. In 2012, Italy, one of the world's richest countries, is demanding an Orwellian-named fund to bail out the low competitiveness of German firms caused by a slushy welfare state and an overregulated economy. There can be no vote other than against this euro nonsense.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Italian airline Alitalia suffered financial losses in the air transport sector due to major structural changes and globalisation, resulting in the redundancies of 1247 employees.  In March 2015, Italy applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Alitalia's €1.5 million airline. The European Fund was created to help former employees find a new job, education or self-employment, which lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis. I supported Mp Vana, who is approving a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Alitalia manage redundante employees.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The aid concerns 1 249 former Alitalia workers from italy's Lazio region, affected by the global economic crisis and the less active use of airlines by passengers. The majority of these former employees are aged between 30 and 54 (96.79 %) and a further 3.3% from 55 to 64 years old. Helping these people to retrain and gradually return to the labour market in order to participate actively in their country's progressive economic life in the future. Overall, this is the second application relating to the European aviation sector. The technical assistance targets apply directly to only 15% of these people (184 people), but it could still allow them to return to the labour market as early as possible in the same sphere or in another.
