It is particularly good that some of the former workers affected are over 50 years old. Despite the fact that these people technically only had a decade (or one and a half) active employment until retirement, their return to the labour market would allow them to continue to use their accumulated knowledge and experience.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy applied in August 2015 for EFG support for reintegration into the labour market of those employees who were made redundant from nace rev. NACE Rev. Groupo Alitalia. 2 division 51 (air transport). The reason for the redundancies was the decrease in passengers in 2014, with 1 249 redundancies, but only 184 redundancies will be affected by the assistance provided in the form of personalised services. Personalised services consist of recruitment and skills assessment, support for active job search, training, reimbursement of mobility costs and benefits provided for the employment of staff over the age of 50. As Italy has fulfilled the conditions for EFG support, there is nothing to prevent the release of EUR 1 414 848.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (Request EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia, from Italy), because the Italian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 1 April 2015, well before the decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Italy to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Gruppo Alitalia.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 24 March 2015, Italy submitted its EGF application for a financial contribution from the EGF following the 1 249 workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group in Italy mainly concentrated in the Lazio region. The total estimated cost of the package amounts to approximately EUR 1.4 million. The air transport sector is changing strongly, competition has become much more intense and to date the transport sector has been the subject of two applications for intervention by the EGF, both of which are attributable to the globalisation of trade.  It was appropriate to mobilise the Fund because the services and instruments offered to redundant workers, such as mobility bonuses for training and recruitment bonuses over 50, will go to protect workers and families and to ensure levels of competitiveness vis-off with regard to large airlines as a result of the negative consequences of changes due to the phenomenon of globalisation.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to support European workers affected by changes in the structure of world trade, due to the effects of globalisation. On 7 August 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Italy, in order to support the professional reintegration of workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group, amounting to EUR 1,414,848. Given that the international air transport sector has deteriorated seriously (due to falling demand and rising oil prices), the European Union must participate in the process of restructuring it. For these reasons, I have decided to support this report, which supports the mobilisation of the EGF for the benefit of Alitalia.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Italian authorities argue that the redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia are due to a decrease in the number of passengers carried in 2014 compared to 2010. Workers (over 50 years of age) will be supported in finding work, training. This report is therefore worthy of support.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as to support European workers who face unforeseen adversities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The request relates to the mobilization of a total of EUR 1,414,848 to help 184 of the 1,249 workers laid off at Gruppo Alitalia. The Italian authorities claim that the layoffs at Gruppo Alitalia stem from the decrease in the number of passengers carried in 2014, coupled with the losses accumulated since the complete privatization of Alitalia in 2009. Now 49% acquired by the UAE airline Etihad Airways, the company is facing a restructuring.  I cannot vote for this fund, which does not even cover 10% of sacked employees and validates a disastrous policy.  My thoughts do not leave the Air France employees threatened with the same fate.  I abstain so as not to deprive The Italian workers of this alms.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This text comes in the context of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, at the request of Italy to obtain a financial contribution from the Fund amounting to EUR 1,414,848 following 1,249 redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia.  This initiative is therefore part of a desire to help workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, and to the reintegration of laid-off workers, in the sad context of the international air transport market which has suffered serious economic disruptions. Indeed, there is a sharp decline in the Union's market share and a considerable increase in the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish airlines which has occurred at the expense of European airlines such as Alitalia. Upon review, this application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Fund Regulations. Italy is committed to taking effective and appropriate measures to reintegrate laid-off workers. I voted FOR.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, application EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia. According to the Commission, the measures described are active labour market measures falling within the eligible actions defined in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. These actions do not replace passive social protection measures.  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This is an application that meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the Unions disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 184 workers formerly employed by Alitalia in Italy.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The international air transport market has suffered serious economic disruptions, in particular a decline in the EU's market share. Employees have been affected. The decision to provide support to laid-off employees and self-employed workers who are out of work through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) and in accordance with the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination is entirely justified, as has been the case for other European airlines.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission decided, after examining application EGF/2015/00IT/Alitalia, that the conditions laid down for the submission and submission of the proposal were fulfilled by Italy and thus the application for a contribution was approved. Italy is eligible for a financial contribution to support redundant workers due to a decrease in numbers. However, the problem is the economic disruption in the international aviation market, when the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish airlines is increasing to the detriment of European air transport. I agree with the decision to mobilise a fund to provide staffing services and measures for workers in order to integrate into the labour market and ensure benefits and better conditions for hiring, especially for workers over the age of 50.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because it is important to give the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Italy. The application relates to 1 247 redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia within the period 31 August 2014 – 30 December 2014. The EGAF funding of EUR 1 414 848 shall contribute to help 184 former workers through a coordinated package of measures such as intake and skill assessment, active job-search support, training, reimbursement of mobility costs, hiring benefits for over 50s. The redundancies were caused by were caused by the major structural changes in the international air transport market directly linked to globalisation.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created with the purpose of giving complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In the present case, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Italy to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in the Alitalia Group, in the economic sector classified in division 51 of the NACE Rev. 2 (Air Transport). At the root of the redundancies is the decline in the number of passengers transported in 2014 to the figures recorded in 2010, corresponding to a decline of 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4 % compared to 2012, in conjunction with the accumulated losses since the total privatisation of Alitalia in 2009. Since the application of the Italian authorities complies with the requirements for determining a financial contribution from the EGF, active employment measures with the aim of reintegrating redundant workers into the labour market and as a mechanism to avoid the harmful consequences of a significant impact on the local economy, this report has my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the decision of the European Parliament and the Council of the Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1.4 million to help 184 workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group and ensure their reintegration into the labour market.  This restructuring is not unrelated to the international competition in the aviation sector, of which Air France is also a victim. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, e.g. when a large company shuts down or production is moved outside the EU, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. Labour MEPs have consistently supported EGF applications, moreover it is worth noting that opportunities for the UK to claim from this fund may arise in the near future and the EGF could help those made redundant and wider communities affected by large shocks to the local economy. It is also worth noting the EGF can do this whilst minimising the cost to the UK Government.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted three reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these three reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1.4 million euros from this fund to 184 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of ALITALIA in Italy.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible.  The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Italy, in order to support the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by the Alitalia Group.  This question concerns 184 of the 1 249 workers made redundant due to the sharp drop in passengers transported in 2014, coupled with the losses accumulated by the total privatisation of Alitalia in 2009. Indeed, the international air transport sector has suffered a serious deterioration in its economic situation, in particular a decrease in the EU's market share, aggravated by other factors, such as the fall in demand following the economic crisis and the rise in oil prices. The tailored services to be offered to workers will constitute active labour market measures, which fall within the scope of the eligible actions referred to in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation.   We also believe that accredited agencies, which provide active support in job search, should be paid on the basis of the results achieved and we believe that differentiation of incentives will encourage the recruitment of workers interested in better conditions.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the advancement of globalisation. This application, the fifteenth in the framework of the 2015 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 1,414,848 for Italy. It covers 184 of the 1,249 workers made redundant by the Alitalia group, operating in the air transport sector. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the Vana report because I believe that workers should benefit from the broadest support from the European Union. This appropriation, which will finance actions aimed at enhancing the professional skills of these workers, will help to offer them new employment opportunities.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in Gruppo Alitalia, Italy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which authorises the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to benefit laid-off workers in Italian airline Alitalia. The EGF was established to provide support for workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation, including the offshoring of jobs and the shifting in production patterns in Europe. It has since been expanded to also apply to workers laid off as a result of the global financial crisis. In general it can be mobilised for use if more than 500 workers in a company or sector are made redundant, and can be used to assist the dismissed workers find new jobs through job-search services and training. In this case, Gruppo Alitalia has made 1,249 workers redundant in Lazio in 2014 as a result of increased global competition in the aviation sector; 184 of these workers have not yet secured new employment. The report authorises the mobilisation of EGF funding in order to provide personalised job-search services. I supported the use of the fund as it will provide valuable practical assistance to the unemployed.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – Alitalia’s case is a typical example of how external factors could endanger economic activity and employment in our regions. Such is the case with 1 249 redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia were provoked. This was a textbook example case, where the help of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was required.  The financial contribution equals EUR 1 414 848. The latter include active job search and training proposed by the Italian authorities, including the re-employment scheme targeting dismissed workers over 50 years of age. Regrettably, only 184 redundant workers will be targeted by the measures. In addition to that, preparatory activities, management, information and publicity and control and reporting - represent a relatively high share of the total costs (3.99%). Last but not least, combination of various types of EU funding support in our regions is a step forward for a stronger and more competitive European economy.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because it makes a positive contribution to the very place where society needs it most. The European Union can therefore do good for its citizens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Italy's air transport sector has been severely affected by the economic downturn. In order to ensure a sustainable air service, Gruppo Alitalia has mobilised a large number of labour force and adopted other austerity measures. Europe's aviation industry competes closely with the Middle East, the fastest growing aviation sector in the world. It is therefore necessary to support local companies in order to remain in the European market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the urgent need for the professional relocation of workers who are made redundant at the Alitalia Group, I consider it necessary to use the fund to solve this problem. For this reason, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. In the last year we have voted for a number of decisions on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. These decisions have helped workers who have found themselves in an unenviable position as a result of major structural changes in global trade flows and the global financial and economic crisis. A huge increase in the number of passengers transported to and from Italy to other airlines, a decrease in the number of passengers transported by Alitalia and the implementation of full privatisation have led to significant losses of this company. Finally, 1,247 Gruppo Alitalia workers were made redundant. I support the request of the Italian authorities to award them a financial contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 414 848, which applies to 1 247 workers. I note that air transport workers have very specific skills that can hardly be used in other sectors, making it much more difficult for them to search for new employment. I also welcome the focus of this report on active job search and other measures to train workers, including measures to re-employ laid-off workers over the age of 50. Therefore, this monetary assistance is necessary to reduce the disadvantage of the early ones who have been made redundant and to enable their reintegration on the labour market. I support this report and voted to adopt it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the decision of the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1.4 million to help 184 workers laid off by the Alitalia group and ensure their reintegration into the labour market.  This restructuring is not unrelated to the international competition in the aviation sector, of which Air France is also a victim. This is a structural problem that deserves otherwise more effective solutions. But these solutions are never envisaged in the Union and, in the meantime, I have decided to vote in favour of this text which helps employees.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an important instrument of solidarity, i.e. assistance for all those affected by structural changes in global trade, in not all workers whose work becomes more costly in the context of production relocation, but also under the impact of the financial crisis and the resulting business decisions or business closures. In the case of Italy's Alitalia, 184 of the 1,249 workers were laid off due to over-capacity. This is a particularly difficult business situation resulting from, on the one hand, changes in world trade flows, which has reduced the EU's global market share in international air transport, and on the other hand, the global economic crisis, falling demand and rising fuel prices. Accordingly, I welcome the Commission's approval for the allocation of EUR 1 414 848 to Italy in this case, as well as personalised assistance services for workers in the form of skills assessments, assistance in active job search, and in particular incentives for the employment of workers over 50.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I certainly could not fail to strongly support the decision to approve the mobilisation of the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in relation to the application submitted by Italy. The question in question aims to support the reintegration into working life of 184 of the 1,249 workers made redundant by the Alitalia group. The total amount from the EGF will be EUR 1,414,848. At the root of this series of redundancies is the return of the number of passengers transported in 2014 to 2010 levels, a decrease of 3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012. I very much hope that the mobilisation of these resources will enable Alitalia employees to be reintegrated as quickly as possible, or at least their timely reintegration into the labour market.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European aviation sector is under a lot of pressure, especially in the face of the emergence of competitors from the Gulf countries. Some European companies, such as Alitalia, have had to restructure and have been forced to lay off some of their staff.  In order to support European workers, Italy has applied to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I voted in favour of this request amounting to 1.4 million euros. In particular, this support will enable them to offer specialized training to laid-off workers to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted this lunchtime to allocate financial aid to 184 workers who lost their jobs at a factory of the aviation group "Alitalia". This grant, amounting to EUR 1,414,848, should enable the Italian authorities to organise personalised services so that these workers can quickly return to work. This aid, enabled by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which has an annual budget of 150 million euros, comes as a result of economic layoffs. The latter are the direct result of increased competition between airlines, which affects an industry heavily affected by the international economic and financial crisis. In addition to this specific case, two other countries have recently benefited from this financial boost for similar cases: Germany for its Adam Opel AG plant and Belgium for Ford Genk.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has established legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in global trade patterns (globalisation) or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Italy submitted this application based on the sharp decline in its alitalia profits. 1247 workers were laid off in this group. EUR 1 414 848 have been mobilised for aid. Italy submitted this application on the basis of a Criterion of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund which defines at least 500 workers made redundant in a company of a Member State within a reference period of 4 months. Without understaining the general principle, it nevertheless appears to be a criterion tailored to large enterprises.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a report on the financial contribution of 1,414,848 euros from the EGF following 1,249 redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia, which operates in the Lazio region of Italy in the air transport sector.    This application contains five types of measures for covered laid-off workers: admission and evaluation of skills, support for the active search for employment, training, reimbursement of mobility costs and support for recruitment of over 50s. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Remember, a few years ago, the Italian carrier had to part with more than 1,200 workers, mainly because of the decline in its share in the international air passenger market, mainly to the benefit of carriers in the Gulf States and Turkey. The company's difficulties were then compounded by the decrease in passenger numbers due to the economic crisis and the increase in the price of oil. Most of the layoffs took place in the central Lazio region. Italy has requested the intervention of the EGF to help 184 workers who are having the most difficulty finding a job. This request for assistance from the EGF is the second to be allocated to the air transport sector (after Air France's in 2013).

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalization are now an unavoidable reality. And no country or company is immune to the effects of these transformations. This was also the case for the Italian economy, which motivated the Italian authorities to apply for a financial contribution from the EGF, as a result of the 1249 redundancies made by the Alitalia Group, which operates in the air transport sector.  We are dealing with a situation related to structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalisation, which has led to serious economic disruptions in the international aviation market and a sharp decline in the Union's market share in this sector. For that reason and under Article 13 of Regulation 1309/2013, I agree with the proposal to mobilise the EGF in the amount of EUR 1 414 848 and I endorse the italian authorities' position to place the emphasis on active job search and training, including the reintegration scheme for redundant workers over 50 years of age. I regret only and, like the rapporteur, the small number of beneficiaries eligible for the measures of this application (184), which represents only 14.7% of the total number of redundancies.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for a total amount of EUR 1 414 848 in favour of the Alitalia Group, a company operating in the economic sector classified in NACE Revision 2 Division 51 ("Air Transport"). This fund will be used to facilitate the professional relocation of 184 of the 1249 redundant workers of the company Alitalia.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds, agreed with the social agents, because of the high number of redundancies in Alitalia. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I do not believe this to be an EU competency. Furthermore the UK does not qualify for this fund.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The application from Italy fulfils the eligibility criteria set down by the EGF Regulation and, in my view, the country should be entitled to the financial contribution afforded by the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament resolution on the application of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in a request by the Italian company Gruppo Alitalia, I voted in line with the ECR's position against this resolution. I consider it important to create a policy that helps employment growth and job creation. At the same time, however, I share the ECR's position and therefore do not consider the European Globalisation Fund to be a proper and adequate instrument for this purpose.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Italian Government requested a financial contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to redundancies that were forced to be notified by Grouppo Alitalia. The reality that caused the redundancies is the fall in the number of passengers transported back to 2010 levels in 2014, resulting in more than 1,000 redundancies. Unfortunately, only 184 employees, or less than 15% of all eligible beneficiaries, were included in the retraining process. However, as most workers have been made redundant in the Lazio region, which is one of italy's less developed areas, I support measures for reintegration into employment. Of the financial contribution of almost EUR 1,5 million, workers should be provided with personalised recruitment services and assessment of their skills, which will support them in active job searches or reimburse mobility costs. The benefits that should be granted to employees over the age of 50 should also be welcomed.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The EGF, the fund of which may not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million, provides financial assistance in cases where major structural changes in world trade flows or the global financial and economic crisis lead to the dismissal of more than 500 workers. The international air transport market has been hit by serious economic disturbances. Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF for 1249 redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia. The application fulfils the eligibility criteria of eur 1 414 848 for the EGF Regulation.  As financial assistance is essential for successfully tackling the current financial and economic crisis, and since I agree that the specific case fulfils the conditions and is eligible for a financial contribution, I supported the report on the proposal for a decision.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Alitalia, in response to the request submitted by the Italian Government in March 2015. The Plenary of the European Parliament has approved the allocation of EUR 1 million and EUR 414 thousand, which will finance the redundancy fund for some 180 employees of the company. The Italian flag carrier had to lay off more than 1,200 workers, mainly due to a decrease in its market share of international passenger air transport and the fall in passenger numbers due to the economic crisis and the increase in the price of fuel. Although the Fund's intervention today affects less than 15% of the staff made redundant, it will help 184 workers by financing personalised career paths aimed at finding new jobs.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Fund here too. It is time for the EGF to be activated also for cases of collective redundancies in Slovak companies and for the Slovak Government to respond to my repeated calls.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the IT/Alitalia motion. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a social policy instrument of the European Union. At the request of EU Member States, workers whose jobs have been lost as a result of globalisation or the global financial crisis can be assisted in their search for a new job. In this case, the Globalisation Fund provides EUR 1.4 million. This money supports the 184 former workers of Alitalia in their search for new jobs. I welcome the investment in training to enable jobseekers to find high-quality jobs again.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is precisely intended to help workers and people made redundant in their workplace, as well as those in need of an incentive for self-employment, and this is precisely the case here when we talk about Italy's request for Gruppo Alitalia, which had to lay off 1,249 workers as a result of the global economic financial crisis. These workers should be helped to re-enter the labour market or enable them to self-employ, which is also the purpose of the EGF. Since Italy submitted this request on time, met all the criteria and conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF, funds may be allocated to that Member State in order to dispose of its citizens in some way, in particular as that requirement complies with the requirements for determining the financial contribution from the EGF. As legal and administrative procedures have been followed, the mobilisation of this Fund intended to assist workers should be supported.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Italian application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1249 redundancies in Gruppo Alitalia. Italy is planning five actions for redundant workers covered by this application: intake and skill assessment, active job search support, training, reimbursement of mobility costs, and hiring benefits for over 50s.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers in the Member States of the European Union suffering as a result of major structural changes in global trade. The European Commission has accepted a decision to mobilise funds for Italy's benefit, which would reintegrate more than 180 workers laid off from the Alitalia Group. Due to a large drop in passenger numbers in 2014 (3.6% compared to 2013 and 6.4% compared to 2012) and accumulated losses from the privatisation of Alitha in 2009, workers had to be laid off.  Mobilising these funds (€1,414,848) will provide five measures to help redundantist workers: skills assessment, active job search support, training, mobility reimbursement and recruitment incentives for people over 50. I support this initiative and I think we need to help workers who have lost their jobs, to re-enter the labour market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: Alitalia - Italy. Gruppo Alitalia has made 1,249 redundancies due to the financial and economic crisis and economic disruption, such as the decline in the EU's market share in the air transport sector. Unfortunately, only a small part of all workers made redundant, 184 out of a total of 1,249 workers, will benefit the financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Italy submitted its application for a financial contribution from the EGF following a redundancy of 1 249 people from gruppo alitalia group, with 184 dismissed workers expected to take part. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation. The European Parliament agrees with the Commission that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation are fulfilled and that Italy is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 under that Regulation. Italy enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) recruitment and skills assessment, (ii) active job search assistance, (iii) vocational training, (iv) reimbursement of mobility costs and (v) employment commission for the over-50s. On the basis of the foregoing, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The M5S is in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help some workers made redundant by Alitalia. We are aware that this is not the optimal solution to support our workers, not least because the figure requested by the Italian Government seems unsuitable for such a small number of beneficiaries compared to potential candidates, but in the absence of other alternative solutions we have decided to give our support. The Aim of the Fund is to provide additional financial support to workers, in this case Alitalia, who are affected by major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the decline in car sales and the mass redundancies of car construction plants have been in the public's attention and ours, the Members of the European Parliament, the international air transport market could not avoid the disastrous economic effects of the 2008 crisis.  Turkish and Gulf airlines have taken on a huge number of passengers, causing European airlines to decline in market share in the EU.  Alitalia is among these companies and has asked the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for financial assistance for the reintegration of the 1,249 newly made redundant workers. Although I supported this measure, I regret that it will apply to a small number of workers, 14.7% of the total. It is gratifying that the measures are aimed at workers who are made redundant over the age of 50 who traditionally have difficulty finding a new job. The personalised service package has been developed in conjunction with the social partners and accredited professional agencies, which can only contribute to efficiency in the implementation of the measures.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund. Indeed, it is also Europe's role to help countries, but especially citizens who have experienced the worst, and to be able to give them the tools to rebuild their lives and their futures.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is in line with the efforts to support workers made redundant due to global economic crisis. The company Gruppo Alitalia, which provides international air-passenger transport, has been negatively affected by the decline in the EU’s share at the air transport market and a huge increase in the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish carriers that has occurred at the expense of European companies such as Alitalia. Following its dismissal of 1 249 workers in 2014, Italy applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). It is entitled to EUR 1 414 848 that will enable the implementation of measures targeting 184 dismissed workers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the mobilisation of the European Global Development Fund in the event of an Italian request for assistance to redundant workers in Gruppo Alitalia operating in the air transport sector.  In my view, the proposed measures cannot solve the serious economic problems faced by many Member States, including Italy.  Unfortunately, the measures offered by the Fund are only short-term and I therefore reiterate that only eliminating bureaucratic burdens and reducing tax obligations will help all Member States and their citizens and businesses to preserve jobs and economic recovery and growth.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management (application EGF/2015/004 IT/Alitalia, Italy) was supported. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to workers who lose their jobs as a result of structural changes in world trade or as a result of the cessation of business or the relocation of their production. The Italian airline has laid off 1,200 people, mainly due to a reduction in its market share in international passenger air transport. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to reintegrate 184 workers into the labour market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activity has ceased as a result of major structural changes. It helps workers and assists them with their reintegration into the labour market. However Alitalia has some serious work to do and needs to restructure and become a modern company. The world where there was automatic State-aid backup in the event of troubles is over! This is also valid for the recent Air France situation.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of funds should be transparent and efficient. I voted in favour of the application report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of mobilizing this new EGF heading following our traditional position: we cannot oppose the financial implementation of commitments that have already been made and which ultimately alleviate a situation of unprotection of workers affected by the closure of companies, but we do not stop considering that this Fund not only does not solve at all the impacts of the massive labour deind industrialization and easing policies that imposes the neoliberal model applied today in Europe, but legitimizes it by alleviating its direct and immediate effects.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ In favour as agree for the use of the EGF in this case.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this EGF application filed on 24 March 2015 by the Italian Gruppo Alitalia, following 1 249 redundancies caused mainly by the huge increase in the number of passengers carried by Gulf and Turkish carriers. It is worthwhile to remind that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and/or as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market. In this particular case, therefore, the EGF will be mobilised in order to provide a financial contribution of EUR 1 414 848 in respect of the application submitted by Italy.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay redundancies as a result of the cessation of different business activities of Member States. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of responding favourably to this request for funds, agreed with the social agents, because of the high number of redundancies in Alitalia. However, situations such as this are a consequence of the liberalisation policies followed by the EU and the overall strategy of multinationals, so EGF contributions are not sufficient to solve the serious labour crisis in Europe.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The application under consideration relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1.4 million from the EGF in favour of Italy to compensate for the loss of 184 jobs following the dismissal of 1249 workers at Alitalia.  This amount will be used for training, support for active work demand and reimbursement of mobility costs to attend training and incentives for hiring over 50 years. These 184 workers find themselves in a situation of greater difficulty in the search for work as they are in a region of Italy, Lazio, which is characterised by the great importance of services and a low level of industrialisation, and the effects of the economic and financial crisis have affected employment in the Lazio region, although to a lesser extent than employment at national level.  By supporting employers in the redundancy decision, giving way to justifications that clear them from taking responsibility and which has nothing to do with the ability of workers to perform their function, these Funds "legitimise" their policy of dismissals, rather than serving to support access to employment with rights.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Italian authorities argue that the redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia are due to a decrease in the number of passengers carried in 2014 compared to 2010. Workers (over 50 years of age) will be supported in finding work, training. This report is therefore worthy of support.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Like my group, I am voting against any disbursement from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), as well as against it. The EGF is designed to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020. This fund can cover up to 60% of the costs of projects that can help redundant workers find a new job or start their own business. The EGF is only used where more than 500 workers are made redundant by a single company (including suppliers and downstream companies) or where many workers in a single industry lose their jobs in one or more neighbouring regions. There is no reason to locate these measures at European level. This is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices. I voted in favour of mobilising more than EUR 1.4 million from the EGF, with a view to reintegrating 184 of the 1,249 redundant workers from Gruppo Alitalia into the labour market. According to the Italian authorities, the underlying event of these redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia is the decrease in the number of passengers carried in 2014 to the 2010 figures, which represents a decrease of 3,6 % compared to 2013 and 6,4 % compared to 2012, in conjunction with the losses accumulated since the full privatisation of Alitalia in 2009.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Vana's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund financial contribution from the EGF following the 1,249 redundancies at Gruppo Alitalia. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can be an important European support tool for workers affected by the effects of globalisation. The countries of the European South, which also face the biggest problem, should make the most of the provisions of this Fund, which should have already been strengthened with even more funding.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today supported the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for the Alitalia case. Last March, Italy requested the support of the EGF following the dismissal of 1,249 workers of the company Alitalia, which was privatised in 2009. The causes of the redundancies are linked to the decrease in Alitalia's market share and the decrease in passengers, due to the economic crisis and the increase in the price of fuel. To help the company's former employees, Italy has requested the intervention of the EGF, the EU's tool to offer support to redundant workers. The EGF offers a number of tools to redundant employees, such as support for business start-ups, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training courses. The estimated total cost of the interventions amounts to approximately EUR 2.3 million; the EGF will provide €1,414,848 and will affect 184 beneficiaries. Although, on the one hand, the demand for such a small number of beneficiaries is quite anomalous compared to potential candidates, we can only support the granting of facilities that will support redundant workers.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) by granting Italy a contribution of 1,414,848 euros to deal with the consequences of the redundancy of 1,249 employees of the Alitalia group. I also welcome the speed of the procedure for assessing the Italian application, which lasted less than 5 months. It is important that these funds are used, as the Italian authorities have already begun to do independently, for active support in job search and training measures, including the programme for the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers over the age of 50.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report. I am from the Czech Republic, which supports and is itself active in supporting developing countries. It should be said that for the next period 2014-2020, the Czech Republic's contribution to the European Development Fund is doubling. We are, of course, interested and concerned about the extent to which the money we provide to third countries is being used effectively. This report can certainly contribute to this, which clearly states that more cooperation with local authorities, not just central governments, should be used in the allocation and use of this money, because in certain cases, and we have also debated this several times here in plenary, the use of money is often questionable and the question is to what extent the money ends up with final recipients, those who need it and who are supposed to help it. So greater involvement of local authorities, which is the philosophy of this report, is, in my think, right. I welcome it, which is why I supported the report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo chomh maith agus ní raibh aon deacracht ag baint leis, mar bhí an chuid is mó de na Feisirí i bhfabhar chomh maith; sé chéad caoga a sé as sé chéad seachtó naoi a vótáil.  Is maith sin, mar is ag an leibhéal áitiúil a dhéantar an chuid is mó den obair. Má dhéanann údaráis áitiúla an jab i gceart bíonn daoine sásta; feiceann siad cad atá á dhéanamh acu, agus dar ndóigh cabhraíonn sé leo saol níos fearr a bheith acu. Bíonn aithne ag daoine ar a chéile ag an leibhéal seo. Má théimíd trí na rialtais, uaireanta deachtóirí agus mar sin de, cuirtear a lán airgid amú agus ní úsáidtear an t-airgead mar is mian linn.  Dá bhrí sin, is tuarascáil mhaith í seo agus cabhróidh sí leis na tíortha atá ag forbairt airgead a úsáid sa tslí a theastaíonn uainn.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – As we know, the European Union is the world's largest donor of financial and other forms of aid. As one of the most developed and richest regions, we have a duty to help others. And one of the most effective ways of doing this is, in my view, cooperation with municipalities. To a large extent, direct regions of countries outside the capital contribute to national development, both economically, culturally and politically. It is therefore absolutely necessary to share national treasures with such regions and never – never – to forget about the periphery. This principle can be applied to any country, not only in the case of development, for example, my country – there is a strong difference in economic development and overall wealth in Latvia between the capital City of Riga and the Latgale region. And I believe that, given the kind of support, we can get very good results.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report by my fellow members of the faction, not only because I consider local authorities to be important, but above all because, in my opinion, these institutions often far better implement the objectives of European Union policy and protect its values than is seen with central governments. It is indeed a manifestation of subsidiarity, decentralisation, I would even say that certain principles of proportionality, which are reflected in the work of local authorities, must therefore be supported in their efforts. I consider it essential that the role of local authorities also reflects their budgetary role. Unfortunately, this is often not the case, but if, for example, the central government's debt obligations are not respected, local authorities do very little to contribute to it. In the Czech Republic, this is only less than ten percent, as opposed to central government debt. It must therefore be known that central authorities often manage far worse than local authorities.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I voted in favour of it now precisely because, on the previous subject, in order not to be able to dethrate EU public funds, it should be distributed among friends and friends. And I would like to return to where I was just going, that this is also the case, for example, in the case of Hungarian hectare-based and area-based land subsidies. I was pleased, and I encourage the recipients of all kinds of EU money, such as local communities in Africa or even the Hungarian people, to turn to the competent authorities for evidence. In our case, the case number and address of OLAF, under which the case of land manipulation in Hungary is running, will now appear in this recording, and their evidence should be reported here.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the vast amount of corruption present in local authorities in developing nations; there is a strong indication that taxpayers’ money would be unsafe in the hands of local authorities in developing nations. The endemic nature of corruption at a local level in developing nations combined with weak data and records capability due to the absence of modern technology, means that allocating finance directly to local authorities will only increase this possibility. Therefore UKIP voted against this report based on this justification.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because it promotes the development of public-private agreements as the axis of the role of local authorities in impoverished countries.  We reject such consortia as we understand that this investment model makes it impossible to make a real project of improving the living conditions of the majority of the population of impoverished countries in the medium and long term impossible and seeks to ensure the benefits of large corporations at the cost of shifting the risk of their investments to the public sector.   However, I abstained on the ground that the report includes positive aspects of the need to develop public services at the local level, strengthening the role of local authorities in achieving higher gender equality quotas or promoting social organisations to achieve truly inclusive development.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are aspects of this report which are good. I recognise the need for and benefit of internal devolution and decentralisation to strengthen local authorities and address regional development discrepancies. I acknowledged the role of local authorities in representing minorities and protecting their interests. However, the emphasis placed on the private sector as a ‘key enabler’ of development and its encouragement of public-private initiatives means that I am unable to support the report and have abstained accordingly.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report by the Committee on Development highlightes the role of Local Government in the implementation of development aid in third countries. Particularly after the adoption by the UN General Assembly of global development goals for the next fifteen years, local communities should have an active role. That is why the report calls on the European Commission to take action and the guidelines it has presented to be translated into acts that will have a substantial effect.  For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution encourages developing country states to transfer some of their budgetary resources to local authorities. The aim is to ensure proper, accountable and transparent governance of local authorities and civil society organisations.  This problem directly concerns the organization of states, I objected to this text.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the role of local authorities in development cooperation in developing countries. Local authorities play a key role in the setting, preparation and implementation of development objectives and play a close role in the interconnection between community, national and global objectives. I agree with the need to ensure a fairer transfer of resources from national level to regions, cities and municipalities.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which excludes states from European aid policies for developing countries. It is not for the European Union to decide, especially since it shows every day that it is pursuing interests that are not those of its Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In order to make decentralised cooperation one of the main means of implementing the EU's post-2015 development framework, this report calls on the European Commission to: make decentralisation a sector of concentration of its external aid financial instruments; intensify its efforts to integrate local authorities as full players in the implementation of the 11th European Development Fund. I supported this report, which supports the idea that strategic planning at the national and local level is absolutely necessary for the promotion and integration of the social, economic and environmental dimensions of development aid.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation tells us that it is essential to ensure proper, transparent and accountable governance of local authorities and civil society organisations. The report urges the European Union to promote decentralised cooperation as a means of implementing the development of a post-2015 framework and encourages national governments to transfer resources at the local or regional level (decentralisation). The report believes that this would be a means of combating corruption, especially for multinationals.  I strongly oppose the recommendations of this report because I believe that the organisation of States is a matter of a choice that concerns them directly and that decentralisation will not limit corruption in any way. On the contrary, in Europe, decentralisation increases costs, constraints and encourages arrangements at the local level. Finally, this report wants to undermine the sovereignty of States and that is why I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I support many of its points, I have chosen to abstain from this report because it touches on well-known topics without proposing concrete and innovative solutions.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I've dropped my voice. There are positive wordings about the role of civil society and the importance of gender equality work, while at the same time the report is based on a position in which the private sector is seen as the most essential actor for development. That's why I choose to abstain.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Local authorities are the key state agent for achieving the newly adopted sustainable development goals in New York that will shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years. Its role in protecting vulnerable populations in middle-income countries and especially in fragile states in crisis is essential. This report proposes strengthening the decentralization of development cooperation and launching innovative partnerships to ensure positive results in the implementation of the new development agenda, the conclusions of the Climate Change Summit. The urgent need for local authorities to be integrated as full actors in the implementation of the European Development Fund and the Development Cooperation Instrument should be highlighted. It also includes the establishment of a partnership between the European Union and local authorities, and promotes collaboration agreements between those authorities of the Member States and the local authorities of developing countries, in areas such as training and human capacity.  I therefore support this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because local authorities play a key role in the protection of vulnerable groups of the population in crisis-stricken and middle-income countries in development cooperation in developing countries. The new global development programme allows for the wide-ranging involvement of civil society organisations, local authorities and national parliaments. It is therefore important to empower local authorities and civil society organisations in order to ensure fair, transparent and accountable governance. The European Parliament calls on the EU to continue to pay particular attention to local authorities in development planning, implementation and financial assistance. It is also important to ensure that local authorities are better represented in international negotiations on the adoption of the post-2015 development agenda at the International Conference on Financing for Development and the 21st United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP 21).

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public security, justice or environmental challenges all play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. I agree with the above objectives, so I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, following the People's Party line.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Times we have warned in Slovenia that the local and regional level must also be involved in economic development. It is closer to the citizens, is more responsible and keeps in touch with what people really want. Good governance at local level is the key to sustainable development, and the principle of subsidiarity is one of those things that should be taken into account as much as possible by all national governments. The report largely supports such an approach, and I was pleased to support it. I would be happy, however, if one of those who are speaking today in Slovenia about changes in the field of local self-government would also read this report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Millennium Development Goals promoted by the United Nations represent a project agreed with all countries in the world and shared by the largest international institutions, including the European Union. The European Development Fund and the cooperation instruments available to the Union have made a major contribution to the implementation of these objectives. In planning development strategies, it is essential to increase efforts to ensure that global goals are translated into national and local dynamics. Local authorities have been key players from the earliest stages of planning the growth of a specific community, and their contribution to setting the European development agenda is an opportunity that we must not miss. In this way, we would help national governments to take responsibility for resource management and make it easier for the international community to invest more focused on the specific territorial issues of each reality. For these reasons, I fully support the need for decentralised cooperation and regular dialogue with civil and local society in setting the post-2015 agenda.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report on the role of local authorities of developing countries in development cooperation.  The report welcomes the establishment of EU-wide cooperation with developing countries, and calls on the Union to promote decentralised cooperation as a way of implementing the development framework.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on "The role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation". Indeed, this report excludes states from European development aid policies. Recipient states must be able to distribute development aid according to their national policy wishes.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that strategic planning at national, and above all, local level is fundamental to the promotion and integration of the three main dimensions of development: the social, economic and environmental dimensions. It is important that the local authorities of the Member States and states receiving the funds commit themselves to making the development cooperation system more efficient.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Any social and economic development programme cannot take root without the active participation of those who live and administer the territory covered by the intervention. The support of the central authority – which is often too labile and perceived as distant or alien from the citizens of rural areas – is not enough to be successful: consistent with what has emerged from the WORKING GROUPS on the Sustainable Development Goals (OWGs) of the UN General Assembly, it is necessary to focus on subnational, regional and local levels of government. The EU must adopt and promote a new form of decentralised cooperation as a means of implementing the development framework for the next five years. Decentralisation must be a priority area for the use of external aid financial instruments, such as SDN and EDF, and must be accompanied by the integration of local authorities as full players in the implementation of the 11th EDF at the level of partner countries, their regions and sector aid. Today, the absolute priority must be the protection of the right to medical care and access to water: the WHO Monitoring Group has shown that it is impossible to achieve these objectives without involving the local authorities which, materially, control these resources; good cooperation can only be territorial.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for promoting decentralization in developing countries and encouraging governments to transfer some of their powers to local authorities. According to the rapporteur, decentralisation would be the most effective way to combat corruption of elected representatives, particularly orchestrated by representatives of large groups, and would help to better meet the needs of their constituents. To do so, national governments would be strongly encouraged to make large-scale budget transfers to local authorities. True to itself, the European Commission is trying to propagate its erroneous vision of a territorial organisation. Decentralization does not limit the corruption of elected officials, it does not allow budget savings. We see that in Europe and especially in France, it is a source of gabegies, unnecessary administrative duplicates and costly for the taxpayer. Finally, territorial organisation is the responsibility of states and European bodies do not have to interfere in the national affairs of sovereign countries. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Local authorities play a fundamental role in defining, organising and achieving development objectives, providing a strong bridge between Community and national and global objectives, while playing a crucial role in protecting vulnerable populations in fragile and middle-income countries. In this context, it should be noted that the establishment of partnership agreements between local authorities in the Member States of the European Union and local authorities in developing countries could be beneficial, especially in areas such as human training and capacity, in order to benefit as much as possible from them. I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in development cooperation in developing countries because it underlines the essential role that local authorities play in developing countries and, in particular, gives a clearer definition of the development agenda in the post-2015 process.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. It is very difficult to vote against the Report of the Committee on Development, despite the scepticism with which we very often approach the reports approved in DEVE. Of course, the text does not make any original proposals; the topics touched on are those known for some time and between the lines there is an optimistic and positive judgment. Indeed, one of the major problems with development policies is precisely that of the poor results achieved. In this sense, we would have felt more comfortable with a document attacking the European Commission for not having been able, over all these years, to effectively activate controls on the large mass of aid that, in any case, comes from Europe. In a report on the involvement of local authorities in developing countries, we would have preferred Parliament to dare more, because this issue is important and solutions are needed. The involvement of local authorities in development policies is not only necessary – in order to prevent aid from being dispersed or not to produce results – but is also in line with the ideals of the Northern League. Several of the notes that the text makes are important. The references to the importance of strengthening the role of indigenous peoples in development planning are entirely acceptable.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the area of development cooperation, the European Union's main objective is to combat poverty. It is not only a moral obligation, but also a contribution to building a more stable, prosperous and equitable world. According to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the EU ensures coherence between its various policies and actions and takes into account development cooperation in the implementation of policies that may affect developing countries.  In this respect, I believe that, by strengthening the role of local authorities in development cooperation in these countries, the tasks undertaken by the European Parliament in the Resolution of 13 June 2013 on the Millennium Development Goals will be able to be carried out. The EU can support this process through effective participation in the development planning phase, implementation and financial aid flows to local authorities in these countries. I therefore support the adoption of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The role of local authorities is crucial to development cooperation. Decentralized cooperation has shown beneficial results in sharing best practices. It is important that these cooperations are incentives for good governance and the fight against corruption. The European Union is very advanced in terms of social and economic structures. It must be able to export its values and standards to the world. Decentralized cooperation is one way to achieve this goal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour of the report on the 'role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation', because local authorities play a decisive role in defining, organising and achieving development objectives. It should also be borne in mind that by 2050 the world's population is expected to grow by around 7 to 9.3 billion people, with most of it expected in developing countries, so the EU must continue to pay particular attention to local authorities in planning, implementation and development financial flows, recognising and strengthening decentralised public aid in order to ensure their increased participation in the definition of development strategies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report contains some positive provisions. It supports internal devolution and decentralisation to strengthen local authorities and acknowledges the role of local authorities in representing minorities and protecting their interests.  However, the emphasis placed on the private sector as a ‘key enabler’ of development and its encouragement of public-private initiatives meant that I had to abstain on this vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the vast amount of corruption present in local authorities in developing nations; there is a strong indication that taxpayers’ money would be unsafe in the hands of local authorities in developing nations. The endemic nature of corruption at a local level in developing nations combined with weak data and records capability due to the absence of modern technology, means that allocating finance directly to local authorities will only increase this possibility. Therefore I voted against this report based on this justification.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that local authorities are regarded as essential state and institutional actors in local governance. Local authorities are important in the emergence of grassroots democracy and sustainable territorial development on the basis of local-community involvement. This will have an essential role to play in achieving the post-2015 objectives. Local governments are on the frontline to deal with an increasing number of crises, but that most of the time they lack the capacity, and the means, to develop an effective response and the EU should support their development. I believe that it is more effective to act at local level in order to improve living conditions for communities.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Local authorities clearly play a central role in defining, organising and achieving development objectives. It is therefore of the utmost importance that they should be involved, as they can, in turn, be more easily known and involve the local populations and the strata most in difficulty.  In the new framework of global sustainable development, the involvement of local authorities is possible and I therefore voted wholely in favour of this report.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The report urges the EU to promote decentralised cooperation as a means of implementing the development of a post-2015 framework. It stresses the need to encourage national governments to transfer some of their national budgetary resources to regional and local levels of government. However, the organization of states is a choice that directly affects them. That would be interference. This proposal could undermine the sovereignty of States and does nothing to limit corruption, contrary to what the rapporteur points out. I voted against this report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The need to ensure a fairer transfer of financial resources from the national level to the subreg region, municipalities and communities is rightly stressed. It is necessary to encourage Member States to transfer part of the national budgetary resources to regional and local authorities and to give greater support to strengthening the financial and budgetary capacity of the TDAs. It is necessary to use part of the European financial assistance to finance the TDAs.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation.
