The report reiterates that local authorities must play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 objectives, as public and institutional actors for local governance, the establishing of basic democracy, sustainable development based on the participation of local populations and their democratic expression.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that local authorities play an important role in protecting vulnerable populations in fragile states in crisis and in middle-income states. In addition, the European Union has played a strong part in supporting local authorities in developing countries to help reduce poverty. The new global sustainable development framework provides an opportunity to ensure the broad participation of civil society organisations, which is necessary to ensure fair, transparent and accountable governance. Finally, I fully agree that international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows must be increased in order to ensure equality in the area of taxation on local and international companies.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the vast amount of corruption present in local authorities in developing nations, there is a strong indication that taxpayers’ money would be unsafe in the hands of local authorities in developing nations. The endemic nature of corruption at a local level in developing nations combined with weak data and records capability due to the absence of modern technology, means that allocating finance directly to local authorities will only increase this possibility. Therefore UKIP voted against this report based on this justification.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Local authorities, as key state and institutional actors of local governance, fostering democracy at basic level and sustainable territorial development, have an essential role to play in achieving the post-2015 objectives. It is resofound that it is the local authorities that, by virtue of their closer proximity to the populations, reflect more faithfully the needs of the populations and are able, more efficiently and quickly, to assist in situations of need. This highlighted the results of the millennium goals, in particular in the fight against poverty and in the provision of community services such as water supply, sanitation, primary health care and education. I support the Theocharous Report, in particular by highlighting this central role of local authorities in development cooperation policy, encouraging the conclusion of partnership agreements between local authorities in Member States and developing countries in areas such as training and strengthening human capacities, recognising the need for indigenous peoples to participate in the definition of local and regional development and investment plans and the creation of new decentralised funding resources adapted to the characteristics of these entities.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Because local authorities are public bodies close to citizens, they have a duty to ensure transparent and accountable territorial governance that respects the principle of democracy and facilitates sustainable development. Local authorities play an essential role within the new global sustainable development framework based on the UN development agenda for the post-2015 period. The most critical local governance objectives and challenges in developing countries concern the ability to provide primary services such as education, health, work, transport and infrastructure, also in view of the continuous population growth and the process of increasing urbanisation in developing countries.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that local authorities should benefit from a greater degree of autonomy, acquire specific competences and receive more public and private funding. The European Union has strongly promoted the support of local authorities in the least developed countries and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals. The achievement of these objectives will depend on local governance action and the establishment of strong partnerships with the private sector and civil society.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Local government is the lifeblood and foundation of Europe. They are the frontlines of democracy and are able to listen clearly to the voices and concerns of citizens, with strong potential to directly impact people's lives. This is because local government requires honour and sacrifice to be successful. Corruption, funds mismanagement, bribery, and other faults have no place in modern Europe and Member States. As an MEP I strongly urge the European Parliament to use its power to maintain checks over the effectiveness of local governments using civil conduct codes and regulations to root out ineffectiveness. In order to provide services for citizens, promote sustainable practices for the future I am voting in favour of this proposal because it recognises the invaluable importance of regional governance in our society.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because it promotes the development of public-private agreements as the axis of the role of local authorities in impoverished countries.  We reject such consortia as we understand that this investment model makes it impossible to make a real project of improving the living conditions of the majority of the population of impoverished countries in the medium and long term impossible and seeks to ensure the benefits of large corporations at the cost of shifting the risk of their investments to the public sector.   However, I abstained on the ground that the report includes positive aspects of the need to develop public services at the local level, strengthening the role of local authorities in achieving higher gender equality quotas or promoting social organisations to achieve truly inclusive development.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent statistics show that up to 9.3 billion people are expected to grow the world's population by 2050; growth largely concentrated in developing countries, and particularly in urban areas. An excess of concentration and consequent urbanization that puts the sustainability of development at risk: about two and a half billion new inhabitants of the city will need education, health services, jobs, food, transport, housing. These are crucial challenges for local and regional authorities, which will have a key role to play. That is why, as European institutions, we have a duty to put these authorities in a position to play this role in the best possible way, starting with the ability to mobilise public revenue and the strengthening of the tax system. We must act, in a complementary way, to support the emergence of a middle class through the promotion of private entrepreneurship, especially among young people and women. At the same time, we must encourage the role of civil society organisations to grow by contributing to the development of mechanisms for regular dialogue. Only in this way will we be able to create the conditions for the day-to-day management of flows, which avoids a repetition of crises which, as we know, also have repercussions on Europe.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution since it welcomes the establishment of a partnership at EU level with local authorities and encourages the establishment of partnership arrangements between these local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries in areas such as training and human capacity. I believe that local authorities can play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals, which have just been adopted in New York and which shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since poverty reduction is a matter of inequity and inequalities between and within countries have deepened in both developed and developing countries, I believe that in the area of development it is necessary to ensure a fairer transfer of financial resources from national to sub-regional level, cities or localities.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights the importance of quality local governance in developing countries to address the challenges of social exclusion, food security, rapid urbanization, resource depletion, public security and violence, adaptation to climate change, and the rule of law and access to justice. Considering that the development of effective local governments and their links with civil society should be promoted, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report to strengthen the role of local authorities in our development cooperation. Strategic planning at the local level is key to mobilizing public opinion and enhancing the effectiveness of our development assistance.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public security, justice or environmental challenges all play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. To have for more than 10 years, at the head of a regional executive, supported a policy of decentralised cooperation with several cities and provinces in the south and in particular Burkina Faso, I would like to highlight some key proposals in this report that go in the right direction and are likely to advance practices.  I wholeheartedly support the need to maintain the development aid and decentralized cooperation budgets that are engines in the fight against poverty, conflict, humanitarian and climate crises, and thus limit the massive flows of destabilizing populations for the countries of the South and for those of the North.  Beyond the political impulse, I also support the involvement of the people, the private sector and civil society in these proceedings. Diagnosis of needs must emerge locally. Similarly, there is a need to strengthen the exchange of know-how on both sides through a network of micro-projects.  Finally, I encourage States to transfer budgetary resources to regional and local governments, better placed to encourage the proliferation of projects that bind communities in the South and the North and create fundamental shared solidarity for human progress.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Local authorities play an essential role in the definition and implementation of European and international development policy. They are the providers of all basic public services. Recognition and consideration of their expertise must therefore be a central element in the implementation of the European cooperation and development policy. I supported this report because it underlines the key role of decentralisation and calls on the European Union to promote decentralised cooperation as a means of implementing the post-2015 development framework. The Commission should step up its efforts to integrate local authorities as full players in the implementation of the European Development Fund. Member States should reserve sufficient place for local authorities in their development programmes and coordinate their actions with those of the Commission and other Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report intended to impose an obligation on Member States to federalise its territory. The European Union is once again trying to force states to push to the point of absurd decentralisation which is far from having benefited our country. Both in terms of overlapping skills and increasing costs, decentralization is far from producing the desired effects. Thus, by trying to force the hand of the States in the organisation of their own territory, the European Union is pursuing its plan to reduce the sovereignty of states. As the territorial reform of the merger of the regions has already proved in France, these reforms of the territorial organization of states are imprecise and risky projects. It is not conceivable that a country, whose main attributes of its sovereignty is the control of the organization of its territory, could be dispossessed of its regal prerogatives. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since then, policymakers have been looking at various options to improve the effectiveness of international development assistance. For decades, we have witnessed how this aid for the development of the poorest countries has been squandered in corrupt deals and does not reach people.  This report is a step towards improving efficiency because it addresses the role of local authorities in the development process. I support the view of the rapporteur, who believes that decentralisation is needed in the Union's external assistance, because this will reach those most in need, help the development of small and medium-sized businesses and generally empower people at local level. That is why I strongly support this report by Mrs Eleni Theojarus.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against because, although the report has many good elements, it nevertheless gives weight to the so-called 'civil society', a term which simply indicates the involvement of NGOs in decision-making. Our view is that these organisations have no legitimacy to intervene, they represent only their members and not society, and very often they represent interests contrary to both the interests of the people and the state.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public security, justice or environmental challenges. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. This is a good report that emphasises the role of local authorities in development work and the importance of cooperation between local authorities, the private sector and civil society. In particular, I believe that the parts of the report that highlight the need to allocate European budget support to local authorities and greater decentralisation of budgetary resources are important positions in promoting local development and strengthening local levels of government.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. According to the most recent studies, the world's population is expected to grow from around 7 billion to 9.3 billion people by 2050, with a higher incidence in developing countries, especially in urban areas, expected. Some 2.5 billion new inhabitants in urban areas will need access to education, health services, employment, food, sanitation, transport, housing and electricity, which poses key challenges for local and regional authorities. In my opinion, local authorities, as key state and institutional actors of local governance, will have an essential role to play in achieving the post-2015 objectives. I agree that it is more effective to act at local level to improve the living conditions of populations, in particular in rural areas and that the new global sustainable development framework offers an opportunity to ensure broad participation of civil society organisations (CSOs), local authorities and national parliaments.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I believe that cooperation must remain within the competence of States.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas local authorities play a decisive role in safeguarding vulnerable populations and safeguarding local governance; Whereas it is also necessary to ensure that they are more involved in defining development strategies, I voted in favour of the report signed by Mrs Theocharous.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because of the support for public-private policies which has done nothing but bleed public funding dry.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains a high standard in the protection of human rights and freedoms and seeks to set an example for the whole world and to promote their respect and respect also in third countries. The case of the Italian company Hacking Team, which sells tools enabling governments and other users to monitor and record every digital movement of individuals, including countries criticised by the EU for its human rights record, including Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Egypt, Morocco and Uzbekistan, is therefore of concern. The European Commission must respond promptly, because the market in which this firm operates is currently very little controlled and largely unregulated, thus sending a clear signal to its partners that violations and non-respect of fundamental human rights and freedoms will not be tolerated in the European Union. The European Commission must find a way to stop the sale of products that allow such violations through effective policies. On this issue, the European Commission should give serious thought to the budget of the European Network and Information Security Agency, which has long suffered from significant financial undersized.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that local authorities can play in the correct and functional use of development aid funds. However, I cannot fully support this report and will therefore abstain because there is no sign of any self-criticism of the system used so far by the EU.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation because, although the report has many good elements, it nevertheless gives weight to the so-called 'civil society', a term which simply indicates the involvement of NGOs in decision-making. My view is that these organisations have no legitimacy to intervene, they represent only their members and not society, and very often represent interests contrary to both the interests of the people and the state.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities will play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals that have just been adopted in New York and that shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years. Moreover they play a crucial role in safeguarding vulnerable populations in fragile crisis conditions. I strongly support partnership programs with local authorities with a view of ensuring that they are the main actors who implement the new agenda at the level that is closest to citizens. Acknowledgement of their role as state stakeholders represents a major step forward for the EU’s new development agenda.  However these new guidelines must be translated into effective implementation, both in terms of the 11th European Development Fund and in terms of the Development Cooperation Instrument. I welcome the establishment of a partnership at the EU level with Local Authorities and I encourage the establishment of partnership arrangements between local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries in areas such as training and human capacity.  Promoting decentralised cooperation is a way of implementing the post- 2015 development framework and should become a priority funding sector for our external aid financing instruments.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public security, justice or environmental challenges all play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report bearing in mind that local authorities play a key role in defining, organizing and achieving development objectives and should play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 objectives. The EU should therefore support local authorities in developing countries in order to contribute not only to poverty reduction and the achievement of the MDGs, but also to the integration of democratic governance at the local level.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. There is no possibility of sustainable development where there is no protection and guarantee of human dignity. The significant increase in the world's population by 2050, humanitarian crises and violent conflicts, poverty and hidden hunger are challenges of exceptional complexity that are mainly concentrated in developing countries.  Investment in a better future and the hope of restoring dignity to the most vulnerable populations must necessarily include greater involvement in the national and European political and administrative planning of local authorities, which are the first to face the inadequacy of services to the population, the lack of education, a health service that is not always up to the task of emergencies, with a labour market that needs to be developed, including the use of public/private partnerships to restore strength and breath to small businesses, and therefore to employment. The growth and objective of sustainable development of countries necessarily requires greater autonomy and accountability of urban authorities.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, because I am convinced that development cooperation policy must at the same time be a local policy. Consequently, an increasingly strong and defined role must be recognised by local authorities, because of their potential for democracy as an expression of the will of the people and because development can only start from the bottom up by involving institutional actors and not in an increasingly strong partnership. The Millennium Development Goals, which the world's major donors, including the EC, had set themselves, have not been achieved, the global crisis has only helped to clearly expose the failings of many states and at best to delay the action of those who wanted to invest in development cooperation. It is time to look ahead and focus on the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda, the objectives of which can only be achieved if all the actors involved play their part financially and by giving local authorities, as providers of social, health, education and education services, a central role.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report today on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation because, as a development expert and ACP coordinator of my group, I believe that investment in development policy can only help if they reach the area, in rural areas and in the people. Local authorities, as well as local family businesses, have a special role to play in this. I reject pure budgetary policy, as the EU has promoted far too often and for far too long.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. Local authorities are an important part of development cooperation and sustainable development. They are closer to the citizens than other public bodies and bear the responsibility for forming opinions within society.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is vital we follow up on recently agreed UN sustainable development goals with decisive action, by empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and providing the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must play a role in this agenda.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities play a key role in achieving the Millennium Development Goals, in particular in the fight against poverty and in the delivery of community services such as water sanitation, healthcare and education. They should be at the centre of the implementation of the international development policy. I welcome this report that recalls the importance of the local dimension for development and that encourages the spread of decentralised development cooperation initiatives and the use of mechanisms for cooperation among cities in order to achieve these goals.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in cooperation.  This report presupposes that improving governance requires encouraging governments in developing countries to transfer some of their national budgetary resources to regional and local communities. The rapporteur considers that decentralisation is an effective means of combating corruption, including corruption from multinational corporations, and would contribute to the modernisation of public administration. It is reasonable to doubt that this is the case, given the experience of European countries, which shows that decentralisation does not really limit corruption.  It has also led to a drift in public finances and an administrative millefeuille that is incomprehensible to citizens.  Finally, it is undeniable that this project constitutes an interference in the way States are organized.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We vote to abstain because although the report includes positive language in relation to public services, the role of civil society and on gender issues, the report identifies the private sector as an essential partner - through instruments such as blending and public-private partnerships - for development. We believe that this may open the door to the privatization of development cooperation policy. In addition, we believe that the report will have little or no impact on cooperation policy when it comes at a time when the normative and financial aspects of the new 2030 development framework have already been internationally agreed and approved.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group I voted in favour of this report as the recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Empowering local authorities in developing countries is essential to ensure accountability and transparency. Local authorities provide basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all and we must encourage them to play a role in this agenda.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public security, justice or environmental challenges all play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report due to the fact that I am a firm believer that efficient governance at a local level is vital in order to achieve sustainable development and positive results. Good governance at a local level helps to manufacture conditions for inclusive and effective development processes. The quality of local governance is also related to the way local authorities manage and implement public policies and services on the basis of local policymaking processes and interactions with other public institutions, citizens and private sectors. Challenges which local communities face are more urgently and effectively solved when there is good governance at a local level, such as migration, rapid urbanisation, depletion of resources, public safety and violence, climate adaptation and mitigation and so forth.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of the Theocharous report. Most of my working life has been linked to regional development and local authorities, which is why I believe so much in their extraordinary potential to identify the real needs of the region and its people and thus contribute to its faster development. I am therefore convinced that, with regard to cooperation with developing countries, we should, wherever possible, rely precisely on cooperation with local authorities, and on this point I agree with the proposal in Mrs Theocharous's report for the Commission to consider the possibility of decentralising the main area of funding from the EU's external instruments.  I also believe that combating poverty and improving living standards in developing countries, including with the support of local and regional authorities, is one of the important ways of preventing the migration crisis at its source, which is why I am in favour of increasing funding for this purpose in the 2016 budget.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. These institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens. Their opinion-forming, mobilising role can make a major contribution to change in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public safety, justice or environmental challenges, all of which play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer a new framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice around the world. This new global development framework provides a sound basis for this but the hard work has only just started. We need to ensure that local authorities are empowered in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency. If this agenda is to be implemented effectively, we cannot adopt a top-down approach. Local authorities must be able to provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The success of development policy also depends on local authorities who are confronted on a daily basis with the realities and needs of the people and fully grasp the territorial, economic, social and cultural issues... I am convinced that local authorities can be an engine of development and that is why I advocate that they be associated with the sustainable development strategy. Mrs Theocharous's report rightly highlights this dimension by showing how local authorities are able to communicate with civil society organisations, to understand and respond to very concrete challenges such as social exclusion, insecurity, lack of basic infrastructure, rampant urbanization... The question of local governance and the degree of autonomy granted to these authorities by the central government is very clear. This is a subject on which I believe that the EU must work actively in consultation with the countries concerned.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities are generally closer to the people than central government and therefore have an important role to play in development cooperation. This is a worthwhile report and it is to be hoped that the Commission and the Member States take note of its conclusions.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We therefore vote to abstain that although the report includes positive language in relation to public services, the role of civil society and on gender issues, the report identifies the private sector as an essential partner - through instruments such as blending and public-private partnerships - for development. We believe that this may open the door to the privatization of development cooperation policy. In addition, we believe that the report will have little or no impact on cooperation policy when it comes at a time when the normative and financial aspects of the new 2030 development framework have already been internationally agreed and approved.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities will have an essential role to play in achieving the post-2015 objectives. The report underlines that the new guidelines set out in the Commission´s communication on local authorities represent a major step forward for the EU´s new development agenda.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the role of local authorities of developing countries in development cooperation, as I am convinced that both in the EU and in countries with which the EU cooperates, the principle of subsidiarity and decentralisation should be strengthened. The role of local authorities is extremely important for the faster development of countries, it is important for the economy and social development and environmental protection. It is precisely by strengthening the role of local authorities that better results in addressing the real needs of citizens and greater involvement of citizens in the work of public authorities and decision-making at local level. In this regard, I support further strengthening cooperation and transferring the experience of local self-government units from the EU, towards the local authorities of developing countries. In my work I had many opportunities to convince myself that local and regional authorities can solve some problems much faster and more efficiently than the state level of government. In this regard, I support this report, but I also want to stress that more attention needs to be paid to the position of local and regional authorities in the Member States in the European Parliament.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution encourages states to transfer some of their budgetary resources to local authorities. The aim is to ensure proper, accountable and transparent governance of local authorities and civil society organisations.  This problem directly concerns the organisation of states, I objected to this text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities, more than any other actors, have a key role to play in achieving the post-2015 climate and development challenges. They are frontline players as regards local governance, sustainable territorial development but also conflict prevention. This report highlights their strategic role in promoting the 3 main dimensions of development: social, economic and environmental, while calling on the Commission to facilitate decentralised cooperation, which is also what I see as the best way to implement the development framework post 2015.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eleni Theocharous's report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. The text stresses the importance of quality local governance to address the many challenges facing local authorities in developing countries. This quality is due in particular to the political will of the central authorities to create an environment conducive at the local level and to the granting of sufficient autonomy to adapt to the realities on the ground. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because strategic planning at the local level is essential in terms of development cooperation. This report proposes the establishment of decentralised cooperation, providing a place for local authorities to make European development aid more effective.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes good proposals on how to give local institutions more ownership of development projects and better take advantage of the EU's financial interests in the field of development cooperation, but it fails to keep the measures as general as possible so that they can be adapted to local-specific circumstances. Rather, it points to very specific models that would not provide the best possible results in all circumstances. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The success of development policies is dependent on the effective implementation on local level that directly targets the communities and individuals in need. European external policies, including development policies need to reach far and create the desired multiplier effect. In the current refugee crisis, it has become even more evident that Europe has to do more to aid communities in their home regions. This does not only mean allocating more funds, but making also sure that these funds actually reach local communities and are spent in a meaningful, sustainable way creating added value within the community.  The UN last week adopted the ambitious sustainable development goals. Many of expected outcomes can only be reached if local authorities and communities are fully on board. EU should play a constructive role here and empower local communities as much as possible, for example by considering decentralised financing mechanisms that would enable in case of difficult, or malfunctioning state hierarchies to bypass those.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. However, the work must be done at every level. Empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must therefore play an important role in this agenda.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their opinion-forming and mobilising role can make a major contribution to change, addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public safety, justice or environmental challenges all play an important role for local authorities. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I agreed with that part of the report that local micro, small and medium-sized enterprises should be put in a position in terms of job creation, sustainable and inclusive economic growth. I could not support the report as a whole, even though the intention would be essentially good, but the way it is implemented is not fair, it is done in political and economic interests. On the other hand, it is worth looking at the figure in the Millennium Development Goal Gap Task Force 2015 report, which shows that Official Development Aid (ODA), which should have been 0.7% of GDP for decades, is reaching the desired level in so few developed countries, while spending many times the aid on armaments and wars.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of this proposal as first and foremost, the local level is the birth place of democracy which is the prerequisite for genuine growth. Local authorities have to be empowered through financial, technological and human resources fairly allocated between the central and the local governance levels as it is the local authorities that can help the most to ensure proper implementation for the goals of sustainable development. Decentralisation and good governance at a local level is crucial for ensuring support for indigenous people, meaning better use of natural resources, better understanding of the needs of inhabitants, fighting poverty, and providing security, educational and social guarantees. Support for local authorities also promotes a bottom-up policy approach and safeguards the communities from one-size-fits-all approaches.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcomed the report as the post-2015 development agenda should facilitate the implementation of the results of the Rio+ 20 Conference. It has given a fundamental role to local and regional authorities in pushing towards the potential of the green economy. Consequently, I believe that decentralised cooperation should be promoted as a means of implementing the post-2015 development framework, together with a strengthening of the mobilisation of multilateral resources and partnerships.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. I consider it necessary to recognise the role of these authorities as major players in the implementation of decentralised cooperation by giving them a sufficient place in development programmes. In particular, through this report, we would like to stress the importance of the association of the private sector and civil society with development programmes, but also call for the development of reliable indicators of sustainable development.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. It stresses the "necessity" of encouraging national governments to transfer some of their national budgetary resources to regional and local government levels. The rapporteur considers that the decentralisation of power is an effective means of combating corruption, including corruption from multinational corporations, and that it would contribute to the modernization of public administration by meeting the needs of people through economic and social reforms. Decentralization can seriously undermine the sovereignty of states and does nothing to limit corruption. In European countries, this mode of organisation has only led to increased costs and the entanglement of skills.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this development aid text for two reasons: first, because it strips donor states of their sovereignty for the benefit of the EU; secondly, because it too radically prevents recipient states from using these aids at their convenience.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Local authorities (AL) are the key state agent for achieving the newly adopted sustainable development goals in New York that will shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years. This report proposes strengthening the decentralization of development cooperation and launching innovative partnerships to ensure positive results in the implementation of the new development agenda, the conclusions of the Climate Change Summit. The report also urges the Commission to consider making decentralised a priority element for financing in its external aid instruments. For all these reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Local authorities are the main drivers of promoting and integrating the social, economic and environmental dimensions of development. Predictions suggest that the world's population will grow from 7 billion to 9.3 billion people by 2050, with most of the growth expected in developing countries, especially urban areas. However, excessive urbanisation can jeopardise the sustainability of development in all its dimensions.  The report highlights the necessity of allocating additional resources to strengthen the capacity of local authorities in order to provide them with better public service offerings, guarantee equal opportunities and build social cohesion. Frequent crises also require the use of instruments combining loans and grants and adapting them to the specific needs of local authorities. I supported MP Elena Theocharous's report for highlighting the utmost importance of local authorities in tackling poverty, providing public services such as water, sanitation, primary care and education.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopted a resolution aimed at strengthening the role of local authorities in developing countries in defining, organising and achieving development objectives.  Despite the EU's continued efforts to reduce global poverty and their effectiveness, further action is still needed towards a sustainable and balanced development at global level. A key factor is the involvement of local authorities in the process of building overall capacity to address the challenges facing developing countries. The decentralisation of cooperation would help to shape a comprehensive and effective approach capable of covering the three main dimensions of development – social, economic and environmental. Dialogue between the EU, national states and their local authorities would lead to a much more coherent and achievable vision for the future. I encourage the establishment of partnership agreements between local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries, as well as the targeting of additional resources to strengthen the capacity of decentralised authorities. I believe that real change can only be achieved when all stakeholders interact in this direction.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Eu support and cooperation with local authorities, which are essential in achieving development goals in developing countries, helps not only to reduce poverty, but also to promote democratic principles and transparency in public administration, thus contributing more to respect for human rights. The weak economic and economic situation of developing countries also increases political instability, resulting in local wars. All this ultimately also affects the current refugee crisis, where it is difficult to separate political and economic refugees. In particular, the EU must use the diplomatic path and political dialogue to solve problems in developing countries and, together with effective, targeted and controlled financial support, help build a democratic and economically strong society that respects human rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 5/10/2015, and because in order to provide resources to local government, the budgets of developing countries must not go to debt servicing. That is why the most important thing is to write off the debt of developing countries. The second is to use EU Regulation 472/2013 to audit debt in the countries of the European Union and in particular Greece and write off the shameful debt.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against the report. This text aims to encourage excessive decentralisation to ensure greater transparency and fight corruption. According to the author, the transfer of budgetary resources to local levels and the strengthening of their financial capacity should be sufficient to ensure the correct, transparent and accountable governance of local authorities.  We oppose this report for two reasons: firstly on principle, because the organisation of states is a sovereign decision that directly affects them, and the EU does not have to impose it on them. Secondly, because the European reality proves that decentralisation does not work: in all the European countries that have implemented it, this mode of organisation has led to increased costs and a tangle of skills that slows down the system more than it relieves.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which among other things ‘Applauds the mobilisation and commitment of African cities in the preparations for the Habitat III United Nations Conference on Housing and Sustainable Urban Development; calls on the Commission to support these mobilisation processes and to factor support for the management of a sustainable urbanisation process into its partnership plans’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. The report highlights the importance of local authorities in developing countries as public and institutional actors who must play a leading role in achieving the objectives of the post-2015 Global Development Agenda The EU and its Member States have strongly participated in supporting local authorities in developing countries by helping to reduce poverty, through aid and financial resources. Europe is, in fact, one of the major players in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, as it establishes the coherence of development policies.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it was right to vote in favour of mrs Theocharous's report, which calls for a strengthening of the role played by local authorities in developing countries, and of cooperation between them and local authorities in the Member States, through the conclusion of partnership agreements. Partnership agreements, in fact, allow strategic planning at national and local level. The same is of fundamental importance, inso far as it allows integration between the main dimensions of development: social, economic, and environmental.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes good proposals on how to give local institutions more ownership of development projects, but fails to keep the measures general and aims to promote very specific measures. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as I consider good governance at a local level to be pivotal in achieving sustainable development.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This generous report calls for cooperation with local authorities in development aid to promote decentralised cooperation. It therefore proposes to take better account of civil society, minorities, environmental issues, etc. This banter has been going on for 30 years, but the text also recalls the essential role that the private sector plays in development by promoting public-private partnerships, for example. Finally, while it intends to define the new Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), the report will in fact have no real impact on the global development agenda since the new MDGs (now Sustainable Development Goals) have just been decided by the UN in September. For all these reasons, I abstain rather than vote against as common sense would like.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This resolution encourages states to transfer some of their budgetary resources to local authorities. The aim is to ensure proper, accountable and transparent governance of local authorities and civil society organisations.  Moreover, this problem is the responsibility of the states. The congresswoman voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the role of local authorities in developing countries in the field of development cooperation. Local authorities play a crucial role in defining, organizing and achieving development objectives. Local authorities will have a key role to play in the post-2015 Development Agenda.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it highlights the role of local authorities as essential stakeholders in regards to development of community involvement and democracy. Additionally, it stresses the need for fairer transfer of resources, especially for the benefit of local authorities.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Local authorities are indispensable actors for poverty reduction and the implementation of the sustainable development strategy. Local governance is at the very heart of democracy in that it allows for greater involvement of local people in the country's socio-economic programmes. It brings local and community objectives closer to national and global objectives as part of the international development agenda. The report on the role of local authorities in developing countries is timely. It helps to define the strategic means for the implementation of the development programme adopted in September within the United Nations. I am delighted to have been the shadow rapporteur of this report, which recalls the fundamentals of democratic governance at the local level. Sustainable development is only possible if it is based on effective, transparent and accountable governance that gives greater autonomy to local authorities, civil society organizations, women, young people, minorities, etc.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. Centrally managed and 'top-up' organised development policies and programmes are not, as experience has shown, capable of delivering solutions to sustainable development and the fight against poverty, thus not effectively accessing those to whom it is addressed. The EU will not only not only not see concrete positive results that reflect the real lives of local people, but also suffer negative consequences, currently in the form of a migration crisis, as people from developing countries are being driven from their homes by a bad situation. I therefore consider it important that part of the European budget aid should be reserved directly for the financing of local administrative units. This applies in particular to countries where gross human rights violations are taking place.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, which I believe is very positive that the local authorities will play an essential role in achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals, which have just been adopted in New York and which shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years. LAs play a crucial role in safeguarding vulnerable populations in fragile states in crisis. The report thus proposes innovative partnerships with LAs to ensure that local authorities are the main actors implementing the new agenda at the level closest to citizens. The report stresses that the new guidelines set out in the Commission’s communication on LAs recognising their role as state stakeholders represent a major step forward for the EU’s new development agenda.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal proposes that the EP take a position on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. It will address the role of these local authorities in development cooperation, review opportunities, take into account the problems that are occurring and how to resolve them. I supported the proposal in line with the position of the S&D group.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls on the EU to promote decentralised cooperation within its development aid programmes. It stresses the need to encourage national governments in the countries concerned to transfer some of their national budgetary resources to regional and local levels.  The report takes the questionable side that decentralization of power is an effective means of combating corruption, particularly that of multinational corporations, and that it would contribute to the modernization of public administration. However, the administrative organisation of states is a sovereign choice in which the EU does not have to interfere. Moreover, decentralization, far from helping to limit corruption, has been one of the main vectors in countries such as France. In addition, it has only led to increased costs and the entanglement of skills. The report cannot therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Local Authorities have been playing a key role over the past few years and are expected to achieve key partner status in pursuit of the objectives of the post-2015 Development Agenda. I would like to support the local authorities, given their proximity to the population, to be at the forefront of addressing the growing number of crisis situations, but that they often lack the capacity and means to respond effectively.  It is important to stress that local authorities are fundamental in the fight against hunger, against poverty; the provision of community services such as water supply and sanitation, primary health care and education; promoting dialogue in local cultures, indigenous peoples, migrants and minorities; improvement of the living conditions of the populations. This report deserves my vote in favour of what has been identified above and essentially for the performance of local authorities in protecting the most vulnerable populations.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This scandalous report calls for sovereign Member States to adopt a decentralised civil society organisation as a means of developing a post-2015 framework. The EU, no more than an MEP, cannot give such injunctions to states, especially when it comes to dismantling them for the benefit of local authorities! The report encourages governments to transfer some of their budgetary resources to regional and local levels. This interference by European institutions, which is not based on any sovereignty or legitimacy, shows the real purpose of the EU: to destroy any idea of a central state and a nation. The funnyness of this report is limitless. We learn that the local level would be a source of less corruption while electoral clientelism is often king... The organisation of states is a matter of sovereign choices and the EU does not have to interfere. And if we had to remove a rung, I would definitely choose the EU! So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Now the real work begins, and this must be done at every level. Empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must play a role in this agenda.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the THEOCHAROUS report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. Closer to citizens than other public institutions, local authorities have a responsibility to mobilize local public opinion, while acting as catalysts for change, including more effective public administration, more open development processes, cooperation with civil society organizations, and solutions to the urgent challenges facing local communities. These challenges include social exclusion, migration, food security, limited infrastructure, rapid urbanization, resource depletion, public security and violence, the environmental and social consequences of extractive activities, adaptation to and mitigation of climate change, the rule of law and access to justice. Good governance at the local level is necessary to achieve sustainable development and equitable results.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the adoption of this report, which underlines the importance of the Commission's new guidelines on local authorities and the recognition of their role as state actors on the Eu ropean Union's development agenda.  We have always supported the important task played by local authorities in developing countries. We therefore now believe that we should call for the conclusion of new partnership agreements between local authorities in the EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries: these coordination structures can, in fact, play an essential role in technical and methodological support for the development of local skills in the field of skills exchanges, with a view to promoting the process of decentralisation and the provision of basic services. We call on the Commission to promote decentralised cooperation in the financial instruments of external aid as well and to step up its efforts to integrate local authorities as full players in the implementation of development policies.  We agree on the need to transfer part of the European budget's support to the financing of local authorities, stressing the importance of transparency and the promotion of multilateral dialogues in order to strengthen the participation of local cultures, indigenous peoples, migrants and minorities.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In relation to development cooperation, the commitment of local authorities to achieving the objectives set is always a key issue. In fact, it is in vain for the EU to help local communities in their daily democratic struggles, or to combat poverty, if most of the funds land in corrupt pockets, or if the other party does not cross two straws because of lack of interest. In this respect, local authorities and authorities have a key role to play in this matter, and it often only makes sense to start any kind of cooperation if there are conditions for straight, open communication with local authorities and there is political will to achieve results. Otherwise, even if we tighten up, our development aid will become a waste of money. I therefore welcome the report which highlights the importance of this issue.  The next step for us is, in the light of all this, to really undertake a development policy that has concrete results. Otherwise, the EU will only be counted as a milking cow by corrupt governments in third countries. There is also a legitimate need on the part of our own citizens for the euro invested.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will improve the role of local authorities in the implementation of the Millennium Development Goals that represent a crucial role in the fight against poverty and in the delivery of community services, such as water and sanitation, primary healthcare and education.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are aspects of this report which are good. I recognise the need for and benefit of internal devolution and decentralisation to strengthen local authorities and address regional development discrepancies. I acknowledged the role of local authorities in representing minorities and protecting their interests. However, the emphasis placed on the private sector as a ‘key enabler’ of development and its encouragement of public-private initiatives means that I am unable to support the report and have abstained accordingly.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes good proposals. For example, he has on how to give local institutions more involvement in development projects. However, the measures failed to promote specific measures. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given the important role played by local authorities in promoting development cooperation, it is important to further support and encourage them and to finance them accordingly.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  In particular, local authorities play a crucial role in the development cooperation process by integrating three main aspects of development: social, economic and environmental and promoting development at both local and national level.  In order to ensure their effective involvement in development cooperation activities, local authorities should be provided with adequate funding and other assistance measures.  The involvement of the private and public sectors in development cooperation activities needs to be strengthened. Greater attention must be paid to partnership agreements between local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries. More power is needed to empower local, micro, small and medium-sized enterprises in job creation and sustainable and inclusive growth,

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider the role of local authorities to promote the development of the Union to be of central importance, especially in their role as intermediaries in the political dialogue between the citizen and the institutions. For this reason, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report because it supports the role of local authorities as development actors. However, the local level can only play its part under certain conditions. In order to achieve the objectives, it is important that the local authority is democratically constructed and that it is organised and financed in such a way that it can competently and successfully carry out development tasks at its level. In this context, I welcome the rapporteur's emphasis on decentralisation. This makes sense if the principle of subsidiarity is applied, which has harmonised different levels of decision-making in Europe and has contributed to greater efficiency in achieving development goals. I see another important emphasis in the principle of participability. As a third important element and a challenge, I see the principle of good governance, which is not without accountability, transparency and respect for the rule of law.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. Since they are closer to citizens than any other public institution, local authorities have the most significant responsibility in taking care of the well-being of local people. The role of local actors is indispensable in creating any successful policy, as such stakeholders are responsible for regional development and strengthening social cohesion. The importance of local actors stems from their adaptability to the context, as well as their knowledge of the challenges, needs, problems and concerns of the local population. Such challenges include social exclusion, migration, food security, resource depletion, public security and violence, climate adaptation, the rule of law, access to justice and more. However, in order to strengthen the role of local authorities in fostering cooperation with developing countries, it is first and foremost necessary to ensure that funding is transferred as fairly as possible from national (and even European) to the local level, i.e. to the level of cities and municipalities. The quality of local government is linked primarily to the central government's political willingness to ensure that decisions are implemented at local level, through legal and regulatory instruments, allowing local authorities to use a sufficient degree of autonomy in exercising power and acquiring certain capabilities. It is precisely because of the indispensable role of local actors in the development of sustainable cooperation and because of their close connection with the local population that I support this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This scandalous report calls for sovereign member states to adopt a decentralised civil society organisation as a means of developing a post-2015 framework. The EU, no more than an MEP, cannot give such injunctions to states, especially when it comes to dismantling them for the benefit of local authorities! The report encourages governments to transfer some of their budgetary resources to regional and local levels. This interference by European institutions, which is not based on any sovereignty or legitimacy, shows the real purpose of the EU: to destroy any idea of a central state and a nation.  The involuntary comedy of this report is limitless. We learn that the local level would be a source of less corruption while electoral clientelism is often king... The organisation of states is a matter of the sovereign choices of the peoples and the EU does not have to interfere. And if we have to remove a step, I choose the EU without hesitation! So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The principle of subsidiarity is one of the founding principles of the European Union that guarantees and demonstrates its commitment to addressing issues and problems at the level at which they arise, which is particularly relevant in the context of local community needs, i.e. their role in initiing development, which is what this proposal deals with. In this regard, the emphasis of the proposal on strengthening the capacity of local authorities in order to achieve integration of the social, economic and environmental dimensions of development is particularly important and commendable.  Strengthening local government entails efforts to develop lasting and institutionalised forms of cooperation and communication between all levels of government within the EU, but also horizontally with other stakeholders such as civil society organisations and the private sector. In doing so, it is necessary to support the efforts of the proposal to strengthen the involvement of local authorities as full actors in the implementation of the European Development Fund, i.e. to ensure a genuine participatory process.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Good governance at local level is essential to achieve sustainable development. I support my colleague Theocharous's report, which welcomes the support of strengthening the capacity of local authorities as well as the structure for coordinating them at national, regional and European level. Partnerships between member states' local authorities and developing countries should be encouraged in order to achieve greater well-being, such as better environmental planning. The quality of local government is primarily linked to the central government's political willingness to give sufficient autonomy to local authorities through legal and regulatory instruments. By exercising a certain degree of autonomy, local authorities can manage and implement public policies and services based on local political decision-making processes and interactions with other public institutions, as well as with citizens and the private sector. Coordination and political dialogue with local authorities are necessary to enable the evaluation of the results achieved, to spot obstacles and to find opportunities to improve the impacts at local level. In this context, I would also highlight the necessity of allocating additional resources to strengthen the capacity of local authorities in order to better offer public services, guarantee equal opportunities and social cohesion.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the support given to strengthening the capacities of local authorities in developing countries is essential in order to achieve the EU's development cooperation objectives. Within these states, it is important to make decentralisation a priority institutional issue, giving greater support to strengthening the financial and budgetary capacities of local authorities. The report reiterates that local authorities must play an essential role as public and institutional actors essential for good local governance, the establishing of basic democracy, sustainable development based on the participation of local populations and their democratic expression. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation underlines the importance of involving local authorities and national parliaments in the planning and implementation of development strategies, while emphasising the decentralisation of state aid.  The MDG has omipped local authorities in its implementation strategy and the SDGs should therefore pay particular attention to strengthening the capacity of local authorities in urban taxation and budgetary planning so that national measures can be effectively activated at local level.  As a member of the EU-ACP Parliamentary Assembly and at the same time of the Committee on Regional Development, I fully understand the problems of colleagues from developing countries and also draw attention to the role of local authorities in strengthening local, micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, creating new jobs and strengthening sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. European development policy is a broad policy that is based on several levels: international, European, national and regional. Local authorities play a key role in disseminating this policy and in setting up and monitoring European projects locally.  The European Parliament has adopted a text emphasizing the role of these actors in promoting development cooperation policy. These actors are in constant contact with local realities and the civil community. I voted in favour of this resolution and I stress the importance of including these actors in the definition and management of development cooperation policy.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which supports the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation.  Local authorities in developing countries, in coordination with other legitimate actors, will play a leading role in implementing the public policies needed to meet the social, economic and environmental goals of post-2015 development. The European Union must support their action. In particular, it will have to use the European Development Fund and the Development Cooperation Instrument to provide financial and budgetary support. Another lever for action will be the establishment of cooperation partnerships between local authorities in Member States and those in developing countries. Finally, let us institutionalize a genuine political dialogue with these local actors within the framework of European cooperation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Local authorities (LA) are key actors in sustainable territorial development. They are an important interface between community objectives and national and global objectives under the post-2015 Development Agenda. They also play a key role in protecting the weakest population layers. It is therefore necessary for the EU to ensure a more equitable transfer of financial resources from the national level to the sub-regional level, to cities and municipalities (without neglecting accountability). This report goes precisely towards the recognition of these coordination structures in terms of technical and methodological assistance to the development of local capacities, as well as the exchange of knowledge to support decentralisation processes and the provision of basic services.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Local authorities are the key state agent for achieving the newly adopted sustainable development goals in New York that will shape the new global development agenda for the next fifteen years. Its role in protecting vulnerable populations in middle-income countries and especially in fragile states in crisis is essential. This report proposes strengthening the decentralization of development cooperation and launching innovative partnerships to ensure positive results in the implementation of the new development agenda, the conclusions of the Climate Change Summit. The urgent need for local authorities to be integrated as full actors in the implementation of the European Development Fund and the Development Cooperation Instrument should be highlighted. It also includes the establishment of a partnership between the European Union and local authorities, and promotes collaboration agreements between those authorities of the Member States and the local authorities of developing countries, in areas such as training and human capacity.  I therefore support this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is a reminder of the leading role played by local authorities. Closer to citizens than other public institutions, local authorities have a responsibility to mobilize opinions while acting as catalysts for change, including to make public administrations more efficient, to make development processes more open, in cooperation with civil society organizations, and to find solutions to the urgent challenges facing local communities (such as social exclusion). , migration, food security, lack of infrastructure, urbanization, resource depletion, etc.). Good governance, which the report advocates, particularly at the local level, is therefore paramount. It creates the conditions for open, reactive and efficient development processes.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Local self-government is the level of government closest to each resident. It is from this level that successful activities, the provision of everyday services depends to a large extent on citizens' trust in their own country.
