The importance of cooperation with local and regional authorities has been particularly growing in recent times, seeing that a significant proportion of EU development cooperation initiatives implemented jointly with the governments of the partner countries have not achieved their objectives.  I agree with the objectives of the document in question. The EU is actively seeking to expand the area of good governance in the world. The main condition for this is the strengthening of local self-government in partner countries, the strengthening of their administrative and expertise, and support for the implementation of projects of particular importance for small but local communities.  At the same time, I would like to point out that this document could have been stronger. It is not enough to identify local and regional authorities in partner countries as 'important partners'. European support for projects implemented by municipalities and regions, capacity building of local administrations, and promotion of the capacity of municipalities to work together with local community organisations had to be clearly identified as unconditional priorities and developed further European development cooperation policies on the basis the basis of them. Given that effective local and regional self-government is a condition for a successful state, the document could also have focused more on the EU's objective of promoting partner countries' financial and administrative autonomy to their local and regional powers through their development cooperation policy.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses that good governance is fundamental to achieving sustainable development and equitable results.  By their very nature, closer to citizens than other European and national public institutions, local authorities have the capacity to mobilize public opinion and the duty to be the instigators of change by making public administration more effective, instituting more open development processes and cooperating closely with civil society organisations.  In this European year of development, it was important to remember that local authorities and public administrations must also be able to respond to the current challenges of migration, social exclusion, food security, security, the rule of law and climate change.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. The report underlines the key role that local authorities in developing countries must play in achieving the objectives set out in the post-2015 Global Development Agenda. Local authorities must be able to ensure local governance, affirm basic democracy, guarantee freedom of democratic expression and promote the participation of local people in political activities.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We therefore vote to abstain that although the report includes positive language in relation to public services, the role of civil society and on gender issues, the report identifies the private sector as an essential partner - through instruments such as blending and public-private partnerships - for development. We believe that this may open the door to the privatization of development cooperation policy. In addition, we believe that the report will have little or no impact on cooperation policy when it comes at a time when the normative and financial aspects of the new 2030 development framework have already been internationally agreed and approved.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their role in shaping and mobilising opinions can make a major contribution to change. Local authorities all play an important role in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public safety, justice or environmental challenges. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because it promotes the development of public-private agreements as the axis of the role of local authorities in impoverished countries.  We reject such consortia as we understand that this investment model makes it impossible for a real project to improve the living conditions of the majority of the population of impoverished countries in the medium and long term and seeks to secure the profits of large corporations at the cost of shifting the risk of their investments to the public sector.  However, I abstained on the ground that the report includes positive aspects of the need to develop public services at the local level, strengthening the role of local authorities in achieving higher gender equality quotas or promoting social organisations to achieve truly inclusive development.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. Local authorities have first-hand experience and valuable expertise in territorial development, decentralisation and the strengthening of democratic governance. It is precisely because of their proximity to the territory that they are able, not only to ensure better management of Community funds and resources with higher levels of transparency, but also to strengthen the links between the European institutions and local companies. Indeed, the EU has always supported local authorities in developing countries in achieving the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as local authorities do not have the technological coordination or organisation to properly manage vast amounts of money.  I am also against EU interference: the EU should not be sending UK taxpayers’ hard-earned money abroad. This is a national government competency, not an EU one.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The sustainability development goals recently agreed by the UN give us an important framework in the fight against inequality, miscarriages of justice and extreme poverty. This should be carried out at every level, empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure both transparency and accountability. Local authorities also need to be empowered to provide basic social services and the infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all and, in this agenda, they must play a role.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is the largest donor in global development aid. Unfortunately, with a significant amount of money being invested in development cooperation, a large part of these resources will not go directly to its primary beneficiaries – specific people. This unchling phenomenon is to some extent linked to the low level of involvement of local authorities in the system of this cooperation. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, which stresses the need for special attention for local authorities in planning and implementing development and financial assistance flows.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The world's population is projected to grow from around 7 billion people to 9.3 billion people in 2050, a major part of which is expected in developing countries in urban areas. I believe that in order to successfully cope with this onslaught, which can seriously threaten sustainability in developing countries, the EU and its Member States must look for ways of better and more coordinated cooperation. I supported the resolution because I think it is a good report that not only highlights the shortcomings of local authorities in developing countries, but also comes with concrete measures and proposals in development cooperation. I expect the gradual strengthening of the role of local authorities in developing countries to become an important element that will create better preconditions for transferring competences from the central state level to local and regional institutions. I also believe that local authorities in developing countries with real powers will ensure that governance is performed after 2015 so that it is even more efficient and create a better future for its people. However, I believe that if local authorities are not helped with financial and technical assistance and their capacities are not strengthened, they will find it difficult to expect greater successes.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Be it in developed or developing countries, it can be witnessed that decentralised governance is the most efficient way of public administration: being closer to citizens, local authorities have better knowledge of the local cultures and local needs and can more efficiently deal with problems at source. This has to be recognized in our development policy as well: The EU should promote the political, administrative and financial autonomy of local authorities in partner countries and thus work in favour of democratically legitimate, accountable and representative forms of governance. Of course, decentralisation alone is not a quick fix to every problem a society faces but, if it is appropriately implemented, it can strongly contribute to human development.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Local authorities are essential state and institutional actors in the area of local governance. The emergence of direct democracy and sustainable territorial development, based on the involvement of the local community and its democratic will, will play a central role in achieving the objectives of the post-2015 development agenda. The new Global Sustainable Development Framework offers an opportunity to ensure the wide involvement of civil society organisations, local authorities and national parliaments. Strengthening the role of local authorities and civil society organisations is essential to ensure proper, transparent and accountable governance.  I believe that local authorities in developing countries have a very important role to play, and I agree that partnership agreements must be concluded in areas such as training and human resources between local authorities in EU Member States and local authorities in developing countries. However, I also believe that it is necessary to ensure a fairer transfer of funds from national level to sub-regions, cities and municipalities, and that part of european budgetary assistance should be allocated to the financing of local authorities.  As local authorities are essential for identifying, planning and achieving development goals and as such a strong link between the community and the national and global objectives of the post-2015 development agenda, I supported the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report because local authorities as key state and institutional actors for grassroots governance will play a key role in achieving the post-2015 targets. Increasing democratic decision-making at local level and sustainable territorial development based on local community participation will lead to the empowerment of local authorities. They also represent a strong link between the community and national and global objectives for the coming period. Likewise, the EU is intensively involved in supporting local authorities in developing countries in order to reduce poverty and achieve the Millennium Development Goals. The Rio Declaration emphasises that indigenous people and their communities play a key role in the development and management of the environment. Climate change and environmental degradation threaten poverty reduction and pose an enormous challenge for local authorities. Therefore, the EU and its members should remain the main driving force in the development of local authorities and the most important provider of official development assistance.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Now the real work begins, and this must be done at every level. Empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and provide the basic social services infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must play a role in this agenda.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ As local people are closer than some other public institutions, local authorities are responsible for mobilising and conducting the opinions of local societies. This responsibility is particularly concerned with effective public administration, more extensive development processes in cooperation with civil society organisations, and finding solutions to urgent challenges faced by local communities, such as social isolation, migration, food security, rapid urbanisation, public safety and environmental impacts by extraction activities. The quality of local government governance is primarily linked to the will of central government to create an environment in which local government will acquire certain capabilities and effectively implement them in their own territory. It should therefore be stressed that the quality of local governance depends largely on how local authorities implement the necessary laws and services at the local level, and that they will cooperate with other public institutions, citizens and the private sector. I support this position because quality governance at local level is necessary to achieve sustainable development and ensure fair outcomes.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The main reason for the low efficiency of development aid is not that it focuses insufficiently on local authorities, but that it itself has inappropriate objectives. Developing countries must first of all become more productive and more self-sufficient, and financial support for selected enterprises leads to the exact opposite. Like the EU funds, this aid only increases the dependence of the beneficiaries and distorts the market environment, thus making it more difficult for entrepreneurs who have not received financial support to operate.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. Local authorities are an important player who can make an important contribution both to the establishment and implementation of an effective development policy, to eradicate poverty and to ensure a dignified life for all. We need good cooperation between countries and local authorities, as local authorities are an important factor in regional stability. I would like to stress here that if we are going to solve the problems on site, the European Union will also have minor problems, as we can see in the case of the migrant flows that we have been facing recently.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in the field of development cooperation, as I believe that all the impulses that can make development cooperation an effective instrument of assistance to the various regions of the world should be used to help these regions gradually become a decent place to live for local people. Focusing on local governments is certainly not the only solution and does not guarantee, for example, the misuse of development aid, but the experience not only of NGOs shows that supporting local governments or directly specific local people can contribute to the emergence of many useful local initiatives, starting with the creation of schools or hospitals and ending with programmes to support local tradesmen, farmers, etc. These people can then create the foundations of civil society.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Local authorities have an important role to play in achieving the objective of poverty reduction, combating hunger and protecting the environment. In addition, they have a role in local development and in the creation of new, quality and decent jobs. The report considers that EU support for the local community is important and makes mobilising resources at local level vital. It also calls on the Commission to promote innovative sources of funding for decentralised cooperation.  We voted in favour of this report as it promotes the strengthening of local government. As acpel we have always fought and to this day we continue to claim a modern, strengthened Local Government that guarantees social goods and democratic expression and participation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Report has many good elements, but it gives weight to the so-called "civil society", a term that simply indicates the participation of NGOs in decision-making. These organisations have no legitimacy to intervene, they represent only their members and not society, and many represent interests contrary to the interests of the people but also of the state.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report emphasises the importance of the role of local authorities in the field of international development. As these institutions play an important role in the lives of citizens, their role in shaping and mobilising opinions can make a major contribution to change. Local authorities all play an important role in addressing challenges such as social exclusion, migration, food security, public safety, justice or environmental challenges. Achieving good governance at local level is therefore, on the whole, an important condition for achieving sustainable development. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, taking into account that the UN Sustainable Development Programme for 2030 highlights, in addition to governments, parliaments and other international organisations, local authorities as important actors in the organisation and achievement of development goals. In line with this, the EU should continue to support local authorities in developing countries. Their involvement is absolutely necessary to ensure transparent and accountable governance and to achieve the objectives set after 2015 as close as possible to the people. I agree with the finding that the main objectives and challenges of the development programme depend on local action. I also think it is important that the report mentions the role of local authorities in preventing and managing conflicts. I therefore support the aim of decentralised cooperation, as urged by the report, and the recommendation that Member States maintain a place for local authorities in their development programmes in coordination with their aspirations. As the largest donor of development aid, the EU plays a key role in achieving the SDGs. And by promoting decentralised cooperation, we have a good chance of achieveing these goals by 2030.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Democracy equals decentralisation. It is difficult to imagine the development of democracy in developing countries without strengthening local power, especially in those countries where authoritarian or even totalitarian systems previously operated. In all these countries, in addition to supporting constitutional solutions for the building of democracy, efforts should be encouraged to create and represent civil society at the lowest level, namely local government. It plays an important role in reducing various types of exclusions and resolving social tensions. That is why I decided to vote in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly, the role of local authorities is to institutionally represent the state at the level of local government. Thus, local authorities contribute to the creation of democracy at the base of society and to sustainable territorial development based on the active participation of the local population in political decisions.  The definition, organisation and achievement of development objectives shall be part of the portfolio of state activities in the territory.  And while the fundamental role of local authorities is evident in developed countries, it becomes fundamental in developing countries with unstable governance and vulnerable populations. I voted in favour of a political dialogue through this report. The new global framework for sustainable development must provide opportunities for civil society, local authorities and national parliaments to get involved. More autonomy for local authorities will mean much fairer, more transparent and more accountable governance. The objectives and challenges of the global development agenda for the post-2015 period require strong partnerships with civil society, and their success will depend exclusively on local action.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It is our duty to help local authorities. The world's population is expected to grow from about 7 billion to 9.3 billion people by 2050, with most of this growth expected in developing countries, particularly in urban areas. Excessive urbanization undermines the viability of development in all its dimensions. We must therefore support the local authorities: this cooperation is very valuable and useful for many European citizens.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I appreciate that this own-initiative report stresses the need for strategic planning in development and I therefore voted in favour of it. It urges the EU to promote decentralised cooperation as a way of implementing the post 2015 development objectives. With this report, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to consider the possibility of making decentralisation a priority funding sector for its external aid financing instruments and to step up efforts to include local authorities as full stakeholders in the implementation of the 11th European Development Fund. Local authorities should also be given an appropriate part by the Member States in their development programmes. Among other benefits, the role of local authorities in development has been crucial in relation to achieving the Millennium Development Goals, especially in the fight against poverty and in the delivery of community services.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. With the adoption of the UN Agenda for Sustainable Development by 2030, the European Union must be at the forefront of achieving the new targets. The Theocharous report aims to highlight the importance of local communities as local democratic institutions.  If the text enshrines the principle of decentralisation, it correctly points out that decentralisation, which merely transfers powers, without budget transfers, is doomed to failure. It emphasizes the key role that communities play in dialogue with civil society, in maintaining close ties with businesses, and affirms the need to support these communities so that they can provide quality public services. It is thus a balanced text, which I have chosen to support, even though I voted to abolish the reference to public-private partnerships, because I remain convinced that services of general interest should be of full public management.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report highlighting that local authorities are key state and institutional actors for managed locally, and play a key role in defining, organising and achieving development goals.  As I myself come from a smaller local background and from a centralized country where villages are dying, I am pleased that the need to promote decentralised cooperation as an instrument for implementing the development framework has been recognised, and I support the strengthening of the financial and budgetary capacities of local authorities accordingly.  Indeed, local authorities play a key role in combating poverty and providing public services, so the Union should ensure representation in international negotiations on the adoption of the post-2015 development plan.  They are also extremely important in empowering local, micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, and the focus should be on the importance of good governance at local level by putting at the forefront the principles of accountability, transparency, participation, response and the rule of law.  Particularly useful for the development of local communities, I consider it a call for national governments and local authorities to empower local legislation to recognise traditional land-owning agreements, and to work with traditional authorities in the disposal of natural resources.  I believe that the precondition for local development is to strengthen decentralised budgets that will improve living conditions in communities, especially in rural areas.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation, as it contributes to sustainable development and effective management at local level. I believe that it is necessary to create the conditions for inclusive, responsive and effective development processes.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We therefore vote to abstain that although the report includes positive language in relation to public services, the role of civil society and on gender issues, the report identifies the private sector as an essential partner - through instruments such as blending and public-private partnerships - for development. We believe that this may open the door to the privatization of development cooperation policy. In addition, we believe that the report will have little or no impact on cooperation policy when it comes at a time when the normative and financial aspects of the new 2030 development framework have already been internationally agreed and approved.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Local authorities play a key role because they are closest to citizens and know first hand what are the most vulnerable. Furthermore, strategic planning at national and local level is absolutely necessary for the promotion and integration of the three main dimensions of development, namely the social, economic and environmental dimensions. I welcome the support aimed at strengthening coordination structures of the authorities at national, regional and continental level and the establishment of a partnership at European level.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The organization of states is a matter of choice directly affecting them. Decentralization can seriously undermine the sovereignty of states and does nothing to limit corruption. In European countries, this mode of organisation has only led to increased costs and the entanglement of skills. I objected to that text.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. It is known that local authorities are key players in the creation of democracy at local level and sustainable territorial development, playing a fundamental role in ensuring transparent, fair and responsible governance. Local authorities, being the closest to citizens, will play an extremely important role in achieving the objectives and challenges of the post-2015 global development agenda, which is based on people, the principles of human rights and the rule of law. The report underlines the crucial role of these authorities in developing countries and encourages the development of partnerships between local authorities in the EU and those in developing countries in multiple areas. This can foster the emergence of democracy, conflict prevention and resolution, which are the main obstacles to the development of many countries. In this respect, the European Union has a budget of EUR 1.7 billion by 2020 to support decentralisation reforms and local initiatives, as well as to strengthen the competences of these authorities. These resources must ensure concrete results in strengthening the role of local authorities and in implementing development cooperation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We therefore vote to abstain that although the report includes positive language in relation to public services, the role of civil society and on gender issues, the report identifies the private sector as an essential partner - through instruments such as blending and public-private partnerships - for development. We believe that this may open the door to the privatization of development cooperation policy. In addition, we believe that the report will have little or no impact on cooperation policy when it comes at a time when the normative and financial aspects of the new 2030 development framework have already been internationally agreed and approved.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Voted in favour since most of our Group amendments were integrated into the report which somewhat rectified the lack of concrete ideas on how to support local authorities.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report concerning the role of local authorities in developing countries.  Local authorities are key actors in development assistance and I believe their participation in the design and implementation of European development policy should be strengthened. The strategic planning at national and local level is absolutely essential to the promotion and integration of the three main dimensions of development: the social, economic and environmental dimensions. I also welcome the spread of decentralised development cooperation initiatives and the use of mechanisms for cooperation among cities and I agree with the need to allocate additional resources to strengthening the capacities of decentralised authorities so that they can provide high-quality public services, guarantee equality of opportunity and build social cohesion.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this report because it promotes the development of public-private agreements as the axis of the role of local authorities in impoverished countries.  We reject such consortia as we understand that this investment model makes it impossible to make a real project of improving the living conditions of the majority of the population of impoverished countries in the medium and long term impossible and seeks to ensure the benefits of large corporations at the cost of shifting the risk of their investments to the public sector.   However, I abstained on the ground that the report includes positive aspects of the need to develop public services at the local level, strengthening the role of local authorities in achieving higher gender equality quotas or promoting social organisations to achieve truly inclusive development.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals are a challenge that we must all strive to meet. They also represent an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Local authorities represent an important partner in meeting these targets. By empowering, not emaciating local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must play a role in this agenda. By delivering aid as closely to the people who need as possible we can empower communities. This report represents a step in the right direction and therefore I have supported it.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Millennium Development Goals, adopted in 2000, are far from being achieved and the UN has just adopted 17 new sustainable development goals. Yet, despite the rhetoric, public aid for development aid is in free fall in many states, including France. Today's initiative report attempts to take stock of the contribution of local authorities in developing countries to development cooperation.  The report stresses the importance of local authorities, public services and civil society in the implementation of development cooperation and proposes that development aid be more geared towards them in order to avoid the grabbing of such aid by national authorities and to direct them towards the population. While I can only support this idea, I regret that this report is in line with the usual liberal guidelines and promotes a greater share of private financing in this aid as well as the use of loans rather than grants.  That is not how we will achieve the objectives, I abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Local authorities play a key role in protecting the weakest population layers of the most weakened states in crisis and middle-income countries. Local authorities are central to the fight against poverty and in the provision of community services. Strengthening local authorities and civil society organisations is therefore essential to ensure a fairer transfer of financial resources from the national level to the sub-regional and local level. It therefore makes sense to encourage national states to transfer part of the budget to the level of regional and local governments. However, it should be noted that this issue cannot delude the austerity issues which have penalised and much the transfers from the central state to local authorities as was the case in Portugal and in most of the intervened countries. In this way, we fear that this report is yet another manifestation of pious intentions without any practical effect

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report makes good proposals on how to give local institutions more ownership of development projects, but fails to keep the measures general and aims to promote very specific measures. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the ideas expressed here on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development aid. This resolution cites, across four typewriter pages, the recent parliamentary resolutions, opinions, Commission communications, Council papers and other evaluation reports on United Nations development programmes. We cannot therefore accuse the institutions of not having already written, made, intended and adopted much. But now it is too late to invoke the role of local authorities in development cooperation. If all these papers, proposals, decisions and advice had been implemented, we would not be faced today with the unmanageable number of refugees from prosperity who are flocking to Germany in particular. So we have one thing above all else: other typewriter pages that come up with wise advice on decentralisation, but which are not heeded by a centrally organised super-bureaucracy such as the Commission.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals (SDGs) offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Now the real work begins, and this must be done at every level. Empowering local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all must play a role in this agenda. Local authorities in Europe and in the developing world should work together and learn from each other in order to meet common challenges and share best practice. Policy-making innovations, such as the Brazilian model of ‘participatory budgeting’, proves that local authorities can be important actors in creating a more deliberative, more democratic society.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recently agreed UN sustainable development goals offer an important framework in the fight against extreme poverty, inequality and injustice. Now the real work begins, and this must be done at every level. Labour MEPs voted to empower local authorities in developing countries to ensure accountability and transparency, and to provide the basic social services and infrastructure needed to ensure a decent life for all.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because quality local governance is essential to ensure a vibrant democracy. As key players, local authorities are seeing their tasks multiply, while accompanying the changes that are going through our societies, particularly in the area of sustainable development. That is why I support this report and the strengthening of local power, which, at its scale, is best placed to face the challenges ahead

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Theocharous' report on the role of local authorities in developing countries in development cooperation. This is an excellent text and I would like to congratulate her warmly on the quality of her work and the broad consensus she has achieved.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The role of local authorities in developing countries is critical to achieving the global challenges we face. Cooperation with local authorities must be strengthened, after all they are the ones who know the day-to-day needs of the inhabitants of developing countries best. Our development aid can be maximized by establishing more direct channels of dialogue with local authorities, we can achieve a greater impact of funding instruments and a more direct improvement in the living conditions of people living in developing countries.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on local authorities as crucial to achieving the European Union's development goals. This report highlights the great importance of local authorities for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, for job creation and sustainable economic growth. I support the idea of decentralisation, as well as the importance of local authorities, which have better and more accurate information on regions and local circumstances and can therefore respond more quickly and appropriately to specific problems. Likewise, the idea of economic benefits for small and medium-sized enterprises – which could be strengthened through decentralisation and thus, as job providers, greatly help sustainable development – which I support in the long term, has led me to decide to give this report its voice.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Development as a social and economic phenomenon always has a clear local context, which is why success in breaking inequalities and raising living standards in developing countries is not possible without the involvement of local authorities. From identifying the most pressing problems to the distribution of funds and development aid, the participation of local authorities must be duly taken into account and supported. Especially in multi-ethnic and tribal communities, where large cultural differences are often insufficiently taken into account at the central level, local authority is the best partner in planning and spending development aid.  However, strengthening the role of local authorities in development cooperation should also take into account the creation of tools to promote democratic and effective governance, which often faces many pathologies at this level: corruption, abuse of power or discrimination against ethnic and cultural minorities. Close cooperation between international institutions, local authorities and social organisations is essential in order to achieve the development goals, combat extreme poverty and raise the standard of living of people living in developing countries. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the EU has an important role to play in this process. The role that local and local authorities can play, inter alia, through greater involvement in this process.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The minutes of yesterday's meeting were distributed. Are there any comments? No. The minutes of the previous session are therefore approved.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have a procedural proposal. With other colleagues, we have been preparing an oral question to the Commission on the best interests of children, and we are asking for this to be a new item on the agenda. I am pointing this out because we have learned today that the Norwegian authorities have taken away a child from a Czech mother and have put the child up for adoption by Norwegian parents. It is horrible. We are angry and we are disappointed. The Czech Republic is working on this issue, but here in the European Parliament we are not able to do anything for the rights of children from the EU. I am asking you, Madam President, and my colleagues to support the oral question to the Commission for the next plenary.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Madam, this is obviously a very important subject, but I think that the procedure requires going first through the Conference of Presidents in order to be able to register this point. We will therefore respond to your request on this important subject.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on Emissions Measurements in the Automotive Sector, by Giovanni La Via, Vicky Ford, Jerzy Buzek and Michael Cramer, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, and the Committee on Transport and Tourism (O-000113/2015 - B8-0764/2015) (2015/2865 (RSP)).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are talking about a sad story.  This is a very sad story because, as legislators we thought in recent years that we had made a real and active contribution to reducing emissions in the automotive sector, we thought that we had achieved important objectives so that European citizens could live in a cleaner environment, in fact we are faced with something profoundly different, because we have not been able to guarantee citizens better air to breathe. We now have the certainty that our legislative desire was just an illusion, an illusion based on fraud that we were unable to avoid or detect.  It is therefore clear that we now know that the limits on nitrogen monoxide emissions have been deliberately exceeded for many years by one of the largest and most powerful car manufacturers. As chairman of the ENVI Committee, I am therefore concerned, like my fellow Members who will speak after me, and I would like to ask the European Commission whether there have been other pollutants involved, such as particulate matter, carbon monoxide or others, or whether we are just talking about nitrogen monoxide, given the great link between these pollutants.  Is it also true, as we have read in some press articles, that emissions were more than forty times higher than the permitted limits? We want to know the truth, and i therefore call on the European Commission to proceed with the necessary investigations and, above all, to keep the European Parliament constantly informed of the results of the investigations. We would like to thank the Commission for being prepared to come to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, to report immediately after the scandal has been identified, but we would also like to know whether it is true, as stated by many car manufacturers besides Volkswagen, that they have not manipulated car emissions tests. However, we therefore call on the Commission to put them to an independent ballot as well, because what is at stake is very important, since it concerns the health of European citizens.  Mr President, what has happened is also a sad story for another reason. I am referring here to the role of the type-approval authorities. How is it that these authorities have not discovered the existence of illegal mechanisms in such a long period of time? How are these tests carried out and with what tools and equipment? As we all know, who discovered this fraud was an American university, but should we also ask the Member States, which are responsible for the controls, who is responsible for these technical bodies, how is it possible that these cars have passed the type-approval tests? What, then, is the exact role for the European Commission in this area and what does Commissioner Bieńkowska think of the possible establishment of a type-approval or surveillance authority which will, of course, be able to monitor the control and verification operations carried out in the individual Member States?  I am also thinking of the local authorities and cities which are currently failing to meet the required air quality standards and against which infringement proceedings have already been announced by the European Commission, at least now they know what was going on. There was someone who did not respect the rules and they were held, perhaps wrongly, unjustly responsible.  Mr President, Commissioner Bieńkowska, we have therefore discovered in recent days that today's nitrogen monoxide emissions from certain diesel vehicles measured on the road may in fact differ and differ from what is calculated in the laboratory, and that is why the Commission is developing new ways of measuring these emissions, the so-called real drive emission, based on the use of the car under normal driving conditions. With regard to this new test methodology from 2017, I would like to ask whether the Commission can clarify whether it will be based on compliance factors or a sample test.  In conclusion, I hope that this scandal will help to find out to the full what is happening in this area and whether we are dealing with an isolated case or illegal behaviour common to several companies. I wonder, however, why the European Union always has to wait for scandal or tragedy to act. It has happened in the past in the food sector, with BSE to have meat traceability. What has happened is that there has been a need to have thousands of deaths in the Mediterranean in order to react with a European policy and an agenda on migration. Now we are faced with a scandal, did it take this scandal to realise that the system had to change and had to be set up differently?

name: Vicky Ford
text: author. – Madam President, for the vast majority of consumers buying a car is the single biggest purchase they make in their lives after they have bought a home. This Volkswagen scandal is not just about money. It is about health as well.  Cheating the standards brings a massive and fundamental breach of trust. For the market to work properly there must be trust – trust that a service or a good is what the supplier claims it is, trust that it complies with the relevant laws or regulations, trust that your competitors are acting honestly, and trust that official bodies have done their jobs properly. This principle has to apply all across the single market – all across all 28 Member States – and each of these standards must be applied in every country, because once we lose the trust of consumers it cannot easily be restored.  Currently Volkswagen customers face chaos. They do not know if the car that they own is going to be recalled or upgraded or what they will be paid. Consumers who are looking to buy a new car from another company are also very uncertain. They want to know whether or not it is just Volkswagen who has used defeat devices or if there are other companies involved. They want to know why officials did not act sooner. Who knew what? They want to know why this was discovered in the US before the EU. Consumers want answers to all those questions and I agree with them.  We need drivers to use diesel cars and to have confidence that when they purchase one they have made the correct choice. We cannot let the actions of one company tarnish an entire sector. So we need a full investigation, an investigation that people can have trust in, across the entire single market.  I know that it is not possible to regulate away fraud, but proper oversight can minimise it. National regulators are required by law to enforce legislation. If our Member States agree laws, they must implement them because the strength of any approval across the EU, including type approval, is only as strong as the weakest link. Every single national regulator must work to the same high standard. Otherwise, there is a race to the regulatory bottom, and turning a blind eye in one Member State means that those goods can be sent across all 28. So our Member States must work together in a coordinated fashion. We know that the emission tests are already being updated. We have known for many years that the emissions test and fuel efficiency claims do not represent real-world experience. That is why the Commission is already due to announce new testing processes by the end of this year. Indeed, early last month, before this broke out, Commission officials came into my committee to discuss what they were doing, but without any details. The Commission needs to make these announcements soon, because manufacturers need to know what they have to deliver, and they have to deliver in line with the new tests any new cars that are approved after the end of next year. The Commission must also keep Parliament involved. Parliament has a role to scrutinise delegated acts, and 500 million people expect us to do our job properly. I get a bit fed up with secondary legislation being written in the Commission but then arriving in Parliament very much last-minute with some comment saying not to worry as it is just detail. People expect us to do our job, to scrutinise both the primary and the secondary legislation, and we must get the details right. We have to have time to understand it and we have to have time to listen to both consumers and manufacturers, and to expert advice too if necessary. In Parliament we talk a lot about better lawmaking. The Commission is, I believe, trying to deliver better lawmaking. We need to make that happen too and we cannot let this happen again.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: author. – Madam President, I agree with my colleagues from both committees. I sent the written question to the Commission, but let me add that Volkswagen’s manipulations endanger the general reputation of EU car makers and the whole European industry. As Chair of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), which always defends European industry, I want to say that what happened was completely unacceptable. We expect a full investigation and the full accountability of those who are responsible.  This has happened while we are negotiating TTIP, which is a very sensitive issue in our relations with the USA, but the case shows that we should not be afraid that TTIP will lower our environmental standards. America shares our standards and perhaps is even more advanced in scrutinising them.  The Industry Committee stressed two years ago that testing must be improved and harmonised, together with tackling misleading information on fuel consumption and environmental performance, which is very important. The issue has not yet been resolved, so the Commission and Member States must also investigate whether the case concerns just one manufacturer or whether we might be facing a much broader problem. If that is the case, it will be necessary to look at the reasons. We like to talk a lot about ambitious standards, but what are these worth if they are not technologically realistic, cannot be implemented cost effectively, enforced and controlled? They are not worth very much.

name: Michael Cramer
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Committee on Transport and Transport is also affected by this scandal, because we know that climate change will not be stopped without a change in mobility. Transport is responsible for 24% of emissions and road transport in this sector for 72%. That is bad enough. But since 1990 we have achieved a reduction of 32% in industry. Emissions from transport have increased by 28%. In other words, transport is eating up all that has been achieved with billions of our taxpayers' money in other sectors. Therefore, without changing mobility, we will not stop climate change. But we must stop it so that our children and their children have a chance to live on this planet. That is another reason why, in the 2011 White Paper, we decided by a large majority here in Parliament that by 2030 50% of conventional transport should be reduced in urban transport and that by 2050 there should be no conventional drive at all in cities. We then decided that this would be achieved through greater efficiency, new engines, new propulsion materials and new design methods. We have decided that, but not that this will happen through fraud and criminal activity. We must condemn this in the strongest possible terms. This was not a technological deficit. It was a financial deficit. That's why Volkswagen decided, No, we'd rather cheat than be honest – then the car would have become a bit more expensive. The technical revision was there. Unfortunately, it has not been applied. And that has to change! We also voted and agreed on the European Union's transport targets for 2030 and 2050, the Commission's ambitious targets, but we, as the Committee on Transport, did not go far enough. That is why we have said that we cannot take the second and third steps without the first, and we have decided that CO2 emissions must also be reduced by 20% in the transport sector by 2020, based on 1990. We decided on this by a large majority. And now we have a revision of the White Paper with the rapporteur, Wim van de Camp. And he has documented there once again, and we have also decided by a large majority, that the test cycles must be revised and correspond to reality. We do not benefit from the best values in the laboratory, which have nothing to do with reality and the road. That is what we have to take into measure. That is, of course, also the Commission's question. First of all, it also needs to analyse why – since 2008 has been manipulated – why it has not been noticed earlier. You need to analyse what mistakes the Commission may have made. What mistakes have the Member States made? What are the mistakes of the state authorities? This too, all of this must be investigated. And, of course, we want absolute clarification, both in the car industry and elsewhere, because that should not be repeated. That is why we need proposals, and we expect them from the Commission after you have revised all this. What is your proposal for the future, so that such a disaster with criminal activity does not happen again? Because that was fraud on the customer. He thinks my car consumes four litres, but in reality it is six litres. This is also a fraud on the part of the taxpayer, because in many countries the tax on cars is based on CO2 emissions, which we have always advocated. But you can't reverse that. And it is, of course, enormous damage to the environment that we cannot afford. We, also as a committee, of course condemn these criminal activities that have taken place here, and we are afraid that it will also happen in other sectors. Nor do we want to continue to guarantee the use of the loopholes. Many so-called legal loopholes have also been used to reduce emissions. The TRAN Committee wants complete clarification and that such a thing will not happen again in the future.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am grateful for the opportunity to have this point on the agenda and to explain to you the actions of the Commission over the past 10 days, because we face a very difficult case of fraud.  Let me speak frankly: this is fraud committed by one company and this fraud has put at stake public trust in European cars, and has seriously put at stake the credibility of our legal system and its efficiency in protecting consumers and the environment, which is the backbone of the European Union’s actions and regulations. I believe we will be able to overcome it. I thank the European Parliament for giving me this opportunity to share information and also – at the very beginning – I want to say that I am ready to continue providing you with every piece of information about my future actions to ensure that such a fraud will not happen again. The Commission and Member States agreed, at the Competitiveness Council on Thursday 1 October 2015, just last week, to act quickly and to act collectively. This means three things. Firstly, investigating and establishing the facts and enforcing the existing rules – which is what all of you are calling for. Secondly, accelerating the adoption of the regulatory framework formations. And thirdly, changing the approval and surveillance systems so that this cannot happen again. I will speak about each of these in turn and I want you to know that the Commission will play a full role in sorting this out.  Let me begin with the first point: establishing the facts and enforcing the existing rules. This is the point from where we have to start. We must start by establishing the facts.  You ask me how the Commission will investigate any potential wrongdoing. The Commission does not have the power to carry out our own investigation in the automotive sector. We rely on the authorities of the Member States. These institutions are professional. Let us not jeopardise what we have built together so far: a widespread feeling of mutual suspicion is not helping coherent and effective European action. In fact, investigations have already been launched in several Member States and the Commission has encouraged all the others, every Member State and every manufacturer, to do the same – I have sent a letter to all of the Member States. The Commission is providing a platform for the exchange of information between Member States, in the sense that we have already convened several meetings of government and type-approval authorities. We have also discussed this matter in detail, as I mentioned before, at the Competitiveness Council on 1 October 2015. The national authorities are together exchanging information with the Commission about this case and the Commission is also organising a meeting with the national type-approval authorities that will be held on 15 October 2015.  We need, as soon as possible, to have clarification on the extent of the fraud. For instance, the following questions: how many vehicle models are involved; how many vehicles in total; and under which conditions have vehicle sales been banned? And once we have the facts, we must act. As I have stressed several times, we have zero tolerance for fraud. We must send a very clear message today on the enforcement of existing rules, and those rules must be strictly adhered to. Here again, national authorities have a very crucial role to play. We need to be clear about what we will do and when we will do it; what actions will be taken to remedy this situation and when they will be carried out.  We need to restore consumer confidence as quickly as possible – I think this is where the real damage that has been done – and we need to apply the rules even if that means sanctions. We owe this to Europe’s citizens. I have asked Member States to work together on this because I think uncoordinated national action will make things even worse. We will only succeed if we act together. On the second point, regarding accelerating the change in the regulatory framework for emissions, the question was whether we noticed that something was wrong. We noticed that the system of testing emissions in laboratories is not the right one, and the Commission proposed draft regulations on real-driving emission (RDE) testing a few years ago. The first package was voted on in May, but I think we have to accelerate matters. The new legislation will improve the test procedure for directly assessing the regulated emissions of light-duty vehicles under real driving conditions. The new testing procedure will eliminate the possibility of using defeat devices and it will ensure that the regulatory emissions limits are actually met. The second package of the RDE procedure, setting out the exact timing and level of what are called conformity factors, is planned to be voted on this year. We will do it. On the third point, improving the approval and surveillance system so this cannot happen again, where should we act at EU level? Let me list those areas where action is urgently needed and where full support is essential – including the full support of the European Parliament. The existing approval system for motor vehicles in the EU lies with pre-market testing and the approval of vehicles. This is a system that is used almost all over the world, and it has been studied and evaluated in detail for several years. So far, I want to stress ‘so far’, the conclusion of our studies has been that this system has been effective in ensuring safe and environmentally friendly cars on our roads.  It has also ensured that the internal market is fully harmonised and that every time a Member State authority approves a vehicle type it can be bought and registered in 28 Member States. This has obvious advantages for both citizens and industry. Our study’s conclusion also indicated that we can improve the system – and this has to be stressed – especially as regards governance and market surveillance. We have therefore been working on a new Commission proposal for the last years on the EU type-approval system for motor vehicles.  However, in light of the Volkswagen problem, and drawing conclusions from what has occurred, we will analyse our proposal again and will suggest further changes that will prevent similar events from happening. I hope to present the proposal to the College of Commissioners as soon as possible. It will then be presented to you and to the Council, and we expect that our common work will be quick. We expect that the resulting work will contribute to more effective market surveillance, to implementing robust ex-post checks and to improving safeguard measures and recall procedures. Let me say it again: European consumers must be reassured that non-confirmed products are not circulated on the EU market. And finally, I have a message to us all. We need to ask ourselves what lesson we can draw from this fraud and this behaviour. We have to remind companies that they should respect the letter and the spirit of the law, because socially and environmentally responsible companies have been one of Europe’s biggest assets. I hope that we can work together for this to continue to be the truth.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, the revelation of the Volkswagen scandal made by the American authorities sounded for everyone, like a thunderbolt in a blue sky. There are still many questions to be solved, but we can already learn from them and, above all, seek the truth. First, fraud, it is of course unacceptable, it must be punished. Volkswagen wanted to cheat, Volkswagen lost. Such is taken who thought to take. It is a real betrayal of consumers because their health is at stake, their environment is at stake, towards the public authorities and all those who, like me, defend a responsible, innovative and job-creating European industry. This is a shameful act that could cast shame on our entire automotive sector and threatens to permanently undermine the credibility of European industry in the world and, among others, across the Atlantic, in the context of the TTIP negotiations. That being said, we must absolutely prevent this scandal of diesel engine fraud from being an oil stain. It would not be the right solution to predict the imminent end of diesel, when many of our low-income citizens are driving diesel vehicles and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are using diesel commercial vehicles. We know that in Europe we have a real technological advance on clean diesel. It would therefore be a mistake today to condemn the diesel industry and the car industry that uses diesel. Of course, Commissioner, you have made a number of proposals to us, we are of course waiting for the probate tests to be carried out as soon as possible in the context of real-life driving situations. I also wonder about the realism of our environmental legislation. Aren't we sometimes too ambitious? Certainly, when it comes to air quality and health, ambition is necessary, but also pragmatism. However, our large industrial firms must play the game of transparency and respect for the rules if they want to be able to maintain their confidence.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, criminal behaviour from any company at all, no matter the size, is absolutely intolerable in the European Union. It not only breaks public trust, but it also undermines the quality of our European products. In addition, especially in this case, it damages the health of our European citizens. As we all know, air pollution across the EU is already causing more than 400 premature deaths a year. Madam Commissioner, the mere fact that it was the EPA in the US and not our national approval authorities in the EU that discovered the defeat devices is really embarrassing, and I do not share your confidence in our national authorities. I think the European system as it is today, where car makers pay national testing organisations and they can choose themselves where they want their models to be tested, is not working. Madam Commissioner, therefore we would like to ask you to establish an independent EU type-approval authority. There is also a very inconvenient truth. Even the cars that passed testing in a proper way – or let us presume in a proper way – are polluting much more than they should. In the S&D Group, we have long advocated the real-driving emission (RDE) test and we urge you to come up with the conformity factor of one and not more, as you said Commissioner, by September 2017, at the latest, and without any loopholes.  Let me conclude by saying that we should never waste a serious crisis such as this one, and it is not about being against or in favour of diesel. What I think we should do is leapfrog from clean diesel to electric, and we need to support that. We need to make sure that we have a European Union that supports that, so that car makers can bring solutions instead of problems.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for A lot of the right things have been said today about Volkswagen, but also a lot of the wrong things. It is true that Volkswagen has manipulated the emission values. But it is wrong, as has been said several times today, that this has something to do with the normal difference between testing and road traffic operations. It is true that we are dealing here with the biggest industrial scandal in German post-war history. It is wrong to put it as typical of the German automotive industry. Because Volkswagen – and I attach great importance to this – is a special case. If the state itself is involved in a company, if trade union officials and politicians have a majority on the supervisory board, if that majority then appoints autocrats to the top, if then politicians also interfere daily in the business of Volkswagen, then a culture of cunning, of looking away, of displacing, of fear and finally of the plotting of customs arises. I would remind you that business union leaders and works councils were bought at company expense with ludicrous privileges and brothel visits. Even without this scandal, Volkswagen was hardly competitive due to excessive personnel costs and long overdue restructuring. And now Volkswagen is a restructuring case. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro only leads to strife and discord in Europe and must therefore be abolished.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, 11 million buyers of Volkswagen diesel cars, of which 8 million are in Europe, have been cheated, but many more have been exposed to severe air pollution due to the additional emissions of roughly 1 million tonnes of NOx. We still do not know whether this is just the tip of the iceberg, but all signs point in that direction.  Obviously the companies involved are the first to blame. They deliberately manipulated the tests. They should not be rewarded for these illegal actions by again watering down the European standards or allowing further delay in their enforcement. So firstly, I expect the Commission to now stop stalling the process and to have a new real-driving emissions (RDE) test up and running within six months.  I also expect the Commission to change the surveillance system. The current national approach apparently is not working. Therefore, a European independent oversight body must be established with the means to test cars itself.  But there is another very important political question that has to be answered. Were the Commission and certain Member State authorities aware of the cheating? The 2007 regulation explicitly prohibits the use of defeat devices, so their existence has been known for more than a decade. Several reports, including a report from the Commission’s own research body, the JRC, reported unexplainable differences between real emissions on the road and the laboratory test results. Why then did the Commission never initiate any investigations into this matter?  I ask the Commission here today: was the Commission aware of the practices by the car industry? Is the Commission willing to disclose internal documents on this matter, including correspondence with certain Member States, the JRC and the International Council on Clean Transportation?

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we found this act by Volkswagen to be totally shameful and unacceptable, and a serious breach, against consumers and also against European environmental legislation. As 11 million cars and 11 million car owners are subject to fraud, the European people will be heavily affected as citizens, because of the very harmful health effects and excessive air pollution, and also as consumers. The falsified results in emissions tests have been reported to be up to 40 times the legal maximum. Volkswagen is by far the biggest car manufacturer in the EU market, with a market share of around 25%, but it is not the only one. Is this the only company which has this problem or are there other ones? What is the Commission doing with these? Are we only checking on Volkswagen? European standards are for the protection of European citizens and consumers; however this massive fraud was revealed in the US market. What do you think, too, about the COP-21 climate conference in Paris: how will it be affected and how will the Commission advance the emission-test requirements to improve market surveillance in Europe?

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very important one. As environmental, consumer and health policymakers in this House, over the nearly ten years we have made the car regulations for clean air or climate protection or fuel efficiency, we have become accustomed to the fact that the representatives of the car industry always see all our rules as an attack on their corporate strategies. What I did not expect, despite all the negative experiences with lobbyists from all car companies – and that was the only surprise in recent weeks – was that a company as large and as strong as VW, if it cannot prevent an ambitious test cycle, systematically deceives authorities with criminal energy for years. For me, this is still something i can't believe. I have become accustomed to this old thinking that environmental policy is seen as an imposition. But I cannot understand this willingness to cheat and to crime. What led to this? I would also like to take a direct critical look at the Commission, but also my German Federal Government. I do not know of any other area of regulation in which the Federal Government has so systematically tried to protect the interests of German corporations, at least against regulation from Brussels. Over and over again, the auto chancellor – we not only have a climate chancellor in Germany, we also have an auto chancellor – has finally advocated that we have lower limit values, that we still have not had the test cycle that we have discussed for a long time. And I believe that this kind of aggressive protection also creates a hubris in companies, as it is, that we can be as criminal as VW has now admitted. What is to be done now? I think the Commission should admit that all this has not come out of the blue as it is portrayed. The Federal Government, like the European Commission, has been repeatedly reminded that the test cycle is not working. And this applies not only to the diesel Euronorms, but also to fuel efficiency targets or to climate protection targets. So: don't be naive, go to the verification of the facts! I think that what you have said today is a far cry from what is necessary. We are putting jobs in Europe at risk through weak action and weak targets. It is not the environmental laws that endanger industry, but the protection of industry at the wrong level. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I listened with interest to many of the things in your speech. I was wondering whether, in your opinion, the Volkswagen scandal is a one—off – or do you think, judging from your critical remarks about the German Government, that perhaps they and/or the Commission have maybe in some way conspired with other companies to break their own rules? What are your views on this? Do you think this is maybe more widespread than we know?

name: Rebecca Harms (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – I cannot see the kind of criminal energy that VW has used on its fake software for other companies at the moment, but I am no longer aware of any car company that does not have a problem with the test cycles. I am not aware of any group that does not need to be audited. That is why it is so important that we talk about a European study and that we talk about how we give ourselves European instruments so that we can act as well as EPA on such problems.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is our concern to draw attention to the fact that the consequences of this case for damage to the environment and citizens will unfortunately not only stop at the fact itself, but will, in a systemic and continuing way, extend to the entire European set of standards and tests, undermining credibility in any type of certificate.  What will be the next scandal? Who can trust me anymore? We have two paths: the first is to do nothing and to acknowledge in fact that European certifications are a joke and a fraud for all the citizens of the Union, making all our legislative efforts, past and future, in vain. The second way is to react, to react strongly, first of all by immediately adopting exemplary and historical punishments of the manager of the brands involved, which do not end with fines, however salty. This is to make it clear to citizens and industries that the time for circumventable testing has ended forever.  Secondly, we should work towards a strict revision of the directives to identify the legislative gaps in technical tests and qualified certifying bodies. I would remind you that the Commission's Joint Research Centre had already identified the problem of Volkswagen diesels in a 2013 dossier. In recent days, infringement reports have also reached the press concerning Samsung, UK and Swedish products, and the Commission was warned in 2011 and again in 2014 about the televisions of that brand capable of circumventing European tests on energy consumption. Are diesels and televisions the only alarm bells the Commission has heard ringing without reacting? We'd like to know.

name: Georg Mayer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There is not much nice to talk about in this causa VW, I think. VW has manipulated, cheated, deliberately manipulated software – that is out of dispute. It is not a particularly glamorous approach for a group of this size and for a group with this responsibility. The damage to the procedure will be done by many. The damage will be on the one hand and primarily with the consumers. The damage also lies with the environment, as we have heard many times today. But the company itself, and thus the employees, will also suffer damage from this scandal. For consumers, and I believe that this is one of our essential tasks, there must at least be compensation. Compensation that is more than just words of apology, compensation that really compensates them for the damage they have suffered. But, as is so often the case in life, there is also a second side of the coin. Without wishing to say anything about it, we also have a similar situation in the context of the fuel consumption of passenger cars. Data from all manufacturers are never really real when it comes to petrol consumption. These are consumption values that are generated purely in the laboratory. And that is tolerated by all of us. However, this in turn has a direct impact on the environment, and it also has a direct impact on the consumer, namely the consumer's wallet. A second aspect concerns America. We are talking about a US test. Because the Americans regularly revise these nitrogen oxide levels downwards as far as passenger cars are concerned, but on the other hand, they do not care what their diesel trucks emit.
