This is up to three times more than cars do. So who benefits from this thing, I ask here. One thing must also be said: there have been no deaths here, as in other cases in the car industry. So think - Honi soit qui mal y pense!

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, the indications are now clear and the European Union and the German Government were aware of the dirty Volkswagen case which, it seems, is spreading to other groups. The revelation of the scandal was not motivated by advertised so-called transparency, but by competing American monopolies fighting for market shares.  A struggle escalating under the Transatlantic Agreement between the European Union and the United States. It turns out that all aspects of European Union policy, such as green and environmentally friendly investments, have one objective: profits with every sacrifice of the quality of life of peoples, at all levels. Huge business lobbies have an official role as a real co-legislator in the European Union. The well-known and unknown scandals are not mere aberrations, but the way in which they operate, the proof of the character of the European Union of monopolies and the capitalist system it serves. Economic, social and political rot is what people who do not bow to overthrow can expect.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – The fact that Americans, not ourselves, are discovering to the world today that European companies do not comply with the applicable law is simply a great shame for us. We show that Member States do not enforce European law and that the European Commission does not have sufficient control instruments. And today we are talking again about what our Commission – the Internal Market and Consumer Protection – has already said many times. My colleague Andreas Schwab was the author of a report a few years ago, where we called for improved governance of the single market. We need a great deal of involvement from the European Commission, but above all a commitment from the Member States to improve this situation. Not so long ago, we also dealt with harmful, very dangerous nitrogen oxides that enter our atmosphere from vehicles, and I proposed at the time that the regulation limiting vehicle emissions give more powers to the European Commission, but then many colleagues in the ALDE and ecr were against it. I am listening to you today, dear colleagues, and I hope that you have already changed your mind, because negotiations with the Council are just beginning, there is still a chance. But let's not panic.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I agree – we need to carefully analyse the European market and see how the rules are being complied with, and of course we need to regain citizens' trust, trust in European businesses, that they are not deceiving them. And the information that is given in the specifications of the vehicles, but also in the specifications of other devices, is true. We must regain confidence in the European institutions and in the national institutions that they actually ensure that the law is respected.  Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We need to move away from laboratory tests to measure real emissions as soon as possible, as you said, because it is a secret that cars that meet the standards in laboratories violate them many times in road conditions. This is about the health of our citizens. There is a great challenge before the committee. We... (The President received the speaker's vote.)

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have to say, Mrs Bie-kowska, that I am a little surprised at how calmly you have been about this scandal and that you have great confidence in the licensing offices of the individual Member States. I have to say that this is not how I enface competition in Europe in the internal market. That the admissions bodies that have the lowest standard are preferred – I believe that we must get on with it. We will not fail to have a European authorisation procedure with a European institution. That would be a conclusion that we should draw. And we also have the opportunity to put this on paper again by means of a resolution in the next plenary. We know this from the medical field, in the case of medical approvals. The authorities are also working together there. The European authority, the EMA, and on the other hand, the American authority. Have you been given information by the Americans? If so, when were they played to you? When did you become aware of the scandal? Or have you been informed about this from the newspaper? Mrs Harms has just mentioned once again that something is wrong. We have often had environmental organisations complaining about this. The Commission has not followed this up. National authorities such as the German authority have carried out zero tests in real operation. Has there been tests by the European Commission at the joint research centre in Ispra, where test benches for cars are also available, or has there been no tests there, and have you noticed any discrepancies there?

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is worth recalling that the information disclosed so far shows that manipulation of software that activates the emission reduction system and activates the economical mode of operation only for the duration of official test measurements already affect almost 11 million Volkswagen vehicles. In reality, however, the case may be much wider, and I would not personally be surprised if this type of practice also affected other brands. The question is whether this is not the result of an unconditional effort to reduce transport emissions as much as possible and absolute pressure to decarbonise all sectors of the European economy.  Indeed, it appears that even the largest and richest unscrupulent companies are falsially falsiing the results of actual emissions adversely affecting human health and the environment in particular. It is unacceptable that the costs of this type of corporate behaviour are borne primarily by consumers, and it is ordinary citizens who are already paying out of their own pockets not only for stringent environmental standards, but also for the unprecedented drive to maximise profit. In this situation, it is the citizens of the European Union – car users – who should know the truth and find out what really happened to Volkswagen. This must be carefully examined and clarified, but above all lessons must be learned so that this type of situation does not recur in the future.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the revelations that have surfaced are not defensible. Nevertheless, I do not think that today our aim cannot be to bring to justice the European car industry or its possible liquidation. On the contrary, I think that we must work together to restore consumer confidence so that each of us who owns or wants to buy a car has accurate information about that vehicle. In an urgent solution to the situation, we need to act urgently in the first place, not only for the car industry, but also for us, the European institutions. Secondly, a rational approach must calm the atmosphere and, last but not least, we must put a clear and factual solution to the problem on the table. I therefore welcome your efforts to create stricter and more precise rules for verifying vehicle emissions, taking into account the interests of consumers, but also the views of the automotive industry. The current rules are clearly outdated and do not correspond to the current situation. I call on you, Commissioner, to come forward as soon as possible with a compiled proposal that will clearly regulate the procedures for testing emissions in real-world conditions and include requirements and performance limits for these tests. The rules in this area must not leave room for more interpretations and therefore more possibilities for carrying out such tests. Of course, I cannot forget the control mechanisms that have clearly failed in this area. If we are not able to consistently demand that the rules that we create here be respected, we will find it very difficult to explain to our citizens that we are capable of defending their rights and interests.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, firstly, I would like to say that this matter may not have happened. There has been an invention in the Czech Republic for many years that eliminates 70% of emissions from motor vehicles. It can be applied to any type of vehicle regardless of age, so even the old car actually meets the relevant emission standards. But here in the European Commission, I am resisting, because I have been trying to put this invention into practice for many years. The second point concerns the fact that there is clearly a double standard here. How come, when Toyota had to change eleven million transmissions around the world, nothing happened at all? How come when there was an airbag affair, which was the thing where people could have been killed, nothing happened? In the case of Volkswagen, there is suddenly a huge scandal and a fine.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is clear that Volkswagen has deliberately broken the law and deliberately misled both regulators and consumers. It was wrong to do so, and it should rightly face appropriate and proportionate penalties, but we must understand the regulatory environment in which this scandal has emerged. The truth is that legislators were consumed by climate hysteria and carbon phobia and as a result we pushed car owners and the auto industry towards diesel, which was seen as a lower emissions fuel. In fact its CO2 emissions are only marginally below those of petrol, and, in any case, CO2 is not a pollutant. It is a natural non-toxic gas which is essential to life on earth. But as we are now realising, diesel’s other emissions – SOx and NOx and particulates – are highly toxic, and our dash for diesel has done more harm than good.  Volkswagen was trying to follow the pressure by moving to diesel power but found that it was unable at the same time to meet emissions targets, so it decided to cheat. It was wrong to do so, but so were we as legislators wrong to impose conflicting and contradictory demands on the industry. I see a parallel here with our ill-judged rush to promote biofuels before we understood the issue of energy inputs to agriculture and the impact of indirect land-use change. By mandating 10% biofuels and then rowing back later, we sent confused signals to industry and caused great damage to investors. It is no part of my job to defend German industry, but nor is this a time for Schadenfreude. I am concerned that the potential hit to Volkswagen could damage all of us, especially if, as many expect, other companies are drawn into the scandal. With the prospect of multimillion dollar fines in several countries, recall costs, class actions from owners and so on, it is not inconceivable that VW could fail. That is an outcome which we should all seek to prevent.

name: La Présidente. –
text: Mr. Eickhout, I hope you will excuse me, I did not have your name on my document.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I think I could summarise the Commissioner’s eight-minute speech as ‘We are on top of it, sleep well Parliament, do not be afraid.’ That is how I summarise your speech, Madam Commissioner, and I really have a problem there because, to give just one simple example, when the US Environmental Protection Agency was investigating, was there no contact at all between Washington and Brussels on what they were doing, and did your staff not know anything? That is really hard to believe, and you have to be more precise on the actions you are taking now because these remarks are way too general.  So, first of all on the investigation, can you confirm that this investigation is not only into Nox but also broader, taking in the other substances like CO2 where you also see a growing gap between the test and reality? Secondly, on European type approval, you said that we have done our analysis and now because of this scandal we are going to look at it again. Why? Where exactly are you going to look again? We need to know. Thirdly, on the new RDE tests: can you please deny that the Commission is at this moment proposing a conformity factor of 1.6? While this is being discussed in Brussels, I hope that you can say that a conformity factor of 1.6 in the RDE tests for 2017 is not on the cards. Finally, for Ms Grossetête who said, let us see whether we are ambitious: the standard of the EU is 80 mg per kilometre, in the US it is 43, in California 35. Who is more ambitious now? (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Congressman, I would like to argue with you in part, but most of all, to ask you a question. My argument is that, along human boundaries, we have to be careful that whoever does this is a good guy, and those who don't do it are bad guys. Everyone who makes automobiles today and uses carbon-based fuel pollutes the air. My question is: do you agree that the real answer here in Europe would be to move to the same direction that we do not have petrol or diesel cars at all?

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is very simple. We impose the standards for our safety and public health. If the car industry cannot comply with these with diesel, then maybe they should not go into diesel. That is a discussion we need to have on the basis of the standards for our own safety. Those standards we agreed upon – for example this 80 mg per kilometre, which is not very ambitious – were introduced only in 2007, when they already knew that new tests would be coming. The car industry has known this for eight years and yet it has not been doing anything apart from cheating with the software. That should be addressed.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am a Volkswagen customer, I have a Beetle turbodiesel that I bought after European standards forced me to take euro 5 because the others polluted, so I am one of those eleven million who have problems.  So I was scammed. Volkswagen is the world's leading car industry today. So I wonder, mrs Merkel who commands the world has to explain to us a little bit how it works because every time there is a problem, Merkel moves. Then Mrs Merkel will be here with us tomorrow, she has to tell us what happened, whether she knew or did not know what was happening with Volkswagen: did she know it or did she not know? I think that in the history of Europe... (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: La Présidente. –
text: Mr. Buonanno, listen to me for a moment. I don't think the t-shirt you're wearing is suitable for this speaker. Sir, I think you have to be careful what you do. Your t-shirt is not suitable for this speaker at all. (The speaker wears a t-shirt with a picture of Angela Merkel depicted with a Hitler-style mustache)

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Volkswagen fraud scandal is economic, environmental and extremely political. The number of cars with 'experimented' software on the European market must be verified. Were such software only installed by this company?  What measures should we take to prevent the recurrence of such phenomena? It is unacceptable for a company to go unpunished for the fraud it committed against the environment and the health of all of us. We cannot let Volkswagen's links to the German political scene prevent its punishment. Chancellor Merkel herself is a big supporter of the German car industry, as are other large German companies, which are involved in fraud and kickbacks. They are impoverished the countries of the South with their austerity measures, accusing them of corruption, and while dozens of German scandals have been uncovered, their companies are left in the doe.  The German Government, in cooperation with the powerful German capital, can no longer treat the other countries as colonies, unable to enforce their laws. There must now be an exemplary punishment for Volkswagen!

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. VW officials wanted to cut costs, but they saved at the expense of the environment and health. Nitrogen oxides are one of the main causes of ozone formation; they lead, among other things, to the worsening of asthma and many other health problems. The misconduct of some of Volkswagen's responsible people has now caused economic damage that far exceeds what they wanted to save. That should be a lesson for everyone. I am sorry for those who are now innocently affected: the employees, the suppliers and many others. Those responsible must be held accountable with the utmost rigour. I cannot understand why the former CEO, Mr Winterkorn, is still claiming his full pension and that he is still active in Volkswagen's holding company. The most important questions for us as the EU are: firstly, why did our authorities not detect the fraud, when there are eight million rigged vehicles in Europe, and only a few hundred thousand in the United States? And secondly, what might happen to other manufacturers? Some of them are surprisingly quiet to me. Commissioner, I really want to motivate you to devote a little more energy and not just trust in the national authorities. I think we have to give some people legs. I also agree with Francoise Grossetéte: it is not appropriate now to demonise diesel. A lot of little people need diesel because they drive long distances. Of course, we have an economic situation where we cannot get out of diesel. That would cost many millions of jobs. But it is also necessary from an environmental point of view in order to achieve the medium-term climate targets, and it can be cleaned up. Even VW complies with Euro-6, the stricter standard, but Euro-5 they cheated. So this is not because of the rigour of the norm, but because they must finally stop cheating. We should also think of the local authorities. We are putting up air pollution control plans for the municipalities, so we have to accept at the same time ........ (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are dealing here with a whole series of scandals. Fraud is, of course, a scandal, and it must in any case be clarified and regulated. However, it is also scandalous that control in the European Union has totally failed and that we have needed the United States to clarify what is happening here. The third scandal that I cannot yet properly define: is it a scandal that the EPO has not informed the European Commission, or is it a scandal that the European Commission has been informed and then kept quiet? That is a question that we still have to resolve. I really need information from our Commissioner on these issues. Another point that we need to address is that we must finally stop laboratory tests and let proper tests take place, which are also really meaningful. But conventional tests – even on the streets – will not be enough, because in the digitised world in which we live today, with the software that can be installed, it is not enough for us to test on the road, but we will also have to check these many different software. And I would be very interested, Commissioner, in what you intend to do on this issue. There was no mention of that in your speech earlier. Here, too, we will have to think about how these tests can take place.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is obviously a very complex issue but I want to talk about it very simply from my perspective as the rapporteur for the report on national emissions ceilings, the vote on which will be at the next session of plenary in a couple of weeks’ time. The information that has come before us in the last few weeks could, you might think, have thrown us into disarray. Far from it. The reason for that is that we know all about this. The only bit that is a surprise is quite how devious and criminal Volkswagen has been, but we know that the testing does not work. In fact, one of the first things that happened to me as rapporteur was a presentation from the Commission which set out quite graphically, in numbers, how it had not been working over the last three iterations of Euro standards. So this is no surprise to anyone. Maybe – and I want to emphasise that I am being ironic here – I am the only Member who is actually pleased that this has happened. I am pleased because now everybody is talking about one of the major issues, one of the major scandals, that we need to deal with. Indeed, we have highlighted in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) our dissatisfaction with real-driving emissions, with the type approval as it currently stands, and we have put into our report that we expect the Commission to come up with new proposals on type approval that actually work in real life, immediately. So it is with some disappointment that I listen to Ms Bieńkowska because, while she is not personally responsible, she would have had the opportunity here and now to have been able to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is not a question of demonising diesel, nor is it about demonising car production as such. This is a very serious case of economic crime and deliberate fraud, which in this case affects 11 million motorists worldwide, eight million of whom are in the EU. And it is indeed the case that the NOX values have been exceeded by up to forty times. In this case, I can only say that Mr Eickhout has already said that we have 80 milligrams per kilometre, which are allowed, in the United States only 31 milligrams, and that has just been exceeded several times. That's something that can't be done at all. That is why we need to do something. The question now is, what should be done? First of all, we must ensure that there is a truly complete and transparent investigation and that we find out who is really responsible for this. That is where we are now; you just have to see that.  The second is the tests. It is actually the case – as we know, we have known for a long time – that the laboratory tests that we have at the moment to certify the types do not really reflect the values that we really have in serious driving behaviour. That is why we in Parliament have been calling for these tests, which take place under real driving conditions, for some time. Then you need a mobile trailer that measures this. Anything is possible. We need this as soon as possible. I agree with all my colleagues on this. But one thing that really scares me is the story that we now have with this scam. It was really already 2014 that students, as part of their university studies, found that there is a discrepancy between what is written on it and what comes out. That is what you could say. As a result, VW has even ordered a recall of 500,000 cars in the United States. So, I have to say, I didn't notice anything here at the time, and that's something that can scare you, that we didn't know. Then the same cars were tested again later, and then you really realized how big the manipulation is. The software has been revised beforehand and obviously not realistic and also not willingly so that there are really reasonable values. The question now is: what is the control of the Executive Board by the Supervisory Board, and how can we in the EU ensure control?

name: Cornelia Ernst (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The VW emissions scandal is not just a failure of individuals – it must be made clear – but an economic fraud comparable to the major banking scandals of recent years. Ultimately, this fraud affects the backbone of the economy, not only in Germany, but in other European countries: suppliers, consumers around the world. In addition to the material and rightly mentioned environmental damage, there is also a great other damage, namely the loss of confidence in an entire industry. But the worst – and this has not yet been said here – is that more than 600,000 workers worldwide are now fearing for their jobs. In my home region of Eastern Germany alone, there are three VW locations. Others could sing even worse songs. Enlightenment is necessary, real consequences are needed, and those responsible – all of them – must answer and, if necessary, be brought to justice. What we need are safe procedures and tests to implement standards so that European cars are actually low-emission and energy-efficient. One thing must not happen, which is that it should be carried out on the backs of the workers.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the Volkswagen scandal reminds us that in 2015 breathing kills. 400,000 premature deaths are due to pollution each year in Europe. That's the reality. If we want to protect the health of citizens and the climate, we must change things in transport in Europe.  Fine particulate air pollution from diesel is enough! CO2 emissions because of the road at all, that's enough! But for that to change, everyone has to do their job in the service of the public interest. That is why, on 30 May 2014, ICCT, the International Clean Transport Council, published an investigation showing the fraud of car manufacturers in diesel testing. For eighteen months, the information had been known. No one has reacted, neither the European Commission nor the Member States, let alone the manufacturers. How can we stand idly by when such a case arises?  Today, I ask you for transparency and I am not alone. There are already 120,000 people who have signed a petition and are calling for it. For Europeans, I ask you to shed light on this scandal.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the scandal involving Volkswagen is serious, it is serious for two reasons: one because it involves a company that was named as the flagship of European industry, secondly because it involves a country that is always taken as a model of integrity and fairness.  The Commissioner asks what we can do and now asks for mutual help. Of course, the important thing is that the rumours made by the Commission and the German Government about these facts are not true. What do we learn from this lesson? Something very important to me. A truth that is uncomfortable for some, that there are no second-class Member States and second-class Member States, the famous Europe that we hear so much about at double speed is an excuse, it is an excuse for some to be smart. We must act, we must act not late, as always, but we must ask those Member States that are in the chair and teach to come down from that chair because they are no better than the others, and they must, on an equal footing, negotiate with everyone else in order to build a real Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since the emissions scandal became public, Europe's largest carmaker, the world market leader in the automotive industry, has been covered with lawsuits, penalties and claims for damages amounting to billions of dollars. The VW boss had to resign and the head of VW USA must testify before Congress on Thursday. Today there was a company meeting in Wolfsburg, at which the new VW boss said: "More needs to be saved", and the works council chief immediately added "no jobs are affected yet" – yet. Dieselgate is in fact a super-GAU for the consumer, for the industrial location europe and for VW itself, which may even be a case of reorganisation. The new VW management has promised clarification, transparency, information and damages. At the same time, confidence in the brand must be restored, and this fraud and ethical misconduct must be punished. That is one side of the coin. The other side of the coin is a technical side, as has been mentioned several times today. For years and decades, attempts have been made to bring European clean diesel technology to the market in the USA, small and medium-sized efficient diesel engines with good technology. Time and again, it has been possible to reduce nitrogen levels for passenger cars in the USA, whereas they have always been held up for trucks. Previous speakers have said: why now? Why in the US? That should be questioned. The fact is that clean diesel technology is a clean technology, a European technology that achieves peak values in both the minimisation of pollutants and the reduction of CO2. Every second car registered in Western Europe is diesel. Diesel is a technology of the future, as is e-mobility. And as far as exhaust gas tests are concerned, differences between laboratory results and values from practical tests, i.e. driving tests, are technically conditioned and a result of more than 20 years old measurement methods that are no longer state of the art. So what is to be done? We need a rethink. The automotive industry must use techniques that effectively reduce pollutant emissions. And the legislator must ensure that reliable emissions controls are carried out under practical conditions and regular market observations.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – As legislators, we are generally very important in developing new regulations. Most often with the aim of somehow improving the world. This has also been the case in the car industry, where we have been tightening up co2 and harmful emissions over the years, especially NOX. And so we have also believed for years that from year to year new products are becoming increasingly green and we and our children have a better world. But what actually happened? It turns out that we're generally deceived. One, possibly, several car manufacturers' firms have deliberately cheated on technology to supposedly meet the standards – but don't actually meet. What do we learn from this? In my opinion, it is not the European Commission or an agency in the European Union that has discovered this in the United States. And why could it be discovered in this way? Obviously, because there's an independent agency, unrelated to the auto industry, that could discover this and show us, consumers, what's going on. In my opinion, we in Europe should actually learn from this, and I would call on the Commission, and in particular the Commissioner, to be more aggressive in offering us a system of how an independent inspection body could be set up that could test not only cars, but generally all the goods that we buy. Because it is important that we once develop environmental requirements that they are indeed respected. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – I wanted to ask our colleague what he relies on to say that other automakers have done the same. Do you have any information about it? How can such claims, which they do, make a shadow of doubt and general mistrust throughout the European car industry, without , of course in principle, having evidence or data? I'd like to know how you can make that appreciation.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: answer to the blue card question. – Colleagues, let us not be naïve, I do not believe that only one car factory would have been interested in somehow bypassing the law. I don't have any evidence at this time. But what has happened is that we have confidence in the system at the moment. And in order to regain this trust, I call on the European Commission to come up with a proposal on how we could set up a single European supervisor who is completely independent of any car manufacturer. Let this suspicion be here, which I, and perhaps many, have, disappear.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Bieńkowska, unfortunately, the issue of measuring the level of emissions in the car sector poses an undeserved question mark on the automotive industry in Europe as a whole. We call on the Commission to immediately launch a comprehensive investigation programme at European Union level to identify the defeat devices used on vehicles sold in Europe, regardless of the brand or fuel used.  In addition, in order to ensure the smooth functioning of the vehicle testing system in the future, we establish an independent approval authority to supervise testing and to ensure that new diesel cars operating in Europe meet the conditions laid down in 2007.  I would like to ask the Commission what measures are envisaged together with the companies concerned to compensate or compensate those bona fide consumers who purchased these so-called clean machines. In addition, what will be the penalties applicable to producers and the measures for their implementation, given that the provisions of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 have been infringed? These penalties should be effective, appropriate and dissuasive. Also, if any Director within the Commission intended to take responsibility for this failure that we have experienced in Europe and if these things have happened, it would be good, Commissioner, to make them public.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Madam President, today in the European Parliament we are having a complex debate on the very serious situation of the Volkswagen scandal. Any infringement by any body must be investigated with all legal consequences. At the moment, an internal and mainly external investigation is underway, including investigations by law enforcement authorities. It is in the interest of the Volkswagen Group to explain everything as credibly as possible and, above all, it is entirely up to it to regain its lost customer trust. It is important to monitor this process and to wait for the conclusions of the investigation, including the opinion of the German authority, which is also alleged to be dealing with this, as it is also its responsibility. It is important for us as the European Parliament that people on the European market do not lose confidence in functioning consumer protection. On the other hand, it is important for us to understand exactly what actually happened and why. After examination, it is necessary to consider whether the measurement system is set up correctly and whether even the adoption of some extreme, hard regulatory limits does not cause circumvention and encourage it. I believe that it would be very unfortunate to draw quick conclusions without knowing the facts. We could very much damage the entire car industry, which is not only the driver of the European economy, but also the engine of technological progress in many areas.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this scandal is of course an embarrassment for all European institutions. All the signs were there, but we have been dragging our feet and the story is very old.  Actually, it is an interesting case of past dependency on engine factories. The first turbocharged direct injection (TDI) engine was presented in 1989. The second TDI engine, which ought to have met our standards, was presented in 2008 but it did not reach the standard. So the TDI technology is not able to solve the problems, and that is going to be a huge problem for Volkswagen in the future. But that is not the full story. During the past 10 years the discrepancy between test results and the real world has been increasing. We know that the European car industry is still a big, important job creator and a driver of economy, but it needs also to be a driver of ecology.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it would be very naïve to think that a giant such as Volkswagen has decided to risk ruin with this fraud without being able to count on vast high complicity in Germany and Europe. For example, everyone knows, as even the Volkswagen summits knew, that the European Commission, so inflexible in imposing the rules of austerity on governments, when it comes to detecting violations of standards by large groups, willingly turns a blind eye or even both.  I am one of the millions of customers scammed by Volkswagen and, after your speech, Commissioner, I no longer feel protected at all. You assure us that in the future you will do the checks that you have not done in the past and we have heard this many times. The truth is that you continue to delegate the role of controllers to the controllers. To give another example: in Italy you rely on anti-Mafia self-certifications, which have been the basis of a robbery of European funds for decades, as everyone knows. Do we have to wait every time for an American university, a European magistrate, to do the work that you should do first?

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The VW scandal is a triple scandal. Firstly, VW's fraud. Secondly, German authorities, which protect the fraudsters for 18 months, and thirdly, an EU Commission that had information and did not take action. And we can now quickly restore confidence, including by Parliament's amendment to the Dess report to improve the test cycle quickly, starting in 2017 with a correlation factor of 1. In the Council, the mood is more in favour of this amendment. And what is the Commission doing today? Today, within the framework of comitology, the Commission has tried to torpedo this good proposal from Parliament, which may have a majority in the Council, by putting a correlation factor of 1.6 on the table. They really are not making good policy with it. The Eu Commission should now work with us to restore confidence.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the car causes six million deaths a year worldwide and more than 16 million people have been injured. If it was a disease, we would have already raised the money to eradicate it.  We must stop giving the car the privileged position it has had so far. With these words Beppe Grillo, who for more than twenty years in his shows transmits information on alternative technologies to that of the combustion engine, commented on the Volkswagen scandal suggesting that the problem is not limited to the individual car manufacturer, but is a problem related to the very concept of the car. What is a car at the end of the day? She is a 110-year-old woman who has done about twenty facelifts, but inside it continues to remain a four-wheeled stove, always quoting the co-founder of the 5 Star Movement.  We need to learn something important from this scandal. Those who are called upon to legislate must stop getting their jackets pulled from the oil lobbies, a difficulty can be turned into an opportunity if we only have the courage to do so. The green light is therefore clear for the sharing economy and for public transport, possibly free of charge in urban areas.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning of September, the revelation of Volkswagen's fraud stunned both sides of the Atlantic. Diesel cars marketed in the United States emitted 5 to 35 times more nitrogen dioxide than the rate allowed by U.S. standards.  The issue is addressed only from an ideological and environmental point of view, whereas it is primarily a technical issue. I would like to recall a basic law of thermodynamics: any combustion causes emissions, everything is only proportional to the different gases emitted, but pollution remains. A technical precision: to make more efficient engines, you have to increase the rate of combustion in the cylinders. As a result, the vehicle uses less fuel per kilometre, releases less oil that is badly burned and gains acceleration.  Volkswagen diesel engines no longer produce carbon monoxide, which is beneficial for health and the environment, but a lot of nitrogen oxides, which is more critical, of course. This gets to the heart of the problem, because carbon monoxide turned nitrogen dioxide into simple nitrogen, which is a perfectly harmless gas. The father of modern chemistry, Lavoisier, said 250 years ago: "Nothing is lost, nothing is created, everything is transformed".  What are Volkswagen's wrongs? The fault of its engineers was to produce powerful engines producing low carbon dioxide and a lot of nitrogen dioxide, when they claimed otherwise.  From a legal point of view, it is a big scandal, but from an environmental point of view, what they have done is neutral. U.S. standards are impossible to meet for small cars and have not been set to protect the environment but to undermine the irresistible rise of the European Volkswagen Group, which in July 2015 became the world's leading manufacturer.  In short, Volkswagengate is an outstalring of the economic war waged by the United States and a sector of European industry. The analysis must therefore be technical, even chemical and strategic. The environmental aspect here is only a tool in the service of antagonistic powers. The environment is a lever for 21st century protectionism. Europeans must get rid of all naivety in this area. This is particularly urgent in view of the COP 21 in Paris in December.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European emissions tests are wrong. In the context of the mid-term review of the 2011 Transport White Paper, we have already made this clear and made a number of proposals for improvement. It must indeed be better and more independent. But Mr President, if companies are deliberately intent on fraud, then no politician can compete with that. I think we should say the same thing here today. The Commissioner has clearly used the word fraud.  It is important that we get these emission tests in real driving conditions as soon as possible. All the proposals for this will be welcomed by all the proposals, especially to our colleagues in the Committee on the Environment. But Mr President, we should not be blaming this afternoon alone. We're not going to get there by accusing us alone. Peter Liese has already spoken about the employees of the car industry, who are in danger of becoming innocent of this. Solving problems and not unnecessarily damaging the car industry will also be our task in the near future.  Then perhaps, Mr President, let's take a moment to see how the relationship with TTIP is. TTIP talks a lot about testing cars. Maybe it's helpful to take a very good look at that chapter. The Americans are testing the cars themselves. What's happened now comes from the Environmental Protection Agency. We test the cars too, but then paid again. Both methods are therefore, I think, not wise and susceptible to improvement. (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Actually, it is not a question, but a request that I would like to make, because I am pleased that Mr Member, who is the Coordinator of the People's Party in the Committee on Transport, mentioned his workers to the car industry. As a Hungarian, I would like to ask you that the People's Party should take part in a joint programme to save workers in the automotive industry. Hungary 8% of its GDP and the employment of tens of thousands of people if Volkswagen is to make redundancies as a result of the current scandal. Can the People's Party faction and you, as a Member, support such an initiative?

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, in Dutch politics we have the saying 'You have to sweep the stairs from above'. So I very much agree with my colleague from Hungary. The guilty must be punished. Serious mistakes have been made here. Let's not justify it. But volkswagen's ordinary worker with dozens of factories in many European countries must not fall victim to this.

name: Ismail Ertug (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is undeniable that what has happened cannot be excused. However, I would also like to point out that we should refrain from bringing the whole industry into disrepute now, because – as has already been mentioned – millions of people earn their daily bread. Nevertheless, I believe that this scandal must be a prelude to measures that have not yet been capable of winning a majority. I want to make a list. Firstly, I believe that random tests must be carried out for vehicles that have already been registered. That is crucial. Secondly, the principle of the real driving emission test must be introduced, because I do not think it can be explained that laboratory values are more or less decisive and that the actual real exhaust emissions are not taken into account. It would also contribute to the protection of the air and the environment and would benefit consumers through greater transparency. I am still thinking of more Europe in networking the competent authorities. This scandal may be a prelude to the integration of the automotive industry in Europe to invest in new technologies such as storage technology, hybrid technology, etc. However, I would like to put one question to the European Commission in conclusion: there are voices that speak of the fact that the German authorities and the German Ministry of Transport have been aware of such practices for some time. Does your institution intend to investigate these indications?

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this is an ongoing issue. We do not know how big it is or how far it will spread and we need to be clear what went wrong before proposing new legislation. We should not be too hasty here. But one thing is clear – even if our air is not anymore – and that is that huge damage has been done to consumer trust. Millions of consumers have been misled. Many chose diesel models specifically for their lower emissions and for their fuel efficiency. They have been treated with contempt and now face recalls, inconvenience and increased running costs as a result. We know that manufacturers have been gaming the test for some time. We know that the tests are not up to scratch, and consumers know the manufacturers’ claims do not stack up either. And the Commission now is working on new testing legislation, which we are looking forward to seeing, but this should not be sneaked through in delegated acts. It needs proper parliamentary scrutiny. The issue is too big to do anything otherwise. In this House we are constantly told, by those who do not like the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement, that the US is some sort of regulatory Wild West where anything goes and there are no rules at all. Yet it was the US regulators that found this, not the Europeans. Why were our regulators asleep at the wheel? Maybe we should start looking to the US for help on this. This scandal resonates across the Atlantic and it also shows the need for regulatory coherence, which is a key part of TTIP. One final plea here: let us find out what happened before rushing into legislation. That is the only way we will get better legislation. Please, can the Commission not use this to justify another power grab?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we all know that this is an unprecedented scandal which needs to be investigated: that is something that we will agree on. We clearly also know that we will have to have a thorough investigation. There is one under way in Germany, and the Commission will do its work. We will want to be informed, and we will want to be informed in detail. It is a question that Parliament has to be engaged in. We should focus on what was to be implemented, what was to be enforced, what has not been enforced and, of course, how the legislation should eventually be changed. In this respect, Madam Commissioner, I would have expected you today, or hopefully in the near future, to be somewhat more concrete. We will need to change the system and I think it is worthwhile looking into how exactly to be decisive, and to be very concrete. You have mentioned that you will tell us what you have been doing in the past 10 days. I would wonder what the Commission has been doing since the time of the first suspicion, since the first communication and, of course, your communication. In this respect I think that we will want to be informed in detail, and we will look into the papers made available. A final remark – just one sentence: industry, of course, is already affected, and everything that we do we should do in such a way as to minimise that effect.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: Commissioner, I have listened to you very carefully. In September you declared ignorance of the Volkswagen scandal and announced, as you do today, zero tolerance for fraud and strict compliance with European rules. But you did not say anything about the cover-up, so let me remind you that in the Commission you were aware of the problem of falsification of results since 2011. You admit it in November 2012 and you invoke the launch of a real-world driving test process from January 2011. In November 2013, Parliament's competent committee, ITRE, speaks clearly in a report on consumer fraud, and calls on you to immediately introduce real-world testing. In the same year, your Joint Research Centre clearly informed you of the possibility of carrying out this fraud.  So consciously, and in favour of certain European car manufacturers, you have ignored all the recommendations. You have consciously chosen to freeze the procedure and cover up and, because, in this way, you have avoided proper controls, you have the main responsibility for not complying with the conditions in the Community subsidies given to the cars in dispute.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I must admit that I was appalled by your intervention. With the Volkswagen scandal, we are here in the face of a health and environmental crime, we are here in front of an organized gang scam, we are here in the face of tax evasion and, basically, you are not proposing anything serious. If you want to regain the trust of the Europeans, you must of course check all the national authorities where the collusion of states and the car industry is proven. If you want to regain the confidence of the Europeans, you must of course get out of the diesel from the moment it is shown that diesel is a major factor in the death of tens of thousands of Europeans. If you want to win the trust of Europeans, stop working on European lies.  We set targets and the European Commission, together with the car manufacturers, organises the flexibilities, organises a total disconnect between what is promised to the Europeans and what is done in reality. So, ma'am, if you want to reassure them, work, but work hard.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite legislative efforts, the air quality of European cities continues to deteriorate, claimed hundreds of thousands of avoidable victims, as the European Environment Agency says.  The Volkswagen scandal has answered what is a paradox. Air quality is getting worse simply because emission limits are not being met. But who should have prevented this from happening? The Commission recalls the exclusive role of the Member States in the type-approval of engines and in the carrying out of checks. Yet as early as 2011, as has been mentioned, the Joint Research Centre at Ispra had highlighted how much the limits were higher – of NOX in particular – than those declared and also highlighted how portable detectors were able to reduce the risk of using tools that could distort data.  The Commission knew, it also knew why in a 2014 presentation one of its officials spoke precisely about the existence of these devices. We have no choice but to ask ourselves at this point whether the Commission was aware of volkswagen's fraud, and what other car manufacturers are using this device and what it has done to prevent what has happened.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too have tabled a parliamentary question on this subject, which I believe is of fundamental importance because of its impact on consumer protection, respect for the environment, the protection of human health and the very serious damage in the image of the European business system and the car industry in particular.  That is why we must immediately ascertain who is responsible and therefore impose the necessary sanctions, even if, as has been said on several sides, it is truly paradoxical that all this has been found in the United States and not in Europe, but we must also understand what the European Commission has done in recent years, and whether what has been the subject of journalistic deepening is true and not only , that is, that some Bodies of the European Commission have been aware since 2013 of the existence of software, it tools used by some car manufacturers in order to alter the results of analyses of pollutants from diesel engines. If this were to be true, as I think is absolutely true, it would be another extremely serious element which requires the identification of those responsible and their exemplary punishment.  That is why – and I am about to conclude – I hope that the necessary antibodies can be identified and that the rules system can be changed in order to prevent this from happening in the future, through, for example, the modification of the emission detection system, no longer laboratory but on the street.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, now we have it in black and white that at least one car manufacturer toyed with the air people breathe. For me it is evident that the tests we have in place to measure emissions are not working, and independent testing of cars in real driving conditions is required.  There are two issues which until now have been given very little importance, particularly since the Commissioner spoke about sanctions. First, employees: this scandal might put jobs at risk, and employees should not be the ones to shoulder the responsibility. Second: consumers, who paid for cars, believing that they did not emit more than what was promised, are not the ones to blame, nor should they be the ones suffering the consequences.  I urge the Commission to keep in mind both employees and consumers to ensure that neither one nor the other will end up paying the price. I would like to know what the Commission intends to do in this regard.  (Applause)

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: Mr President, 'Made in Germany' is now an infected concept and the underlying question is: is that fair business actually exists? How many times have we seen companies commit fraud and double standards. Of course, the Commissioner must now adapt the emission measurements quickly. But Beetle Gate is mostly a reminder to companies to do honest business. We are now seeing the fatal effect of fraud at Volkswagen, which may even go bankrupt. And the entire car industry and the German business community are now infected. Even the government is smeared because the president of Lower Saxony sits on the supervisory board at Volkswagen. "Made in Germany" must again be "Honest and reliable", with a government remote that can give an independent verdict. This should also apply to "Made in Holland" and "Made in Europe". Anyone who thinks they're standing firm should be careful not to fall. That biblical wisdom, Mr President, applies to all of us.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE).
text: Mr President, a lot has been said. I would like to dwell on two points.  Today, in the name of the principle of subsidiarity, it is clear that Member States have full latitude in the implementation of tests, that a model tested in one state applies to all other States and that sanctions are, moreover, not mandatory and make only fairly light recommendations. In short, we defined the standards and then abandoned them to the Member States.  On the other hand, while we had known for a long time that the testing conditions on the bench were not valid — we had known this since 2007 — we waited and postponed to 2017, that is, ten years later, our ability to improve things. I wanted to make a second point. I have heard colleagues marvel at American controls. I will simply point out that, in another system, the American financial controls imposed more than 70 billion fines on our own financial officers after being responsible for the 2008 crisis and sending us the subprimes. So beware.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, it seems that the European Commission has already known since 2011 that emission controls on Volkswagen cars did not show reliable figures and no one has acted to prevent it. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a shameful new scandal, already known as Dieselgate, which cannot be left as a mere remedy or a sanction on the irresponsible automotive industry, its lobbies, and also, why not say so, its institutional trainers. The case of Volkswagen fraud is yet another example of the crisis in the productive, energy and transport model that undermines the ecological foundations of our survival, violates our rights as consumers, costs hundreds of thousands of jobs and , why hide it – also the lives of hundreds of Europeans because of pollution. We are going to demand responsibility for this and all the corruption cases that have shaken and shaken this rapacious capitalism that most of you continue to support in this House.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, we must face up to the true values of the car manufacturers. The case of manipulated engines was not only a one-off stumble, but also highlighted their general attitude. Allow me to give you a concrete example of what I am talking about. One of the world's largest engine factories is located in Hungary. Audi produces engines here, including some two million tricky units that the Volkswagen group recently unveiled. The factory did not have sufficient capacity, so Audi was committed to expanding and looking at a Natura 2000 site as a site. Given that Audi accounts for nearly 10% of Hungarian GDP, it has not encountered much regulatory resistance. One civilian environmentalist questioned the legality of the investment. He was initially tried out of court by Audi, then trickily brought to justice and sent to prison. Since then, the innocent Audi has been found to have produced millions of cheating engines, the Natura 2000 site has been destroyed, compensatory measures have failed, the court has sentenced Ferenc Bag to three years in prison, and Audi and Volkswagen remain the proud owners of the European environmental management standard ISO 14001. Commissioner, I ask you, for how long?

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: We are all listening - I hope the Commissioner is listening because she is talking to her staff member, but perhaps the President can draw her attention to this - still a little in shock - good afternoon, the Commissioner - about what has happened, but it is time to learn from this now. There are, Commissioner, colleagues, two things that we need to do now, and most of them have already been mentioned. I would like to emphasise to them very strongly: an independent European audit that monitors the matter. We all know that the type-approval is done by national authorities and that this is a cheese with holes. That has to stop. That's where we need to intervene. I think most of us agree on that. It doesn't have to cost a lot of money. There is no need for a new European agency. Contrary. This is a question of political will, and we can put it in order in a relatively quick way.  Secondly - as the Commissioner referred to it in her introduction - this new test method must be introduced quickly. The Commissioner has said that we will agree with that. In 2017, emissions tests should be operational in real driving conditions. That is a good thing. I think we all support that. That is going to be a tough business for the car manufacturers, we know that, but I think we have no choice now. It is high time to take a fundamental step forward. Then there are the diesels. There is a lot of criticism of the diesels. I don't think the diesels need disappear from our streets at all. On the contrary, this is important European technology that we should not be throwing away at the right. But this is the ultimate unique moment to make diesels cleaner and clean technology. Now is the time to do that.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as far as Volkswagen means in terms of image and numbers, it is clear that the damage done to the credibility of the European industrial system goes beyond the damage done to the car manufacturer.  Consumer confidence has been betrayed by unfair practice, if not by out-of-pocket fraud and a chain of ineffective controls. That is why today the European institutions must give impartial and firm answers that will restore consumer confidence. Regaining credibility means strengthening the rules of the internal market with higher common standards and more effective control systems, clarifying national and Community competences.  This also reminds us of the need and urgency to have European legislation that guarantees us on the quality and safety of products and, finally, how it is necessary to achieve, beyond bilateral treaties, real regulatory cooperation at least with our most important trading partners.

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR).
text: Mr President! I can't figure out what's embarrassing: that a manufacturer like Volkswagen markets itself as environmentally friendly and turns out to be a lie, or that it's the Americans who expose that fraud. The EU system has certainly spent a lot of euros, millions of euros, in the name of the environment, but for what good? Volkswagen bosses are rewarded with large redundancy payments and consumers pay. The established EU system has failed. Consumers in the European Union have been deceived and there are only losers in this case. The only winners are the bosses who get their thick severance payments. But what about the future? How can we control the cars? Should a "travel team" be set up to control all cars? Which manufacturers can keep to the figures they give? I don't think anyone can do that. If it turns out that the Commission has known, then surely it must also have consequences, and heads must roll.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Volkswagen has cheated, cheated against the law, cheated on consumers, of course, and the implications in Europe, the largest market for diesel, are not yet known. A lot has already been said this afternoon. Beyond the legal and technical aspects, which, of course, have been widely discussed, I also have the impression that the Volkswagen case must make us think about the car model we want for the Europe of tomorrow. The current situation is not sustainable. We will probably have to admit one day that we cannot continue to promise ever bigger, ever more powerful vehicles that, at the same time, are constantly polluting less. Just a number in that regard. In Belgium alone, the number of REGISTRATIONs of SUV vehicles increased fivefold between 2000 and 2013 So, beyond a revised law that requires, it has been said, real-world testing, strict and independent controls to be enforced everywhere, I wonder if the question today is not whether we are not approaching a kind of new paradigm, a paradigm shift. Technology has limits and pollute less, it is also for the driver to consume the road differently. Incidentally, this is also what victims' parents' associations advocate with the Lisa Charter, such as Light and Safe.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, 'in Volkswagen we are not content to build cars with less CO2, we have developed a global attitude towards ecological sustainability'. This is what Volkswagen's website says today. Not only have they been violating European polluting emissions legislation since 2008, but they also boast otherwise sell sustainability and respect for the environment and, now that scandal threatens to reduce the benefits of their managers, they are acting with blackmail and threats about their production in Europe.  What is at stake at the moment is whether the European Commission is going to take strong action or whether, on the contrary, the European Commission will continue to act as dictated by the lobists of the automotive industry, placing its interests above our health and that of the planet. Make no mistake: the European Commission was aware of what was going on and has been covering it up. A commission of inquiry has to come out of here today for all companies because maybe it's not just Volkswagen. Otherwise, if this commission of inquiry is not created, the message that is sent is that the great ones, that the powerful, that German multinationals do not have to comply with the law.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Volkswagen case was uncovered by the US authorities, but let us imagine for a minute that it had been disclosed by a whistle—blower or an independent researcher. They would most likely have come into conflict with the law. Criminalisation of firmware analysis enables dark secrets to stay in the dark for too long. It is not enough to just strengthen our testing authorities. We must allow researchers, consumer organisations, hackers and even competitors to analyse the firmware deployed on end-user goods, be this your car, your coffee machine or your pacemaker. The US Environmental Protection Agency is now investigating, but it has in the past argued before the US Copyright Office not to allow the circumvention of technological protection in cars. Volkswagen itself sold millions of cars which could be opened by anyone who had a fake remote key. In 2013, Volkswagen was alerted and then went after the researchers, preventing them from publishing their security-relevant findings because they were disclosing trade secrets. So, dear colleagues, let us be very careful when negotiating the Trade Secrets Directive in trilogue not to include new lines of defence for Volkswagen’s dirty secrets.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I believe that this is quite a serious scandal. Unlike the Commissioner, I do not think that this scandal is limited to one firm, nor is it a scandal about diesel engines. This is a scandal about the credibility and the reputation of European regulation. For many years, we have accepted the manipulation of the measurement of official consumption – the consumption that is used for the purposes of regulation, for tax authorities and for consumers. We have also known about it from other sources, for example from the Mind the Gap report that was published in 2013. As a consequence, we were running a higher health risk and we forced consumers to accept higher running costs for their cars. So what should we do about it? First of all, I believe that we should consider introducing a new standard created by the United Nations – called the Worldwide Harmonised Light Vehicle Testing Procedure (WLTP) – maybe sooner than the end of 2017, at least as an alternative measure of consumption. At the same time, we must be quite sure that there will be no manipulation of the test and that the cars that are used are the same as those being driven by consumers. Generally speaking, we should improve regulations and the enforcement of regulations and ensure the consistency of policy. If we opt for regulation – and I do not think we should do this as often as we have done in the past – we should insist on it being complied with and not undermine or question the regulation, except in the case of cheating. Lastly, let me mention consistency. If we believe that diesel engines can be more dangerous to health, I am still puzzled as to why we are supporting diesel cars with the low cost of diesel. When I look at the data for many Member States, diesel is 20—28% percent cheaper than petrol, and only a few Member States have roughly the same prices.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this scandal has created, in addition to harm to citizens and the environment, a great crisis of confidence in our laws, European laws that have seemed as severe as they can be circumvented by our citizens, and also, of course, a crisis of confidence in the industrial system, at a time when we are relaunching, as the Commission and Parliament , with great effort all the productive activity.  We must therefore quickly regain this confidence in European laws, in their effectiveness, in the control that they must have. We will support the programme that you have presented to us, Commissioner. This scandal, however, must not be the reason for lowering the level of quality, the level of certainty of our standards for which Europe is a leader. So, more quality, more rigor, more control.  In this regard, I would like to say that consumer protection also involves certainty of rules, control and completeness of information, and in this regard I would remind you of the regulation on product safety, which also contains the 'made in', a certainty of where products are made, of the rules that accompany them and that it is another means of giving consumers more confidence. , and I say this to you, Commissioner, because I know your attention and your commitment to these dossiers.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We all agree here that the Volkswagen scandal is huge, we all agree that those who have led to it should suffer the consequences and the legal consequences, because the law has been broken, not only German law, but also European law. But this is also about the real effectiveness of European climate policy: all the biggest proponents of decarbonising the economy are precisely responsible for this scandal. And the question arises: why, why was this scandal detected in the United States? Dear Commissioner, does there not have a suitable office in Germany to deal with these matters? And if it is, what did this office do or did not do? Does the Commissioner have such knowledge? It would be good for us to know that.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the Volkswagen scandal has brought air quality and environmental issues into the debate in a whole new way. It is not a question of more or less than human health. Environmental legislation is enacted to protect people.  In addition to car manufacturers, the finger of blame shows inadequate control. The problems of measurements have been overlooked in Europe. The European Commission and national authorities have at least suspected that the results of the tests have not corresponded to reality. However, nothing has been done. The Commission has ignored international environmental agreements, nor about compliance with the EU's own legislation. I hope that will change now.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you said at the beginning of your speech that there is only one company that has defrauded in Europe. How do you know? How can we know that no serious investigation has been carried out and alerts have been issued for years without anything happening?  Commissioner, do you think it is enough for a CEO to come and make amends, take a few million on one side and then say, ''Move around, there is nothing to see'? Now, let's look to the future: how do you want to solve the questions that arise? You must defend the general European interest. The general European interest is like democracy, it is more transparency, it is fighting conflicts of interest. We need to separate controls from car manufacturers and from oil or state interests.  The first action to be taken by your Commission, Commissioner, is to ensure that an independent European authority, financed by European funds, can control. It is about the health of 500 million consumers.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – In Europe, we have achieved enormous results in making cars cleaner. Euro 6 is the cleanest engine ever. Our air quality has already improved enormously. We have always wanted to take into account the environment, employment and health. And now we've been duped. This time it's about the Volkswagen and the software fraud. But what about the actual emissions of, among other things. American and Asian cars? This also needs to be investigated. In Europe, before the current scandal, we always wanted to know emissions in real driving conditions. That is why the Commission has been working on the bill on emissions in real driving conditions for some time. Our distrust of emissions measurements is now clear. Therefore, an accelerated and mandatory introduction of the RDE method is necessary. Measuring in real driving conditions, no phased introduction until November 2017 and the introduction date of the euro 6c standard but via an accelerated route, actually as early as 2016.  So on the road! From the laboratory! New portable PEM measurement systems make it possible to measure the exhaust, so that the EU resumes its leading role, even before the introduction of the UN WLTP testing procedure. We have to do this ourselves in Europe. Measuring is knowing. Mr President, that is why the creation of a single central European testing authority is necessary. European monitoring of implementation in national test centres. We must prevent a trade war to the detriment of European car makers. Our car production stands for craftsmanship and quality worldwide, also for environmental quality. Practicality is of course important, but speeding up is essential. All sectors must contribute to reducing emissions. It is about nitrogen and public health, and in addition to the common cow, the sacred cow should certainly not be missing.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we now know that up to half of the savings that we have seen – apparent savings that we have seen – in emissions from cars have come from faulty testing, which means of course in effect that half the saving has not actually existed. This is a terrible indictment on the systems that we have in place. Of course it is unfair on consumers, but it is also unfair on policymakers because we have to rely on the facts in order to make the laws that we put forward. I am very confused by some of the comments I have heard – particularly from my conservative opponents – stating that they recognise the problem that we are all talking about, but they do not want to put the tools in place to actually deal with it. It is absolutely incumbent on the Commission to act at European level, because we have to take European action in order to hold individual countries’ industries to account. We need independent testing; we need in-use surveillance testing; and we need real-driving emission (RDE) standards as part of that. We cannot wait any longer. Commissioner, forgive me, but I do not feel a sense of urgency from you yet. We need that urgency.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that citizens – at least in Germany – are far less interested in the question of how emissions are measured and what impact this has on the environment, but rather in the question: what is actually with VW now? What about VW, this wavering giant? What about the enterprise, which has been a kind of driving force for German industry and now suddenly seems to be on very clay feet, with a fall in the stock markets of 43% of pre-crisis value? The question is, what if such a large company may now get into serious trouble? What if VW goes bankrupt, with more than a quarter of a million jobs, plus suppliers, more than half a million jobs? The question then arises, how will this be responded to? What I personally do not want is that it is suddenly the taxpayer who has to help VW out of trouble. I think we need to think about the fact that, as with the banks, we are also creating a kind of reciprocal hedging for large industrial companies.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz (PPE).
text: Mr President, old friend, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has I am pleased to be able to speak here today on this subject. The facts are well known. I have been involved in this issue for 25 years and sometimes See the division of responsibilities, the criticism somewhat differently. Earlier, someone said: yes, when will the Commission first take action? The Commission can only take action as far as the Council follows Parliament and the Commission. I very much regret, Mr President, that the Council is once again not here today, because, in the case of type-approval over the last twenty years, the Council – including my own country – has always blocked, postponed, ripped and used all the other tricks of the world to avoid reaching a result or a holey cheese. That is what we have now, and that is our problem. The Commission will still be biting its teeth. I therefore believe that the points that have been written down and presented are very important. Rapid and complete enlightenment, no question at all; strict control. But at this moment we are working on the new type cycle data, and that is exactly where errors are blocked. You have to take a close look. There is a coefficient – the Commission says that we are taking one, and that the car industry wants to have a different one for each individual company, yes, that is also a Swiss cheese. We need to work much more this. I believe that the Council really must be held accountable here. We are currently negotiating a NEC directive. The NEC directive is not about CO2, but about the air quality of cities. And that is precisely where we have done the citizens a disservice by letting eight million cars with the wrong data drive through the area. I would ask all colleagues to be involved in this issue with the NEC, and this is about the NOX values, and to develop feasible but strict regulations. The car industry needs to change from the ground up, and nothing will be the same again than it was a month ago.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, for the past 20 years, the European Union has been constantly strengthening its standards for road vehicle emissions to combat the scourge of air pollution and to try to stem climate change, but emissions levels remain above current standards. This is a reality that can no longer be denied. We have a political but also moral responsibility to act to stop this. For too long, the European Union has turned a blind eye to the flaws in pollution tests that do not reflect the actual emission conditions. The Volkswagen scandal reveals a biased and obsolete system.  Diesel must no longer be encouraged and European manufacturers must change their production to stay in the race. Last June, the Socialists of the Committee on Transport and Tourism had already taken the initiative to table amendments in favour of pollution tests carried out in real conditions.
