Commissioner, where is the work in the Commission to get these new tests into force as soon as possible? Can you assure us that these tests will be as cumbersome as possible? Is the Commission finally considering the creation of an autonomous European Air Protection Agency for the control of pollutant emissions? The public interest must guide our action and the Socialists will remain vigilant and mobilised for the Commission to respond.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In my opinion, this is not just a scandal concerning one major car company. This is not an individual fraud, it is a scandal concerning the regulatory power of the European Union, its climate policy. Many citizens have long been convinced that the Union applies double criteria – in the case of the car industry it applies looser criteria than other industries, that it looks through its fingers at environmental pollution caused by the car industry. Yet the transport sector in the Union emits a quarter of all greenhouse gases and more than two thirds of these emissions come from road transport.  Volkswagen's fraud confirms these concerns. This scam was made possible by inef-effective tests. Test requirements should be tightened up. An important tool in achieving this goal is to measure actual emissions during the operation of the vehicle. A comprehensive inspection of the entire automotive market should be carried out and a total ban on the production and use of diesel engines must be considered in the future.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union has an ambitious goal of 20% of our gross domestic product by 2020 coming from industry. We also have the goal—as it could not be otherwise—to reduce CO2 emissions. To achieve these objectives, we need to improve our competitiveness. And, in order to improve our competitiveness, reforms are key, both at national and European level. No one doubts either that, in order to achieve this ambitious 20% target, the automotive industry is key, and within the automotive industry, I believe that no one in this Chamber doubts that Volkswagen is key. Because Volkswagen has almost five hundred thousand workers in the European Union, many of them in Spain, many of them in my region, in Navarra. Therefore, further research is key. We have to investigate and get to where it is necessary, we have to go as far as we need to go, but it is also important, ladies and gentlemen, not to prejudge. It is also key not to reach pre-set or hasty conclusions. It is key to be cautious with un baseless speculation. Ladies and gentlemen, the prestige and reputation of European industry are at risk, this key to achieving the long-awaited 20% target. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, I appeal to everyone's responsibility. It's a lot at stake. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" question. – Those who put European industry at risk are the ones who manipulate, they are the ones who lie, they are the ones who misrepresent the accounts, they are the ones who have set up precisely this plot. It's Volkswagen. It is the managers who are really jeopardizing the company and the jobs, not only in Navarra, but in the whole of Europe.  Its head of government, Mr Rajoy, said that the investment of Volkswagen's 4.2 billion was beneficial for Spain. You're going to ask and you're going to demand that Minister Soria demand Volkswagen do what he had to do?

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Urbán, no one has said otherwise. If you had read the press, you would have seen that the Minister of Industry, Mr Soria, has demanded responsibilities and asked to go all the way to the end of this matter. But I too, Mr Urbán, would encourage you to worry about those five hundred thousand workers in Europe, and many of them , as I said - in Spain, many of them in Catalonia and many of them in Navarra, who are the ones that we all have to worry about here.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his The Volkswagen scandal must be investigated to the bottom. It is important that this signal be made clear to the Commission. Those who have manipulated the tests have not only deceived us and the system, but they have misled citizens, which has also put people's health at risk. At the same time, it is important that you take note of the message from this House that we also review the tests as a whole, because we need to have sharper opportunities at European level to ensure that the tests are complied with, work and become sharper. We must also learn from what the US does better and from the way they do tests in reality. Moreover, their authorities have stronger financial muscle, and they have tougher sanctions when the tests have not worked. We also need independent testing in the type-approval process. At present, car manufacturers contract companies to conduct laboratory tests. They are not independent. Bring these messages from us.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I have been driving a diesel-powered car for many years, and I intend to drive a diesel car in the next few years. After all, diesel is an environmentally friendly technology that leads to low emissions of pollutants, and I think that, despite the real scandal, we must not let diesel technology be badly talked about either. The VW scandal is a major scandal. Fraud in the conduct of the test procedures is totally unacceptable. Manipulation is unacceptable, and there is no doubt that full information must be carried out so that this does not happen again. However, I would also like to say that we must be careful not to discredit an entire industry. The automotive industry is home to hundreds of thousands of jobs across Europe. Many colleagues have pointed this out. That is why I simply ask for a differentiated approach. In addition to VW, other cars were also tested in the USA at the time, all of which passed the tests. So it's not that bad. What should be done now? Well, a procedure that is being tested on the test bench is currently required, and for many years, as Far as I know, we have been considering further developing this test procedure so that the tests can also achieve more real values on the road. I therefore believe that this test procedure must now be developed at great speed. And I would also like to put my question to the Commission, so that I can be told why all this takes so long, how long it will take, and what possibilities the Commission has for getting to grips with this more quickly. I believe that people in Europe are waiting for there to be testing procedures here that really correspond to the real situation on the road. That is why I would ask you to do everything possible to implement this as soon as possible. We have good cars that are produced here in Europe, which are internationally competitive, and we must not let that be ruined. It should be noted that scandals must be resolved.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. There has been a lot of talk today, and also in recent days, about VW's fraud. However, I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the confidence of the employees – almost 600 000 employees of the group worldwide – has been abused by the company's top management. Almost all of them may not have known about this manipulation, and yet their jobs may now be under threat. It is precisely in their interests that the Group has a responsibility, but also the duty, to clarify now. Transparent enlightenment is one thing. VW can also regain confidence, for example, by supporting the preparation and implementation of the new emissions tests itself. For the European car industry as a whole, I also think it is certainly important to focus more on innovative and sustainable drives. In fact, the Asian and, above all, the American manufacturers still have a very large lead in this respect. This should be part of a strategy that safeguards jobs in Europe.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The European automotive industry is a success story. Production and subcontracting create millions of jobs in Eastern Europe, southern Europe, the Czech Republic, France, Germany. European diesel technology is a success story, innovation, CO2 reduction, economy, longevity – the environment and customers benefit. But where there is light, there is also shadow. VW has deceived customers. We must clarify and sanction this, no doubt at all. But please, let's not throw the baby out with the bathwater! We are talking about fraud, not even stricter emission standards, which would not survive large parts of the European car industry. It is a question of realistic measurement methods; it is not a question of banning successful and economical diesel technology. Let us also take a look at the United States: it is clear that the US authorities have known about illegal practices for some time. Why now that the new Passat was on the verge of shaking up the US market? And why, when they care so much about the environment, aren't the US problematizing the US trucks, these gigantic nitric oxide slingshots? So, ladies and gentlemen, let us clarify, create transparency, but not place an entire industry under general suspicion! The employees and their families did not deserve this. This does not do justice to the outstanding ecological advances of the automotive industry.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, three messages: responsibility, rectification and trust. We must demand responsibility, but we must demand it from those who have it: to the managers of the company who modified the production systems to lower costs and increase profits, other than now with sanctions, which have to be fair and balanced, let us put the company and workers in a bind. Today we have already announced that Volkswagen paralyzes all investments, which has nailed workers and also casts the shadow of doubt on its own viability, while giving itself the paradox that, for example, the manager who allowed this production fraud to leave the company with thousands of euros of compensation. Responsibility, who has it.  Rectification, to whom it may: to the Commission, which may amend the regulation so that the new checks are carried out on actual driving tests. We urgently need it to regain trust.  And trust, too, for the industry as a whole, which represents twelve million jobs, which must also have the encouragement of the Commission and the parliamentary institutions today so as not to sow doubts in the European industry as a whole. An industry that is exemplary, as I say, with twelve million jobs. It is also the responsibility of the European Commission to restore confidence to the automotive industry as a whole.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, volkswagen's emissions scam is a real embarrassment to the entire European car industry. This is europe's largest industry, employing the most and also investing the most in research and product development. Europe has been perfectly placed to become the world's leading pioneer in clean transport, and that objective has now taken a serious hit and it will take time to restore credibility. It is clear that things need to be investigated, abuses must be tackled rigorously and emissions measurements need to be developed in the direction of real driving emissions testing. At the same time, however, it is important to remember, when we want to tighten up the technical requirements, that we must be realistic and sufficiently long-term in the reforms.  We in Europe have wanted to cut CO2 emissions in particular, and we know that diesel engines are very good at it. In the US, on the other hand, strict restrictions are related to nitrogen oxides and in these diesel engines are no match for gasoline because diesel produces much more fine particles that are harmful to breathing air.  Reforms need to be made and demands must certainly be tightened up in many ways, but we must be long-term here that industry also knows which way the regulation is going. We know that if we want more industrial investment in Europe, it is investors who want perseverance and legal certainty for their own activities. Product development is a very long-term job. We already have a lot of alternative fuels, sustainable biofuels, hydrogen engines in Europe and we can electrify transport. What is important is that we, as a political decision-maker, are as technologically neutral as possible, that only targets are set, and car manufacturers themselves can see for themselves which technology best achieves that objective.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what Volkswagen has put in place is in fact a bad fraud and those responsible for fraud must be identified and penalised, but the question that others have already asked is: why have we not been able to bring to light the use of illegal devices to alter the control of pollutants and, above all, because fraud has been discovered in the United States and not in Europe?  The Volkswagen case clearly shows that it is not so much a problem of standards, linked to emission targets, here the standards are there and they are also stringent. , as has already been said, for the assessment of polluting emissions, based on real driving conditions, without granting excessive flexibility that could lead once again to untrue results.  Mrs Bieńkowska, that is what we would like to see concrete progress on. What is at stake here is not just the reputation of a country or a car manufacturer, here, in addition to the health of our citizens, what is at stake is the credibility of the rules we give ourselves and their respect.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Bonafè, earlier here someone mentioned that 400 000 people die every year from air pollution. Now you know that in this pollution, in addition to Volkswagen nitrogen monoxide there is also dioxin from incinerators, do you know this? So, before you come here and get your good talk, could you talk to our prime minister and ask him to shut down these blessed incinerators instead of encouraging the construction of new ones?

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: answer "blue card". Mr Pedicini, I am beginning to think that you have a problem because it is not possible for you to report back to my country every time I speak, with all the good I want to my country.  I would advise you next time, Mr Pedicini, not to stand for election to the European Parliament, but to stand as a candidate for the Italian Parliament, so at least you can discuss it at length with colleagues.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is clear that, first and foremost, there must be a proper investigation into what happened. On the part of the automotive industry, I consider it necessary and self-evident to cooperate as much as possible with the competent national authorities, to find a technical solution in the shortest possible time and to ensure that the customers concerned and the public are informed. In addition to eliminating the consequences, legislative measures must be taken to ensure that the results of the test processes correspond to the values of real driving, not only for emissions, but also for vehicle consumption. The whole case can also have major economic impacts on the whole sector, including the supply chain, and hit employees hard. Therefore, it is necessary to examine it fairly and to expedite the negotiation of redress in order to restore trust. Better regulation means that we are creating legislation that is controllable and enforceable. However, as long as it is true that investing in circumvention of standards is preferable to complying with these standards, then not only in the automotive industry, we are likely to see various unpleasant surprises in the future.

name: Bernd Lange (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Three points. Firstly, we must investigate the fraud as quickly as possible and ensure that this does not happen again. Secondly, we need legislation quickly to measure real emissions – RDE – and I hope that the Commission will get this off the line quickly, without there being any cheating opportunities. Thirdly, I do not entirely agree that we are constantly pillorying Volkswagen as a whole. These were some engineers and board members who cheated. But 600 000 Members have done their job, have done a good job of quality and have been committed to social responsibility. That is why let us really name the fraudsters and ensure that the 600 000 Members have a perspective in their professional futures! We must set the tone for industrial policy so that our colleagues at Volkswagen and with suppliers are not in danger of losing their jobs. That is why the Commission is called upon to take action here.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: Mr President, today it is revealed that there are more than 8 million people living in Europe. Volkswagen cars with illegal software, and that the European Commission had as early as 2013 identified differences between declared and actual emissions of pollutants, without doing anything. The facts demonstrate the inability of the Union, but also of the national supervisory authorities, to implement the laws effectively. This scandal, above all else, undermines our credibility just before the climate change summit in Paris.  For these reasons, there must immediately be a centralised control mechanism throughout the European Union, so that every state is not allowed to protect its illegal industries. Also, the size of the fine that those involved will have to pay must be commensurate with the lost credibility, while sending two messages: - that we are not negotiating the health of European citizens and. - that we do not sacrifice our environmental morality even in this time of economic crisis on the altar of profit and distorted competition of multinationals.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, a group of managers of the world's largest car company, the Volkswagen Group, has decided to destroy the most important premise that exists in any area of the business: trust. More than eleven million vehicles have been intentionally tampered with worldwide, with software designed to distort emissions tests into the atmosphere. Volkswagen has perpetrated a fraud of catastrophic consequences for the automotive sector globally. Millions of customers looking for more environmentally friendly cars were scammed. States that have allocated tax incentives for the purchase of less polluting cars have been circumvented. And tens of thousands of Volkswagen group workers may now see their jobs in danger. Leaving its own oversight in the hands of a sector is a risk. Today we are once again met with the result. We may be facing a new Pandora's box for the automotive sector and raise serious credibility issues in other European industrial sectors. Responsibility for environmental and public health crimes that have been committed must be determined. The interests of European consumers must be reassed and reassured and re-confidence in the markets. It is important to ask the European Commission what measures it will take to re-set the truth in the emission tests and to know, above all, what it will do to better monitor the implementation of European legislation.   (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Faria, you mentioned that we have to take immediate action because we, as the European Union, were investing a huge amount of money in technological development for a low carbon footprint, but we were not improving or harmonising our emissions testing. Do you not think that one step Europe must take is to standardise emissions testing at the level of the 28 Member States?

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. – Dear Colleague, firstly it has to be a coordinated effort and, secondly, the emission, the emission tests, has to be an independent and European body, it cannot be left to the industry alone to resolve this situation. It's unthinkable. It's unthinkable that we've come this far. The European Union must be united around this issue. And that's the way I think of resolving the situation.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Some of you will know: I had the honour of being Prime Minister of Lower Saxony for a while, from 2010 to 2013. Lower Saxony is the home of Volkswagen, and the Prime Minister is automatically a member of the Supervisory Board. I know this company and I suffer from this company. Volkswagen is currently experiencing difficult times. The irresponsible manipulation of exhaust emissions poses the biggest challenges that Volkswagen will certainly face for several years. Today was a meeting of the staff in Wolfsburg. Mr Müller was there to answer questions, and the staff – And I would like to emphasise what has been said – has been completely surprised by this development. Volkswagen employs more than 600,000 people who work hard for the company every day and do a very good job. And that is why it is irresponsible and unfair to place the company under general suspicion in its entirety. That is why our appeal today must also be: we stand by Volkswagen, we stand by its employees. Volkswagen is the largest industrial company in Europe. We must all have an interest in keeping the European car industry, and hence Volkswagen, stable in the long term.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the distortion of volkswagen's emissions tests is a high-impact aggression that goes far beyond the environmental component. A 21st century disease where excessive faith in technology and corporate denial of global warming, often driven by easy demand for profit, often reduces corporate environmental responsibility to advertising and image actions. This is a serious warning and requires looking in detail at large corporations where economic, easy and immediate interests are worth omission, masking and even lying. In addition, this behavior has a potential for contagion to other sectors, and may contribute to consumer disbelief in the efforts made by regulators and brands to reduce the ecological footprint. This is behaviour that can call into question the confidence of the world's citizens in relation to the entire European automotive sector. A thorough reflection on how this fraud could be seen in the United States of America and not in Europe. What happened?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, on 23 September I tabled a question about the now well-known Volkswagengate scandal. Black funds and kickbacks, from Siemens, led the Libor rate, by Deutsche Bank and the list of scandals involving German multinationals, of all sectors, is long. Man, ThyssenKrupp, Deutsche Telekom, BMW, Mercedes and now Volkswagen. At a time when Schäuble is waving his finger at Greece and asking my country to take additional harsh memorial measures to supposedly improve the competitiveness of the country's economy, the Volkswagen scandal proves, once again, that the famous competitiveness of German companies is almost exclusively due to the kickbacks and illegal and dirty practices they use to deceive the supervisory authorities and consumers.  The European Union should take immediate action by carrying out strict checks on cars of all companies, throughout Europe, to protect the environment, health and consumers themselves.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, our credibility is at stake, and that is why we need the truth, and that is why we need an investigation because in this way we will protect our credibility, the credibility of our regulations, but at the same time we will help one great group that we have in Europe. Investigation and truth can also help Volkswagen and can help the automotive industry. And that is why I believe that this is the only correct way because we know what it means for every citizen of Europe, every citizen of the world, to buy a car.  Therefore, if we in this difficult situation are not credible, if we do not help to win back this credibility of Volkswagen and the automotive industry, it will not be good. I'm in it to investigate everything and let the truth come out.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, the Volkswagen scandal must be investigated to the end, as this is not an isolated incident. On the contrary, it has wider dimensions, in terms of the role played by large multinational companies which, unfortunately, with the complicity of some governments impose policies, are out of control and serve their private interests at the expense of society and public health. In addition to the German Government, Commissioner, the Commission also has serious responsibilities. Although the Commission's investigative agency knew and warned, in a report in 2013, that Volkswagen's defeat systems could falsify the results of the measurements, it did not take any action. The fraud that has occurred is a serious violation of both European environmental legislation and consumer rights. It is necessary for the Union to promote, immediately, concrete measures so that there is effective control, always with a view to protecting consumer rights, human health and environmental protection.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President, respected Commissioners, respected colleagues, imagine that today we are discussing medical equipment that has sold millions of copies and is used daily in the European Union, but whose software has been adapted to provide false information about our health, that is, to show that we are healthier than we actually are. I hope that this comparison will help you understand how important this topic we are discussing is, how important it is to influence it because it will actually burden and harm our health and our public health system, not today but in the next ten years. But back to some economic issues. Where has the competition protections we swear so much to have disappeared? How much has this cheating slowed down the development of the hybrid and electric car market? How much has it challenged job creation in this automotive sector where green or greener jobs are created or should be created? What about the European Commission's policy of promoting green public procurement in public companies and the public sector, especially in transport, precisely to achieve climate goals and health protection? What about funding clean technologies? Because it is the states that have introduced a system for polluters to pay and thus fill the funds with which the development of renewable energy sources and clean transport are financed.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, representatives of the Commission, please let us put an end to this antics.  Now they are all ready to ask for explanations of rigour, everyone is ready to reassure that it will never happen again and everyone is ready to suggest new solutions, but here everyone knew. He knew Parliament, but he did nothing, the Commission knew, but it did nothing, the German Parliament knew, but let alone if it did something, the Americans knew, but they only brought this up now, during the TTIP negotiations. The citizens and environmental associations had denounced this scandal for several years, but they were never heard because these institutions only listen to big industry and power lobbies, so please let us stop this great antics.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this debate. I think it was very useful and valuable for both sides. I can assure you that I share emotion about the credibility of European industry, about cheating on consumers, about preventing jobs and about the credibility of our environmental ambitions. I really feel the sense of urgency here. We have to act very quickly. There is one point that has to be clarified; I will refer to the others later on. The Commission did not receive any information before the official information disclosed by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and no information was received by us from the EPA nor from any Member States. On the contrary, we contacted the EPA after they revealed their statement. The Commission took initiatives to resolve this crisis. In the past 20 years we have made great progress in reducing polluting emissions in the EU. In the last years, for the first time in 2010-2011, the Commission has concluded that the test cycles that we developed in the 1990s, in the beginning of the whole process, are not adequate anymore and that they are not able to reflect the emissions produced in real driving conditions.  Let me just touch upon the Joint Research Centre (JRC) analysis that we conducted then. All Joint Research Centre studies were made available on the internet. The Joint Research Centre studies did not check for defeat devices. It was not part of the studies. The JRC only indicated that defeat devices could be one of the reasons for big differences between emissions in the laboratory and those on the roads. Nothing more, and only this.  We have therefore made efforts to develop new test cycles that can indeed reflect real driving conditions. Work has progressed. It took a lot of time because they are very detailed technical issues but the work is almost complete, and it has to be completed in the fastest possible time. But let us not under-evaluate it when we are facing the current difficult and serious situation. We have to approve and implement new rules as quickly as possible and we need your support on this. At this moment we are analysing or finalising the analysis on how to improve the internal market in the framework of internal market strategy and in the case of the automotive sector we will propose soon a change of the rules on the approval of market surveillance. We will probably want to establish a new European instrument, on an institutional and European level, to check whether EU type-approval systems are implemented properly at the national level.  However, also for the internal market, let us not question what has worked well. What we need now are cool heads and strong action, and I am really counting on you here. I want to make sure that I will do everything in my capacity, firstly to restore the confidence of the consumers in the automotive industry in Europe, and secondly to ensure adequate compensation for the citizens who have been affected by this fraud. I will of course, keep you informed about every step of our action in the future.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the October III part-session.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, on a point of order, we have had a very lengthy debate and you may have your doubts whether that is the most efficient way, but that is not the point. My problem is that during the debate we have tabled I do not know how many questions to the Commission, and of course it was impossible for Commissioner Bieńkowska to answer all those questions. The fact is that in two weeks’ time we will vote on a resolution in this House on this same topic, and many of the questions that have been raised will be part of this resolution.  Is it possible to receive some kind of answer in writing for at least a few of the relevant questions that have been tabled, because they are really crucial for our resolution in two weeks’ time?

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – I apologise for not saying this before: of course you will receive written answers to all of your questions. We have noted it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. – The Volkswagen scandal that originated cannot be regarded as merely unethical and consumer-dishonest behaviour by the group. This is a blow to confidence in the European Union's system and its ability to ensure effective control. The message sent to EU citizens that the EU's loud slogans on consumer rights and well-being cannot be trusted, and the environmental and climate change priorities that are emphasised cannot be believed. This scandal has caused even greater damage to the EU's reputation in global politics, especially when it comes to the EU's positions on climate change. The global climate change conference in Paris is approaching, but how will the EU be able to require other countries to take on binding CO2 reduction targets if it has not been able to control its own producers. The Commission must examine this case in detail in order to avoid similar cases of unfair treatment in the future.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. The fraud carried out by europe's largest automotive group on CO2 emissions indelibly marks the end of two myths, which, between the lines, are being put to us as a model for this Europe. The first, most evident, is the one that wanted to draw peoples and states more virtuous than high; almost a "cultural" assumption to impose restrictive policies on "un virtuous" countries. Europe's reaction must be exemplary, because the rules circumvented on emissions by these very powerful behemoths are the same standards to which citizens, businesses, are obliged to comply with extremely strict and with an intolerable increase in costs and bureaucracy. The second is that this Europe is transparent, super partes and third in relation to the interests at stake. The reports of pressure from lobbies and some governments to cover up ongoing fraud show how far-reaching transparent procedures are, how much even 'officials' can be manipulated, how absent self-defence mechanisms are by EU legislators against undue pressure.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. – Due to the Volkswagen scandal, it is estimated that failure to meet the reduction targets set by EU standards in Europe could result in an additional 1.5 billion tonnes of CO2 being released into the atmosphere in 2030, with a fuel consumption cost of as much as EUR 1 000 billion more. It is therefore a good thing that criminal investigations have also been launched as soon as possible in order to establish responsibilities, and it seems appropriate in any case to review the entire emissions testing system. As I said in a priority question of mine, I have the impression that these problems will soon extend to the entire supply chain of consumer goods production, if only samsung televisions in Europe seem to use more energy than is apparent from the tests, raising questions about energy efficiency tests. I await a firm response from the Commission, given that it seems reasonable to assume that the world's major producers of goods have, by profit reasons, increased the volume of WEEE, violated the principle of efficient use of resources, threatened the planet and sown mistrust among consumers.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. The Volkswagen scandal, which erupted a few weeks ago, has shocked European public opinion. For years, the manufacturer of one of the most popular car brands has provided consumers with false emissions data in order to ensure its market leadership. The case is exemplary and it can only be hoped that other manufacturers have not acted in the same way in order to comply with strict environmental standards. We need to learn the lessons from what has happened, the setting of strict emission values is not enough, but we need proper controls, real-world testing. Many predict the end of diesel engines, which vary from one Member State to another, but make up a significant part of the European car fleet.  I believe that the alarm bells need not be raised immediately, that Europe is at the forefront of technological development of diesel engines, and that many European households can use their own cars thanks to cars powered by cheaper diesel fuel. Those involved in the Volkswagen fraud cannot be held accountable without restoring consumer confidence. The competitiveness of European car production and European industry must be strengthened by EU action.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The Volkswagen emissions scandal is the case of a company that has begun to expand into the Us market. But this is only the tip of the iceberg, a kind of warning to Europe, which is defending itself against the TTiP agreement, m.in. for environmental reasons. This is a broader issue, not just an element of competition from US and European car companies. You don't need to have the knowledge of physicochemistics to easily deduce that maximising the energy efficiency of diesel engines, in order to reduce CO2 emissions as much as possible, is accompanied by an increase in the combustion temperature, and exceeding a certain threshold threatens to generate poisonous endothermic compounds like NOx. Does this mean the end of diesel? I do not think the technical possibilities of reducing the amount of NOx and particulate matter through the specificity of injection and catalytic elimination, as well as the reduction of aromatic hydrocarbons from gases emitted by diesel engines are large. What to do? - New diesel cars should be tested not only during approval but also during the warranty period for Euro-6 compliance both at the test bench, i.e. 400 mg/kWh and while driving, i.e. 0,08 g/km; - non-compliance with Euro-6 standards during the warranty period should be compensated to users; - The Fix Clause should be extended to all EU countries in order to activate the innovation potential of SMEs to fight poisonous emissions, especially in central and eastern European countries, where millions of poisonous cars are registered.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – The crisis created by the Volkswagen case in Europe has long-term effects and many of them have already been mentioned. I want to point out a few. It is clear that the effects have been on citizens, because of pollution, by putting millions of cars into circulation, on buyers who have been deceived, but also on workers and on SMEs, who have worked as suppliers and sub-suppliers for this company. I am surprised by the statement by the German Chancellor, who said that Germany will get over this problem! But the problem was created not only for Germany, but also for Europe. Commissioner, you need to put in place uniform measures to eliminate the cause, not let each state handle it. We need to have a unitary approval, testing and control system. You need to determine who pays and how they pay for the damage caused to consumers and not let states impoverish national budgets by paying compensation. I am convinced that, since the deficiency was discovered by the US, it will influence the negotiation of TTIP. The US will seek to use this case in their favor when we negotiate harmonization of standards. National, local and central authorities treat large brands and SMEs differently in terms of control.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. – The rigged exhaust emissions at the volkswagen manufacturer Volkswagen are an environmental and economic scandal. What we need now, however, is not new laws, but the fight against fraud and targeted prosecution. Few VW employees are harming not only the environment, but the entire European car industry, putting tens of thousands of jobs in Europe at risk. Those responsible must draw the consequences. The primary objective must be to restore confidence and ensure maximum transparency in education. Exhaust gas tests and product information must be beyond doubt. Pollutant emissions may only be measured in accordance with applicable law. We also need emissions measurements on the road instead of laboratory tricks, and the reforms of fuel consumption tests and exhaust gas measurements that have already begun must be speeded up. In any case, I would like to warn against unnecessary legislation and call for full concentration on more consistent monitoring and enforcement of the existing objectives.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. "Volkswagen's emissions measurement scam speaks harsh language that market surveillance in EU countries has failed. In the scandal, the European Commission has placed responsibility on the Member States, which must ensure that there are no wrongly marketed cars on the market. According to calculations, air pollution causes 400 000 premature deaths in the European Union. One of the most significant sources of emissions is transport. For this reason, emission limits for nitrogen oxides (NO), particulate matter emissions (PN/PM), carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrocarbons (CH) have been defined for cars, parcels and lorries through Euro standards. In addition, the maximum emission value for greenhouse gas carbon dioxide has been set since 2012. It has long been known that there are major differences between official laboratory measurements and actual values measured in traffic. For example, nitrogen oxide emissions from diesel cars have been seven times higher in traffic than in official laboratory measurements. The Volkswagen case has involved deliberate manipulation of the test results. The Commission needs a stronger role in the supervision of cars already admitted to the market. This would allow the Commission to intervene more effectively in non-compliance with products circulating on the EU market.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – I find the European Commission's response to the dieselgate questions to be completely unsatisfactory. We did not know how the scandal was exposed in the US and not in the EU, nor how long the Commission had evidence of breaches of the law. Despite all the Commission's positive statements on the need to change the status quo, restore trust to customers and prevent such things from happening again, no concrete steps have been presented that should follow. An independent, US-wide investigation has not yet been launched to confirm or refute the presumption that this is not an isolated case. The transition to Parliament' long-required new real-world testing system, which would take into account not only laboratory data but actual driving conditions, is desperately slow. No guarantees were given that employees who were not responsible for volkswagen executives' decisions would not lose their jobs as a result of the planned cuts. It is also unclear how the company will approach obtaining green subsidies and tax breaks in the EU and the US. I therefore call on the Commission to reconsider the lax and toothless approach to date, because the case itself damages, in addition to European consumers, the EU's position as a leader in the fight against climate change at the forthcoming COP 21 in Paris, as well as the potential to weaken the EU's negotiating position in the ttip negotiations.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal shocked Europe and severely damaged the reputation of the European car industry. How could a reputable and well-looking company take so many risks? Faced with the enormity of the deception, it is no longer an error of course, but rather a vast organized hacking operation. The group has not only deceived European and international regulators, but also several hundred thousand consumers in Europe and around the world. This case has shown that we must impose a check in real driving conditions, as I asked in my cars2020 report, voted by Parliament a year ago. I call on the Commission to do this in order to promote the reputation of its companies in Europe and around the world.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – In my view, it is inadmissible that Volkswagen infringed the provisions on maximum car exhaust values. I would certainly not have expected anything like this from a German company with such a reputation, especially since it is part of an industry that has also co-designed standards, but the desire for profit clearly tramples morale even in so-called reputable corporations. This is certainly not a good forward journey, and it is difficult to restore a reputation after such a scandal, and the event of such dimensions inadvertently casts a shadow on the entire car industry. Unfortunately, as usual, consumers will be 'shortest again', which for me, as a member of the EP Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, is particularly unacceptable and pressing. Imagine that as a deceived European you buy a car in good faith, that everything that is written in the technical specifications, really, it turns out that is not the case. This is by no means just a question of penalties for a corporation, it also raises the question of who will reimburse consumers for overpaid standards that did not correspond to the facts. The most important role must now be played by European regulators and to prepare relevant measures so that something like this cannot happen again."

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Member States and regions must be pushed to file a complaint against the German company. To bring an action for damages would be justice; indeed, the tax incentives granted by the government to individuals in connection with purchases of environmentally friendly vehicles are based on a Volkswagen lie.  On the other hand, asking companies to self-control is like asking drivers to fine themselves! Fraud on CO2 emissions is fraud on tax incentives, especially in countries where these incentives were linked to the power of the car or environmental virtues. The authorities must therefore file a complaint to seek redress.  To avoid the lies succeeding each other, I wanted to clarify this: some took advantage of the VW crisis to extol the merits of the American authorities and therefore the TTIP always in search of allies given the suspicions that hang over the treaty. Lack of pot: the pot of roses on the exhaust pipes was discovered by independent researchers, German and then American, and not by the U.S. authorities!

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya (2015/2872(RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, Libya is at a critical juncture. The situation on the ground has continued to deteriorate. The number of internally displaced civilians has increased. In several areas – notably in a number of Benghazi neighbourhoods – we are facing a serious humanitarian crisis. Health and educational services have been disrupted: many hospitals and schools are now barely functioning. Oil production is at its lowest, cash reserves are fast being depleted and the government is cutting subsidies. The Libyan dinar has tragically devalued. As a result, there have been shortages of basic goods such as flour, and the price of bread and other staples has climbed.  The security situation has also deteriorated. The ceasefires established locally are welcome but are not enough. There is little law or order. In many cities crime takes place with impunity. This has also facilitated the continued trafficking of migrants by criminal gangs. Libya’s southern border is essentially open. Too many lives are put at risk at sea in unsafe boats.  More and more Libyans themselves are trying to move abroad. Both Tunisia and Egypt have been very welcoming and supportive but many Libyan families there, having used up most of their savings, find it impossible to make ends meet. The majority of Libyans are sick of the conflict. The war has only benefited terrorist groups like Daesh. They represent a threat that cannot be ignored. They prosper thanks to the war and the divisions of Libyan society. When they do not manage to ally with local militias, they struggle to keep control on the ground. Last summer they lost Derna but they managed to put down a rebellion in Sirte, a key city on the motorway connecting Tripoli and Benghazi, and the terrorist threat extends not just to Libya but to neighbouring countries. This is yet another reason to push for a national unity government – a government that can put the greatest number of militias under the authority of the state institutions.  There has been progress in the political process. The UN special envoy, Bernardino León, with our full and active support, is doing all he can to bring together the government of the National Assembly in Tobruk and the rival GNC in Tripoli. Last week, in New York at the UN General Assembly, the international community showed its unanimous support for Leon’s efforts, in front of representatives of both factions and of civil society. We urged both sides to sign the negotiated agreements.  In New York we witnessed something new and encouraging, finally. The whole international community, including all Libya’s neighbours, shared the same views on the way forward. This is in part a result of the active lobbying by the European Union and its Member States. The European Union has played an important role in getting the process this far. We have worked day and night – literally – to support the perspective of a government of national accord. Now the international community is united on this: it is the Libyans who have to take responsibility now and form a government to put an end to their country’s collapse.  We know very well that even if a government of national accord were formed, change in Libya would not happen overnight. It might take time for the situation to improve, even if we get all the main parties to sign this agreement. But it would create an opportunity for improvement. It will not be a conclusion, but a starting point.  Let me set out what the European Union’s strategic objectives are and the action we are currently taking – and preparing to take – to achieve them. We want security, stability, accountable government and the rule of law in Libya. The people there deserve to live in peace and have their human rights respected. We want the Libyan economy to flourish once again, and also their commerce with the European Union, and we want the traffickers who prey on the desperate to be finally brought to book.  Our initial efforts to help Libya establish control of its borders and build stronger institutions can only start once we have a deal and we have a new government to work with. But we stand ready, as we pledged to all parties in New York last week, to launch a support package worth EUR 100 million as soon as a political agreement is reached.  This would include a range of measures funded from the European Union’s Programme Budget for Libya as well as the Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace (IcSP). This money will help rebuild Libya’s institutions. It will encourage dialogue between the country’s different groups, support local governance, civil society and of course the media. It will help allow people to get their lives back to normal, helping with the delivery of basic services, including health. We will assist the ministries most concerned with helping to manage migration. We will support SMEs and employment opportunities to give a chance to Libya’s youth and put the country back on track. This will be in addition to the humanitarian aid we are already providing for the most urgent needs of the most vulnerable people. We are undertaking planning work to help provide a secure environment for a government of national accord and the European Union is assisting the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) with a planning cell based in Tunis. We are also working with the UN on longer term planning to assist the new government in other sectors and we intend to play a prominent role in all the joint working groups. Working groups from both the international community and the Libyan Government are being set up right now. But now it is up to the Libyan parties to make a move: the decisive one. No—one can take this decision in their place. I know how much this House has always been supportive of a political agreement. I am sure it will continue to play a key role to help the parties reach a stable solution. It is now high time that parties show leadership, take on their responsibilities and sign the agreement. It is time for Libya to get back on its feet.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, for the first time since 2011, Libya has a roadmap for a full transition. The efforts of the UN Special Representative, Bernardino Leon, must once again be commended and the European Union must continue to provide unwavering support. Three remarks. The various parties must now take responsibility, not only for Libyans but also to put an end to a situation that makes the country a hotbed of threat to regional and international security. International pressure must be maintained from all sides. As you said, Commissioner, the time is no longer for the negotiation of terms but for responsibility, to get to work in a government of national unity.  At the regional level and from the point of view of the European Union, I stress the link with the Sahel region. As I have said many times, this is a key region to prevent the spread of areas of insecurity. I welcome the announcement of the increase in EUCAP Sahel Niger's budget. Let us not let go of our support for the Malian transition, whose future is also linked to the situation in Libya, particularly in the fight against terrorism and trafficking. In this context, I would like to take this opportunity to call for more consistent work by the European Union with African partners for the operationalisation of intelligence systems on this continent. Finally, I insist that the European Union and the United Nations continue to focus their efforts and support the various initiatives to bring the peace process to the local level, including women and minorities. Even more so in Libya than elsewhere, the construction of peace and a state is based on local power. Commissioner, we are at a turning point in the Libyan conflict, even as the international community is active on the Syrian issue. What is the small plus that the European Union can put in the balance in Libya in order to maximise the chances of regional stabilisation? The question remains open.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the information just provided to the House because it is very important to see that Libya was one of the major topics on the UN General Assembly agenda.  On the situation in Libya, we must once more repeat ourselves. We have said it many times in this House, deadline after deadline: no more time can be lost. But unfortunately every single time the end of the tunnel seems to be reachable the final agreement on the unity government does not see the light. This is not a joke. This cannot be a matter of personal interests: it is about the fate of an entire country, the fate of an entire people, and practically the fate of an entire region.  The future and the stability of the entire region are somehow connected to how things will evolve in Libya. Daesh does not lose time, it does not wait, it grows and spreads where it finds fertile soil and from there it tries to destabilise the region. The EU and the whole international community cannot afford a failed state in Libya, but more importantly those who really care about Libya and about the Libyans cannot afford once again a failure of the peace plan.  Libya is today in the hands of the Libyan people and their leaders. Violence and the aggravating humanitarian crisis must come to an end. As the High Representative has said so many times, the EU stands ready – and the Commissioner has just mentioned how Europe can help any national unity government in Libya.  In this regard, it is important to find an agreement that brings all sides together, but let us be realistic: no agreement can be perfect for all sides. Everybody must give something up. This is about compromises. Once again there is on the table a peace plan brokered by the UN Special Representative, and there is now a new deadline. This must be the very last one. Should that not be the case, the Libyan people will be the ones who will have to pay the price if the agreement fails.  And one final word about what Europe can do: let us not forget that Europe should do something on two fronts, namely by considering sanctions against those who do not sign the agreement and equally against those who promote the proxy wars.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. We know that the High Representative rightly prioritises the situation in Libya, a country in ruins, a population in despair. The image you have given is certainly not pretty. Not only does the proposed formation of a unity government do indeed impose itself, because attention must also be paid to the development of properly functioning public institutions. You have also pointed that out.  Many questions remain unanswered, such as those about justice, punishment and reconciliation. How can the different groups and communities start living together and working together again? How can they reconcile? How can justice be achieved for the victims of war crimes and can the perpetrators be punished? I would also like to stress the importance of education. Young people need to learn to think for themselves. They should be able to form their own opinions. After all, how else do we build an independent civil society that has to steer the political leadership to make the right decisions? If the European Union ignores these challenges in Libya, peace and stability will not be possible. We have to avoid that. The clock is ticking. We face a huge challenge. We will have to step up our efforts.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for agreement which we now have on the table is surely the last opportunity for the two factions to lay the groundwork for a ceasefire and for the formation of a government of national unity to advance the pacification of the country and the stabilisation of the region. And I don't say it, says Bernardino León. To achieve this, October 20 is the deadline. If a government of national unity fails to form by then, we will have to start from scratch with the negotiations, and worse, a lack of agreement will not only be negative for the people of Libya, as it will have regional consequences in the continuation of the country's balkanization process, but will promote the growth of the Islamic State. As we speak here, Daesh continues to advance and already controls in Libya a coastal strip the size of Switzerland. It is organized militarily in both Iraq and Syria and has access to aircraft and warships. And we still do not act, without being able to reach vital agreements for the viability of the region, located on the southern border of the European Union. We cannot continue to elude our responsibilities. We must give our support and exert all possible pressure to get the negotiations to fruition, and then we must offer all assistance to the Libyan authorities to intervene militarily against the Islamic State and prevent its expansion. Only in this way will we be able to lay the groundwork for a stable future in the region.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we saloon Bernardino León's efforts, just as we saloon Mr Mistura's efforts in Syria, because we believe it is the only way to a solution: the regional solution that has all the actors. The Commissioner told us about a series of catastrophes , which looked like a natural catastrophe that had struck Libya. The thing is, you have to have memory so you don't repeat.  In 2011, unilateral action was taken over seven months (10,000 missions) involving the United States, NATO and many European Union countries under the infamous alibi for responsibility to protect. In the end, who did you protect? Because I see you didn't protect Libyans or Libyans or Europe. What did they get? Destroy the Libyan state as before destroyed the Iraqi state and as they are now destroying the Syrian state. Back to the beginning, the bad news is that with thousands of dead, thousands of drowned, hundreds of thousands of refugees and terrorist expansion.  We told Bernardino León on the Foreign Affairs Committee. An agreement had been reached — an opportunity with mediation by the African Union and Algeria – accepted even by Gaddafi, but no case was reached, military action was used. That's why we support this effort. But the agreement reached in New York with regional actors and with the two governments for the formation of a national unity government must be the beginning for a comprehensive agreement that integrates all actors, including tribes and national forces. Let us deepen and support this path and flee from the temptation of other unilateral military action.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday I came back from Tunis. There I held talks with UNSMIL with representatives of Libyan parties, human rights activists and representatives of various tribes. A declaration of political agreement was supported by all sides, although there was criticism that many of the more influential actors were not consulted. Similarly, the text of the declaration, as far as we have it before us, can be considered positive, particularly as regards the protection of human rights and law enforcement. Nevertheless, we cannot be under any illusions. Achieving an agreement is important, and its implementation is all the more difficult. There are a large number of militias that pursue their interests. Not everyone will sign. Even if signed, there is a risk of new escalation and violence. The rift through the country has also deepened economically and socially. In all these circumstances, forming and stabilising a national unity government is an enormous challenge that will continue to require strong support from the EU. And the EU's influence would be all the stronger if all Member States spoke with one voice. In recent years, we have received repeated reports of horrific human rights violations against Libyans, migrants and refugees. We must fight this with all our might. I very much hope that the EU will continue to support the work of human rights defenders inside and outside Libya, because their work is also of great importance for the peace process.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, now that the agreement has been reached, we should now convince the contracting parties, even more so. This paraphrase of Cavour seems appropriate to me to describe yet another episode of the Libyan crisis.  Once again, I fully support bernardino León's relentless efforts and work for a government of national unity, even if this project has the defect of not taking into account the existence of the opinion of the non-Arab tribes in southern Libya, but the conclusion is essential to regain control of the southern borders. Let us hope that some people will not soon regret this by perhaps commenting on another civil war, in any case the complicated but inevitable alchemy of the León plan still seems opposed by so many, too many actors, by Haftar, ready to damage them with his sudden military escalation in Benghazi, from the unilateral extensions of the Parliament of Tobruk, to the amendments of the Tripoli Parliament, to the plan, to the efforts of the international sponsors of all of them.  While fighting in Morocco over the names of the prime minister and two deputies, another 95 bodies are shipwrecked on the Libyan coast. No, the time for peace, unity and reconstruction is still a long way off and frankly President Obama's mea culpa at the United Nations on 28 September, in which he recriminate the mistakes of the past, sincerely does not appear to me to be credible, indeed it is quite hypocritical. This war didn't inherit it from Bush. The international community he mentioned is in fact made up of the United States, France and Great Britain, all those who have bombarded the country very lightly without then committing themselves to a genuine democratic transition. The insatiable appetite for Libyan oil was more important than the future of the Mediterranean.  It is up to the Libyans to assume their responsibilities, As you said, Commissioner, I agree, but when will those responsible for this disaster assume their responsibilities? (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Castaldo, thank you for accepting my blue card and I must say that I agree with your analysis of what was happening and why Libya was some way devastated. I want to ask you a question concerning some analyses that say that the solution of Syria and Libya should resemble Bosnia and Herzegovina and that this could achieve peace. I don't think that's quite the case, because Bosnia and Herzegovina doesn't work either, regardless of what we have peace of mind. So, for the future of Syria and Libya, and especially now Libya, do you agree with me that it should primarily be left to them to decide their fate, and we should just be facilitators of that process?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: answer "blue card". I fully agree with you, Mr McKenna. These plans, like the Dayton Agreements, are often completely ineffective, they are good for finding an armistice, for finding peace, but they are in no way capable of making a state governable.  I think that we need to reach a cease-fire at the moment, but then we must not make the same mistake and repeat that huge mistake again, otherwise we will end up with another paralyzed state and we will end up with an even bigger problem to solve in a few years' time, and it will certainly also be an ineffective government to combat the advance of the Caliphate.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Representative of the Commission spoke for almost ten minutes in the absence of High Representative Mogherini, whose incisiveness on the issue of the dossier we are examining seems to me to be highlighted – I beg your pardon – by the almost absolute nothing conclusions, the concrete conclusions presented to us by the Representative of the Commission.  Almost absolute nothingness. In fact, it is not clear, in my opinion, how such an uncertain and confused European Union position is being impacted on the situation in Libya, which is our southern neighbour, given the need and urgency every day to stop the activities of illegal traffickers operating in Libya and responsible for the damage, such as today's.  Furthermore, the news of the statement made by the Grand Mufti of Libya, Sheikh Sadek Al-Ghariani, that it is not enough for the agreement sponsored by the UN representative that sharìa should be considered for the future of the Libyan Government of National Unity as the only source of the legislation is simply chilling. For Islamic religious authorities, it is not acceptable that the sharìa should simply be a source of law because it must be considered the law.  So my question is this: what does the European Union think, that the new state of national unity to which the UN is working with your moral support – because you are not here, there are services thank God Italians, French and other countries that work very well. Europe is not there! Are you preparing us for the future for a beautiful state in which the law of sharìa applies as the only law?

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, the case of Libya is yet another proof of the European Union's flawed foreign policy. It was involved for no reason and, above all, without serving its interests in the first of the country's two civil wars, so instead of solving the problem it managed to become part of the problem. A humanitarian crisis has been created, all the warring factions have violated and continue to violate human rights and waves of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants have been brought to Europe via Italy. Worse still, powerful forces of ISIS jihadists have developed in the country. Something similar happened with Syria: in spite of the evolution of events, and therefore logic, the European Union continued to insist on overthrowing President Assad. You know the results. Similarly to Turkey: the European Union has tolerated Turkey supporting ISIS forces and promoting thousands of illegal immigrants in Greece and, through it, in Europe.  And now what is the European Union doing? It asks Turkey to do the obvious and makes it a privileged interlocutor, instead of reminding it that it is a country to join and must be consistent with its obligations. So if we do not get rid of the obsessions in our foreign policy, we will not be able to solve the problems and we will simply try to deal with their results.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, as we all know, the civil war in Libya has been going on for four years. It completely ruined the country and destroyed all the institutions as they were under the former regime. It is now complete chaos, which is a danger to regional stability but also, of course, to the stability of the European Union. As we can see, Libya is the hub of all trafficking, from illegal immigration, including, of course, to our countries. Added to this is the terrorist threat with the establishment of Daesh in this country. We were able to measure the consequences in the neighbouring country of Tunisia, where the terrorist attacks were actually carried out by people from Libyan terrorist networks. I would like to commend the Efforts of the Union to end the crisis. We have supported the PEACE negotiations under the aegis of the United Nations. We now have Operation Sophia, but this operation can only be successful when Libya has a government of national unity, a stable government that can be a partner of the Union. The last text negotiated by the UN Special Envoy, Bernardino Leon, is in a way the last-chance agreement. Three attempts to sign a political agreement have failed. A new deadline has been set for October 20. I believe that the extension of the mandate of the Libyan parliament beyond 20 October would not be an encouraging sign at all. That is why we must remain hopeful and we must continue to believe in this agreement, in this compromise. Secondly, I am sure, the time will come for the Union to work to support the democratic process.

name: Presidente. –
text: Is there a question for you from Mr Chauprade, do you accept the question?

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: "No, Mr President, I do not want to talk to the National Front.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at the most complicated stage and we should all be aware of this.  It is essential for the European Union to exert all the necessary pressure to reach an agreement between the different Libyan components and the deadline must be 20 October, we cannot go any further. The final stage is difficult, but it must be made clear to all those who escape will take on a great responsibility, including with regard to their future recognition.  And I have to say quite frankly that in this context it was not a brilliant idea to have opened the debate now in the UN on the replacement of the current UN negotiator Bernardino León, but now we are aiding him, Bernardino León, at this final stage, in order to reach an agreement without which not only will the problems in the region, but also in Europe, increase. I am thinking, in fact, of the risks associated with the enlargement of the conflict and the fact that terrorism is taking even more force; I am thinking of the hundreds of thousands of people who have fled Libya, who are close to the Tunisian border in very difficult conditions for them and for Tunisia itself, and I am thinking, finally, of the trafficking of immigrants.  For all this, the agreement in Libya is now an indivisible necessity and I hope that the European Union will do everything possible to ensure that this agreement is reached. We have very few days at our disposal, use them to the best.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Panzeri, you seem very critical of the United Nations and it would seem – from where I am sitting in this Chamber – that you took some sort of high and mighty approach that the European Union is the best international organisation to try and get a result. Are you really so sure, with the European Union’s own abysmal record in certain areas, that you are better placed to deal with this than the United Nations? I think perhaps you need to have a look at the bigger picture, and this is the problem.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: answer "blue card". I think you have understood little about my speech. I did not criticise the UN for the things it does, I just said that it was wrong to open the debate on the possibility of replacing Bernardino León, the current negotiator, with the German Kobler.  It was a stage, in my view wrong, to open this debate today and it was necessary to do so afterwards, because this inevitably leads to the current negotiator being put in a more precarious position. That is why criticism of the UN was necessary.

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today's disastrous situation in Libya is one of the biggest failures of global politics – mainly European – in the last decade and the result of the incredible hypocrisy of western elites. Large concessions on the extraction of Libyan kerosene and gas were enough for Gaddafi, previously disgraced by support of terrorist movements around the world and a sponsor of numerous local wars in Africa, to suddenly be promoted to a friend of the leaders of some European countries. The new friendship, however, did not last long. In Libya, the Iraqi scenario was repeated. Today, the same countries, which have recently been closely linked by a thread of not entirely pure economic interests with Libya and the regime that is firming there, and then overthrow it on the pretext of protecting human rights and, in fact, more of their influence in the region, are calling on all states to show solidarity in resolving the refugee crisis, including those fleeing the Libyan coast. Countries such as Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia, for whom links to the Libyan regime sound like exoticism, are being publicly pillaloged for their rational opposition to imposing co-responsibility on them for the crisis caused by other North Africans. However, gaddafi's former allies lured by the smell of Libyan oil now have no right to act as moral authorities and instruct others.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the question. I broadly agreed with much of your speech. Do you agree with me that there is a great irony in the fact that, in countries – including, to our shame, countries like the UK where we had Tony Blair cosying up to Gaddafi and other European countries – which have had really detrimental effects on Libya, people now think they can go in and solve all these problems? Well, let us be truthful: the countries represented in the EU are the ones that caused most of the problems. Would you agree?

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Speaking of the leaders of some European countries, I was referring to countries such as the United Kingdom, France and Italy.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, first question: Libya does not exist, there are two Parliaments which represent nothing and two governments that do not govern. What exists are militias, tribes and clans defending themselves in self-defense and practicing the best of business, which is the control of the territory and, consequently, of traffic. This is the reality. Let's move on. We have a south that is not represented and is a black hole, origin, destination and transit of all dangerous drug, male and gun trafficking. And we have a reality, which is what has prevented us from agreeing, or attempted agreement, which is the Islamic State, which is the point of unification. That Islamic State that has created a government that will not govern, but which will claim with apparent legitimacy the inevitable intervention of the international community, that is, the intervention of Western military action to end or weaken Daesh.  This is the New York and Skhirat agreement, nothing more or nothing less. And perhaps he is the only one, and therefore, unfortunately, in this terrible circumstance we will have to continue to support the fiction that Bernardino León is creating, an absolute fiction that will legitimize Western military action.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr "The world let go when we got halfway." Mrs Lochbihler and I heard this this weekend when we visited exiled Libyans in Tunisia. By that they mean we got there, we bombed Gaddafi away, we went home, but we had no plan for how to help Libya create a state once we had left the country. We left a country in chaos with great divisions between people, and where weapons flow freely in all directions and still do so. What was also very clear during our visit to Tunisia, where we spoke both with the Tunisian authorities and with Libyans, is that there is no support for the new military operation planned by the EU, EUNAVFOR or the so-called Sophia operation. No one thought that it would lead to greater security for the Libyan people. It is a completely private issue, so to speak, for eu countries to stop people trying to come to us, but it does not in any way help the Libyan people.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD).
