text: – Mr President, what makes the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy think she can have any influence on the course of Libyan politics and push for a government of national unity when there is little unity within the Member States of the EU itself? Just look at the individual Member States’ reactions to the current migrant crisis. The folly of the initial western intervention in Libya is well documented and the collective failure of the international community – including the Commission – to effectively secure peace in North Africa has led to a power vacuum in Libya that even President Obama has been forced to acknowledge. This in turn has created a breeding ground for terrorist groups such as Islamic State to build fiefdoms, operate criminal empires with impunity and threaten the very fabric of security in the EU’s Member States by flooding the continent with their fighters. In fact, there is no better example of the EU’s foreign policy failures than the vile human-trafficking trade operating from Libya, which has led to countless deaths and has left European politicians scratching around for a reactive solution to the mayhem they helped create in the first place. And what does the EU do instead of seeking a head-on solution to the migration crisis? They demand yet more European centralisation, this time through the creation of an EU—wide coastguard and border force. Having seen what has happened to countries that put their trust in the EU’s management of the euro, I would not trust any EU bureaucrat to effectively police our seas, secure our borders or give advice on unity governance.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF).
text: Mr President, since 2014, Libya - a direct consequence of the Western intervention of 2011, defended by many of you here - is a failed state, fractured into two governments, two parliaments and two opposing military alliances.  To the west, the predominantly Islamist Tripoli camp relies on a non-UN-recognized government and a military coalition backed by Qatar and Turkey. To the east, the Tobruk camp of liberals, Cyrenaica federalists and ex-Gaddafis is recognized by the United Nations and supported by Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, the United States and the European Union, and relies on General Khalifa Haftar's military coalition against the Islamist militias in Benghazi.  The Islamist coalition co-exists with the jihadists of Ansar al-Sharia with those of Al Qaeda of the Islamic Maghreb and with those of Egypt, who now have a rear base in addition to Sinai, not to mention the installation in 2014 of the Islamic State.  Syrian Islamic State cadres are training in Cyrenaica, a province that now gives a strategic advantage to the Islamic caliphate, which now has a maritime disenfranchisement. Today, in order to protect Europe, there is, in my opinion, only one solution: a naval blockade of the Libyan coast by our fleets to stop the departures of boats at the source. Boats must be boarded as soon as they leave, migrants sent back to shore and smugglers' boats sunk.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, when I hear my colleague Chauprade, I feel like I am Saint Bonaventure hearing St. Thomas in a theological dispute and tearing the own leaves of the presentation he was preparing to make, as the situation has been beautifully described.  I understand very well that Mr Preda does not want to debate with him because it is Mr Preda's political friends who are responsible for the current situation. It must still be named: it was Mr Sarkozy, under the inspiration of Mr Bernard-Henri Lévy, who, after having received Mr. Gaddafi magnificently, having let him pitch his tent at a distance from the Élysée, having rolled out 100 meters of red carpet, after fraternizing with him, stabbed him in the back at the first difficulty and had him participate live in his assassination.  So, in this extraordinarily difficult context, at least, that experience serves us. We Westerners have destabilized Iraq, we have destabilized Libya and we are still preparing, in any case, a number of us here are preparing to destabilize the Syrian government. It is the policy of Gribouille, it is the one that sets the stage for extremists, for Islamists and for those you wrongly claim to be fighting.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The best that can be seen in the current situation is the fact that the international community is essentially behind the Plan of Bernardino Leon. That is a good thing as such, but unfortunately it does not help us in the current situation. It is also good that we are ready with a support package in the event of a political deal. But I am afraid that we will not get there any time soon. As you can hear, both the delegation from Tripoli appears to have been recalled from Morocco, which means that the mediation efforts of Morocco, too, are not being continued, and on the other hand, it seems that Parliament in Tobruk has also extended its mandate to the period after 20 October. So there is no good chance on either side that we will reach a solution in the near future. I believe that we have to note that there are certain militias that have no interest whatsoever in agreeing in Tripoli and Tobruk, because they do their business, practice their criminal activities. But we also see that different forces support Tripoli and Tobruk. Now Tobruk is the recognized government. I do not have to criticise if it is supported. But names are mentioned who supports Tripoli: Turkey, Qatar and Sudan. The question for me is whether, in connection with the talks we are having with Turkey, for example, anyway, we are not even asking what interest that country can have in the fact that there is a different structure in Tripoli, and we are not able or unwilling to produce results here. I believe that this would be an important point that we should raise, among other things, with Turkey.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to say something about the chaos and the humanitarian disaster in Libya, which we helped develop through the lack of convergent and coordinated European action after the fall of Gaddafi and through the stupid failure to assist the transitional authorities on security sector reform (SSR) and disarmament, demobilisation and reintegration (DDR), thus enabling the militias to turn into the terrorist and criminal gangs of today. Do not fool yourself, Commissioner. The seventh version of the UN-brokered national accord is not likely to be signed any time soon, according to what we hear in Tripoli and Tobruk today. A major military operation following the disastrous model of Yemen seems to be under preparation by General Haftar, the aspiring new Gaddafi, counting on Salafist fighters. Tragic consequences will befall the Libyan people, foreign migrants, foreigners trying to flee and, inevitably, Europe. The European failure to act is the result of lack of union and indeed rivalry among our Member States over oil and other interests. That is leaving some European capitals more exposed to Libya, and they are now contemplating military intervention, which will require thousands of boots on the ground, not to mention a legal justification.  Another mistake made by the EU, the US and the UN is to pretend that all this is internal factionalism and not to denounce and deter the powers that are fighting a proxy war in Libya, namely Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Egypt, backing the government in Tobruk, and Turkey and Qatar backing the Muslim Brotherhood in the Tripoli—Misrata axis. By not stopping this proxy war, we are enabling an expansion of the terrorist Daesh and the Salafists in Libya. This is not just against the people – this is against the people of Europe.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Militia country - I would like to emphasise this - militia country Libya is currently in a complete civil war with two parallel governments and two parallel parliaments. The European Commission, in the absence of the High Representative, I would like to put you three questions. Perhaps I hope to obtain a written answer to these questions on this Libyan situation which is also dangerous for Europe. Are the persistent reports of Turkish arms deliveries to the Libyan Islamists camp correct, and if so, has the EU appealed to Turkey about this? I heard Mr. Gahler about this. Interesting question. What position does the EU take with regard to Russian arms supplies to the Libyan Government in Tobroek, which is also recognised by the EU? And finally, what measures is the EU taking to reverse the threats - and they have been repeatedly there - by the Islamic State from Libya, the huge flow of migrants and thousands of jihadists?

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: I do think that the situation is very critical and many members have already said it here. 400 000 people are fleeing within Libya itself and so many other people are seeking refuge elsewhere. The Mediterranean has become a perilous shortcut for hundreds of thousands. Since Skhirat's declaration, there's been hope. Now it will only be serious if all parties are going to sign the agreements, and the Libyans need our support to do so. I understand that the Commission is also ready to provide EUR 100 million to support the democratic transition.  Ladies and gentlemen, giving money will not be enough in my view. It is an essential issue, but we must dare to give support on the ground, together with the United Nations, with the knowledge and technical support of the police and the judiciary. We must dare to consider resuming police and military cooperation. EUBAM Libya, suspended, should resume operations. And as a final point, I would like to make a plea here to support human rights watch's request: let the guilty be tried by the International Criminal Court.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We must remember that the first victim of any war is the truth. If we lack truth here, many of our speeches are instable either with shallow demagogoy or utterly simple propaganda. This will not allow us to solve these problems. Europe is sick, and it is not in the way that the symptoms of the disease can be healed. We need to remove the causes of this disease, and the causes remain unknown to us and this is our main problem. Libya, like many other countries in Europe, North Africa and Asia, has been destroyed with the participation of Western powers. And as before in Iraq, Iraq was destroyed, giving us all the reasons except for the real reasons, and now we have a similar situation in Libya that we know a great deal except the truth about the causes of this state of affairs. This will certainly not allow us to improve the situation. We simply need to find out and get knowledge of the real causes from Western governments, because Europe is sinking, and we are just thinking about it here, just to sink evenly and in accordance. This is a disaster for European foreign policy.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, in 2011, as part of the Arab Spring, the United States and its European allies decided to take democracy to Libya, so they removed the dictator by deploying NATO. It is an interesting coincidence that Gaddafi had just initiated the introduction of the gold dinars, the single African currency, which would have replaced the dollar. The dictator was killed, but instead of democracy, anarchy ensued. The head of the U.N. mission in Libya says the divided country is in a state of disrepression and more repression than under Gaddafi. Stability and the creation of a functioning state are also in the european Union's fundamental interest. Indeed, if the war situation in the North African countries remains high, then together this and Angela Merkel's call will constitute an explosive mixture of migration to the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, allow me to wish Mr Mogherini a speedy recovery, who is not here with us today, but I would like to take this opportunity to thank you very much for the respect and availability you have for this institution, Parliament and the AFET Committee of which I am a member.  Today we are talking about Libya, but let us say frankly, countries such as Libya, Somalia, Yemen and others are unfortunately now without their own statehood. There are no more governments in these countries with which we can seriously talk, and that is the cause of the problems in these countries. On Libya, the context is much more complex due to clashes between factions, ethnic groups and popular traditions, which have been responsible for a long and bloody civil conflict. In such a situation, it is not easy to find reliable interlocutors. The Parliament of Tripoli is in fact hostage to a large number of oltranzist and turkish-type members of parliament, military leaders claim their legitimacy to power and the Government of Tobruk is in fact run by Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Unfortunately, we are now dealing not with a dictator, but with more dictators.  In this serious situation, the UN has played its part with Bernardino León, who has perseveredly initiated a series of important meetings aimed at repairing the political fabric torn apart by a fratricidal war. Europe must now give even stronger support to the UN initiative by seeking to achieve the objective of forming a government. The delicate agreements reached at the end of September to be lasting must be monitored day by day. That is why we must work as a Europe to ensure that León's work continues if possible.  If, then, as Europe, we really want to be protagonists in order to give stability and security in Libya, we must make an effort to put around the same table, not only local players, but above all countries such as Egypt, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, which, together with the Western powers, the United States and Russia, have put an end to a crisis that has been going on for too long.  Mr President, I would like to address you, who are also presiding over the Euro-Mediterranean, to try to bring a serious debate back to this House and to put the issue of the Euro-Mediterranean back at the centre of our policy.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, after the political discussions between the Libyan parties, which have come to an end, in Skhirat, Morocco - we must, once again, welcome the enormous mediation work done by Bernardino Leon - finally remains the most delicate part, the one that demands the most responsibility on the part of both sides; say yes or no. There is an urgent need for a government of national unity to finally get to work.  The threat of Daesh is spreading more than ever in Libya. There are now 5,000 Islamic State fighters in the country, including controlling the coastal city of Sirte. The attacks on the port of Sadra and on Benghazi show, unfortunately, the dynamism of the terrorist organization in Libya.  On the strength of this observation, I believe that the return of a State capable of controlling its borders, of defending its territory is an absolute necessity. The High Representative's statements in favour of the immediate allocation of EUR 100 million to the future Libyan government to assist in its mission should be welcomed.  I think it is essential that we are ready when this new government comes into place.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is four years since the Arab Spring, which led to the removal of the dictator Colonel Gaddafi in Libya. This was done with the significant participation of European countries that supplied weapons there. The overthrow of the dictator destabilised Libya, and the democracy imposed on the country collided with a different, centuries-old tradition. Today, we have two different centres of power in this country, and the chaos that smugglers and the Islamic State are exploiting dominates. This has a direct impact on Europe. The terrorists trained there are planning attacks on our continent, including the Holy See. From there, crowds of refugees head to our continent, compounding the migration crisis. Therefore, the Union should be firmly involved in the stabilisation process there on the ground, in particular in consultation with the United States and its NATO allies, as well as with the countries of North Africa.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Libya, liberated by Nicolas Sarkozy, is now sinking into chaos. Why did France and England wage war on Libya in the name of human rights? Of course, Gaddafi is no longer here to testify, but it is clear that today the liberation of Libya has provoked Islamization through Sharia law, unprecedented unemployment, the departure of investors, the asphyxiation of tourism, the destabilization of the Machrek, the splitting of the country, arms trafficking and the law of militias and above all an unprecedented wave of immigrants. Yes, weakened Libya is now giving peoples who are dislocating, leading to uprooting.  So I have only one warning for the European Union, because all this has been done thanks to the European Union, with the support of the European Union. What I would like to say today is that in Syria as in Libya, the European Union has an overwhelming share of responsibility and that today we must draw conclusions very quickly.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the situation in Libya is increasingly serious because of the prolongation of the conflict. Daily life, as the Commissioner told us, becomes more difficult. Increases the number of displaced and dead. The country's fragmentation facilitates the advance of terrorism, including Daesh's, and the trafficking of weapons, people and drugs throughout the region. There are many important efforts made in recent months with the various parties involved to facilitate the path to a political solution in the country. I would like to highlight the role of the United Nations and the special representative in this task. Since 20 September there has already been a proposal for agreement on the table, which is a sufficient basis for consensus. The situation on the ground calls for an urgent solution and no further details are appropriate. It is time for responsibility; it doesn't make much sense to continue to review a proposal that already contains, as I said, basic elements for the parties' consensus. I don't think any further delays are appropriate. The Skhirat process must be successfully completed, finalized. The turn of the Libyans has therefore come: they must take the reins of their own future, declare a ceasefire and appoint a government of national unity. It will have the important task of tacking fundamentalist radical terrorism and combating the many illicit traffickings that flow through the country and the entire region. Libya is a very important Mediterranean country, with a prominent geographical location and immediate neighbour of the European Union. What happens there affects many of us. The consequences of the power vacuum in the country are also evident in the trafficking of people whose aim is to cross the Mediterranean. I hope that Operation Sophia, which is just beginning tomorrow, will help to stop the mafias from acting so cruelly. The situation in Libya also has a clear impact on the already complex problem of the Sahel.  In conclusion, all the neighbouring countries on the two shores of the Mediterranean and the other actors involved must influence constructively in favour of a united, sovereign and democratic Libya, without interference that fuels violence. Libya is in grave danger and what it needs is peace, unity and stability.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, more than half a million people reached Europe this year via the Mediterranean and nearly three thousand have died crossing the sea. It is not only a humanitarian crisis but also a security crisis. The recently launched naval Common Security and Defence Policy mission to combat smuggling is welcome. However, we need a comprehensive response to the complex problem that we are facing. As long as there is no unity government that can exercise its legitimate authority over Libya, the situation is likely to deteriorate even further. The EU must put in more effort and support more actively the UN-led dialogue process. Libyans want and deserve peace. They should not be held hostage by a small minority that seeks to win this conflict by military means. Regional cooperation should be encouraged in place of destructive interference. We call on external parties to strictly respect the arms embargo and fully support the UN-led dialogue and the draft agreement on the table. The EU must remain fully committed, without taking any sides, to assisting the Libyan people, resolving the crisis to achieve peace and helping them to build strong government institutions.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us listen to the Commission. The Libyan tragedy mirrors the disastrous foreign policy of a NATO-allied European Union, served with the external interests of the United States, with its domestic henchmen, President Sarkozy, in mind.  The result is tribal chaos, that of a country moved between its east and west. Security chaos, that of territory abandoned to the barbaric hordes of the Islamic State and the networks of smugglers. A humanitarian chaos, with a migratory tsunami of about 1.5 million illegal immigrants, some of them Islamist terrorists. And, finally, a chaos that is now coming to us through your harmful migration policies.  To remedy this, it will be necessary to help again the meeting of the various Libyan factions and to deal with the issue of illegal immigrants on the spot. But it requires a policy that is not your policy, the worst policy. Will it still take the intervention of Russia and perhaps Egypt to avoid the worst you are preparing for us?

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we greet with hope and political will the agreement, the result, among others, of the tireless work of the representative of the United Nations, Bernardino León, whose term ended on the first of September, and which is the subject of pressure and intrigue on those who do not want peace in Libya and prefer war, which is most lucrative for them.  An agreement reached overcoming enormous difficulties and much skepticism—the worst enemy—in a country, moreover, ravaged by forty-two years of brutal dictatorship, by the subsequent war unleashed by mafias and traffickers faced and, if that were not, by the Daesh's growing presence in Darna. It is therefore important that this Parliament also supports this agreement, so that as soon as possible, and in any event before 20 October, the date on which Parliament's mandate expires, it can be implemented. It will also be necessary to provide the necessary financial resources to accompany the first steps and be credible, and this Parliament will have to respond to budgetary demands. Finally, we need Libyans to build their own unity in order to react against the common enemy, the Islamic State, on their own territory and before it is too late. They urge peace and ceasefire in Libya, for their people, first of all, and also for their neighbours, countries such as Tunisia, the victim of attacks such as Susa or the Bard National Museum for defending themselves and erecting a wall against traffickers on their borders. Commissioner, we need the European Union to act quickly and effectively, helping to overcome the obstacles that now arise at the United Nations, so that the agreement — the only one we have — is the basis for a unitary structure in Libya. If we do not succeed, you know that from a new territory razed in the south of the Mediterranean thousands of desperate people will be re-shipped and victims of the most abject of traffic and exploitation, heading to our beaches and coasts, but from there to Vienna, Berlin, Calais and London.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When we discuss Libya, we usually discuss the mistakes of the West and what has been done wrong. This question is, of course, justified, but it does not take us any further; rather the answer to the question why everything is going so slowly. There is an urgent need for the situation to return to normal, that is to say, for a statehood to be restored in Libya. There is an urgent need for a national unity government that can finally start its work. That is a matter for the Libyan people, as we know. But there is also a European responsibility, and we have to ask whether we can do more to do so. Because it is necessary, firstly because we need stability in this region – it is in our neighbourhood, Mare Nostrum. Secondly, because we must prevent the spread of Daish, and Libya is the gateway to Africa. Thirdly, because we have a refugee problem. Up to a million people are waiting to reach Europe. In other words, we need a sensible and reliable partner with whom we can solve these problems together.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Għal żmien twil ilna nittamaw li jintlaħaq ftehim favur stabilità fil-Libja. Imma jekk se nibqgħu f'sitwazzjoni fejn jibqa' i jintlaħaqx ftehim, nemmen li l-Ġnus Magħquda bl-appoġġ tal-Unjoni Ewropea u anke l-komunità internazzjonli għandhom jappoġjaw lil dawk kollha li lesti jilħqu ftehim u jwarrbu lilrbu min mhux lest jikkollabora għall-ġid ta' pajjiżu, b'mod partikolari jekk id-data tal-20 ta' Ottubru trid tinżamm. Nagħmilha. L-isforz tal-Ġnus Magħquda biex ikun hemm pro大ess ta' rikon大iljazzjoni fil-Libja u eventwalment gvern t'Għaqda Nazzjonali għandu jibqa' jkun appoġġjat. Nemmen li l-Libjani ġenwini jħarsu lejn il-Libja bħala art twelidhom, dik l-art fejn l-attakki vjolenti għandhom jieqfu u fejn għandha tirrenja l-istabilità u l-pa大i. Biex dan isir, iżda, hemm bżonn li l-partijiet kollha Libjani jkomplu jieħdu sehem b'mod attiv f'dan il-pro大ess politiku. Għalhekk nittama li naraw ftehim ta' pa大i li jiġi implimentat fil-prattika u jibda jwitti t-triq għal Libja stabbli u sigura.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, four years after taking to the streets for dignity, freedom and democracy, Libyans find themselves in a country characterised by political division and violence. The crisis has heavily affected the population, with civilian suffering, casualties, mass displacement and a spreading humanitarian crisis. Today it is high time for an act of courage and responsibility by all parties. The latest UN-brokered efforts represent a last chance. The negotiated text constitutes a fair, inclusive and sustainable solution for the country. Now it is up to the parties to demonstrate their real and genuine commitment to a new democratic Libya which is able to provide the peace, security and prosperity all Libyans ask for and deserve. The European Union has always stood ready to provide the necessary support but it is up to the negotiating parties alone to seize this last opportunity for peace.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The recent reports from Libya are simply disappointing. Nevertheless, although there has been no breakthrough so far, the example of Libya shows what the European Union is capable of by mobilising its diplomatic forces together with the United Nations. However, this robust foreign policy is not only necessary with regard to Libya, but the EU must also show its flag more clearly than before in the other trouble spots in the Middle East. As far as Libya is concerned, we must make it very clear to those responsible that there is no alternative to peace. The parties to the conflict must be aware that this opportunity that the country now has will not come back so quickly. And we need to know what further years of civil war can mean for our security and even more refugees for our social fabric.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at a decisive stage for the future of Libya.  At this time, the parties could find a compromise for a government of national unity, on the basis of the agreement defined in recent months, thanks to the fundamental work of Bernardino León and with the support of our High Representative Mogherini. The whole world is waiting to see whether or not there is any real political will on the part of the representatives of Tobruk and Tripoli to go all the way. Much news about these hours is not entirely encouraging, as Mrs Gomes also mentioned.  There are also many problems still to be resolved, from the representativeness of the interlocutors, to the management of the implementation of the agreement, to the growing humanitarian emergency in the country, up to the crucial need to re-establish a security framework in an area of conquest for the Islamic State and the scene of all kinds of trafficking.  The situation is still very tense, but it is our duty to continue to support every diplomatic effort without ever relaxing the political pressure on the parties towards the restoration of state authority, national pacification, which is necessarily in the hands and choices of the Libyans as a last resort. We cannot let such a strategic country in the region sink permanently into collapse, which would have catastrophic repercussions for Europe.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, if the European Union and the international community is to be successful, we will have to show that we have learned some lessons from the past, namely our own nations’ failings once again in post-conflict planning; how arms sales to Gaddafi from the European Union of more than EUR 800 million in five years came back to haunt us; how we must not let ourselves be complicit with security responses which do not respect democratic or legal norms – there must be no new Gaddafi; and that a moment of transition can itself be transitory. Benghazi, which was a symbol of resistance, is now one of destruction.  So today we must be sincere in seeking a peaceful reconciliation in the interests of the Libyan people themselves, and not only through the prism of controlling migration to our shores. That means support for security sector reform in future in relation to the country’s southern as well as its maritime borders, supporting its local authorities, and preventing groups from being recruited into ISIS-Daesh. Europe talks about creating hotspots for migration control, but the consequences of the failure of democratic transition in Libya have created a hotspot for terror. What is needed now is consistent European effort to help turn down the heat in the politics of Libya, for its security and for its people.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, four years after the toppling of Gaddafi, Libya suffers from an increasingly devastating political, economic, security and humanitarian crisis. I share the view that these problems would be best dealt with through a power-sharing agreement between the two factions in the country and the swift formation of a government of national accord.  This would also make it possible for Eunavfor Med – in phase II from tomorrow – to be more effective in stopping people smugglers in international and Libyan waters. As long as there is not a functioning unified Libyan state, people smugglers, warlords and terrorist groups will continue to profit from the chaos that has engulfed the country, leaving millions in misery and forcing thousands more to flee.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I believe that it is time to take a crucial step towards building a democratic civil state through national consensus in Libya and addressing the needs and aspirations of the Libyan people. The entire region is facing increasing destabilisation and terrorism. The EU must work with the international community to bring the conflicts to an end and to restore peace and security. Effective multilateralism in the past has shown that international crises can be resolved if all sides demonstrate that they are willing to restore political dialogue, to cooperate with other international actors and to implement effectively the agreements signed. Moreover, restoring a safe situation in Libya will help to reduce the number of migrants arriving in Europe and the pressure on our external borders. In order to allow migrants to remain in their home countries, Libya needs stability, and the democratic rights of the Libyan people must be ensured.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the situation in Libya highlights the new challenges for the European Union. In the refugee crisis we have over 400,000 refugees fleeing the civil war and coming to Europe. The question is who is supporting the jihadists right now in Libya, as in Syria. What is Turkey's role? What is the role of other forces?  Is the Commission aware that, according to journalistic information, the ship HADDAD 1 which left Alexandretta with the aim of going to Libya, in an area in Misrata where the jihadists exist, was arrested outside Crete with illegal weapons containing 5,000 weapons and 500,000 bullets? Do you have a picture in the Commission of where these weapons that left a turkish port were going? What about illegal weaponry in these matters? Who now equips the jihadists?

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the crisis in Libya and the two warring countries were among the main causes of some of the tragic events with innocent people that we have witnessed in the past months. Here is the place to congratulate the UN Special Envoy for Libya Bernardino Leon on the efforts he has made in drawing up a peace plan for the country.  Of course, no such document is perfect. Unfortunately, at the moment, the two governments in Libya are not signalling that they intend to sign the agreement, and this must happen by 20 October at the latest. It is necessary for the European Union, in the face of Mrs Mogherini, to make every effort to bring the two sides back to the negotiating table as soon as possible and to form a government of national unity. Otherwise, we will show that diplomacy is not a way of success in the region and leave the door to future tragedies wide open.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are all aware that many refugees from Libya make the perilous journey across the Mediterranean and very often find only death there. This is a sad end, but not the beginning of the problem. The current situation is due to the fact that Libya has been in turmoil for several years. Political and diplomatic consensus must therefore be found as soon as possible on how to help Libya get back on its feet as quickly as possible and that its institutions are able to enforce law and order in the country. But this is a complex task, given that the US and other NATO countries have been involved in breaking the country's original governing structure and continue to intervene nationally in the country. But the consequences of the war, poor postwar reconstruction, and the country's rather complicated stratification make stabilizing the country seem in sight. The European Union should therefore step up diplomatic and humanitarian efforts in Libya. Now that we have been involved in how bad this country is today, we could plead guilty and work hard to make amends.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, the Commissioner gave some detail on the aid that is available to Libya, including some additional EUR 100 million. That is in addition to already existing programmes. Can you confirm, Commissioner, that this generous aid going forward will be connected to guarantees on such important issues as freedom from persecution and discrimination for Christians and other religious minorities?  Secondly, under Colonel Gaddafi, Libya armed the Irish Republican Army – terrorists who were responsible for thousands of deaths and many victims who are still living in Northern Ireland with trauma and injury. Speaking to the Northern Ireland Affairs Committee in Westminster, a UK Government minister claimed that GBP 900 million of Libya’s frozen assets in the UK could not be used as compensation for these victims because that contravened EU law. Can you confirm if this is the case? If so, will you work with the victims of Libyan-sponsored terrorism in Northern Ireland to remove the barriers to appropriate compensation and right a terrible wrong?

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you so much for this very rich discussion and for this interesting exchange which I shall convey to the High Representative, of course. We shall continue to support the efforts of the United Nations Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) in the next few weeks and, of course, we hope that an agreement can be signed by all parties in the coming days. We are confident all the parties involved realise there is no time to waste and that the time has come to think about Libya’s future. Libya’s economy is already collapsing and its social fabric is being destroyed. We stand ready to sanction those who, during the past year, have proven they were bent on sabotaging the talks. The European Union will not accept that Libya splits. The European Union will not accept that any party takes over and imposes its rule by force. The European Union will not accept that Libya’s neutral financial institutions – I am thinking of the national oil company, the central bank and the Libyan investment agency – cease to be neutral and are engulfed in this partisan struggle. It is their neutrality that has kept the country together – only just – and it is their neutrality that will keep the country together in the future.  This is, I think, our moral obligation as the European Union.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council by Elee Valenciano, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the death penalty (O-000103/2015 - B-0761/2015) (2015/2879(RSP))

name: Elena Valenciano
text: Author. – Mr President, World Day Against the Death Penalty is commemorated on the 10th. It is a good time for the European Union to re-entrust its international leadership in efforts to abolish capital punishment and for a universal moratorium on executions. Where are we? Well, there's good news—few—and a lot of bad news. I'm going to start the hard way. Fifty-eight countries in the world still maintain the death penalty in their legal system. Twenty-two of them carried out executions in 2014. Some states apply the death penalty to an alarmingly high number of people. The information, by the way, is very difficult to add, because there are countries that do not provide data on their executions. This is the case for China and Vietnam, very important countries, practically partners of the European Union. They hide information that we should strongly demand, because, moreover, the lack of data on China destroys any statistics we need to make a real assessment of the application of the death penalty in the world. So, this is my first conclusion: the European Union must require the countries with which it maintains important relations certain data on the number of executions that occur under its civil and military laws. Executions in countries with data decreased in 2014 by 20% compared to 2013. In some specific countries, however, executions have not only not declined, but have increased in the same period of time. The dishonor for executions is headed by Iran, with 289 executions announced in 2014, and Saudi Arabia, with 130 executions that same year. By the way, our most precious ally, the United States of America, is way up in the death penalty implementation table—35 executions in 2014. Of the 607 people executed in 2014, 70% were in only three countries: Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia. In 2014, the United States of America, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia and Pakistan executed people with mental, physical and intellectual disabilities. The second part of my speech I want to dedicate to what we call the 'global death row', that is, those who have been sentenced and who have not yet been executed: the condemned who wait. Nearly 30% more people were sentenced to death in 2014 than in 2013. Thus, the global death row not only does not diminish, but increases. And we also think that the actual data is far superior to those we know. Egypt, with 509; Nigeria, with 659; Pakistan, with 231, and Bangladesh, with 142, top the conviction rankings in 2014. Egypt and Nigeria record a huge increase in the number of these convictions. Our ally, the United States of America, is back high in the sentence table, with 72 death sentences in 2014. Worldwide, more than 19,000 people were sentenced to death by the end of 2014, and of them 8,500 in Pakistan alone, a country that, as you know, has lifted the moratorium to which it had committed. This afternoon's debate was driven by political groups in this Parliament's Subcommittee on Human Rights. We want to know what measures the European Union has put in place to advance the abolition of the death penalty and, in particular, in its bilateral relations with the countries that maintain it, especially those in which convictions are being increased. Personally, I would also like to know to what extent we are prepared to push from the institutions of the European Union. Are we even willing to sacrifice our negotiation of agreements with some countries to demand moratorium and abolition? Are we ready? Some countries are very different from us and it will be very difficult to reach agreements with them, but some are very similar. Some share our vision: for example, the United States of America. I believe that we are entitled to add — and we can afford it — to the difficulty of the TCE negotiation the moratorium and abolition of the death penalty. You see, it's about saving lives. It is about the European Union helping to save lives, fulfilling its commitment to saving lives. Also in their relations with third countries.

name: President. –
text: Do you accept a blue-card question from Mr Korwin-Mikke?

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Frankly, I think we'd better get on with the debate.

name: President. –
text: Thank you for that frank answer. I now give the floor to President-in-Office of the Council, Nicolas Schmit.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this very important and very crucial question because the abolition of the death penalty lies at the heart of our European values. No state should have a right to decide on the life and death of its citizens. We all believe that, and I am quoting, ‘a just and necessary punishment must never exclude the dimension of hope and the goal of rehabilitation’. These are the words pronounced by Pope Francis in front of the US Congress recently. Since 1983, the ‘no’ to capital punishment is part of the acquis communautaire, it is part of who we are. It is, then, an honour to address this plenary debate only days away from 10 October, the 13th World and Europe Day against the death penalty. The end of the death penalty is something that is worth fighting for. Let us not forget our own history. Still in the 1970s executions took place in Western Europe and I remember that in one of the big countries a Socialist president abolished the death penalty in 1982. Behind the Iron Curtain executions took place till the late 1980s but today the European Union is 100% free from capital punishment. Things can change. We can and must be a force for this change. So we have to be clear on one thing: never be afraid to raise the issue of abolition as part of our external action. It must be a cornerstone of our own European foreign policy. Ten years ago only 59 countries had fully abolished the death penalty. Now there are 101 of us. Ten years ago, 41 countries carried out executions. In 2014 the number went down to 22, a lot less, although still too many. Many countries have ended capital punishments in practice. Others have taken steps to narrow the scope of the death penalty. Today 140 countries are abolitionist in law or in practice. However, the grim side of the statistics is that still in 2015 thousands of people were executed or sentenced to death and thousands of people are on death row worldwide. And the number of death sentences went up between 2013 and 2014, a scary statistic. You mentioned it in your presentation. The abolition of the death penalty worldwide requires all our best energies, all our political commitment. The use of the death penalty for drug offences is a very emblematic and cruel aspect of death penalty use. The international human rights law is clear: drug crimes do not constitute most serious crimes for which capital punishment may be prescribed. Unfortunately, many Asian countries still retain the death penalty for those crimes, including as a mandatory form of punishment. In Iran at least 75% out of this year’s 660 executions have been related to drug crimes. On a smaller but still significant scale, the same happens in Saudi Arabia and other countries. But this is not the only worrying trend. The death penalty is still applied for crimes which again fall outside the category of most serious ones. This includes economic crimes, apostasy, adultery or even sexual relationships between consenting adults. Furthermore, despite explicit international law provisions, some countries sentence and even execute minors and mentally disabled persons. We also cannot ignore the fact that many death sentences are the products of unfair trials, often without appeals, guarantee or clemency procedures. Some countries resort to the cruellest of execution methods such as public beheadings or crucifixions, and many refuse to notify the families of death row inmates prior to executions. Let there be no doubt the EU is a leading actor in the abolitionist cause. Abolition is embodied in strong, rigorous and effective EU guidelines on the matter. The fight against the death penalty features as a top priority in the new action plan on human rights and democracy which we adopted last July. Throughout 2015 the EU has used all diplomatic tools to advance the cause of worldwide abolition. We condemn the continuing extensive use of the death penalty in parts of the world some of which are at our doorstep. Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, Indonesia, Belarus, Egypt, Japan, Singapore, China, Vietnam and the United States of America were a particular focus of attention. More than 30 statements were issued and demarches were carried out in many other countries, based on the minimum standards defined by international law and the EU guidelines on that penalty. We have been the most vocal advocate of abolition worldwide. Still, I know some of you believe the EU has not always been as loud as it should be. Let me be frank: condemnation is important but it is often not enough. Ultimately, I believe there is no alternative to engagement with those who do not share our views and values. This is the most effective contribution we can give to the cause of abolition. For this reason, we are intensifying our dialogue with the most fervent retentionist countries at all levels. We are constantly stepping up efforts, especially in countries where there is a spike in executions or the reintroduction of capital punishment, sometimes after decades of moratorium. Our individual human rights country strategies have identified the abolition of the death penalty as a top priority in all retentionist countries. Our political or dedicated human rights dialogues constantly feature the issue on their agendas, even when we meet with like-minded countries such as the United States or Japan. Let me assure you that the question of the death penalty is raised with all interlocutors concerned, beyond any strategic considerations. We are talking to our counterparts in Pakistan, Iran, Saudi Arabia and also other countries, and we make it clear that the death penalty is not a remedy to terrorism or criminality, or a question of justice for the victim’s family. We will keep on this double track: challenge and engage. Bilateral relations are not the only forum for raising this kind of issue. We are also exploring our regional connections. For example, we are conscious that Africa represents the biggest concentration of countries which are abolitionist in practice, and it could potentially become the next death-free continent after Europe. This is why the EU actively supported the recent steps taken by the African Union towards the adoption of an additional protocol to the African Charter on Human and Peoples’ Rights on the abolition of the death penalty. We are currently planning a regional campaign on the Asian continent with the aim of animating the public debate on the question of the right to life and human dignity. On an even bigger stage, the EU has worked extensively on the United Nations General Assembly resolution on a moratorium on executions. I am proud to say that, thanks to the EU’s extensive lobbying and support, the moratorium was adopted in December 2014 with an unprecedented number of 117 votes in favour and a record number of 95 co-sponsors. The EU can be a beacon for abolitionists worldwide but we need to build partnerships on a global scale to succeed, and our success on the moratorium tells us something; we are not alone in this fight. Mr President, I would like to take the opportunity to express my gratitude for the European Parliament’s constant and fervent dedication to the abolitionist cause. This is reflected in numerous resolutions and dedicated debates but also in missions in third countries where honourable Members do not shy away from raising the issue of executions, even with the most difficult interlocutors. We can count on a global network of partners advancing human dignity, and the global moratorium on the death penalty is at the core of our foreign policy. This is about the foundations and the fundamental values of Europe, and we will keep engaging with our partners on this issue for a world where no state can dispose of the life of its citizens.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I would like to inform you, ladies and gentlemen, that Members of the European Parliament cannot use the 'blue card' procedure against representatives of the Council, but they can, of course, be against other members of Parliament.

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr According to Amnesty International, most executions are taking place today in Communist China. The dictatorships follow Iran and Saudi Arabia. In Saudi Arabia, there is talk of executions as the only form of public entertainment, alongside football. As with Islamic State, executions are carried out through beheadings and crucifixions. To take note of the stories and images of these executions is a study of evil and barbarism. At the same time, the issue of the death penalty cannot be simplified to be about the procedures alone. The fundamental issue for any rule of law must be human dignity. Based on the Judeo-Christian ethic on which our civilisation is based, criminals should be punished, atone for their actions and then given another chance. Society condemns the crime, but not the criminal. The death penalty does not make this distinction. The death penalty violates the fundamental principle of the right to life. As the European Parliament today celebrates the thirteenth World Day against the Death Penalty, it is important to highlight the values on which the European Union is based and our duty to always place human dignity at the forefront on the basis of those values.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the death penalty is the cruellest, most inhuman and degrading punishment, it violates the right to life and, whatever form it takes, it remains a violent punishment that cannot have a place in today's criminal justice system.  In many countries, governments justify the use of the death penalty by arguing that it is a deterrent to violent crime, makes society safer, reduces drug-related crime, is enforceable because it is supported by most public opinion and provides the best cost-effective cost-effective solution to violent crime. Many argue that the abolition of the death penalty causes a higher crime rate, but studies in Canada, for example, refute this theory. In 2003, 27 years after the abolition of the death penalty in Canada, the murder rate had fallen by 44%.  Far from making society safer, the death penalty has proved to have a brutalising effect on society, being the extreme sanction that a state can impose on a person, serves only to approve the use of force and to persist in the cycle of violence. Once criminals are aware that they have committed a capital crime they no longer have any interest in reducing their potential, on pain of not committing new murders or crimes. If, for example, armed robbery involves the death penalty, the robber has nothing to lose in killing any witnesses during the escape attempt.  At the same time, it should be remembered that the use of the death penalty for drug-related offences is a violation of international law. Countries that put people to death for drug-related crimes include Indonesia, Saudi Arabia, China, Iran, Malaysia and Singapore, and there is no clear evidence that the use of the death penalty for such crimes acts as a more effective deterrent than long-term detention.  I believe that politics must assert its leadership by putting human rights first, opposing the death penalty and explaining to its voters why these actions cannot be taken by a state. Research by Amnesty International reports that public support for the death penalty is mainly based on a desire to be free from crime. And here, too, surveys conducted in the United States, for example, show that support for the death penalty fell from 65 % to 48 % when life imprisonment was proposed as an option.  Finally, society cannot accept violence and the sacrifice of human rights as a cost-cutting measure. The decision to take away a human life should not be based on economic reasons. Using the death penalty to reduce the prison population is a vain argument. The United States, for example, has a prison population of two and a half million people, of which 3 000 have been sentenced to death, if they were all convicted and killed it would not change anything compared to the prison population.  Hence all this our 'no' vote as Socialists and Democrats to the death penalty and the need for the European Union to take decisive action to abolish it everywhere.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR-Fracti. – Every execution makes me quiet. Every execution is a defeat and a proof of impotence. A defeat for all mankind. A defeat for humanity. A sign of impotence to do justice in a humane way and not in a barbaric or degrading way. It is true that the number of executions worldwide has decreased and that many countries have abolished the death penalty in recent years, but we are far from a global abolition and in some countries the figures are nothing short of chilling. They are often state secrets, but we do know, for example, that Iran executed 600 people in the first half of this year alone, often because of non-violent acts such as adultery or drug offences. We are also seeing a worrying trend in other countries. I therefore welcome the initiative of my own federal government last week at the UN Human Rights Council to put the death penalty back on the international agenda. If the EU institutions take on an even greater emphasis in the fight against the death penalty, if they put forward not only economic interests, but also human rights and the fight against the death penalty, then they will find our full support in this Parliament.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. "The death penalty is a peculiar sign of barbarism," victor Hugo said. The European Union is defined by its values and democratic principles. We must be a key player in ending the death penalty around the world, because we cannot tolerate barbarism. And on the eve of World Day Against the Death Penalty, it is up to us to set an example for all those countries that sentenced nearly 2,500 people to death in 2014.  We must also be exemplary with ourselves. Under no circumstances should any Member State consider reintroducing the death penalty in Europe: it would violate the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. It's a monumental task and we can't carry it out alone. That is why we need the United States to complete the path to total abolition in all its states and to deal commonly with us to make this practice disappear completely. According to Amnesty International, China, Iran and Saudi Arabia are on the podium in executions. In China, the figures remain state secret. Saudi Arabia makes extensive use of public executions: Ali Mohamed al-Nimr, who was arrested at the age of 17 for demonstrating and asking for democracy for his country, is sentenced to beheaded to death. But let me tell you about Iran. In the first half of this year, rohani's so-called "moderate" government has executed nearly seven hundred people: three people a day. If we asked Atena Daemi or Atena Farghadani his opinion, they would not be able to give it to us, because both young Iranians are in prison for criticizing on social media, with cartoons and vignettes, executions and human rights violations perpetrated by the Government of Iran.  But I want to think that, if you could, what you would certainly tell us is that this endeavor is worthwhile, that we cannot tolerate barbarism in any of its manifestations and the death penalty is the cruellest of them all. We can't let them down.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, no act is more barbaric than the death penalty, regardless of the conditions under which it was carried out. It is a universal fight but it is a fight that seems to be more than ever on the agenda.  The number of abolitionist countries continues to increase, of course, and it is to be welcomed. The United States, however, remains a stain on democracies, including mentally deficient people. There are growing sources of concern. Countries that had decided on a moratorium resumed executions, such as Pakistan and Indonesia. Worse, Senegal, which had abolished the death penalty, is now trying to restore it, which would be a first and therefore a dramatic breach. Others, who are among those who practice the most capital punishment, see the number of executions increase, such as Iran and Saudi Arabia. The fight against drugs, but also against terrorism, serves as a pretext for the increase in executions after summary trials, as we have seen in Egypt. Countries that were thought to be immune to this have reinstated the death penalty in this area, as Tunisia has just done, where a moratorium has been in place since 1991.  Our countries are not immune to going backwards, as the statements of Viktor Orban last May showed. Too many people are surfing on unhealthy populism. So yes, more than ever we must convince, support popular education programmes in this area, ensure that European programmes are never used to directly or indirectly finance these barbaric practices. More than ever, we must remain vigilant.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The death penalty is not an adequate response to murder and crime. Where the state rises to become a judge of life and death, it is not justice that takes its course, but revenge and retribution. This attitude is the basis of the EU's policy of advocating the abolition of the death penalty worldwide, and it has been successful: 101 countries have abolished the death penalty for all crimes, and 33 states have abolished it in practice, but not in law. Unfortunately, in some countries, there has been a drastic increase in executions, and unfortunately seven states resumed or partially ended long-standing moratoria in 2014. The death penalty can be imposed under international law for the most serious crimes, but the death penalty is used for drug offences in 33 countries, for example in China, Iran or Saudi Arabia. Here, too, the EU is committed to the abolition of the death penalty. At the same time, however, the EU and EU Member States in these countries are involved in anti-drugs programmes through the funding of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime. The independent examination of these UN programmes in Pakistan and Iran raises fears that there is a direct link with the use of the death penalty. The EU must ensure that human rights standards are consistently applied in all anti-drugs programmes it supports and that information on this programme is available. The abolition of the death penalty for drug offences should therefore be a prerequisite for financial and technical support in this area.

name: President. –
text: Do you accept a blue-card question from Mr Korwin-Mikke?

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE).
text: – I prefer to continue with the debate. (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8) from Mr Korwin-Mikke)

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am no fan of the death penalty, although I am a fan of democracy. We have heard the anti-death penalty view over and over again in this Chamber and, in general, I share it. However, if I were to ask my constituents what they thought, opinion would be very divided indeed as to whether somebody who deliberately and callously takes a life should have the potential of losing their own as punishment. When we look more broadly, ask me to condemn the Saudi Arabian injustice system and I will – not because of the death penalty itself, because that is a decision for a sovereign government, but because of its systematic unfairness and the crimes for which the penalty can be given. So I do not support the death penalty, but also I believe it is wrong to politicise trade to enforce one view over others, and to say that we believe this is the only valid view. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Whilst Mr Arnott and I normally agree on most things, on this we disagree. Whilst my colleague takes a more moderate view – and I believe some crimes could be forgiven only by God and I hasten to make that judgment come forward – would he not agree with me that the primacy of democracy is the single most important factor in any nation-state and for any politician, and that if the people of a country democratically decide through a referendum to have the death penalty restored, that should be respected by any true democrat?

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I believe in the principle of democracy and, yes, if the people of a country wished to bring that in, then of course I would have to accept it. But equally, I would expect Mr Etheridge to accept that, if my personal view were to win out, you should not have the death penalty. That is what democracy is. However, we are at a point where I do not believe that we can fundamentally trust the state always to get it right and to have that power of life or death, which cannot be undone.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the abolition of the death penalty is essential for the protection of human dignity, which is fundamental in the effective protection of human rights. Let us be clear: when we speak of the abolition of the death penalty, we are not saying that a crime is to remain unpunished. Without getting engrossed in the debate about punishments being proportionate to the crime, there is, in relation to the death penalty, an even more fundamental issue at stake. We cannot tolerate the imposition of a punishment which is itself a violation of human rights since it attacks the very core of human dignity. When one considers that vulnerable persons, such as minors, are still subject to capital punishment, and when one sees that the death penalty is often associated with judicial systems which do not aspire to – never mind attain – the highest standards of fair process, then the EU must show a stronger commitment towards abolishing this punishment worldwide. It is good that the European institutions and Member States are acting to raise awareness against the death penalty on the day dedicated to this, but stronger and ongoing commitment is needed. We need to strengthen our political and financial support to encourage public debate; strengthen public opposition through education and awareness raising; support strategies for replacing the death penalty; and take concrete steps to secure legal assistance and fair trials.

name: President. –
text: Do you accept a blue-card question from Mr Korwin-Mikke?

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – No I do not. I would prefer that the debate goes on. (The speaker refused to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8) from Mr Korwin-Mikke)

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the abolition of the death penalty in all countries of the world is one of the main objectives of the European Union's human rights policy. The death penalty is clearly incompatible with humanity and human dignity, and studies and research have shown that they do not deter crimes committed through violence.  The European Union is the largest donor of funds in the efforts of civil society organisations around the world to abolish the death penalty. We are the first to adopt rules prohibiting trade in goods used for the application of capital punishment, as well as torture and ill-treatment, as well as the provision of technical assistance related to such goods used in this heinous practice. We, the European Union, have a duty to encourage a consistent and constructive dialogue, to raise public awareness through education and information campaigns, to get countries using capital punishment to abolish it or, at the very least, to introduce a moratorium as a first step in this direction.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr There is nothing as definitive as death, nothing as irreversible. Everyone, including courts, sometimes mistakes. In the vast majority of countries, it sometimes happens that an imprisoned person after many, many years requests and receives a suseve when new evidence can show that one has been innocently convicted. But death is irreversible. There is no way back to life, once that punishment has been imposed. The state is supposed to protect and not end people's lives. The death penalty is brutal. It is non-civilised, it is illegitimate and it is inhumane. That is why I appeal today both to the Presidency and to the Commission, which is conspicuous by its absence, to take this as an absolute priority to ensure that it is abolished everywhere in the world where it still occurs.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as you know, tomorrow the King of Spain, whose family has a huge friendship with the royal family of Saudi Arabia, one of the champions countries, is involved in the application of the death penalty. Perhaps it would not be wrong for this House to move this concern to the king of Spain tomorrow and for the Spanish Deputies to ask the king of Spain to use his influence with the Saudi monarchy to end, at once, the death penalty. It is going to be difficult for other Spanish Members to find out about this, because there are not many in this debate. They don't seem to care. On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that while we are all against the death penalty, it gives the impression that the European Union has too many trading partners applying the death penalty. Some of these partners are required to be in the World Trade Organization, but we do not ask them to abolish the death penalty. I believe that an economic giant such as the European Union could perhaps afford fewer parties and fewer commemorations and apply more demands for its trading partners to respect human rights.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, like others I welcome the EU’s opposition to the death penalty but would agree that we need consistency of approach. I believe that the EU’s human rights interventions can be effective, especially when they are made in the context of negotiations that genuinely matter for the countries concerned. Take the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSP+), for example, or assistance to law enforcement institutions. I also agree with others who have made the point that the quality of justice in so many countries that maintain the death penalty leaves much to be desired. Indeed, the use of the death penalty can be seen in some of those countries as a political instrument. Like others, I find it regrettable that Pakistan has lifted its moratorium on the death penalty and resumed executions, including of some of those tried under the Musharraf regime. However, I welcome the recent stay of execution in Pakistan for Abdul Basit, who is a severely disabled person, and I trust that the EU will continue to pursue this case within the context of GSP+.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems clear to me that the death penalty is the most degrading, the highest violation of human rights.  I agree with what the chairman of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, Mrs Valenciano, said at the beginning. Now, but here the point is this: I would make a small reasoning. We are used to thinking, here in Europe, that the death penalty is something medieval, ancient. We take it for granted that it no longer exists. Yet we continue to have very great trade relations with countries where the death penalty is something that is on the agenda and, above all, I want to refer to what we consider to be our state, not to say closer, friender, the one from which we have received the most influence, I am talking about the United States of America, from which we have taken economic policy, from which we take influence from all points of view.  Well, when we think that the death penalty is still in place in the United States of America, it seems almost absurd, and yet it is, and we cannot even force it to be abolished in the state with which we have the greatest friendship. That should make us think.

name: President. –
text: By the way, congratulations on your mission on behalf of the European Parliament to Kyrgyzstan. Do you accept a blue-card question from Mr Korwin-Mikke?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Thank you, Mr President, I think it is more interesting to continue with the debate. (The speaker refused to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, thank you, among other things, for your beautiful Czech. I would like to point out that the European Union is indeed a leader in abolishing the death penalty, and in this sense its efforts must be appreciated. So far, no scientific arguments have been put forward to support the fact that the death penalty has any deterrent effect on people who commit capital crimes. There has been no deterrent effect. There has also been no increase in the number of these capital crimes, if the death penalty has been abolished, I think it is very important that it be heard here.  I would like the European Union not to give up on its efforts – from the moratorium to the complete abolition of the death penalty. However, where it fails, that is, if there are still states that will carry out the death penalty, I think it would be necessary to insist on some minimum standards. Firstly, the death penalty can only be imposed for a deliberate and violent crime, never retroactively, always only to persons who are over eighteen years of age, never to pregnant women, mothers of newborns and mentally ill persons. Of course, it must be based on compelling evidence. The convicted person should also have the right to appeal or request a change of sentence at any time after it has been granted. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that Slovak Prime Minister Fico wrote the book The Death Penalty in 1998. I would advise him to look at it again, because what he describes in it suggests so much of it to refugees, and it would be good for him to think about it.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too fully endorse what our President of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, Elena Valenciano, said. With this resolution, we reaffirm our commitment to combating the death penalty globally, in a world where Iran, Saudi Arabia and China top the list of the worst. We also show concern about the application of capital punishment for terrorism and drug trafficking crimes in countries where there are no adequate procedural safeguards and where police and judicial persecution of suspects may hide political motivations, such as in China, against Uighurs in Pakistan, where the moratorium was shamefully lifted, or in Equatorial Guinea, although linked to the Community of Portuguese-speaking Countries , to the shame of this community. We also draw attention to the complicity of certain Member States in the execution of capital punishments in third countries through financial support to combat drug trafficking, which is unacceptable.  That is why we want the European Union to work closely to ensuring that funds to combat drug trafficking in certain countries are only provided if the country abolishes the death penalty — as a matter of principle, but also because these policies disproportionately affect the most vulnerable in drug chains. The European Union must also be firm and vigilant in banning the export of drugs that can be used for the application of capital penalties, maintaining pressure on its pharmaceutical industry over new drugs and practices used in third countries, such as the United States of America.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, just the other day, it was announced in Saudi Arabia that they would behead a young man and then crucifie him in public view. This is not only an insult to Saudi Arabia, it is an insult to all of us, which we may oppose, but our governments and the European Union, in fact, are doing nothing but rhetoric.  In Iran, they hang people in public, hang them on cranes, in public view, but at the same time, Ms. Mogherini visited Iran's leader and was unable to whisper two words about the convictions. It stood only in the resulting economic interests, in the face of the lifting of sanctions against Iran. So what we need to do is demand that the leaders of the European Union report these situations to the leaders of these countries, call it out. And when Mr Schulz visits Iran tomorrow, he should not only stand up to the interests of the finances, refer to them, but also whisper two words about this vile violation of human rights.  And one last sentence, the United States applying this method, has crime in the United States decreased at all?

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as many other speakers have already mentioned, this Saturday people all over the world will stand up against the death penalty. That includes in the UK, where support for the death penalty for the first time this year is below 50% – something I am very pleased to have noted. We all have to continue to condemn those countries that make the greatest use of the death penalty, and like other colleagues I single out here the case of Iran. I am very pleased that diplomatic relations between the EU and Iran are becoming normalised, but I am disturbed that we have not seen more public condemnation from the EU of the escalation in the use of the death penalty under President Rouhani. Lastly, I am also disappointed that none of my UK Conservative colleagues appear to be here in the Chamber for this debate. In the past they have often allowed their Group to have a free vote on death penalty resolutions or to abstain. I hope that policy will change this week in the face of the continuing massive use of the death penalty by many undemocratic regimes across the world.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Mr President, almost unanimously, the parliamentarians here condemn the death penalty. The death penalty is inhumane, degrading, barbaric, we can never say it enough. Moreover, contrary to popular belief, it is not a deterrent. Let us look at the phenomenon in the United States, and this has been recalled by several of my colleagues.  Yet the list of countries that still kill is long. In Europe, vigilance must be de rigueur in the face of populists who would see the death penalty as a solution to all the ills of society. Elsewhere, we all remember the face of Ali Al—Nimr, the 21-year-old Saudi man arrested in Qatif for taking part in a demonstration for democracy. I would like here not to describe the horror of punishment, it is indescribable, but, on the contrary, to salute the hope of Ali, of this youth, of this beautiful and strong youth which manifests itself and mobilizes for the advent of a more just society.  In conclusion, since the representative of the Council is here, I have two questions to ask him. Is the Council ready to fight for Ali, for democracy, for life, against barbarism? Is the Council prepared to impose respect for human rights, the right to life rather than the sale of arms as a rule of international negotiation?

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – Mr President, one of the european Community's greatest human rights achievements is the abolition of the death penalty throughout Europe. Not only in the Member States of the European Union, but also in European countries outside the European Union. In particular, the European Community's ambition to try to spread this around the world is particularly important, to try to ensure that countries outside Europe that still use the death penalty will be able to de-go down this path in the future. More recently, however, this system has been challenged from the inside, because the leader of a Member State of the European Union, the Hungarian Government, was Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who announced that he would examine the reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary. This is unacceptable. This goes against everything we think about Europe, which is the European civilisation heritage for us.  The fact that the European Community, not only our institutions, but also the Member States, has been able to act on this is not only a proof of how strong these values are within the European Union, but also that if we act as hard as possible against a Member State heading towards dictatorship, the Government of the Member States will back down, just as the Orban government has backed down on the death penalty.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, more than 2,000 people have been hanged during the presidency of iran's so-called moderate leader Rouhani.
