According to Amnesty International, 700 people were executed in the first half of this year in the first half of this year and are expected to exceed 1,000 by the end of the year. It's the world's largest number of executions per capita. At the end of the week, President Schulz will fly to Tehran. Mr President Schulz, I ask you, as the representative of Europe, not to forget human rights when creating a nuclear deal with Iran.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am very concerned by the fact that, in opposition to the general trend of recent decades, an increasing number of countries have enacted laws permitting the death penalty for drug-related offences. I therefore strongly support the call on the Commission to mainstream the campaign to abolish the death penalty in new foreign policy and external relations, and to have talks with third countries that are responsible for a significant rise in the number of executions or for restarting executions. The death penalty is the ultimate cruel, inhumane and degrading punishment, which violates the right to life as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and an act of torture unacceptable to states respecting human rights. We need to stick to our strong position against the death penalty, establishing a universal moratorium with a view to the global abolition of capital punishment as a key objective of the Union’s human rights policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, all the Member States of the European Union have now abolished the death penalty, as its abolition was a prerequisite for their accession to the European Union. The death penalty, however, continues to apply to countries such as the United States, China and many countries in the Muslim world, such as Saudi Arabia and Iran. The right to life should not be taken away from anyone and in any way. The sentences imposed on a defendant, following a fair trial, must be, on the one hand, punitive and, on the other, dissuasive.  On the basis of these principles, it is unacceptable for certain governments, which openly or covertly propose the reintroduction of the death penalty, thus questioning respect for human dignity and human rights. However, for specific heinous crimes or offences, heavy penalties must be imposed, which will be exemplary and dissuasive, but which do not go far enough in imposing the last sentences, which is the imposition of the death penalty. I am therefore in favour of the cessation of the death penalty throughout the world.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the death penalty offends the value of man, turning the convict into an object, for the purpose of example, and invalidates the very concept of human rights, since it prematurely terminates human status. That is why the death penalty has been banned, in accordance with the Second Protocol to the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, as well as by a number of other texts of international law. The European Union is founded on the values of the protection of human dignity and human rights and aims to promote precisely those values, in accordance with Articles 2 and 3 of its founding Treaty. The Union must therefore promote, more actively, the abolition of the death penalty in the countries with which it deals economically and politically. We must do whatever it takes to end this barbarity once and for all.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – So it is a subject that we must pay close attention to at all times. Abolishing the death penalty is a civilisational achievement that we must defend at all costs. And here, the European Union can be very proud to defend the absolute right to life. Of course, the countries that have the death penalty have some kind of treatment that are worthy of every judgment we condemn. And I think that the European Union and the European Parliament, which can impose so-called political pressure with countries that have the death penalty, are also stepping up this political pressure. And I think it is right that, when the European Union is also negotiating with countries on various trade agreements that have the death penalty, it should point to this in particular as a strong argument that trade agreements are not signed with such countries.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the oral question asks the Council to use its power to pressurise those countries that still have the death penalty to abolish it. If only the Council would reply that it is not doing anything because it is none of its business. The EU has no right to tell civilised countries that they should not execute the worst of their criminals – and I mean criminals and not political opponents. I cannot think of a single reason why British criminals, such as the Moors murderers, the Yorkshire Ripper and Robert Black, the child murderer, should not pay for their crimes with their lives. If a referendum were held in England tomorrow on the return of the death penalty, it is my guess that the British people would vote for it, and I certainly would. I hope that those civilised countries that do have the death penalty will tell the EU to mind its own business.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Before I give you the floor, I would just like to make it clear to all the ladies and gentlemen who apply for this procedure that such a notification can be taken into account by the President of Parliament before the debate on this point begins, i.e. to those who are already reporting during the debate, unfortunately I cannot give a voice.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have this debate every year. For what reason? Because we believe that every person has the right to life. This right is a fundamental human right. It arises from human dignity, it stems from natural law. European civilisation has gone through a period when the death penalty has been applied here, although there are still countries in Europe that apply the penalty there. But I also come from a country where, more than twenty-five years ago, we introduced a moratorium and then abolished the death penalty. The question is always, do we have the instruments to abolish this death penalty in all countries? This, of course, is a process. It is never an easy process, there are always serious arguments of the parties with whom we talk that this death penalty is not to be abolished: because it is terrorism, because it is a tradition, because it is a deterrent to crime. However, words seem to have their own power too. We have many resolutions that have been adopted here, which have decided that people sentenced to death for political reasons, for example, have been liberated from this punishment, that they are alive. And this is also part of our policy in the European Parliament, among others.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the abolition of the death penalty is one of Europe's great achievements, but even today, in view of the hundreds of executions in more than twenty countries over the last year, it is a goal, a mission to be carried out with determination in the rest of the world.  Respect for dignity and respect for life are universal values which we have a duty to disseminate by all the peaceful and legitimate means at our disposal by putting pressure on governments with equal rigour vis-à-vis all countries and by assessing the most effective general and particular measures to promote a reform of legislation and in the meantime to block the implementation of judgments which have not yet been implemented. , to facilitate its amendment, to prevent new death sentences from being handed down.  It is a question of coherence and we must not fear that our dutiful commitment to the death penalty could be seen as undue interference or a form of cultural imperialism, so to speak. On the death penalty, which is certainly not justice, there can be no tolerance.

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Human life is of the utmost value, but I think it is important to take into account that there are different situations in which the death penalty is imposed. In all cases, we are against. On the other hand, as was rightly pointed out in the debate, in the case of murder, in the case of the most serious crimes, international law allows this situation, although we are trying to ensure that states successively give up their ancient, transigoal powers.  Now we are faced with the second yet second situation of the death penalty for actions such as adultery, political crimes, change of religion, drug trafficking. These actions, although these death sentences, although dressed in the form of court judgments, are judicial crimes. We should have no doubt that the specific people who apply for these sentences, who adjudicating them, who execute them, are criminals dressed in judges' toga. After World War II, German Nazi prosecutors and judges also stood trial. I believe that such judges should be sentenced to death for adultery, political offences, religious change, drug trafficking to be identified and at least blacklisted, unless they are judged in possible situations under universal jurisdiction.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the discussion on the death penalty as it is an opportunity for us to recognise European countries’ longstanding opposition to capital punishment. But I am here tonight to ask you to spare a thought for Ibrahim Halawa, an Irish teenager and the only EU citizen who has been held in an Egyptian prison since August 2013, who currently faces the death penalty. His crime was to exercise his freedom of expression by attending a protest. Amnesty has deemed him a prisoner of conscience and his imprisonment is, in fact, in contravention of Article 2 of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. So, while I welcome the comment from Mr Schmit tonight that the European Council is vocal on the death sentence, I would like to say that actions speak louder than words. Egypt is ranked seventh for executions, and only last week opposed a UN motion to prohibit the death penalty. It is now time for the European Union and the Irish Government to act on Egypt and to put an end to cases like that of Ibrahim Halawa, languishing in jail awaiting a death sentence.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2 October was World Day against the Death Penalty.  This is yet another sad day, not least because, unfortunately, we have to note that he always enjoys excellent health in the friends' club where there is the degradation of that crime against humanity called the death penalty. There are members of europe's very civilised friends, such as the United States and Japan. There are also our strategic allies, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Pakistan, belarus, which is also in Europe a stone's throw away from us, and this terrible moral and ethical degradation is often used to punish political opponents, to punish, therefore, in essence, the right to oppose.  The nuclear treaty with Iran, which we welcome, must also not be reduced to yet another green light for investment, to savage trade, but must instead be a key instrument for a constructive approach and progress on the subject of human rights, because almost 700 death sentences have taken place in Iran and we are not talking about the 1 200 or more in China. , which has always been seen as a great trading partner.  How much we could do if we used trade and the economy as a means of strengthening human rights and not the other way round. Let Europe once again make Europe, fight this shame and utter the only right death sentence, the death penalty itself.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, Europe has its own position on the death penalty and it is almost unanimous. I am happy that our societies have transcended this outdated method and we are treating even the most serious criminals today as befits people whose civilization was shaped by Christianity.  I believe that such a European position on the death penalty should be promoted around the world, especially in relations with those third countries with which strong trade, diplomatic or military partnerships connect us. But in doing so, we must always bear in mind cultural differences and at this delicate political moment choose the means by which we will achieve our goals, because the death penalty has no place in the 21st century.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I could simply conclude what has just been said, namely that the death penalty has no place in the twenty-first century. Indeed, I thank you for a very broad and determined commitment against the death penalty. This commitment is also a very clear message that we will have to give to countries that have not yet arrived, in fact, in the twenty-first century, as you said. There is no easy solution. It is clear that, at every opportunity, persuasion must be used. We need to talk about it, we also need to mobilize our civil societies, our non-governmental organizations to attack, indeed, this practice of another time.  International public opinion can play an important role, and I am thinking, in particular, of everything that has been done at the United Nations. Of course, it is too long a process because, in the meantime, thousands of people are being executed, but I think this debate shows that Europe, in this respect, is true to its values. These values must be heard by countries that do not share them. In fact, we do this by enshrining the principle of human rights in the various agreements we conclude with partners.  But we also have to be realistic. We cannot now block or punish, by refusing any agreement with countries that practice the death penalty, because that would not change them. It will be rather through dialogue but also through very clear signals that they will be changed.  I remain optimistic that one day they will also arrive in the twenty-first century.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 110(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. According to Amnesty International, 607 executions and 2,466 death sentences were recorded in 22 countries in 2014. Yet, according to the NGO, there is no evidence that the deterrent effect of the death penalty is greater than that of the prison sentence on criminal acts. But above all, the death penalty is contrary to European values and European law. The EU Charter of Fundamental Rights explicitly bans the death penalty (Article 2). At a time when some countries are going so far as to consider the reintroduction of the death penalty, including within the continent, it is the EU's duty to recall its outright condemnation of the death penalty and the ultimate goal of total abolition at the global level. I can, of course, only support this resolution in line with respect for human rights and human dignity.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In addition to the debate on the oral question on the death penalty, I recall the efforts of the European Parliament, including in the framework of the activities of the Delegation for Relations with Belarus, which I chair. These efforts are directed at the Belarusian authorities and concern a moratorium on the death penalty, which would be the first step towards the permanent abolition of the death penalty. Belarus is the last country in Europe to continue to carry out the death penalty. Since 2010, 10 people have been executed in Belarus, three executions were carried out in 2014 alone and another death sentence was handed down on 18 March 2015.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Cain, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007. establishing the European Small Claims Procedure and Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 December 2006 establishing a European order for payment procedure (COM(2013)0794 – C7-0414/2013 – 2013/0403(COD)) (A8-0140/2015).

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As cross-border trade in the European Union has increased, it has become increasingly urgent to provide effective and rapid redress mechanisms for both individual and small and medium-sized enterprises as a means of supporting their economic activities.  The proposed revision of the European Small Claims Procedure aims to raise the amount of claims from EUR 2 000 to EUR 5 000 and aims primarily at simplifying the procedures for resolving cross-border disputes in civil and commercial matters, reducing the duration of legal proceedings from an average of more than 2 years to 5 months and reducing costs by 40%. The increase in the quota threshold in the disputed proceedings will further increase the potential number of individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises able to benefit from this new simplified way of pursuing their claims.  I am pleased, as chief negotiator for the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Ities, that, after one and a half years of debates with the Council in the final of the Latvian Presidency, a solution has been negotiated which will now be put to the vote of the European Parliament in its fourth since the start of work on the Presidency document. I am convinced that the new cross-border redress procedure will help citizens to assert their rights effectively, quickly and cheaply.  In fact, the case concerns billions of euros across the European Union, consisting of small amounts that have not yet been profitable to claim, as court and legal costs have often exceeded them. The result was the flourishing of companies notorious and with impunity deceiving customers. The new simplified procedure also provides for administrative cases to be dealt with without the need to hire a lawyer and without the need to go to another country, as possible hearings will take place, for example, by videoconference, teleconference or other distance communication; gives you the opportunity to pay court fees by bank transfer or card (and not as has often been the case in the court window); it does not require all documents to be translated into another language – now the originals are enough, and only a brief description of the case will have to be translated. The costs of a cross-border investigation cannot be higher than the legal costs in a similar case in their own country and cannot be disproportional to the amount of the claim.  In the original proposal, which I negotiated with the Council, there was an idea to extend the procedure to certain aspects of labour law, which would seem natural in an era of universal labour mobility in the European Union. Unfortunately, the resistance in the Council was insurmountable, but the compromise reached nevertheless includes a revision clause, both in terms of the possibility of raising the threshold for claims and further extending the scope of the procedure to include issues relating to remuneration. I think that with the implementation of this new simplified procedure (which will take place at the latest 16 months after the entry into force of the Regulation), it will eventually be profitable to go to court in cross-border disputes, and with it, I hope, there will be an end to massive and unpunished customer deception. Finally, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the JURI secretariat, the Representatives of the Council and the European Commission, my advisers and assistants for very good cooperation. The shadow rapporteur Daniel Boudin, the European Commission's Michael Shotter and Jacek Garstka, the Latvian Presidency's Justice Minister Dzintars Rasnačs, as well as Ilze Lepiksone, Vita Sliede and Barbara Mekel, contributed in particular to the compromise. I would also like to thank Alexander Keys, Lind Moldovan and Annie Czerwonec for their great involvement in my parliamentary work.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, every day citizens and businesses conclude cross-border transactions or enter into cross-border civil-legal relations benefiting from the European single market. But things may go wrong. Products may be faulty or services may not be delivered. In such situations people need to be able to assert and enforce their rights. The European small claims procedure offers a uniform procedure to enforce rights in a cheaper and faster way. The current system has been operational for five years. We have assessed it and identified its shortcomings. Now is the time for improvement. I would like to thank Ms Geringer de Oedenberg, the rapporteur, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation on this dossier. It was not easy to come to a meaningful compromise so speedily. The Commission’s objective was to modernise the small claims procedure. We proposed extending its application to claims of up to EUR 10 000, paying close attention in particular to the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises. The final compromise sets the limit at EUR 5 000. Currently it is only EUR 2 000, so this is a significant improvement.  I know that some of you would have welcomed it if employees’ claims could have been included in the scope of the regulation. We agreed that we would come back to this issue in the future after having analysed the practical needs in this respect. The overarching priority for the Commission in these negotiations has been to improve effective access to justice for more EU citizens. The level of court fees plays a key role in this regard. Citizens must not be discouraged from effectively enforcing their rights. The prohibition of disproportionate court fees, which is included in the compromise text, is a step forward. We will monitor its implementation and application in the interest of citizens.  More generally, the Commission will support the practical application of the revised regulation through awareness raising and the wide dissemination of information.

name: Daniel Buda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I first thank rapporteur Geringer de Oedenberg for her good cooperation, Commissioner Jourová for her excellent cooperation, but also all the colleagues involved in the preparation of this report.  A European justice needs a single European legal area, and effective justice needs simplified procedures. Citizens of the European Union will be beneficiaries of a simplified procedure for the resolution of cross-border disputes of up to EUR 5 000. National barriers will no longer be an obstacle in judicial matters for individuals and in particular SMEs. Electronic means of communication and distance payment will become effective tools, within the reach of stakeholders, and the definition of cross-border cases has been expanded as well as important clarifications. Stamp duty will have to be set in a reasonable amount and proportionate to the value of the application, so as not to become prohibitive for citizens. Good faith in the execution of civil and commercial contracts will be even more vigorously protected and the legal certainty of the commercial circuit will be guaranteed. It is therefore important to ensure a level playing field for both the creditor and the debtor throughout the European Union, as well as a consequence of membership in the same legal area. However, Member States are required to implement this Regulation and this procedure will become a reality at national level. I regret that it has not been possible to extend the scope of this regulation in the field of labour law, so that European citizens who have performed an activity under an individual employment contract have the opportunity to use this simplified instrument for the recovery of wage rights from bad employers. Clearly, we would have had to deal with both a reduction in black work and a considerable reduction in tax evasion. I am convinced, however, that in the near and reasonable future, both the Commission and the Council, together with Parliament, will find an effective solution to this.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleague Geringer de Odenberg for the report and for the compromise that I and my colleagues in the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists supported in the JURI Committee.  Already in July 2011, a small claims instrument was adopted aimed at improving and simplifying civil and commercial procedures. According to this instrument, the Commission must submit to the European Parliament, the Council and the European Economic and Social Committee a detailed report reviewing the functioning of the European procedure, which necessite the review of the existing Regulation. The aim of this review was to make the existing instrument more attractive and useful to European citizens, who increasingly enter into financial relationships of a cross-border nature, thanks to the functioning of the European free market. I believe that with common efforts we have been able to achieve this goal.  I welcome the decision to increase the ceiling on the value of actions from EUR 2 000 to EUR 5 000 for civil and commercial cases of a cross-border nature. This will ensure effective protection for European citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. I support other proposals which I believe contribute to improving the instrument and making it more feasible in practice.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, On behalf of my group, I would like to welcome the work done by the rapporteur and I would like to remind you that the initiative to update this regulation belonged precisely to my political group, the ALDE, in 2011, through the former Mrs Wallace. The Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European small claims procedure is intended to simplify and speed up small claims in cross-border cases, as well as to reduce their procedural costs, always with the specific aim of helping consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to take action by ensuring access to justice more quickly and easily. This objective cannot be lost in the tangle of Brussels bureaucracy which leaves, more often, citizens and small businesses lost in procedural complexity. I also recall that this work of simplifying and bringing citizens and businesses closer to justice is part of a broader work related to the ALDE's initiative to better legislate. The European small claims procedure can only be successful if it comes to the attention of consumers, businesses, courts and advisory associations.  The data cited by the Commission show that 86 % of citizens and almost half of the courts have never heard of this process. It is also necessary to take into mind the costs, reduce them and increase the speed of decision, especially of the courts.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, today, as has been said, we are discussing an amendment to the so-called European Small Claims Procedure. The proceedings are regulated as an alternative to ordinary disputed proceedings under the Code of Civil Procedure. In particular, it aims to assist consumers in exercising their rights in cross-border disputes and to improve access to justice for SMEs in the recovery of smaller claims. The amendment to the Regulation is intended to eliminate some of the problems encountered by the proceedings since the beginning of their existence, namely since 2009, in particular: firstly, the setting of a limit on court fees, the amount of which often discouraged consumers from using those proceedings, secondly, it limited SMEs to a limit of EUR 2 000 for a change, since only a small percentage of their cross-border claims fit within that limit. In my view, the outcome of the trilogue represents a balanced compromise that responds to the practical needs of the parties and facilitates effective access to justice for consumers and SMEs. I thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs, the secretariat of our committee for the work done, and I support the proposal.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises often give up their rights in court over the costs and complications of cross-border legal proceedings.  The aim of the reform of the small claims procedure was precisely to simplify and further extend the way in which access to justice was initiated. An ambitious goal that we share. The Commission's proposal was already welcome, the JURI Committee, with the sole exception of the limits set for the value of the dispute, further improved the text by also providing adequate judicial guarantees for citizens, in particular those without adequate financial means.  The text that has emerged from the trialogue, however, is unfortunately a step backwards. We do not agree with the ceiling of EUR 5 000 on the value of disputes and the deletion of the amendment which provided for a minimum income threshold below which a party is not obliged to pay court costs. Finally, the text of the trialogue appears twisted, in the way of the very idea of simplification, probably a missed opportunity to guarantee the citizens' right to justice and at the same time lighten the burden of ordinary judgments pending in the courts of Europe.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this text has the merit of favouring the settlement of cross-border disputes of less than EUR 5,000 in civil and commercial matters, but it will probably have the same failure as its predecessor, who pursued the same objective for disputes of less than EUR 2,000 The European Union is unable to organise local justice, because, in the minds of Europeans, , justice is a national matter. Moreover, it does not always give justice the respect it deserves. As proof of this, I take as evidence its current plan to double the number of judges of the Court of Justice which it is trying to force through in violation of Article 257 of the FUE Treaty and Article 63 of our regulation and in defiance of our parliamentary procedure. The truth it seeks to conceal is that this doubling does not correspond to any necessity, as the judges of the Court themselves have confessed. Shame on the European Union, which is about to distribute unnecessary and handsomely paid places, without regard for the millions of Europeans who are suffering, victims of its ultra-liberal austerity policy!

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to congratulate the Rapporteur and all those involved in the negotiations on the good outcome of the work on the reform of the small claims procedure. The changes introduced will lead, among other things, to two important effects. Firstly, the procedure will become more common and well-known, secondly, more attractive to citizens and small business in the European Union. The most important solutions are, firstly, raising the upper limit of claims to EUR 5 000 and, secondly, obliging the courts to use modern communication technologies. Those amendments will therefore increase the attractiveness of the solution, while reducing the costs of its application also by the parties to the proceedings. This will therefore reduce, inter alia, the costs of travelling and attending the hearing of the parties. As a result, this instrument has the opportunity to become more accessible and more widely used in Europe. For this reason, it should become a tool that will have a positive impact on closing the loophole – the gap in access to justice in cross-border cases. At present, many businesses and citizens do not pay to assert their rights mainly because the value of the claim is too high.  The most important thing now should be to promote this procedure. We are creating a very interesting instrument, which unfortunately few people know about. This can also increase the willingness of small businesses to do business in other countries as well. The amendment may remove the fear of any legal proceedings, even if the amount in question is relatively low. For these reasons, this solution should be promoted and through the European Commission and the Member States.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this regulation is an important instrument available to citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises, and the changes on which agreement has been reached between the European institutions are positive because they improve their effectiveness and broaden their scope, and also set a possible path for further progress in the future.  This is an important result for Parliament, as I said, because it achieves improvements on the issue of increasingly effective procedures available to citizens and businesses, procedures that can be implemented throughout the European Union. This is in addition to the progress made on this great challenge made during the last parliamentary term, for example on the issue of the conservative seizure of debtors' assets, thanks once again to parliament's commitment. These issues may seem minor, but they are essential to create a real perception among citizens of being part of a journey and a community, part of a common project and to improve their material living conditions in an environment where movement, cross-border relationships and activities are increasingly common within the European Union, as are increasingly frequent court cases that have effects and implications for those working between a country and the other.  These rules must now be implemented, starting with the need to provide further answers to the needs of cross-border workers.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We in the ECR Group have clear ideas about how we envisage this EU. We call ourselves critical of the EU, but critical in a positive sense, which means that we want a well-functioning EU. There is much to criticise, because we fundamentally believe that the EU must limit itself to things where it can create added value. But in this case, we can happily say: this is such a case. This is because the procedure envisaged creates standards and unifies things which have otherwise caused major problems with national regulations for the private people concerned, but also for companies. We have a wonderful case here where the EU can create added value. We very much welcome the fact that we have been able to persuade us to raise the points of dispute that have been at issue up to now and to provide electronic support for the procedures in future. And, of course, we also hope that we will be able to map these procedures in practice in such a way that they are easily applicable to all parties involved.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am very glad that the trilogue has managed to arrive at the text that we will be voting on tomorrow. First of all, let me thank all my colleagues in the JURI committee who have contributed to this result, especially the rapporteur. I think that the small claims procedure is an example of legislation that is not at first glance attractive to the general public, but which can be very valid for this public and can thus contribute to a more positive perception of the European Union and EU legislation as a result. Citizens rightly expect legislation that reflects the current reality, whether it is simplifying and speeding up proceedings with electronic means of communication or a tool to achieve justice even in cases with a cross-border element. I believe that the proposed compromise on the amount of the limit on claims is necessary, since in some Member States, at least for individuals, the amount of EUR 10 000 cannot be identified with a small claim, however only the terminology. This reality also needs to be reflected in the legislation. Moreover, the proposal already foresees the possibility of adjusting the threshold of EUR 5 000 in the future. I therefore hope that we will also discuss any future amendments in a spirit as constructive as the current text, for which I thank you.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the modifications made by this regulation mean a great lot to consumers. In situations where a consumer buys goods online from another EU country and realizes by delivery that they have been deprived or cheated, the consumer usually calculates that due to a smaller amount it is not worth entering into an expensive process with the trader. Of course, next time they will not shop online which has negative consequences on the European economy.  This mechanism has been poorly used by SMEs so far, so I welcome the decision to increase the value of the lawsuit, as it is estimated that around 50% of their claims will be resolved through this system.  In conclusion, in addition to commending the simplification and cost reduction of the process, I must highlight my concerns with the European Commission's research – as many as 82% of consumers do not know that they can use this instrument in situations where they have small claims, when they cannot be charged or when seeking, for example, compensation for a vehicle that has been damaged outside their country. We must not forget that an informed consumer is the key to a fair functioning of the common market.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We all want the European internal market, and for many years the Commission and we in Parliament have been working to remove all obstacles and obstacles. We all want to realise the full potential of digitisation for our citizens and for our SMEs in the European Union. This includes the ability to order products and services from anywhere in the EU. However, this also means that when there are disputes, when difficulties arise, one can simply and cost-effectively enforce one's law in the European Union. And that is precisely the purpose, and this is the aim of what we will be voting on tomorrow at noon. Some 25 years after the creation of the European Single Market, a European procedure was introduced in 2007 to enable citizens and SMEs to achieve a faster, more efficient and cost-effective settlement of these very cross-border disputes across the EU. What we have now negotiated – thanks to the rapporteurs from all the political groups – on the revision and what we will be voting on tomorrow is another step in the right direction. The benefits are obvious. There are multilingual forms. The procedure can be started online. The court fees must also be proportionate to the value of the dispute. It is also true, in my view, that the ceiling for small claims was set at EUR 5 000 and not EUR 10 000, as the Commission's original proposal provided for. A major problem remains – and it has also been mentioned – that, unfortunately, the procedure is still far too little used. That is why we must work, in particular, to make this procedure public, precisely in order to make full use of the possibilities offered by the European internal market. We are all called upon to do this, as are the Commission and we MEPs. We will do that!

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the document presented today. This report is an important step towards improving the European procedure on small claims and establishing a common order for payment procedure. Increasing the threshold to EUR 5 000 is really to the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are currently discouraged from bringing legal proceedings when they have cross-border claims. If at present the fixed value of only EUR 2 000 comprises only 20 % of the applications submitted by undertakings, the new threshold increases the percentage to almost 40 %. Improved access to this procedure would thus increase confidence in cross-border transactions and help to make full use of the opportunities offered by the internal market.  I also fully support the recommendation to introduce modern or online technology systems to improve access to this European procedure. Whether we are talking about the application procedure for the claim or we are talking about the conduct of judicial proceedings, new technologies can allow for greater transparency and better access to European judicial mechanisms.  The report also proposes three other important elements which I would like to mention and which push me to support this report: cost reductions in procedure, free assistance and guidance, including through online means, and calibration of the judicial fee, which allows for wider access to these European judicial mechanisms and greater facilitation for European citizens and SMEs.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their work on the report. I believe that the simplified small claims procedure is one step forward towards introducing common rules in European civil proceedings. Increasing the eligibility thresholds for the claim to EUR 5 000 is largely in the economic reality. I am sure that this will help to better implement the Regulation in a better practical way and will benefit from a maximum number of small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The future inclusion of labour law claims within the scope of the Regulation would enable many citizens working in other Member States to gain faster and cheaper access to justice. In this way, they will be able to make the most of the free movement of persons in the European Union, with guaranteed legal protection. The possibilities for remote payment of court fees, remote hearings of the parties and simplified written procedure are very attractive and advantageous for small and medium-sized enterprises. In this way, they will save time and costs for both travel to the court and legal advice. I believe that with this regulation we will be able to facilitate access to justice for our citizens and help to resolve cross-border disputes more easily. I hope that small claims proceedings will be widely used in the Member States.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the report we are debating today is very important, as it deals with the introduction of a European order for payment procedure with regard to small claims. I therefore agree that the order for payment procedure for small claims should be simplified, because this will strengthen cross-border trade and trade.  Allow me now to refer to the process of wage and pension seizures imposed by the troika in Memorandum III on Greece. The irrepressable fell from 1,500 euros to 1,000 euros, resulting in the state and banks "putting their hands" on the bank accounts of poor Greeks. Therefore, in Greece, the process of executing payment orders is essentially put at the service of the Memorandum State and the loan lenders.  Madam President, from the floor of the European Parliament, I would like to point out, once again, that the anti-monumental citizens will continue to fight for the abolition of the memorandums in Greece, the write-off of the shameful debt and the eviction of the troika from our country.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – The proposal for this regulation came at the right time and, as the Commissioner said, it can also mean effective access to justice. Citizens must not, of course, be allowed to have such circumstances as to keep them from protecting their rights, and that is why this regulation is certainly a step forward. Above all, it is important to ensure that costs are proportionate, that, of course, also account for these disputes, the costs otherwise claimed by individual states. At the same time, however, we can say that we can be sorry that this regulation does not also concern labour law, especially since there are many cases where employers do not pay workers wages, contributions and, of course, those taxes that are important for their income and, of course, for cross-border online fraud, where this procedure can, of course, allow people to exercise their rights in these proceedings.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the compromise Parliament has reached with the Council will bring new advantages to citizens and businesses. They will be able to use the European small claims procedure more often and at a lower cost. Also, the length of the procedure will be reduced. I would like to thank the honourable Members again for their cooperation: after today’s discussion I am more confident that you will vote in favour of the agreed compromise.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to thank you for your kind words about the quality of my work and our cooperation with each other. I am pleased that we are giving citizens a useful tool for redress. It is intended to work according to the principle: cheaply, quickly and easily.  The so-called small claims procedure so far has been ineffective. Citizens, firstly, mostly did not know it, and considered it too complicated and expensive, and often waved their hand, paying money as a lesson for their own naivety or stupidity. With this tool, we will stop this practice, which was widespread, especially on the Internet. I ask you to give strong support to this initiative, which has been unanimously approved in the Committee on Legal Remedies. I would like a similar result in tomorrow's vote.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 7 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I welcome the revision of this regulation, as it is primarily for the benefit of consumers– the new rules will make it easier and cheaper to recover small debts in other EU countries except Denmark. The European Small Claims Procedure will enable individuals and businesses to recover debts incurred in other EU countries through standard forms. This procedure will apply to claims of up to EUR 5 000, no lawyers will have to be hired to recover the amounts, and the stamp duty on this procedure will be reduced to one that applies to domestic debt collection and can be paid not only in cash, but also by wire transfer or bank card. This Regulation obliges EU countries to provide free assistance in filling out dispute forms and selecting the competent court. Member States are also encouraged to use video or audio conferences to deal with disputes in order to prevent parties to hear disputes from travelling to another country, which also makes a significant contribution to reducing the costs of debt collection. This procedure has been in place since 2009, and the study has revealed that the costs of cross-border claims have since fallen by as much as 40% and the duration of proceedings has been reduced from two and a half years to five months. The improvements adopted by this session in the European Parliament will allow our citizens, consumers and small and medium-sized businesses to achieve even better results.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – By raising the upper limit of the claim to EUR 5 000 and obliging the courts to use modern communication technologies that reduce travel and trial costs for the parties, the small claims procedure has the chance to become more accessible and more widely used. In the broader perspective, it should become a tool that will have a positive impact on closing the gap in access to justice in cross-border cases. Today, many businesses and citizens simply do not pay to assert their rights mainly because the costs of cross-border legal proceedings are too high in relation to the claim.  Now the most important thing is to promote this procedure. We have a good instrument, which unfortunately few people know about, both on the side of law practitioners and citizens. Being aware of such a simplified procedure in the area of low claims can, above all, change the approach of many small entrepreneurs to develop their business outside the country. I would therefore like to ask both the Commission and the Member States to actively promote this procedure, as this is an excellent example of the benefits and added value of cooperation in the area of civil and commercial law in the European Union. It is worth it for citizens to see and feel these benefits.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on and the report by Andrzej Grzyb on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Environment, public health and food safety on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to limit emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants into the air (COM(2013)0919 - C7-0003/2014 - 2013/0442(COD)) (A8-0160/2015).

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The directive we will vote on tomorrow sets limits on emissions of dust – sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides – and introduces monitoring of carbon monoxide emissions without setting emission limits in combustion plants between 1 and 50MW. In a word, this directive is part of the air protection package. It thus fills the legislative gap that we have between the Ecodesign Directive, the Ecodesign Directive, which sets standards for combustion plants smaller than 1MW, and the Industrial Emissions Directive, which applies to plants larger than 50MW. Emission limits have been set at an ambitious level that guarantees a gradual improvement in air quality, but also the preservation of the protection of functioning combustion plants and investments. This protection is primarily covered by small facilities up to 5MW, the operators of which are mainly small and medium-sized enterprises or municipal companies, or are an important element of, inter alia, equipment such as schools, hospitals, universities and those that have already been modernized or built to a high standard, which, however, would require significant additional expenditure to meet the standards imposed by the new directive, for example those imposed by the new Directive. , which use biomass – this is particularly the case in the Nordic countries.  Special protection has been granted to heating plants which supply heat to dwellings in residential areas, thereby allowing the costs of their operation to be maintained and thus for not increasing the cost of supplying heat to final customers. This is important not only for social but also environmental reasons, which I want to stress. It promotes a policy of exchanging individual heating sources, in particular in single-family houses, which is particularly important for certain regions in Central and Eastern Europe and can significantly improve air quality.  I wanted to stress that the final text of the directive is an example of a good reconciling of the challenges that come from the need to protect the environment, economic reality and social needs. We have set ambitious targets, but can be achieved without imposing excessive costs on both operators and end-users. On 23rd June an agreement was reached between Parliament, the Council and the European Commission during the informal trilogy. The agreement was also approved by COREPER on 30th June with only one state voting against and voted in the Committee on the Environment on 15th July by an overwhelming majority of 59 votes in favour, with 6 against. I acknowledge, however, that the negotiations with the Council were very complicated and that all the provisions of the directive were subject to detailed arrangements in turn. This agreement must be regarded as a package and a change to any element would require a new approach to reading this project.  I wanted to thank everyone for their support, especially the entire negotiating team of the European Parliament, all the shadow rapporteurs. I would also like to thank you very much for the cooperation of the Latvian Presidency and the Representatives of the European Commission, who have managed to find many very good solutions that are satisfactory to all sides.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am pleased to participate in this debate on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Vella, who unfortunately cannot be here this evening. The directive to reduce pollution from medium combustion installations is a key component of the Commission’s Clean Air Policy Package presented in December 2013. It is an important deliverable for the 7th Environmental Action Programme, which would help to reduce significantly the potential risks to human health, a programme that I am very familiar with, which was adopted during the Irish Presidency in 2013. Air pollution degrades our environment and it remains the number one environmental cause of death in the EU. It causes 400 000 premature deaths and more than 100 000 lost working days in the EU each year. The Medium Combustion Plants Directive will close an unacceptable gap in our legislation and will thus make an important contribution to reaching the future reduction targets as proposed in the amendment to the National Emission Ceilings Directive that is still on the table for the co-legislators. On behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Vella, let me thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Grzyb, and his colleagues from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) for their commitment and hard work on this proposal.  Thanks to the work of the Parliament negotiating team, it has been possible to maintain the environmental integrity of the proposed directive, whilst addressing justified cases where Member States needed flexibility for implementation. The flexibility provisions that cover district heating and the use of biomass as a fuel, which are two major issues for Parliament, will ensure that climate and air quality policies are consistent and their synergies are maximised. Parliament also made clear that certain further issues are important, such as energy efficiency and carbon monoxide emissions. The Commission will address these under the agreed review clauses.  Allow me also to point out that the Medium Combustion Plants Directive is a good example of better regulation. It has been designed to be affordable for SMEs and it provides long-term certainty for all economic operators concerned, while minimising the administrative burden for both industry and Member States.  Finally, I would like to underline that, beyond being environmentally efficient, this directive promotes advanced EU technology. It will encourage continued innovation and help EU industry gain shares of the rapidly growing global market in pollution control technology. The Commission thus fully supports the compromise, although I have to make a declaration on the use of the no-opinion clause for the adoption of implementing acts.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Hogan, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Grzyb, and all my fellow Members who have worked hard to reach this agreement, which allows us to have European legislation and emission limits for a sector that has not been regulated until now.  I would also like to thank the Commissioner and the Presidency for the cooperative spirit they have shown throughout the process of the proposal. The proposal, as the rapporteur has pointed out, concerns medium combustion plants, 150 000 plants in Europe with a nominal thermal power of between 1 and 50 megawatts, and is designed to make a significant contribution to reducing pollution by setting limit values for existing and new plants and also by establishing a registration system that can enable emissions reduction obligations to be fulfilled in the Member States.  The aim, of course, is to preserve air quality and therefore the health of citizens from possible factors in the increase in air pollution. The text represents a compromise between the different positions, but in general an agreement has been reached which has partly amended the Commission's proposal, improving the chances of realistically implementing the directive, enabling it to achieve the objective of improving atmospheric quality in the European Union, without imposing excessive burdens on companies.  Among the most important points are the obligation for Member States to assess the need to apply stricter emission limit values in areas that do not comply with EU air quality standards and the inclusion of a review clause to enable progress in energy efficiency of combustion plants to be monitored in 2020. These efforts are part of the wider framework of preparation for COP21 in Paris, to confirm the European Union as the main player in the fight against climate change, and we hope that an ambitious agreement will be reached thanks also to the commitment of all the parties involved.

name: Massimo Paolucci
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after so many words we are following up a few things.  Finally we cover a glaring regulatory vacuum, more than 142 000 companies with combustion plants between 1 and 50 megawatts were without clear regulation. We are talking about plants for the production of electricity, for heating, for cooling, for the production of vapors in industrial processes. We are talking about sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, particulate matter. An important step forward to combat air pollution more effectively.  We will never forget this – as the Commissioner mentioned earlier, the leading cause of death in Europe – one of the main causes of eutrophication, of which 62% of the European Union's surface area is at risk. That is not all we in the Group of socialists and democrats would have liked. Certainly a step forward, a sensible agreement that defends our health and that of the planet, without harming European businesses. We make clear choices, I would remind you of some of them, we extend the scope of monitoring to carbon monoxide as well, we have reached a reasonable compromise on emission limit values on implementation times, the obligation for Member States to assess the need for stricter measures for areas that are above air quality limits, reduction of derogations and then a compromise on the somewhat longer implementation times for installations that are part of biomass-powered heating networks.  It is for all these reasons that tomorrow, as the Group of Socialists and Democrats, we will wholeheartedly support this measure.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! It is good that the final shape of the Directive on reducing emissions of certain substances into the air from medium combustion plants takes into account the wide range of concerns expressed by different environments.  My particular attention was paid to the role of district heating, which is very popular in many European Union countries, including Poland. In Poland, such installations are mainly based on coal, or raw material, which we have in abundance. Installations in Poland have undergone the modernisation required by national law in recent years, so too quickly imposing an obligation on them to further modernise would lead to a drastic increase in costs and, as a result, perhaps, an increase in the use of individual heating systems, which would lead to an increase in emissions, because these systems are more difficult to control. From an environmental and health policy point of view, this would therefore be counterproductive. The possibility for States to exclude such installations from the need for stricter limits by 2030 is therefore a manifestation of common sense.  I am also pleased that my amendment, which states that emissions should be measured under stable conditions under a representative, even load, is in the final form of the agreement. The scandal over Volkswagen's falsification of emission measurements in a country that is a promoter of emission reductions shows the importance, on the one hand, of realisticly imposing mandatory emission reductions and, on the other hand, of careful monitoring of compliance with those limits.

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. First of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteur of the ALDE Group, the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs for the excellent cooperation. I really think we have achieved this result together. As far as I am concerned, this piece of legislation is the circle and emissions from medium-sized combustion plants are also regulated, as was previously the case with the large combustion plants. The aim is to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen and particulate matter, which have a major impact on air quality, but also on public health. After good cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament, a solid package is now on the table that is workable and guarantees a level playing field throughout Europe.  My commitment and that of our group was to reduce exceptions to the emission limit values as much as possible if there was no clear reason for doing so. It worked. However, some of the exceptions, in our view, are justified. As co-legislators, I believe that we should take into account the practice, especially if the European Union is to encourage the use of biomass. The requirements for biomass combustion plants, for example, have therefore been adapted. We have also avoided overlap with other regulations, which means that dual legislation with, for example, the Industrial Emissions Directive is no longer present.  There are other loopholes also closed. For example, an installation intended for emergencies can really only be used during an emergency and cannot operate under normal conditions. We have managed to reduce red tape and bureaucracy. Rules must be able to be applied unambiguously by a uniform licensing system. Finally, it is good that Member States want to learn from each other. In some Member States, business is already much further. It is up to other Member States to show that ambition as well. Mr President, I welcome this outcome of the negotiations. We keep room for innovation and air quality is being worked on across Europe by tackling the problem at source.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we are pleased to have reached consensus on this proposal and we believe that its implementation throughout Europe is important. When we say all of Europe, we also refer to the Canary Islands, the Azores, Madeira and any other European territory, because we refuse to believe that the remoteness of these islands is an impediment for their citizens to enjoy clean air as well. We prefer to prevent certain corporations from taking advantage of any legal vacuum to continue abusing the rights of people and the health of our planet. It seems that others are more willing to defend the interests of corporations than the rights of citizenship. If not, where were they when Repsol turned the Canary Islands into Europe's main gas station? In addition, we believe that the Commission must ensure in particular compliance with the rules in order to prevent certain pollutants from being issued to the atmosphere, because it is a disgrace that what has happened with Volkswagen has happened, since since 2009 there were suspicions of possible fraud and nothing has been done until the scandal has e broke out. The root cause of climate change is the burning of fossil fuels, but we know that those who continue to enrich themselves at the expense of exploiting our natural resources are unwilling to take a necessary turn in the productive model. The Paris Summit is held in two months. So we have to be decisive in the fight against climate change. We'll see, at that moment, who gets on each side.

name: Bas Eickhout
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all, on behalf of our shadow rapporteur, Michèle Rivasi, who unfortunately could not come tonight, I would like to thank the rapporteur for doing a very fair and good job, which has been really appreciated, on this important matter. We have been discussing source emissions quite a lot today. We were discussing cars this afternoon and now we are doing medium combustion plans. Let us be fair to each other: it is always pretty difficult to get to legislation. Every time we discuss air quality people say that what is most important is to have policies aimed at attacking the source but, as soon as we do that with a policy, there is a lot of demand for the extension of deadlines, a lot of loopholes, all kinds of exemptions, etcetera. That has been the case here too. In that sense, it is a pity that the Council is not here because the Council was the leader in creating loopholes in this legislation. I am very happy that Parliament managed to delete a lot of these loopholes, but it was something of an exercise in damage control. So we will support this because it is an improvement. It will address 20% of the emissions under the national emissions ceiling. But, whenever we deal with these source policies, let us be vigilant. Let us be sure that we are attacking the source because otherwise we will continue to have difficulty in reaching our air quality standards. In the end, that is in the interests of our citizens, and we have to treat all sources fairly. On this one we managed more or less, but it could have been better had the Council cooperated a bit more. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card at this late time of the night. Very briefly: you speak about attacking the source, and the source of the pollutants you speak of is industry. Without industry, there is not the finance to pay for the fine aspirations about clean air which, I am sure, we both share. Would you not accept that industry needs to be taken into account, and that we must make sure that whatever measures come forth from this place are at least industry-friendly so that industry continues to be a source of wealth as well as pollution?

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – That is an easy one. I think we have been very industry-friendly on this one. At the moment we are paying billions for health care because of our polluted air: that is paid by everyone. I think you also agree with the ‘polluter pays’ principle. What we are trying to do here is to make sure that those who are polluting are the ones who pay and not have society in general paying for those who are polluting. I think that, even from your side, this is a policy you can welcome.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is true that this proposal for a directive fills a legislative gap on average combustion plants that have never been regulated before, but vacuum cannot be replaced by nothing, here there has been no desire to include pollutants that are particularly toxic to human health, such as mercury or dioxins, so that this directive is now a genuine unfinished directive.  The amendments made by Parliament have even weakened the Commission's proposal, but above all offshore oil platforms and biomass-fired plants have been excluded from the legislation, which can pollute without limits, and if we talk about employment, the real competitiveness of companies lies in the capacity for ecological innovation and therefore in the use of new clean and free energy sources. , and instead under the usual pretext that this is better than nothing we are paying yet another lace to the power plant industry and the oil multinationals.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Madam President, at the Commission's July hearing, we were perhaps proud to say that the European Union has repeatedly signalled its commitment to reducing emissions of air pollutants in international for a and is seeking to give exemplary behaviour to third countries. Well, in the context of the Volkswagen scandal, this proud, swollen bosom may be a little decaying, but that doesn't mean it's our duty to fill a loophole, to make a policy in a given performance range, which is, of course, necessary. Mainly because, I say another health data, this air pollution shortens the lifespan of EU citizens by eight months. By the way, I am pleased that the Commissioner congratulated the reporter, because that means that the very serious and important amendments without which I would not be able to accept this proposal are in your favour.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: – Thanks to the rapporteur and his efforts in this technical dossier, which is no less political. Today we are talking about reducing emissions of certain air pollutants through large incinerators, gas turbines, emergency generators, mobile power supplies on islands, in rural areas, in agriculture and in workshops, things that affect a lot of people. In Europe, we have made enormous progress in improving air quality in some areas, but the same air quality still does not meet the standard in some parts of the EU.  Good legislation, that is good source policy on air quality, good for public health. That is why we must not leave unnecessary back doors open in this proposal while, together, we want to ensure workability and feasibility by stakeholders. It is therefore important for the European Commission to assess within a reasonable period of time whether the emission limit values should be changed on the basis of the new technologies. The best technologies must be taken into account. We cannot always allow higher emission limits if air purification technology improves rapidly and its affordability increases rapidly in the future. That's important, too. That innovation is moving fast.  But that ambition does not absolve us of the obligation to think about workability, feasibility, economic consequences and employment. Where large-scale redundancies and the cessation of economic activities are imminent, tailor-made solutions must be provided, including by us in Europe. Our environmental ambition, and I clearly support it, must not turn into blind fanaticism, without distinction. That is why there was also broad support from many groups in the Committee on the Environment for some exceptions to locations where air quality is already good.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, just a few weeks before COP 21, to be held in Paris, limiting our greenhouse gas emissions and defending air quality are at the heart of our concerns.  We must repeat, all we can do to combat climate change and improve the air we breathe must be done. In Europe, a study shows that 348,000 deaths a year are due to poor air quality. The observation is clear: our health is clearly endangered by an unclean air in Europe.  I also welcome the adoption of this report today. We have been able to achieve limits on emissions of highly harmful pollutants, such as nitrogen dioxide, for health and the environment. The european Parliament's addition of the carbon monoxide census will also provide the information needed to force the Commission to legislate as soon as possible. Madam President, as rapporteur for COP 21 on our Parliament, I welcome the fact that this report is the right sign to effectively combat this unclean air.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, on behalf of my delegation I would like to welcome this agreement. I know that this has been a difficult negotiation and this agreement represents a fair compromise between very different points of view. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the rapporteur particularly for his skilful handling and for steering this through. I believe that it is vitally important to get an agreement and to get it in place as quickly as possible. Poor air quality is one of the most serious health issues we currently face in Europe. It is very easy to ask for perfection but sometimes perfection is the enemy of the good, so I am delighted to see ambition tempered by pragmatism, and the setting of conditions that will allow investment in new technologies and new renewables to take place. So I welcome this.

name: Nils Torvalds (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we have been discussing air quality for almost the whole day, and different aspects of it. That shows a bit of concern, and not without due reason. Just before I left for Strasbourg, I saw an interesting note back in Finland which said: ‘The cleanest air in Europe can be breathed in Finnish Lapland.’  That is, of course, no coincidence, as there is a very sparse population: less than two persons per square kilometre.  Having clear air is important, but it is not everything in life. In this case we have a fairly balanced compromise which ensures that installations in all Member States make equal efforts to combat air pollution. However, we still have a disturbing tendency to find one-size-fits-all solutions, and again Lapland is a good example. Most members of the Commission and the Council probably know that we have cold winters in Lapland. They have seen Santa Claus coming in his sledge. That is all for today, and good night.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, both the European Parliament and national legislation have long dealt with the reduction of emissions of harmful substances from large sources above 50 MW and have achieved great success. Today, we are at the limit of technical possibilities for further reduction. Therefore, I am glad that we have turned our attention to resources below 50 MW, where there are certainly large reserves. I believe that, while the requirement to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide may have gone too far, these limits may have a counterproductive effect in some countries. By shutting down, for example, small heating plants, local coal heating can be developed, which is much harder to control and emissions are higher there, but I will still support the proposal for a directive. However, I believe that we must also look at local heating in the future. In our country, in the Moravian-Silesian region, a significant part of the pollution is caused by local heating sites, not only from our area, but also from the Polish border. Emission reductions must apply to all, small and large, as well as to all states of the European Union. Let's be fair, let's treat each other fairly, and let's all do as it's given.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, my party believes in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. However, we are firmly opposed to the Commission’s proposal to create new EU legislation in this field. We opposed the Eco-design Directive and the Industrial Emissions Directive, so we will categorically oppose a directive covering all medium combustion plants. We oppose a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants, because we do not think that this is a matter that should be regulated by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. Conversely, we support those exceptions to the directive that alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation. Current EU policy frameworks have failed to deliver legal certainty to investors, and few can afford to invest in this environment. Over—regulation threatens the free-market system of investment and production, and additional EU regulation will not promote the re-industrialisation of Europe. Europe needs to become competitive, create jobs and increase productivity.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Commissioner, air pollution has a significant impact on the environment and health. According to data presented by the 2013 Clean Air for Europe programme, annual premature deaths due to air pollution in 2010 reached 400,000 people.  The total external cost of the impact of air pollution on health varies from €330 billion to €940 billion. Direct economic damage includes 15 billion euros from lost working days, 4 billion euros in healthcare costs, a 3 billion euro loss on crop yields and 1 billion euros in damage to buildings. The latest report by the European Environment Agency on the air quality of the European Union shows that the average air quality in the European Union has been improving since 2003 to date. However, the problem of pollution in Central Europe and some other parts of Europe remains pronounced.  I must say here that Croatia has for more than a decade had its own national legislation prescribed conditions for small and medium-sized fireboxes, as evidenced by the exceptional general air quality measured at the stations of our state network. Unfortunately, Croatia suffers damage due to cross-border air pollution from neighbouring Bosnia and Herzegovina due to the operation of the refinery in Bosanski Brod, but we also have a problem with imports of pollution from other neighbouring countries. I welcome this proposal for a directive that fills the legislative gap and reaches the compromise necessary for its adoption. It is essential that 150 000 medium combustion plants introduce minimum emission requirements for pollutants in the air while keeping the administrative burden at the lowest possible level.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the report under consideration has gained particular importance by bringing the Climate Summit closer and also by the debate on the problem of emissions in general, which has been posed by the recent crisis associated with car emissions.  We must continue firmly to be leaders in the approach to emission control at source, which, on the one hand, benefits air quality and, on the other hand, poses technological challenges that Europe must take to strengthen its position in the green economy and the sustainable economy. Ensuring environmental quality and sustainability cannot be seen as a problem. It is an opportunity for social leadership and technological leadership.  The air quality strategy must also be strongly articulated with the Energy Union. They empower each other. We are facing a moment of great public attention from the world and we must be credible. Credible before ourselves and credible to the world.  I would also point out the characteristics of this directive in terms of simplifying the registration, monitoring process and the phasing possibilities in its implementation.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
