text: – Madam President, as the various measurements in the border territories of the Member States show, some areas suffer from significant air pollution. Pollution from one country thus impacts on the territory of another state, with various exceptions often in individual countries in small sources. Trying to solve this problem caused by smaller resources is certainly important. Of course, it is difficult to rationally influence smaller resources. But limiting emissions from a large number of these resources on a large area is also a real problem. In order to achieve a real result in reducing air pollution, we need to take a comprehensive approach to this issue, so that it is not only administratively required regulation, but also incentive tools, including the necessary awareness- This encourages interest in modernising these resources, whether in promoting innovation or, for example, research into modern energy sources meeting the required tightened limits.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this proposal, of course, but one point raises my complete misunderstanding. It is the exclusion of the outermost regions from the benefit of this very good directive. No doubt the energy lobby has been there. But, as the elected representative of the outermost regions, I reject this exclusion which aims to deprive ultramarine of air quality benefits and these very positive measures for health.  Does this mean that these measures apply only to continents? I don't believe it. I think it would have been possible to do otherwise, leaving time, taking into account the particular characteristics of these regions. But, you see, section 349 is now being hijacked for regressive purposes. That is what I do not accept.  Therefore, I invite my colleagues tomorrow to vote in favour of the separate amendments I have proposed.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, so here we are: a new directive to combat air pollution. We all want clean air. I am from an area of the West Midlands of England called the Black Country and the reason it was called that was because during more industrial times the air was black with smog and many people in my area died from air pollution, so I understand entirely the requirement for cleaner air. Over the years, that has no longer been an issue because deindustrialisation unfortunately means we have less production, but also the British Government has taken measures to clean the air. I do not believe that, as the UK, we need to be subject to an EU regulation and more rules on this kind of thing. I believe we can handle this ourselves. But I do believe that whoever handles this must be extremely cautious and careful that they do not take measures which make life even harder than it is now for industry, manufacturing and output. Our economies cannot take more self-inflicted punishment, so I urge caution and I state that the UK can do this on its own.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There is no doubt that climate policy, energy, which is one of the key issues of the European Union, in the age of recent crises and developments in Europe, on the one hand, is of particular importance and, on the other hand, it is quite a challenge for the European Union and the Member States, especially when we realise that air pollutant emissions contribute to almost 400 000 premature deaths in the European Union and that the costs of health protection related to the emission of harmful compounds range between EUR 300 billion and EUR 900 billion.  Nevertheless, referring to today's discussion on Volkswagen, someone who thinks responsibly must ask himself what we have done to the European industry, that industry is resorting to fraud or that we are not putting too high emission reduction requirements, or that is a one-off incident like that of Volkswagen. I am pleased that this directive has taken this common sense approach and I congratulate the rapporteur Andrzej Grzyb on his well-done work and that he takes all these concerns into account by all the stakeholders, because it is very important that we take action by the bodies of the European Union accompanied by reason, balance and prudence in the decisions taken.  I believe that the compromise reached on reducing emissions of certain pollutants, including emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitric oxide and particulate matter, on the one hand, will protect what is most valuable: healthy, human life and the environment, and, on the other hand, will not create an excessive administrative and financial burden for small and medium-sized enterprises operating in this sector, which could increase the cost of heat to individual household consumers.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am pleased that today, with a few exceptions, a debate is being held in a way that is perhaps understandable to Europeans. That is, by talking about the objectives we want to achieve. This measure is about ensuring clean air in Europe, preventing 400 000 people in Europe from dying prematurely from airborne diseases each year – dying of cancer. Today we are discussing how important it is that we can prevent these associated costs – which are somewhere between EUR 330 and 900 billion a year. That is the right approach: we say why we do it. We have finally shown that it is not a question of bullying companies, that it is not a question of just taking action. We have explained what the aim is. I believe that this compromise is a reasonable compromise, because it represents the legitimate concerns that Europeans have, but on the other hand it also provides for measures so that industry, so that the economy can live with this compromise. I believe that we should give our assent to this compromise.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Andrzej Grzyb's report deals with a very important matter. The lack of regulation of medium combustion plants creates a serious legal loophole and regulatory inconsistency in the industry. Of course, we should aim to reduce emissions of harmful substances into the atmosphere, but let us remember that too far-reaching emission regulations are putting the Eu economy at risk of uncompetitiveness and putting the Member States of the Union at serious financial risk. At the same time as the Union imposes regulations on itself, other big polluters such as the US, China and Japan remain deaf to the call for similar standards. As a consequence, this means increasingly difficult operating and competitive conditions for European businesses and, for the citizens of the European Union, thousands of jobs are often lost. That is why we should look particularly attentively on such solutions, also because the new regulations are not only further costly, but also inefficient rules.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, although I disagree with a number of exemptions in this report, I do welcome this piece of legislation, which will see emission limits for medium combustion plants covered by law for the first time. It is right that the regulatory gap between small and large combustion plants is finally filled. Air pollution is a major, yet preventable, killer in Europe, and in my home country, Ireland, 1 300 premature deaths are attributed to bad air quality. It is estimated that the cost to the health service amounts to a staggering EUR 3 billion every year. These immense costs to citizens’ health, national budgets and, of course, to the environment should be taken very seriously indeed, and we cannot continue to kick the can down the road on air quality. Added to Ireland’s continual breach of nitrogen oxide limits, it shows that much more must be done if we are serious about tackling air pollution.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, despite the strong progress in tackling air pollutants such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust in the European Union, air quality still falls short in many areas of the norms set by the EU, the UN, and the World Health Organisation. As a consequence, harmful air pollutants continue to cause serious problems to our health, our quality of life and our environment. The damage is also financially costly: the impact of air pollution on health alone amounts to hundreds of billions of euros each year in the European Union. That is why I am glad that, with the adoption of this piece of legislation, we can fill the gap left between the Eco-design Directive and the Industrial Emissions Directive, while avoiding double regulation. However, considering that about 75% of medium combustion plants are run by SMEs, it is also important not to impose a too high administrative and financial burden on such companies. Therefore I think that the gradual adoption of rules – depending on the size of the plants – strikes a good balance between affordability and environmental protection.  Last but not least, I also welcome the flexible compliance deadlines for existing district heating systems, biomass plants and plants that are part of small, isolated systems.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, an important subject so late in the evening. There is an acute need to improve Air Quality in The European Air Quality, which has not improved for ten years. Every year, there are far too many breathing problems and premature deaths. People who live in cities can't choose the air they breathe. The end result shows that it is a good compromise and an indication that it is possible to establish common rules for the various regions.  Air quality in certain regions of Europe is clearly lower than in others. It was disappointing to me that we could not have an obligation in the most polluting areas to act more radically to improve air quality. On the other hand, I welcome the final compromise, which allows longer transitional periods for the clean air area and for those who use renewable biofuels or are district heating plants. Now the benefits and costs are better balanced.  Thank you also to the negotiators for taking into account the cold winter conditions. It is important not to find ourselves in a situation where low-air reserve power plants have to be run down on a fast schedule.  Finally, clean technology. In a common market, we can help when we promote these things.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my strong support for this measure, which is a very important measure.  Firstly, as has already been said, there is a legislative gap, since medium-combustion plants of up to 50 megawatts are not regulated at European level despite the fact that these plants account for 80% of the total, are used for a large number of applications and produce about a third of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and polluting particles.  Air pollution has a strong impact on citizens' health and on the costs of national health systems. The final text is a good result, also thanks to the work carried out by the rapporteur – whom I thank, our shadow rapporteur Massimo Paolucci and the Minister for the Environment, Mr Galletti, during the Italian Presidency. A courageous proposal which, when applied gradually to both new and existing plants, aims to make a significant contribution to reducing pollution, without, however, imposing excessive burdens on our companies.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this legislation is welcome and positively illustrates the effort to identify and develop synergies between sea and air quality, the impact of polluting substances on human life, the environment and the need to mitigate global climate change. The proposals we will vote on will require us to adapt existing technology, with the emission limits proposed by the Commission and using relative targets. The exception to the outermost regions in this area is also essential. In this way, the impact of insularity is recognised with regard to logistical and technical aspects of energy response in these regions, which are characterised by a dispersed and relatively small population occupation. The Azores, the region from which I come, are an example of a broadly positive balance in terms of preserving the environment, thanks to a continuous commitment to the defense of its natural, landscape and cultural heritage. This is a journey that we will continue to go realistically.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to inform you of the enormous problem facing my country, Greece, over the last two winters, due to the smog that has occurred in Greek cities and especially in Athens and Thessaloniki. The appearance of smog is due solely to the memorandum that imposed the increase in taxes on heating oil and electricity and thus led thousands of my fellow citizens to search for heating methods of the previous century, such as improvised magals and burning any kind of inappropriate fuel.  These methods are extremely dangerous, for the citizens themselves and for public health. For these reasons, I call on the Greek Government to decide, immediately, to impose zero VAT and to reduce to a minimum the excise duty on electricity and heating oil, otherwise, the Greek people will also freeze this winter and we will again this year be faced with the sanitary bomb of smog, solely under the responsibility of the troika and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I support this report, which imposes strict obligations to reduce air pollution, in particular particulate matter. I think it is right that biomass boiler rooms have been left with exemptions of up to 30 years. As you know, in countries such as Lithuania, for clear geopolitical reasons, the transition to renewable heat is taking place very rapidly. Many municipalities have installed relatively new boiler rooms which, after the adoption of the directive, will not comply with the emission limit. I call on the Commission, together with the obligation to enable companies producing energy from renewable sources to meet the new requirements. If we were to do so at our own expense alone, it would not be right and would not be an incentive for the development of biomass in energy, which not only reduces climate change, but also creates jobs and taxes and forms energy independence.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, several of you have stressed in your statements that the Medium Combustion Plants Directive will improve our citizens’ health, that and the final adoption of this directive will be an important step forward for our air quality policy and that hopefully it will soon be followed by others. Many of you have mentioned that the increased use of biomass as a fuel, if not accompanied by adequate pollution abatement, leads to a significant degradation of air quality, and the Medium Combustion Plants Directive will enable the environmentally-sound use of biomass as a fuel. It gives the necessary time for upgrading recent biomass plants that do not adequately reduce emissions of particulate matter. Some of you mentioned and sought clarification as to how this particular directive would be imposed on the medium combustion plants. The rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, and the legislation generally, avoid as far as possible, or minimise, the burden for SMEs as part of a key objective, and the proposal was designed with exactly this objective in mind. The emission limits ensure the most favourable cost-benefit ratio, and mitigation measures have been incorporated to help SMEs, such as the phased implementation for existing plants, exemptions for plants operating a limited number of hours, and reduced monitoring requirements for small plants.  To my friend Mr Omarjee, let me say that the situation in La Réunion, or indeed in the outermost regions, is not being ignored. The legislation does contain proposals which are applicable in the outermost regions, but Member States must take appropriate action to address the air quality situation in those regions while taking account of their specific circumstances. You cannot have the same criteria in those particular areas and islands in the same way as you would have on the mainland, and I know that you would accept that as a legitimate point of view.  On behalf of my colleague Commissioner Vella, I want to thank all of the people who contributed to this debate and again to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, and all the people who have been involved in this particular legislation, for the compromise which has been reached and which has met with almost universal agreement. Commission statement The Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of Regulation 182/2011 (OJ L 55 of 28.2.2011, p. 13) to invoke Article 5 § 4, subparagraph 2, point b) in a systematic manner. Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered. Given that it is an exception to the general rule established by Article 5 § 4 recourse to subparagraph 2, point b), cannot be simply seen as a "discretionary power" of the Legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified.

name: Andrzej Grzyb
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would also like to thank the Commissioner for this, in particular, to emphasise that this is the result of the work of the entire negotiating team and that this is a good compromise that takes into account both important environmental objectives that will contribute to the change and shaping of this environment and will also contribute to reducing the number of diseases caused, inter alia, by air pollution, but it is also a compromise with regard to the important economic interests of both small and medium-sized enterprises listed here. , but also individual countries that have smaller or larger problems with medium combustion plants.  I would also like to thank President La Vii, who was in the process of negotiating the trilogy and who also stressed that Member States can introduce stricter standards than the directive on the basis of tests in zones that do not meet air quality standards taking into account the best available technologies. That is, it is not the case that The Member States do not have the possibility to shape their policies in this area. They can also use their prerogatives, which is also important where intervention is necessary, where air pollution in particular is higher. It was also the introduction of exceptions – it was reasonable, because we took into account what are the possibilities for decisions. However, in cases where there are, inter alia, renewable energy sources where biomass is used, this biomass has the effect of increasing dust content. Well, we found that what would be the environmental and economic effect, if it is the case that setting up a new installation or introducing a dust collector installation would exceed the cost of the entire existing one, but it would be better to use this installation here for a certain period or until technical death, and consequently also to allow a new installation to be built in the future.  I would like to thank you very much for all the voices, Madam President, who thank you for this good cooperation and for the results that we have in the form of this draft directive, and at the same time thank you once again for all the support we have shown in the work on this project.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 7 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – As we know air pollution causes lung diseases and cancer, as well as heart diseases and strokes. According to the WHO and the European Commission ambient air pollution is responsible for 400 000 premature deaths in Europe in 2010 and 2012, with lung cancer being the leading cause of respiratory death. Air pollution has damaging impacts on the environment, impacting the quality of the water and soil, causing animal and plant life loss. It damages also the materials and buildings, having also a strong impact on the climate itself. We can admit that in Europe we have a clearer air than 2 decades ago, but we still have to work to improve the quality of the air we breathe. It is our role to ask for compliance with existing air quality rules in the Member States and require maintaining tough emission limit values. We have to support the compromise package and therefor contribute to a thorough EU climate policy.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – Mr President, the report by European Member Grzyb on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air in the European Union has launched a very important topic for countries such as Lithuania, where the weather is still of quite good quality. Therefore, the country can still be attractive to tourists and it is possible to prepare so-called healthy food. The rapporteur notes very well that air pollution is a cross-border problem that comes to many Member States from neighbouring countries. This is why limiting emissions to air is very important for the countries of north-eastern Europe with the continental green lungs. As the European Commission's data shows, we have a serious loophole in environmental legislation today. Action by the European Union on the grounds of harmful pollutants is therefore necessary. The report on the Directive is important for several reasons. In particular, the legal provisions introduced will reduce future health costs in relation to air pollution. Secondly, the legal provisions will have a significant impact on environmental protection, which will be particularly important for farming, as crop losses are expected to be reduced. Thirdly, the legal provisions introduced will contribute to maintaining the attractiveness of tourism and nature in countries such as mine, i.e. In Lithuania, and what is important, will allow these countries to expand in a very important area of the economy in the future, i.e. organic farming, which is an alternative to large-scale agricultural production.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Giovanni La Via's report on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The Environment, public health and food safety on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of Member States' legislation on casine and caseinates for human consumption and the repeal of Council Directive 83/417/EEC (COM(2014)0174 - C7-0105/2014 - 2014/0096(COD)) (A8-0042/2015).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in March 2014, the European Commission presented the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption and repealing Council Directive 83/417/EEC, on the basis of Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  Tomorrow's vote is basically a vote on a technical dossier which, however, has consequences for citizens and consumers, so I have worked on this proposal very carefully, together with my fellow shadow rapporteurs, whom I thank for the excellent cooperation that has enabled us to reach the final agreement with the Council very quickly.  In general, we welcomed the Commission's proposal and felt it appropriate to amend certain aspects of it. In particular, the Commission's proposal provides for the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to certain lactoproteins intended for human consumption. Since the entry into force of the directive, however, a number of changes have taken place, in particular the development of a broad regulatory framework in the food sector and the adoption of international codex alimentarius legislation on casein-based food products.  The production of caseins and dairy products from milk was subject to a subsidy scheme within the Union until 2006. The scheme therefore ceased and was subsequently definitively repealed by the 2013 political agreement on the reform of the single common organisation of the market in agricultural products. On 24 February 2015, the ENVI Committee adopted six amendments to the Commission's proposal and we have worked to lay the foundations for providing food business operators with equal treatment on the world market, given the adaptation of the requirements for the composition of caseins and food casein defined in the annexes to that of the Codex Alimentarius standard.  Specifically, the proposal is aimed at aligning the powers conferred on the Commission with the distinction between delegated acts and implementing acts introduced by the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, updating the provisions applicable to caseins and caseinates, taking into account eu legislation adopted in the meantime, in particular that applicable to foodstuffs, and adapting the requirements for the composition of caseins to the international standard.  Following the agreement reached with the Council, the final text provides for the maximum moisture content of food casein to be set at 12% compared with the 10% previously envisaged, and the maximum fat content of food acid casein milk at 2% compared with 2.25 previously. In this way, we will enable us to adapt rapidly in the future to international standards and technical progress.  Although the products covered by the proposal are not directly intended for sale to the final consumer, but for sale between food preparation companies, it is important, however, that food business operators have the necessary data for the labelling of finished products, in particular with regard to allergens. Consequently, the proposal includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption, so that their presence is indicated in a visible, legible and indelible manner. If the required information provided for does not appear on packaging, containers or labels, the products concerned may not be marketed or used for the preparation of foodstuffs. It is clear that this will enable final consumers to make informed choices, particularly in the presence of food allergies and intolerances, and all this confirms once again our action to protect European consumers and their health.  With tomorrow's vote, Europe has paid close attention to food issues, with a particular focus on food safety, which is always at the heart of our political agenda.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Mr La Via and the shadow rapporteurs for getting themselves involved in this technical issue. The text in the debate today is the fruit of very constructive work between the three EU institutions and it is an example of how the Commission, with its right of initiative, and the Council and Parliament, as co—legislators, can cooperate for the benefit of jobs and growth in an innovative branch of the dairy sector, which is one of the pillars of European agriculture.  The objectives that were pursued by the Commission when the proposal was tabled in 2014 have been fully understood and supported by the co—legislators throughout the legislative process. Those objectives continue to be at the heart of the text in the debate today, which is putting the EU dairy sector on a level playing field with world—market competitors in an area where innovation helps add value to milk production in the form of high—tech ingredients that serve customers both in the Union and indeed outside it. Today’s text aligns the EU rules to the international standards adopted under the Codex Alimentarius for edible casein and caseinates. Differences that existed in the past are no longer justified today, as no public subsidy is now paid to casein production in the Union following the CAP reform that you agreed to in 2013. In conclusion, let me take the opportunity again to thank Parliament for the excellent technical cooperation that has characterised this dossier throughout the various steps of the adoption procedure. We hope that both arms of the legislator will now quickly vote on a final text so that there will no longer be any obstacle for our dairy industry in benefiting from a level playing field on the world market.

name: Marijana Petir
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, caseins and caseinates are substances obtained by technological procedures from milk. The widespread use of these substances in industry, in particular food, represents valuable products in the milk sector production chain, which are then intended as raw materials for further use in other industries.  The proposed directive aligns European practice with standards applied globally according to Codex Alimentarius recommendations and standards. Thus, European caseins and caseinates will be of the same characteristics as in other countries of the world, which is significant for industrial production in terms of the safety of sources and the stability of the supply of raw materials. We know that the different characteristics of raw materials affect the technological processes of production and ultimately the quality of the final product. The industry that uses them prefers those raw materials that have similar characteristics because they do not require process adjustment depending on the supplier of raw materials, and therefore new costs that are then ultimately paid by consumers. Given the elimination of previous differences in moisture content and maximum milk fat content in edible cases, I expect this change to make these European products more competitive on the global market.  This will also help europe's crisis-hit dairy sector. Namely, in the milk sector, the alarming situation arose from the abolition of quotas and the Russian embargo, and I must say that in Croatia milk production in the first 4 months of this year fell by 5% and 1200 small milk producers failed. Therefore, I also use this opportunity to call on the Commission to carry out a review of the milk package, introduce a crisis programme, as the dairy sector is the most sensitive sector in agriculture and deserves special attention, and the intervention measures so far are only a drop in the sea and unfortunately have not yielded the desired results.

name: Susanne Melior
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The directive on kaseins and caseinates, which is under discussion here today, is , as has already been said – a very technical matter. The attention, especially around this time of day, is also correspondingly low. I think the importance is underestimated because we all like to eat quark and cheese. Caseine and its water-soluble form, the caseinates, are an important prerequisite for their production. But you can do more. They are also used for milk whites in coffee or even as a clarifying agent for rosé wines. Edible caseins and caseinates – and this is the only issue at stake here – are milk proteins and are therefore also subject to labelling as allergens, regulated by EU Regulation No 1169/2011. This fact has been taken into account in the new directive, as has the Codex Alimentarius, which has already been mentioned, which deals with the water content and lactic acid content of caders. In addition, the trialogue increased implementation in the Member States from 9 to 12 months. I would like to thank the chairman of the ENVI Committee, Mr La Via, for its speedy consultation and cooperative cooperation, and I commend Parliament for approving the directive so that we in the European Union can all continue to enjoy good cheese and quark. Incidentally, the current dispute over cheese from milk or milk powder in Italy has not yet been resolved. I personally wish parmigiano from milk.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The final agreement on this dossier provides for the Commission to repeal the existing provisions relating to certain milk proteins, mainly casein and caseinates, and to replace them with a new directive.  Much has been said here in previous debates about Volkswagen and pollution, but we are talking about caseinates and casein in this technical document. They are ubiquitous: they are processed meats, in pottery, bakery, confectionery, dairy, beverage production, also alcoholic beverages, special products intended for children, infants, newborns, are also in conditioners for athletes. Therefore, this initiative, which is linked to our Parliament's REFIT programme, is welcomed by the ECR Group and we welcome this agreement that has been reached – important! – quickly and without organising unnecessary trilogue negotiations. For this, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for this.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I agree and, in particular, welcome the compliance of the project in question with the principles of good governance. It clearly identifies the hierarchy of legislation and aligns the casein market with the Codex Alimenta. I very much appreciate the rapporteur's desire to ensure that consumers are properly informed about food. Although the document in question is intended for products not intended for sale to final consumers, it is necessary to ensure that information on ingredients and, in particular, allergens are clearly traced throughout the food chain. At the same time, I would like to draw the attention of colleagues to the fact that casein is a very small element of the milk market. Despite the fact that the adoption of this directive will lead to better management of the milk market, this will not solve the structural problems that currently plague it. I would therefore like to take this opportunity to remind and call once again on the Commission, together with the Member States and milk producer organisations, to seek long-term, balanced solutions to the milk crisis.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we needed safe food to circulate in our markets, we needed to give consumers security on the minimum content of casein and caseinates, and we also needed a safe sale with labelling that provided all the necessary information for the consumer, particularly with regard to allergens.  This information will now be mandatory and foodstuffs containing casein and caseinates can only be marketed under the appropriate labels on packaging and containers. We have also ensured that we can use a label that clearly indicates a higher level of quality of dairy products that have a higher lactoprotein content, a mechanism that stimulates higher quality production without additional burdens on farms. That is why we consider this proposal to be fundamentally positive and will vote in favour of it.

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As has already been said by several previous speakers, this dossier is a very technical dossier, and I think that when it comes to updating EU rules on nutrient caseinates and adapting them to the Codex Alimentarius, there is actually little to be said for it. I would therefore like to return to the issue of the use of caders and milk powder in cheese making, which has already been raised. As you know, in Italy – I come from Italy – we have a law prohibiting this. The European Commission now wants to lift this ban with all its strength. In Italy, we assume that cheese is to be produced from milk. If the same Commission, which proposed a report to the House a few weeks ago so that the Member States can ban the import of genetically modified organisms on their territory, and said at the time that this is not relevant to the internal market, now claims that the ban on the addition of milk powder and carines in cheese should be relevant to the internal market, then I no longer understand the world. That is why, Commissioner, may I ask you to really look at this thing again. The European Union as a whole is not in a state where we can afford such things. If you look at the debates on this in Italy, I think it is a good thing if we should put an end to this as soon as possible and allow the Italians to produce cheese from milk and not from milk powder or from kaders.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all I would like to say that I appreciate the efforts that the Commission is making on food safety.  As we know, the long-term consequences of food consumption can only be assessed in the long term, and that is why I am in favour of legislative proposals such as the one we are debating, aimed at integrating Community legislation into the broader framework of international food law. However, while it is true that these changes simplify the exchange of information between food companies, it is also true that this measure will also, and above all, affect the information on the label that final consumers will be able to obtain. Labelling requirements for caseins and caseinates will enable consumers to make informed and informed choices, particularly in the presence of food allergies or intolerances.  I believe that the text we are going to vote on tomorrow is a positive text that will give a boost to the valorisation of milk on the market, especially if it is intended for cheese processing, in the knowledge that the challenge of quality must be constantly pursued in order to ensure safety standards.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, we in UKIP firmly believe in preserving the health and well-being of all citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also think that it is important for companies involved in food production to have access to the information they require in order to label the final product, particularly in the case of allergens. However, we do not think that these issues should be regulated at an EU level, and we believe that Britain should have the autonomy to legislate in this domain. In addition to replacing existing legislation on caseins with a new EU directive, the Commission also seeks to align the powers of the Commission to adopt delegated or implementing acts with provisions introduced with the Lisbon Treaty. We in UKIP reject the Lisbon Treaty, which is an EU constitution in disguise, and we object to any more powers being transferred to the Commission.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to commend both the rapporteur and the Commission for the proposal for a directive. I support this proposal and I agree with what most of my pre-ers have said. This proposal is not about a new bureaucratic regulation that bullies or somehow complicates the lives of European citizens or companies operating in Europe. On the contrary, it is a regulation that will strengthen the internal market and unify rules that are either inconsistent or obsolete, since they date back to the early 1980s. While I am reticent to extend the scope of the European Union and to over-bureaucraticise, I strongly support this regulation because it will bring uniform and clear rules to the entire food industry in the European Union. It has been said here several times, I think the industry welcomes this. I myself have spoken to some representatives of the food industry about this proposal for a directive in my country, in the Czech Republic, and they have seen these clear rules as a good impetus to be able to see clearly what they are making decisions on. I think it is very good that we are based here on an expert opinion, on the technical standards developed by the international organisation Codex Alimentarius. It is good that we are accepting of what casein food sour, casein food sweet should look like, and that this, as I said, will increase the certainty of manufacturers. In addition, it is also very good that there will be a clear obligation of information for individual producers in relation to those who use casein in their products. Ultimately, this will also be reflected in favour of the end product user, who will be informed whether the product contains casein because, as we know, some users are allergic to this substance. I agree with and support the proposal.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we certainly take a positive view of President La Via's report, for which I thank him above all for his cultural approach.  The reasons for the business system when it comes to demanding rules that make the international market accessible must cross our great ambition, which is to put end consumers more and more secure. The challenge, then, is to lay down rules on competition, for the free movement of food whose quality and safety will be further traced and therefore guaranteed.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, one of the aspects of particular relevance in the text we are discussing is the best possible information for the consumer. It is essential to have a system that allows the clear identification of potentially allergenic substances, which involves the obligation of their labelling. As regards the milk and milk products market, taking advantage of Commissioner Hogan's presence in the context of the recently presented study on origin labelling, it seems to me that the only defensible position is that the original labelling concerns the place where the milk is collected and not the place where it is processed. I know the context is much more complex and includes other variables, but here I don't have time for more. This position seems to me to be the only one that can defend itself morally, because it is the only one that really defends primary products and territorial balance. This is probably also what requires more immediate decision-making at European level.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the new directive enhances the transparency resulting from labelling and thus allows consumers of dairy products to be better informed. Furthermore, alignment with international standards on the composition of edible casein contributes to the protection of the health of milk consumers, because we also have cases of changes in milk legislation aimed at strengthening milk multinationals.  Thus, in Greece, with the new memorandum passed in August, by the Memorandum of Understanding SYRIZA, ANEL, PASOK, SW, Potami, the full life of pasteurized milk was fully liberalized, resulting in pastered milk of up to eleven days, a period of time sufficient to transfer pasterified milk from Mr Dijsselbloem's Netherlands to Greece. In this way, the Greek dairy industries are dissolved and Greek livestock farming is destroyed.  Finally, Commissioner, cheese must be produced from milk and not from milk powder.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the overwhelming support for the proposal, and again I wish to thank the rapporteur, Mr La Via, and the shadow rapporteurs for their work. I just have two remarks that, I suppose, I should make. One of the Italian issues that was raised by a number of speakers from Italy concerned a matter that goes back in regulatory form to 1974 – so a little bit before my time – but has nevertheless raised its head because of an objection and a complaint brought before the Commission by an Italian company, which is the subject of investigation at the moment. The matter will hopefully be clarified in due course, but I want to undertake that we will send a note of the present state of play to the various individuals who are here from the Italian delegation, in order to clarify the situation as of now. In relation to the question raised by my good friend Mr Serrão Santos on the Azores, the labelling issues are a matter for my colleague, Commissioner Andriukaitis, but I am aware of the reports which came down against mandatory labelling. I am sure that you are aware of them as well. Voluntary labelling is available for Member States if they wish to proceed on that basis, but it is a rather contentious matter because you have to respect the fact that we are in an internal market, with a common agricultural policy, where the free movement of goods and services are actually appropriate vis-à-vis consumers. But I understand where you are coming from: from the position of the Azores where the high-quality products that you have there – which get the recognition of 26% of the consumer market in dairy products in mainland Portugal – represent quite a significant industry. I am sure that, from the point of view of your producers in the Azores and from that perspective of high-quality products, you would be very pleased to have labelling. But it is not yet universally accepted around the European Union.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that the debate in this House has been constructive and, above all, has led to broad convergence on the part of all the political groups towards the Commission's proposal, as amended by Parliament and agreed and agreed with the Council.  The trialogue and trialogues we made to reach an agreement were swift and swift, a clear sign that there was a shared position, but there was also a desire to have a new regulatory reference more appropriate to the times and in line with the needs of the market. I am sure that tomorrow there will be broad agreement on this proposal from this Parliament in terms of the vote, and I hope that the legislative procedure can be closed down as soon as possible in order to have a regulatory framework that is useful for all companies in Europe that deal with small houses and caseinates, but above all useful in ensuring a better information framework for consumers.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 7 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As a Member of Polish I am very positive about the Commission's proposed adaptation of the rules on edible caseins and caseinates to changes in EU food law and changes in international standards.  Every year, people who have been diagnosed with food allergies arrive, a significant proportion of which are allergies to cow's milk proteins. Most often they are produced by casein, which accounts for 80% of cow's milk proteins. That is why it is so important to properly label foods produced with dairy products.  The consumer has the right to proper and complete information about the product, both in terms of its characteristics, composition, quality and origin. Dairy products, as they cause numerous allergies and intolerances, must be labelled. The lack of such information is extremely dangerous for allergic people, because the reception of casein by people allergic to it not only results in numerous ailments on the part of the digestive system, but contributes to the degradation of the immune system of allergy sufferers, which causes serious and often incurable diseases of the bone, skin and even cancer. I therefore fully support the proposed changes and the maintenance of the obligation to fully inform consumers about the ingredients of the product they are buying.
